36   and editing by those who wish to do so.  To be sure you have an
37   up to date first edition [xxxxx10x.xxx] please check file sizes
38   in the first week of the next month.  Since our ftp program has
39   a bug in it that scrambles the date [tried to fix and failed] a
40   look at the file size will have to do, but we will try to see a
41   new copy has at least one byte more or less.

46   We produce about two million dollars for each hour we work.  The
47   fifty hours is one conservative estimate for how long it we take
48   to get any etext selected, entered, proofread, edited, copyright
49   searched and analyzed, the copyright letters written, etc.  This
50   projected audience is one hundred million readers.  If our value
51   per text is nominally estimated at one dollar, then we produce 2
52   million dollars per hour this year we, will have to do four text
53   files per month:  thus upping our productivity from one million.
54   The Goal of Project Gutenberg is to Give Away One Trillion Etext
55   Files by the December 31, 2001.  [10,000 x 100,000,000=Trillion]
56   This is ten thousand titles each to one hundred million readers,
57   which is 10% of the expected number of computer users by the end
58   of the year 2001.

107  Why is this "Small Print!" statement here?  You know: lawyers.
108  They tell us you might sue us if there is something wrong with
109  your copy of this etext, even if you got it for free from
110  someone other than us, and even if what's wrong is not our
111  fault.  So, among other things, this "Small Print!" statement
112  disclaims most of our liability to you.  It also tells you how
113  you can distribute copies of this etext if you want to.
114  
115  *BEFORE!* YOU USE OR READ THIS ETEXT
116  By using or reading any part of this PROJECT GUTENBERG-tm
117  etext, you indicate that you understand, agree to and accept
118  this "Small Print!" statement.  If you do not, you can receive
119  a refund of the money (if any) you paid for this etext by
120  sending a request within 30 days of receiving it to the person
121  you got it from.  If you received this etext on a physical
122  medium (such as a disk), you must return it with your request.

130  on or for this work, so the Project (and you!) can copy and
131  distribute it in the United States without permission and
132  without paying copyright royalties.  Special rules, set forth
133  below, apply if you wish to copy and distribute this etext
134  under the Project's "PROJECT GUTENBERG" trademark.

199       *EITHER*:

245  
246  
247  
248  
249  
250  VOLUME I
251  
252  
253  
254  CHAPTER I
255  
256  
257  Emma Woodhouse, handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home
258  and happy disposition, seemed to unite some of the best blessings
259  of existence; and had lived nearly twenty-one years in the world
260  with very little to distress or vex her.
261  
262  She was the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate,
263  indulgent father; and had, in consequence of her sister's marriage,
264  been mistress of his house from a very early period.  Her mother
265  had died too long ago for her to have more than an indistinct
266  remembrance of her caresses; and her place had been supplied
267  by an excellent woman as governess, who had fallen little short
268  of a mother in affection.
269  
270  Sixteen years had Miss Taylor been in Mr. Woodhouse's family,
271  less as a governess than a friend, very fond of both daughters,
272  but particularly of Emma.  Between _them_ it was more the intimacy
273  of sisters.  Even before Miss Taylor had ceased to hold the nominal
274  office of governess, the mildness of her temper had hardly allowed
275  her to impose any restraint; and the shadow of authority being
276  now long passed away, they had been living together as friend and
277  friend very mutually attached, and Emma doing just what she liked;
278  highly esteeming Miss Taylor's judgment, but directed chiefly by
279  her own.
280  
281  The real evils, indeed, of Emma's situation were the power of having
282  rather too much her own way, and a disposition to think a little
283  too well of herself; these were the disadvantages which threatened
284  alloy to her many enjoyments.  The danger, however, was at present
285  so unperceived, that they did not by any means rank as misfortunes
286  with her.
287  
288  Sorrow came--a gentle sorrow--but not at all in the shape of any
289  disagreeable consciousness.--Miss Taylor married.  It was Miss
290  Taylor's loss which first brought grief.  It was on the wedding-day
291  of this beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought
292  of any continuance.  The wedding over, and the bride-people gone,
293  her father and herself were left to dine together, with no prospect
294  of a third to cheer a long evening.  Her father composed himself
295  to sleep after dinner, as usual, and she had then only to sit
296  and think of what she had lost.
297  
298  The event had every promise of happiness for her friend.  Mr. Weston
299  was a man of unexceptionable character, easy fortune, suitable age,
300  and pleasant manners; and there was some satisfaction in considering
301  with what self-denying, generous friendship she had always wished
302  and promoted the match; but it was a black morning's work for her.
303  The want of Miss Taylor would be felt every hour of every day.
304  She recalled her past kindness--the kindness, the affection of sixteen
305  years--how she had taught and how she had played with her from five
306  years old--how she had devoted all her powers to attach and amuse
307  her in health--and how nursed her through the various illnesses
308  of childhood.  A large debt of gratitude was owing here; but the
309  intercourse of the last seven years, the equal footing and perfect
310  unreserve which had soon followed Isabella's marriage, on their
311  being left to each other, was yet a dearer, tenderer recollection.
312  She had been a friend and companion such as few possessed: intelligent,
313  well-informed, useful, gentle, knowing all the ways of the family,
314  interested in all its concerns, and peculiarly interested in herself,
315  in every pleasure, every scheme of hers--one to whom she could speak
316  every thought as it arose, and who had such an affection for her
317  as could never find fault.
318  
319  How was she to bear the change?--It was true that her friend was
320  going only half a mile from them; but Emma was aware that great must
321  be the difference between a Mrs. Weston, only half a mile from them,
322  and a Miss Taylor in the house; and with all her advantages,
323  natural and domestic, she was now in great danger of suffering
324  from intellectual solitude.  She dearly loved her father, but he
325  was no companion for her.  He could not meet her in conversation,
326  rational or playful.
327  
328  The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and Mr. Woodhouse had
329  not married early) was much increased by his constitution and habits;
330  for having been a valetudinarian all his life, without activity
331  of mind or body, he was a much older man in ways than in years;
332  and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart
333  and his amiable temper, his talents could not have recommended him
334  at any time.
335  
336  Her sister, though comparatively but little removed by matrimony,
337  being settled in London, only sixteen miles off, was much beyond
338  her daily reach; and many a long October and November evening must
339  be struggled through at Hartfield, before Christmas brought the next
340  visit from Isabella and her husband, and their little children,
341  to fill the house, and give her pleasant society again.
342  
343  Highbury, the large and populous village, almost amounting to a town,
344  to which Hartfield, in spite of its separate lawn, and shrubberies,
345  and name, did really belong, afforded her no equals.  The Woodhouses
346  were first in consequence there.  All looked up to them.  She had
347  many acquaintance in the place, for her father was universally civil,
348  but not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss
349  Taylor for even half a day.  It was a melancholy change; and Emma
350  could not but sigh over it, and wish for impossible things,
351  till her father awoke, and made it necessary to be cheerful.
352  His spirits required support.  He was a nervous man, easily depressed;
353  fond of every body that he was used to, and hating to part with them;
354  hating change of every kind.  Matrimony, as the origin of change,
355  was always disagreeable; and he was by no means yet reconciled
356  to his own daughter's marrying, nor could ever speak of her but
357  with compassion, though it had been entirely a match of affection,
358  when he was now obliged to part with Miss Taylor too; and from
359  his habits of gentle selfishness, and of being never able to
360  suppose that other people could feel differently from himself,
361  he was very much disposed to think Miss Taylor had done as sad
362  a thing for herself as for them, and would have been a great deal
363  happier if she had spent all the rest of her life at Hartfield.
364  Emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as she could, to keep him
365  from such thoughts; but when tea came, it was impossible for him
366  not to say exactly as he had said at dinner,
367  
368  "Poor Miss Taylor!--I wish she were here again.  What a pity it
369  is that Mr. Weston ever thought of her!"
370  
371  "I cannot agree with you, papa; you know I cannot.  Mr. Weston is such
372  a good-humoured, pleasant, excellent man, that he thoroughly deserves
373  a good wife;--and you would not have had Miss Taylor live with us
374  for ever, and bear all my odd humours, when she might have a house of her own?"
375  
376  "A house of her own!--But where is the advantage of a house of her own?
377  This is three times as large.--And you have never any odd humours,
378  my dear."
379  
380  "How often we shall be going to see them, and they coming to see
381  us!--We shall be always meeting! _We_ must begin; we must go and pay
382  wedding visit very soon."
383  
384  "My dear, how am I to get so far? Randalls is such a distance.
385  I could not walk half so far."
386  
387  "No, papa, nobody thought of your walking.  We must go in the carriage,
388  to be sure."
389  
390  "The carriage! But James will not like to put the horses to for
391  such a little way;--and where are the poor horses to be while we
392  are paying our visit?"
393  
394  "They are to be put into Mr. Weston's stable, papa.  You know we
395  have settled all that already.  We talked it all over with Mr. Weston
396  last night.  And as for James, you may be very sure he will always like
397  going to Randalls, because of his daughter's being housemaid there.
398  I only doubt whether he will ever take us anywhere else.  That was
399  your doing, papa.  You got Hannah that good place.  Nobody thought
400  of Hannah till you mentioned her--James is so obliged to you!"
401  
402  "I am very glad I did think of her.  It was very lucky, for I would
403  not have had poor James think himself slighted upon any account;
404  and I am sure she will make a very good servant: she is a civil,
405  pretty-spoken girl; I have a great opinion of her.  Whenever I see her,
406  she always curtseys and asks me how I do, in a very pretty manner;
407  and when you have had her here to do needlework, I observe she
408  always turns the lock of the door the right way and never bangs it.
409  I am sure she will be an excellent servant; and it will be a great
410  comfort to poor Miss Taylor to have somebody about her that she is
411  used to see.  Whenever James goes over to see his daughter, you know,
412  she will be hearing of us.  He will be able to tell her how we
413  all are."
414  
415  Emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas,
416  and hoped, by the help of backgammon, to get her father tolerably
417  through the evening, and be attacked by no regrets but her own.
418  The backgammon-table was placed; but a visitor immediately afterwards
419  walked in and made it unnecessary.
420  
421  Mr. Knightley, a sensible man about seven or eight-and-thirty, was not
422  only a very old and intimate friend of the family, but particularly
423  connected with it, as the elder brother of Isabella's husband.
424  He lived about a mile from Highbury, was a frequent visitor,
425  and always welcome, and at this time more welcome than usual,
426  as coming directly from their mutual connexions in London.  He had
427  returned to a late dinner, after some days' absence, and now walked
428  up to Hartfield to say that all were well in Brunswick Square.
429  It was a happy circumstance, and animated Mr. Woodhouse for some time.
430  Mr. Knightley had a cheerful manner, which always did him good;
431  and his many inquiries after "poor Isabella" and her children were
432  answered most satisfactorily.  When this was over, Mr. Woodhouse
433  gratefully observed, "It is very kind of you, Mr. Knightley, to come
434  out at this late hour to call upon us.  I am afraid you must have
435  had a shocking walk."
436  
437  "Not at all, sir.  It is a beautiful moonlight night; and so mild
438  that I must draw back from your great fire."
439  
440  "But you must have found it very damp and dirty.  I wish you may
441  not catch cold."
442  
443  "Dirty, sir! Look at my shoes.  Not a speck on them."
444  
445  "Well! that is quite surprising, for we have had a vast deal
446  of rain here.  It rained dreadfully hard for half an hour
447  while we were at breakfast.  I wanted them to put off the wedding."
448  
449  "By the bye--I have not wished you joy.  Being pretty well aware
450  of what sort of joy you must both be feeling, I have been in no hurry
451  with my congratulations; but I hope it all went off tolerably well.
452  How did you all behave? Who cried most?"
453  
454  "Ah! poor Miss Taylor! 'Tis a sad business."
455  
456  "Poor Mr. and Miss Woodhouse, if you please; but I cannot possibly
457  say `poor Miss Taylor.' I have a great regard for you and Emma;
458  but when it comes to the question of dependence or independence!--At
459  any rate, it must be better to have only one to please than two."
460  
461  "Especially when _one_ of those two is such a fanciful, troublesome creature!"
462  said Emma playfully.  "That is what you have in your head,
463  I know--and what you would certainly say if my father were not by."
464  
465  "I believe it is very true, my dear, indeed," said Mr. Woodhouse,
466  with a sigh.  "I am afraid I am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome."
467  
468  "My dearest papa! You do not think I could mean _you_, or suppose
469  Mr. Knightley to mean _you_.  What a horrible idea! Oh no! I meant
470  only myself.  Mr. Knightley loves to find fault with me, you know--
471  in a joke--it is all a joke.  We always say what we like to one another."
472  
473  Mr. Knightley, in fact, was one of the few people who could see
474  faults in Emma Woodhouse, and the only one who ever told her of them:
475  and though this was not particularly agreeable to Emma herself,
476  she knew it would be so much less so to her father, that she would
477  not have him really suspect such a circumstance as her not being
478  thought perfect by every body.
479  
480  "Emma knows I never flatter her," said Mr. Knightley, "but I
481  meant no reflection on any body.  Miss Taylor has been used
482  to have two persons to please; she will now have but one.
483  The chances are that she must be a gainer."
484  
485  "Well," said Emma, willing to let it pass--"you want to hear
486  about the wedding; and I shall be happy to tell you, for we all
487  behaved charmingly.  Every body was punctual, every body in their
488  best looks: not a tear, and hardly a long face to be seen.  Oh no;
489  we all felt that we were going to be only half a mile apart,
490  and were sure of meeting every day."
491  
492  "Dear Emma bears every thing so well," said her father.
493  "But, Mr. Knightley, she is really very sorry to lose poor Miss Taylor,
494  and I am sure she _will_ miss her more than she thinks for."
495  
496  Emma turned away her head, divided between tears and smiles.
497  "It is impossible that Emma should not miss such a companion,"
498  said Mr. Knightley.  "We should not like her so well as we do, sir,
499  if we could suppose it; but she knows how much the marriage is to
500  Miss Taylor's advantage; she knows how very acceptable it must be,
501  at Miss Taylor's time of life, to be settled in a home of her own,
502  and how important to her to be secure of a comfortable provision,
503  and therefore cannot allow herself to feel so much pain as pleasure.
504  Every friend of Miss Taylor must be glad to have her so happily
505  married."
506  
507  "And you have forgotten one matter of joy to me," said Emma,
508  "and a very considerable one--that I made the match myself.
509  I made the match, you know, four years ago; and to have it take place,
510  and be proved in the right, when so many people said Mr. Weston would
511  never marry again, may comfort me for any thing."
512  
513  Mr. Knightley shook his head at her.  Her father fondly replied,
514  "Ah! my dear, I wish you would not make matches and foretell things,
515  for whatever you say always comes to pass.  Pray do not make any
516  more matches."
517  
518  "I promise you to make none for myself, papa; but I must, indeed,
519  for other people.  It is the greatest amusement in the world! And
520  after such success, you know!--Every body said that Mr. Weston would
521  never marry again.  Oh dear, no! Mr. Weston, who had been a widower
522  so long, and who seemed so perfectly comfortable without a wife,
523  so constantly occupied either in his business in town or among his
524  friends here, always acceptable wherever he went, always cheerful--
525  Mr. Weston need not spend a single evening in the year alone if he did
526  not like it.  Oh no! Mr. Weston certainly would never marry again.
527  Some people even talked of a promise to his wife on her deathbed,
528  and others of the son and the uncle not letting him.  All manner
529  of solemn nonsense was talked on the subject, but I believed none
530  of it.
531  
532  "Ever since the day--about four years ago--that Miss Taylor and I
533  met with him in Broadway Lane, when, because it began to drizzle,
534  he darted away with so much gallantry, and borrowed two umbrellas
535  for us from Farmer Mitchell's, I made up my mind on the subject.
536  I planned the match from that hour; and when such success has blessed
537  me in this instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave
538  off match-making."
539  
540  "I do not understand what you mean by `success,'" said Mr. Knightley.
541  "Success supposes endeavour.  Your time has been properly and
542  delicately spent, if you have been endeavouring for the last four
543  years to bring about this marriage.  A worthy employment for a young
544  lady's mind! But if, which I rather imagine, your making the match,
545  as you call it, means only your planning it, your saying to yourself
546  one idle day, `I think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor
547  if Mr. Weston were to marry her,' and saying it again to yourself
548  every now and then afterwards, why do you talk of success? Where
549  is your merit? What are you proud of? You made a lucky guess;
550  and _that_ is all that can be said."
551  
552  "And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?--
553  I pity you.--I thought you cleverer--for, depend upon it a lucky
554  guess is never merely luck.  There is always some talent in it.
555  And as to my poor word `success,' which you quarrel with, I do not
556  know that I am so entirely without any claim to it.  You have drawn
557  two pretty pictures; but I think there may be a third--a something
558  between the do-nothing and the do-all. If I had not promoted Mr. Weston's
559  visits here, and given many little encouragements, and smoothed
560  many little matters, it might not have come to any thing after all.
561  I think you must know Hartfield enough to comprehend that."
562  
563  "A straightforward, open-hearted man like Weston, and a rational,
564  unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their
565  own concerns.  You are more likely to have done harm to yourself,
566  than good to them, by interference."
567  
568  "Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others,"
569  rejoined Mr. Woodhouse, understanding but in part.  "But, my dear,
570  pray do not make any more matches; they are silly things, and break up
571  one's family circle grievously."
572  
573  "Only one more, papa; only for Mr. Elton.  Poor Mr. Elton! You
574  like Mr. Elton, papa,--I must look about for a wife for him.
575  There is nobody in Highbury who deserves him--and he has been
576  here a whole year, and has fitted up his house so comfortably,
577  that it would be a shame to have him single any longer--and I thought
578  when he was joining their hands to-day, he looked so very much as if
579  he would like to have the same kind office done for him! I think
580  very well of Mr. Elton, and this is the only way I have of doing
581  him a service."
582  
583  "Mr. Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very
584  good young man, and I have a great regard for him.  But if you
585  want to shew him any attention, my dear, ask him to come
586  and dine with us some day.  That will be a much better thing.
587  I dare say Mr. Knightley will be so kind as to meet him."
588  
589  "With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time," said Mr. Knightley,
590  laughing, "and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much
591  better thing.  Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the best
592  of the fish and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife.
593  Depend upon it, a man of six or seven-and-twenty can take care
594  of himself."
595  
596  
597  
598  CHAPTER II
599  
600  
601  Mr. Weston was a native of Highbury, and born of a respectable family,
602  which for the last two or three generations had been rising into
603  gentility and property.  He had received a good education, but,
604  on succeeding early in life to a small independence, had become
605  indisposed for any of the more homely pursuits in which his brothers
606  were engaged, and had satisfied an active, cheerful mind and social
607  temper by entering into the militia of his county, then embodied.
608  
609  Captain Weston was a general favourite; and when the chances
610  of his military life had introduced him to Miss Churchill,
611  of a great Yorkshire family, and Miss Churchill fell in love
612  with him, nobody was surprized, except her brother and his wife,
613  who had never seen him, and who were full of pride and importance,
614  which the connexion would offend.
615  
616  Miss Churchill, however, being of age, and with the full command
617  of her fortune--though her fortune bore no proportion to the
618  family-estate--was not to be dissuaded from the marriage, and it
619  took place, to the infinite mortification of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill,
620  who threw her off with due decorum.  It was an unsuitable connexion,
621  and did not produce much happiness.  Mrs. Weston ought to have found
622  more in it, for she had a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper
623  made him think every thing due to her in return for the great goodness
624  of being in love with him; but though she had one sort of spirit,
625  she had not the best.  She had resolution enough to pursue
626  her own will in spite of her brother, but not enough to refrain
627  from unreasonable regrets at that brother's unreasonable anger,
628  nor from missing the luxuries of her former home.  They lived beyond
629  their income, but still it was nothing in comparison of Enscombe:
630  she did not cease to love her husband, but she wanted at once
631  to be the wife of Captain Weston, and Miss Churchill of Enscombe.
632  
633  Captain Weston, who had been considered, especially by the Churchills,
634  as making such an amazing match, was proved to have much the worst
635  of the bargain; for when his wife died, after a three years' marriage,
636  he was rather a poorer man than at first, and with a child to maintain.
637  From the expense of the child, however, he was soon relieved.
638  The boy had, with the additional softening claim of a lingering
639  illness of his mother's, been the means of a sort of reconciliation;
640  and Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, having no children of their own,
641  nor any other young creature of equal kindred to care for, offered to
642  take the whole charge of the little Frank soon after her decease.
643  Some scruples and some reluctance the widower-father may be supposed
644  to have felt; but as they were overcome by other considerations,
645  the child was given up to the care and the wealth of the Churchills,
646  and he had only his own comfort to seek, and his own situation to
647  improve as he could.
648  
649  A complete change of life became desirable.  He quitted the militia
650  and engaged in trade, having brothers already established in a
651  good way in London, which afforded him a favourable opening.
652  It was a concern which brought just employment enough.  He had still
653  a small house in Highbury, where most of his leisure days were spent;
654  and between useful occupation and the pleasures of society,
655  the next eighteen or twenty years of his life passed cheerfully away.
656  He had, by that time, realised an easy competence--enough to secure
657  the purchase of a little estate adjoining Highbury, which he had
658  always longed for--enough to marry a woman as portionless even
659  as Miss Taylor, and to live according to the wishes of his own
660  friendly and social disposition.
661  
662  It was now some time since Miss Taylor had begun to influence
663  his schemes; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth
664  on youth, it had not shaken his determination of never settling
665  till he could purchase Randalls, and the sale of Randalls was long
666  looked forward to; but he had gone steadily on, with these objects
667  in view, till they were accomplished.  He had made his fortune,
668  bought his house, and obtained his wife; and was beginning a new
669  period of existence, with every probability of greater happiness
670  than in any yet passed through.  He had never been an unhappy man;
671  his own temper had secured him from that, even in his first marriage;
672  but his second must shew him how delightful a well-judging and truly
673  amiable woman could be, and must give him the pleasantest proof
674  of its being a great deal better to choose than to be chosen,
675  to excite gratitude than to feel it.
676  
677  He had only himself to please in his choice: his fortune was
678  his own; for as to Frank, it was more than being tacitly brought
679  up as his uncle's heir, it had become so avowed an adoption
680  as to have him assume the name of Churchill on coming of age.
681  It was most unlikely, therefore, that he should ever want his
682  father's assistance.  His father had no apprehension of it.
683  The aunt was a capricious woman, and governed her husband entirely;
684  but it was not in Mr. Weston's nature to imagine that any caprice
685  could be strong enough to affect one so dear, and, as he believed,
686  so deservedly dear.  He saw his son every year in London,
687  and was proud of him; and his fond report of him as a very fine
688  young man had made Highbury feel a sort of pride in him too.
689  He was looked on as sufficiently belonging to the place to make his
690  merits and prospects a kind of common concern.
691  
692  Mr. Frank Churchill was one of the boasts of Highbury, and a lively
693  curiosity to see him prevailed, though the compliment was so little
694  returned that he had never been there in his life.  His coming
695  to visit his father had been often talked of but never achieved.
696  
697  Now, upon his father's marriage, it was very generally proposed,
698  as a most proper attention, that the visit should take place.
699  There was not a dissentient voice on the subject, either when
700  Mrs. Perry drank tea with Mrs. and Miss Bates, or when Mrs. and
701  Miss Bates returned the visit.  Now was the time for Mr. Frank
702  Churchill to come among them; and the hope strengthened when it was
703  understood that he had written to his new mother on the occasion.
704  For a few days, every morning visit in Highbury included some mention
705  of the handsome letter Mrs. Weston had received.  "I suppose you
706  have heard of the handsome letter Mr. Frank Churchill has written
707  to Mrs. Weston? I understand it was a very handsome letter, indeed.
708  Mr. Woodhouse told me of it.  Mr. Woodhouse saw the letter, and he
709  says he never saw such a handsome letter in his life."
710  
711  It was, indeed, a highly prized letter.  Mrs. Weston had, of course,
712  formed a very favourable idea of the young man; and such a pleasing
713  attention was an irresistible proof of his great good sense,
714  and a most welcome addition to every source and every expression
715  of congratulation which her marriage had already secured.  She felt
716  herself a most fortunate woman; and she had lived long enough
717  to know how fortunate she might well be thought, where the only
718  regret was for a partial separation from friends whose friendship
719  for her had never cooled, and who could ill bear to part with her.
720  
721  She knew that at times she must be missed; and could not think,
722  without pain, of Emma's losing a single pleasure, or suffering
723  an hour's ennui, from the want of her companionableness: but dear
724  Emma was of no feeble character; she was more equal to her situation
725  than most girls would have been, and had sense, and energy,
726  and spirits that might be hoped would bear her well and happily
727  through its little difficulties and privations.  And then there was
728  such comfort in the very easy distance of Randalls from Hartfield,
729  so convenient for even solitary female walking, and in Mr. Weston's
730  disposition and circumstances, which would make the approaching
731  season no hindrance to their spending half the evenings in the
732  week together.
733  
734  Her situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude
735  to Mrs. Weston, and of moments only of regret; and her
736  satisfaction--her more than satisfaction--her cheerful enjoyment,
737  was so just and so apparent, that Emma, well as she knew her father,
738  was sometimes taken by surprize at his being still able to pity
739  `poor Miss Taylor,' when they left her at Randalls in the centre
740  of every domestic comfort, or saw her go away in the evening
741  attended by her pleasant husband to a carriage of her own.
742  But never did she go without Mr. Woodhouse's giving a gentle sigh,
743  and saying, "Ah, poor Miss Taylor! She would be very glad to stay."
744  
745  There was no recovering Miss Taylor--nor much likelihood of
746  ceasing to pity her; but a few weeks brought some alleviation
747  to Mr. Woodhouse.  The compliments of his neighbours were over;
748  he was no longer teased by being wished joy of so sorrowful an event;
749  and the wedding-cake, which had been a great distress to him,
750  was all eat up.  His own stomach could bear nothing rich, and he
751  could never believe other people to be different from himself.
752  What was unwholesome to him he regarded as unfit for any body;
753  and he had, therefore, earnestly tried to dissuade them from having
754  any wedding-cake at all, and when that proved vain, as earnestly
755  tried to prevent any body's eating it.  He had been at the pains
756  of consulting Mr. Perry, the apothecary, on the subject.  Mr. Perry
757  was an intelligent, gentlemanlike man, whose frequent visits were one
758  of the comforts of Mr. Woodhouse's life; and upon being applied to,
759  he could not but acknowledge (though it seemed rather against the
760  bias of inclination) that wedding-cake might certainly disagree
761  with many--perhaps with most people, unless taken moderately.
762  With such an opinion, in confirmation of his own, Mr. Woodhouse hoped
763  to influence every visitor of the newly married pair; but still the
764  cake was eaten; and there was no rest for his benevolent nerves till
765  it was all gone.
766  
767  There was a strange rumour in Highbury of all the little Perrys
768  being seen with a slice of Mrs. Weston's wedding-cake in their
769  hands: but Mr. Woodhouse would never believe it.
770  
771  
772  
773  CHAPTER III
774  
775  
776  Mr. Woodhouse was fond of society in his own way.  He liked very much
777  to have his friends come and see him; and from various united causes,
778  from his long residence at Hartfield, and his good nature,
779  from his fortune, his house, and his daughter, he could command the
780  visits of his own little circle, in a great measure, as he liked.
781  He had not much intercourse with any families beyond that circle;
782  his horror of late hours, and large dinner-parties, made him unfit
783  for any acquaintance but such as would visit him on his own terms.
784  Fortunately for him, Highbury, including Randalls in the same parish,
785  and Donwell Abbey in the parish adjoining, the seat of Mr. Knightley,
786  comprehended many such.  Not unfrequently, through Emma's persuasion,
787  he had some of the chosen and the best to dine with him: but evening
788  parties were what he preferred; and, unless he fancied himself at any
789  time unequal to company, there was scarcely an evening in the week
790  in which Emma could not make up a card-table for him.
791  
792  Real, long-standing regard brought the Westons and Mr. Knightley;
793  and by Mr. Elton, a young man living alone without liking it,
794  the privilege of exchanging any vacant evening of his own blank solitude
795  for the elegancies and society of Mr. Woodhouse's drawing-room,
796  and the smiles of his lovely daughter, was in no danger of being
797  thrown away.
798  
799  After these came a second set; among the most come-at-able
800  of whom were Mrs. and Miss Bates, and Mrs. Goddard, three ladies
801  almost always at the service of an invitation from Hartfield,
802  and who were fetched and carried home so often, that Mr. Woodhouse
803  thought it no hardship for either James or the horses.  Had it
804  taken place only once a year, it would have been a grievance.
805  
806  Mrs. Bates, the widow of a former vicar of Highbury, was a
807  very old lady, almost past every thing but tea and quadrille.
808  She lived with her single daughter in a very small way, and was
809  considered with all the regard and respect which a harmless old lady,
810  under such untoward circumstances, can excite.  Her daughter enjoyed
811  a most uncommon degree of popularity for a woman neither young,
812  handsome, rich, nor married.  Miss Bates stood in the very worst
813  predicament in the world for having much of the public favour;
814  and she had no intellectual superiority to make atonement to herself,
815  or frighten those who might hate her into outward respect.
816  She had never boasted either beauty or cleverness.  Her youth
817  had passed without distinction, and her middle of life was devoted
818  to the care of a failing mother, and the endeavour to make a small
819  income go as far as possible.  And yet she was a happy woman,
820  and a woman whom no one named without good-will.  It was her own
821  universal good-will and contented temper which worked such wonders.
822  She loved every body, was interested in every body's happiness,
823  quicksighted to every body's merits; thought herself a most fortunate
824  creature, and surrounded with blessings in such an excellent mother,
825  and so many good neighbours and friends, and a home that wanted
826  for nothing.  The simplicity and cheerfulness of her nature,
827  her contented and grateful spirit, were a recommendation to every body,
828  and a mine of felicity to herself.  She was a great talker upon
829  little matters, which exactly suited Mr. Woodhouse, full of trivial
830  communications and harmless gossip.
831  
832  Mrs. Goddard was the mistress of a School--not of a seminary,
833  or an establishment, or any thing which professed, in long sentences of
834  refined nonsense, to combine liberal acquirements with elegant morality,
835  upon new principles and new systems--and where young ladies for
836  enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity--but
837  a real, honest, old-fashioned Boarding-school, where a reasonable
838  quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price,
839  and where girls might be sent to be out of the way, and scramble
840  themselves into a little education, without any danger of coming
841  back prodigies.  Mrs. Goddard's school was in high repute--and
842  very deservedly; for Highbury was reckoned a particularly healthy
843  spot: she had an ample house and garden, gave the children plenty
844  of wholesome food, let them run about a great deal in the summer,
845  and in winter dressed their chilblains with her own hands.
846  It was no wonder that a train of twenty young couple now walked
847  after her to church.  She was a plain, motherly kind of woman,
848  who had worked hard in her youth, and now thought herself entitled
849  to the occasional holiday of a tea-visit; and having formerly
850  owed much to Mr. Woodhouse's kindness, felt his particular claim
851  on her to leave her neat parlour, hung round with fancy-work,
852  whenever she could, and win or lose a few sixpences by his fireside.
853  
854  These were the ladies whom Emma found herself very frequently
855  able to collect; and happy was she, for her father's sake,
856  in the power; though, as far as she was herself concerned,
857  it was no remedy for the absence of Mrs. Weston.  She was delighted
858  to see her father look comfortable, and very much pleased with
859  herself for contriving things so well; but the quiet prosings
860  of three such women made her feel that every evening so spent
861  was indeed one of the long evenings she had fearfully anticipated.
862  
863  As she sat one morning, looking forward to exactly such a close
864  of the present day, a note was brought from Mrs. Goddard, requesting,
865  in most respectful terms, to be allowed to bring Miss Smith with her;
866  a most welcome request: for Miss Smith was a girl of seventeen,
867  whom Emma knew very well by sight, and had long felt an interest in,
868  on account of her beauty.  A very gracious invitation was returned,
869  and the evening no longer dreaded by the fair mistress of the mansion.
870  
871  Harriet Smith was the natural daughter of somebody.  Somebody had
872  placed her, several years back, at Mrs. Goddard's school,
873  and somebody had lately raised her from the condition of scholar
874  to that of parlour-boarder. This was all that was generally known
875  of her history.  She had no visible friends but what had been
876  acquired at Highbury, and was now just returned from a long visit
877  in the country to some young ladies who had been at school there with her.
878  
879  She was a very pretty girl, and her beauty happened to be of a sort
880  which Emma particularly admired.  She was short, plump, and fair,
881  with a fine bloom, blue eyes, light hair, regular features,
882  and a look of great sweetness, and, before the end of the evening,
883  Emma was as much pleased with her manners as her person, and quite
884  determined to continue the acquaintance.
885  
886  She was not struck by any thing remarkably clever in Miss Smith's
887  conversation, but she found her altogether very engaging--not
888  inconveniently shy, not unwilling to talk--and yet so far from pushing,
889  shewing so proper and becoming a deference, seeming so pleasantly
890  grateful for being admitted to Hartfield, and so artlessly
891  impressed by the appearance of every thing in so superior a style
892  to what she had been used to, that she must have good sense,
893  and deserve encouragement.  Encouragement should be given.
894  Those soft blue eyes, and all those natural graces, should not be
895  wasted on the inferior society of Highbury and its connexions.
896  The acquaintance she had already formed were unworthy of her.
897  The friends from whom she had just parted, though very good sort
898  of people, must be doing her harm.  They were a family of the name
899  of Martin, whom Emma well knew by character, as renting a large farm
900  of Mr. Knightley, and residing in the parish of Donwell--very creditably,
901  she believed--she knew Mr. Knightley thought highly of them--but they
902  must be coarse and unpolished, and very unfit to be the intimates
903  of a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance
904  to be quite perfect.  _She_ would notice her; she would improve her;
905  she would detach her from her bad acquaintance, and introduce her
906  into good society; she would form her opinions and her manners.
907  It would be an interesting, and certainly a very kind undertaking;
908  highly becoming her own situation in life, her leisure, and powers.
909  
910  She was so busy in admiring those soft blue eyes, in talking
911  and listening, and forming all these schemes in the in-betweens, that
912  the evening flew away at a very unusual rate; and the supper-table,
913  which always closed such parties, and for which she had been
914  used to sit and watch the due time, was all set out and ready,
915  and moved forwards to the fire, before she was aware.  With an
916  alacrity beyond the common impulse of a spirit which yet was never
917  indifferent to the credit of doing every thing well and attentively,
918  with the real good-will of a mind delighted with its own ideas,
919  did she then do all the honours of the meal, and help and recommend
920  the minced chicken and scalloped oysters, with an urgency which she
921  knew would be acceptable to the early hours and civil scruples of their guests.
922  
923  Upon such occasions poor Mr. Woodhouses feelings were in sad warfare.
924  He loved to have the cloth laid, because it had been the fashion
925  of his youth, but his conviction of suppers being very unwholesome
926  made him rather sorry to see any thing put on it; and while his
927  hospitality would have welcomed his visitors to every thing,
928  his care for their health made him grieve that they would eat.
929  
930  Such another small basin of thin gruel as his own was all that
931  he could, with thorough self-approbation, recommend; though he
932  might constrain himself, while the ladies were comfortably clearing
933  the nicer things, to say:
934  
935  "Mrs. Bates, let me propose your venturing on one of these eggs.
936  An egg boiled very soft is not unwholesome.  Serle understands boiling
937  an egg better than any body.  I would not recommend an egg boiled
938  by any body else; but you need not be afraid, they are very small,
939  you see--one of our small eggs will not hurt you.  Miss Bates,
940  let Emma help you to a _little_ bit of tart--a _very_ little bit.
941  Ours are all apple-tarts. You need not be afraid of unwholesome
942  preserves here.  I do not advise the custard.  Mrs. Goddard, what say
943  you to _half_ a glass of wine? A _small_ half-glass, put into a tumbler
944  of water? I do not think it could disagree with you."
945  
946  Emma allowed her father to talk--but supplied her visitors in
947  a much more satisfactory style, and on the present evening had
948  particular pleasure in sending them away happy.  The happiness
949  of Miss Smith was quite equal to her intentions.  Miss Woodhouse
950  was so great a personage in Highbury, that the prospect of the
951  introduction had given as much panic as pleasure; but the humble,
952  grateful little girl went off with highly gratified feelings,
953  delighted with the affability with which Miss Woodhouse had treated
954  her all the evening, and actually shaken hands with her at last!
955  
956  
957  
958  CHAPTER IV
959  
960  
961  Harriet Smith's intimacy at Hartfield was soon a settled thing.
962  Quick and decided in her ways, Emma lost no time in inviting, encouraging,
963  and telling her to come very often; and as their acquaintance increased,
964  so did their satisfaction in each other.  As a walking companion,
965  Emma had very early foreseen how useful she might find her.
966  In that respect Mrs. Weston's loss had been important.  Her father
967  never went beyond the shrubbery, where two divisions of the ground
968  sufficed him for his long walk, or his short, as the year varied;
969  and since Mrs. Weston's marriage her exercise had been too much confined.
970  She had ventured once alone to Randalls, but it was not pleasant;
971  and a Harriet Smith, therefore, one whom she could summon at any
972  time to a walk, would be a valuable addition to her privileges.
973  But in every respect, as she saw more of her, she approved her,
974  and was confirmed in all her kind designs.
975  
976  Harriet certainly was not clever, but she had a sweet, docile,
977  grateful disposition, was totally free from conceit, and only desiring
978  to be guided by any one she looked up to.  Her early attachment
979  to herself was very amiable; and her inclination for good company,
980  and power of appreciating what was elegant and clever, shewed that
981  there was no want of taste, though strength of understanding must
982  not be expected.  Altogether she was quite convinced of Harriet
983  Smith's being exactly the young friend she wanted--exactly the
984  something which her home required.  Such a friend as Mrs. Weston
985  was out of the question.  Two such could never be granted.
986  Two such she did not want.  It was quite a different sort of thing,
987  a sentiment distinct and independent.  Mrs. Weston was the object
988  of a regard which had its basis in gratitude and esteem.
989  Harriet would be loved as one to whom she could be useful.
990  For Mrs. Weston there was nothing to be done; for Harriet every thing.
991  
992  Her first attempts at usefulness were in an endeavour to find out who
993  were the parents, but Harriet could not tell.  She was ready to tell
994  every thing in her power, but on this subject questions were vain.
995  Emma was obliged to fancy what she liked--but she could never
996  believe that in the same situation _she_ should not have discovered
997  the truth.  Harriet had no penetration.  She had been satisfied
998  to hear and believe just what Mrs. Goddard chose to tell her;
999  and looked no farther.
1000 
1001 Mrs. Goddard, and the teachers, and the girls and the affairs of the
1002 school in general, formed naturally a great part of the conversation--and
1003 but for her acquaintance with the Martins of Abbey-Mill Farm,
1004 it must have been the whole.  But the Martins occupied her thoughts
1005 a good deal; she had spent two very happy months with them,
1006 and now loved to talk of the pleasures of her visit, and describe
1007 the many comforts and wonders of the place.  Emma encouraged her
1008 talkativeness--amused by such a picture of another set of beings,
1009 and enjoying the youthful simplicity which could speak with so much
1010 exultation of Mrs. Martin's having "_two_ parlours, two very good parlours,
1011 indeed; one of them quite as large as Mrs. Goddard's drawing-room;
1012 and of her having an upper maid who had lived five-and-twenty years
1013 with her; and of their having eight cows, two of them Alderneys,
1014 and one a little Welch cow, a very pretty little Welch cow indeed;
1015 and of Mrs. Martin's saying as she was so fond of it, it should be
1016 called _her_ cow; and of their having a very handsome summer-house
1017 in their garden, where some day next year they were all to drink
1018 tea:--a very handsome summer-house, large enough to hold a dozen people."
1019 
1020 For some time she was amused, without thinking beyond the immediate cause;
1021 but as she came to understand the family better, other feelings arose.
1022 She had taken up a wrong idea, fancying it was a mother and daughter,
1023 a son and son's wife, who all lived together; but when it appeared
1024 that the Mr. Martin, who bore a part in the narrative, and was always
1025 mentioned with approbation for his great good-nature in doing something
1026 or other, was a single man; that there was no young Mrs. Martin,
1027 no wife in the case; she did suspect danger to her poor little
1028 friend from all this hospitality and kindness, and that, if she
1029 were not taken care of, she might be required to sink herself forever.
1030 
1031 With this inspiriting notion, her questions increased in number
1032 and meaning; and she particularly led Harriet to talk more of Mr. Martin,
1033 and there was evidently no dislike to it.  Harriet was very ready
1034 to speak of the share he had had in their moonlight walks and merry
1035 evening games; and dwelt a good deal upon his being so very good-humoured
1036 and obliging.  He had gone three miles round one day in order to bring
1037 her some walnuts, because she had said how fond she was of them,
1038 and in every thing else he was so very obliging.  He had his
1039 shepherd's son into the parlour one night on purpose to sing to her.
1040 She was very fond of singing.  He could sing a little himself.
1041 She believed he was very clever, and understood every thing.
1042 He had a very fine flock, and, while she was with them,
1043 he had been bid more for his wool than any body in the country.
1044 She believed every body spoke well of him.  His mother and sisters
1045 were very fond of him.  Mrs. Martin had told her one day (and there
1046 was a blush as she said it,) that it was impossible for any body
1047 to be a better son, and therefore she was sure, whenever he married,
1048 he would make a good husband.  Not that she _wanted_ him to marry.
1049 She was in no hurry at all.
1050 
1051 "Well done, Mrs. Martin!" thought Emma.  "You know what you are about."
1052 
1053 "And when she had come away, Mrs. Martin was so very kind as to send
1054 Mrs. Goddard a beautiful goose--the finest goose Mrs. Goddard had
1055 ever seen.  Mrs. Goddard had dressed it on a Sunday, and asked all
1056 the three teachers, Miss Nash, and Miss Prince, and Miss Richardson,
1057 to sup with her."
1058 
1059 "Mr. Martin, I suppose, is not a man of information beyond the line
1060 of his own business? He does not read?"
1061 
1062 "Oh yes!--that is, no--I do not know--but I believe he has
1063 read a good deal--but not what you would think any thing of.
1064 He reads the Agricultural Reports, and some other books that lay
1065 in one of the window seats--but he reads all _them_ to himself.
1066 But sometimes of an evening, before we went to cards, he would read
1067 something aloud out of the Elegant Extracts, very entertaining.
1068 And I know he has read the Vicar of Wakefield.  He never read the
1069 Romance of the Forest, nor The Children of the Abbey.  He had never
1070 heard of such books before I mentioned them, but he is determined
1071 to get them now as soon as ever he can."
1072 
1073 The next question was--
1074 
1075 "What sort of looking man is Mr. Martin?"
1076 
1077 "Oh! not handsome--not at all handsome.  I thought him very plain
1078 at first, but I do not think him so plain now.  One does not, you know,
1079 after a time.  But did you never see him? He is in Highbury every
1080 now and then, and he is sure to ride through every week in his way
1081 to Kingston.  He has passed you very often."
1082 
1083 "That may be, and I may have seen him fifty times, but without
1084 having any idea of his name.  A young farmer, whether on horseback
1085 or on foot, is the very last sort of person to raise my curiosity.
1086 The yeomanry are precisely the order of people with whom I feel I
1087 can have nothing to do.  A degree or two lower, and a creditable
1088 appearance might interest me; I might hope to be useful to their
1089 families in some way or other.  But a farmer can need none of my help,
1090 and is, therefore, in one sense, as much above my notice as in every
1091 other he is below it."
1092 
1093 "To be sure.  Oh yes! It is not likely you should ever have
1094 observed him; but he knows you very well indeed--I mean by sight."
1095 
1096 "I have no doubt of his being a very respectable young man.
1097 I know, indeed, that he is so, and, as such, wish him well.
1098 What do you imagine his age to be?"
1099 
1100 "He was four-and-twenty the 8th of last June, and my birthday is
1101 the 23rd just a fortnight and a day's difference--which is very odd."
1102 
1103 "Only four-and-twenty. That is too young to settle.  His mother is
1104 perfectly right not to be in a hurry.  They seem very comfortable
1105 as they are, and if she were to take any pains to marry him,
1106 she would probably repent it.  Six years hence, if he could meet
1107 with a good sort of young woman in the same rank as his own,
1108 with a little money, it might be very desirable."
1109 
1110 "Six years hence! Dear Miss Woodhouse, he would be thirty years old!"
1111 
1112 "Well, and that is as early as most men can afford to marry,
1113 who are not born to an independence.  Mr. Martin, I imagine,
1114 has his fortune entirely to make--cannot be at all beforehand with
1115 the world.  Whatever money he might come into when his father died,
1116 whatever his share of the family property, it is, I dare say,
1117 all afloat, all employed in his stock, and so forth; and though,
1118 with diligence and good luck, he may be rich in time, it is next to
1119 impossible that he should have realised any thing yet."
1120 
1121 "To be sure, so it is.  But they live very comfortably.
1122 They have no indoors man, else they do not want for any thing;
1123 and Mrs. Martin talks of taking a boy another year."
1124 
1125 "I wish you may not get into a scrape, Harriet, whenever he does
1126 marry;--I mean, as to being acquainted with his wife--for though
1127 his sisters, from a superior education, are not to be altogether
1128 objected to, it does not follow that he might marry any body at all fit
1129 for you to notice.  The misfortune of your birth ought to make you
1130 particularly careful as to your associates.  There can be no doubt
1131 of your being a gentleman's daughter, and you must support your
1132 claim to that station by every thing within your own power, or there
1133 will be plenty of people who would take pleasure in degrading you."
1134 
1135 "Yes, to be sure, I suppose there are.  But while I visit
1136 at Hartfield, and you are so kind to me, Miss Woodhouse,
1137 I am not afraid of what any body can do."
1138 
1139 "You understand the force of influence pretty well, Harriet; but I
1140 would have you so firmly established in good society, as to be
1141 independent even of Hartfield and Miss Woodhouse.  I want to see you
1142 permanently well connected, and to that end it will be advisable
1143 to have as few odd acquaintance as may be; and, therefore, I say
1144 that if you should still be in this country when Mr. Martin marries,
1145 I wish you may not be drawn in by your intimacy with the sisters,
1146 to be acquainted with the wife, who will probably be some mere
1147 farmer's daughter, without education."
1148 
1149 "To be sure.  Yes.  Not that I think Mr. Martin would ever marry any body
1150 but what had had some education--and been very well brought up.
1151 However, I do not mean to set up my opinion against your's--and I
1152 am sure I shall not wish for the acquaintance of his wife.  I shall
1153 always have a great regard for the Miss Martins, especially Elizabeth,
1154 and should be very sorry to give them up, for they are quite as well
1155 educated as me.  But if he marries a very ignorant, vulgar woman,
1156 certainly I had better not visit her, if I can help it."
1157 
1158 Emma watched her through the fluctuations of this speech,
1159 and saw no alarming symptoms of love.  The young man had been
1160 the first admirer, but she trusted there was no other hold,
1161 and that there would be no serious difficulty, on Harriet's side,
1162 to oppose any friendly arrangement of her own.
1163 
1164 They met Mr. Martin the very next day, as they were walking on the
1165 Donwell road.  He was on foot, and after looking very respectfully
1166 at her, looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at her companion.
1167 Emma was not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey;
1168 and walking a few yards forward, while they talked together, soon made
1169 her quick eye sufficiently acquainted with Mr. Robert Martin.
1170 His appearance was very neat, and he looked like a sensible young man,
1171 but his person had no other advantage; and when he came to be
1172 contrasted with gentlemen, she thought he must lose all the ground
1173 he had gained in Harriet's inclination.  Harriet was not insensible
1174 of manner; she had voluntarily noticed her father's gentleness
1175 with admiration as well as wonder.  Mr. Martin looked as if he
1176 did not know what manner was.
1177 
1178 They remained but a few minutes together, as Miss Woodhouse must
1179 not be kept waiting; and Harriet then came running to her with a
1180 smiling face, and in a flutter of spirits, which Miss Woodhouse
1181 hoped very soon to compose.
1182 
1183 "Only think of our happening to meet him!--How very odd! It was
1184 quite a chance, he said, that he had not gone round by Randalls.
1185 He did not think we ever walked this road.  He thought we walked
1186 towards Randalls most days.  He has not been able to get the
1187 Romance of the Forest yet.  He was so busy the last time he was
1188 at Kingston that he quite forgot it, but he goes again to-morrow.
1189 So very odd we should happen to meet! Well, Miss Woodhouse, is he
1190 like what you expected? What do you think of him? Do you think him
1191 so very plain?"
1192 
1193 "He is very plain, undoubtedly--remarkably plain:--but that is
1194 nothing compared with his entire want of gentility.  I had no
1195 right to expect much, and I did not expect much; but I had no
1196 idea that he could be so very clownish, so totally without air.
1197 I had imagined him, I confess, a degree or two nearer gentility."
1198 
1199 "To be sure," said Harriet, in a mortified voice, "he is not
1200 so genteel as real gentlemen."
1201 
1202 "I think, Harriet, since your acquaintance with us, you have been
1203 repeatedly in the company of some such very real gentlemen,
1204 that you must yourself be struck with the difference in Mr. Martin.
1205 At Hartfield, you have had very good specimens of well educated,
1206 well bred men.  I should be surprized if, after seeing them,
1207 you could be in company with Mr. Martin again without perceiving
1208 him to be a very inferior creature--and rather wondering at
1209 yourself for having ever thought him at all agreeable before.
1210 Do not you begin to feel that now? Were not you struck? I am sure
1211 you must have been struck by his awkward look and abrupt manner,
1212 and the uncouthness of a voice which I heard to be wholly unmodulated
1213 as I stood here."
1214 
1215 "Certainly, he is not like Mr. Knightley.  He has not such a fine
1216 air and way of walking as Mr. Knightley.  I see the difference
1217 plain enough.  But Mr. Knightley is so very fine a man!"
1218 
1219 "Mr. Knightley's air is so remarkably good that it is not fair
1220 to compare Mr. Martin with _him_.  You might not see one in a hundred
1221 with _gentleman_ so plainly written as in Mr. Knightley.  But he is
1222 not the only gentleman you have been lately used to.  What say you
1223 to Mr. Weston and Mr. Elton? Compare Mr. Martin with either of _them_.
1224 Compare their manner of carrying themselves; of walking; of speaking;
1225 of being silent.  You must see the difference."
1226 
1227 "Oh yes!--there is a great difference.  But Mr. Weston is almost
1228 an old man.  Mr. Weston must be between forty and fifty."
1229 
1230 "Which makes his good manners the more valuable.  The older a
1231 person grows, Harriet, the more important it is that their manners
1232 should not be bad; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness,
1233 or coarseness, or awkwardness becomes.  What is passable in youth
1234 is detestable in later age.  Mr. Martin is now awkward and abrupt;
1235 what will he be at Mr. Weston's time of life?"
1236 
1237 "There is no saying, indeed," replied Harriet rather solemnly.
1238 
1239 "But there may be pretty good guessing.  He will be a completely gross,
1240 vulgar farmer, totally inattentive to appearances, and thinking
1241 of nothing but profit and loss."
1242 
1243 "Will he, indeed? That will be very bad."
1244 
1245 "How much his business engrosses him already is very plain from the
1246 circumstance of his forgetting to inquire for the book you recommended.
1247 He was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing
1248 else--which is just as it should be, for a thriving man.  What has
1249 he to do with books? And I have no doubt that he _will_ thrive,
1250 and be a very rich man in time--and his being illiterate and coarse
1251 need not disturb _us_."
1252 
1253 "I wonder he did not remember the book"--was all Harriet's answer,
1254 and spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which Emma thought might
1255 be safely left to itself.  She, therefore, said no more for some time.
1256 Her next beginning was,
1257 
1258 "In one respect, perhaps, Mr. Elton's manners are superior
1259 to Mr. Knightley's or Mr. Weston's. They have more gentleness.
1260 They might be more safely held up as a pattern.  There is an openness,
1261 a quickness, almost a bluntness in Mr. Weston, which every body
1262 likes in _him_, because there is so much good-humour with it--but
1263 that would not do to be copied.  Neither would Mr. Knightley's
1264 downright, decided, commanding sort of manner, though it suits
1265 _him_ very well; his figure, and look, and situation in life seem
1266 to allow it; but if any young man were to set about copying him,
1267 he would not be sufferable.  On the contrary, I think a young man
1268 might be very safely recommended to take Mr. Elton as a model.
1269 Mr. Elton is good-humoured, cheerful, obliging, and gentle.
1270 He seems to me to be grown particularly gentle of late.  I do not
1271 know whether he has any design of ingratiating himself with either
1272 of us, Harriet, by additional softness, but it strikes me that his
1273 manners are softer than they used to be.  If he means any thing,
1274 it must be to please you.  Did not I tell you what he said of you
1275 the other day?"
1276 
1277 She then repeated some warm personal praise which she had drawn
1278 from Mr. Elton, and now did full justice to; and Harriet blushed
1279 and smiled, and said she had always thought Mr. Elton very agreeable.
1280 
1281 Mr. Elton was the very person fixed on by Emma for driving
1282 the young farmer out of Harriet's head.  She thought it would
1283 be an excellent match; and only too palpably desirable, natural,
1284 and probable, for her to have much merit in planning it.
1285 She feared it was what every body else must think of and predict.
1286 It was not likely, however, that any body should have equalled
1287 her in the date of the plan, as it had entered her brain during
1288 the very first evening of Harriet's coming to Hartfield.  The longer
1289 she considered it, the greater was her sense of its expediency.
1290 Mr. Elton's situation was most suitable, quite the gentleman himself,
1291 and without low connexions; at the same time, not of any family
1292 that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of Harriet.  He had a
1293 comfortable home for her, and Emma imagined a very sufficient income;
1294 for though the vicarage of Highbury was not large, he was known
1295 to have some independent property; and she thought very highly
1296 of him as a good-humoured, well-meaning, respectable young man,
1297 without any deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of the world.
1298 
1299 She had already satisfied herself that he thought Harriet a beautiful
1300 girl, which she trusted, with such frequent meetings at Hartfield,
1301 was foundation enough on his side; and on Harriet's there could be
1302 little doubt that the idea of being preferred by him would have all
1303 the usual weight and efficacy.  And he was really a very pleasing
1304 young man, a young man whom any woman not fastidious might like.
1305 He was reckoned very handsome; his person much admired in general,
1306 though not by her, there being a want of elegance of feature which
1307 she could not dispense with:--but the girl who could be gratified
1308 by a Robert Martin's riding about the country to get walnuts
1309 for her might very well be conquered by Mr. Elton's admiration.
1310 
1311 
1312 
1313 CHAPTER V
1314 
1315 
1316 "I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley, "of
1317 this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a bad thing."
1318 
1319 "A bad thing! Do you really think it a bad thing?--why so?"
1320 
1321 "I think they will neither of them do the other any good."
1322 
1323 "You surprize me! Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her
1324 with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good.
1325 I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure.
1326 How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any
1327 good! This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels
1328 about Emma, Mr. Knightley."
1329 
1330 "Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you,
1331 knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle."
1332 
1333 "Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here,
1334 for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject.  We were speaking
1335 of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma,
1336 that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with.
1337 Mr. Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.
1338 You are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value
1339 of a companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort
1340 a woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used
1341 to it all her life.  I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith.
1342 She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be.
1343 But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed,
1344 it will be an inducement to her to read more herself.  They will
1345 read together.  She means it, I know."
1346 
1347 "Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve
1348 years old.  I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at
1349 various times of books that she meant to read regularly through--and
1350 very good lists they were--very well chosen, and very neatly
1351 arranged--sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.
1352 The list she drew up when only fourteen--I remember thinking it
1353 did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time;
1354 and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.  But I
1355 have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.
1356 She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience,
1357 and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.  Where Miss Taylor
1358 failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do
1359 nothing.--You never could persuade her to read half so much as you
1360 wished.--You know you could not."
1361 
1362 "I dare say," replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "that I thought
1363 so _then_;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's
1364 omitting to do any thing I wished."
1365 
1366 "There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as _that_,"--said
1367 Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done.  "But I,"
1368 he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses,
1369 must still see, hear, and remember.  Emma is spoiled by being the
1370 cleverest of her family.  At ten years old, she had the misfortune of
1371 being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.
1372 She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.
1373 And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house
1374 and of you all.  In her mother she lost the only person able to cope
1375 with her.  She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been
1376 under subjection to her."
1377 
1378 "I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on
1379 _your_ recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse's family and wanted
1380 another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for
1381 me to any body.  I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held."
1382 
1383 "Yes," said he, smiling.  "You are better placed _here_; very fit
1384 for a wife, but not at all for a governess.  But you were preparing
1385 yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield.
1386 You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would
1387 seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from _her_,
1388 on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will,
1389 and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend
1390 him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor."
1391 
1392 "Thank you.  There will be very little merit in making a good wife
1393 to such a man as Mr. Weston."
1394 
1395 "Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away,
1396 and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing
1397 to be borne.  We will not despair, however.  Weston may grow cross
1398 from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."
1399 
1400 "I hope not _that_.--It is not likely.  No, Mr. Knightley, do not
1401 foretell vexation from that quarter."
1402 
1403 "Not I, indeed.  I only name possibilities.  I do not pretend to Emma's
1404 genius for foretelling and guessing.  I hope, with all my heart,
1405 the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.--But
1406 Harriet Smith--I have not half done about Harriet Smith.  I think
1407 her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have.
1408 She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing.
1409 She is a flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse,
1410 because undesigned.  Her ignorance is hourly flattery.  How can
1411 Emma imagine she has any thing to learn herself, while Harriet
1412 is presenting such a delightful inferiority? And as for Harriet,
1413 I will venture to say that _she_ cannot gain by the acquaintance.
1414 Hartfield will only put her out of conceit with all the other places
1415 she belongs to.  She will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable
1416 with those among whom birth and circumstances have placed her home.
1417 I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind,
1418 or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties
1419 of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish."
1420 
1421 "I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more
1422 anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance.
1423 How well she looked last night!"
1424 
1425 "Oh! you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you?
1426 Very well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma's being pretty."
1427 
1428 "Pretty! say beautiful rather.  Can you imagine any thing nearer
1429 perfect beauty than Emma altogether--face and figure?"
1430 
1431 "I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have
1432 seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers.
1433 But I am a partial old friend."
1434 
1435 "Such an eye!--the true hazle eye--and so brilliant! regular features,
1436 open countenance, with a complexion! oh! what a bloom of full health,
1437 and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure!
1438 There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head,
1439 her glance.  One hears sometimes of a child being `the picture
1440 of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete
1441 picture of grown-up health.  She is loveliness itself.  Mr. Knightley,
1442 is not she?"
1443 
1444 "I have not a fault to find with her person," he replied.
1445 "I think her all you describe.  I love to look at her; and I
1446 will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain.
1447 Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little
1448 occupied with it; her vanity lies another way.  Mrs. Weston, I am
1449 not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread
1450 of its doing them both harm."
1451 
1452 "And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its
1453 not doing them any harm.  With all dear Emma's little faults,
1454 she is an excellent creature.  Where shall we see a better daughter,
1455 or a kinder sister, or a truer friend? No, no; she has qualities
1456 which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong;
1457 she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the
1458 right a hundred times."
1459 
1460 "Very well; I will not plague you any more.  Emma shall be an angel,
1461 and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John
1462 and Isabella.  John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore
1463 not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does;
1464 except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children.
1465 I am sure of having their opinions with me."
1466 
1467 "I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind;
1468 but excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself,
1469 you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's
1470 mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think
1471 any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made
1472 a matter of much discussion among you.  Pray excuse me; but supposing
1473 any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy,
1474 it cannot be expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father,
1475 who perfectly approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it,
1476 so long as it is a source of pleasure to herself.  It has been so
1477 many years my province to give advice, that you cannot be surprized,
1478 Mr. Knightley, at this little remains of office."
1479 
1480 "Not at all," cried he; "I am much obliged to you for it.
1481 It is very good advice, and it shall have a better fate than your
1482 advice has often found; for it shall be attended to."
1483 
1484 "Mrs. John Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy
1485 about her sister."
1486 
1487 "Be satisfied," said he, "I will not raise any outcry.  I will keep
1488 my ill-humour to myself.  I have a very sincere interest in Emma.
1489 Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a
1490 greater interest; perhaps hardly so great.  There is an anxiety,
1491 a curiosity in what one feels for Emma.  I wonder what will become
1492 of her!"
1493 
1494 "So do I," said Mrs. Weston gently, "very much."
1495 
1496 "She always declares she will never marry, which, of course,
1497 means just nothing at all.  But I have no idea that she has yet
1498 ever seen a man she cared for.  It would not be a bad thing for her
1499 to be very much in love with a proper object.  I should like to see
1500 Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good.
1501 But there is nobody hereabouts to attach her; and she goes so seldom
1502 from home."
1503 
1504 "There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break
1505 her resolution at present," said Mrs. Weston, "as can well be;
1506 and while she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be
1507 forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties
1508 on poor Mr. Woodhouse's account.  I do not recommend matrimony
1509 at present to Emma, though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you."
1510 
1511 Part of her meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of
1512 her own and Mr. Weston's on the subject, as much as possible.
1513 There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it
1514 was not desirable to have them suspected; and the quiet transition
1515 which Mr. Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston
1516 think of the weather; shall we have rain?" convinced her that he
1517 had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield.
1518 
1519 
1520 
1521 CHAPTER VI
1522 
1523 
1524 Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy
1525 a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity
1526 to a very good purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible
1527 than before of Mr. Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most
1528 agreeable manners; and as she had no hesitation in following up
1529 the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon
1530 pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side,
1531 as there could be any occasion for.  She was quite convinced
1532 of Mr. Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love,
1533 if not in love already.  She had no scruple with regard to him.
1534 He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could
1535 not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.
1536 His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner,
1537 since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least
1538 agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
1539 
1540 "You have given Miss Smith all that she required," said he;
1541 "you have made her graceful and easy.  She was a beautiful creature
1542 when she came to you, but, in my opinion, the attractions you have
1543 added are infinitely superior to what she received from nature."
1544 
1545 "I am glad you think I have been useful to her; but Harriet
1546 only wanted drawing out, and receiving a few, very few hints.
1547 She had all the natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness
1548 in herself.  I have done very little."
1549 
1550 "If it were admissible to contradict a lady," said the gallant
1551 Mr. Elton--
1552 
1553 "I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character,
1554 have taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her
1555 way before."
1556 
1557 "Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me.  So much superadded
1558 decision of character! Skilful has been the hand!"
1559 
1560 "Great has been the pleasure, I am sure.  I never met with
1561 a disposition more truly amiable."
1562 
1563 "I have no doubt of it." And it was spoken with a sort
1564 of sighing animation, which had a vast deal of the lover.
1565 She was not less pleased another day with the manner
1566 in which he seconded a sudden wish of hers, to have Harriet's picture.
1567 
1568 "Did you ever have your likeness taken, Harriet?" said she: "did
1569 you ever sit for your picture?"
1570
