1571 Harriet was on the point of leaving the room, and only stopt to say,
1572 with a very interesting naivete,
1573 
1574 "Oh! dear, no, never."
1575 
1576 No sooner was she out of sight, than Emma exclaimed,
1577 
1578 "What an exquisite possession a good picture of her would be! I would
1579 give any money for it.  I almost long to attempt her likeness myself.
1580 You do not know it I dare say, but two or three years ago I had
1581 a great passion for taking likenesses, and attempted several of
1582 my friends, and was thought to have a tolerable eye in general.
1583 But from one cause or another, I gave it up in disgust.
1584 But really, I could almost venture, if Harriet would sit to me.
1585 It would be such a delight to have her picture!"
1586 
1587 "Let me entreat you," cried Mr. Elton; "it would indeed be a delight!
1588 Let me entreat you, Miss Woodhouse, to exercise so charming a
1589 talent in favour of your friend.  I know what your drawings are.
1590 How could you suppose me ignorant? Is not this room rich in
1591 specimens of your landscapes and flowers; and has not Mrs. Weston
1592 some inimitable figure-pieces in her drawing-room, at Randalls?"
1593 
1594 Yes, good man!--thought Emma--but what has all that to do with taking
1595 likenesses? You know nothing of drawing.  Don't pretend to be
1596 in raptures about mine.  Keep your raptures for Harriet's face.
1597 "Well, if you give me such kind encouragement, Mr. Elton, I believe
1598 I shall try what I can do.  Harriet's features are very delicate,
1599 which makes a likeness difficult; and yet there is a peculiarity
1600 in the shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth which one ought
1601 to catch."
1602 
1603 "Exactly so--The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth--I
1604 have not a doubt of your success.  Pray, pray attempt it.
1605 As you will do it, it will indeed, to use your own words,
1606 be an exquisite possession."
1607 
1608 "But I am afraid, Mr. Elton, Harriet will not like to sit.
1609 She thinks so little of her own beauty.  Did not you observe her
1610 manner of answering me? How completely it meant, `why should my
1611 picture be drawn?'"
1612 
1613 "Oh! yes, I observed it, I assure you.  It was not lost on me.
1614 But still I cannot imagine she would not be persuaded."
1615 
1616 Harriet was soon back again, and the proposal almost immediately made;
1617 and she had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the earnest
1618 pressing of both the others.  Emma wished to go to work directly,
1619 and therefore produced the portfolio containing her various attempts
1620 at portraits, for not one of them had ever been finished, that they
1621 might decide together on the best size for Harriet.  Her many
1622 beginnings were displayed.  Miniatures, half-lengths, whole-lengths,
1623 pencil, crayon, and water-colours had been all tried in turn.
1624 She had always wanted to do every thing, and had made more progress
1625 both in drawing and music than many might have done with so little
1626 labour as she would ever submit to.  She played and sang;--and drew
1627 in almost every style; but steadiness had always been wanting;
1628 and in nothing had she approached the degree of excellence which she
1629 would have been glad to command, and ought not to have failed of.
1630 She was not much deceived as to her own skill either as an artist
1631 or a musician, but she was not unwilling to have others deceived,
1632 or sorry to know her reputation for accomplishment often higher
1633 than it deserved.
1634 
1635 There was merit in every drawing--in the least finished, perhaps the most;
1636 her style was spirited; but had there been much less, or had there
1637 been ten times more, the delight and admiration of her two companions
1638 would have been the same.  They were both in ecstasies.  A likeness
1639 pleases every body; and Miss Woodhouse's performances must be capital.
1640 
1641 "No great variety of faces for you," said Emma.  "I had only my
1642 own family to study from.  There is my father--another of my
1643 father--but the idea of sitting for his picture made him so nervous,
1644 that I could only take him by stealth; neither of them very
1645 like therefore.  Mrs. Weston again, and again, and again, you see.
1646 Dear Mrs. Weston! always my kindest friend on every occasion.
1647 She would sit whenever I asked her.  There is my sister; and really
1648 quite her own little elegant figure!--and the face not unlike.
1649 I should have made a good likeness of her, if she would have
1650 sat longer, but she was in such a hurry to have me draw her four
1651 children that she would not be quiet.  Then, here come all my
1652 attempts at three of those four children;--there they are,
1653 Henry and John and Bella, from one end of the sheet to the other,
1654 and any one of them might do for any one of the rest.  She was so
1655 eager to have them drawn that I could not refuse; but there is no
1656 making children of three or four years old stand still you know;
1657 nor can it be very easy to take any likeness of them, beyond the
1658 air and complexion, unless they are coarser featured than any
1659 of mama's children ever were.  Here is my sketch of the fourth,
1660 who was a baby.  I took him as he was sleeping on the sofa, and it
1661 is as strong a likeness of his cockade as you would wish to see.
1662 He had nestled down his head most conveniently.  That's very like.
1663 I am rather proud of little George.  The corner of the sofa is very good.
1664 Then here is my last,"--unclosing a pretty sketch of a gentleman
1665 in small size, whole-length--"my last and my best--my brother,
1666 Mr. John Knightley.--This did not want much of being finished, when I
1667 put it away in a pet, and vowed I would never take another likeness.
1668 I could not help being provoked; for after all my pains, and when I
1669 had really made a very good likeness of it--(Mrs. Weston and I
1670 were quite agreed in thinking it _very_ like)--only too handsome--too
1671 flattering--but that was a fault on the right side--after
1672 all this, came poor dear Isabella's cold approbation of--"Yes,
1673 it was a little like--but to be sure it did not do him justice."
1674 We had had a great deal of trouble in persuading him to sit at all.
1675 It was made a great favour of; and altogether it was more than I
1676 could bear; and so I never would finish it, to have it apologised
1677 over as an unfavourable likeness, to every morning visitor in
1678 Brunswick Square;--and, as I said, I did then forswear ever drawing
1679 any body again.  But for Harriet's sake, or rather for my own,
1680 and as there are no husbands and wives in the case _at_ _present_,
1681 I will break my resolution now."
1682 
1683 Mr. Elton seemed very properly struck and delighted by the idea,
1684 and was repeating, "No husbands and wives in the case at present
1685 indeed, as you observe.  Exactly so.  No husbands and wives,"
1686 with so interesting a consciousness, that Emma began to consider
1687 whether she had not better leave them together at once.  But as she
1688 wanted to be drawing, the declaration must wait a little longer.
1689 
1690 She had soon fixed on the size and sort of portrait.
1691 It was to be a whole-length in water-colours, like Mr. John
1692 Knightley's, and was destined, if she could please herself,
1693 to hold a very honourable station over the mantelpiece.
1694 
1695 The sitting began; and Harriet, smiling and blushing, and afraid
1696 of not keeping her attitude and countenance, presented a very sweet
1697 mixture of youthful expression to the steady eyes of the artist.
1698 But there was no doing any thing, with Mr. Elton fidgeting behind
1699 her and watching every touch.  She gave him credit for stationing
1700 himself where he might gaze and gaze again without offence;
1701 but was really obliged to put an end to it, and request him to
1702 place himself elsewhere.  It then occurred to her to employ him
1703 in reading.
1704 
1705 "If he would be so good as to read to them, it would be a kindness
1706 indeed! It would amuse away the difficulties of her part, and lessen
1707 the irksomeness of Miss Smith's."
1708 
1709 Mr. Elton was only too happy.  Harriet listened, and Emma drew
1710 in peace.  She must allow him to be still frequently coming to look;
1711 any thing less would certainly have been too little in a lover;
1712 and he was ready at the smallest intermission of the pencil,
1713 to jump up and see the progress, and be charmed.--There was no
1714 being displeased with such an encourager, for his admiration
1715 made him discern a likeness almost before it was possible.
1716 She could not respect his eye, but his love and his complaisance
1717 were unexceptionable.
1718 
1719 The sitting was altogether very satisfactory; she was quite
1720 enough pleased with the first day's sketch to wish to go on.
1721 There was no want of likeness, she had been fortunate in the attitude,
1722 and as she meant to throw in a little improvement to the figure,
1723 to give a little more height, and considerably more elegance, she had
1724 great confidence of its being in every way a pretty drawing at last,
1725 and of its filling its destined place with credit to them both--a
1726 standing memorial of the beauty of one, the skill of the other,
1727 and the friendship of both; with as many other agreeable associations
1728 as Mr. Elton's very promising attachment was likely to add.
1729 
1730 Harriet was to sit again the next day; and Mr. Elton, just as he ought,
1731 entreated for the permission of attending and reading to them again.
1732 
1733 "By all means.  We shall be most happy to consider you as one
1734 of the party."
1735 
1736 The same civilities and courtesies, the same success and satisfaction,
1737 took place on the morrow, and accompanied the whole progress
1738 of the picture, which was rapid and happy.  Every body who saw it
1739 was pleased, but Mr. Elton was in continual raptures, and defended
1740 it through every criticism.
1741 
1742 "Miss Woodhouse has given her friend the only beauty she
1743 wanted,"--observed Mrs. Weston to him--not in the least suspecting
1744 that she was addressing a lover.--"The expression of the eye is
1745 most correct, but Miss Smith has not those eyebrows and eyelashes.
1746 It is the fault of her face that she has them not."
1747 
1748 "Do you think so?" replied he.  "I cannot agree with you.
1749 It appears to me a most perfect resemblance in every feature.
1750 I never saw such a likeness in my life.  We must allow for the effect
1751 of shade, you know."
1752 
1753 "You have made her too tall, Emma," said Mr. Knightley.
1754 
1755 Emma knew that she had, but would not own it; and Mr. Elton warmly added,
1756 
1757 "Oh no! certainly not too tall; not in the least too tall.  Consider,
1758 she is sitting down--which naturally presents a different--which
1759 in short gives exactly the idea--and the proportions must
1760 be preserved, you know.  Proportions, fore-shortening.--Oh no! it
1761 gives one exactly the idea of such a height as Miss Smith's. Exactly so indeed!"
1762 
1763 "It is very pretty," said Mr. Woodhouse.  "So prettily done! Just
1764 as your drawings always are, my dear.  I do not know any body who draws
1765 so well as you do.  The only thing I do not thoroughly like is,
1766 that she seems to be sitting out of doors, with only a little shawl
1767 over her shoulders--and it makes one think she must catch cold."
1768 
1769 "But, my dear papa, it is supposed to be summer; a warm day in summer.
1770 Look at the tree."
1771 
1772 "But it is never safe to sit out of doors, my dear."
1773 
1774 "You, sir, may say any thing," cried Mr. Elton, "but I must confess
1775 that I regard it as a most happy thought, the placing of Miss
1776 Smith out of doors; and the tree is touched with such inimitable
1777 spirit! Any other situation would have been much less in character.
1778 The naivete of Miss Smith's manners--and altogether--Oh, it is
1779 most admirable! I cannot keep my eyes from it.  I never saw such
1780 a likeness."
1781 
1782 The next thing wanted was to get the picture framed; and here were a
1783 few difficulties.  It must be done directly; it must be done in London;
1784 the order must go through the hands of some intelligent person whose taste
1785 could be depended on; and Isabella, the usual doer of all commissions,
1786 must not be applied to, because it was December, and Mr. Woodhouse
1787 could not bear the idea of her stirring out of her house in the fogs
1788 of December.  But no sooner was the distress known to Mr. Elton,
1789 than it was removed.  His gallantry was always on the alert.
1790 "Might he be trusted with the commission, what infinite pleasure
1791 should he have in executing it! he could ride to London at any time.
1792 It was impossible to say how much he should be gratified by being
1793 employed on such an errand."
1794 
1795 "He was too good!--she could not endure the thought!--she would
1796 not give him such a troublesome office for the world,"--brought
1797 on the desired repetition of entreaties and assurances,--and
1798 a very few minutes settled the business.
1799 
1800 Mr. Elton was to take the drawing to London, chuse the frame,
1801 and give the directions; and Emma thought she could so pack it
1802 as to ensure its safety without much incommoding him, while he
1803 seemed mostly fearful of not being incommoded enough.
1804 
1805 "What a precious deposit!" said he with a tender sigh, as he
1806 received it.
1807 
1808 "This man is almost too gallant to be in love," thought Emma.
1809 "I should say so, but that I suppose there may be a hundred different
1810 ways of being in love.  He is an excellent young man, and will suit
1811 Harriet exactly; it will be an `Exactly so,' as he says himself;
1812 but he does sigh and languish, and study for compliments rather more
1813 than I could endure as a principal.  I come in for a pretty good
1814 share as a second.  But it is his gratitude on Harriet's account."
1815 
1816 
1817 
1818 CHAPTER VII
1819 
1820 
1821 The very day of Mr. Elton's going to London produced a fresh occasion
1822 for Emma's services towards her friend.  Harriet had been at Hartfield,
1823 as usual, soon after breakfast; and, after a time, had gone home
1824 to return again to dinner: she returned, and sooner than had been
1825 talked of, and with an agitated, hurried look, announcing something
1826 extraordinary to have happened which she was longing to tell.
1827 Half a minute brought it all out.  She had heard, as soon as she got
1828 back to Mrs. Goddard's, that Mr. Martin had been there an hour before,
1829 and finding she was not at home, nor particularly expected, had left
1830 a little parcel for her from one of his sisters, and gone away;
1831 and on opening this parcel, she had actually found, besides the two
1832 songs which she had lent Elizabeth to copy, a letter to herself;
1833 and this letter was from him, from Mr. Martin, and contained a direct
1834 proposal of marriage.  "Who could have thought it? She was so surprized
1835 she did not know what to do.  Yes, quite a proposal of marriage;
1836 and a very good letter, at least she thought so.  And he wrote
1837 as if he really loved her very much--but she did not know--and so,
1838 she was come as fast as she could to ask Miss Woodhouse what she
1839 should do.--" Emma was half-ashamed of her friend for seeming so
1840 pleased and so doubtful.
1841 
1842 "Upon my word," she cried, "the young man is determined not to lose
1843 any thing for want of asking.  He will connect himself well if he can."
1844 
1845 "Will you read the letter?" cried Harriet.  "Pray do.  I'd rather
1846 you would."
1847 
1848 Emma was not sorry to be pressed.  She read, and was surprized.
1849 The style of the letter was much above her expectation.
1850 There were not merely no grammatical errors, but as a composition it
1851 would not have disgraced a gentleman; the language, though plain,
1852 was strong and unaffected, and the sentiments it conveyed very much
1853 to the credit of the writer.  It was short, but expressed good sense,
1854 warm attachment, liberality, propriety, even delicacy of feeling.
1855 She paused over it, while Harriet stood anxiously watching for
1856 her opinion, with a "Well, well," and was at last forced to add,
1857 "Is it a good letter? or is it too short?"
1858 
1859 "Yes, indeed, a very good letter," replied Emma rather slowly--"so
1860 good a letter, Harriet, that every thing considered, I think one of
1861 his sisters must have helped him.  I can hardly imagine the young
1862 man whom I saw talking with you the other day could express himself
1863 so well, if left quite to his own powers, and yet it is not the
1864 style of a woman; no, certainly, it is too strong and concise;
1865 not diffuse enough for a woman.  No doubt he is a sensible man,
1866 and I suppose may have a natural talent for--thinks strongly and
1867 clearly--and when he takes a pen in hand, his thoughts naturally find
1868 proper words.  It is so with some men.  Yes, I understand the sort
1869 of mind.  Vigorous, decided, with sentiments to a certain point,
1870 not coarse.  A better written letter, Harriet (returning it,)
1871 than I had expected."
1872 
1873 "Well," said the still waiting Harriet;--"well--and--and what
1874 shall I do?"
1875 
1876 "What shall you do! In what respect? Do you mean with regard
1877 to this letter?"
1878 
1879 "Yes."
1880 
1881 "But what are you in doubt of? You must answer it of course--and speedily."
1882 
1883 "Yes. But what shall I say? Dear Miss Woodhouse, do advise me."
1884 
1885 "Oh no, no! the letter had much better be all your own.  You will
1886 express yourself very properly, I am sure.  There is no danger of your
1887 not being intelligible, which is the first thing.  Your meaning must
1888 be unequivocal; no doubts or demurs: and such expressions of gratitude
1889 and concern for the pain you are inflicting as propriety requires,
1890 will present themselves unbidden to _your_ mind, I am persuaded.
1891 You need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow
1892 for his disappointment."
1893 
1894 "You think I ought to refuse him then," said Harriet, looking down.
1895 
1896 "Ought to refuse him! My dear Harriet, what do you mean? Are you
1897 in any doubt as to that? I thought--but I beg your pardon, perhaps I
1898 have been under a mistake.  I certainly have been misunderstanding
1899 you, if you feel in doubt as to the _purport_ of your answer.
1900 I had imagined you were consulting me only as to the wording of it."
1901 
1902 Harriet was silent.  With a little reserve of manner, Emma continued:
1903 
1904 "You mean to return a favourable answer, I collect."
1905 
1906 "No, I do not; that is, I do not mean--What shall I do? What would
1907 you advise me to do? Pray, dear Miss Woodhouse, tell me what I
1908 ought to do."
1909 
1910 "I shall not give you any advice, Harriet.  I will have nothing to
1911 do with it.  This is a point which you must settle with your feelings."
1912 
1913 "I had no notion that he liked me so very much," said Harriet,
1914 contemplating the letter.  For a little while Emma persevered
1915 in her silence; but beginning to apprehend the bewitching flattery
1916 of that letter might be too powerful, she thought it best to say,
1917 
1918 "I lay it down as a general rule, Harriet, that if a woman _doubts_
1919 as to whether she should accept a man or not, she certainly ought
1920 to refuse him.  If she can hesitate as to `Yes,' she ought to say
1921 `No' directly.  It is not a state to be safely entered into
1922 with doubtful feelings, with half a heart.  I thought it my duty
1923 as a friend, and older than yourself, to say thus much to you.
1924 But do not imagine that I want to influence you."
1925 
1926 "Oh! no, I am sure you are a great deal too kind to--but if you
1927 would just advise me what I had best do--No, no, I do not mean
1928 that--As you say, one's mind ought to be quite made up--One should
1929 not be hesitating--It is a very serious thing.--It will be safer
1930 to say `No,' perhaps.--Do you think I had better say `No?'"
1931 
1932 "Not for the world," said Emma, smiling graciously, "would I advise
1933 you either way.  You must be the best judge of your own happiness.
1934 If you prefer Mr. Martin to every other person; if you think him
1935 the most agreeable man you have ever been in company with, why should
1936 you hesitate? You blush, Harriet.--Does any body else occur to you
1937 at this moment under such a definition? Harriet, Harriet, do not
1938 deceive yourself; do not be run away with by gratitude and compassion.
1939 At this moment whom are you thinking of?"
1940 
1941 The symptoms were favourable.--Instead of answering, Harriet turned
1942 away confused, and stood thoughtfully by the fire; and though
1943 the letter was still in her hand, it was now mechanically twisted
1944 about without regard.  Emma waited the result with impatience,
1945 but not without strong hopes.  At last, with some hesitation,
1946 Harriet said--
1947 
1948 "Miss Woodhouse, as you will not give me your opinion, I must
1949 do as well as I can by myself; and I have now quite determined,
1950 and really almost made up my mind--to refuse Mr. Martin.  Do you
1951 think I am right?"
1952 
1953 "Perfectly, perfectly right, my dearest Harriet; you are doing just
1954 what you ought.  While you were at all in suspense I kept my feelings
1955 to myself, but now that you are so completely decided I have no
1956 hesitation in approving.  Dear Harriet, I give myself joy of this.
1957 It would have grieved me to lose your acquaintance, which must have
1958 been the consequence of your marrying Mr. Martin.  While you were in
1959 the smallest degree wavering, I said nothing about it, because I would
1960 not influence; but it would have been the loss of a friend to me.
1961 I could not have visited Mrs. Robert Martin, of Abbey-Mill Farm.
1962 Now I am secure of you for ever."
1963 
1964 Harriet had not surmised her own danger, but the idea of it struck
1965 her forcibly.
1966 
1967 "You could not have visited me!" she cried, looking aghast.
1968 "No, to be sure you could not; but I never thought of that before.
1969 That would have been too dreadful!--What an escape!--Dear Miss Woodhouse,
1970 I would not give up the pleasure and honour of being intimate with you
1971 for any thing in the world."
1972 
1973 "Indeed, Harriet, it would have been a severe pang to lose you;
1974 but it must have been.  You would have thrown yourself out of all
1975 good society.  I must have given you up."
1976 
1977 "Dear me!--How should I ever have borne it! It would have killed
1978 me never to come to Hartfield any more!"
1979 
1980 "Dear affectionate creature!--_You_ banished to Abbey-Mill Farm!--_You_
1981 confined to the society of the illiterate and vulgar all your life!
1982 I wonder how the young man could have the assurance to ask it.
1983 He must have a pretty good opinion of himself."
1984 
1985 "I do not think he is conceited either, in general," said Harriet,
1986 her conscience opposing such censure; "at least, he is very good natured,
1987 and I shall always feel much obliged to him, and have a great regard
1988 for--but that is quite a different thing from--and you know,
1989 though he may like me, it does not follow that I should--and
1990 certainly I must confess that since my visiting here I have seen
1991 people--and if one comes to compare them, person and manners,
1992 there is no comparison at all, _one_ is so very handsome and agreeable.
1993 However, I do really think Mr. Martin a very amiable young man,
1994 and have a great opinion of him; and his being so much attached
1995 to me--and his writing such a letter--but as to leaving you,
1996 it is what I would not do upon any consideration."
1997 
1998 "Thank you, thank you, my own sweet little friend.  We will not
1999 be parted.  A woman is not to marry a man merely because she is asked,
2000 or because he is attached to her, and can write a tolerable letter."
2001 
2002 "Oh no;--and it is but a short letter too."
2003 
2004 Emma felt the bad taste of her friend, but let it pass with a
2005 "very true; and it would be a small consolation to her, for the
2006 clownish manner which might be offending her every hour of the day,
2007 to know that her husband could write a good letter."
2008 
2009 "Oh! yes, very.  Nobody cares for a letter; the thing is, to be always
2010 happy with pleasant companions.  I am quite determined to refuse him.
2011 But how shall I do? What shall I say?"
2012 
2013 Emma assured her there would be no difficulty in the answer,
2014 and advised its being written directly, which was agreed to,
2015 in the hope of her assistance; and though Emma continued to protest
2016 against any assistance being wanted, it was in fact given in the
2017 formation of every sentence.  The looking over his letter again,
2018 in replying to it, had such a softening tendency, that it was
2019 particularly necessary to brace her up with a few decisive expressions;
2020 and she was so very much concerned at the idea of making him unhappy,
2021 and thought so much of what his mother and sisters would think and say,
2022 and was so anxious that they should not fancy her ungrateful,
2023 that Emma believed if the young man had come in her way at that moment,
2024 he would have been accepted after all.
2025 
2026 This letter, however, was written, and sealed, and sent.
2027 The business was finished, and Harriet safe.  She was rather low
2028 all the evening, but Emma could allow for her amiable regrets,
2029 and sometimes relieved them by speaking of her own affection,
2030 sometimes by bringing forward the idea of Mr. Elton.
2031 
2032 "I shall never be invited to Abbey-Mill again," was said in rather
2033 a sorrowful tone.
2034 
2035 "Nor, if you were, could I ever bear to part with you, my Harriet.
2036 You are a great deal too necessary at Hartfield to be spared
2037 to Abbey-Mill."
2038 
2039 "And I am sure I should never want to go there; for I am never happy
2040 but at Hartfield."
2041 
2042 Some time afterwards it was, "I think Mrs. Goddard would be very
2043 much surprized if she knew what had happened.  I am sure Miss Nash
2044 would--for Miss Nash thinks her own sister very well married,
2045 and it is only a linen-draper."
2046 
2047 "One should be sorry to see greater pride or refinement in the
2048 teacher of a school, Harriet.  I dare say Miss Nash would envy you
2049 such an opportunity as this of being married.  Even this conquest
2050 would appear valuable in her eyes.  As to any thing superior for you,
2051 I suppose she is quite in the dark.  The attentions of a certain
2052 person can hardly be among the tittle-tattle of Highbury yet.
2053 Hitherto I fancy you and I are the only people to whom his looks
2054 and manners have explained themselves."
2055 
2056 Harriet blushed and smiled, and said something about wondering
2057 that people should like her so much.  The idea of Mr. Elton was
2058 certainly cheering; but still, after a time, she was tender-hearted
2059 again towards the rejected Mr. Martin.
2060 
2061 "Now he has got my letter," said she softly.  "I wonder what they
2062 are all doing--whether his sisters know--if he is unhappy,
2063 they will be unhappy too.  I hope he will not mind it so very much."
2064 
2065 "Let us think of those among our absent friends who are more
2066 cheerfully employed," cried Emma.  "At this moment, perhaps, Mr. Elton
2067 is shewing your picture to his mother and sisters, telling how much
2068 more beautiful is the original, and after being asked for it five
2069 or six times, allowing them to hear your name, your own dear name."
2070 
2071 "My picture!--But he has left my picture in Bond-street."
2072 
2073 "Has he so!--Then I know nothing of Mr. Elton.  No, my dear
2074 little modest Harriet, depend upon it the picture will not be
2075 in Bond-street till just before he mounts his horse to-morrow.
2076 It is his companion all this evening, his solace, his delight.
2077 It opens his designs to his family, it introduces you among them,
2078 it diffuses through the party those pleasantest feelings of our nature,
2079 eager curiosity and warm prepossession.  How cheerful, how animated,
2080 how suspicious, how busy their imaginations all are!"
2081 
2082 Harriet smiled again, and her smiles grew stronger.
2083 
2084 
2085 
2086 CHAPTER VIII
2087 
2088 
2089 Harriet slept at Hartfield that night.  For some weeks past she
2090 had been spending more than half her time there, and gradually
2091 getting to have a bed-room appropriated to herself; and Emma
2092 judged it best in every respect, safest and kindest, to keep her
2093 with them as much as possible just at present.  She was obliged
2094 to go the next morning for an hour or two to Mrs. Goddard's,
2095 but it was then to be settled that she should return to Hartfield,
2096 to make a regular visit of some days.
2097 
2098 While she was gone, Mr. Knightley called, and sat some time with
2099 Mr. Woodhouse and Emma, till Mr. Woodhouse, who had previously made up
2100 his mind to walk out, was persuaded by his daughter not to defer it,
2101 and was induced by the entreaties of both, though against the scruples
2102 of his own civility, to leave Mr. Knightley for that purpose.
2103 Mr. Knightley, who had nothing of ceremony about him, was offering
2104 by his short, decided answers, an amusing contrast to the protracted
2105 apologies and civil hesitations of the other.
2106 
2107 "Well, I believe, if you will excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if you
2108 will not consider me as doing a very rude thing, I shall take
2109 Emma's advice and go out for a quarter of an hour.  As the sun
2110 is out, I believe I had better take my three turns while I can.
2111 I treat you without ceremony, Mr. Knightley.  We invalids think we
2112 are privileged people."
2113 
2114 "My dear sir, do not make a stranger of me."
2115 
2116 "I leave an excellent substitute in my daughter.  Emma will be happy
2117 to entertain you.  And therefore I think I will beg your excuse
2118 and take my three turns--my winter walk."
2119 
2120 "You cannot do better, sir."
2121 
2122 "I would ask for the pleasure of your company, Mr. Knightley,
2123 but I am a very slow walker, and my pace would be tedious to you;
2124 and, besides, you have another long walk before you, to Donwell Abbey."
2125 
2126 "Thank you, sir, thank you; I am going this moment myself; and I
2127 think the sooner _you_ go the better.  I will fetch your greatcoat
2128 and open the garden door for you."
2129 
2130 Mr. Woodhouse at last was off; but Mr. Knightley, instead of being
2131 immediately off likewise, sat down again, seemingly inclined
2132 for more chat.  He began speaking of Harriet, and speaking
2133 of her with more voluntary praise than Emma had ever heard before.
2134 
2135 "I cannot rate her beauty as you do," said he; "but she is a
2136 pretty little creature, and I am inclined to think very well of
2137 her disposition.  Her character depends upon those she is with;
2138 but in good hands she will turn out a valuable woman."
2139 
2140 "I am glad you think so; and the good hands, I hope, may not be wanting."
2141 
2142 "Come," said he, "you are anxious for a compliment, so I will
2143 tell you that you have improved her.  You have cured her of her
2144 school-girl's giggle; she really does you credit."
2145 
2146 "Thank you.  I should be mortified indeed if I did not believe I
2147 had been of some use; but it is not every body who will bestow
2148 praise where they may.  _You_ do not often overpower me with it."
2149 
2150 "You are expecting her again, you say, this morning?"
2151 
2152 "Almost every moment.  She has been gone longer already than
2153 she intended."
2154 
2155 "Something has happened to delay her; some visitors perhaps."
2156 
2157 "Highbury gossips!--Tiresome wretches!"
2158 
2159 "Harriet may not consider every body tiresome that you would."
2160 
2161 Emma knew this was too true for contradiction, and therefore
2162 said nothing.  He presently added, with a smile,
2163 
2164 "I do not pretend to fix on times or places, but I must tell you
2165 that I have good reason to believe your little friend will soon
2166 hear of something to her advantage."
2167 
2168 "Indeed! how so? of what sort?"
2169 
2170 "A very serious sort, I assure you;" still smiling.
2171 
2172 "Very serious! I can think of but one thing--Who is in love
2173 with her? Who makes you their confidant?"
2174 
2175 Emma was more than half in hopes of Mr. Elton's having dropt a hint.
2176 Mr. Knightley was a sort of general friend and adviser, and she knew
2177 Mr. Elton looked up to him.
2178 
2179 "I have reason to think," he replied, "that Harriet Smith will
2180 soon have an offer of marriage, and from a most unexceptionable
2181 quarter:--Robert Martin is the man.  Her visit to Abbey-Mill,
2182 this summer, seems to have done his business.  He is desperately
2183 in love and means to marry her."
2184 
2185 "He is very obliging," said Emma; "but is he sure that Harriet
2186 means to marry him?"
2187 
2188 "Well, well, means to make her an offer then.  Will that do? He came
2189 to the Abbey two evenings ago, on purpose to consult me about it.
2190 He knows I have a thorough regard for him and all his family, and,
2191 I believe, considers me as one of his best friends.  He came to ask
2192 me whether I thought it would be imprudent in him to settle so early;
2193 whether I thought her too young: in short, whether I approved his
2194 choice altogether; having some apprehension perhaps of her being
2195 considered (especially since _your_ making so much of her) as in a line
2196 of society above him.  I was very much pleased with all that he said.
2197 I never hear better sense from any one than Robert Martin.
2198 He always speaks to the purpose; open, straightforward, and very
2199 well judging.  He told me every thing; his circumstances and plans,
2200 and what they all proposed doing in the event of his marriage.  He is
2201 an excellent young man, both as son and brother.  I had no hesitation
2202 in advising him to marry.  He proved to me that he could afford it;
2203 and that being the case, I was convinced he could not do better.
2204 I praised the fair lady too, and altogether sent him away very happy.
2205 If he had never esteemed my opinion before, he would have thought
2206 highly of me then; and, I dare say, left the house thinking me the
2207 best friend and counsellor man ever had.  This happened the night
2208 before last.  Now, as we may fairly suppose, he would not allow
2209 much time to pass before he spoke to the lady, and as he does not
2210 appear to have spoken yesterday, it is not unlikely that he should
2211 be at Mrs. Goddard's to-day; and she may be detained by a visitor,
2212 without thinking him at all a tiresome wretch."
2213 
2214 "Pray, Mr. Knightley," said Emma, who had been smiling to herself
2215 through a great part of this speech, "how do you know that Mr. Martin
2216 did not speak yesterday?"
2217 
2218 "Certainly," replied he, surprized, "I do not absolutely know it;
2219 but it may be inferred.  Was not she the whole day with you?"
2220 
2221 "Come," said she, "I will tell you something, in return for what
2222 you have told me.  He did speak yesterday--that is, he wrote,
2223 and was refused."
2224 
2225 This was obliged to be repeated before it could be believed;
2226 and Mr. Knightley actually looked red with surprize and displeasure,
2227 as he stood up, in tall indignation, and said,
2228 
2229 "Then she is a greater simpleton than I ever believed her.
2230 What is the foolish girl about?"
2231 
2232 "Oh! to be sure," cried Emma, "it is always incomprehensible
2233 to a man that a woman should ever refuse an offer of marriage.
2234 A man always imagines a woman to be ready for any body who asks her."
2235 
2236 "Nonsense! a man does not imagine any such thing.  But what is
2237 the meaning of this? Harriet Smith refuse Robert Martin? madness,
2238 if it is so; but I hope you are mistaken."
2239 
2240 "I saw her answer!--nothing could be clearer."
2241 
2242 "You saw her answer!--you wrote her answer too.  Emma, this is
2243 your doing.  You persuaded her to refuse him."
2244 
2245 "And if I did, (which, however, I am far from allowing) I should
2246 not feel that I had done wrong.  Mr. Martin is a very respectable
2247 young man, but I cannot admit him to be Harriet's equal; and am
2248 rather surprized indeed that he should have ventured to address her.
2249 By your account, he does seem to have had some scruples.  It is
2250 a pity that they were ever got over."
2251 
2252 "Not Harriet's equal!" exclaimed Mr. Knightley loudly and warmly;
2253 and with calmer asperity, added, a few moments afterwards, "No, he
2254 is not her equal indeed, for he is as much her superior in sense
2255 as in situation.  Emma, your infatuation about that girl blinds you.
2256 What are Harriet Smith's claims, either of birth, nature or education,
2257 to any connexion higher than Robert Martin? She is the natural
2258 daughter of nobody knows whom, with probably no settled provision
2259 at all, and certainly no respectable relations.  She is known only
2260 as parlour-boarder at a common school.  She is not a sensible girl,
2261 nor a girl of any information.  She has been taught nothing useful,
2262 and is too young and too simple to have acquired any thing herself.
2263 At her age she can have no experience, and with her little wit,
2264 is not very likely ever to have any that can avail her.
2265 She is pretty, and she is good tempered, and that is all.
2266 My only scruple in advising the match was on his account, as being
2267 beneath his deserts, and a bad connexion for him.  I felt that,
2268 as to fortune, in all probability he might do much better; and that as
2269 to a rational companion or useful helpmate, he could not do worse.
2270 But I could not reason so to a man in love, and was willing
2271 to trust to there being no harm in her, to her having that sort
2272 of disposition, which, in good hands, like his, might be easily led
2273 aright and turn out very well.  The advantage of the match I felt
2274 to be all on her side; and had not the smallest doubt (nor have I now)
2275 that there would be a general cry-out upon her extreme good luck.
2276 Even _your_ satisfaction I made sure of.  It crossed my mind immediately
2277 that you would not regret your friend's leaving Highbury, for the
2278 sake of her being settled so well.  I remember saying to myself,
2279 `Even Emma, with all her partiality for Harriet, will think this a
2280 good match.'"
2281 
2282 "I cannot help wondering at your knowing so little of Emma as to say
2283 any such thing.  What! think a farmer, (and with all his sense and all
2284 his merit Mr. Martin is nothing more,) a good match for my intimate
2285 friend! Not regret her leaving Highbury for the sake of marrying
2286 a man whom I could never admit as an acquaintance of my own! I
2287 wonder you should think it possible for me to have such feelings.
2288 I assure you mine are very different.  I must think your statement
2289 by no means fair.  You are not just to Harriet's claims.
2290 They would be estimated very differently by others as well as myself;
2291 Mr. Martin may be the richest of the two, but he is undoubtedly
2292 her inferior as to rank in society.--The sphere in which she moves
2293 is much above his.--It would be a degradation."
2294 
2295 "A degradation to illegitimacy and ignorance, to be married
2296 to a respectable, intelligent gentleman-farmer!"
2297 
2298 "As to the circumstances of her birth, though in a legal sense
2299 she may be called Nobody, it will not hold in common sense.
2300 She is not to pay for the offence of others, by being held below
2301 the level of those with whom she is brought up.--There can scarcely
2302 be a doubt that her father is a gentleman--and a gentleman of
2303 fortune.--Her allowance is very liberal; nothing has ever been grudged
2304 for her improvement or comfort.--That she is a gentleman's daughter,
2305 is indubitable to me; that she associates with gentlemen's daughters,
2306 no one, I apprehend, will deny.--She is superior to Mr. Robert Martin."
2307 
2308 "Whoever might be her parents," said Mr. Knightley, "whoever may
2309 have had the charge of her, it does not appear to have been any part
2310 of their plan to introduce her into what you would call good society.
2311 After receiving a very indifferent education she is left in
2312 Mrs. Goddard's hands to shift as she can;--to move, in short,
2313 in Mrs. Goddard's line, to have Mrs. Goddard's acquaintance.
2314 Her friends evidently thought this good enough for her; and it _was_
2315 good enough.  She desired nothing better herself.  Till you chose
2316 to turn her into a friend, her mind had no distaste for her own set,
2317 nor any ambition beyond it.  She was as happy as possible with the
2318 Martins in the summer.  She had no sense of superiority then.
2319 If she has it now, you have given it.  You have been no friend to
2320 Harriet Smith, Emma.  Robert Martin would never have proceeded so far,
2321 if he had not felt persuaded of her not being disinclined to him.
2322 I know him well.  He has too much real feeling to address any
2323 woman on the haphazard of selfish passion.  And as to conceit,
2324 he is the farthest from it of any man I know.  Depend upon it he
2325 had encouragement."
2326 
2327 It was most convenient to Emma not to make a direct reply to this
2328 assertion; she chose rather to take up her own line of the subject again.
2329 
2330 "You are a very warm friend to Mr. Martin; but, as I said before,
2331 are unjust to Harriet.  Harriet's claims to marry well are not
2332 so contemptible as you represent them.  She is not a clever girl,
2333 but she has better sense than you are aware of, and does not
2334 deserve to have her understanding spoken of so slightingly.
2335 Waiving that point, however, and supposing her to be, as you
2336 describe her, only pretty and good-natured, let me tell you, that in
2337 the degree she possesses them, they are not trivial recommendations
2338 to the world in general, for she is, in fact, a beautiful girl,
2339 and must be thought so by ninety-nine people out of an hundred;
2340 and till it appears that men are much more philosophic on the subject
2341 of beauty than they are generally supposed; till they do fall
2342 in love with well-informed minds instead of handsome faces, a girl,
2343 with such loveliness as Harriet, has a certainty of being admired
2344 and sought after, of having the power of chusing from among many,
2345 consequently a claim to be nice.  Her good-nature, too, is not so very
2346 slight a claim, comprehending, as it does, real, thorough sweetness
2347 of temper and manner, a very humble opinion of herself, and a great
2348 readiness to be pleased with other people.  I am very much mistaken
2349 if your sex in general would not think such beauty, and such temper,
2350 the highest claims a woman could possess."
2351 
2352 "Upon my word, Emma, to hear you abusing the reason you have,
2353 is almost enough to make me think so too.  Better be without sense,
2354 than misapply it as you do."
2355 
2356 "To be sure!" cried she playfully.  "I know _that_ is the feeling
2357 of you all.  I know that such a girl as Harriet is exactly
2358 what every man delights in--what at once bewitches his senses
2359 and satisfies his judgment.  Oh! Harriet may pick and chuse.
2360 Were you, yourself, ever to marry, she is the very woman for you.
2361 And is she, at seventeen, just entering into life, just beginning
2362 to be known, to be wondered at because she does not accept the first
2363 offer she receives? No--pray let her have time to look about her."
2364 
2365 "I have always thought it a very foolish intimacy," said Mr. Knightley
2366 presently, "though I have kept my thoughts to myself; but I now
2367 perceive that it will be a very unfortunate one for Harriet.
2368 You will puff her up with such ideas of her own beauty, and of what
2369 she has a claim to, that, in a little while, nobody within her
2370 reach will be good enough for her.  Vanity working on a weak head,
2371 produces every sort of mischief.  Nothing so easy as for a young lady
2372 to raise her expectations too high.  Miss Harriet Smith may not find
2373 offers of marriage flow in so fast, though she is a very pretty girl.
2374 Men of sense, whatever you may chuse to say, do not want silly wives.
2375 Men of family would not be very fond of connecting themselves
2376 with a girl of such obscurity--and most prudent men would be
2377 afraid of the inconvenience and disgrace they might be involved in,
2378 when the mystery of her parentage came to be revealed.  Let her marry
2379 Robert Martin, and she is safe, respectable, and happy for ever;
2380 but if you encourage her to expect to marry greatly, and teach
2381 her to be satisfied with nothing less than a man of consequence
2382 and large fortune, she may be a parlour-boarder at Mrs. Goddard's
2383 all the rest of her life--or, at least, (for Harriet Smith is a
2384 girl who will marry somebody or other,) till she grow desperate,
2385 and is glad to catch at the old writing-master's son."
2386 
2387 "We think so very differently on this point, Mr. Knightley,
2388 that there can be no use in canvassing it.  We shall only be making
2389 each other more angry.  But as to my _letting_ her marry Robert Martin,
2390 it is impossible; she has refused him, and so decidedly, I think,
2391 as must prevent any second application.  She must abide by the evil
2392 of having refused him, whatever it may be; and as to the refusal itself,
2393 I will not pretend to say that I might not influence her a little;
2394 but I assure you there was very little for me or for any body to do.
2395 His appearance is so much against him, and his manner so bad,
2396 that if she ever were disposed to favour him, she is not now.
2397 I can imagine, that before she had seen any body superior,
2398 she might tolerate him.  He was the brother of her friends,
2399 and he took pains to please her; and altogether, having seen
2400 nobody better (that must have been his great assistant)
2401 she might not, while she was at Abbey-Mill, find him disagreeable.
2402 But the case is altered now.  She knows now what gentlemen are;
2403 and nothing but a gentleman in education and manner has any chance
2404 with Harriet."
2405 
2406 "Nonsense, errant nonsense, as ever was talked!" cried Mr. Knightley.--"Robert
2407 Martin's manners have sense, sincerity, and good-humour to recommend
2408 them; and his mind has more true gentility than Harriet Smith could understand."
2409 
2410 Emma made no answer, and tried to look cheerfully unconcerned, but was
2411 really feeling uncomfortable and wanting him very much to be gone.
2412 She did not repent what she had done; she still thought herself
2413 a better judge of such a point of female right and refinement than he
2414 could be; but yet she had a sort of habitual respect for his judgment
2415 in general, which made her dislike having it so loudly against her;
2416 and to have him sitting just opposite to her in angry state,
2417 was very disagreeable.  Some minutes passed in this unpleasant silence,
2418 with only one attempt on Emma's side to talk of the weather,
2419 but he made no answer.  He was thinking.  The result of his thoughts
2420 appeared at last in these words.
2421 
2422 "Robert Martin has no great loss--if he can but think so; and I
2423 hope it will not be long before he does.  Your views for Harriet
2424 are best known to yourself; but as you make no secret of your love
2425 of match-making, it is fair to suppose that views, and plans,
2426 and projects you have;--and as a friend I shall just hint to you
2427 that if Elton is the man, I think it will be all labour in vain."
2428 
2429 Emma laughed and disclaimed.  He continued,
2430 
2431 "Depend upon it, Elton will not do.  Elton is a very good sort of man,
2432 and a very respectable vicar of Highbury, but not at all likely
2433 to make an imprudent match.  He knows the value of a good income
2434 as well as any body.  Elton may talk sentimentally, but he will
2435 act rationally.  He is as well acquainted with his own claims, as you
2436 can be with Harriet's. He knows that he is a very handsome young man,
2437 and a great favourite wherever he goes; and from his general way
2438 of talking in unreserved moments, when there are only men present,
2439 I am convinced that he does not mean to throw himself away.
2440 I have heard him speak with great animation of a large family
2441 of young ladies that his sisters are intimate with, who have all
2442 twenty thousand pounds apiece."
2443 
2444 "I am very much obliged to you," said Emma, laughing again.
2445 "If I had set my heart on Mr. Elton's marrying Harriet, it would
2446 have been very kind to open my eyes; but at present I only want
2447 to keep Harriet to myself.  I have done with match-making indeed.
2448 I could never hope to equal my own doings at Randalls.  I shall leave
2449 off while I am well."
2450 
2451 "Good morning to you,"--said he, rising and walking off abruptly.
2452 He was very much vexed.  He felt the disappointment of the young man,
2453 and was mortified to have been the means of promoting it, by the
2454 sanction he had given; and the part which he was persuaded Emma had
2455 taken in the affair, was provoking him exceedingly.
2456 
2457 Emma remained in a state of vexation too; but there was more
2458 indistinctness in the causes of her's, than in his.  She did not always
2459 feel so absolutely satisfied with herself, so entirely convinced that
2460 her opinions were right and her adversary's wrong, as Mr. Knightley.
2461 He walked off in more complete self-approbation than he left for her.
2462 She was not so materially cast down, however, but that a little
2463 time and the return of Harriet were very adequate restoratives.
2464 Harriet's staying away so long was beginning to make her uneasy.
2465 The possibility of the young man's coming to Mrs. Goddard's
2466 that morning, and meeting with Harriet and pleading his own cause,
2467 gave alarming ideas.  The dread of such a failure after all became the
2468 prominent uneasiness; and when Harriet appeared, and in very good spirits,
2469 and without having any such reason to give for her long absence,
2470 she felt a satisfaction which settled her with her own mind,
2471 and convinced her, that let Mr. Knightley think or say what he would,
2472 she had done nothing which woman's friendship and woman's feelings
2473 would not justify.
2474 
2475 He had frightened her a little about Mr. Elton; but when she considered
2476 that Mr. Knightley could not have observed him as she had done,
2477 neither with the interest, nor (she must be allowed to tell herself,
2478 in spite of Mr. Knightley's pretensions) with the skill of such
2479 an observer on such a question as herself, that he had spoken it
2480 hastily and in anger, she was able to believe, that he had rather
2481 said what he wished resentfully to be true, than what he knew
2482 any thing about.  He certainly might have heard Mr. Elton speak
2483 with more unreserve than she had ever done, and Mr. Elton might not
2484 be of an imprudent, inconsiderate disposition as to money matters;
2485 he might naturally be rather attentive than otherwise to them;
2486 but then, Mr. Knightley did not make due allowance for the influence
2487 of a strong passion at war with all interested motives.  Mr. Knightley
2488 saw no such passion, and of course thought nothing of its effects;
2489 but she saw too much of it to feel a doubt of its overcoming any
2490 hesitations that a reasonable prudence might originally suggest;
2491 and more than a reasonable, becoming degree of prudence, she was very
2492 sure did not belong to Mr. Elton.
2493 
2494 Harriet's cheerful look and manner established hers: she came back,
2495 not to think of Mr. Martin, but to talk of Mr. Elton.  Miss Nash
2496 had been telling her something, which she repeated immediately
2497 with great delight.  Mr. Perry had been to Mrs. Goddard's to attend
2498 a sick child, and Miss Nash had seen him, and he had told Miss Nash,
2499 that as he was coming back yesterday from Clayton Park, he had met
2500 Mr. Elton, and found to his great surprize, that Mr. Elton was
2501 actually on his road to London, and not meaning to return till
2502 the morrow, though it was the whist-club night, which he had been
2503 never known to miss before; and Mr. Perry had remonstrated with him
2504 about it, and told him how shabby it was in him, their best player,
2505 to absent himself, and tried very much to persuade him to put off
2506 his journey only one day; but it would not do; Mr. Elton had been
2507 determined to go on, and had said in a _very_ _particular_ way indeed,
2508 that he was going on business which he would not put off for any
2509 inducement in the world; and something about a very enviable commission,
2510 and being the bearer of something exceedingly precious.  Mr. Perry
2511 could not quite understand him, but he was very sure there must
2512 be a _lady_ in the case, and he told him so; and Mr. Elton only
2513 looked very conscious and smiling, and rode off in great spirits.
2514 Miss Nash had told her all this, and had talked a great deal more
2515 about Mr. Elton; and said, looking so very significantly at her,
2516 "that she did not pretend to understand what his business might be,
2517 but she only knew that any woman whom Mr. Elton could prefer,
2518 she should think the luckiest woman in the world; for, beyond a doubt,
2519 Mr. Elton had not his equal for beauty or agreeableness."
2520 
2521 
2522 
2523 CHAPTER IX
2524 
2525 
2526 Mr. Knightley might quarrel with her, but Emma could not quarrel
2527 with herself.  He was so much displeased, that it was longer than
2528 usual before he came to Hartfield again; and when they did meet,
2529 his grave looks shewed that she was not forgiven.  She was sorry,
2530 but could not repent.  On the contrary, her plans and proceedings
2531 were more and more justified and endeared to her by the general
2532 appearances of the next few days.
2533 
2534 The Picture, elegantly framed, came safely to hand soon after
2535 Mr. Elton's return, and being hung over the mantelpiece of the common
2536 sitting-room, he got up to look at it, and sighed out his half sentences
2537 of admiration just as he ought; and as for Harriet's feelings, they were
2538 visibly forming themselves into as strong and steady an attachment
2539 as her youth and sort of mind admitted.  Emma was soon perfectly
2540 satisfied of Mr. Martin's being no otherwise remembered, than as
2541 he furnished a contrast with Mr. Elton, of the utmost advantage to the latter.
2542 
2543 Her views of improving her little friend's mind, by a great deal
2544 of useful reading and conversation, had never yet led to more than
2545 a few first chapters, and the intention of going on to-morrow.
2546 It was much easier to chat than to study; much pleasanter to let
2547 her imagination range and work at Harriet's fortune, than to be
2548 labouring to enlarge her comprehension or exercise it on sober facts;
2549 and the only literary pursuit which engaged Harriet at present,
2550 the only mental provision she was making for the evening of life,
2551 was the collecting and transcribing all the riddles of every sort
2552 that she could meet with, into a thin quarto of hot-pressed paper,
2553 made up by her friend, and ornamented with ciphers and trophies.
2554 
2555 In this age of literature, such collections on a very grand scale
2556 are not uncommon.  Miss Nash, head-teacher at Mrs. Goddard's,
2557 had written out at least three hundred; and Harriet, who had taken
2558 the first hint of it from her, hoped, with Miss Woodhouse's help,
2559 to get a great many more.  Emma assisted with her invention,
2560 memory and taste; and as Harriet wrote a very pretty hand,
2561 it was likely to be an arrangement of the first order, in form
2562 as well as quantity.
2563 
2564 Mr. Woodhouse was almost as much interested in the business as the girls,
2565 and tried very often to recollect something worth their putting in.
2566 "So many clever riddles as there used to be when he was young--he
2567 wondered he could not remember them! but he hoped he should in time."
2568 And it always ended in "Kitty, a fair but frozen maid."
2569 
2570 His good friend Perry, too, whom he had spoken to on the subject,
2571 did not at present recollect any thing of the riddle kind;
2572 but he had desired Perry to be upon the watch, and as he went about
2573 so much, something, he thought, might come from that quarter.
2574 
2575 It was by no means his daughter's wish that the intellects of
2576 Highbury in general should be put under requisition.  Mr. Elton
2577 was the only one whose assistance she asked.  He was invited
2578 to contribute any really good enigmas, charades, or conundrums
2579 that he might recollect; and she had the pleasure of seeing him
2580 most intently at work with his recollections; and at the same time,
2581 as she could perceive, most earnestly careful that nothing ungallant,
2582 nothing that did not breathe a compliment to the sex should pass
2583 his lips.  They owed to him their two or three politest puzzles;
2584 and the joy and exultation with which at last he recalled,
2585 and rather sentimentally recited, that well-known charade,
2586 
2587     My first doth affliction denote,
2588       Which my second is destin'd to feel
2589     And my whole is the best antidote
2590       That affliction to soften and heal.--
2591 
2592 made her quite sorry to acknowledge that they had transcribed it
2593 some pages ago already.
2594 
2595 "Why will not you write one yourself for us, Mr. Elton?" said she;
2596 "that is the only security for its freshness; and nothing could be
2597 easier to you."
2598 
2599 "Oh no! he had never written, hardly ever, any thing of the kind
2600 in his life.  The stupidest fellow! He was afraid not even Miss
2601 Woodhouse"--he stopt a moment--"or Miss Smith could inspire him."
2602 
2603 The very next day however produced some proof of inspiration.
2604 He called for a few moments, just to leave a piece of paper on the
2605 table containing, as he said, a charade, which a friend of his had
2606 addressed to a young lady, the object of his admiration, but which,
2607 from his manner, Emma was immediately convinced must be his own.
2608 
2609 "I do not offer it for Miss Smith's collection," said he.
2610 "Being my friend's, I have no right to expose it in any degree
2611 to the public eye, but perhaps you may not dislike looking at it."
2612 
2613 The speech was more to Emma than to Harriet, which Emma
2614 could understand.  There was deep consciousness about him,
2615 and he found it easier to meet her eye than her friend's.
2616 He was gone the next moment:--after another moment's pause,
2617 
2618 "Take it," said Emma, smiling, and pushing the paper towards
2619 Harriet--"it is for you.  Take your own."
2620 
2621 But Harriet was in a tremor, and could not touch it; and Emma,
2622 never loth to be first, was obliged to examine it herself.
2623 
2624         To Miss--
2625 
2626           CHARADE.
2627 
2628     My first displays the wealth and pomp of kings,
2629       Lords of the earth! their luxury and ease.
2630     Another view of man, my second brings,
2631       Behold him there, the monarch of the seas!
2632 
2633     But ah! united, what reverse we have!
2634       Man's boasted power and freedom, all are flown;
2635     Lord of the earth and sea, he bends a slave,
2636       And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.
2637 
2638       Thy ready wit the word will soon supply,
2639       May its approval beam in that soft eye!
2640 
2641 She cast her eye over it, pondered, caught the meaning, read it through
2642 again to be quite certain, and quite mistress of the lines, and then
2643 passing it to Harriet, sat happily smiling, and saying to herself,
2644 while Harriet was puzzling over the paper in all the confusion
2645 of hope and dulness, "Very well, Mr. Elton, very well indeed.
2646 I have read worse charades.  _Courtship_--a very good hint.  I give
2647 you credit for it.  This is feeling your way.  This is saying very
2648 plainly--`Pray, Miss Smith, give me leave to pay my addresses to you.
2649 Approve my charade and my intentions in the same glance.'
2650 
2651       May its approval beam in that soft eye!
2652 
2653 Harriet exactly.  Soft is the very word for her eye--of all epithets,
2654 the justest that could be given.
2655 
2656       Thy ready wit the word will soon supply.
2657 
2658 Humph--Harriet's ready wit! All the better.  A man must be very much
2659 in love, indeed, to describe her so.  Ah! Mr. Knightley, I wish
2660 you had the benefit of this; I think this would convince you.
2661 For once in your life you would be obliged to own yourself mistaken.
2662 An excellent charade indeed! and very much to the purpose.
2663 Things must come to a crisis soon now.
2664 
2665 She was obliged to break off from these very pleasant observations,
2666 which were otherwise of a sort to run into great length, by the
2667 eagerness of Harriet's wondering questions.
2668 
2669 "What can it be, Miss Woodhouse?--what can it be? I have not an idea--I
2670 cannot guess it in the least.  What can it possibly be? Do try
2671 to find it out, Miss Woodhouse.  Do help me.  I never saw any thing
2672 so hard.  Is it kingdom? I wonder who the friend was--and who could
2673 be the young lady.  Do you think it is a good one? Can it be woman?
2674 
2675       And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.
2676 
2677 Can it be Neptune?
2678 
2679       Behold him there, the monarch of the seas!
2680 
2681 Or a trident? or a mermaid? or a shark? Oh, no! shark is only
2682 one syllable.  It must be very clever, or he would not have brought it.
2683 Oh! Miss Woodhouse, do you think we shall ever find it out?"
2684 
2685 "Mermaids and sharks! Nonsense! My dear Harriet, what are you
2686 thinking of? Where would be the use of his bringing us a charade made
2687 by a friend upon a mermaid or a shark? Give me the paper and listen.
2688 
2689 For Miss ----------, read Miss Smith.
2690 
2691     My first displays the wealth and pomp of kings,
2692       Lords of the earth! their luxury and ease.
2693 
2694 That is _court_.
2695 
2696     Another view of man, my second brings;
2697       Behold him there, the monarch of the seas!
2698 
2699 That is _ship_;--plain as it can be.--Now for the cream.
2700 
2701     But ah! united, (_courtship_, you know,) what reverse we have!
2702       Man's boasted power and freedom, all are flown.
2703     Lord of the earth and sea, he bends a slave,
2704       And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.
2705 
2706 A very proper compliment!--and then follows the application,
2707 which I think, my dear Harriet, you cannot find much difficulty
2708 in comprehending.  Read it in comfort to yourself.  There can
2709 be no doubt of its being written for you and to you."
2710 
2711 Harriet could not long resist so delightful a persuasion.
2712 She read the concluding lines, and was all flutter and happiness.
2713 She could not speak.  But she was not wanted to speak.  It was enough
2714 for her to feel.  Emma spoke for her.
2715 
2716 "There is so pointed, and so particular a meaning in this compliment,"
2717 said she, "that I cannot have a doubt as to Mr. Elton's intentions.
2718 You are his object--and you will soon receive the completest proof
2719 of it.  I thought it must be so.  I thought I could not be so deceived;
2720 but now, it is clear; the state of his mind is as clear and decided,
2721 as my wishes on the subject have been ever since I knew you.
2722 Yes, Harriet, just so long have I been wanting the very circumstance
2723 to happen what has happened.  I could never tell whether an attachment
2724 between you and Mr. Elton were most desirable or most natural.
2725 Its probability and its eligibility have really so equalled each
2726 other! I am very happy.  I congratulate you, my dear Harriet, with all
2727 my heart.  This is an attachment which a woman may well feel pride
2728 in creating.  This is a connexion which offers nothing but good.
2729 It will give you every thing that you want--consideration, independence,
2730 a proper home--it will fix you in the centre of all your real friends,
2731 close to Hartfield and to me, and confirm our intimacy for ever.
2732 This, Harriet, is an alliance which can never raise a blush in either
2733 of us."
2734 
2735 "Dear Miss Woodhouse!"--and "Dear Miss Woodhouse," was all that Harriet,
2736 with many tender embraces could articulate at first; but when they
2737 did arrive at something more like conversation, it was sufficiently
2738 clear to her friend that she saw, felt, anticipated, and remembered
2739 just as she ought.  Mr. Elton's superiority had very ample acknowledgment.
2740 
2741 "Whatever you say is always right," cried Harriet, "and therefore
2742 I suppose, and believe, and hope it must be so; but otherwise I could
2743 not have imagined it.  It is so much beyond any thing I deserve.
2744 Mr. Elton, who might marry any body! There cannot be two opinions
2745 about _him_.  He is so very superior.  Only think of those sweet
2746 verses--`To Miss --------.' Dear me, how clever!--Could it really
2747 be meant for me?"
2748 
2749 "I cannot make a question, or listen to a question about that.
2750 It is a certainty.  Receive it on my judgment.  It is a sort
2751 of prologue to the play, a motto to the chapter; and will be soon
2752 followed by matter-of-fact prose."
2753 
2754 "It is a sort of thing which nobody could have expected.  I am sure,
2755 a month ago, I had no more idea myself!--The strangest things do
2756 take place!"
2757 
2758 "When Miss Smiths and Mr. Eltons get acquainted--they do indeed--and
2759 really it is strange; it is out of the common course that what is
2760 so evidently, so palpably desirable--what courts the pre-arrangement
2761 of other people, should so immediately shape itself into the proper form.
2762 You and Mr. Elton are by situation called together; you belong
2763 to one another by every circumstance of your respective homes.
2764 Your marrying will be equal to the match at Randalls.  There does
2765 seem to be a something in the air of Hartfield which gives love
2766 exactly the right direction, and sends it into the very channel
2767 where it ought to flow.
2768 
2769       The course of true love never did run smooth--
2770 
2771 A Hartfield edition of Shakespeare would have a long note on that passage."
2772 
2773 "That Mr. Elton should really be in love with me,--me, of all people,
2774 who did not know him, to speak to him, at Michaelmas! And he,
2775 the very handsomest man that ever was, and a man that every body
2776 looks up to, quite like Mr. Knightley! His company so sought after,
2777 that every body says he need not eat a single meal by himself if he
2778 does not chuse it; that he has more invitations than there are days
2779 in the week.  And so excellent in the Church! Miss Nash has put down
2780 all the texts he has ever preached from since he came to Highbury.
2781 Dear me! When I look back to the first time I saw him! How little
2782 did I think!--The two Abbots and I ran into the front room and
2783 peeped through the blind when we heard he was going by, and Miss
2784 Nash came and scolded us away, and staid to look through herself;
2785 however, she called me back presently, and let me look too,
2786 which was very good-natured. And how beautiful we thought he looked!
2787 He was arm-in-arm with Mr. Cole."
2788 
2789 "This is an alliance which, whoever--whatever your friends may be,
2790 must be agreeable to them, provided at least they have common sense;
2791 and we are not to be addressing our conduct to fools.  If they
2792 are anxious to see you _happily_ married, here is a man whose amiable
2793 character gives every assurance of it;--if they wish to have you
2794 settled in the same country and circle which they have chosen
2795 to place you in, here it will be accomplished; and if their only
2796 object is that you should, in the common phrase, be _well_ married,
2797 here is the comfortable fortune, the respectable establishment,
2798 the rise in the world which must satisfy them."
2799 
2800 "Yes, very true.  How nicely you talk; I love to hear you.
2801 You understand every thing.  You and Mr. Elton are one as clever
2802 as the other.  This charade!--If I had studied a twelvemonth,
2803 I could never have made any thing like it."
2804 
2805 "I thought he meant to try his skill, by his manner of declining
2806 it yesterday."
2807 
2808 "I do think it is, without exception, the best charade I ever read."
2809 
2810 "I never read one more to the purpose, certainly."
2811 
2812 "It is as long again as almost all we have had before."
2813 
2814 "I do not consider its length as particularly in its favour.
2815 Such things in general cannot be too short."
2816 
2817 Harriet was too intent on the lines to hear.  The most satisfactory
2818 comparisons were rising in her mind.
2819 
2820 "It is one thing," said she, presently--her cheeks in a glow--"to
2821 have very good sense in a common way, like every body else,
2822 and if there is any thing to say, to sit down and write a letter,
2823 and say just what you must, in a short way; and another, to write
2824 verses and charades like this."
2825 
2826 Emma could not have desired a more spirited rejection of Mr. Martin's prose.
2827 
2828 "Such sweet lines!" continued Harriet--"these two last!--But
2829 how shall I ever be able to return the paper, or say I have found
2830 it out?--Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what can we do about that?"
2831 
2832 "Leave it to me.  You do nothing.  He will be here this evening,
2833 I dare say, and then I will give it him back, and some nonsense
2834 or other will pass between us, and you shall not be committed.--Your
2835 soft eyes shall chuse their own time for beaming.  Trust to me."
2836 
2837 "Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what a pity that I must not write this beautiful
2838 charade into my book! I am sure I have not got one half so good."
2839 
2840 "Leave out the two last lines, and there is no reason why you
2841 should not write it into your book."
2842 
2843 "Oh! but those two lines are"--
2844 
2845 --"The best of all.  Granted;--for private enjoyment; and for private
2846 enjoyment keep them.  They are not at all the less written you know,
2847 because you divide them.  The couplet does not cease to be, nor does
2848 its meaning change.  But take it away, and all _appropriation_ ceases,
2849 and a very pretty gallant charade remains, fit for any collection.
2850 Depend upon it, he would not like to have his charade slighted,
2851 much better than his passion.  A poet in love must be encouraged in
2852 both capacities, or neither.  Give me the book, I will write it down,
2853 and then there can be no possible reflection on you."
2854 
2855 Harriet submitted, though her mind could hardly separate the parts,
2856 so as to feel quite sure that her friend were not writing down
2857 a declaration of love.  It seemed too precious an offering for any
2858 degree of publicity.
2859 
2860 "I shall never let that book go out of my own hands," said she.
2861 
2862 "Very well," replied Emma; "a most natural feeling; and the longer
2863 it lasts, the better I shall be pleased.  But here is my father
2864 coming: you will not object to my reading the charade to him.
2865 It will be giving him so much pleasure! He loves any thing of
2866 the sort, and especially any thing that pays woman a compliment.
2867 He has the tenderest spirit of gallantry towards us all!--You must
2868 let me read it to him."
2869 
2870 Harriet looked grave.
2871 
2872 "My dear Harriet, you must not refine too much upon this
2873 charade.--You will betray your feelings improperly, if you are
2874 too conscious and too quick, and appear to affix more meaning,
2875 or even quite all the meaning which may be affixed to it.
2876 Do not be overpowered by such a little tribute of admiration.
2877 If he had been anxious for secrecy, he would not have left the paper
2878 while I was by; but he rather pushed it towards me than towards you.
2879 Do not let us be too solemn on the business.  He has encouragement
2880 enough to proceed, without our sighing out our souls over this charade."
2881 
2882 "Oh! no--I hope I shall not be ridiculous about it.  Do as you please."
2883 
2884 Mr. Woodhouse came in, and very soon led to the subject again,
2885 by the recurrence of his very frequent inquiry of "Well, my dears,
2886 how does your book go on?--Have you got any thing fresh?"
2887 
2888 "Yes, papa; we have something to read you, something quite fresh.
2889 A piece of paper was found on the table this morning--(dropt,
2890 we suppose, by a fairy)--containing a very pretty charade, and we
2891 have just copied it in."
2892 
2893 She read it to him, just as he liked to have any thing read,
2894 slowly and distinctly, and two or three times over, with explanations
2895 of every part as she proceeded--and he was very much pleased, and,
2896 as she had foreseen, especially struck with the complimentary conclusion.
2897 
2898 "Aye, that's very just, indeed, that's very properly said.
2899 Very true.  `Woman, lovely woman.' It is such a pretty charade,
2900 my dear, that I can easily guess what fairy brought it.--Nobody
2901 could have written so prettily, but you, Emma."
2902 
2903 Emma only nodded, and smiled.--After a little thinking,
2904 and a very tender sigh, he added,
2905 
2906 "Ah! it is no difficulty to see who you take after! Your dear mother
2907 was so clever at all those things! If I had but her memory! But I
2908 can remember nothing;--not even that particular riddle which you
2909 have heard me mention; I can only recollect the first stanza;
2910 and there are several.
2911 
2912     Kitty, a fair but frozen maid,
2913       Kindled a flame I yet deplore,
2914     The hood-wink'd boy I called to aid,
2915     Though of his near approach afraid,
2916       So fatal to my suit before.
2917 
2918 And that is all that I can recollect of it--but it is very clever
2919 all the way through.  But I think, my dear, you said you had got it."
2920 
2921 "Yes, papa, it is written out in our second page.  We copied it
2922 from the Elegant Extracts.  It was Garrick's, you know."
2923 
2924 "Aye, very true.--I wish I could recollect more of it.
2925 
2926     Kitty, a fair but frozen maid.
2927 
2928 The name makes me think of poor Isabella; for she was very near
2929 being christened Catherine after her grandmama.  I hope we shall
2930 have her here next week.  Have you thought, my dear, where you
2931 shall put her--and what room there will be for the children?"
2932 
2933 "Oh! yes--she will have her own room, of course; the room she always
2934 has;--and there is the nursery for the children,--just as usual,
2935 you know.  Why should there be any change?"
2936 
2937 "I do not know, my dear--but it is so long since she was here!--not
2938 since last Easter, and then only for a few days.--Mr. John Knightley's
2939 being a lawyer is very inconvenient.--Poor Isabella!--she is sadly
2940 taken away from us all!--and how sorry she will be when she comes,
2941 not to see Miss Taylor here!"
2942 
2943 "She will not be surprized, papa, at least."
2944 
2945 "I do not know, my dear.  I am sure I was very much surprized
2946 when I first heard she was going to be married."
2947 
2948 "We must ask Mr. and Mrs. Weston to dine with us, while Isabella
2949 is here."
2950 
2951 "Yes, my dear, if there is time.--But--(in a very depressed tone)--she
2952 is coming for only one week.  There will not be time for any thing."
2953 
2954 "It is unfortunate that they cannot stay longer--but it seems a case
2955 of necessity.  Mr. John Knightley must be in town again on the 28th,
2956 and we ought to be thankful, papa, that we are to have the whole
2957 of the time they can give to the country, that two or three days
2958 are not to be taken out for the Abbey.  Mr. Knightley promises
2959 to give up his claim this Christmas--though you know it is longer
2960 since they were with him, than with us."
2961 
2962 "It would be very hard, indeed, my dear, if poor Isabella were
2963 to be anywhere but at Hartfield."
2964 
2965 Mr. Woodhouse could never allow for Mr. Knightley's claims on
2966 his brother, or any body's claims on Isabella, except his own.
2967 He sat musing a little while, and then said,
2968 
2969 "But I do not see why poor Isabella should be obliged to go back
2970 so soon, though he does.  I think, Emma, I shall try and persuade
2971 her to stay longer with us.  She and the children might stay very well."
2972 
2973 "Ah! papa--that is what you never have been able to accomplish,
2974 and I do not think you ever will.  Isabella cannot bear to stay
2975 behind her husband."
2976 
2977 This was too true for contradiction.  Unwelcome as it was, Mr. Woodhouse
2978 could only give a submissive sigh; and as Emma saw his spirits
2979 affected by the idea of his daughter's attachment to her husband,
2980 she immediately led to such a branch of the subject as must raise them.
2981 
2982 "Harriet must give us as much of her company as she can while
2983 my brother and sister are here.  I am sure she will be pleased
2984 with the children.  We are very proud of the children, are not we,
2985 papa? I wonder which she will think the handsomest, Henry or John?"
2986 
2987 "Aye, I wonder which she will.  Poor little dears, how glad they
2988 will be to come.  They are very fond of being at Hartfield, Harriet."
2989 
2990 "I dare say they are, sir.  I am sure I do not know who is not."
2991 
2992 "Henry is a fine boy, but John is very like his mama.  Henry is the eldest,
2993 he was named after me, not after his father.  John, the second,
2994 is named after his father.  Some people are surprized, I believe,
2995 that the eldest was not, but Isabella would have him called Henry,
2996 which I thought very pretty of her.  And he is a very clever boy,
2997 indeed.  They are all remarkably clever; and they have so many
2998 pretty ways.  They will come and stand by my chair, and say,
2999 `Grandpapa, can you give me a bit of string?' and once Henry asked me
3000 for a knife, but I told him knives were only made for grandpapas.
3001 I think their father is too rough with them very often."
3002 
3003 "He appears rough to you," said Emma, "because you are so very
3004 gentle yourself; but if you could compare him with other papas,
3005 you would not think him rough.  He wishes his boys to be active and hardy;
3006 and if they misbehave, can give them a sharp word now and then;
3007 but he is an affectionate father--certainly Mr. John Knightley
3008 is an affectionate father.  The children are all fond of him."
3009 
3010 "And then their uncle comes in, and tosses them up to the ceiling
3011 in a very frightful way!"
3012 
3013 "But they like it, papa; there is nothing they like so much.
