3014 It is such enjoyment to them, that if their uncle did not lay down
3015 the rule of their taking turns, whichever began would never give way
3016 to the other."
3017 
3018 "Well, I cannot understand it."
3019 
3020 "That is the case with us all, papa.  One half of the world cannot
3021 understand the pleasures of the other."
3022 
3023 Later in the morning, and just as the girls were going to separate
3024 in preparation for the regular four o'clock dinner, the hero
3025 of this inimitable charade walked in again.  Harriet turned away;
3026 but Emma could receive him with the usual smile, and her quick eye
3027 soon discerned in his the consciousness of having made a push--of
3028 having thrown a die; and she imagined he was come to see how it
3029 might turn up.  His ostensible reason, however, was to ask whether
3030 Mr. Woodhouse's party could be made up in the evening without him,
3031 or whether he should be in the smallest degree necessary at Hartfield.
3032 If he were, every thing else must give way; but otherwise his friend
3033 Cole had been saying so much about his dining with him--had made
3034 such a point of it, that he had promised him conditionally to come.
3035 
3036 Emma thanked him, but could not allow of his disappointing his
3037 friend on their account; her father was sure of his rubber.
3038 He re-urged--she re-declined; and he seemed then about to make
3039 his bow, when taking the paper from the table, she returned it--
3040 
3041 "Oh! here is the charade you were so obliging as to leave with us;
3042 thank you for the sight of it.  We admired it so much, that I have
3043 ventured to write it into Miss Smith's collection.  Your friend
3044 will not take it amiss I hope.  Of course I have not transcribed
3045 beyond the first eight lines."
3046 
3047 Mr. Elton certainly did not very well know what to say.
3048 He looked rather doubtingly--rather confused; said something about
3049 "honour,"--glanced at Emma and at Harriet, and then seeing the book
3050 open on the table, took it up, and examined it very attentively.
3051 With the view of passing off an awkward moment, Emma smilingly said,
3052 
3053 "You must make my apologies to your friend; but so good a charade
3054 must not be confined to one or two.  He may be sure of every woman's
3055 approbation while he writes with such gallantry."
3056 
3057 "I have no hesitation in saying," replied Mr. Elton, though hesitating
3058 a good deal while he spoke; "I have no hesitation in saying--at
3059 least if my friend feels at all as _I_ do--I have not the smallest
3060 doubt that, could he see his little effusion honoured as _I_ see it,
3061 (looking at the book again, and replacing it on the table), he
3062 would consider it as the proudest moment of his life."
3063 
3064 After this speech he was gone as soon as possible.  Emma could not
3065 think it too soon; for with all his good and agreeable qualities,
3066 there was a sort of parade in his speeches which was very apt
3067 to incline her to laugh.  She ran away to indulge the inclination,
3068 leaving the tender and the sublime of pleasure to Harriet's share.
3069 
3070 
3071 
3072 CHAPTER X
3073 
3074 
3075 Though now the middle of December, there had yet been no weather
3076 to prevent the young ladies from tolerably regular exercise;
3077 and on the morrow, Emma had a charitable visit to pay to a poor
3078 sick family, who lived a little way out of Highbury.
3079 
3080 Their road to this detached cottage was down Vicarage Lane, a lane
3081 leading at right angles from the broad, though irregular, main street
3082 of the place; and, as may be inferred, containing the blessed abode
3083 of Mr. Elton.  A few inferior dwellings were first to be passed,
3084 and then, about a quarter of a mile down the lane rose the Vicarage,
3085 an old and not very good house, almost as close to the road as it
3086 could be.  It had no advantage of situation; but had been very much
3087 smartened up by the present proprietor; and, such as it was,
3088 there could be no possibility of the two friends passing it without
3089 a slackened pace and observing eyes.--Emma's remark was--
3090 
3091 "There it is.  There go you and your riddle-book one of these days."--
3092 Harriet's was--
3093 
3094 "Oh, what a sweet house!--How very beautiful!--There are the yellow
3095 curtains that Miss Nash admires so much."
3096 
3097 "I do not often walk this way _now_," said Emma, as they proceeded,
3098 "but _then_ there will be an inducement, and I shall gradually get
3099 intimately acquainted with all the hedges, gates, pools and pollards
3100 of this part of Highbury."
3101 
3102 Harriet, she found, had never in her life been within side the Vicarage,
3103 and her curiosity to see it was so extreme, that, considering exteriors
3104 and probabilities, Emma could only class it, as a proof of love,
3105 with Mr. Elton's seeing ready wit in her.
3106 
3107 "I wish we could contrive it," said she; "but I cannot think
3108 of any tolerable pretence for going in;--no servant that I want
3109 to inquire about of his housekeeper--no message from my father."
3110 
3111 She pondered, but could think of nothing.  After a mutual silence
3112 of some minutes, Harriet thus began again--
3113 
3114 "I do so wonder, Miss Woodhouse, that you should not be married,
3115 or going to be married! so charming as you are!"--
3116 
3117 Emma laughed, and replied,
3118 
3119 "My being charming, Harriet, is not quite enough to induce me to marry;
3120 I must find other people charming--one other person at least.
3121 And I am not only, not going to be married, at present, but have
3122 very little intention of ever marrying at all."
3123 
3124 "Ah!--so you say; but I cannot believe it."
3125 
3126 "I must see somebody very superior to any one I have seen yet,
3127 to be tempted; Mr. Elton, you know, (recollecting herself,)
3128 is out of the question:  and I do _not_ wish to see any such person.
3129 I would rather not be tempted.  I cannot really change for the better.
3130 If I were to marry, I must expect to repent it."
3131 
3132 "Dear me!--it is so odd to hear a woman talk so!"--
3133 
3134 "I have none of the usual inducements of women to marry.
3135 Were I to fall in love, indeed, it would be a different thing!
3136 but I never have been in love; it is not my way, or my nature;
3137 and I do not think I ever shall.  And, without love, I am sure I
3138 should be a fool to change such a situation as mine.  Fortune I
3139 do not want; employment I do not want; consequence I do not want:
3140 I believe few married women are half as much mistress of their
3141 husband's house as I am of Hartfield; and never, never could I expect
3142 to be so truly beloved and important; so always first and always
3143 right in any man's eyes as I am in my father's."
3144 
3145 "But then, to be an old maid at last, like Miss Bates!"
3146 
3147 "That is as formidable an image as you could present, Harriet; and if I
3148 thought I should ever be like Miss Bates! so silly--so satisfied--
3149 so smiling--so prosing--so undistinguishing and unfastidious--
3150 and so apt to tell every thing relative to every body about me,
3151 I would marry to-morrow. But between _us_, I am convinced there never
3152 can be any likeness, except in being unmarried."
3153 
3154 "But still, you will be an old maid! and that's so dreadful!"
3155 
3156 "Never mind, Harriet, I shall not be a poor old maid; and it is
3157 poverty only which makes celibacy contemptible to a generous public!
3158 A single woman, with a very narrow income, must be a ridiculous,
3159 disagreeable old maid! the proper sport of boys and girls,
3160 but a single woman, of good fortune, is always respectable,
3161 and may be as sensible and pleasant as any body else.  And the
3162 distinction is not quite so much against the candour and common
3163 sense of the world as appears at first; for a very narrow income
3164 has a tendency to contract the mind, and sour the temper.
3165 Those who can barely live, and who live perforce in a very small,
3166 and generally very inferior, society, may well be illiberal and cross.
3167 This does not apply, however, to Miss Bates; she is only too good
3168 natured and too silly to suit me; but, in general, she is very
3169 much to the taste of every body, though single and though poor.
3170 Poverty certainly has not contracted her mind:  I really believe,
3171 if she had only a shilling in the world, she would be very likely
3172 to give away sixpence of it; and nobody is afraid of her:  that is a
3173 great charm."
3174 
3175 "Dear me! but what shall you do? how shall you employ yourself
3176 when you grow old?"
3177 
3178 "If I know myself, Harriet, mine is an active, busy mind, with a great
3179 many independent resources; and I do not perceive why I should be
3180 more in want of employment at forty or fifty than one-and-twenty.
3181 Woman's usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to me then
3182 as they are now; or with no important variation.  If I draw less,
3183 I shall read more; if I give up music, I shall take to carpet-work.
3184 And as for objects of interest, objects for the affections,
3185 which is in truth the great point of inferiority, the want of which
3186 is really the great evil to be avoided in _not_ marrying, I shall
3187 be very well off, with all the children of a sister I love so much,
3188 to care about.  There will be enough of them, in all probability,
3189 to supply every sort of sensation that declining life can need.
3190 There will be enough for every hope and every fear; and though my
3191 attachment to none can equal that of a parent, it suits my ideas
3192 of comfort better than what is warmer and blinder.  My nephews
3193 and nieces!--I shall often have a niece with me."
3194 
3195 "Do you know Miss Bates's niece?  That is, I know you must have
3196 seen her a hundred times--but are you acquainted?"
3197 
3198 "Oh! yes; we are always forced to be acquainted whenever she comes
3199 to Highbury.  By the bye, _that_ is almost enough to put one out
3200 of conceit with a niece.  Heaven forbid! at least, that I should
3201 ever bore people half so much about all the Knightleys together,
3202 as she does about Jane Fairfax.  One is sick of the very name
3203 of Jane Fairfax.  Every letter from her is read forty times over;
3204 her compliments to all friends go round and round again; and if she
3205 does but send her aunt the pattern of a stomacher, or knit a pair
3206 of garters for her grandmother, one hears of nothing else for a month.
3207 I wish Jane Fairfax very well; but she tires me to death."
3208 
3209 They were now approaching the cottage, and all idle topics
3210 were superseded.  Emma was very compassionate; and the distresses
3211 of the poor were as sure of relief from her personal attention
3212 and kindness, her counsel and her patience, as from her purse.
3213 She understood their ways, could allow for their ignorance and
3214 their temptations, had no romantic expectations of extraordinary
3215 virtue from those for whom education had done so little; entered into
3216 their troubles with ready sympathy, and always gave her assistance
3217 with as much intelligence as good-will.  In the present instance,
3218 it was sickness and poverty together which she came to visit;
3219 and after remaining there as long as she could give comfort or advice,
3220 she quitted the cottage with such an impression of the scene
3221 as made her say to Harriet, as they walked away,
3222 
3223 "These are the sights, Harriet, to do one good.  How trifling they
3224 make every thing else appear!--I feel now as if I could think of
3225 nothing but these poor creatures all the rest of the day; and yet,
3226 who can say how soon it may all vanish from my mind?"
3227 
3228 "Very true," said Harriet.  "Poor creatures! one can think
3229 of nothing else."
3230 
3231 "And really, I do not think the impression will soon be over,"
3232 said Emma, as she crossed the low hedge, and tottering footstep
3233 which ended the narrow, slippery path through the cottage garden,
3234 and brought them into the lane again.  "I do not think it will,"
3235 stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of the place,
3236 and recall the still greater within.
3237 
3238 "Oh! dear, no," said her companion.
3239 
3240 They walked on.  The lane made a slight bend; and when that bend
3241 was passed, Mr. Elton was immediately in sight; and so near
3242 as to give Emma time only to say farther,
3243 
3244 "Ah!  Harriet, here comes a very sudden trial of our stability
3245 in good thoughts.  Well, (smiling,) I hope it may be allowed that
3246 if compassion has produced exertion and relief to the sufferers,
3247 it has done all that is truly important.  If we feel for the wretched,
3248 enough to do all we can for them, the rest is empty sympathy,
3249 only distressing to ourselves."
3250 
3251 Harriet could just answer, "Oh! dear, yes," before the gentleman
3252 joined them.  The wants and sufferings of the poor family, however,
3253 were the first subject on meeting.  He had been going to call
3254 on them.  His visit he would now defer; but they had a very
3255 interesting parley about what could be done and should be done.
3256 Mr. Elton then turned back to accompany them.
3257 
3258 "To fall in with each other on such an errand as this," thought Emma;
3259 "to meet in a charitable scheme; this will bring a great increase
3260 of love on each side.  I should not wonder if it were to bring
3261 on the declaration.  It must, if I were not here.  I wish I were
3262 anywhere else."
3263 
3264 Anxious to separate herself from them as far as she could, she soon
3265 afterwards took possession of a narrow footpath, a little raised
3266 on one side of the lane, leaving them together in the main road.
3267 But she had not been there two minutes when she found that Harriet's
3268 habits of dependence and imitation were bringing her up too, and that,
3269 in short, they would both be soon after her.  This would not do;
3270 she immediately stopped, under pretence of having some alteration
3271 to make in the lacing of her half-boot, and stooping down in complete
3272 occupation of the footpath, begged them to have the goodness to walk on,
3273 and she would follow in half a minute.  They did as they were desired;
3274 and by the time she judged it reasonable to have done with her boot,
3275 she had the comfort of farther delay in her power, being overtaken
3276 by a child from the cottage, setting out, according to orders,
3277 with her pitcher, to fetch broth from Hartfield.  To walk by the side
3278 of this child, and talk to and question her, was the most natural
3279 thing in the world, or would have been the most natural, had she been
3280 acting just then without design; and by this means the others were
3281 still able to keep ahead, without any obligation of waiting for her.
3282 She gained on them, however, involuntarily:  the child's pace was quick,
3283 and theirs rather slow; and she was the more concerned at it,
3284 from their being evidently in a conversation which interested them.
3285 Mr. Elton was speaking with animation, Harriet listening with a very
3286 pleased attention; and Emma, having sent the child on, was beginning
3287 to think how she might draw back a little more, when they both
3288 looked around, and she was obliged to join them.
3289 
3290 Mr. Elton was still talking, still engaged in some interesting detail;
3291 and Emma experienced some disappointment when she found that he
3292 was only giving his fair companion an account of the yesterday's
3293 party at his friend Cole's, and that she was come in herself for
3294 the Stilton cheese, the north Wiltshire, the butter, the cellery,
3295 the beet-root, and all the dessert.
3296 
3297 "This would soon have led to something better, of course," was her
3298 consoling reflection; "any thing interests between those who love;
3299 and any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart.
3300 If I could but have kept longer away!"
3301 
3302 They now walked on together quietly, till within view of the vicarage
3303 pales, when a sudden resolution, of at least getting Harriet into
3304 the house, made her again find something very much amiss about her boot,
3305 and fall behind to arrange it once more.  She then broke the lace
3306 off short, and dexterously throwing it into a ditch, was presently
3307 obliged to entreat them to stop, and acknowledged her inability to
3308 put herself to rights so as to be able to walk home in tolerable comfort.
3309 
3310 "Part of my lace is gone," said she, "and I do not know how I am
3311 to contrive.  I really am a most troublesome companion to you both,
3312 but I hope I am not often so ill-equipped. Mr. Elton, I must beg
3313 leave to stop at your house, and ask your housekeeper for a bit
3314 of ribband or string, or any thing just to keep my boot on."
3315 
3316 Mr. Elton looked all happiness at this proposition; and nothing
3317 could exceed his alertness and attention in conducting them into
3318 his house and endeavouring to make every thing appear to advantage.
3319 The room they were taken into was the one he chiefly occupied,
3320 and looking forwards; behind it was another with which it immediately
3321 communicated; the door between them was open, and Emma passed
3322 into it with the housekeeper to receive her assistance in the most
3323 comfortable manner.  She was obliged to leave the door ajar as she
3324 found it; but she fully intended that Mr. Elton should close it.
3325 It was not closed, however, it still remained ajar; but by engaging
3326 the housekeeper in incessant conversation, she hoped to make it
3327 practicable for him to chuse his own subject in the adjoining room.
3328 For ten minutes she could hear nothing but herself.  It could
3329 be protracted no longer.  She was then obliged to be finished,
3330 and make her appearance.
3331 
3332 The lovers were standing together at one of the windows.  It had a
3333 most favourable aspect; and, for half a minute, Emma felt the glory
3334 of having schemed successfully.  But it would not do; he had not
3335 come to the point.  He had been most agreeable, most delightful;
3336 he had told Harriet that he had seen them go by, and had purposely
3337 followed them; other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt,
3338 but nothing serious.
3339 
3340 "Cautious, very cautious," thought Emma; "he advances inch by inch,
3341 and will hazard nothing till he believes himself secure."
3342 
3343 Still, however, though every thing had not been accomplished
3344 by her ingenious device, she could not but flatter herself
3345 that it had been the occasion of much present enjoyment to both,
3346 and must be leading them forward to the great event.
3347 
3348 
3349 
3350 CHAPTER XI
3351 
3352 
3353 Mr. Elton must now be left to himself.  It was no longer in Emma's
3354 power to superintend his happiness or quicken his measures.
3355 The coming of her sister's family was so very near at hand,
3356 that first in anticipation, and then in reality, it became henceforth
3357 her prime object of interest; and during the ten days of their stay
3358 at Hartfield it was not to be expected--she did not herself expect--
3359 that any thing beyond occasional, fortuitous assistance could
3360 be afforded by her to the lovers.  They might advance rapidly
3361 if they would, however; they must advance somehow or other whether
3362 they would or no.  She hardly wished to have more leisure for them.
3363 There are people, who the more you do for them, the less they will
3364 do for themselves.
3365 
3366 Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, from having been longer than usual
3367 absent from Surry, were exciting of course rather more than the
3368 usual interest.  Till this year, every long vacation since their
3369 marriage had been divided between Hartfield and Donwell Abbey;
3370 but all the holidays of this autumn had been given to sea-bathing
3371 for the children, and it was therefore many months since they had
3372 been seen in a regular way by their Surry connexions, or seen at all
3373 by Mr. Woodhouse, who could not be induced to get so far as London,
3374 even for poor Isabella's sake; and who consequently was now most
3375 nervously and apprehensively happy in forestalling this too short visit.
3376 
3377 He thought much of the evils of the journey for her, and not a
3378 little of the fatigues of his own horses and coachman who were to
3379 bring some of the party the last half of the way; but his alarms
3380 were needless; the sixteen miles being happily accomplished,
3381 and Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, their five children, and a competent
3382 number of nursery-maids, all reaching Hartfield in safety.
3383 The bustle and joy of such an arrival, the many to be talked to,
3384 welcomed, encouraged, and variously dispersed and disposed of,
3385 produced a noise and confusion which his nerves could not have borne
3386 under any other cause, nor have endured much longer even for this;
3387 but the ways of Hartfield and the feelings of her father were
3388 so respected by Mrs. John Knightley, that in spite of maternal
3389 solicitude for the immediate enjoyment of her little ones,
3390 and for their having instantly all the liberty and attendance,
3391 all the eating and drinking, and sleeping and playing,
3392 which they could possibly wish for, without the smallest delay,
3393 the children were never allowed to be long a disturbance to him,
3394 either in themselves or in any restless attendance on them.
3395 
3396 Mrs. John Knightley was a pretty, elegant little woman, of gentle,
3397 quiet manners, and a disposition remarkably amiable and affectionate;
3398 wrapt up in her family; a devoted wife, a doating mother,
3399 and so tenderly attached to her father and sister that, but for
3400 these higher ties, a warmer love might have seemed impossible.
3401 She could never see a fault in any of them.  She was not a woman
3402 of strong understanding or any quickness; and with this resemblance
3403 of her father, she inherited also much of his constitution;
3404 was delicate in her own health, over-careful of that of her children,
3405 had many fears and many nerves, and was as fond of her own Mr. Wingfield
3406 in town as her father could be of Mr. Perry.  They were alike too,
3407 in a general benevolence of temper, and a strong habit of regard
3408 for every old acquaintance.
3409 
3410 Mr. John Knightley was a tall, gentleman-like, and very clever man;
3411 rising in his profession, domestic, and respectable in his
3412 private character; but with reserved manners which prevented his being
3413 generally pleasing; and capable of being sometimes out of humour.
3414 He was not an ill-tempered man, not so often unreasonably cross
3415 as to deserve such a reproach; but his temper was not his
3416 great perfection; and, indeed, with such a worshipping wife,
3417 it was hardly possible that any natural defects in it should not
3418 be increased.  The extreme sweetness of her temper must hurt his.
3419 He had all the clearness and quickness of mind which she wanted,
3420 and he could sometimes act an ungracious, or say a severe thing.
3421 
3422 He was not a great favourite with his fair sister-in-law. Nothing
3423 wrong in him escaped her.  She was quick in feeling the little
3424 injuries to Isabella, which Isabella never felt herself.
3425 Perhaps she might have passed over more had his manners been
3426 flattering to Isabella's sister, but they were only those of a calmly
3427 kind brother and friend, without praise and without blindness;
3428 but hardly any degree of personal compliment could have made her
3429 regardless of that greatest fault of all in her eyes which he sometimes
3430 fell into, the want of respectful forbearance towards her father.
3431 There he had not always the patience that could have been wished.
3432 Mr. Woodhouse's peculiarities and fidgetiness were sometimes provoking
3433 him to a rational remonstrance or sharp retort equally ill-bestowed.
3434 It did not often happen; for Mr. John Knightley had really a great
3435 regard for his father-in-law, and generally a strong sense of what was
3436 due to him; but it was too often for Emma's charity, especially as
3437 there was all the pain of apprehension frequently to be endured,
3438 though the offence came not.  The beginning, however, of every visit
3439 displayed none but the properest feelings, and this being of necessity
3440 so short might be hoped to pass away in unsullied cordiality.
3441 They had not been long seated and composed when Mr. Woodhouse,
3442 with a melancholy shake of the head and a sigh, called his daughter's
3443 attention to the sad change at Hartfield since she had been there last.
3444 
3445 "Ah, my dear," said he, "poor Miss Taylor--It is a grievous business."
3446 
3447 "Oh yes, sir," cried she with ready sympathy, "how you must
3448 miss her!  And dear Emma, too!--What a dreadful loss to you both!--
3449 I have been so grieved for you.--I could not imagine how you could
3450 possibly do without her.--It is a sad change indeed.--But I hope
3451 she is pretty well, sir."
3452 
3453 "Pretty well, my dear--I hope--pretty well.--I do not know
3454 but that the place agrees with her tolerably."
3455 
3456 Mr. John Knightley here asked Emma quietly whether there were any
3457 doubts of the air of Randalls.
3458 
3459 "Oh! no--none in the least.  I never saw Mrs. Weston better in my life--
3460 never looking so well.  Papa is only speaking his own regret."
3461 
3462 "Very much to the honour of both," was the handsome reply.
3463 
3464 "And do you see her, sir, tolerably often?" asked Isabella
3465 in the plaintive tone which just suited her father.
3466 
3467 Mr. Woodhouse hesitated.--"Not near so often, my dear, as I could wish."
3468 
3469 "Oh! papa, we have missed seeing them but one entire day since
3470 they married.  Either in the morning or evening of every day,
3471 excepting one, have we seen either Mr. Weston or Mrs. Weston,
3472 and generally both, either at Randalls or here--and as you
3473 may suppose, Isabella, most frequently here.  They are very,
3474 very kind in their visits.  Mr. Weston is really as kind as herself.
3475 Papa, if you speak in that melancholy way, you will be giving
3476 Isabella a false idea of us all.  Every body must be aware that Miss
3477 Taylor must be missed, but every body ought also to be assured
3478 that Mr. and Mrs. Weston do really prevent our missing her by any
3479 means to the extent we ourselves anticipated--which is the exact truth."
3480 
3481 "Just as it should be," said Mr. John Knightley, "and just as I hoped
3482 it was from your letters.  Her wish of shewing you attention could
3483 not be doubted, and his being a disengaged and social man makes it
3484 all easy.  I have been always telling you, my love, that I had no idea
3485 of the change being so very material to Hartfield as you apprehended;
3486 and now you have Emma's account, I hope you will be satisfied."
3487 
3488 "Why, to be sure," said Mr. Woodhouse--"yes, certainly--I cannot deny
3489 that Mrs. Weston, poor Mrs. Weston, does come and see us pretty often--
3490 but then--she is always obliged to go away again."
3491 
3492 "It would be very hard upon Mr. Weston if she did not, papa.--
3493 You quite forget poor Mr. Weston."
3494 
3495 "I think, indeed," said John Knightley pleasantly, "that Mr. Weston
3496 has some little claim.  You and I, Emma, will venture to take the part
3497 of the poor husband.  I, being a husband, and you not being a wife,
3498 the claims of the man may very likely strike us with equal force.
3499 As for Isabella, she has been married long enough to see the convenience
3500 of putting all the Mr. Westons aside as much as she can."
3501 
3502 "Me, my love," cried his wife, hearing and understanding only in part.--
3503 "Are you talking about me?--I am sure nobody ought to be, or can be,
3504 a greater advocate for matrimony than I am; and if it had not been
3505 for the misery of her leaving Hartfield, I should never have thought
3506 of Miss Taylor but as the most fortunate woman in the world;
3507 and as to slighting Mr. Weston, that excellent Mr. Weston, I think
3508 there is nothing he does not deserve.  I believe he is one of the
3509 very best-tempered men that ever existed.  Excepting yourself
3510 and your brother, I do not know his equal for temper.  I shall
3511 never forget his flying Henry's kite for him that very windy day
3512 last Easter--and ever since his particular kindness last September
3513 twelvemonth in writing that note, at twelve o'clock at night,
3514 on purpose to assure me that there was no scarlet fever at Cobham,
3515 I have been convinced there could not be a more feeling heart nor
3516 a better man in existence.--If any body can deserve him, it must be
3517 Miss Taylor."
3518 
3519 "Where is the young man?" said John Knightley.  "Has he been here
3520 on this occasion--or has he not?"
3521 
3522 "He has not been here yet," replied Emma.  "There was a strong
3523 expectation of his coming soon after the marriage, but it ended
3524 in nothing; and I have not heard him mentioned lately."
3525 
3526 "But you should tell them of the letter, my dear," said her father.
3527 "He wrote a letter to poor Mrs. Weston, to congratulate her,
3528 and a very proper, handsome letter it was.  She shewed it to me.
3529 I thought it very well done of him indeed.  Whether it was his own idea
3530 you know, one cannot tell.  He is but young, and his uncle, perhaps--"
3531 
3532 "My dear papa, he is three-and-twenty. You forget how time passes."
3533 
3534 "Three-and-twenty!--is he indeed?--Well, I could not have thought it--
3535 and he was but two years old when he lost his poor mother!  Well,
3536 time does fly indeed!--and my memory is very bad.  However, it was
3537 an exceeding good, pretty letter, and gave Mr. and Mrs. Weston
3538 a great deal of pleasure.  I remember it was written from Weymouth,
3539 and dated Sept. 28th--and began, `My dear Madam,' but I forget
3540 how it went on; and it was signed `F. C. Weston Churchill.'--
3541 I remember that perfectly."
3542 
3543 "How very pleasing and proper of him!" cried the good-hearted Mrs. John
3544 Knightley.  "I have no doubt of his being a most amiable young man.
3545 But how sad it is that he should not live at home with his father!
3546 There is something so shocking in a child's being taken away from his
3547 parents and natural home!  I never could comprehend how Mr. Weston
3548 could part with him.  To give up one's child!  I really never
3549 could think well of any body who proposed such a thing to any body else."
3550 
3551 "Nobody ever did think well of the Churchills, I fancy,"
3552 observed Mr. John Knightley coolly.  "But you need not imagine
3553 Mr. Weston to have felt what you would feel in giving up Henry
3554 or John.  Mr. Weston is rather an easy, cheerful-tempered man,
3555 than a man of strong feelings; he takes things as he finds them,
3556 and makes enjoyment of them somehow or other, depending, I suspect,
3557 much more upon what is called society for his comforts, that is,
3558 upon the power of eating and drinking, and playing whist with his
3559 neighbours five times a week, than upon family affection, or any
3560 thing that home affords."
3561 
3562 Emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on Mr. Weston,
3563 and had half a mind to take it up; but she struggled, and let
3564 it pass.  She would keep the peace if possible; and there was
3565 something honourable and valuable in the strong domestic habits,
3566 the all-sufficiency of home to himself, whence resulted her brother's
3567 disposition to look down on the common rate of social intercourse,
3568 and those to whom it was important.--It had a high claim to forbearance.
3569 
3570 
3571 
3572 CHAPTER XII
3573 
3574 
3575 Mr. Knightley was to dine with them--rather against the inclination
3576 of Mr. Woodhouse, who did not like that any one should share with him
3577 in Isabella's first day.  Emma's sense of right however had decided it;
3578 and besides the consideration of what was due to each brother,
3579 she had particular pleasure, from the circumstance of the late
3580 disagreement between Mr. Knightley and herself, in procuring him
3581 the proper invitation.
3582 
3583 She hoped they might now become friends again.  She thought it
3584 was time to make up.  Making-up indeed would not do.  _She_ certainly
3585 had not been in the wrong, and _he_ would never own that he had.
3586 Concession must be out of the question; but it was time to appear
3587 to forget that they had ever quarrelled; and she hoped it might rather
3588 assist the restoration of friendship, that when he came into the room
3589 she had one of the children with her--the youngest, a nice little girl
3590 about eight months old, who was now making her first visit to Hartfield,
3591 and very happy to be danced about in her aunt's arms.  It did assist;
3592 for though he began with grave looks and short questions, he was soon
3593 led on to talk of them all in the usual way, and to take the child
3594 out of her arms with all the unceremoniousness of perfect amity.
3595 Emma felt they were friends again; and the conviction giving
3596 her at first great satisfaction, and then a little sauciness,
3597 she could not help saying, as he was admiring the baby,
3598 
3599 "What a comfort it is, that we think alike about our nephews and nieces.
3600 As to men and women, our opinions are sometimes very different;
3601 but with regard to these children, I observe we never disagree."
3602 
3603 "If you were as much guided by nature in your estimate of men
3604 and women, and as little under the power of fancy and whim in your
3605 dealings with them, as you are where these children are concerned,
3606 we might always think alike."
3607 
3608 "To be sure--our discordancies must always arise from my being
3609 in the wrong."
3610 
3611 "Yes," said he, smiling--"and reason good.  I was sixteen years
3612 old when you were born."
3613 
3614 "A material difference then," she replied--"and no doubt you were
3615 much my superior in judgment at that period of our lives; but does
3616 not the lapse of one-and-twenty years bring our understandings
3617 a good deal nearer?"
3618 
3619 "Yes--a good deal _nearer_."
3620 
3621 "But still, not near enough to give me a chance of being right,
3622 if we think differently."
3623 
3624 "I have still the advantage of you by sixteen years' experience, and by
3625 not being a pretty young woman and a spoiled child.  Come, my dear Emma,
3626 let us be friends, and say no more about it.  Tell your aunt, little Emma,
3627 that she ought to set you a better example than to be renewing
3628 old grievances, and that if she were not wrong before, she is now."
3629 
3630 "That's true," she cried--"very true.  Little Emma, grow up
3631 a better woman than your aunt.  Be infinitely cleverer and not
3632 half so conceited.  Now, Mr. Knightley, a word or two more, and I
3633 have done.  As far as good intentions went, we were _both_ right,
3634 and I must say that no effects on my side of the argument have yet
3635 proved wrong.  I only want to know that Mr. Martin is not very,
3636 very bitterly disappointed."
3637 
3638 "A man cannot be more so," was his short, full answer.
3639 
3640 "Ah!--Indeed I am very sorry.--Come, shake hands with me."
3641 
3642 This had just taken place and with great cordiality, when John
3643 Knightley made his appearance, and "How d'ye do, George?" and "John,
3644 how are you?" succeeded in the true English style, burying under
3645 a calmness that seemed all but indifference, the real attachment
3646 which would have led either of them, if requisite, to do every thing
3647 for the good of the other.
3648 
3649 The evening was quiet and conversable, as Mr. Woodhouse declined
3650 cards entirely for the sake of comfortable talk with his
3651 dear Isabella, and the little party made two natural divisions;
3652 on one side he and his daughter; on the other the two Mr. Knightleys;
3653 their subjects totally distinct, or very rarely mixing--and Emma
3654 only occasionally joining in one or the other.
3655 
3656 The brothers talked of their own concerns and pursuits, but principally
3657 of those of the elder, whose temper was by much the most communicative,
3658 and who was always the greater talker.  As a magistrate, he had
3659 generally some point of law to consult John about, or, at least,
3660 some curious anecdote to give; and as a farmer, as keeping in hand
3661 the home-farm at Donwell, he had to tell what every field was to bear
3662 next year, and to give all such local information as could not fail
3663 of being interesting to a brother whose home it had equally been
3664 the longest part of his life, and whose attachments were strong.
3665 The plan of a drain, the change of a fence, the felling of a tree,
3666 and the destination of every acre for wheat, turnips, or spring corn,
3667 was entered into with as much equality of interest by John, as his
3668 cooler manners rendered possible; and if his willing brother ever
3669 left him any thing to inquire about, his inquiries even approached
3670 a tone of eagerness.
3671 
3672 While they were thus comfortably occupied, Mr. Woodhouse was enjoying
3673 a full flow of happy regrets and fearful affection with his daughter.
3674 
3675 "My poor dear Isabella," said he, fondly taking her hand,
3676 and interrupting, for a few moments, her busy labours for some one
3677 of her five children--"How long it is, how terribly long since you
3678 were here!  And how tired you must be after your journey!  You must
3679 go to bed early, my dear--and I recommend a little gruel to you
3680 before you go.--You and I will have a nice basin of gruel together.
3681 My dear Emma, suppose we all have a little gruel."
3682 
3683 Emma could not suppose any such thing, knowing as she did,
3684 that both the Mr. Knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article
3685 as herself;--and two basins only were ordered.  After a little
3686 more discourse in praise of gruel, with some wondering at its
3687 not being taken every evening by every body, he proceeded to say,
3688 with an air of grave reflection,
3689 
3690 "It was an awkward business, my dear, your spending the autumn
3691 at South End instead of coming here.  I never had much opinion
3692 of the sea air."
3693 
3694 "Mr. Wingfield most strenuously recommended it, sir--or we
3695 should not have gone.  He recommended it for all the children,
3696 but particularly for the weakness in little Bella's throat,--
3697 both sea air and bathing."
3698 
3699 "Ah! my dear, but Perry had many doubts about the sea doing her
3700 any good; and as to myself, I have been long perfectly convinced,
3701 though perhaps I never told you so before, that the sea is very
3702 rarely of use to any body.  I am sure it almost killed me once."
3703 
3704 "Come, come," cried Emma, feeling this to be an unsafe subject, "I must
3705 beg you not to talk of the sea.  It makes me envious and miserable;--
3706 I who have never seen it!  South End is prohibited, if you please.
3707 My dear Isabella, I have not heard you make one inquiry about
3708 Mr. Perry yet; and he never forgets you."
3709 
3710 "Oh! good Mr. Perry--how is he, sir?"
3711 
3712 "Why, pretty well; but not quite well.  Poor Perry is bilious,
3713 and he has not time to take care of himself--he tells me he has
3714 not time to take care of himself--which is very sad--but he is
3715 always wanted all round the country.  I suppose there is not a man
3716 in such practice anywhere.  But then there is not so clever a man
3717 any where."
3718 
3719 "And Mrs. Perry and the children, how are they? do the children grow?
3720 I have a great regard for Mr. Perry.  I hope he will be calling soon.
3721 He will be so pleased to see my little ones."
3722 
3723 "I hope he will be here to-morrow, for I have a question or two to ask
3724 him about myself of some consequence.  And, my dear, whenever he comes,
3725 you had better let him look at little Bella's throat."
3726 
3727 "Oh! my dear sir, her throat is so much better that I have hardly
3728 any uneasiness about it.  Either bathing has been of the greatest
3729 service to her, or else it is to be attributed to an excellent
3730 embrocation of Mr. Wingfield's, which we have been applying
3731 at times ever since August."
3732 
3733 "It is not very likely, my dear, that bathing should have been
3734 of use to her--and if I had known you were wanting an embrocation,
3735 I would have spoken to--
3736 
3737 "You seem to me to have forgotten Mrs. and Miss Bates," said Emma,
3738 "I have not heard one inquiry after them."
3739 
3740 "Oh! the good Bateses--I am quite ashamed of myself--but you
3741 mention them in most of your letters.  I hope they are quite well.
3742 Good old Mrs. Bates--I will call upon her to-morrow, and take
3743 my children.--They are always so pleased to see my children.--
3744 And that excellent Miss Bates!--such thorough worthy people!--
3745 How are they, sir?"
3746 
3747 "Why, pretty well, my dear, upon the whole.  But poor Mrs. Bates
3748 had a bad cold about a month ago."
3749 
3750 "How sorry I am!  But colds were never so prevalent as they have been
3751 this autumn.  Mr. Wingfield told me that he has never known them
3752 more general or heavy--except when it has been quite an influenza."
3753 
3754 "That has been a good deal the case, my dear; but not to the degree
3755 you mention.  Perry says that colds have been very general,
3756 but not so heavy as he has very often known them in November.
3757 Perry does not call it altogether a sickly season."
3758 
3759 "No, I do not know that Mr. Wingfield considers it _very_ sickly except--
3760 
3761 "Ah! my poor dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always
3762 a sickly season.  Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be.
3763 It is a dreadful thing to have you forced to live there! so far off!--
3764 and the air so bad!"
3765 
3766 "No, indeed--_we_ are not at all in a bad air.  Our part of London is
3767 very superior to most others!--You must not confound us with London
3768 in general, my dear sir.  The neighbourhood of Brunswick Square
3769 is very different from almost all the rest.  We are so very airy!
3770 I should be unwilling, I own, to live in any other part of the town;--
3771 there is hardly any other that I could be satisfied to have my
3772 children in:  but _we_ are so remarkably airy!--Mr. Wingfield thinks
3773 the vicinity of Brunswick Square decidedly the most favourable as
3774 to air."
3775 
3776 "Ah! my dear, it is not like Hartfield.  You make the best of it--
3777 but after you have been a week at Hartfield, you are all of you
3778 different creatures; you do not look like the same.  Now I cannot say,
3779 that I think you are any of you looking well at present."
3780 
3781 "I am sorry to hear you say so, sir; but I assure you, excepting those
3782 little nervous head-aches and palpitations which I am never entirely
3783 free from anywhere, I am quite well myself; and if the children were
3784 rather pale before they went to bed, it was only because they were
3785 a little more tired than usual, from their journey and the happiness
3786 of coming.  I hope you will think better of their looks to-morrow;
3787 for I assure you Mr. Wingfield told me, that he did not believe
3788 he had ever sent us off altogether, in such good case.  I trust,
3789 at least, that you do not think Mr. Knightley looking ill,"
3790 turning her eyes with affectionate anxiety towards her husband.
3791 
3792 "Middling, my dear; I cannot compliment you.  I think Mr. John
3793 Knightley very far from looking well."
3794 
3795 "What is the matter, sir?--Did you speak to me?" cried Mr. John
3796 Knightley, hearing his own name.
3797 
3798 "I am sorry to find, my love, that my father does not think you
3799 looking well--but I hope it is only from being a little fatigued.
3800 I could have wished, however, as you know, that you had seen
3801 Mr. Wingfield before you left home."
3802 
3803 "My dear Isabella,"--exclaimed he hastily--"pray do not concern
3804 yourself about my looks.  Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling
3805 yourself and the children, and let me look as I chuse."
3806 
3807 "I did not thoroughly understand what you were telling your brother,"
3808 cried Emma, "about your friend Mr. Graham's intending to have a bailiff
3809 from Scotland, to look after his new estate.  What will it answer?
3810 Will not the old prejudice be too strong?"
3811 
3812 And she talked in this way so long and successfully that, when forced
3813 to give her attention again to her father and sister, she had nothing
3814 worse to hear than Isabella's kind inquiry after Jane Fairfax;
3815 and Jane Fairfax, though no great favourite with her in general,
3816 she was at that moment very happy to assist in praising.
3817 
3818 "That sweet, amiable Jane Fairfax!" said Mrs. John Knightley.--
3819 "It is so long since I have seen her, except now and then for a moment
3820 accidentally in town!  What happiness it must be to her good old
3821 grandmother and excellent aunt, when she comes to visit them!
3822 I always regret excessively on dear Emma's account that she cannot
3823 be more at Highbury; but now their daughter is married, I suppose
3824 Colonel and Mrs. Campbell will not be able to part with her at all.
3825 She would be such a delightful companion for Emma."
3826 
3827 Mr. Woodhouse agreed to it all, but added,
3828 
3829 "Our little friend Harriet Smith, however, is just such another
3830 pretty kind of young person.  You will like Harriet.  Emma could
3831 not have a better companion than Harriet."
3832 
3833 "I am most happy to hear it--but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be
3834 so very accomplished and superior!--and exactly Emma's age."
3835 
3836 This topic was discussed very happily, and others succeeded of
3837 similar moment, and passed away with similar harmony; but the evening
3838 did not close without a little return of agitation.  The gruel came
3839 and supplied a great deal to be said--much praise and many comments--
3840 undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution,
3841 and pretty severe Philippics upon the many houses where it was
3842 never met with tolerable;--but, unfortunately, among the failures
3843 which the daughter had to instance, the most recent, and therefore
3844 most prominent, was in her own cook at South End, a young woman
3845 hired for the time, who never had been able to understand what she
3846 meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel, thin, but not too thin.
3847 Often as she had wished for and ordered it, she had never been able
3848 to get any thing tolerable.  Here was a dangerous opening.
3849 
3850 "Ah!" said Mr. Woodhouse, shaking his head and fixing his eyes on
3851 her with tender concern.--The ejaculation in Emma's ear expressed,
3852 "Ah! there is no end of the sad consequences of your going to
3853 South End.  It does not bear talking of."  And for a little while
3854 she hoped he would not talk of it, and that a silent rumination
3855 might suffice to restore him to the relish of his own smooth gruel.
3856 After an interval of some minutes, however, he began with,
3857 
3858 "I shall always be very sorry that you went to the sea this autumn,
3859 instead of coming here."
3860 
3861 "But why should you be sorry, sir?--I assure you, it did the children
3862 a great deal of good."
3863 
3864 "And, moreover, if you must go to the sea, it had better not
3865 have been to South End.  South End is an unhealthy place.
3866 Perry was surprized to hear you had fixed upon South End."
3867 
3868 "I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is
3869 quite a mistake, sir.--We all had our health perfectly well there,
3870 never found the least inconvenience from the mud; and Mr. Wingfield
3871 says it is entirely a mistake to suppose the place unhealthy;
3872 and I am sure he may be depended on, for he thoroughly understands
3873 the nature of the air, and his own brother and family have been
3874 there repeatedly."
3875 
3876 "You should have gone to Cromer, my dear, if you went anywhere.--
3877 Perry was a week at Cromer once, and he holds it to be the best
3878 of all the sea-bathing places.  A fine open sea, he says, and very
3879 pure air.  And, by what I understand, you might have had lodgings there
3880 quite away from the sea--a quarter of a mile off--very comfortable.
3881 You should have consulted Perry."
3882 
3883 "But, my dear sir, the difference of the journey;--only consider how
3884 great it would have been.--An hundred miles, perhaps, instead of forty."
3885 
3886 "Ah! my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else
3887 should be considered; and if one is to travel, there is not much
3888 to chuse between forty miles and an hundred.--Better not move at all,
3889 better stay in London altogether than travel forty miles to get
3890 into a worse air.  This is just what Perry said.  It seemed to him
3891 a very ill-judged measure."
3892 
3893 Emma's attempts to stop her father had been vain; and when he
3894 had reached such a point as this, she could not wonder at her
3895 brother-in-law's breaking out.
3896 
3897 "Mr. Perry," said he, in a voice of very strong displeasure,
3898 "would do as well to keep his opinion till it is asked for.
3899 Why does he make it any business of his, to wonder at what I do?--
3900 at my taking my family to one part of the coast or another?--I may
3901 be allowed, I hope, the use of my judgment as well as Mr. Perry.--
3902 I want his directions no more than his drugs."  He paused--
3903 and growing cooler in a moment, added, with only sarcastic dryness,
3904 "If Mr. Perry can tell me how to convey a wife and five children
3905 a distance of an hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense
3906 or inconvenience than a distance of forty, I should be as willing to
3907 prefer Cromer to South End as he could himself."
3908 
3909 "True, true," cried Mr. Knightley, with most ready interposition--
3910 "very true.  That's a consideration indeed.--But John, as to what I
3911 was telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning
3912 it more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows,
3913 I cannot conceive any difficulty.  I should not attempt it,
3914 if it were to be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people,
3915 but if you call to mind exactly the present line of the path. . . .
3916 The only way of proving it, however, will be to turn to our maps.
3917 I shall see you at the Abbey to-morrow morning I hope, and then we
3918 will look them over, and you shall give me your opinion."
3919 
3920 Mr. Woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on
3921 his friend Perry, to whom he had, in fact, though unconsciously,
3922 been attributing many of his own feelings and expressions;--
3923 but the soothing attentions of his daughters gradually removed
3924 the present evil, and the immediate alertness of one brother,
3925 and better recollections of the other, prevented any renewal of it.
3926 
3927 
3928 
3929 CHAPTER XIII
3930 
3931 
3932 There could hardly be a happier creature in the world than Mrs. John
3933 Knightley, in this short visit to Hartfield, going about every morning
3934 among her old acquaintance with her five children, and talking
3935 over what she had done every evening with her father and sister.
3936 She had nothing to wish otherwise, but that the days did not pass
3937 so swiftly.  It was a delightful visit;--perfect, in being much too short.
3938 
3939 In general their evenings were less engaged with friends than
3940 their mornings; but one complete dinner engagement, and out
3941 of the house too, there was no avoiding, though at Christmas.
3942 Mr. Weston would take no denial; they must all dine at Randalls
3943 one day;--even Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded to think it a possible
3944 thing in preference to a division of the party.
3945 
3946 How they were all to be conveyed, he would have made a difficulty
3947 if he could, but as his son and daughter's carriage and horses
3948 were actually at Hartfield, he was not able to make more than
3949 a simple question on that head; it hardly amounted to a doubt;
3950 nor did it occupy Emma long to convince him that they might in one
3951 of the carriages find room for Harriet also.
3952 
3953 Harriet, Mr. Elton, and Mr. Knightley, their own especial set,
3954 were the only persons invited to meet them;--the hours were to be early,
3955 as well as the numbers few; Mr. Woodhouse's habits and inclination
3956 being consulted in every thing.
3957 
3958 The evening before this great event (for it was a very great event
3959 that Mr. Woodhouse should dine out, on the 24th of December) had been
3960 spent by Harriet at Hartfield, and she had gone home so much indisposed
3961 with a cold, that, but for her own earnest wish of being nursed
3962 by Mrs. Goddard, Emma could not have allowed her to leave the house.
3963 Emma called on her the next day, and found her doom already signed
3964 with regard to Randalls.  She was very feverish and had a bad
3965 sore throat:  Mrs. Goddard was full of care and affection, Mr. Perry
3966 was talked of, and Harriet herself was too ill and low to resist
3967 the authority which excluded her from this delightful engagement,
3968 though she could not speak of her loss without many tears.
3969 
3970 Emma sat with her as long as she could, to attend her in Mrs. Goddard's
3971 unavoidable absences, and raise her spirits by representing how much
3972 Mr. Elton's would be depressed when he knew her state; and left her
3973 at last tolerably comfortable, in the sweet dependence of his having
3974 a most comfortless visit, and of their all missing her very much.
3975 She had not advanced many yards from Mrs. Goddard's door, when she
3976 was met by Mr. Elton himself, evidently coming towards it, and as
3977 they walked on slowly together in conversation about the invalid--
3978 of whom he, on the rumour of considerable illness, had been going
3979 to inquire, that he might carry some report of her to Hartfield--
3980 they were overtaken by Mr. John Knightley returning from the
3981 daily visit to Donwell, with his two eldest boys, whose healthy,
3982 glowing faces shewed all the benefit of a country run, and seemed
3983 to ensure a quick despatch of the roast mutton and rice pudding they
3984 were hastening home for.  They joined company and proceeded together.
3985 Emma was just describing the nature of her friend's complaint;--
3986 "a throat very much inflamed, with a great deal of heat about her,
3987 a quick, low pulse, &c.  and she was sorry to find from Mrs. Goddard
3988 that Harriet was liable to very bad sore-throats, and had often
3989 alarmed her with them."  Mr. Elton looked all alarm on the occasion,
3990 as he exclaimed,
3991 
3992 "A sore-throat!--I hope not infectious.  I hope not of a putrid
3993 infectious sort.  Has Perry seen her?  Indeed you should take care
3994 of yourself as well as of your friend.  Let me entreat you to run
3995 no risks.  Why does not Perry see her?"
3996 
3997 Emma, who was not really at all frightened herself, tranquillised this
3998 excess of apprehension by assurances of Mrs. Goddard's experience
3999 and care; but as there must still remain a degree of uneasiness
4000 which she could not wish to reason away, which she would rather
4001 feed and assist than not, she added soon afterwards--as if quite
4002 another subject,
4003 
4004 "It is so cold, so very cold--and looks and feels so very much
4005 like snow, that if it were to any other place or with any other party,
4006 I should really try not to go out to-day--and dissuade my father
4007 from venturing; but as he has made up his mind, and does not seem
4008 to feel the cold himself, I do not like to interfere, as I know it
4009 would be so great a disappointment to Mr. and Mrs. Weston.  But, upon
4010 my word, Mr. Elton, in your case, I should certainly excuse myself.
4011 You appear to me a little hoarse already, and when you consider
4012 what demand of voice and what fatigues to-morrow will bring,
4013 I think it would be no more than common prudence to stay at home
4014 and take care of yourself to-night."
4015 
4016 Mr. Elton looked as if he did not very well know what answer to make;
4017 which was exactly the case; for though very much gratified by the kind
4018 care of such a fair lady, and not liking to resist any advice of
4019 her's, he had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;--
4020 but Emma, too eager and busy in her own previous conceptions
4021 and views to hear him impartially, or see him with clear vision,
4022 was very well satisfied with his muttering acknowledgment of its
4023 being "very cold, certainly very cold," and walked on, rejoicing in
4024 having extricated him from Randalls, and secured him the power
4025 of sending to inquire after Harriet every hour of the evening.
4026 
4027 "You do quite right," said she;--"we will make your apologies
4028 to Mr. and Mrs. Weston."
4029 
4030 But hardly had she so spoken, when she found her brother was civilly
4031 offering a seat in his carriage, if the weather were Mr. Elton's
4032 only objection, and Mr. Elton actually accepting the offer with much
4033 prompt satisfaction.  It was a done thing; Mr. Elton was to go,
4034 and never had his broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than
4035 at this moment; never had his smile been stronger, nor his eyes
4036 more exulting than when he next looked at her.
4037 
4038 "Well," said she to herself, "this is most strange!--After I
4039 had got him off so well, to chuse to go into company, and leave
4040 Harriet ill behind!--Most strange indeed!--But there is, I believe,
4041 in many men, especially single men, such an inclination--
4042 such a passion for dining out--a dinner engagement is so high in
4043 the class of their pleasures, their employments, their dignities,
4044 almost their duties, that any thing gives way to it--and this must
4045 be the case with Mr. Elton; a most valuable, amiable, pleasing young
4046 man undoubtedly, and very much in love with Harriet; but still,
4047 he cannot refuse an invitation, he must dine out wherever he is asked.
4048 What a strange thing love is! he can see ready wit in Harriet,
4049 but will not dine alone for her."
4050 
4051 Soon afterwards Mr. Elton quitted them, and she could not but do him
4052 the justice of feeling that there was a great deal of sentiment
4053 in his manner of naming Harriet at parting; in the tone of his
4054 voice while assuring her that he should call at Mrs. Goddard's
4055 for news of her fair friend, the last thing before he prepared
4056 for the happiness of meeting her again, when he hoped to be
4057 able to give a better report; and he sighed and smiled himself
4058 off in a way that left the balance of approbation much in his favour.
4059 
4060 After a few minutes of entire silence between them, John Knightley
4061 began with--
4062 
4063 "I never in my life saw a man more intent on being agreeable than
4064 Mr. Elton.  It is downright labour to him where ladies are concerned.
4065 With men he can be rational and unaffected, but when he has ladies
4066 to please, every feature works."
4067 
4068 "Mr. Elton's manners are not perfect," replied Emma; "but where there
4069 is a wish to please, one ought to overlook, and one does overlook
4070 a great deal.  Where a man does his best with only moderate powers,
4071 he will have the advantage over negligent superiority.  There is
4072 such perfect good-temper and good-will in Mr. Elton as one cannot
4073 but value."
4074 
4075 "Yes," said Mr. John Knightley presently, with some slyness,
4076 "he seems to have a great deal of good-will towards you."
4077 
4078 "Me!" she replied with a smile of astonishment, "are you imagining
4079 me to be Mr. Elton's object?"
4080 
4081 "Such an imagination has crossed me, I own, Emma; and if it never
4082 occurred to you before, you may as well take it into consideration now."
4083 
4084 "Mr. Elton in love with me!--What an idea!"
4085 
4086 "I do not say it is so; but you will do well to consider whether
4087 it is so or not, and to regulate your behaviour accordingly.
4088 I think your manners to him encouraging.  I speak as a friend,
4089 Emma.  You had better look about you, and ascertain what you do,
4090 and what you mean to do."
4091 
4092 "I thank you; but I assure you you are quite mistaken.  Mr. Elton
4093 and I are very good friends, and nothing more;" and she walked on,
4094 amusing herself in the consideration of the blunders which often
4095 arise from a partial knowledge of circumstances, of the mistakes
4096 which people of high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into;
4097 and not very well pleased with her brother for imagining her blind
4098 and ignorant, and in want of counsel.  He said no more.
4099 
4100 Mr. Woodhouse had so completely made up his mind to the visit,
4101 that in spite of the increasing coldness, he seemed to have no idea
4102 of shrinking from it, and set forward at last most punctually
4103 with his eldest daughter in his own carriage, with less apparent
4104 consciousness of the weather than either of the others; too full
4105 of the wonder of his own going, and the pleasure it was to afford at
4106 Randalls to see that it was cold, and too well wrapt up to feel it.
4107 The cold, however, was severe; and by the time the second carriage
4108 was in motion, a few flakes of snow were finding their way down,
4109 and the sky had the appearance of being so overcharged as to want only
4110 a milder air to produce a very white world in a very short time.
4111 
4112 Emma soon saw that her companion was not in the happiest humour.
4113 The preparing and the going abroad in such weather, with the sacrifice
4114 of his children after dinner, were evils, were disagreeables at least,
4115 which Mr. John Knightley did not by any means like; he anticipated
4116 nothing in the visit that could be at all worth the purchase;
4117 and the whole of their drive to the vicarage was spent by him in
4118 expressing his discontent.
4119 
4120 "A man," said he, "must have a very good opinion of himself when
4121 he asks people to leave their own fireside, and encounter such
4122 a day as this, for the sake of coming to see him.  He must think
4123 himself a most agreeable fellow; I could not do such a thing.
4124 It is the greatest absurdity--Actually snowing at this moment!--
4125 The folly of not allowing people to be comfortable at home--and the
4126 folly of people's not staying comfortably at home when they can!
4127 If we were obliged to go out such an evening as this, by any call of
4128 duty or business, what a hardship we should deem it;--and here are we,
4129 probably with rather thinner clothing than usual, setting forward
4130 voluntarily, without excuse, in defiance of the voice of nature,
4131 which tells man, in every thing given to his view or his feelings,
4132 to stay at home himself, and keep all under shelter that he can;--
4133 here are we setting forward to spend five dull hours in another
4134 man's house, with nothing to say or to hear that was not said
4135 and heard yesterday, and may not be said and heard again to-morrow.
4136 Going in dismal weather, to return probably in worse;--four horses
4137 and four servants taken out for nothing but to convey five idle,
4138 shivering creatures into colder rooms and worse company than they
4139 might have had at home."
4140 
4141 Emma did not find herself equal to give the pleased assent, which no doubt
4142 he was in the habit of receiving, to emulate the "Very true, my love,"
4143 which must have been usually administered by his travelling companion;
4144 but she had resolution enough to refrain from making any answer
4145 at all.  She could not be complying, she dreaded being quarrelsome;
4146 her heroism reached only to silence.  She allowed him to talk,
4147 and arranged the glasses, and wrapped herself up, without opening
4148 her lips.
4149 
4150 They arrived, the carriage turned, the step was let down,
4151 and Mr. Elton, spruce, black, and smiling, was with them instantly.
4152 Emma thought with pleasure of some change of subject.  Mr. Elton
4153 was all obligation and cheerfulness; he was so very cheerful
4154 in his civilities indeed, that she began to think he must have
4155 received a different account of Harriet from what had reached her.
4156 She had sent while dressing, and the answer had been, "Much the same--
4157 not better."
4158 
4159 "_My_ report from Mrs. Goddard's," said she presently, "was not
4160 so pleasant as I had hoped--`Not better' was _my_ answer."
4161 
4162 His face lengthened immediately; and his voice was the voice
4163 of sentiment as he answered.
4164 
4165 "Oh! no--I am grieved to find--I was on the point of telling you that
4166 when I called at Mrs. Goddard's door, which I did the very last thing
4167 before I returned to dress, I was told that Miss Smith was not better,
4168 by no means better, rather worse.  Very much grieved and concerned--
4169 I had flattered myself that she must be better after such a cordial
4170 as I knew had been given her in the morning."
4171 
4172 Emma smiled and answered--"My visit was of use to the nervous part
4173 of her complaint, I hope; but not even I can charm away a sore throat;
4174 it is a most severe cold indeed.  Mr. Perry has been with her,
4175 as you probably heard."
4176 
4177 "Yes--I imagined--that is--I did not--"
4178 
4179 "He has been used to her in these complaints, and I hope to-morrow
4180 morning will bring us both a more comfortable report.  But it is
4181 impossible not to feel uneasiness.  Such a sad loss to our party to-day!"
4182 
4183 "Dreadful!--Exactly so, indeed.--She will be missed every moment."
4184 
4185 This was very proper; the sigh which accompanied it was really estimable;
4186 but it should have lasted longer.  Emma was rather in dismay when
4187 only half a minute afterwards he began to speak of other things,
4188 and in a voice of the greatest alacrity and enjoyment.
4189 
4190 "What an excellent device," said he, "the use of a sheepskin
4191 for carriages.  How very comfortable they make it;--impossible to
4192 feel cold with such precautions.  The contrivances of modern days
4193 indeed have rendered a gentleman's carriage perfectly complete.
4194 One is so fenced and guarded from the weather, that not a breath
4195 of air can find its way unpermitted.  Weather becomes absolutely
4196 of no consequence.  It is a very cold afternoon--but in this carriage
4197 we know nothing of the matter.--Ha! snows a little I see."
4198 
4199 "Yes," said John Knightley, "and I think we shall have a good deal
4200 of it."
4201 
4202 "Christmas weather," observed Mr. Elton.  "Quite seasonable;
4203 and extremely fortunate we may think ourselves that it did not
4204 begin yesterday, and prevent this day's party, which it might very
4205 possibly have done, for Mr. Woodhouse would hardly have ventured had
4206 there been much snow on the ground; but now it is of no consequence.
4207 This is quite the season indeed for friendly meetings.  At Christmas
4208 every body invites their friends about them, and people think little
4209 of even the worst weather.  I was snowed up at a friend's house once
4210 for a week.  Nothing could be pleasanter.  I went for only one night,
4211 and could not get away till that very day se'nnight."
4212 
4213 Mr. John Knightley looked as if he did not comprehend the pleasure,
4214 but said only, coolly,
4215 
4216 "I cannot wish to be snowed up a week at Randalls."
4217 
4218 At another time Emma might have been amused, but she was too
4219 much astonished now at Mr. Elton's spirits for other feelings.
4220 Harriet seemed quite forgotten in the expectation of a pleasant party.
4221 
4222 "We are sure of excellent fires," continued he, "and every thing
4223 in the greatest comfort.  Charming people, Mr. and Mrs. Weston;--
4224 Mrs. Weston indeed is much beyond praise, and he is exactly
4225 what one values, so hospitable, and so fond of society;--
4226 it will be a small party, but where small parties are select,
4227 they are perhaps the most agreeable of any.  Mr. Weston's dining-room
4228 does not accommodate more than ten comfortably; and for my part,
4229 I would rather, under such circumstances, fall short by two than
4230 exceed by two.  I think you will agree with me, (turning with a soft
4231 air to Emma,) I think I shall certainly have your approbation,
4232 though Mr. Knightley perhaps, from being used to the large parties
4233 of London, may not quite enter into our feelings."
4234 
4235 "I know nothing of the large parties of London, sir--I never dine
4236 with any body."
4237 
4238 "Indeed! (in a tone of wonder and pity,) I had no idea that the
4239 law had been so great a slavery.  Well, sir, the time must come
4240 when you will be paid for all this, when you will have little
4241 labour and great enjoyment."
4242 
4243 "My first enjoyment," replied John Knightley, as they passed through
4244 the sweep-gate, "will be to find myself safe at Hartfield again."
4245 
4246 
4247 
4248 CHAPTER XIV
4249 
4250 
4251 Some change of countenance was necessary for each gentleman
4252 as they walked into Mrs. Weston's drawing-room;--Mr. Elton must
4253 compose his joyous looks, and Mr. John Knightley disperse his
4254 ill-humour. Mr. Elton must smile less, and Mr. John Knightley more,
4255 to fit them for the place.--Emma only might be as nature prompted,
4256 and shew herself just as happy as she was.  To her it was real
4257 enjoyment to be with the Westons.  Mr. Weston was a great favourite,
4258 and there was not a creature in the world to whom she spoke with
4259 such unreserve, as to his wife; not any one, to whom she related
4260 with such conviction of being listened to and understood, of being
4261 always interesting and always intelligible, the little affairs,
4262 arrangements, perplexities, and pleasures of her father and herself.
4263 She could tell nothing of Hartfield, in which Mrs. Weston had not
4264 a lively concern; and half an hour's uninterrupted communication
4265 of all those little matters on which the daily happiness of private
4266 life depends, was one of the first gratifications of each.
4267 
4268 This was a pleasure which perhaps the whole day's visit might
4269 not afford, which certainly did not belong to the present half-hour;
4270 but the very sight of Mrs. Weston, her smile, her touch, her voice
4271 was grateful to Emma, and she determined to think as little as
4272 possible of Mr. Elton's oddities, or of any thing else unpleasant,
4273 and enjoy all that was enjoyable to the utmost.
4274 
4275 The misfortune of Harriet's cold had been pretty well gone through
4276 before her arrival.  Mr. Woodhouse had been safely seated long
4277 enough to give the history of it, besides all the history of his own
4278 and Isabella's coming, and of Emma's being to follow, and had indeed
4279 just got to the end of his satisfaction that James should come
4280 and see his daughter, when the others appeared, and Mrs. Weston,
4281 who had been almost wholly engrossed by her attentions to him,
4282 was able to turn away and welcome her dear Emma.
4283 
4284 Emma's project of forgetting Mr. Elton for a while made her rather
4285 sorry to find, when they had all taken their places, that he was
4286 close to her.  The difficulty was great of driving his strange
4287 insensibility towards Harriet, from her mind, while he not only sat
4288 at her elbow, but was continually obtruding his happy countenance
4289 on her notice, and solicitously addressing her upon every occasion.
4290 Instead of forgetting him, his behaviour was such that she could
4291 not avoid the internal suggestion of "Can it really be as my brother
4292 imagined? can it be possible for this man to be beginning to transfer
4293 his affections from Harriet to me?--Absurd and insufferable!"--
4294 Yet he would be so anxious for her being perfectly warm, would be
4295 so interested about her father, and so delighted with Mrs. Weston;
4296 and at last would begin admiring her drawings with so much zeal
4297 and so little knowledge as seemed terribly like a would-be lover,
4298 and made it some effort with her to preserve her good manners.
4299 For her own sake she could not be rude; and for Harriet's, in the hope
4300 that all would yet turn out right, she was even positively civil;
4301 but it was an effort; especially as something was going on amongst
4302 the others, in the most overpowering period of Mr. Elton's nonsense,
4303 which she particularly wished to listen to.  She heard enough
4304 to know that Mr. Weston was giving some information about his son;
4305 she heard the words "my son," and "Frank," and "my son,"
4306 repeated several times over; and, from a few other half-syllables
4307 very much suspected that he was announcing an early visit from
4308 his son; but before she could quiet Mr. Elton, the subject was
4309 so completely past that any reviving question from her would have
4310 been awkward.
4311 
4312 Now, it so happened that in spite of Emma's resolution of never marrying,
4313 there was something in the name, in the idea of Mr. Frank Churchill,
4314 which always interested her.  She had frequently thought--especially since
4315 his father's marriage with Miss Taylor--that if she _were_ to marry,
4316 he was the very person to suit her in age, character and condition.
4317 He seemed by this connexion between the families, quite to belong to her.
4318 She could not but suppose it to be a match that every body who knew
4319 them must think of.  That Mr. and Mrs. Weston did think of it, she was
4320 very strongly persuaded; and though not meaning to be induced by him,
4321 or by any body else, to give up a situation which she believed more
4322 replete with good than any she could change it for, she had a great
4323 curiosity to see him, a decided intention of finding him pleasant,
4324 of being liked by him to a certain degree, and a sort of pleasure
4325 in the idea of their being coupled in their friends' imaginations.
4326 
4327 With such sensations, Mr. Elton's civilities were dreadfully ill-timed;
4328 but she had the comfort of appearing very polite, while feeling
4329 very cross--and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not
4330 possibly pass without bringing forward the same information again,
4331 or the substance of it, from the open-hearted Mr. Weston.--So it proved;--
4332 for when happily released from Mr. Elton, and seated by Mr. Weston,
4333 at dinner, he made use of the very first interval in the cares
4334 of hospitality, the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton,
4335 to say to her,
4336 
4337 "We want only two more to be just the right number.  I should
4338 like to see two more here,--your pretty little friend, Miss Smith,
4339 and my son--and then I should say we were quite complete.
4340 I believe you did not hear me telling the others in the drawing-room
4341 that we are expecting Frank.  I had a letter from him this morning,
4342 and he will be with us within a fortnight."
4343 
4344 Emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure; and fully assented
4345 to his proposition of Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Smith making
4346 their party quite complete.
4347 
4348 "He has been wanting to come to us," continued Mr. Weston,
4349 "ever since September:  every letter has been full of it;
4350 but he cannot command his own time.  He has those to please
4351 who must be pleased, and who (between ourselves) are sometimes
4352 to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices.  But now
4353 I have no doubt of seeing him here about the second week in January."
4354 
4355 "What a very great pleasure it will be to you! and Mrs. Weston
4356 is so anxious to be acquainted with him, that she must be almost
4357 as happy as yourself."
4358 
4359 "Yes, she would be, but that she thinks there will be another
4360 put-off. She does not depend upon his coming so much as I do:
4361 but she does not know the parties so well as I do.  The case,
4362 you see, is--(but this is quite between ourselves:  I did not mention
4363 a syllable of it in the other room.  There are secrets in all families,
4364 you know)--The case is, that a party of friends are invited to pay
4365 a visit at Enscombe in January; and that Frank's coming depends upon
4366 their being put off.  If they are not put off, he cannot stir.
4367 But I know they will, because it is a family that a certain lady,
4368 of some consequence, at Enscombe, has a particular dislike to:
4369 and though it is thought necessary to invite them once in two or
4370 three years, they always are put off when it comes to the point.
4371 I have not the smallest doubt of the issue.  I am as confident
4372 of seeing Frank here before the middle of January, as I am
4373 of being here myself:  but your good friend there (nodding
4374 towards the upper end of the table) has so few vagaries herself,
4375 and has been so little used to them at Hartfield, that she cannot
4376 calculate on their effects, as I have been long in the practice
4377 of doing."
4378 
4379 "I am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case,"
4380 replied Emma; "but am disposed to side with you, Mr. Weston.  If you
4381 think he will come, I shall think so too; for you know Enscombe."
4382 
4383 "Yes--I have some right to that knowledge; though I have never been
4384 at the place in my life.--She is an odd woman!--But I never allow
4385 myself to speak ill of her, on Frank's account; for I do believe
4386 her to be very fond of him.  I used to think she was not capable
4387 of being fond of any body, except herself:  but she has always been
4388 kind to him (in her way--allowing for little whims and caprices,
4389 and expecting every thing to be as she likes). And it is no small credit,
4390 in my opinion, to him, that he should excite such an affection;
4391 for, though I would not say it to any body else, she has no more
4392 heart than a stone to people in general; and the devil of a temper."
4393 
4394 Emma liked the subject so well, that she began upon it, to Mrs. Weston,
4395 very soon after their moving into the drawing-room: wishing her joy--
4396 yet observing, that she knew the first meeting must be rather alarming.--
4397 Mrs. Weston agreed to it; but added, that she should be very
4398 glad to be secure of undergoing the anxiety of a first meeting
4399 at the time talked of:  "for I cannot depend upon his coming.
4400 I cannot be so sanguine as Mr. Weston.  I am very much afraid
4401 that it will all end in nothing.  Mr. Weston, I dare say, has been
4402 telling you exactly how the matter stands?"
4403 
4404 "Yes--it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill-humour
4405 of Mrs. Churchill, which I imagine to be the most certain
4406 thing in the world."
4407 
4408 "My Emma!" replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "what is the certainty
4409 of caprice?"  Then turning to Isabella, who had not been
4410 attending before--"You must know, my dear Mrs. Knightley,
4411 that we are by no means so sure of seeing Mr. Frank Churchill,
