4412 in my opinion, as his father thinks.  It depends entirely upon
4413 his aunt's spirits and pleasure; in short, upon her temper.
4414 To you--to my two daughters--I may venture on the truth.
4415 Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe, and is a very odd-tempered woman;
4416 and his coming now, depends upon her being willing to spare him."
4417 
4418 "Oh, Mrs. Churchill; every body knows Mrs. Churchill,"
4419 replied Isabella:  "and I am sure I never think of that poor young
4420 man without the greatest compassion.  To be constantly living
4421 with an ill-tempered person, must be dreadful.  It is what we
4422 happily have never known any thing of; but it must be a life
4423 of misery.  What a blessing, that she never had any children!
4424 Poor little creatures, how unhappy she would have made them!"
4425 
4426 Emma wished she had been alone with Mrs. Weston.  She should then have
4427 heard more:  Mrs. Weston would speak to her, with a degree of unreserve
4428 which she would not hazard with Isabella; and, she really believed,
4429 would scarcely try to conceal any thing relative to the Churchills
4430 from her, excepting those views on the young man, of which her own
4431 imagination had already given her such instinctive knowledge.
4432 But at present there was nothing more to be said.  Mr. Woodhouse
4433 very soon followed them into the drawing-room. To be sitting
4434 long after dinner, was a confinement that he could not endure.
4435 Neither wine nor conversation was any thing to him; and gladly did
4436 he move to those with whom he was always comfortable.
4437 
4438 While he talked to Isabella, however, Emma found an opportunity
4439 of saying,
4440 
4441 "And so you do not consider this visit from your son as by any
4442 means certain.  I am sorry for it.  The introduction must be unpleasant,
4443 whenever it takes place; and the sooner it could be over, the better."
4444 
4445 "Yes; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays.
4446 Even if this family, the Braithwaites, are put off, I am still
4447 afraid that some excuse may be found for disappointing us.
4448 I cannot bear to imagine any reluctance on his side; but I am sure
4449 there is a great wish on the Churchills' to keep him to themselves.
4450 There is jealousy.  They are jealous even of his regard for his father.
4451 In short, I can feel no dependence on his coming, and I wish Mr. Weston
4452 were less sanguine."
4453 
4454 "He ought to come," said Emma.  "If he could stay only a couple
4455 of days, he ought to come; and one can hardly conceive a young man's
4456 not having it in his power to do as much as that.  A young _woman_,
4457 if she fall into bad hands, may be teazed, and kept at a distance
4458 from those she wants to be with; but one cannot comprehend a young
4459 _man_'s being under such restraint, as not to be able to spend a week
4460 with his father, if he likes it."
4461 
4462 "One ought to be at Enscombe, and know the ways of the family,
4463 before one decides upon what he can do," replied Mrs. Weston.
4464 "One ought to use the same caution, perhaps, in judging of the
4465 conduct of any one individual of any one family; but Enscombe,
4466 I believe, certainly must not be judged by general rules:
4467 _she_ is so very unreasonable; and every thing gives way to her."
4468 
4469 "But she is so fond of the nephew:  he is so very great a favourite.
4470 Now, according to my idea of Mrs. Churchill, it would be most natural,
4471 that while she makes no sacrifice for the comfort of the husband,
4472 to whom she owes every thing, while she exercises incessant caprice
4473 towards _him_, she should frequently be governed by the nephew,
4474 to whom she owes nothing at all."
4475 
4476 "My dearest Emma, do not pretend, with your sweet temper,
4477 to understand a bad one, or to lay down rules for it:  you must
4478 let it go its own way.  I have no doubt of his having, at times,
4479 considerable influence; but it may be perfectly impossible for him
4480 to know beforehand _when_ it will be."
4481 
4482 Emma listened, and then coolly said, "I shall not be satisfied,
4483 unless he comes."
4484 
4485 "He may have a great deal of influence on some points,"
4486 continued Mrs. Weston, "and on others, very little:  and among those,
4487 on which she is beyond his reach, it is but too likely, may be
4488 this very circumstance of his coming away from them to visit us."
4489 
4490 
4491 
4492 CHAPTER XV
4493 
4494 
4495 Mr. Woodhouse was soon ready for his tea; and when he had drank his
4496 tea he was quite ready to go home; and it was as much as his three
4497 companions could do, to entertain away his notice of the lateness
4498 of the hour, before the other gentlemen appeared.  Mr. Weston was
4499 chatty and convivial, and no friend to early separations of any sort;
4500 but at last the drawing-room party did receive an augmentation.
4501 Mr. Elton, in very good spirits, was one of the first to walk in.
4502 Mrs. Weston and Emma were sitting together on a sofa.  He joined
4503 them immediately, and, with scarcely an invitation, seated himself
4504 between them.
4505 
4506 Emma, in good spirits too, from the amusement afforded her mind
4507 by the expectation of Mr. Frank Churchill, was willing to forget
4508 his late improprieties, and be as well satisfied with him as before,
4509 and on his making Harriet his very first subject, was ready to listen
4510 with most friendly smiles.
4511 
4512 He professed himself extremely anxious about her fair friend--
4513 her fair, lovely, amiable friend.  "Did she know?--had she
4514 heard any thing about her, since their being at Randalls?--
4515 he felt much anxiety--he must confess that the nature of her
4516 complaint alarmed him considerably."  And in this style he talked
4517 on for some time very properly, not much attending to any answer,
4518 but altogether sufficiently awake to the terror of a bad sore throat;
4519 and Emma was quite in charity with him.
4520 
4521 But at last there seemed a perverse turn; it seemed all at once as if
4522 he were more afraid of its being a bad sore throat on her account,
4523 than on Harriet's--more anxious that she should escape the infection,
4524 than that there should be no infection in the complaint.  He began
4525 with great earnestness to entreat her to refrain from visiting
4526 the sick-chamber again, for the present--to entreat her to _promise_
4527 _him_ not to venture into such hazard till he had seen Mr. Perry
4528 and learnt his opinion; and though she tried to laugh it off
4529 and bring the subject back into its proper course, there was no
4530 putting an end to his extreme solicitude about her.  She was vexed.
4531 It did appear--there was no concealing it--exactly like the pretence
4532 of being in love with her, instead of Harriet; an inconstancy,
4533 if real, the most contemptible and abominable! and she had difficulty
4534 in behaving with temper.  He turned to Mrs. Weston to implore
4535 her assistance, "Would not she give him her support?--would not she
4536 add her persuasions to his, to induce Miss Woodhouse not to go
4537 to Mrs. Goddard's till it were certain that Miss Smith's disorder
4538 had no infection?  He could not be satisfied without a promise--
4539 would not she give him her influence in procuring it?"
4540 
4541 "So scrupulous for others," he continued, "and yet so careless
4542 for herself!  She wanted me to nurse my cold by staying at home to-day,
4543 and yet will not promise to avoid the danger of catching an ulcerated
4544 sore throat herself.  Is this fair, Mrs. Weston?--Judge between us.
4545 Have not I some right to complain?  I am sure of your kind support
4546 and aid."
4547 
4548 Emma saw Mrs. Weston's surprize, and felt that it must be great,
4549 at an address which, in words and manner, was assuming to himself
4550 the right of first interest in her; and as for herself, she was
4551 too much provoked and offended to have the power of directly
4552 saying any thing to the purpose.  She could only give him a look;
4553 but it was such a look as she thought must restore him to his senses,
4554 and then left the sofa, removing to a seat by her sister, and giving
4555 her all her attention.
4556 
4557 She had not time to know how Mr. Elton took the reproof, so rapidly
4558 did another subject succeed; for Mr. John Knightley now came
4559 into the room from examining the weather, and opened on them
4560 all with the information of the ground being covered with snow,
4561 and of its still snowing fast, with a strong drifting wind;
4562 concluding with these words to Mr. Woodhouse:
4563 
4564 "This will prove a spirited beginning of your winter engagements,
4565 sir.  Something new for your coachman and horses to be making
4566 their way through a storm of snow."
4567 
4568 Poor Mr. Woodhouse was silent from consternation; but every body else
4569 had something to say; every body was either surprized or not surprized,
4570 and had some question to ask, or some comfort to offer.  Mrs. Weston
4571 and Emma tried earnestly to cheer him and turn his attention
4572 from his son-in-law, who was pursuing his triumph rather unfeelingly.
4573 
4574 "I admired your resolution very much, sir," said he, "in venturing
4575 out in such weather, for of course you saw there would be snow
4576 very soon.  Every body must have seen the snow coming on.
4577 I admired your spirit; and I dare say we shall get home very well.
4578 Another hour or two's snow can hardly make the road impassable;
4579 and we are two carriages; if one is blown over in the bleak part
4580 of the common field there will be the other at hand.  I dare say we
4581 shall be all safe at Hartfield before midnight."
4582 
4583 Mr. Weston, with triumph of a different sort, was confessing that he
4584 had known it to be snowing some time, but had not said a word,
4585 lest it should make Mr. Woodhouse uncomfortable, and be an excuse
4586 for his hurrying away.  As to there being any quantity of snow fallen
4587 or likely to fall to impede their return, that was a mere joke;
4588 he was afraid they would find no difficulty.  He wished the road might
4589 be impassable, that he might be able to keep them all at Randalls;
4590 and with the utmost good-will was sure that accommodation might
4591 be found for every body, calling on his wife to agree with him,
4592 that with a little contrivance, every body might be lodged,
4593 which she hardly knew how to do, from the consciousness of there
4594 being but two spare rooms in the house.
4595 
4596 "What is to be done, my dear Emma?--what is to be done?"
4597 was Mr. Woodhouse's first exclamation, and all that he could say
4598 for some time.  To her he looked for comfort; and her assurances
4599 of safety, her representation of the excellence of the horses,
4600 and of James, and of their having so many friends about them,
4601 revived him a little.
4602 
4603 His eldest daughter's alarm was equal to his own.  The horror of
4604 being blocked up at Randalls, while her children were at Hartfield,
4605 was full in her imagination; and fancying the road to be now just
4606 passable for adventurous people, but in a state that admitted no delay,
4607 she was eager to have it settled, that her father and Emma should remain
4608 at Randalls, while she and her husband set forward instantly through
4609 all the possible accumulations of drifted snow that might impede them.
4610 
4611 "You had better order the carriage directly, my love," said she;
4612 "I dare say we shall be able to get along, if we set off directly;
4613 and if we do come to any thing very bad, I can get out and walk.
4614 I am not at all afraid.  I should not mind walking half the way.
4615 I could change my shoes, you know, the moment I got home; and it is not
4616 the sort of thing that gives me cold."
4617 
4618 "Indeed!" replied he.  "Then, my dear Isabella, it is the most
4619 extraordinary sort of thing in the world, for in general every
4620 thing does give you cold.  Walk home!--you are prettily shod
4621 for walking home, I dare say.  It will be bad enough for the horses."
4622 
4623 Isabella turned to Mrs. Weston for her approbation of the plan.
4624 Mrs. Weston could only approve.  Isabella then went to Emma;
4625 but Emma could not so entirely give up the hope of their being
4626 all able to get away; and they were still discussing the point,
4627 when Mr. Knightley, who had left the room immediately after his
4628 brother's first report of the snow, came back again, and told them
4629 that he had been out of doors to examine, and could answer for there
4630 not being the smallest difficulty in their getting home, whenever they
4631 liked it, either now or an hour hence.  He had gone beyond the sweep--
4632 some way along the Highbury road--the snow was nowhere above half
4633 an inch deep--in many places hardly enough to whiten the ground;
4634 a very few flakes were falling at present, but the clouds were parting,
4635 and there was every appearance of its being soon over.  He had seen
4636 the coachmen, and they both agreed with him in there being nothing
4637 to apprehend.
4638 
4639 To Isabella, the relief of such tidings was very great, and they
4640 were scarcely less acceptable to Emma on her father's account,
4641 who was immediately set as much at ease on the subject as his nervous
4642 constitution allowed; but the alarm that had been raised could not
4643 be appeased so as to admit of any comfort for him while he continued
4644 at Randalls.  He was satisfied of there being no present danger in
4645 returning home, but no assurances could convince him that it was safe
4646 to stay; and while the others were variously urging and recommending,
4647 Mr. Knightley and Emma settled it in a few brief sentences:  thus--
4648 
4649 "Your father will not be easy; why do not you go?"
4650 
4651 "I am ready, if the others are."
4652 
4653 "Shall I ring the bell?"
4654 
4655 "Yes, do."
4656 
4657 And the bell was rung, and the carriages spoken for.  A few
4658 minutes more, and Emma hoped to see one troublesome companion
4659 deposited in his own house, to get sober and cool, and the other
4660 recover his temper and happiness when this visit of hardship were over.
4661 
4662 The carriage came:  and Mr. Woodhouse, always the first object on
4663 such occasions, was carefully attended to his own by Mr. Knightley
4664 and Mr. Weston; but not all that either could say could prevent some
4665 renewal of alarm at the sight of the snow which had actually fallen,
4666 and the discovery of a much darker night than he had been prepared for.
4667 "He was afraid they should have a very bad drive.  He was afraid
4668 poor Isabella would not like it.  And there would be poor Emma
4669 in the carriage behind.  He did not know what they had best do.
4670 They must keep as much together as they could;" and James was talked to,
4671 and given a charge to go very slow and wait for the other carriage.
4672 
4673 Isabella stept in after her father; John Knightley, forgetting that he
4674 did not belong to their party, stept in after his wife very naturally;
4675 so that Emma found, on being escorted and followed into the second
4676 carriage by Mr. Elton, that the door was to be lawfully shut on them,
4677 and that they were to have a tete-a-tete drive.  It would not have been
4678 the awkwardness of a moment, it would have been rather a pleasure,
4679 previous to the suspicions of this very day; she could have talked
4680 to him of Harriet, and the three-quarters of a mile would have
4681 seemed but one.  But now, she would rather it had not happened.
4682 She believed he had been drinking too much of Mr. Weston's good wine,
4683 and felt sure that he would want to be talking nonsense.
4684 
4685 To restrain him as much as might be, by her own manners, she was
4686 immediately preparing to speak with exquisite calmness and gravity
4687 of the weather and the night; but scarcely had she begun, scarcely had
4688 they passed the sweep-gate and joined the other carriage, than she
4689 found her subject cut up--her hand seized--her attention demanded,
4690 and Mr. Elton actually making violent love to her:  availing himself
4691 of the precious opportunity, declaring sentiments which must be already
4692 well known, hoping--fearing--adoring--ready to die if she refused him;
4693 but flattering himself that his ardent attachment and unequalled
4694 love and unexampled passion could not fail of having some effect,
4695 and in short, very much resolved on being seriously accepted as soon
4696 as possible.  It really was so.  Without scruple--without apology--
4697 without much apparent diffidence, Mr. Elton, the lover of Harriet,
4698 was professing himself _her_ lover.  She tried to stop him; but vainly;
4699 he would go on, and say it all.  Angry as she was, the thought of
4700 the moment made her resolve to restrain herself when she did speak.
4701 She felt that half this folly must be drunkenness, and therefore
4702 could hope that it might belong only to the passing hour.
4703 Accordingly, with a mixture of the serious and the playful, which she
4704 hoped would best suit his half and half state, she replied,
4705 
4706 "I am very much astonished, Mr. Elton.  This to _me_! you forget yourself--
4707 you take me for my friend--any message to Miss Smith I shall
4708 be happy to deliver; but no more of this to _me_, if you please."
4709 
4710 "Miss Smith!--message to Miss Smith!--What could she possibly mean!"--
4711 And he repeated her words with such assurance of accent, such boastful
4712 pretence of amazement, that she could not help replying with quickness,
4713 
4714 "Mr. Elton, this is the most extraordinary conduct! and I can account
4715 for it only in one way; you are not yourself, or you could not speak
4716 either to me, or of Harriet, in such a manner.  Command yourself
4717 enough to say no more, and I will endeavour to forget it."
4718 
4719 But Mr. Elton had only drunk wine enough to elevate his spirits,
4720 not at all to confuse his intellects.  He perfectly knew his own meaning;
4721 and having warmly protested against her suspicion as most injurious,
4722 and slightly touched upon his respect for Miss Smith as her friend,--
4723 but acknowledging his wonder that Miss Smith should be mentioned
4724 at all,--he resumed the subject of his own passion, and was very
4725 urgent for a favourable answer.
4726 
4727 As she thought less of his inebriety, she thought more of his inconstancy
4728 and presumption; and with fewer struggles for politeness, replied,
4729 
4730 "It is impossible for me to doubt any longer.  You have made
4731 yourself too clear.  Mr. Elton, my astonishment is much beyond
4732 any thing I can express.  After such behaviour, as I have witnessed
4733 during the last month, to Miss Smith--such attentions as I
4734 have been in the daily habit of observing--to be addressing me
4735 in this manner--this is an unsteadiness of character, indeed,
4736 which I had not supposed possible!  Believe me, sir, I am far,
4737 very far, from gratified in being the object of such professions."
4738 
4739 "Good Heaven!" cried Mr. Elton, "what can be the meaning of this?--
4740 Miss Smith!--I never thought of Miss Smith in the whole course
4741 of my existence--never paid her any attentions, but as your friend:
4742 never cared whether she were dead or alive, but as your friend.
4743 If she has fancied otherwise, her own wishes have misled her,
4744 and I am very sorry--extremely sorry--But, Miss Smith, indeed!--Oh!
4745 Miss Woodhouse! who can think of Miss Smith, when Miss Woodhouse
4746 is near!  No, upon my honour, there is no unsteadiness of character.
4747 I have thought only of you.  I protest against having paid the smallest
4748 attention to any one else.  Every thing that I have said or done,
4749 for many weeks past, has been with the sole view of marking my
4750 adoration of yourself.  You cannot really, seriously, doubt it.
4751 No!--(in an accent meant to be insinuating)--I am sure you have seen
4752 and understood me."
4753 
4754 It would be impossible to say what Emma felt, on hearing this--
4755 which of all her unpleasant sensations was uppermost.  She was
4756 too completely overpowered to be immediately able to reply:
4757 and two moments of silence being ample encouragement for Mr. Elton's
4758 sanguine state of mind, he tried to take her hand again, as he
4759 joyously exclaimed--
4760 
4761 "Charming Miss Woodhouse! allow me to interpret this interesting silence.
4762 It confesses that you have long understood me."
4763 
4764 "No, sir," cried Emma, "it confesses no such thing.  So far from
4765 having long understood you, I have been in a most complete error
4766 with respect to your views, till this moment.  As to myself, I am
4767 very sorry that you should have been giving way to any feelings--
4768 Nothing could be farther from my wishes--your attachment to my
4769 friend Harriet--your pursuit of her, (pursuit, it appeared,) gave me
4770 great pleasure, and I have been very earnestly wishing you success:
4771 but had I supposed that she were not your attraction to Hartfield,
4772 I should certainly have thought you judged ill in making your visits
4773 so frequent.  Am I to believe that you have never sought to recommend
4774 yourself particularly to Miss Smith?--that you have never thought
4775 seriously of her?"
4776 
4777 "Never, madam," cried he, affronted in his turn:  "never, I assure you.
4778 _I_ think seriously of Miss Smith!--Miss Smith is a very good sort
4779 of girl; and I should be happy to see her respectably settled.
4780 I wish her extremely well:  and, no doubt, there are men who might not
4781 object to--Every body has their level:  but as for myself, I am not,
4782 I think, quite so much at a loss.  I need not so totally despair
4783 of an equal alliance, as to be addressing myself to Miss Smith!--
4784 No, madam, my visits to Hartfield have been for yourself only;
4785 and the encouragement I received--"
4786 
4787 "Encouragement!--I give you encouragement!--Sir, you have been entirely
4788 mistaken in supposing it.  I have seen you only as the admirer
4789 of my friend.  In no other light could you have been more to me than
4790 a common acquaintance.  I am exceedingly sorry:  but it is well that
4791 the mistake ends where it does.  Had the same behaviour continued,
4792 Miss Smith might have been led into a misconception of your views;
4793 not being aware, probably, any more than myself, of the very
4794 great inequality which you are so sensible of.  But, as it is,
4795 the disappointment is single, and, I trust, will not be lasting.
4796 I have no thoughts of matrimony at present."
4797 
4798 He was too angry to say another word; her manner too decided
4799 to invite supplication; and in this state of swelling resentment,
4800 and mutually deep mortification, they had to continue together a few
4801 minutes longer, for the fears of Mr. Woodhouse had confined them
4802 to a foot-pace. If there had not been so much anger, there would have
4803 been desperate awkwardness; but their straightforward emotions left
4804 no room for the little zigzags of embarrassment.  Without knowing
4805 when the carriage turned into Vicarage Lane, or when it stopped,
4806 they found themselves, all at once, at the door of his house;
4807 and he was out before another syllable passed.--Emma then felt it
4808 indispensable to wish him a good night.  The compliment was just returned,
4809 coldly and proudly; and, under indescribable irritation of spirits,
4810 she was then conveyed to Hartfield.
4811 
4812 There she was welcomed, with the utmost delight, by her father,
4813 who had been trembling for the dangers of a solitary drive from
4814 Vicarage Lane--turning a corner which he could never bear to think of--
4815 and in strange hands--a mere common coachman--no James; and there it
4816 seemed as if her return only were wanted to make every thing go well:
4817 for Mr. John Knightley, ashamed of his ill-humour, was now all
4818 kindness and attention; and so particularly solicitous for the comfort
4819 of her father, as to seem--if not quite ready to join him in a basin
4820 of gruel--perfectly sensible of its being exceedingly wholesome;
4821 and the day was concluding in peace and comfort to all their little party,
4822 except herself.--But her mind had never been in such perturbation;
4823 and it needed a very strong effort to appear attentive and cheerful till
4824 the usual hour of separating allowed her the relief of quiet reflection.
4825 
4826 
4827 
4828 CHAPTER XVI
4829 
4830 
4831 The hair was curled, and the maid sent away, and Emma sat down to think
4832 and be miserable.--It was a wretched business indeed!--Such an overthrow
4833 of every thing she had been wishing for!--Such a development of every
4834 thing most unwelcome!--Such a blow for Harriet!--that was the worst
4835 of all.  Every part of it brought pain and humiliation, of some sort
4836 or other; but, compared with the evil to Harriet, all was light;
4837 and she would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken--
4838 more in error--more disgraced by mis-judgment, than she actually was,
4839 could the effects of her blunders have been confined to herself.
4840 
4841 "If I had not persuaded Harriet into liking the man, I could have
4842 borne any thing.  He might have doubled his presumption to me--
4843 but poor Harriet!"
4844 
4845 How she could have been so deceived!--He protested that he
4846 had never thought seriously of Harriet--never!  She looked back
4847 as well as she could; but it was all confusion.  She had taken
4848 up the idea, she supposed, and made every thing bend to it.
4849 His manners, however, must have been unmarked, wavering, dubious,
4850 or she could not have been so misled.
4851 
4852 The picture!--How eager he had been about the picture!--
4853 and the charade!--and an hundred other circumstances;--
4854 how clearly they had seemed to point at Harriet.  To be sure,
4855 the charade, with its "ready wit"--but then the "soft eyes"--
4856 in fact it suited neither; it was a jumble without taste or truth.
4857 Who could have seen through such thick-headed nonsense?
4858 
4859 Certainly she had often, especially of late, thought his manners
4860 to herself unnecessarily gallant; but it had passed as his way,
4861 as a mere error of judgment, of knowledge, of taste, as one proof
4862 among others that he had not always lived in the best society,
4863 that with all the gentleness of his address, true elegance
4864 was sometimes wanting; but, till this very day, she had never,
4865 for an instant, suspected it to mean any thing but grateful respect
4866 to her as Harriet's friend.
4867 
4868 To Mr. John Knightley was she indebted for her first idea on
4869 the subject, for the first start of its possibility.  There was
4870 no denying that those brothers had penetration.  She remembered
4871 what Mr. Knightley had once said to her about Mr. Elton, the caution
4872 he had given, the conviction he had professed that Mr. Elton would
4873 never marry indiscreetly; and blushed to think how much truer
4874 a knowledge of his character had been there shewn than any she
4875 had reached herself.  It was dreadfully mortifying; but Mr. Elton
4876 was proving himself, in many respects, the very reverse of what she
4877 had meant and believed him; proud, assuming, conceited; very full
4878 of his own claims, and little concerned about the feelings of others.
4879 
4880 Contrary to the usual course of things, Mr. Elton's wanting
4881 to pay his addresses to her had sunk him in her opinion.
4882 His professions and his proposals did him no service.  She thought
4883 nothing of his attachment, and was insulted by his hopes.
4884 He wanted to marry well, and having the arrogance to raise his
4885 eyes to her, pretended to be in love; but she was perfectly easy
4886 as to his not suffering any disappointment that need be cared for.
4887 There had been no real affection either in his language or manners.
4888 Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance; but she could
4889 hardly devise any set of expressions, or fancy any tone of voice,
4890 less allied with real love.  She need not trouble herself to pity him.
4891 He only wanted to aggrandise and enrich himself; and if Miss Woodhouse
4892 of Hartfield, the heiress of thirty thousand pounds, were not quite
4893 so easily obtained as he had fancied, he would soon try for Miss
4894 Somebody else with twenty, or with ten.
4895 
4896 But--that he should talk of encouragement, should consider her as
4897 aware of his views, accepting his attentions, meaning (in short),
4898 to marry him!--should suppose himself her equal in connexion
4899 or mind!--look down upon her friend, so well understanding the
4900 gradations of rank below him, and be so blind to what rose above,
4901 as to fancy himself shewing no presumption in addressing her!--
4902 It was most provoking.
4903 
4904 Perhaps it was not fair to expect him to feel how very much he
4905 was her inferior in talent, and all the elegancies of mind.
4906 The very want of such equality might prevent his perception of it;
4907 but he must know that in fortune and consequence she was greatly
4908 his superior.  He must know that the Woodhouses had been settled
4909 for several generations at Hartfield, the younger branch
4910 of a very ancient family--and that the Eltons were nobody.
4911 The landed property of Hartfield certainly was inconsiderable,
4912 being but a sort of notch in the Donwell Abbey estate, to which all
4913 the rest of Highbury belonged; but their fortune, from other sources,
4914 was such as to make them scarcely secondary to Donwell Abbey itself,
4915 in every other kind of consequence; and the Woodhouses had long
4916 held a high place in the consideration of the neighbourhood which
4917 Mr. Elton had first entered not two years ago, to make his way
4918 as he could, without any alliances but in trade, or any thing
4919 to recommend him to notice but his situation and his civility.--
4920 But he had fancied her in love with him; that evidently must
4921 have been his dependence; and after raving a little about the
4922 seeming incongruity of gentle manners and a conceited head,
4923 Emma was obliged in common honesty to stop and admit that her own
4924 behaviour to him had been so complaisant and obliging, so full of
4925 courtesy and attention, as (supposing her real motive unperceived)
4926 might warrant a man of ordinary observation and delicacy,
4927 like Mr. Elton, in fancying himself a very decided favourite.  If _she_
4928 had so misinterpreted his feelings, she had little right to wonder
4929 that _he_, with self-interest to blind him, should have mistaken hers.
4930 
4931 The first error and the worst lay at her door.  It was foolish,
4932 it was wrong, to take so active a part in bringing any two
4933 people together.  It was adventuring too far, assuming too much,
4934 making light of what ought to be serious, a trick of what ought
4935 to be simple.  She was quite concerned and ashamed, and resolved
4936 to do such things no more.
4937 
4938 "Here have I," said she, "actually talked poor Harriet into being
4939 very much attached to this man.  She might never have thought of him
4940 but for me; and certainly never would have thought of him with hope,
4941 if I had not assured her of his attachment, for she is as modest
4942 and humble as I used to think him.  Oh! that I had been satisfied with
4943 persuading her not to accept young Martin.  There I was quite right.
4944 That was well done of me; but there I should have stopped, and left
4945 the rest to time and chance.  I was introducing her into good company,
4946 and giving her the opportunity of pleasing some one worth having;
4947 I ought not to have attempted more.  But now, poor girl, her peace
4948 is cut up for some time.  I have been but half a friend to her;
4949 and if she were _not_ to feel this disappointment so very much, I am
4950 sure I have not an idea of any body else who would be at all desirable
4951 for her;--William Coxe--Oh! no, I could not endure William Coxe--
4952 a pert young lawyer."
4953 
4954 She stopt to blush and laugh at her own relapse, and then resumed
4955 a more serious, more dispiriting cogitation upon what had been,
4956 and might be, and must be.  The distressing explanation she had
4957 to make to Harriet, and all that poor Harriet would be suffering,
4958 with the awkwardness of future meetings, the difficulties of
4959 continuing or discontinuing the acquaintance, of subduing feelings,
4960 concealing resentment, and avoiding eclat, were enough to occupy
4961 her in most unmirthful reflections some time longer, and she went
4962 to bed at last with nothing settled but the conviction of her having
4963 blundered most dreadfully.
4964 
4965 To youth and natural cheerfulness like Emma's, though under
4966 temporary gloom at night, the return of day will hardly fail
4967 to bring return of spirits.  The youth and cheerfulness of morning
4968 are in happy analogy, and of powerful operation; and if the
4969 distress be not poignant enough to keep the eyes unclosed, they
4970 will be sure to open to sensations of softened pain and brighter hope.
4971 
4972 Emma got up on the morrow more disposed for comfort than she had
4973 gone to bed, more ready to see alleviations of the evil before her,
4974 and to depend on getting tolerably out of it.
4975 
4976 It was a great consolation that Mr. Elton should not be really
4977 in love with her, or so particularly amiable as to make it shocking
4978 to disappoint him--that Harriet's nature should not be of that
4979 superior sort in which the feelings are most acute and retentive--
4980 and that there could be no necessity for any body's knowing
4981 what had passed except the three principals, and especially
4982 for her father's being given a moment's uneasiness about it.
4983 
4984 These were very cheering thoughts; and the sight of a great deal
4985 of snow on the ground did her further service, for any thing was
4986 welcome that might justify their all three being quite asunder
4987 at present.
4988 
4989 The weather was most favourable for her; though Christmas Day,
4990 she could not go to church.  Mr. Woodhouse would have been miserable
4991 had his daughter attempted it, and she was therefore safe from
4992 either exciting or receiving unpleasant and most unsuitable ideas.
4993 The ground covered with snow, and the atmosphere in that unsettled
4994 state between frost and thaw, which is of all others the most
4995 unfriendly for exercise, every morning beginning in rain or snow,
4996 and every evening setting in to freeze, she was for many days a most
4997 honourable prisoner.  No intercourse with Harriet possible but by note;
4998 no church for her on Sunday any more than on Christmas Day; and no
4999 need to find excuses for Mr. Elton's absenting himself.
5000 
5001 It was weather which might fairly confine every body at home;
5002 and though she hoped and believed him to be really taking comfort
5003 in some society or other, it was very pleasant to have her father
5004 so well satisfied with his being all alone in his own house,
5005 too wise to stir out; and to hear him say to Mr. Knightley, whom no
5006 weather could keep entirely from them,--
5007 
5008 "Ah!  Mr. Knightley, why do not you stay at home like poor Mr. Elton?"
5009 
5010 These days of confinement would have been, but for her private
5011 perplexities, remarkably comfortable, as such seclusion exactly
5012 suited her brother, whose feelings must always be of great importance
5013 to his companions; and he had, besides, so thoroughly cleared off
5014 his ill-humour at Randalls, that his amiableness never failed him
5015 during the rest of his stay at Hartfield.  He was always agreeable
5016 and obliging, and speaking pleasantly of every body.  But with all
5017 the hopes of cheerfulness, and all the present comfort of delay,
5018 there was still such an evil hanging over her in the hour of explanation
5019 with Harriet, as made it impossible for Emma to be ever perfectly at ease.
5020 
5021 
5022 
5023 CHAPTER XVII
5024 
5025 
5026 Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley were not detained long at Hartfield.
5027 The weather soon improved enough for those to move who must move;
5028 and Mr. Woodhouse having, as usual, tried to persuade his daughter
5029 to stay behind with all her children, was obliged to see the whole
5030 party set off, and return to his lamentations over the destiny
5031 of poor Isabella;--which poor Isabella, passing her life with
5032 those she doated on, full of their merits, blind to their faults,
5033 and always innocently busy, might have been a model of right
5034 feminine happiness.
5035 
5036 The evening of the very day on which they went brought a note
5037 from Mr. Elton to Mr. Woodhouse, a long, civil, ceremonious note,
5038 to say, with Mr. Elton's best compliments, "that he was proposing
5039 to leave Highbury the following morning in his way to Bath;
5040 where, in compliance with the pressing entreaties of some friends,
5041 he had engaged to spend a few weeks, and very much regretted
5042 the impossibility he was under, from various circumstances of
5043 weather and business, of taking a personal leave of Mr. Woodhouse,
5044 of whose friendly civilities he should ever retain a grateful sense--
5045 and had Mr. Woodhouse any commands, should be happy to attend to them."
5046 
5047 Emma was most agreeably surprized.--Mr. Elton's absence just
5048 at this time was the very thing to be desired.  She admired
5049 him for contriving it, though not able to give him much credit
5050 for the manner in which it was announced.  Resentment could not
5051 have been more plainly spoken than in a civility to her father,
5052 from which she was so pointedly excluded.  She had not even a
5053 share in his opening compliments.--Her name was not mentioned;--
5054 and there was so striking a change in all this, and such an
5055 ill-judged solemnity of leave-taking in his graceful acknowledgments,
5056 as she thought, at first, could not escape her father's suspicion.
5057 
5058 It did, however.--Her father was quite taken up with the surprize
5059 of so sudden a journey, and his fears that Mr. Elton might never get
5060 safely to the end of it, and saw nothing extraordinary in his language.
5061 It was a very useful note, for it supplied them with fresh matter
5062 for thought and conversation during the rest of their lonely evening.
5063 Mr. Woodhouse talked over his alarms, and Emma was in spirits
5064 to persuade them away with all her usual promptitude.
5065 
5066 She now resolved to keep Harriet no longer in the dark.  She had
5067 reason to believe her nearly recovered from her cold, and it was
5068 desirable that she should have as much time as possible for getting
5069 the better of her other complaint before the gentleman's return.
5070 She went to Mrs. Goddard's accordingly the very next day, to undergo
5071 the necessary penance of communication; and a severe one it was.--
5072 She had to destroy all the hopes which she had been so industriously
5073 feeding--to appear in the ungracious character of the one preferred--
5074 and acknowledge herself grossly mistaken and mis-judging in all her
5075 ideas on one subject, all her observations, all her convictions,
5076 all her prophecies for the last six weeks.
5077 
5078 The confession completely renewed her first shame--and the sight
5079 of Harriet's tears made her think that she should never be in charity
5080 with herself again.
5081 
5082 Harriet bore the intelligence very well--blaming nobody--
5083 and in every thing testifying such an ingenuousness of disposition
5084 and lowly opinion of herself, as must appear with particular
5085 advantage at that moment to her friend.
5086 
5087 Emma was in the humour to value simplicity and modesty to the utmost;
5088 and all that was amiable, all that ought to be attaching,
5089 seemed on Harriet's side, not her own.  Harriet did not consider
5090 herself as having any thing to complain of.  The affection of such
5091 a man as Mr. Elton would have been too great a distinction.--
5092 She never could have deserved him--and nobody but so partial
5093 and kind a friend as Miss Woodhouse would have thought it possible.
5094 
5095 Her tears fell abundantly--but her grief was so truly artless,
5096 that no dignity could have made it more respectable in Emma's eyes--
5097 and she listened to her and tried to console her with all her heart
5098 and understanding--really for the time convinced that Harriet was
5099 the superior creature of the two--and that to resemble her would
5100 be more for her own welfare and happiness than all that genius or
5101 intelligence could do.
5102 
5103 It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple-minded
5104 and ignorant; but she left her with every previous resolution
5105 confirmed of being humble and discreet, and repressing imagination
5106 all the rest of her life.  Her second duty now, inferior only to her
5107 father's claims, was to promote Harriet's comfort, and endeavour
5108 to prove her own affection in some better method than by match-making.
5109 She got her to Hartfield, and shewed her the most unvarying kindness,
5110 striving to occupy and amuse her, and by books and conversation,
5111 to drive Mr. Elton from her thoughts.
5112 
5113 Time, she knew, must be allowed for this being thoroughly done; and she
5114 could suppose herself but an indifferent judge of such matters in general,
5115 and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to Mr. Elton
5116 in particular; but it seemed to her reasonable that at Harriet's age,
5117 and with the entire extinction of all hope, such a progress might be
5118 made towards a state of composure by the time of Mr. Elton's return,
5119 as to allow them all to meet again in the common routine of acquaintance,
5120 without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing them.
5121 
5122 Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the non-existence
5123 of any body equal to him in person or goodness--and did, in truth,
5124 prove herself more resolutely in love than Emma had foreseen;
5125 but yet it appeared to her so natural, so inevitable to strive
5126 against an inclination of that sort _unrequited_, that she could not
5127 comprehend its continuing very long in equal force.
5128 
5129 If Mr. Elton, on his return, made his own indifference as evident
5130 and indubitable as she could not doubt he would anxiously do,
5131 she could not imagine Harriet's persisting to place her happiness
5132 in the sight or the recollection of him.
5133 
5134 Their being fixed, so absolutely fixed, in the same place, was bad
5135 for each, for all three.  Not one of them had the power of removal,
5136 or of effecting any material change of society.  They must encounter
5137 each other, and make the best of it.
5138 
5139 Harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of her companions at
5140 Mrs. Goddard's; Mr. Elton being the adoration of all the teachers
5141 and great girls in the school; and it must be at Hartfield only
5142 that she could have any chance of hearing him spoken of with cooling
5143 moderation or repellent truth.  Where the wound had been given,
5144 there must the cure be found if anywhere; and Emma felt that,
5145 till she saw her in the way of cure, there could be no true peace
5146 for herself.
5147 
5148 
5149 
5150 CHAPTER XVIII
5151 
5152 
5153 Mr. Frank Churchill did not come.  When the time proposed
5154 drew near, Mrs. Weston's fears were justified in the arrival
5155 of a letter of excuse.  For the present, he could not be spared,
5156 to his "very great mortification and regret; but still he looked
5157 forward with the hope of coming to Randalls at no distant period."
5158 
5159 Mrs. Weston was exceedingly disappointed--much more disappointed,
5160 in fact, than her husband, though her dependence on seeing the
5161 young man had been so much more sober:  but a sanguine temper,
5162 though for ever expecting more good than occurs, does not
5163 always pay for its hopes by any proportionate depression.
5164 It soon flies over the present failure, and begins to hope again.
5165 For half an hour Mr. Weston was surprized and sorry; but then he
5166 began to perceive that Frank's coming two or three months later
5167 would be a much better plan; better time of year; better weather;
5168 and that he would be able, without any doubt, to stay considerably
5169 longer with them than if he had come sooner.
5170 
5171 These feelings rapidly restored his comfort, while Mrs. Weston,
5172 of a more apprehensive disposition, foresaw nothing but a repetition
5173 of excuses and delays; and after all her concern for what her husband
5174 was to suffer, suffered a great deal more herself.
5175 
5176 Emma was not at this time in a state of spirits to care really
5177 about Mr. Frank Churchill's not coming, except as a disappointment
5178 at Randalls.  The acquaintance at present had no charm for her.
5179 She wanted, rather, to be quiet, and out of temptation; but still, as it
5180 was desirable that she should appear, in general, like her usual self,
5181 she took care to express as much interest in the circumstance,
5182 and enter as warmly into Mr. and Mrs. Weston's disappointment,
5183 as might naturally belong to their friendship.
5184 
5185 She was the first to announce it to Mr. Knightley; and exclaimed
5186 quite as much as was necessary, (or, being acting a part, perhaps
5187 rather more,) at the conduct of the Churchills, in keeping him away.
5188 She then proceeded to say a good deal more than she felt, of the
5189 advantage of such an addition to their confined society in Surry;
5190 the pleasure of looking at somebody new; the gala-day to Highbury entire,
5191 which the sight of him would have made; and ending with reflections
5192 on the Churchills again, found herself directly involved in a
5193 disagreement with Mr. Knightley; and, to her great amusement,
5194 perceived that she was taking the other side of the question from her
5195 real opinion, and making use of Mrs. Weston's arguments against herself.
5196 
5197 "The Churchills are very likely in fault," said Mr. Knightley,
5198 coolly; "but I dare say he might come if he would."
5199 
5200 "I do not know why you should say so.  He wishes exceedingly to come;
5201 but his uncle and aunt will not spare him."
5202 
5203 "I cannot believe that he has not the power of coming, if he made
5204 a point of it.  It is too unlikely, for me to believe it without proof."
5205 
5206 "How odd you are!  What has Mr. Frank Churchill done, to make you
5207 suppose him such an unnatural creature?"
5208 
5209 "I am not supposing him at all an unnatural creature, in suspecting
5210 that he may have learnt to be above his connexions, and to care
5211 very little for any thing but his own pleasure, from living with
5212 those who have always set him the example of it.  It is a great deal
5213 more natural than one could wish, that a young man, brought up
5214 by those who are proud, luxurious, and selfish, should be proud,
5215 luxurious, and selfish too.  If Frank Churchill had wanted to see
5216 his father, he would have contrived it between September and January.
5217 A man at his age--what is he?--three or four-and-twenty--cannot be
5218 without the means of doing as much as that.  It is impossible."
5219 
5220 "That's easily said, and easily felt by you, who have always
5221 been your own master.  You are the worst judge in the world,
5222 Mr. Knightley, of the difficulties of dependence.  You do not know
5223 what it is to have tempers to manage."
5224 
5225 "It is not to be conceived that a man of three or four-and-twenty
5226 should not have liberty of mind or limb to that amount.  He cannot
5227 want money--he cannot want leisure.  We know, on the contrary,
5228 that he has so much of both, that he is glad to get rid of them at
5229 the idlest haunts in the kingdom.  We hear of him for ever at some
5230 watering-place or other.  A little while ago, he was at Weymouth.
5231 This proves that he can leave the Churchills."
5232 
5233 "Yes, sometimes he can."
5234 
5235 "And those times are whenever he thinks it worth his while;
5236 whenever there is any temptation of pleasure."
5237 
5238 "It is very unfair to judge of any body's conduct, without an
5239 intimate knowledge of their situation.  Nobody, who has not been
5240 in the interior of a family, can say what the difficulties
5241 of any individual of that family may be.  We ought to be
5242 acquainted with Enscombe, and with Mrs. Churchill's temper,
5243 before we pretend to decide upon what her nephew can do.
5244 He may, at times, be able to do a great deal more than he can at others."
5245 
5246 "There is one thing, Emma, which a man can always do, if he chuses,
5247 and that is, his duty; not by manoeuvring and finessing, but by vigour
5248 and resolution.  It is Frank Churchill's duty to pay this attention
5249 to his father.  He knows it to be so, by his promises and messages;
5250 but if he wished to do it, it might be done.  A man who felt rightly
5251 would say at once, simply and resolutely, to Mrs. Churchill--
5252 `Every sacrifice of mere pleasure you will always find me ready to make
5253 to your convenience; but I must go and see my father immediately.
5254 I know he would be hurt by my failing in such a mark of respect to him
5255 on the present occasion.  I shall, therefore, set off to-morrow.'--
5256 If he would say so to her at once, in the tone of decision becoming
5257 a man, there would be no opposition made to his going."
5258 
5259 "No," said Emma, laughing; "but perhaps there might be some made to his
5260 coming back again.  Such language for a young man entirely dependent,
5261 to use!--Nobody but you, Mr. Knightley, would imagine it possible.
5262 But you have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly
5263 opposite to your own.  Mr. Frank Churchill to be making such
5264 a speech as that to the uncle and aunt, who have brought him up,
5265 and are to provide for him!--Standing up in the middle of the room,
5266 I suppose, and speaking as loud as he could!--How can you imagine
5267 such conduct practicable?"
5268 
5269 "Depend upon it, Emma, a sensible man would find no difficulty in it.
5270 He would feel himself in the right; and the declaration--made,
5271 of course, as a man of sense would make it, in a proper manner--
5272 would do him more good, raise him higher, fix his interest stronger
5273 with the people he depended on, than all that a line of shifts
5274 and expedients can ever do.  Respect would be added to affection.
5275 They would feel that they could trust him; that the nephew who had
5276 done rightly by his father, would do rightly by them; for they know,
5277 as well as he does, as well as all the world must know, that he
5278 ought to pay this visit to his father; and while meanly exerting
5279 their power to delay it, are in their hearts not thinking the better
5280 of him for submitting to their whims.  Respect for right conduct
5281 is felt by every body.  If he would act in this sort of manner,
5282 on principle, consistently, regularly, their little minds would bend
5283 to his."
5284 
5285 "I rather doubt that.  You are very fond of bending little minds;
5286 but where little minds belong to rich people in authority,
5287 I think they have a knack of swelling out, till they are quite as
5288 unmanageable as great ones.  I can imagine, that if you, as you are,
5289 Mr. Knightley, were to be transported and placed all at once in
5290 Mr. Frank Churchill's situation, you would be able to say and do
5291 just what you have been recommending for him; and it might have
5292 a very good effect.  The Churchills might not have a word to say
5293 in return; but then, you would have no habits of early obedience
5294 and long observance to break through.  To him who has, it might
5295 not be so easy to burst forth at once into perfect independence,
5296 and set all their claims on his gratitude and regard at nought.
5297 He may have as strong a sense of what would be right, as you can have,
5298 without being so equal, under particular circumstances, to act up
5299 to it."
5300 
5301 "Then it would not be so strong a sense.  If it failed to produce
5302 equal exertion, it could not be an equal conviction."
5303 
5304 "Oh, the difference of situation and habit!  I wish you would try
5305 to understand what an amiable young man may be likely to feel
5306 in directly opposing those, whom as child and boy he has been
5307 looking up to all his life."
5308 
5309 "Our amiable young man is a very weak young man, if this be the first
5310 occasion of his carrying through a resolution to do right against
5311 the will of others.  It ought to have been a habit with him by
5312 this time, of following his duty, instead of consulting expediency.
5313 I can allow for the fears of the child, but not of the man.
5314 As he became rational, he ought to have roused himself and shaken off
5315 all that was unworthy in their authority.  He ought to have opposed
5316 the first attempt on their side to make him slight his father.
5317 Had he begun as he ought, there would have been no difficulty now."
5318 
5319 "We shall never agree about him," cried Emma; "but that is
5320 nothing extraordinary.  I have not the least idea of his being
5321 a weak young man:  I feel sure that he is not.  Mr. Weston would
5322 not be blind to folly, though in his own son; but he is very likely
5323 to have a more yielding, complying, mild disposition than would suit
5324 your notions of man's perfection.  I dare say he has; and though
5325 it may cut him off from some advantages, it will secure him many others."
5326 
5327 "Yes; all the advantages of sitting still when he ought to move,
5328 and of leading a life of mere idle pleasure, and fancying himself
5329 extremely expert in finding excuses for it.  He can sit down and
5330 write a fine flourishing letter, full of professions and falsehoods,
5331 and persuade himself that he has hit upon the very best method
5332 in the world of preserving peace at home and preventing his father's
5333 having any right to complain.  His letters disgust me."
5334 
5335 "Your feelings are singular.  They seem to satisfy every body else."
5336 
5337 "I suspect they do not satisfy Mrs. Weston.  They hardly can
5338 satisfy a woman of her good sense and quick feelings:  standing in
5339 a mother's place, but without a mother's affection to blind her.
5340 It is on her account that attention to Randalls is doubly due,
5341 and she must doubly feel the omission.  Had she been a person
5342 of consequence herself, he would have come I dare say; and it would
5343 not have signified whether he did or no.  Can you think your friend
5344 behindhand in these sort of considerations?  Do you suppose she
5345 does not often say all this to herself?  No, Emma, your amiable
5346 young man can be amiable only in French, not in English.  He may be
5347 very `aimable,' have very good manners, and be very agreeable; but he
5348 can have no English delicacy towards the feelings of other people:
5349 nothing really amiable about him."
5350 
5351 "You seem determined to think ill of him."
5352 
5353 "Me!--not at all," replied Mr. Knightley, rather displeased; "I do
5354 not want to think ill of him.  I should be as ready to acknowledge
5355 his merits as any other man; but I hear of none, except what are
5356 merely personal; that he is well-grown and good-looking, with smooth,
5357 plausible manners."
5358 
5359 "Well, if he have nothing else to recommend him, he will be a
5360 treasure at Highbury.  We do not often look upon fine young men,
5361 well-bred and agreeable.  We must not be nice and ask for all
5362 the virtues into the bargain.  Cannot you imagine, Mr. Knightley,
5363 what a _sensation_ his coming will produce?  There will be but one subject
5364 throughout the parishes of Donwell and Highbury; but one interest--
5365 one object of curiosity; it will be all Mr. Frank Churchill;
5366 we shall think and speak of nobody else."
5367 
5368 "You will excuse my being so much over-powered. If I find him
5369 conversable, I shall be glad of his acquaintance; but if he is only
5370 a chattering coxcomb, he will not occupy much of my time or thoughts."
5371 
5372 "My idea of him is, that he can adapt his conversation to the taste
5373 of every body, and has the power as well as the wish of being
5374 universally agreeable.  To you, he will talk of farming; to me,
5375 of drawing or music; and so on to every body, having that general
5376 information on all subjects which will enable him to follow the lead,
5377 or take the lead, just as propriety may require, and to speak
5378 extremely well on each; that is my idea of him."
5379 
5380 "And mine," said Mr. Knightley warmly, "is, that if he turn out any
5381 thing like it, he will be the most insufferable fellow breathing!
5382 What! at three-and-twenty to be the king of his company--the great man--
5383 the practised politician, who is to read every body's character,
5384 and make every body's talents conduce to the display of his
5385 own superiority; to be dispensing his flatteries around, that he
5386 may make all appear like fools compared with himself!  My dear Emma,
5387 your own good sense could not endure such a puppy when it came
5388 to the point."
5389 
5390 "I will say no more about him," cried Emma, "you turn every
5391 thing to evil.  We are both prejudiced; you against, I for him;
5392 and we have no chance of agreeing till he is really here."
5393 
5394 "Prejudiced!  I am not prejudiced."
5395 
5396 "But I am very much, and without being at all ashamed of it.
5397 My love for Mr. and Mrs. Weston gives me a decided prejudice in
5398 his favour."
5399 
5400 "He is a person I never think of from one month's end to another,"
5401 said Mr. Knightley, with a degree of vexation, which made Emma
5402 immediately talk of something else, though she could not comprehend
5403 why he should be angry.
5404 
5405 To take a dislike to a young man, only because he appeared to be
5406 of a different disposition from himself, was unworthy the real
5407 liberality of mind which she was always used to acknowledge in him;
5408 for with all the high opinion of himself, which she had often laid
5409 to his charge, she had never before for a moment supposed it could
5410 make him unjust to the merit of another.
5411 
5412 
5413 
5414 
5415 VOLUME II
5416 
5417 
5418 
5419 CHAPTER I
5420 
5421 
5422 Emma and Harriet had been walking together one morning, and,
5423 in Emma's opinion, had been talking enough of Mr. Elton for that day.
5424 She could not think that Harriet's solace or her own sins required more;
5425 and she was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject
5426 as they returned;--but it burst out again when she thought she
5427 had succeeded, and after speaking some time of what the poor must
5428 suffer in winter, and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive--
5429 "Mr. Elton is so good to the poor!" she found something else must be done.
5430 
5431 They were just approaching the house where lived Mrs. and Miss Bates.
5432 She determined to call upon them and seek safety in numbers.
5433 There was always sufficient reason for such an attention; Mrs. and
5434 Miss Bates loved to be called on, and she knew she was considered
5435 by the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in her,
5436 as rather negligent in that respect, and as not contributing what she
5437 ought to the stock of their scanty comforts.
5438 
5439 She had had many a hint from Mr. Knightley and some from her own heart,
5440 as to her deficiency--but none were equal to counteract the persuasion
5441 of its being very disagreeable,--a waste of time--tiresome women--
5442 and all the horror of being in danger of falling in with the second-rate
5443 and third-rate of Highbury, who were calling on them for ever,
5444 and therefore she seldom went near them.  But now she made the sudden
5445 resolution of not passing their door without going in--observing,
5446 as she proposed it to Harriet, that, as well as she could calculate,
5447 they were just now quite safe from any letter from Jane Fairfax.
5448 
5449 The house belonged to people in business.  Mrs. and Miss Bates occupied
5450 the drawing-room floor; and there, in the very moderate-sized apartment,
5451 which was every thing to them, the visitors were most cordially
5452 and even gratefully welcomed; the quiet neat old lady, who with her
5453 knitting was seated in the warmest corner, wanting even to give up
5454 her place to Miss Woodhouse, and her more active, talking daughter,
5455 almost ready to overpower them with care and kindness, thanks for
5456 their visit, solicitude for their shoes, anxious inquiries after
5457 Mr. Woodhouse's health, cheerful communications about her mother's,
5458 and sweet-cake from the beaufet--"Mrs. Cole had just been there,
5459 just called in for ten minutes, and had been so good as to sit an
5460 hour with them, and _she_ had taken a piece of cake and been so kind
5461 as to say she liked it very much; and, therefore, she hoped Miss
5462 Woodhouse and Miss Smith would do them the favour to eat a piece too."
5463 
5464 The mention of the Coles was sure to be followed by that of Mr. Elton.
5465 There was intimacy between them, and Mr. Cole had heard from
5466 Mr. Elton since his going away.  Emma knew what was coming; they must
5467 have the letter over again, and settle how long he had been gone,
5468 and how much he was engaged in company, and what a favourite he
5469 was wherever he went, and how full the Master of the Ceremonies'
5470 ball had been; and she went through it very well, with all the
5471 interest and all the commendation that could be requisite, and always
5472 putting forward to prevent Harriet's being obliged to say a word.
5473 
5474 This she had been prepared for when she entered the house;
5475 but meant, having once talked him handsomely over, to be no farther
5476 incommoded by any troublesome topic, and to wander at large amongst
5477 all the Mistresses and Misses of Highbury, and their card-parties.
5478 She had not been prepared to have Jane Fairfax succeed Mr. Elton;
5479 but he was actually hurried off by Miss Bates, she jumped away
5480 from him at last abruptly to the Coles, to usher in a letter from
5481 her niece.
5482 
5483 "Oh! yes--Mr. Elton, I understand--certainly as to dancing--
5484 Mrs. Cole was telling me that dancing at the rooms at Bath was--
5485 Mrs. Cole was so kind as to sit some time with us, talking of Jane;
5486 for as soon as she came in, she began inquiring after her,
5487 Jane is so very great a favourite there.  Whenever she is with us,
5488 Mrs. Cole does not know how to shew her kindness enough;
5489 and I must say that Jane deserves it as much as any body can.
5490 And so she began inquiring after her directly, saying, `I know you
5491 cannot have heard from Jane lately, because it is not her time
5492 for writing;' and when I immediately said, `But indeed we have,
5493 we had a letter this very morning,' I do not know that I ever saw
5494 any body more surprized.  `Have you, upon your honour?' said she;
5495 `well, that is quite unexpected.  Do let me hear what she says.'"
5496 
5497 Emma's politeness was at hand directly, to say, with smiling interest--
5498 
5499 "Have you heard from Miss Fairfax so lately?  I am extremely happy.
5500 I hope she is well?"
5501 
5502 "Thank you.  You are so kind!" replied the happily deceived aunt,
5503 while eagerly hunting for the letter.--"Oh! here it is.  I was sure
5504 it could not be far off; but I had put my huswife upon it, you see,
5505 without being aware, and so it was quite hid, but I had it in my hand
5506 so very lately that I was almost sure it must be on the table.
5507 I was reading it to Mrs. Cole, and since she went away, I was
5508 reading it again to my mother, for it is such a pleasure to her--
5509 a letter from Jane--that she can never hear it often enough;
5510 so I knew it could not be far off, and here it is, only just under
5511 my huswife--and since you are so kind as to wish to hear what
5512 she says;--but, first of all, I really must, in justice to Jane,
5513 apologise for her writing so short a letter--only two pages you see--
5514 hardly two--and in general she fills the whole paper and crosses half.
5515 My mother often wonders that I can make it out so well.
5516 She often says, when the letter is first opened, `Well, Hetty,
5517 now I think you will be put to it to make out all that checker-work'--
5518 don't you, ma'am?--And then I tell her, I am sure she would contrive
5519 to make it out herself, if she had nobody to do it for her--
5520 every word of it--I am sure she would pore over it till she had
5521 made out every word.  And, indeed, though my mother's eyes are not
5522 so good as they were, she can see amazingly well still, thank God!
5523 with the help of spectacles.  It is such a blessing!  My mother's
5524 are really very good indeed.  Jane often says, when she is here,
5525 `I am sure, grandmama, you must have had very strong eyes to see
5526 as you do--and so much fine work as you have done too!--I only wish
5527 my eyes may last me as well.'"
5528 
5529 All this spoken extremely fast obliged Miss Bates to stop for breath;
5530 and Emma said something very civil about the excellence of Miss
5531 Fairfax's handwriting.
5532 
5533 "You are extremely kind," replied Miss Bates, highly gratified;
5534 "you who are such a judge, and write so beautifully yourself.
5535 I am sure there is nobody's praise that could give us so much pleasure
5536 as Miss Woodhouse's. My mother does not hear; she is a little deaf
5537 you know.  Ma'am," addressing her, "do you hear what Miss Woodhouse
5538 is so obliging to say about Jane's handwriting?"
5539 
5540 And Emma had the advantage of hearing her own silly compliment
5541 repeated twice over before the good old lady could comprehend it.
5542 She was pondering, in the meanwhile, upon the possibility, without seeming
5543 very rude, of making her escape from Jane Fairfax's letter, and had
5544 almost resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse,
5545 when Miss Bates turned to her again and seized her attention.
5546 
5547 "My mother's deafness is very trifling you see--just nothing at all.
5548 By only raising my voice, and saying any thing two or three times over,
5549 she is sure to hear; but then she is used to my voice.  But it is very
5550 remarkable that she should always hear Jane better than she does me.
5551 Jane speaks so distinct!  However, she will not find her grandmama
5552 at all deafer than she was two years ago; which is saying a great
5553 deal at my mother's time of life--and it really is full two years,
5554 you know, since she was here.  We never were so long without seeing
5555 her before, and as I was telling Mrs. Cole, we shall hardly know
5556 how to make enough of her now."
5557 
5558 "Are you expecting Miss Fairfax here soon?"
5559 
5560 "Oh yes; next week."
5561 
5562 "Indeed!--that must be a very great pleasure."
5563 
5564 "Thank you.  You are very kind.  Yes, next week.  Every body is
5565 so surprized; and every body says the same obliging things.  I am
5566 sure she will be as happy to see her friends at Highbury, as they
5567 can be to see her.  Yes, Friday or Saturday; she cannot say which,
5568 because Colonel Campbell will be wanting the carriage himself one
5569 of those days.  So very good of them to send her the whole way!
5570 But they always do, you know.  Oh yes, Friday or Saturday next.
5571 That is what she writes about.  That is the reason of her writing out
5572 of rule, as we call it; for, in the common course, we should not have
5573 heard from her before next Tuesday or Wednesday."
5574 
5575 "Yes, so I imagined.  I was afraid there could be little chance
5576 of my hearing any thing of Miss Fairfax to-day."
5577 
5578 "So obliging of you!  No, we should not have heard, if it had not
5579 been for this particular circumstance, of her being to come here
5580 so soon.  My mother is so delighted!--for she is to be three months
5581 with us at least.  Three months, she says so, positively, as I
5582 am going to have the pleasure of reading to you.  The case is,
5583 you see, that the Campbells are going to Ireland.  Mrs. Dixon has
5584 persuaded her father and mother to come over and see her directly.
5585 They had not intended to go over till the summer, but she is so
5586 impatient to see them again--for till she married, last October,
5587 she was never away from them so much as a week, which must make
5588 it very strange to be in different kingdoms, I was going to say,
5589 but however different countries, and so she wrote a very urgent letter
5590 to her mother--or her father, I declare I do not know which it was,
5591 but we shall see presently in Jane's letter--wrote in Mr. Dixon's
5592 name as well as her own, to press their coming over directly,
5593 and they would give them the meeting in Dublin, and take them back
5594 to their country seat, Baly-craig, a beautiful place, I fancy.
5595 Jane has heard a great deal of its beauty; from Mr. Dixon, I mean--
5596 I do not know that she ever heard about it from any body else;
5597 but it was very natural, you know, that he should like to speak
5598 of his own place while he was paying his addresses--and as Jane used
5599 to be very often walking out with them--for Colonel and Mrs. Campbell
5600 were very particular about their daughter's not walking out
5601 often with only Mr. Dixon, for which I do not at all blame them;
5602 of course she heard every thing he might be telling Miss Campbell
5603 about his own home in Ireland; and I think she wrote us word
5604 that he had shewn them some drawings of the place, views that he
5605 had taken himself.  He is a most amiable, charming young man,
5606 I believe.  Jane was quite longing to go to Ireland, from his account
5607 of things."
5608 
5609 At this moment, an ingenious and animating suspicion entering
5610 Emma's brain with regard to Jane Fairfax, this charming Mr. Dixon,
5611 and the not going to Ireland, she said, with the insidious design
5612 of farther discovery,
5613 
5614 "You must feel it very fortunate that Miss Fairfax should be allowed
5615 to come to you at such a time.  Considering the very particular
5616 friendship between her and Mrs. Dixon, you could hardly have expected
5617 her to be excused from accompanying Colonel and Mrs. Campbell."
5618 
5619 "Very true, very true, indeed.  The very thing that we have always
5620 been rather afraid of; for we should not have liked to have her
5621 at such a distance from us, for months together--not able to come
5622 if any thing was to happen.  But you see, every thing turns out
5623 for the best.  They want her (Mr. and Mrs. Dixon) excessively to
5624 come over with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell; quite depend upon it;
5625 nothing can be more kind or pressing than their _joint_ invitation,
5626 Jane says, as you will hear presently; Mr. Dixon does not seem in the
5627 least backward in any attention.  He is a most charming young man.
5628 Ever since the service he rendered Jane at Weymouth, when they were
5629 out in that party on the water, and she, by the sudden whirling
5630 round of something or other among the sails, would have been dashed
5631 into the sea at once, and actually was all but gone, if he had not,
5632 with the greatest presence of mind, caught hold of her habit--
5633 (I can never think of it without trembling!)--But ever since we
5634 had the history of that day, I have been so fond of Mr. Dixon!"
5635 
5636 "But, in spite of all her friends' urgency, and her own wish
5637 of seeing Ireland, Miss Fairfax prefers devoting the time to you
5638 and Mrs. Bates?"
5639 
5640 "Yes--entirely her own doing, entirely her own choice; and Colonel
5641 and Mrs. Campbell think she does quite right, just what they
5642 should recommend; and indeed they particularly _wish_ her to try
5643 her native air, as she has not been quite so well as usual lately."
5644 
5645 "I am concerned to hear of it.  I think they judge wisely.
5646 But Mrs. Dixon must be very much disappointed.  Mrs. Dixon,
5647 I understand, has no remarkable degree of personal beauty; is not,
5648 by any means, to be compared with Miss Fairfax."
5649 
5650 "Oh! no.  You are very obliging to say such things--but certainly not.
5651 There is no comparison between them.  Miss Campbell always was
5652 absolutely plain--but extremely elegant and amiable."
5653 
5654 "Yes, that of course."
5655 
5656 "Jane caught a bad cold, poor thing! so long ago as the 7th
5657 of November, (as I am going to read to you,) and has never been
5658 well since.  A long time, is not it, for a cold to hang upon her?
5659 She never mentioned it before, because she would not alarm us.
5660 Just like her! so considerate!--But however, she is so far from well,
5661 that her kind friends the Campbells think she had better come home,
5662 and try an air that always agrees with her; and they have no doubt
5663 that three or four months at Highbury will entirely cure her--
5664 and it is certainly a great deal better that she should come here,
5665 than go to Ireland, if she is unwell. Nobody could nurse her, as we
5666 should do."
5667 
5668 "It appears to me the most desirable arrangement in the world."
5669 
5670 "And so she is to come to us next Friday or Saturday, and the
5671 Campbells leave town in their way to Holyhead the Monday following--
5672 as you will find from Jane's letter.  So sudden!--You may guess,
5673 dear Miss Woodhouse, what a flurry it has thrown me in!
5674 If it was not for the drawback of her illness--but I am afraid
5675 we must expect to see her grown thin, and looking very poorly.
5676 I must tell you what an unlucky thing happened to me, as to that.
5677 I always make a point of reading Jane's letters through to myself first,
5678 before I read them aloud to my mother, you know, for fear of there
5679 being any thing in them to distress her.  Jane desired me to do it,
5680 so I always do:  and so I began to-day with my usual caution;
5681 but no sooner did I come to the mention of her being unwell, than I
5682 burst out, quite frightened, with `Bless me! poor Jane is ill!'--
5683 which my mother, being on the watch, heard distinctly, and was sadly
5684 alarmed at.  However, when I read on, I found it was not near so bad
5685 as I had fancied at first; and I make so light of it now to her,
5686 that she does not think much about it.  But I cannot imagine
5687 how I could be so off my guard.  If Jane does not get well soon,
5688 we will call in Mr. Perry.  The expense shall not be thought of;
5689 and though he is so liberal, and so fond of Jane that I dare say
5690 he would not mean to charge any thing for attendance, we could not
5691 suffer it to be so, you know.  He has a wife and family to maintain,
5692 and is not to be giving away his time.  Well, now I have just given you
5693 a hint of what Jane writes about, we will turn to her letter, and I am
5694 sure she tells her own story a great deal better than I can tell it
5695 for her."
5696 
5697 "I am afraid we must be running away," said Emma, glancing at Harriet,
5698 and beginning to rise--"My father will be expecting us.
5699 I had no intention, I thought I had no power of staying more than
5700 five minutes, when I first entered the house.  I merely called,
5701 because I would not pass the door without inquiring after Mrs. Bates;
5702 but I have been so pleasantly detained!  Now, however, we must wish
5703 you and Mrs. Bates good morning."
5704 
5705 And not all that could be urged to detain her succeeded.
5706 She regained the street--happy in this, that though much had been
5707 forced on her against her will, though she had in fact heard
5708 the whole substance of Jane Fairfax's letter, she had been able
5709 to escape the letter itself.
5710 
5711 
5712 
5713 CHAPTER II
5714 
5715 
5716 Jane Fairfax was an orphan, the only child of Mrs. Bates's
5717 youngest daughter.
5718 
5719 The marriage of Lieut. Fairfax of the _______ regiment of infantry,
5720 and Miss Jane Bates, had had its day of fame and pleasure,
5721 hope and interest; but nothing now remained of it, save the melancholy
5722 remembrance of him dying in action abroad--of his widow sinking
5723 under consumption and grief soon afterwards--and this girl.
5724 
5725 By birth she belonged to Highbury:  and when at three years old,
5726 on losing her mother, she became the property, the charge,
5727 the consolation, the fondling of her grandmother and aunt, there had
5728 seemed every probability of her being permanently fixed there;
5729 of her being taught only what very limited means could command,
5730 and growing up with no advantages of connexion or improvement,
5731 to be engrafted on what nature had given her in a pleasing person,
5732 good understanding, and warm-hearted, well-meaning relations.
5733 
5734 But the compassionate feelings of a friend of her father gave
5735 a change to her destiny.  This was Colonel Campbell, who had
5736 very highly regarded Fairfax, as an excellent officer and most
5737 deserving young man; and farther, had been indebted to him for
5738 such attentions, during a severe camp-fever, as he believed had saved
5739 his life.  These were claims which he did not learn to overlook,
5740 though some years passed away from the death of poor Fairfax,
5741 before his own return to England put any thing in his power.
5742 When he did return, he sought out the child and took notice of her.
5743 He was a married man, with only one living child, a girl,
5744 about Jane's age:  and Jane became their guest, paying them long visits
5745 and growing a favourite with all; and before she was nine years old,
5746 his daughter's great fondness for her, and his own wish of being
5747 a real friend, united to produce an offer from Colonel Campbell
5748 of undertaking the whole charge of her education.  It was accepted;
5749 and from that period Jane had belonged to Colonel Campbell's family,
5750 and had lived with them entirely, only visiting her grandmother
5751 from time to time.
5752 
5753 The plan was that she should be brought up for educating others;
5754 the very few hundred pounds which she inherited from her father
5755 making independence impossible.  To provide for her otherwise
5756 was out of Colonel Campbell's power; for though his income, by pay
5757 and appointments, was handsome, his fortune was moderate and must
5758 be all his daughter's; but, by giving her an education, he hoped
5759 to be supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter.
5760 
5761 Such was Jane Fairfax's history.  She had fallen into good hands,
5762 known nothing but kindness from the Campbells, and been given
5763 an excellent education.  Living constantly with right-minded
5764 and well-informed people, her heart and understanding had received
5765 every advantage of discipline and culture; and Colonel Campbell's
5766 residence being in London, every lighter talent had been done
5767 full justice to, by the attendance of first-rate masters.
5768 Her disposition and abilities were equally worthy of all that
