5769 friendship could do; and at eighteen or nineteen she was, as far
5770 as such an early age can be qualified for the care of children,
5771 fully competent to the office of instruction herself; but she
5772 was too much beloved to be parted with.  Neither father nor mother
5773 could promote, and the daughter could not endure it.  The evil day
5774 was put off.  It was easy to decide that she was still too young;
5775 and Jane remained with them, sharing, as another daughter, in all
5776 the rational pleasures of an elegant society, and a judicious
5777 mixture of home and amusement, with only the drawback of the future,
5778 the sobering suggestions of her own good understanding to remind
5779 her that all this might soon be over.
5780 
5781 The affection of the whole family, the warm attachment of Miss
5782 Campbell in particular, was the more honourable to each party
5783 from the circumstance of Jane's decided superiority both in beauty
5784 and acquirements.  That nature had given it in feature could not
5785 be unseen by the young woman, nor could her higher powers of mind
5786 be unfelt by the parents.  They continued together with unabated
5787 regard however, till the marriage of Miss Campbell, who by that chance,
5788 that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs,
5789 giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior,
5790 engaged the affections of Mr. Dixon, a young man, rich and agreeable,
5791 almost as soon as they were acquainted; and was eligibly
5792 and happily settled, while Jane Fairfax had yet her bread to earn.
5793 
5794 This event had very lately taken place; too lately for any thing to be
5795 yet attempted by her less fortunate friend towards entering on her path
5796 of duty; though she had now reached the age which her own judgment
5797 had fixed on for beginning.  She had long resolved that one-and-twenty
5798 should be the period.  With the fortitude of a devoted novitiate,
5799 she had resolved at one-and-twenty to complete the sacrifice,
5800 and retire from all the pleasures of life, of rational intercourse,
5801 equal society, peace and hope, to penance and mortification for ever.
5802 
5803 The good sense of Colonel and Mrs. Campbell could not oppose such
5804 a resolution, though their feelings did.  As long as they lived,
5805 no exertions would be necessary, their home might be hers for ever;
5806 and for their own comfort they would have retained her wholly;
5807 but this would be selfishness:--what must be at last, had better
5808 be soon.  Perhaps they began to feel it might have been kinder
5809 and wiser to have resisted the temptation of any delay, and spared
5810 her from a taste of such enjoyments of ease and leisure as must
5811 now be relinquished.  Still, however, affection was glad to catch
5812 at any reasonable excuse for not hurrying on the wretched moment.
5813 She had never been quite well since the time of their daughter's marriage;
5814 and till she should have completely recovered her usual strength,
5815 they must forbid her engaging in duties, which, so far from being
5816 compatible with a weakened frame and varying spirits, seemed,
5817 under the most favourable circumstances, to require something
5818 more than human perfection of body and mind to be discharged with
5819 tolerable comfort.
5820 
5821 With regard to her not accompanying them to Ireland, her account
5822 to her aunt contained nothing but truth, though there might be some
5823 truths not told.  It was her own choice to give the time of their
5824 absence to Highbury; to spend, perhaps, her last months of perfect
5825 liberty with those kind relations to whom she was so very dear:
5826 and the Campbells, whatever might be their motive or motives,
5827 whether single, or double, or treble, gave the arrangement
5828 their ready sanction, and said, that they depended more on a few
5829 months spent in her native air, for the recovery of her health,
5830 than on any thing else.  Certain it was that she was to come;
5831 and that Highbury, instead of welcoming that perfect novelty which
5832 had been so long promised it--Mr. Frank Churchill--must put up for
5833 the present with Jane Fairfax, who could bring only the freshness
5834 of a two years' absence.
5835 
5836 Emma was sorry;--to have to pay civilities to a person she did
5837 not like through three long months!--to be always doing more than
5838 she wished, and less than she ought!  Why she did not like Jane
5839 Fairfax might be a difficult question to answer; Mr. Knightley
5840 had once told her it was because she saw in her the really
5841 accomplished young woman, which she wanted to be thought herself;
5842 and though the accusation had been eagerly refuted at the time,
5843 there were moments of self-examination in which her conscience could
5844 not quite acquit her.  But "she could never get acquainted with her:
5845 she did not know how it was, but there was such coldness and reserve--
5846 such apparent indifference whether she pleased or not--and then,
5847 her aunt was such an eternal talker!--and she was made such a fuss
5848 with by every body!--and it had been always imagined that they were
5849 to be so intimate--because their ages were the same, every body had
5850 supposed they must be so fond of each other."  These were her reasons--
5851 she had no better.
5852 
5853 It was a dislike so little just--every imputed fault was so magnified
5854 by fancy, that she never saw Jane Fairfax the first time after any
5855 considerable absence, without feeling that she had injured her;
5856 and now, when the due visit was paid, on her arrival, after a two years'
5857 interval, she was particularly struck with the very appearance
5858 and manners, which for those two whole years she had been depreciating.
5859 Jane Fairfax was very elegant, remarkably elegant; and she had
5860 herself the highest value for elegance.  Her height was pretty,
5861 just such as almost every body would think tall, and nobody could
5862 think very tall; her figure particularly graceful; her size a most
5863 becoming medium, between fat and thin, though a slight appearance
5864 of ill-health seemed to point out the likeliest evil of the two.
5865 Emma could not but feel all this; and then, her face--her features--
5866 there was more beauty in them altogether than she had remembered;
5867 it was not regular, but it was very pleasing beauty.  Her eyes,
5868 a deep grey, with dark eye-lashes and eyebrows, had never been denied
5869 their praise; but the skin, which she had been used to cavil at,
5870 as wanting colour, had a clearness and delicacy which really needed
5871 no fuller bloom.  It was a style of beauty, of which elegance
5872 was the reigning character, and as such, she must, in honour,
5873 by all her principles, admire it:--elegance, which, whether of person
5874 or of mind, she saw so little in Highbury.  There, not to be vulgar,
5875 was distinction, and merit.
5876 
5877 In short, she sat, during the first visit, looking at Jane Fairfax
5878 with twofold complacency; the sense of pleasure and the sense
5879 of rendering justice, and was determining that she would dislike
5880 her no longer.  When she took in her history, indeed, her situation,
5881 as well as her beauty; when she considered what all this elegance
5882 was destined to, what she was going to sink from, how she was going
5883 to live, it seemed impossible to feel any thing but compassion
5884 and respect; especially, if to every well-known particular entitling
5885 her to interest, were added the highly probable circumstance
5886 of an attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she had so naturally started
5887 to herself.  In that case, nothing could be more pitiable
5888 or more honourable than the sacrifices she had resolved on.
5889 Emma was very willing now to acquit her of having seduced
5890 Mr. Dixon's actions from his wife, or of any thing mischievous
5891 which her imagination had suggested at first.  If it were love,
5892 it might be simple, single, successless love on her side alone.
5893 She might have been unconsciously sucking in the sad poison,
5894 while a sharer of his conversation with her friend; and from the best,
5895 the purest of motives, might now be denying herself this visit
5896 to Ireland, and resolving to divide herself effectually from
5897 him and his connexions by soon beginning her career of laborious duty.
5898 
5899 Upon the whole, Emma left her with such softened, charitable feelings,
5900 as made her look around in walking home, and lament that Highbury
5901 afforded no young man worthy of giving her independence;
5902 nobody that she could wish to scheme about for her.
5903 
5904 These were charming feelings--but not lasting.  Before she had
5905 committed herself by any public profession of eternal friendship for
5906 Jane Fairfax, or done more towards a recantation of past prejudices
5907 and errors, than saying to Mr. Knightley, "She certainly is handsome;
5908 she is better than handsome!"  Jane had spent an evening at Hartfield
5909 with her grandmother and aunt, and every thing was relapsing much
5910 into its usual state.  Former provocations reappeared.  The aunt
5911 was as tiresome as ever; more tiresome, because anxiety for her
5912 health was now added to admiration of her powers; and they had to
5913 listen to the description of exactly how little bread and butter
5914 she ate for breakfast, and how small a slice of mutton for dinner,
5915 as well as to see exhibitions of new caps and new workbags for her
5916 mother and herself; and Jane's offences rose again.  They had music;
5917 Emma was obliged to play; and the thanks and praise which necessarily
5918 followed appeared to her an affectation of candour, an air
5919 of greatness, meaning only to shew off in higher style her own very
5920 superior performance.  She was, besides, which was the worst of all,
5921 so cold, so cautious!  There was no getting at her real opinion.
5922 Wrapt up in a cloak of politeness, she seemed determined
5923 to hazard nothing.  She was disgustingly, was suspiciously reserved.
5924 
5925 If any thing could be more, where all was most, she was more
5926 reserved on the subject of Weymouth and the Dixons than any thing.
5927 She seemed bent on giving no real insight into Mr. Dixon's character,
5928 or her own value for his company, or opinion of the suitableness
5929 of the match.  It was all general approbation and smoothness;
5930 nothing delineated or distinguished.  It did her no service however.
5931 Her caution was thrown away.  Emma saw its artifice, and returned
5932 to her first surmises.  There probably _was_ something more to conceal
5933 than her own preference; Mr. Dixon, perhaps, had been very near
5934 changing one friend for the other, or been fixed only to Miss Campbell,
5935 for the sake of the future twelve thousand pounds.
5936 
5937 The like reserve prevailed on other topics.  She and Mr. Frank Churchill
5938 had been at Weymouth at the same time.  It was known that they were
5939 a little acquainted; but not a syllable of real information could Emma
5940 procure as to what he truly was.  "Was he handsome?"--"She believed
5941 he was reckoned a very fine young man."  "Was he agreeable?"--
5942 "He was generally thought so."  "Did he appear a sensible young man;
5943 a young man of information?"--"At a watering-place, or in a common
5944 London acquaintance, it was difficult to decide on such points.
5945 Manners were all that could be safely judged of, under a much longer
5946 knowledge than they had yet had of Mr. Churchill.  She believed
5947 every body found his manners pleasing."  Emma could not forgive her.
5948 
5949 
5950 
5951 CHAPTER III
5952 
5953 
5954 Emma could not forgive her;--but as neither provocation nor resentment
5955 were discerned by Mr. Knightley, who had been of the party, and had
5956 seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side,
5957 he was expressing the next morning, being at Hartfield again on
5958 business with Mr. Woodhouse, his approbation of the whole; not so
5959 openly as he might have done had her father been out of the room,
5960 but speaking plain enough to be very intelligible to Emma.
5961 He had been used to think her unjust to Jane, and had now great
5962 pleasure in marking an improvement.
5963 
5964 "A very pleasant evening," he began, as soon as Mr. Woodhouse
5965 had been talked into what was necessary, told that he understood,
5966 and the papers swept away;--"particularly pleasant.  You and Miss
5967 Fairfax gave us some very good music.  I do not know a more
5968 luxurious state, sir, than sitting at one's ease to be entertained
5969 a whole evening by two such young women; sometimes with music
5970 and sometimes with conversation.  I am sure Miss Fairfax must
5971 have found the evening pleasant, Emma.  You left nothing undone.
5972 I was glad you made her play so much, for having no instrument
5973 at her grandmother's, it must have been a real indulgence."
5974 
5975 "I am happy you approved," said Emma, smiling; "but I hope I am
5976 not often deficient in what is due to guests at Hartfield."
5977 
5978 "No, my dear," said her father instantly; "_that_ I am sure you
5979 are not.  There is nobody half so attentive and civil as you are.
5980 If any thing, you are too attentive.  The muffin last night--if it
5981 had been handed round once, I think it would have been enough."
5982 
5983 "No," said Mr. Knightley, nearly at the same time; "you are not
5984 often deficient; not often deficient either in manner or comprehension.
5985 I think you understand me, therefore."
5986 
5987 An arch look expressed--"I understand you well enough;" but she
5988 said only, "Miss Fairfax is reserved."
5989 
5990 "I always told you she was--a little; but you will soon overcome
5991 all that part of her reserve which ought to be overcome, all that
5992 has its foundation in diffidence.  What arises from discretion
5993 must be honoured."
5994 
5995 "You think her diffident.  I do not see it."
5996 
5997 "My dear Emma," said he, moving from his chair into one close
5998 by her, "you are not going to tell me, I hope, that you
5999 had not a pleasant evening."
6000 
6001 "Oh! no; I was pleased with my own perseverance in asking questions;
6002 and amused to think how little information I obtained."
6003 
6004 "I am disappointed," was his only answer.
6005 
6006 "I hope every body had a pleasant evening," said Mr. Woodhouse,
6007 in his quiet way.  "I had.  Once, I felt the fire rather too much;
6008 but then I moved back my chair a little, a very little, and it did
6009 not disturb me.  Miss Bates was very chatty and good-humoured,
6010 as she always is, though she speaks rather too quick.  However,
6011 she is very agreeable, and Mrs. Bates too, in a different way.
6012 I like old friends; and Miss Jane Fairfax is a very pretty sort of
6013 young lady, a very pretty and a very well-behaved young lady indeed.
6014 She must have found the evening agreeable, Mr. Knightley, because she
6015 had Emma."
6016 
6017 "True, sir; and Emma, because she had Miss Fairfax."
6018 
6019 Emma saw his anxiety, and wishing to appease it, at least for
6020 the present, said, and with a sincerity which no one could question--
6021 
6022 "She is a sort of elegant creature that one cannot keep one's eyes from.
6023 I am always watching her to admire; and I do pity her from my heart."
6024 
6025 Mr. Knightley looked as if he were more gratified than he cared
6026 to express; and before he could make any reply, Mr. Woodhouse,
6027 whose thoughts were on the Bates's, said--
6028 
6029 "It is a great pity that their circumstances should be so confined!
6030 a great pity indeed! and I have often wished--but it is so little one
6031 can venture to do--small, trifling presents, of any thing uncommon--
6032 Now we have killed a porker, and Emma thinks of sending them
6033 a loin or a leg; it is very small and delicate--Hartfield pork is
6034 not like any other pork--but still it is pork--and, my dear Emma,
6035 unless one could be sure of their making it into steaks, nicely fried,
6036 as ours are fried, without the smallest grease, and not roast it,
6037 for no stomach can bear roast pork--I think we had better send the leg--
6038 do not you think so, my dear?"
6039 
6040 "My dear papa, I sent the whole hind-quarter. I knew you would wish it.
6041 There will be the leg to be salted, you know, which is so very nice,
6042 and the loin to be dressed directly in any manner they like."
6043 
6044 "That's right, my dear, very right.  I had not thought of it before,
6045 but that is the best way.  They must not over-salt the leg; and then,
6046 if it is not over-salted, and if it is very thoroughly boiled,
6047 just as Serle boils ours, and eaten very moderately of, with a
6048 boiled turnip, and a little carrot or parsnip, I do not consider
6049 it unwholesome."
6050 
6051 "Emma," said Mr. Knightley presently, "I have a piece of news for you.
6052 You like news--and I heard an article in my way hither that I think
6053 will interest you."
6054 
6055 "News!  Oh! yes, I always like news.  What is it?--why do you
6056 smile so?--where did you hear it?--at Randalls?"
6057 
6058 He had time only to say,
6059 
6060 "No, not at Randalls; I have not been near Randalls," when the door
6061 was thrown open, and Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax walked into the room.
6062 Full of thanks, and full of news, Miss Bates knew not which to
6063 give quickest.  Mr. Knightley soon saw that he had lost his moment,
6064 and that not another syllable of communication could rest with him.
6065 
6066 "Oh! my dear sir, how are you this morning?  My dear Miss Woodhouse--
6067 I come quite over-powered. Such a beautiful hind-quarter of pork!
6068 You are too bountiful!  Have you heard the news?  Mr. Elton is going
6069 to be married."
6070 
6071 Emma had not had time even to think of Mr. Elton, and she was
6072 so completely surprized that she could not avoid a little start,
6073 and a little blush, at the sound.
6074 
6075 "There is my news:--I thought it would interest you,"
6076 said Mr. Knightley, with a smile which implied a conviction
6077 of some part of what had passed between them.
6078 
6079 "But where could _you_ hear it?" cried Miss Bates.  "Where could
6080 you possibly hear it, Mr. Knightley?  For it is not five minutes
6081 since I received Mrs. Cole's note--no, it cannot be more than five--
6082 or at least ten--for I had got my bonnet and spencer on, just ready
6083 to come out--I was only gone down to speak to Patty again about
6084 the pork--Jane was standing in the passage--were not you, Jane?--
6085 for my mother was so afraid that we had not any salting-pan
6086 large enough.  So I said I would go down and see, and Jane said,
6087 `Shall I go down instead? for I think you have a little cold,
6088 and Patty has been washing the kitchen.'--`Oh! my dear,'
6089 said I--well, and just then came the note.  A Miss Hawkins--
6090 that's all I know.  A Miss Hawkins of Bath.  But, Mr. Knightley,
6091 how could you possibly have heard it? for the very moment Mr. Cole
6092 told Mrs. Cole of it, she sat down and wrote to me.  A Miss Hawkins--"
6093 
6094 "I was with Mr. Cole on business an hour and a half ago.
6095 He had just read Elton's letter as I was shewn in, and handed it
6096 to me directly."
6097 
6098 "Well! that is quite--I suppose there never was a piece of news more
6099 generally interesting.  My dear sir, you really are too bountiful.
6100 My mother desires her very best compliments and regards, and a
6101 thousand thanks, and says you really quite oppress her."
6102 
6103 "We consider our Hartfield pork," replied Mr. Woodhouse--"indeed it
6104 certainly is, so very superior to all other pork, that Emma and I
6105 cannot have a greater pleasure than--"
6106 
6107 "Oh! my dear sir, as my mother says, our friends are only too good
6108 to us.  If ever there were people who, without having great wealth
6109 themselves, had every thing they could wish for, I am sure it is us.
6110 We may well say that `our lot is cast in a goodly heritage.'
6111 Well, Mr. Knightley, and so you actually saw the letter; well--"
6112 
6113 "It was short--merely to announce--but cheerful, exulting, of course."--
6114 Here was a sly glance at Emma.  "He had been so fortunate as to--
6115 I forget the precise words--one has no business to remember them.
6116 The information was, as you state, that he was going to be married
6117 to a Miss Hawkins.  By his style, I should imagine it just settled."
6118 
6119 "Mr. Elton going to be married!" said Emma, as soon as she could speak.
6120 "He will have every body's wishes for his happiness."
6121 
6122 "He is very young to settle," was Mr. Woodhouse's observation.
6123 "He had better not be in a hurry.  He seemed to me very well off
6124 as he was.  We were always glad to see him at Hartfield."
6125 
6126 "A new neighbour for us all, Miss Woodhouse!" said Miss Bates,
6127 joyfully; "my mother is so pleased!--she says she cannot
6128 bear to have the poor old Vicarage without a mistress.
6129 This is great news, indeed.  Jane, you have never seen
6130 Mr. Elton!--no wonder that you have such a curiosity to see him."
6131 
6132 Jane's curiosity did not appear of that absorbing nature as wholly
6133 to occupy her.
6134 
6135 "No--I have never seen Mr. Elton," she replied, starting on this appeal;
6136 "is he--is he a tall man?"
6137 
6138 "Who shall answer that question?" cried Emma.  "My father would
6139 say `yes,' Mr. Knightley `no;' and Miss Bates and I that he is
6140 just the happy medium.  When you have been here a little longer,
6141 Miss Fairfax, you will understand that Mr. Elton is the standard
6142 of perfection in Highbury, both in person and mind."
6143 
6144 "Very true, Miss Woodhouse, so she will.  He is the very best
6145 young man--But, my dear Jane, if you remember, I told you yesterday
6146 he was precisely the height of Mr. Perry.  Miss Hawkins,--I dare say,
6147 an excellent young woman.  His extreme attention to my mother--
6148 wanting her to sit in the vicarage pew, that she might hear the better,
6149 for my mother is a little deaf, you know--it is not much, but she
6150 does not hear quite quick.  Jane says that Colonel Campbell is a
6151 little deaf.  He fancied bathing might be good for it--the warm bath--
6152 but she says it did him no lasting benefit.  Colonel Campbell,
6153 you know, is quite our angel.  And Mr. Dixon seems a very charming
6154 young man, quite worthy of him.  It is such a happiness when good
6155 people get together--and they always do.  Now, here will be Mr. Elton
6156 and Miss Hawkins; and there are the Coles, such very good people;
6157 and the Perrys--I suppose there never was a happier or a better couple
6158 than Mr. and Mrs. Perry.  I say, sir," turning to Mr. Woodhouse,
6159 "I think there are few places with such society as Highbury.
6160 I always say, we are quite blessed in our neighbours.--My dear sir,
6161 if there is one thing my mother loves better than another, it is pork--
6162 a roast loin of pork--"
6163 
6164 "As to who, or what Miss Hawkins is, or how long he has been
6165 acquainted with her," said Emma, "nothing I suppose can be known.
6166 One feels that it cannot be a very long acquaintance.  He has been
6167 gone only four weeks."
6168 
6169 Nobody had any information to give; and, after a few more wonderings,
6170 Emma said,
6171 
6172 "You are silent, Miss Fairfax--but I hope you mean to take
6173 an interest in this news.  You, who have been hearing and seeing
6174 so much of late on these subjects, who must have been so deep
6175 in the business on Miss Campbell's account--we shall not excuse
6176 your being indifferent about Mr. Elton and Miss Hawkins."
6177 
6178 "When I have seen Mr. Elton," replied Jane, "I dare say I
6179 shall be interested--but I believe it requires _that_ with me.
6180 And as it is some months since Miss Campbell married, the impression
6181 may be a little worn off."
6182 
6183 "Yes, he has been gone just four weeks, as you observe, Miss Woodhouse,"
6184 said Miss Bates, "four weeks yesterday.--A Miss Hawkins!--Well, I had
6185 always rather fancied it would be some young lady hereabouts;
6186 not that I ever--Mrs. Cole once whispered to me--but I immediately said,
6187 `No, Mr. Elton is a most worthy young man--but'--In short, I do
6188 not think I am particularly quick at those sort of discoveries.
6189 I do not pretend to it.  What is before me, I see.  At the same time,
6190 nobody could wonder if Mr. Elton should have aspired--Miss Woodhouse
6191 lets me chatter on, so good-humouredly. She knows I would not
6192 offend for the world.  How does Miss Smith do?  She seems quite
6193 recovered now.  Have you heard from Mrs. John Knightley lately?
6194 Oh! those dear little children.  Jane, do you know I always fancy
6195 Mr. Dixon like Mr. John Knightley.  I mean in person--tall, and with
6196 that sort of look--and not very talkative."
6197 
6198 "Quite wrong, my dear aunt; there is no likeness at all."
6199 
6200 "Very odd! but one never does form a just idea of any body beforehand.
6201 One takes up a notion, and runs away with it.  Mr. Dixon, you say,
6202 is not, strictly speaking, handsome?"
6203 
6204 "Handsome!  Oh! no--far from it--certainly plain.  I told you he
6205 was plain."
6206 
6207 "My dear, you said that Miss Campbell would not allow him to be plain,
6208 and that you yourself--"
6209 
6210 "Oh! as for me, my judgment is worth nothing.  Where I have a regard,
6211 I always think a person well-looking. But I gave what I believed
6212 the general opinion, when I called him plain."
6213 
6214 "Well, my dear Jane, I believe we must be running away.
6215 The weather does not look well, and grandmama will be uneasy.
6216 You are too obliging, my dear Miss Woodhouse; but we really must
6217 take leave.  This has been a most agreeable piece of news indeed.
6218 I shall just go round by Mrs. Cole's; but I shall not stop three minutes:
6219 and, Jane, you had better go home directly--I would not have you
6220 out in a shower!--We think she is the better for Highbury already.
6221 Thank you, we do indeed.  I shall not attempt calling on Mrs. Goddard,
6222 for I really do not think she cares for any thing but _boiled_ pork:
6223 when we dress the leg it will be another thing.  Good morning to you,
6224 my dear sir.  Oh!  Mr. Knightley is coming too.  Well, that is
6225 so very!--I am sure if Jane is tired, you will be so kind as to
6226 give her your arm.--Mr. Elton, and Miss Hawkins!--Good morning
6227 to you."
6228 
6229 Emma, alone with her father, had half her attention wanted by him
6230 while he lamented that young people would be in such a hurry to marry--
6231 and to marry strangers too--and the other half she could give
6232 to her own view of the subject.  It was to herself an amusing
6233 and a very welcome piece of news, as proving that Mr. Elton
6234 could not have suffered long; but she was sorry for Harriet:
6235 Harriet must feel it--and all that she could hope was, by giving
6236 the first information herself, to save her from hearing it abruptly
6237 from others.  It was now about the time that she was likely to call.
6238 If she were to meet Miss Bates in her way!--and upon its beginning
6239 to rain, Emma was obliged to expect that the weather would be
6240 detaining her at Mrs. Goddard's, and that the intelligence would
6241 undoubtedly rush upon her without preparation.
6242 
6243 The shower was heavy, but short; and it had not been over five minutes,
6244 when in came Harriet, with just the heated, agitated look which
6245 hurrying thither with a full heart was likely to give; and the
6246 "Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what do you think has happened!" which instantly
6247 burst forth, had all the evidence of corresponding perturbation.
6248 As the blow was given, Emma felt that she could not now shew greater
6249 kindness than in listening; and Harriet, unchecked, ran eagerly
6250 through what she had to tell.  "She had set out from Mrs. Goddard's
6251 half an hour ago--she had been afraid it would rain--she had been
6252 afraid it would pour down every moment--but she thought she might
6253 get to Hartfield first--she had hurried on as fast as possible;
6254 but then, as she was passing by the house where a young woman
6255 was making up a gown for her, she thought she would just step
6256 in and see how it went on; and though she did not seem to stay
6257 half a moment there, soon after she came out it began to rain,
6258 and she did not know what to do; so she ran on directly, as fast
6259 as she could, and took shelter at Ford's."--Ford's was the principal
6260 woollen-draper, linen-draper, and haberdasher's shop united;
6261 the shop first in size and fashion in the place.--"And so,
6262 there she had set, without an idea of any thing in the world,
6263 full ten minutes, perhaps--when, all of a sudden, who should come in--
6264 to be sure it was so very odd!--but they always dealt at Ford's--
6265 who should come in, but Elizabeth Martin and her brother!--
6266 Dear Miss Woodhouse! only think.  I thought I should have fainted.
6267 I did not know what to do.  I was sitting near the door--Elizabeth saw
6268 me directly; but he did not; he was busy with the umbrella.
6269 I am sure she saw me, but she looked away directly, and took
6270 no notice; and they both went to quite the farther end of the shop;
6271 and I kept sitting near the door!--Oh! dear; I was so miserable!
6272 I am sure I must have been as white as my gown.  I could not go away
6273 you know, because of the rain; but I did so wish myself anywhere
6274 in the world but there.--Oh! dear, Miss Woodhouse--well, at last,
6275 I fancy, he looked round and saw me; for instead of going
6276 on with her buyings, they began whispering to one another.
6277 I am sure they were talking of me; and I could not help thinking
6278 that he was persuading her to speak to me--(do you think he was,
6279 Miss Woodhouse?)--for presently she came forward--came quite up
6280 to me, and asked me how I did, and seemed ready to shake hands,
6281 if I would.  She did not do any of it in the same way that she used;
6282 I could see she was altered; but, however, she seemed to _try_ to be
6283 very friendly, and we shook hands, and stood talking some time;
6284 but I know no more what I said--I was in such a tremble!--I remember
6285 she said she was sorry we never met now; which I thought almost
6286 too kind!  Dear, Miss Woodhouse, I was absolutely miserable!
6287 By that time, it was beginning to hold up, and I was determined
6288 that nothing should stop me from getting away--and then--only think!--
6289 I found he was coming up towards me too--slowly you know, and as
6290 if he did not quite know what to do; and so he came and spoke,
6291 and I answered--and I stood for a minute, feeling dreadfully,
6292 you know, one can't tell how; and then I took courage, and said it
6293 did not rain, and I must go; and so off I set; and I had not got
6294 three yards from the door, when he came after me, only to say,
6295 if I was going to Hartfield, he thought I had much better go round
6296 by Mr. Cole's stables, for I should find the near way quite floated
6297 by this rain.  Oh! dear, I thought it would have been the death of me!
6298 So I said, I was very much obliged to him:  you know I could
6299 not do less; and then he went back to Elizabeth, and I came round
6300 by the stables--I believe I did--but I hardly knew where I was,
6301 or any thing about it.  Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, I would rather done
6302 any thing than have it happen:  and yet, you know, there was a sort
6303 of satisfaction in seeing him behave so pleasantly and so kindly.
6304 And Elizabeth, too.  Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, do talk to me and make
6305 me comfortable again."
6306 
6307 Very sincerely did Emma wish to do so; but it was not immediately in
6308 her power.  She was obliged to stop and think.  She was not thoroughly
6309 comfortable herself.  The young man's conduct, and his sister's,
6310 seemed the result of real feeling, and she could not but pity them.
6311 As Harriet described it, there had been an interesting mixture
6312 of wounded affection and genuine delicacy in their behaviour.
6313 But she had believed them to be well-meaning, worthy people before;
6314 and what difference did this make in the evils of the connexion?
6315 It was folly to be disturbed by it.  Of course, he must be sorry
6316 to lose her--they must be all sorry.  Ambition, as well as love,
6317 had probably been mortified.  They might all have hoped to rise
6318 by Harriet's acquaintance:  and besides, what was the value of
6319 Harriet's description?--So easily pleased--so little discerning;--
6320 what signified her praise?
6321 
6322 She exerted herself, and did try to make her comfortable,
6323 by considering all that had passed as a mere trifle, and quite
6324 unworthy of being dwelt on,
6325 
6326 "It might be distressing, for the moment," said she; "but you seem
6327 to have behaved extremely well; and it is over--and may never--
6328 can never, as a first meeting, occur again, and therefore you need
6329 not think about it."
6330 
6331 Harriet said, "very true," and she "would not think about it;"
6332 but still she talked of it--still she could talk of nothing else;
6333 and Emma, at last, in order to put the Martins out of her head,
6334 was obliged to hurry on the news, which she had meant to give
6335 with so much tender caution; hardly knowing herself whether
6336 to rejoice or be angry, ashamed or only amused, at such a state
6337 of mind in poor Harriet--such a conclusion of Mr. Elton's importance
6338 with her!
6339 
6340 Mr. Elton's rights, however, gradually revived.  Though she did not
6341 feel the first intelligence as she might have done the day before,
6342 or an hour before, its interest soon increased; and before their
6343 first conversation was over, she had talked herself into all the
6344 sensations of curiosity, wonder and regret, pain and pleasure,
6345 as to this fortunate Miss Hawkins, which could conduce to place
6346 the Martins under proper subordination in her fancy.
6347 
6348 Emma learned to be rather glad that there had been such a meeting.
6349 It had been serviceable in deadening the first shock, without retaining
6350 any influence to alarm.  As Harriet now lived, the Martins could
6351 not get at her, without seeking her, where hitherto they had wanted
6352 either the courage or the condescension to seek her; for since her
6353 refusal of the brother, the sisters never had been at Mrs. Goddard's;
6354 and a twelvemonth might pass without their being thrown together again,
6355 with any necessity, or even any power of speech.
6356 
6357 
6358 
6359 CHAPTER IV
6360 
6361 
6362 Human nature is so well disposed towards those who are in
6363 interesting situations, that a young person, who either marries
6364 or dies, is sure of being kindly spoken of.
6365 
6366 A week had not passed since Miss Hawkins's name was first
6367 mentioned in Highbury, before she was, by some means or other,
6368 discovered to have every recommendation of person and mind;
6369 to be handsome, elegant, highly accomplished, and perfectly amiable:
6370 and when Mr. Elton himself arrived to triumph in his happy prospects,
6371 and circulate the fame of her merits, there was very little more
6372 for him to do, than to tell her Christian name, and say whose
6373 music she principally played.
6374 
6375 Mr. Elton returned, a very happy man.  He had gone away rejected
6376 and mortified--disappointed in a very sanguine hope, after a series
6377 of what appeared to him strong encouragement; and not only losing
6378 the right lady, but finding himself debased to the level of a very
6379 wrong one.  He had gone away deeply offended--he came back engaged
6380 to another--and to another as superior, of course, to the first,
6381 as under such circumstances what is gained always is to what is lost.
6382 He came back gay and self-satisfied, eager and busy, caring nothing
6383 for Miss Woodhouse, and defying Miss Smith.
6384 
6385 The charming Augusta Hawkins, in addition to all the usual advantages
6386 of perfect beauty and merit, was in possession of an independent fortune,
6387 of so many thousands as would always be called ten; a point of
6388 some dignity, as well as some convenience:  the story told well;
6389 he had not thrown himself away--he had gained a woman of 10,000 l.
6390 or thereabouts; and he had gained her with such delightful rapidity--
6391 the first hour of introduction had been so very soon followed by
6392 distinguishing notice; the history which he had to give Mrs. Cole
6393 of the rise and progress of the affair was so glorious--the steps
6394 so quick, from the accidental rencontre, to the dinner at Mr. Green's,
6395 and the party at Mrs. Brown's--smiles and blushes rising in importance--
6396 with consciousness and agitation richly scattered--the lady
6397 had been so easily impressed--so sweetly disposed--had in short,
6398 to use a most intelligible phrase, been so very ready to have him,
6399 that vanity and prudence were equally contented.
6400 
6401 He had caught both substance and shadow--both fortune and affection,
6402 and was just the happy man he ought to be; talking only of himself
6403 and his own concerns--expecting to be congratulated--ready to be
6404 laughed at--and, with cordial, fearless smiles, now addressing
6405 all the young ladies of the place, to whom, a few weeks ago,
6406 he would have been more cautiously gallant.
6407 
6408 The wedding was no distant event, as the parties had only themselves
6409 to please, and nothing but the necessary preparations to wait for;
6410 and when he set out for Bath again, there was a general expectation,
6411 which a certain glance of Mrs. Cole's did not seem to contradict,
6412 that when he next entered Highbury he would bring his bride.
6413 
6414 During his present short stay, Emma had barely seen him; but just
6415 enough to feel that the first meeting was over, and to give her
6416 the impression of his not being improved by the mixture of pique
6417 and pretension, now spread over his air.  She was, in fact,
6418 beginning very much to wonder that she had ever thought him pleasing
6419 at all; and his sight was so inseparably connected with some very
6420 disagreeable feelings, that, except in a moral light, as a penance,
6421 a lesson, a source of profitable humiliation to her own mind,
6422 she would have been thankful to be assured of never seeing him again.
6423 She wished him very well; but he gave her pain, and his welfare
6424 twenty miles off would administer most satisfaction.
6425 
6426 The pain of his continued residence in Highbury, however, must certainly
6427 be lessened by his marriage.  Many vain solicitudes would be prevented--
6428 many awkwardnesses smoothed by it.  A _Mrs._ _Elton_ would be an excuse for
6429 any change of intercourse; former intimacy might sink without remark.
6430 It would be almost beginning their life of civility again.
6431 
6432 Of the lady, individually, Emma thought very little.  She was good
6433 enough for Mr. Elton, no doubt; accomplished enough for Highbury--
6434 handsome enough--to look plain, probably, by Harriet's side.
6435 As to connexion, there Emma was perfectly easy; persuaded,
6436 that after all his own vaunted claims and disdain of Harriet,
6437 he had done nothing.  On that article, truth seemed attainable.
6438 _What_ she was, must be uncertain; but _who_ she was, might be found out;
6439 and setting aside the 10,000 l., it did not appear that she was at
6440 all Harriet's superior.  She brought no name, no blood, no alliance.
6441 Miss Hawkins was the youngest of the two daughters of a Bristol--
6442 merchant, of course, he must be called; but, as the whole of the
6443 profits of his mercantile life appeared so very moderate, it was
6444 not unfair to guess the dignity of his line of trade had been very
6445 moderate also.  Part of every winter she had been used to spend in Bath;
6446 but Bristol was her home, the very heart of Bristol; for though
6447 the father and mother had died some years ago, an uncle remained--
6448 in the law line--nothing more distinctly honourable was hazarded
6449 of him, than that he was in the law line; and with him the daughter
6450 had lived.  Emma guessed him to be the drudge of some attorney,
6451 and too stupid to rise.  And all the grandeur of the connexion
6452 seemed dependent on the elder sister, who was _very_ _well_ _married_,
6453 to a gentleman in a _great_ _way_, near Bristol, who kept two carriages!
6454 That was the wind-up of the history; that was the glory of
6455 Miss Hawkins.
6456 
6457 Could she but have given Harriet her feelings about it all!
6458 She had talked her into love; but, alas! she was not so easily to be
6459 talked out of it.  The charm of an object to occupy the many vacancies
6460 of Harriet's mind was not to be talked away.  He might be superseded
6461 by another; he certainly would indeed; nothing could be clearer;
6462 even a Robert Martin would have been sufficient; but nothing else,
6463 she feared, would cure her.  Harriet was one of those, who,
6464 having once begun, would be always in love.  And now, poor girl!
6465 she was considerably worse from this reappearance of Mr. Elton.
6466 She was always having a glimpse of him somewhere or other.  Emma saw
6467 him only once; but two or three times every day Harriet was sure
6468 _just_ to meet with him, or _just_ to miss him, _just_ to hear his voice,
6469 or see his shoulder, _just_ to have something occur to preserve him
6470 in her fancy, in all the favouring warmth of surprize and conjecture.
6471 She was, moreover, perpetually hearing about him; for, excepting when
6472 at Hartfield, she was always among those who saw no fault in Mr. Elton,
6473 and found nothing so interesting as the discussion of his concerns;
6474 and every report, therefore, every guess--all that had already
6475 occurred, all that might occur in the arrangement of his affairs,
6476 comprehending income, servants, and furniture, was continually
6477 in agitation around her.  Her regard was receiving strength by
6478 invariable praise of him, and her regrets kept alive, and feelings
6479 irritated by ceaseless repetitions of Miss Hawkins's happiness,
6480 and continual observation of, how much he seemed attached!--
6481 his air as he walked by the house--the very sitting of his hat,
6482 being all in proof of how much he was in love!
6483 
6484 Had it been allowable entertainment, had there been no pain
6485 to her friend, or reproach to herself, in the waverings of
6486 Harriet's mind, Emma would have been amused by its variations.
6487 Sometimes Mr. Elton predominated, sometimes the Martins; and each
6488 was occasionally useful as a check to the other.  Mr. Elton's
6489 engagement had been the cure of the agitation of meeting Mr. Martin.
6490 The unhappiness produced by the knowledge of that engagement had been
6491 a little put aside by Elizabeth Martin's calling at Mrs. Goddard's
6492 a few days afterwards.  Harriet had not been at home; but a note had
6493 been prepared and left for her, written in the very style to touch;
6494 a small mixture of reproach, with a great deal of kindness;
6495 and till Mr. Elton himself appeared, she had been much occupied
6496 by it, continually pondering over what could be done in return,
6497 and wishing to do more than she dared to confess.  But Mr. Elton,
6498 in person, had driven away all such cares.  While he staid,
6499 the Martins were forgotten; and on the very morning of his setting off
6500 for Bath again, Emma, to dissipate some of the distress it occasioned,
6501 judged it best for her to return Elizabeth Martin's visit.
6502 
6503 How that visit was to be acknowledged--what would be necessary--
6504 and what might be safest, had been a point of some doubtful
6505 consideration.  Absolute neglect of the mother and sisters,
6506 when invited to come, would be ingratitude.  It must not be:
6507 and yet the danger of a renewal of the acquaintance!--
6508 
6509 After much thinking, she could determine on nothing better, than Harriet's
6510 returning the visit; but in a way that, if they had understanding,
6511 should convince them that it was to be only a formal acquaintance.
6512 She meant to take her in the carriage, leave her at the Abbey Mill,
6513 while she drove a little farther, and call for her again so soon,
6514 as to allow no time for insidious applications or dangerous
6515 recurrences to the past, and give the most decided proof of what
6516 degree of intimacy was chosen for the future.
6517 
6518 She could think of nothing better:  and though there was something
6519 in it which her own heart could not approve--something of ingratitude,
6520 merely glossed over--it must be done, or what would become of Harriet?
6521 
6522 
6523 
6524 CHAPTER V
6525 
6526 
6527 Small heart had Harriet for visiting.  Only half an hour before her
6528 friend called for her at Mrs. Goddard's, her evil stars had led
6529 her to the very spot where, at that moment, a trunk, directed to
6530 _The_ _Rev._ _Philip_ _Elton_, _White-Hart_, _Bath_, was to be seen under the
6531 operation of being lifted into the butcher's cart, which was to
6532 convey it to where the coaches past; and every thing in this world,
6533 excepting that trunk and the direction, was consequently a blank.
6534 
6535 She went, however; and when they reached the farm, and she was to
6536 be put down, at the end of the broad, neat gravel walk, which led
6537 between espalier apple-trees to the front door, the sight of every
6538 thing which had given her so much pleasure the autumn before,
6539 was beginning to revive a little local agitation; and when they parted,
6540 Emma observed her to be looking around with a sort of fearful curiosity,
6541 which determined her not to allow the visit to exceed the proposed
6542 quarter of an hour.  She went on herself, to give that portion
6543 of time to an old servant who was married, and settled in Donwell.
6544 
6545 The quarter of an hour brought her punctually to the white gate again;
6546 and Miss Smith receiving her summons, was with her without delay,
6547 and unattended by any alarming young man.  She came solitarily
6548 down the gravel walk--a Miss Martin just appearing at the door,
6549 and parting with her seemingly with ceremonious civility.
6550 
6551 Harriet could not very soon give an intelligible account.
6552 She was feeling too much; but at last Emma collected from her
6553 enough to understand the sort of meeting, and the sort of pain it
6554 was creating.  She had seen only Mrs. Martin and the two girls.
6555 They had received her doubtingly, if not coolly; and nothing
6556 beyond the merest commonplace had been talked almost all the time--
6557 till just at last, when Mrs. Martin's saying, all of a sudden,
6558 that she thought Miss Smith was grown, had brought on a more
6559 interesting subject, and a warmer manner.  In that very room
6560 she had been measured last September, with her two friends.
6561 There were the pencilled marks and memorandums on the wainscot by
6562 the window.  _He_ had done it.  They all seemed to remember the day,
6563 the hour, the party, the occasion--to feel the same consciousness,
6564 the same regrets--to be ready to return to the same good understanding;
6565 and they were just growing again like themselves, (Harriet, as Emma
6566 must suspect, as ready as the best of them to be cordial and happy,)
6567 when the carriage reappeared, and all was over.  The style of
6568 the visit, and the shortness of it, were then felt to be decisive.
6569 Fourteen minutes to be given to those with whom she had thankfully
6570 passed six weeks not six months ago!--Emma could not but picture
6571 it all, and feel how justly they might resent, how naturally
6572 Harriet must suffer.  It was a bad business.  She would have given
6573 a great deal, or endured a great deal, to have had the Martins
6574 in a higher rank of life.  They were so deserving, that a _little_
6575 higher should have been enough:  but as it was, how could she have
6576 done otherwise?--Impossible!--She could not repent.  They must
6577 be separated; but there was a great deal of pain in the process--
6578 so much to herself at this time, that she soon felt the necessity
6579 of a little consolation, and resolved on going home by way of Randalls
6580 to procure it.  Her mind was quite sick of Mr. Elton and the Martins.
6581 The refreshment of Randalls was absolutely necessary.
6582 
6583 It was a good scheme; but on driving to the door they heard
6584 that neither "master nor mistress was at home;" they had both
6585 been out some time; the man believed they were gone to Hartfield.
6586 
6587 "This is too bad," cried Emma, as they turned away.  "And now we
6588 shall just miss them; too provoking!--I do not know when I have been
6589 so disappointed."  And she leaned back in the corner, to indulge
6590 her murmurs, or to reason them away; probably a little of both--
6591 such being the commonest process of a not ill-disposed mind.
6592 Presently the carriage stopt; she looked up; it was stopt
6593 by Mr. and Mrs. Weston, who were standing to speak to her.
6594 There was instant pleasure in the sight of them, and still greater
6595 pleasure was conveyed in sound--for Mr. Weston immediately accosted
6596 her with,
6597 
6598 "How d'ye do?--how d'ye do?--We have been sitting with your father--
6599 glad to see him so well.  Frank comes to-morrow--I had a letter
6600 this morning--we see him to-morrow by dinner-time to a certainty--
6601 he is at Oxford to-day, and he comes for a whole fortnight; I knew it would
6602 be so.  If he had come at Christmas he could not have staid three days;
6603 I was always glad he did not come at Christmas; now we are going
6604 to have just the right weather for him, fine, dry, settled weather.
6605 We shall enjoy him completely; every thing has turned out exactly
6606 as we could wish."
6607 
6608 There was no resisting such news, no possibility of avoiding the
6609 influence of such a happy face as Mr. Weston's, confirmed as it all
6610 was by the words and the countenance of his wife, fewer and quieter,
6611 but not less to the purpose.  To know that _she_ thought his coming
6612 certain was enough to make Emma consider it so, and sincerely did
6613 she rejoice in their joy.  It was a most delightful reanimation
6614 of exhausted spirits.  The worn-out past was sunk in the freshness
6615 of what was coming; and in the rapidity of half a moment's thought,
6616 she hoped Mr. Elton would now be talked of no more.
6617 
6618 Mr. Weston gave her the history of the engagements at Enscombe,
6619 which allowed his son to answer for having an entire fortnight at
6620 his command, as well as the route and the method of his journey;
6621 and she listened, and smiled, and congratulated.
6622 
6623 "I shall soon bring him over to Hartfield," said he, at the conclusion.
6624 
6625 Emma could imagine she saw a touch of the arm at this speech,
6626 from his wife.
6627 
6628 "We had better move on, Mr. Weston," said she, "we are detaining
6629 the girls."
6630 
6631 "Well, well, I am ready;"--and turning again to Emma, "but you must
6632 not be expecting such a _very_ fine young man; you have only had _my_
6633 account you know; I dare say he is really nothing extraordinary:"--
6634 though his own sparkling eyes at the moment were speaking a very
6635 different conviction.
6636 
6637 Emma could look perfectly unconscious and innocent, and answer
6638 in a manner that appropriated nothing.
6639 
6640 "Think of me to-morrow, my dear Emma, about four o'clock,"
6641 was Mrs. Weston's parting injunction; spoken with some anxiety,
6642 and meant only for her.
6643 
6644 "Four o'clock!--depend upon it he will be here by three," was Mr. Weston's
6645 quick amendment; and so ended a most satisfactory meeting.
6646 Emma's spirits were mounted quite up to happiness; every thing wore
6647 a different air; James and his horses seemed not half so sluggish
6648 as before.  When she looked at the hedges, she thought the elder at
6649 least must soon be coming out; and when she turned round to Harriet,
6650 she saw something like a look of spring, a tender smile even there.
6651 
6652 "Will Mr. Frank Churchill pass through Bath as well as Oxford?"--
6653 was a question, however, which did not augur much.
6654 
6655 But neither geography nor tranquillity could come all at once,
6656 and Emma was now in a humour to resolve that they should both come
6657 in time.
6658 
6659 The morning of the interesting day arrived, and Mrs. Weston's
6660 faithful pupil did not forget either at ten, or eleven, or twelve
6661 o'clock, that she was to think of her at four.
6662 
6663 "My dear, dear anxious friend,"--said she, in mental soliloquy,
6664 while walking downstairs from her own room, "always overcareful
6665 for every body's comfort but your own; I see you now in all your
6666 little fidgets, going again and again into his room, to be sure
6667 that all is right."  The clock struck twelve as she passed through
6668 the hall.  "'Tis twelve; I shall not forget to think of you four
6669 hours hence; and by this time to-morrow, perhaps, or a little later,
6670 I may be thinking of the possibility of their all calling here.
6671 I am sure they will bring him soon."
6672 
6673 She opened the parlour door, and saw two gentlemen sitting with
6674 her father--Mr. Weston and his son.  They had been arrived only
6675 a few minutes, and Mr. Weston had scarcely finished his explanation
6676 of Frank's being a day before his time, and her father was yet
6677 in the midst of his very civil welcome and congratulations, when
6678 she appeared, to have her share of surprize, introduction, and pleasure.
6679 
6680 The Frank Churchill so long talked of, so high in interest,
6681 was actually before her--he was presented to her, and she did
6682 not think too much had been said in his praise; he was a _very_ good
6683 looking young man; height, air, address, all were unexceptionable,
6684 and his countenance had a great deal of the spirit and liveliness
6685 of his father's; he looked quick and sensible.  She felt immediately
6686 that she should like him; and there was a well-bred ease of manner,
6687 and a readiness to talk, which convinced her that he came intending
6688 to be acquainted with her, and that acquainted they soon must be.
6689 
6690 He had reached Randalls the evening before.  She was pleased
6691 with the eagerness to arrive which had made him alter his plan,
6692 and travel earlier, later, and quicker, that he might gain half
6693 a day.
6694 
6695 "I told you yesterday," cried Mr. Weston with exultation, "I told
6696 you all that he would be here before the time named.  I remembered
6697 what I used to do myself.  One cannot creep upon a journey;
6698 one cannot help getting on faster than one has planned; and the
6699 pleasure of coming in upon one's friends before the look-out begins,
6700 is worth a great deal more than any little exertion it needs."
6701 
6702 "It is a great pleasure where one can indulge in it," said the young man,
6703 "though there are not many houses that I should presume on so far;
6704 but in coming _home_ I felt I might do any thing."
6705 
6706 The word _home_ made his father look on him with fresh complacency.
6707 Emma was directly sure that he knew how to make himself agreeable;
6708 the conviction was strengthened by what followed.  He was very much
6709 pleased with Randalls, thought it a most admirably arranged house,
6710 would hardly allow it even to be very small, admired the situation,
6711 the walk to Highbury, Highbury itself, Hartfield still more,
6712 and professed himself to have always felt the sort of interest
6713 in the country which none but one's _own_ country gives, and the
6714 greatest curiosity to visit it.  That he should never have been
6715 able to indulge so amiable a feeling before, passed suspiciously
6716 through Emma's brain; but still, if it were a falsehood, it was a
6717 pleasant one, and pleasantly handled.  His manner had no air of study
6718 or exaggeration.  He did really look and speak as if in a state of no
6719 common enjoyment.
6720 
6721 Their subjects in general were such as belong to an opening acquaintance.
6722 On his side were the inquiries,--"Was she a horsewoman?--Pleasant rides?--
6723 Pleasant walks?--Had they a large neighbourhood?--Highbury, perhaps,
6724 afforded society enough?--There were several very pretty houses
6725 in and about it.--Balls--had they balls?--Was it a musical society?"
6726 
6727 But when satisfied on all these points, and their acquaintance
6728 proportionably advanced, he contrived to find an opportunity,
6729 while their two fathers were engaged with each other, of introducing
6730 his mother-in-law, and speaking of her with so much handsome praise,
6731 so much warm admiration, so much gratitude for the happiness she
6732 secured to his father, and her very kind reception of himself,
6733 as was an additional proof of his knowing how to please--
6734 and of his certainly thinking it worth while to try to please her.
6735 He did not advance a word of praise beyond what she knew to be
6736 thoroughly deserved by Mrs. Weston; but, undoubtedly he could know
6737 very little of the matter.  He understood what would be welcome;
6738 he could be sure of little else.  "His father's marriage," he said,
6739 "had been the wisest measure, every friend must rejoice in it;
6740 and the family from whom he had received such a blessing must
6741 be ever considered as having conferred the highest obligation
6742 on him."
6743 
6744 He got as near as he could to thanking her for Miss Taylor's merits,
6745 without seeming quite to forget that in the common course of things it
6746 was to be rather supposed that Miss Taylor had formed Miss Woodhouse's
6747 character, than Miss Woodhouse Miss Taylor's. And at last, as if resolved
6748 to qualify his opinion completely for travelling round to its object, he
6749 wound it all up with astonishment at the youth and beauty of her person.
6750 
6751 "Elegant, agreeable manners, I was prepared for," said he;
6752 "but I confess that, considering every thing, I had not expected
6753 more than a very tolerably well-looking woman of a certain age;
6754 I did not know that I was to find a pretty young woman in Mrs. Weston."
6755 
6756 "You cannot see too much perfection in Mrs. Weston for my feelings,"
6757 said Emma; "were you to guess her to be _eighteen_, I should listen
6758 with pleasure; but _she_ would be ready to quarrel with you for using
6759 such words.  Don't let her imagine that you have spoken of her as
6760 a pretty young woman."
6761 
6762 "I hope I should know better," he replied; "no, depend upon it,
6763 (with a gallant bow,) that in addressing Mrs. Weston I should
6764 understand whom I might praise without any danger of being thought
6765 extravagant in my terms."
6766 
6767 Emma wondered whether the same suspicion of what might be expected
6768 from their knowing each other, which had taken strong possession
6769 of her mind, had ever crossed his; and whether his compliments were
6770 to be considered as marks of acquiescence, or proofs of defiance.
6771 She must see more of him to understand his ways; at present she
6772 only felt they were agreeable.
6773 
6774 She had no doubt of what Mr. Weston was often thinking about.
6775 His quick eye she detected again and again glancing towards them
6776 with a happy expression; and even, when he might have determined not
6777 to look, she was confident that he was often listening.
6778 
6779 Her own father's perfect exemption from any thought of the kind,
6780 the entire deficiency in him of all such sort of penetration
6781 or suspicion, was a most comfortable circumstance.  Happily he
6782 was not farther from approving matrimony than from foreseeing it.--
6783 Though always objecting to every marriage that was arranged,
6784 he never suffered beforehand from the apprehension of any;
6785 it seemed as if he could not think so ill of any two persons'
6786 understanding as to suppose they meant to marry till it were
6787 proved against them.  She blessed the favouring blindness.
6788 He could now, without the drawback of a single unpleasant surmise,
6789 without a glance forward at any possible treachery in his guest,
6790 give way to all his natural kind-hearted civility in solicitous
6791 inquiries after Mr. Frank Churchill's accommodation on his journey,
6792 through the sad evils of sleeping two nights on the road, and express
6793 very genuine unmixed anxiety to know that he had certainly escaped
6794 catching cold--which, however, he could not allow him to feel quite
6795 assured of himself till after another night.
6796 
6797 A reasonable visit paid, Mr. Weston began to move.--"He must be going.
6798 He had business at the Crown about his hay, and a great many errands
6799 for Mrs. Weston at Ford's, but he need not hurry any body else."
6800 His son, too well bred to hear the hint, rose immediately also,
6801 saying,
6802 
6803 "As you are going farther on business, sir, I will take the
6804 opportunity of paying a visit, which must be paid some day or other,
6805 and therefore may as well be paid now.  I have the honour of being
6806 acquainted with a neighbour of yours, (turning to Emma,) a lady
6807 residing in or near Highbury; a family of the name of Fairfax.
6808 I shall have no difficulty, I suppose, in finding the house;
6809 though Fairfax, I believe, is not the proper name--I should rather
6810 say Barnes, or Bates.  Do you know any family of that name?"
6811 
6812 "To be sure we do," cried his father; "Mrs. Bates--we passed her house--
6813 I saw Miss Bates at the window.  True, true, you are acquainted
6814 with Miss Fairfax; I remember you knew her at Weymouth, and a fine
6815 girl she is.  Call upon her, by all means."
6816 
6817 "There is no necessity for my calling this morning," said the
6818 young man; "another day would do as well; but there was that degree
6819 of acquaintance at Weymouth which--"
6820 
6821 "Oh! go to-day, go to-day. Do not defer it.  What is right to be done
6822 cannot be done too soon.  And, besides, I must give you a hint, Frank;
6823 any want of attention to her _here_ should be carefully avoided.
6824 You saw her with the Campbells, when she was the equal of every body
6825 she mixed with, but here she is with a poor old grandmother,
6826 who has barely enough to live on.  If you do not call early it
6827 will be a slight."
6828 
6829 The son looked convinced.
6830 
6831 "I have heard her speak of the acquaintance," said Emma; "she is
6832 a very elegant young woman."
6833 
6834 He agreed to it, but with so quiet a "Yes," as inclined her almost
6835 to doubt his real concurrence; and yet there must be a very distinct
6836 sort of elegance for the fashionable world, if Jane Fairfax could
6837 be thought only ordinarily gifted with it.
6838 
6839 "If you were never particularly struck by her manners before,"
6840 said she, "I think you will to-day. You will see her to advantage;
6841 see her and hear her--no, I am afraid you will not hear her at all,
6842 for she has an aunt who never holds her tongue."
6843 
6844 "You are acquainted with Miss Jane Fairfax, sir, are you?"
6845 said Mr. Woodhouse, always the last to make his way in conversation;
6846 "then give me leave to assure you that you will find her a very
6847 agreeable young lady.  She is staying here on a visit to her grandmama
6848 and aunt, very worthy people; I have known them all my life.
6849 They will be extremely glad to see you, I am sure; and one of my
6850 servants shall go with you to shew you the way."
6851 
6852 "My dear sir, upon no account in the world; my father can direct me."
6853 
6854 "But your father is not going so far; he is only going to the Crown,
6855 quite on the other side of the street, and there are a great many houses;
6856 you might be very much at a loss, and it is a very dirty walk,
6857 unless you keep on the footpath; but my coachman can tell you
6858 where you had best cross the street."
6859 
6860 Mr. Frank Churchill still declined it, looking as serious as he could,
6861 and his father gave his hearty support by calling out, "My good friend,
6862 this is quite unnecessary; Frank knows a puddle of water when he
6863 sees it, and as to Mrs. Bates's, he may get there from the Crown
6864 in a hop, step, and jump."
6865 
6866 They were permitted to go alone; and with a cordial nod from one,
6867 and a graceful bow from the other, the two gentlemen took leave.
6868 Emma remained very well pleased with this beginning of the acquaintance,
6869 and could now engage to think of them all at Randalls any hour of
6870 the day, with full confidence in their comfort.
6871 
6872 
6873 
6874 CHAPTER VI
6875 
6876 
6877 The next morning brought Mr. Frank Churchill again.  He came with
6878 Mrs. Weston, to whom and to Highbury he seemed to take very cordially.
6879 He had been sitting with her, it appeared, most companionably at home,
6880 till her usual hour of exercise; and on being desired to chuse
6881 their walk, immediately fixed on Highbury.--"He did not doubt there
6882 being very pleasant walks in every direction, but if left to him,
6883 he should always chuse the same.  Highbury, that airy, cheerful,
6884 happy-looking Highbury, would be his constant attraction."--
6885 Highbury, with Mrs. Weston, stood for Hartfield; and she trusted to
6886 its bearing the same construction with him.  They walked thither directly.
6887 
6888 Emma had hardly expected them:  for Mr. Weston, who had called in
6889 for half a minute, in order to hear that his son was very handsome,
6890 knew nothing of their plans; and it was an agreeable surprize
6891 to her, therefore, to perceive them walking up to the house together,
6892 arm in arm.  She was wanting to see him again, and especially
6893 to see him in company with Mrs. Weston, upon his behaviour to whom
6894 her opinion of him was to depend.  If he were deficient there,
6895 nothing should make amends for it.  But on seeing them together,
6896 she became perfectly satisfied.  It was not merely in fine words
6897 or hyperbolical compliment that he paid his duty; nothing could be
6898 more proper or pleasing than his whole manner to her--nothing could
6899 more agreeably denote his wish of considering her as a friend and
6900 securing her affection.  And there was time enough for Emma to form a
6901 reasonable judgment, as their visit included all the rest of the morning.
6902 They were all three walking about together for an hour or two--
6903 first round the shrubberies of Hartfield, and afterwards in Highbury.
6904 He was delighted with every thing; admired Hartfield sufficiently
6905 for Mr. Woodhouse's ear; and when their going farther was resolved on,
6906 confessed his wish to be made acquainted with the whole village,
6907 and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than Emma
6908 could have supposed.
6909 
6910 Some of the objects of his curiosity spoke very amiable feelings.
6911 He begged to be shewn the house which his father had lived in so long,
6912 and which had been the home of his father's father; and on recollecting
6913 that an old woman who had nursed him was still living, walked in quest
6914 of her cottage from one end of the street to the other; and though
6915 in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit,
6916 they shewed, altogether, a good-will towards Highbury in general,
6917 which must be very like a merit to those he was with.
6918 
6919 Emma watched and decided, that with such feelings as were now shewn,
6920 it could not be fairly supposed that he had been ever voluntarily
6921 absenting himself; that he had not been acting a part, or making
6922 a parade of insincere professions; and that Mr. Knightley certainly
6923 had not done him justice.
6924 
6925 Their first pause was at the Crown Inn, an inconsiderable house,
6926 though the principal one of the sort, where a couple of pair of
6927 post-horses were kept, more for the convenience of the neighbourhood
6928 than from any run on the road; and his companions had not expected
6929 to be detained by any interest excited there; but in passing it they
6930 gave the history of the large room visibly added; it had been built
6931 many years ago for a ball-room, and while the neighbourhood had been
6932 in a particularly populous, dancing state, had been occasionally used
6933 as such;--but such brilliant days had long passed away, and now the
6934 highest purpose for which it was ever wanted was to accommodate a whist
6935 club established among the gentlemen and half-gentlemen of the place.
6936 He was immediately interested.  Its character as a ball-room caught him;
6937 and instead of passing on, he stopt for several minutes at the two
6938 superior sashed windows which were open, to look in and contemplate
6939 its capabilities, and lament that its original purpose should
6940 have ceased.  He saw no fault in the room, he would acknowledge
6941 none which they suggested.  No, it was long enough, broad enough,
6942 handsome enough.  It would hold the very number for comfort.
6943 They ought to have balls there at least every fortnight through
6944 the winter.  Why had not Miss Woodhouse revived the former good
6945 old days of the room?--She who could do any thing in Highbury!
6946 The want of proper families in the place, and the conviction
6947 that none beyond the place and its immediate environs could be
6948 tempted to attend, were mentioned; but he was not satisfied.
6949 He could not be persuaded that so many good-looking houses as he saw
6950 around him, could not furnish numbers enough for such a meeting;
6951 and even when particulars were given and families described, he was
6952 still unwilling to admit that the inconvenience of such a mixture
6953 would be any thing, or that there would be the smallest difficulty
6954 in every body's returning into their proper place the next morning.
6955 He argued like a young man very much bent on dancing; and Emma
6956 was rather surprized to see the constitution of the Weston prevail
6957 so decidedly against the habits of the Churchills.  He seemed to have
6958 all the life and spirit, cheerful feelings, and social inclinations
6959 of his father, and nothing of the pride or reserve of Enscombe.
6960 Of pride, indeed, there was, perhaps, scarcely enough; his indifference
6961 to a confusion of rank, bordered too much on inelegance of mind.
6962 He could be no judge, however, of the evil he was holding cheap.
6963 It was but an effusion of lively spirits.
6964 
6965 At last he was persuaded to move on from the front of the Crown;
6966 and being now almost facing the house where the Bateses lodged,
6967 Emma recollected his intended visit the day before, and asked him
6968 if he had paid it.
6969 
6970 "Yes, oh! yes"--he replied; "I was just going to mention it.
6971 A very successful visit:--I saw all the three ladies; and felt very
6972 much obliged to you for your preparatory hint.  If the talking aunt
6973 had taken me quite by surprize, it must have been the death of me.
6974 As it was, I was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit.
6975 Ten minutes would have been all that was necessary, perhaps all that
6976 was proper; and I had told my father I should certainly be at home
6977 before him--but there was no getting away, no pause; and, to my
6978 utter astonishment, I found, when he (finding me nowhere else)
6979 joined me there at last, that I had been actually sitting with them
6980 very nearly three-quarters of an hour.  The good lady had not given me
6981 the possibility of escape before."
6982 
6983 "And how did you think Miss Fairfax looking?"
6984 
6985 "Ill, very ill--that is, if a young lady can ever be allowed to look ill.
6986 But the expression is hardly admissible, Mrs. Weston, is it?
6987 Ladies can never look ill.  And, seriously, Miss Fairfax is naturally
6988 so pale, as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.--
6989 A most deplorable want of complexion."
6990 
6991 Emma would not agree to this, and began a warm defence of Miss
6992 Fairfax's complexion.  "It was certainly never brilliant, but she
6993 would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general; and there was
6994 a softness and delicacy in her skin which gave peculiar elegance
6995 to the character of her face."  He listened with all due deference;
6996 acknowledged that he had heard many people say the same--but yet he
6997 must confess, that to him nothing could make amends for the want
6998 of the fine glow of health.  Where features were indifferent,
6999 a fine complexion gave beauty to them all; and where they were good,
7000 the effect was--fortunately he need not attempt to describe what the
7001 effect was.
7002 
7003 "Well," said Emma, "there is no disputing about taste.--At least
7004 you admire her except her complexion."
7005 
7006 He shook his head and laughed.--"I cannot separate Miss Fairfax
7007 and her complexion."
7008 
7009 "Did you see her often at Weymouth?  Were you often in the same society?"
7010 
7011 At this moment they were approaching Ford's, and he hastily exclaimed,
7012 "Ha! this must be the very shop that every body attends every day
7013 of their lives, as my father informs me.  He comes to Highbury himself,
7014 he says, six days out of the seven, and has always business at Ford's.
7015 If it be not inconvenient to you, pray let us go in, that I may prove
7016 myself to belong to the place, to be a true citizen of Highbury.
7017 I must buy something at Ford's. It will be taking out my freedom.--
7018 I dare say they sell gloves."
7019 
7020 "Oh! yes, gloves and every thing.  I do admire your patriotism.
7021 You will be adored in Highbury.  You were very popular before you came,
7022 because you were Mr. Weston's son--but lay out half a guinea at
7023 Ford's, and your popularity will stand upon your own virtues."
7024 
7025 They went in; and while the sleek, well-tied parcels of "Men's Beavers"
7026 and "York Tan" were bringing down and displaying on the counter,
7027 he said--"But I beg your pardon, Miss Woodhouse, you were speaking
7028 to me, you were saying something at the very moment of this burst
7029 of my _amor_ _patriae_.  Do not let me lose it.  I assure you the utmost
7030 stretch of public fame would not make me amends for the loss of any
7031 happiness in private life."
7032 
7033 "I merely asked, whether you had known much of Miss Fairfax
7034 and her party at Weymouth."
7035 
7036 "And now that I understand your question, I must pronounce it to be a
7037 very unfair one.  It is always the lady's right to decide on the degree
7038 of acquaintance.  Miss Fairfax must already have given her account.--
7039 I shall not commit myself by claiming more than she may chuse to allow."
7040 
7041 "Upon my word! you answer as discreetly as she could do herself.
7042 But her account of every thing leaves so much to be guessed,
7043 she is so very reserved, so very unwilling to give the least
7044 information about any body, that I really think you may say what you
7045 like of your acquaintance with her."
7046 
7047 "May I, indeed?--Then I will speak the truth, and nothing suits me
7048 so well.  I met her frequently at Weymouth.  I had known the Campbells
7049 a little in town; and at Weymouth we were very much in the same set.
7050 Colonel Campbell is a very agreeable man, and Mrs. Campbell a friendly,
7051 warm-hearted woman.  I like them all."
7052 
7053 "You know Miss Fairfax's situation in life, I conclude; what she
7054 is destined to be?"
7055 
7056 "Yes--(rather hesitatingly)--I believe I do."
7057 
7058 "You get upon delicate subjects, Emma," said Mrs. Weston smiling;
7059 "remember that I am here.--Mr. Frank Churchill hardly knows
7060 what to say when you speak of Miss Fairfax's situation in life.
7061 I will move a little farther off."
7062 
7063 "I certainly do forget to think of _her_," said Emma, "as having ever
7064 been any thing but my friend and my dearest friend."
7065 
7066 He looked as if he fully understood and honoured such a sentiment.
7067 
7068 When the gloves were bought, and they had quitted the shop again,
7069 "Did you ever hear the young lady we were speaking of, play?"
7070 said Frank Churchill.
7071 
7072 "Ever hear her!" repeated Emma.  "You forget how much she belongs
7073 to Highbury.  I have heard her every year of our lives since we
7074 both began.  She plays charmingly."
7075 
7076 "You think so, do you?--I wanted the opinion of some one who
7077 could really judge.  She appeared to me to play well, that is,
7078 with considerable taste, but I know nothing of the matter myself.--
7079 I am excessively fond of music, but without the smallest skill
7080 or right of judging of any body's performance.--I have been used
7081 to hear her's admired; and I remember one proof of her being
7082 thought to play well:--a man, a very musical man, and in love
7083 with another woman--engaged to her--on the point of marriage--
7084 would yet never ask that other woman to sit down to the instrument,
7085 if the lady in question could sit down instead--never seemed
7086 to like to hear one if he could hear the other.  That, I thought,
7087 in a man of known musical talent, was some proof."
7088 
7089 "Proof indeed!" said Emma, highly amused.--"Mr. Dixon is very musical,
7090 is he?  We shall know more about them all, in half an hour, from you,
7091 than Miss Fairfax would have vouchsafed in half a year."
7092 
7093 "Yes, Mr. Dixon and Miss Campbell were the persons; and I thought
7094 it a very strong proof."
7095 
7096 "Certainly--very strong it was; to own the truth, a great deal
7097 stronger than, if _I_ had been Miss Campbell, would have been at all
7098 agreeable to me.  I could not excuse a man's having more music
7099 than love--more ear than eye--a more acute sensibility to fine
7100 sounds than to my feelings.  How did Miss Campbell appear to like it?"
7101 
7102 "It was her very particular friend, you know."
7103 
7104 "Poor comfort!" said Emma, laughing.  "One would rather have a stranger
7105 preferred than one's very particular friend--with a stranger it might
7106 not recur again--but the misery of having a very particular friend
7107 always at hand, to do every thing better than one does oneself!--
7108 Poor Mrs. Dixon!  Well, I am glad she is gone to settle in Ireland."
7109 
7110 "You are right.  It was not very flattering to Miss Campbell;
7111 but she really did not seem to feel it."
7112 
7113 "So much the better--or so much the worse:--I do not know which.
7114 But be it sweetness or be it stupidity in her--quickness of friendship,
7115 or dulness of feeling--there was one person, I think, who must have
7116 felt it:  Miss Fairfax herself.  She must have felt the improper
7117 and dangerous distinction."
7118 
7119 "As to that--I do not--"
7120 
7121 "Oh! do not imagine that I expect an account of Miss Fairfax's
7122 sensations from you, or from any body else.  They are known to no
7123 human being, I guess, but herself.  But if she continued to play
7124 whenever she was asked by Mr. Dixon, one may guess what one chuses."
7125
