7126 "There appeared such a perfectly good understanding among them all--"
7127 he began rather quickly, but checking himself, added, "however, it
7128 is impossible for me to say on what terms they really were--
7129 how it might all be behind the scenes.  I can only say that there
7130 was smoothness outwardly.  But you, who have known Miss Fairfax from
7131 a child, must be a better judge of her character, and of how she
7132 is likely to conduct herself in critical situations, than I can be."
7133 
7134 "I have known her from a child, undoubtedly; we have been children
7135 and women together; and it is natural to suppose that we should
7136 be intimate,--that we should have taken to each other whenever
7137 she visited her friends.  But we never did.  I hardly know how it
7138 has happened; a little, perhaps, from that wickedness on my side
7139 which was prone to take disgust towards a girl so idolized
7140 and so cried up as she always was, by her aunt and grandmother,
7141 and all their set.  And then, her reserve--I never could attach
7142 myself to any one so completely reserved."
7143 
7144 "It is a most repulsive quality, indeed," said he.  "Oftentimes
7145 very convenient, no doubt, but never pleasing.  There is safety
7146 in reserve, but no attraction.  One cannot love a reserved person."
7147 
7148 "Not till the reserve ceases towards oneself; and then the attraction
7149 may be the greater.  But I must be more in want of a friend,
7150 or an agreeable companion, than I have yet been, to take
7151 the trouble of conquering any body's reserve to procure one.
7152 Intimacy between Miss Fairfax and me is quite out of the question.
7153 I have no reason to think ill of her--not the least--except that
7154 such extreme and perpetual cautiousness of word and manner,
7155 such a dread of giving a distinct idea about any body, is apt
7156 to suggest suspicions of there being something to conceal."
7157 
7158 He perfectly agreed with her:  and after walking together so long,
7159 and thinking so much alike, Emma felt herself so well acquainted with him,
7160 that she could hardly believe it to be only their second meeting.
7161 He was not exactly what she had expected; less of the man of the
7162 world in some of his notions, less of the spoiled child of fortune,
7163 therefore better than she had expected.  His ideas seemed more moderate--
7164 his feelings warmer.  She was particularly struck by his manner
7165 of considering Mr. Elton's house, which, as well as the church,
7166 he would go and look at, and would not join them in finding much
7167 fault with.  No, he could not believe it a bad house; not such a house
7168 as a man was to be pitied for having.  If it were to be shared with
7169 the woman he loved, he could not think any man to be pitied for having
7170 that house.  There must be ample room in it for every real comfort.
7171 The man must be a blockhead who wanted more.
7172 
7173 Mrs. Weston laughed, and said he did not know what he was talking about.
7174 Used only to a large house himself, and without ever thinking how many
7175 advantages and accommodations were attached to its size, he could
7176 be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to a small one.
7177 But Emma, in her own mind, determined that he _did_ know what he
7178 was talking about, and that he shewed a very amiable inclination
7179 to settle early in life, and to marry, from worthy motives.
7180 He might not be aware of the inroads on domestic peace to be
7181 occasioned by no housekeeper's room, or a bad butler's pantry,
7182 but no doubt he did perfectly feel that Enscombe could not make
7183 him happy, and that whenever he were attached, he would willingly
7184 give up much of wealth to be allowed an early establishment.
7185 
7186 
7187 
7188 CHAPTER VII
7189 
7190 
7191 Emma's very good opinion of Frank Churchill was a little shaken
7192 the following day, by hearing that he was gone off to London,
7193 merely to have his hair cut.  A sudden freak seemed to have seized him
7194 at breakfast, and he had sent for a chaise and set off, intending to
7195 return to dinner, but with no more important view that appeared than
7196 having his hair cut.  There was certainly no harm in his travelling
7197 sixteen miles twice over on such an errand; but there was an air
7198 of foppery and nonsense in it which she could not approve.  It did
7199 not accord with the rationality of plan, the moderation in expense,
7200 or even the unselfish warmth of heart, which she had believed herself
7201 to discern in him yesterday.  Vanity, extravagance, love of change,
7202 restlessness of temper, which must be doing something, good or bad;
7203 heedlessness as to the pleasure of his father and Mrs. Weston,
7204 indifferent as to how his conduct might appear in general; he became
7205 liable to all these charges.  His father only called him a coxcomb,
7206 and thought it a very good story; but that Mrs. Weston did not like it,
7207 was clear enough, by her passing it over as quickly as possible,
7208 and making no other comment than that "all young people would have
7209 their little whims."
7210 
7211 With the exception of this little blot, Emma found that his visit
7212 hitherto had given her friend only good ideas of him.  Mrs. Weston
7213 was very ready to say how attentive and pleasant a companion he
7214 made himself--how much she saw to like in his disposition altogether.
7215 He appeared to have a very open temper--certainly a very cheerful
7216 and lively one; she could observe nothing wrong in his notions,
7217 a great deal decidedly right; he spoke of his uncle with warm regard,
7218 was fond of talking of him--said he would be the best man in the
7219 world if he were left to himself; and though there was no being
7220 attached to the aunt, he acknowledged her kindness with gratitude,
7221 and seemed to mean always to speak of her with respect.
7222 This was all very promising; and, but for such an unfortunate fancy
7223 for having his hair cut, there was nothing to denote him unworthy
7224 of the distinguished honour which her imagination had given him;
7225 the honour, if not of being really in love with her, of being
7226 at least very near it, and saved only by her own indifference--
7227 (for still her resolution held of never marrying)--the honour, in short,
7228 of being marked out for her by all their joint acquaintance.
7229 
7230 Mr. Weston, on his side, added a virtue to the account which must
7231 have some weight.  He gave her to understand that Frank admired
7232 her extremely--thought her very beautiful and very charming;
7233 and with so much to be said for him altogether, she found she must
7234 not judge him harshly.  As Mrs. Weston observed, "all young people
7235 would have their little whims."
7236 
7237 There was one person among his new acquaintance in Surry, not so
7238 leniently disposed.  In general he was judged, throughout the parishes
7239 of Donwell and Highbury, with great candour; liberal allowances
7240 were made for the little excesses of such a handsome young man--
7241 one who smiled so often and bowed so well; but there was one spirit
7242 among them not to be softened, from its power of censure, by bows
7243 or smiles--Mr. Knightley.  The circumstance was told him at Hartfield;
7244 for the moment, he was silent; but Emma heard him almost immediately
7245 afterwards say to himself, over a newspaper he held in his hand,
7246 "Hum! just the trifling, silly fellow I took him for."  She had
7247 half a mind to resent; but an instant's observation convinced
7248 her that it was really said only to relieve his own feelings,
7249 and not meant to provoke; and therefore she let it pass.
7250 
7251 Although in one instance the bearers of not good tidings,
7252 Mr. and Mrs. Weston's visit this morning was in another respect
7253 particularly opportune.  Something occurred while they were
7254 at Hartfield, to make Emma want their advice; and, which was
7255 still more lucky, she wanted exactly the advice they gave.
7256 
7257 This was the occurrence:--The Coles had been settled some years
7258 in Highbury, and were very good sort of people--friendly, liberal,
7259 and unpretending; but, on the other hand, they were of low origin,
7260 in trade, and only moderately genteel.  On their first coming into
7261 the country, they had lived in proportion to their income, quietly,
7262 keeping little company, and that little unexpensively; but the last
7263 year or two had brought them a considerable increase of means--
7264 the house in town had yielded greater profits, and fortune in general
7265 had smiled on them.  With their wealth, their views increased;
7266 their want of a larger house, their inclination for more company.
7267 They added to their house, to their number of servants,
7268 to their expenses of every sort; and by this time were, in fortune
7269 and style of living, second only to the family at Hartfield.
7270 Their love of society, and their new dining-room, prepared every body
7271 for their keeping dinner-company; and a few parties, chiefly among
7272 the single men, had already taken place.  The regular and best
7273 families Emma could hardly suppose they would presume to invite--
7274 neither Donwell, nor Hartfield, nor Randalls.  Nothing should
7275 tempt _her_ to go, if they did; and she regretted that her father's
7276 known habits would be giving her refusal less meaning than she
7277 could wish.  The Coles were very respectable in their way, but they
7278 ought to be taught that it was not for them to arrange the terms
7279 on which the superior families would visit them.  This lesson,
7280 she very much feared, they would receive only from herself;
7281 she had little hope of Mr. Knightley, none of Mr. Weston.
7282 
7283 But she had made up her mind how to meet this presumption so many
7284 weeks before it appeared, that when the insult came at last,
7285 it found her very differently affected.  Donwell and Randalls
7286 had received their invitation, and none had come for her father
7287 and herself; and Mrs. Weston's accounting for it with "I suppose
7288 they will not take the liberty with you; they know you do not
7289 dine out," was not quite sufficient.  She felt that she should
7290 like to have had the power of refusal; and afterwards, as the idea
7291 of the party to be assembled there, consisting precisely of those
7292 whose society was dearest to her, occurred again and again,
7293 she did not know that she might not have been tempted to accept.
7294 Harriet was to be there in the evening, and the Bateses.  They had
7295 been speaking of it as they walked about Highbury the day before,
7296 and Frank Churchill had most earnestly lamented her absence.
7297 Might not the evening end in a dance? had been a question of his.
7298 The bare possibility of it acted as a farther irritation on her spirits;
7299 and her being left in solitary grandeur, even supposing the omission
7300 to be intended as a compliment, was but poor comfort.
7301 
7302 It was the arrival of this very invitation while the Westons were
7303 at Hartfield, which made their presence so acceptable; for though her
7304 first remark, on reading it, was that "of course it must be declined,"
7305 she so very soon proceeded to ask them what they advised her to do,
7306 that their advice for her going was most prompt and successful.
7307 
7308 She owned that, considering every thing, she was not absolutely
7309 without inclination for the party.  The Coles expressed themselves
7310 so properly--there was so much real attention in the manner of it--
7311 so much consideration for her father.  "They would have solicited the
7312 honour earlier, but had been waiting the arrival of a folding-screen
7313 from London, which they hoped might keep Mr. Woodhouse from any draught
7314 of air, and therefore induce him the more readily to give them the
7315 honour of his company."  Upon the whole, she was very persuadable;
7316 and it being briefly settled among themselves how it might be
7317 done without neglecting his comfort--how certainly Mrs. Goddard,
7318 if not Mrs. Bates, might be depended on for bearing him company--
7319 Mr. Woodhouse was to be talked into an acquiescence of his daughter's
7320 going out to dinner on a day now near at hand, and spending
7321 the whole evening away from him.  As for _his_ going, Emma did
7322 not wish him to think it possible, the hours would be too late,
7323 and the party too numerous.  He was soon pretty well resigned.
7324 
7325 "I am not fond of dinner-visiting," said he--"I never was.
7326 No more is Emma.  Late hours do not agree with us.  I am sorry
7327 Mr. and Mrs. Cole should have done it.  I think it would be
7328 much better if they would come in one afternoon next summer,
7329 and take their tea with us--take us in their afternoon walk;
7330 which they might do, as our hours are so reasonable, and yet get home
7331 without being out in the damp of the evening.  The dews of a summer
7332 evening are what I would not expose any body to.  However, as they
7333 are so very desirous to have dear Emma dine with them, and as you
7334 will both be there, and Mr. Knightley too, to take care of her,
7335 I cannot wish to prevent it, provided the weather be what it ought,
7336 neither damp, nor cold, nor windy."  Then turning to Mrs. Weston,
7337 with a look of gentle reproach--"Ah!  Miss Taylor, if you had
7338 not married, you would have staid at home with me."
7339 
7340 "Well, sir," cried Mr. Weston, "as I took Miss Taylor away,
7341 it is incumbent on me to supply her place, if I can; and I will
7342 step to Mrs. Goddard in a moment, if you wish it."
7343 
7344 But the idea of any thing to be done in a _moment_, was increasing,
7345 not lessening, Mr. Woodhouse's agitation.  The ladies knew better
7346 how to allay it.  Mr. Weston must be quiet, and every thing
7347 deliberately arranged.
7348 
7349 With this treatment, Mr. Woodhouse was soon composed enough
7350 for talking as usual.  "He should be happy to see Mrs. Goddard.
7351 He had a great regard for Mrs. Goddard; and Emma should write a line,
7352 and invite her.  James could take the note.  But first of all,
7353 there must be an answer written to Mrs. Cole."
7354 
7355 "You will make my excuses, my dear, as civilly as possible.  You will
7356 say that I am quite an invalid, and go no where, and therefore must
7357 decline their obliging invitation; beginning with my _compliments_,
7358 of course.  But you will do every thing right.  I need not tell you
7359 what is to be done.  We must remember to let James know that the carriage
7360 will be wanted on Tuesday.  I shall have no fears for you with him.
7361 We have never been there above once since the new approach was made;
7362 but still I have no doubt that James will take you very safely.
7363 And when you get there, you must tell him at what time you would
7364 have him come for you again; and you had better name an early hour.
7365 You will not like staying late.  You will get very tired when tea
7366 is over."
7367 
7368 "But you would not wish me to come away before I am tired, papa?"
7369 
7370 "Oh! no, my love; but you will soon be tired.  There will be
7371 a great many people talking at once.  You will not like the noise."
7372 
7373 "But, my dear sir," cried Mr. Weston, "if Emma comes away early,
7374 it will be breaking up the party."
7375 
7376 "And no great harm if it does," said Mr. Woodhouse.  "The sooner
7377 every party breaks up, the better."
7378 
7379 "But you do not consider how it may appear to the Coles.
7380 Emma's going away directly after tea might be giving offence.
7381 They are good-natured people, and think little of their own claims;
7382 but still they must feel that any body's hurrying away is no
7383 great compliment; and Miss Woodhouse's doing it would be more thought
7384 of than any other person's in the room.  You would not wish to disappoint
7385 and mortify the Coles, I am sure, sir; friendly, good sort of people
7386 as ever lived, and who have been your neighbours these _ten_ years."
7387 
7388 "No, upon no account in the world, Mr. Weston; I am much obliged
7389 to you for reminding me.  I should be extremely sorry to be giving
7390 them any pain.  I know what worthy people they are.  Perry tells
7391 me that Mr. Cole never touches malt liquor.  You would not think
7392 it to look at him, but he is bilious--Mr. Cole is very bilious.
7393 No, I would not be the means of giving them any pain.  My dear Emma,
7394 we must consider this.  I am sure, rather than run the risk of hurting
7395 Mr. and Mrs. Cole, you would stay a little longer than you might wish.
7396 You will not regard being tired.  You will be perfectly safe,
7397 you know, among your friends."
7398 
7399 "Oh yes, papa.  I have no fears at all for myself; and I should have
7400 no scruples of staying as late as Mrs. Weston, but on your account.
7401 I am only afraid of your sitting up for me.  I am not afraid
7402 of your not being exceedingly comfortable with Mrs. Goddard.
7403 She loves piquet, you know; but when she is gone home, I am afraid
7404 you will be sitting up by yourself, instead of going to bed at your
7405 usual time--and the idea of that would entirely destroy my comfort.
7406 You must promise me not to sit up."
7407 
7408 He did, on the condition of some promises on her side:  such as that,
7409 if she came home cold, she would be sure to warm herself thoroughly;
7410 if hungry, that she would take something to eat; that her own maid
7411 should sit up for her; and that Serle and the butler should see
7412 that every thing were safe in the house, as usual.
7413 
7414 
7415 
7416 CHAPTER VIII
7417 
7418 
7419 Frank Churchill came back again; and if he kept his father's
7420 dinner waiting, it was not known at Hartfield; for Mrs. Weston
7421 was too anxious for his being a favourite with Mr. Woodhouse,
7422 to betray any imperfection which could be concealed.
7423 
7424 He came back, had had his hair cut, and laughed at himself with
7425 a very good grace, but without seeming really at all ashamed
7426 of what he had done.  He had no reason to wish his hair longer,
7427 to conceal any confusion of face; no reason to wish the money unspent,
7428 to improve his spirits.  He was quite as undaunted and as lively
7429 as ever; and, after seeing him, Emma thus moralised to herself:--
7430 
7431 "I do not know whether it ought to be so, but certainly silly things
7432 do cease to be silly if they are done by sensible people in an
7433 impudent way.  Wickedness is always wickedness, but folly is not
7434 always folly.--It depends upon the character of those who handle it.
7435 Mr. Knightley, he is _not_ a trifling, silly young man.  If he were,
7436 he would have done this differently.  He would either have gloried
7437 in the achievement, or been ashamed of it.  There would have been
7438 either the ostentation of a coxcomb, or the evasions of a mind too
7439 weak to defend its own vanities.--No, I am perfectly sure that he
7440 is not trifling or silly."
7441 
7442 With Tuesday came the agreeable prospect of seeing him again,
7443 and for a longer time than hitherto; of judging of his general manners,
7444 and by inference, of the meaning of his manners towards herself;
7445 of guessing how soon it might be necessary for her to throw coldness
7446 into her air; and of fancying what the observations of all those
7447 might be, who were now seeing them together for the first time.
7448 
7449 She meant to be very happy, in spite of the scene being laid at
7450 Mr. Cole's; and without being able to forget that among the failings
7451 of Mr. Elton, even in the days of his favour, none had disturbed
7452 her more than his propensity to dine with Mr. Cole.
7453 
7454 Her father's comfort was amply secured, Mrs. Bates as well as
7455 Mrs. Goddard being able to come; and her last pleasing duty,
7456 before she left the house, was to pay her respects to them as
7457 they sat together after dinner; and while her father was fondly
7458 noticing the beauty of her dress, to make the two ladies all
7459 the amends in her power, by helping them to large slices of cake
7460 and full glasses of wine, for whatever unwilling self-denial his
7461 care of their constitution might have obliged them to practise
7462 during the meal.--She had provided a plentiful dinner for them;
7463 she wished she could know that they had been allowed to eat it.
7464 
7465 She followed another carriage to Mr. Cole's door; and was pleased
7466 to see that it was Mr. Knightley's; for Mr. Knightley keeping
7467 no horses, having little spare money and a great deal of health,
7468 activity, and independence, was too apt, in Emma's opinion, to get
7469 about as he could, and not use his carriage so often as became
7470 the owner of Donwell Abbey.  She had an opportunity now of speaking
7471 her approbation while warm from her heart, for he stopped to hand her out.
7472 
7473 "This is coming as you should do," said she; "like a gentleman.--
7474 I am quite glad to see you."
7475 
7476 He thanked her, observing, "How lucky that we should arrive at the same
7477 moment! for, if we had met first in the drawing-room, I doubt whether
7478 you would have discerned me to be more of a gentleman than usual.--
7479 You might not have distinguished how I came, by my look or manner."
7480 
7481 "Yes I should, I am sure I should.  There is always a look of
7482 consciousness or bustle when people come in a way which they know
7483 to be beneath them.  You think you carry it off very well, I dare say,
7484 but with you it is a sort of bravado, an air of affected unconcern;
7485 I always observe it whenever I meet you under those circumstances.
7486 _Now_ you have nothing to try for.  You are not afraid of being
7487 supposed ashamed.  You are not striving to look taller than any
7488 body else.  _Now_ I shall really be very happy to walk into the same
7489 room with you."
7490 
7491 "Nonsensical girl!" was his reply, but not at all in anger.
7492 
7493 Emma had as much reason to be satisfied with the rest of the party
7494 as with Mr. Knightley.  She was received with a cordial respect
7495 which could not but please, and given all the consequence she could
7496 wish for.  When the Westons arrived, the kindest looks of love,
7497 the strongest of admiration were for her, from both husband and wife;
7498 the son approached her with a cheerful eagerness which marked
7499 her as his peculiar object, and at dinner she found him seated
7500 by her--and, as she firmly believed, not without some dexterity
7501 on his side.
7502 
7503 The party was rather large, as it included one other family, a proper
7504 unobjectionable country family, whom the Coles had the advantage of
7505 naming among their acquaintance, and the male part of Mr. Cox's family,
7506 the lawyer of Highbury.  The less worthy females were to come
7507 in the evening, with Miss Bates, Miss Fairfax, and Miss Smith;
7508 but already, at dinner, they were too numerous for any subject
7509 of conversation to be general; and, while politics and Mr. Elton
7510 were talked over, Emma could fairly surrender all her attention to
7511 the pleasantness of her neighbour.  The first remote sound to which
7512 she felt herself obliged to attend, was the name of Jane Fairfax.
7513 Mrs. Cole seemed to be relating something of her that was expected to be
7514 very interesting.  She listened, and found it well worth listening to.
7515 That very dear part of Emma, her fancy, received an amusing supply.
7516 Mrs. Cole was telling that she had been calling on Miss Bates,
7517 and as soon as she entered the room had been struck by the sight
7518 of a pianoforte--a very elegant looking instrument--not a grand,
7519 but a large-sized square pianoforte; and the substance of the story,
7520 the end of all the dialogue which ensued of surprize, and inquiry,
7521 and congratulations on her side, and explanations on Miss Bates's, was,
7522 that this pianoforte had arrived from Broadwood's the day before,
7523 to the great astonishment of both aunt and niece--entirely unexpected;
7524 that at first, by Miss Bates's account, Jane herself was quite at
7525 a loss, quite bewildered to think who could possibly have ordered it--
7526 but now, they were both perfectly satisfied that it could be from only
7527 one quarter;--of course it must be from Colonel Campbell.
7528 
7529 "One can suppose nothing else," added Mrs. Cole, "and I was only
7530 surprized that there could ever have been a doubt.  But Jane,
7531 it seems, had a letter from them very lately, and not a word was said
7532 about it.  She knows their ways best; but I should not consider their
7533 silence as any reason for their not meaning to make the present.
7534 They might chuse to surprize her."
7535 
7536 Mrs. Cole had many to agree with her; every body who spoke on the
7537 subject was equally convinced that it must come from Colonel Campbell,
7538 and equally rejoiced that such a present had been made; and there
7539 were enough ready to speak to allow Emma to think her own way,
7540 and still listen to Mrs. Cole.
7541 
7542 "I declare, I do not know when I have heard any thing that has given
7543 me more satisfaction!--It always has quite hurt me that Jane Fairfax,
7544 who plays so delightfully, should not have an instrument.
7545 It seemed quite a shame, especially considering how many houses
7546 there are where fine instruments are absolutely thrown away.
7547 This is like giving ourselves a slap, to be sure! and it was
7548 but yesterday I was telling Mr. Cole, I really was ashamed
7549 to look at our new grand pianoforte in the drawing-room, while I
7550 do not know one note from another, and our little girls, who are
7551 but just beginning, perhaps may never make any thing of it;
7552 and there is poor Jane Fairfax, who is mistress of music, has not
7553 any thing of the nature of an instrument, not even the pitifullest
7554 old spinet in the world, to amuse herself with.--I was saying this
7555 to Mr. Cole but yesterday, and he quite agreed with me; only he
7556 is so particularly fond of music that he could not help indulging
7557 himself in the purchase, hoping that some of our good neighbours might
7558 be so obliging occasionally to put it to a better use than we can;
7559 and that really is the reason why the instrument was bought--
7560 or else I am sure we ought to be ashamed of it.--We are in great
7561 hopes that Miss Woodhouse may be prevailed with to try it this evening."
7562 
7563 Miss Woodhouse made the proper acquiescence; and finding that nothing
7564 more was to be entrapped from any communication of Mrs. Cole's,
7565 turned to Frank Churchill.
7566 
7567 "Why do you smile?" said she.
7568 
7569 "Nay, why do you?"
7570 
7571 "Me!--I suppose I smile for pleasure at Colonel Campbell's being
7572 so rich and so liberal.--It is a handsome present."
7573 
7574 "Very."
7575 
7576 "I rather wonder that it was never made before."
7577 
7578 "Perhaps Miss Fairfax has never been staying here so long before."
7579 
7580 "Or that he did not give her the use of their own instrument--
7581 which must now be shut up in London, untouched by any body."
7582 
7583 "That is a grand pianoforte, and he might think it too large
7584 for Mrs. Bates's house."
7585 
7586 "You may _say_ what you chuse--but your countenance testifies
7587 that your _thoughts_ on this subject are very much like mine."
7588 
7589 "I do not know.  I rather believe you are giving me more credit for
7590 acuteness than I deserve.  I smile because you smile, and shall probably
7591 suspect whatever I find you suspect; but at present I do not see what
7592 there is to question.  If Colonel Campbell is not the person, who can be?"
7593 
7594 "What do you say to Mrs. Dixon?"
7595 
7596 "Mrs. Dixon! very true indeed.  I had not thought of Mrs. Dixon.
7597 She must know as well as her father, how acceptable an instrument
7598 would be; and perhaps the mode of it, the mystery, the surprize,
7599 is more like a young woman's scheme than an elderly man's. It
7600 is Mrs. Dixon, I dare say.  I told you that your suspicions would
7601 guide mine."
7602 
7603 "If so, you must extend your suspicions and comprehend _Mr_. Dixon
7604 in them."
7605 
7606 "Mr. Dixon.--Very well.  Yes, I immediately perceive that it must
7607 be the joint present of Mr. and Mrs. Dixon.  We were speaking the
7608 other day, you know, of his being so warm an admirer of her performance."
7609 
7610 "Yes, and what you told me on that head, confirmed an idea which I
7611 had entertained before.--I do not mean to reflect upon the good
7612 intentions of either Mr. Dixon or Miss Fairfax, but I cannot help
7613 suspecting either that, after making his proposals to her friend,
7614 he had the misfortune to fall in love with _her_, or that he became
7615 conscious of a little attachment on her side.  One might guess
7616 twenty things without guessing exactly the right; but I am sure
7617 there must be a particular cause for her chusing to come to Highbury
7618 instead of going with the Campbells to Ireland.  Here, she must be
7619 leading a life of privation and penance; there it would have been
7620 all enjoyment.  As to the pretence of trying her native air, I look
7621 upon that as a mere excuse.--In the summer it might have passed;
7622 but what can any body's native air do for them in the months
7623 of January, February, and March?  Good fires and carriages would
7624 be much more to the purpose in most cases of delicate health, and I
7625 dare say in her's. I do not require you to adopt all my suspicions,
7626 though you make so noble a profession of doing it, but I honestly
7627 tell you what they are."
7628 
7629 "And, upon my word, they have an air of great probability.
7630 Mr. Dixon's preference of her music to her friend's, I can answer
7631 for being very decided."
7632 
7633 "And then, he saved her life.  Did you ever hear of that?--
7634 A water party; and by some accident she was falling overboard.
7635 He caught her."
7636 
7637 "He did.  I was there--one of the party."
7638 
7639 "Were you really?--Well!--But you observed nothing of course,
7640 for it seems to be a new idea to you.--If I had been there, I think
7641 I should have made some discoveries."
7642 
7643 "I dare say you would; but I, simple I, saw nothing but the fact,
7644 that Miss Fairfax was nearly dashed from the vessel and that Mr. Dixon
7645 caught her.--It was the work of a moment.  And though the consequent
7646 shock and alarm was very great and much more durable--indeed I
7647 believe it was half an hour before any of us were comfortable again--
7648 yet that was too general a sensation for any thing of peculiar
7649 anxiety to be observable.  I do not mean to say, however, that you
7650 might not have made discoveries."
7651 
7652 The conversation was here interrupted.  They were called on to share
7653 in the awkwardness of a rather long interval between the courses,
7654 and obliged to be as formal and as orderly as the others; but when
7655 the table was again safely covered, when every corner dish was placed
7656 exactly right, and occupation and ease were generally restored,
7657 Emma said,
7658 
7659 "The arrival of this pianoforte is decisive with me.  I wanted to know
7660 a little more, and this tells me quite enough.  Depend upon it,
7661 we shall soon hear that it is a present from Mr. and Mrs. Dixon."
7662 
7663 "And if the Dixons should absolutely deny all knowledge of it we
7664 must conclude it to come from the Campbells."
7665 
7666 "No, I am sure it is not from the Campbells.  Miss Fairfax knows it
7667 is not from the Campbells, or they would have been guessed at first.
7668 She would not have been puzzled, had she dared fix on them.
7669 I may not have convinced you perhaps, but I am perfectly convinced
7670 myself that Mr. Dixon is a principal in the business."
7671 
7672 "Indeed you injure me if you suppose me unconvinced.  Your reasonings
7673 carry my judgment along with them entirely.  At first, while I
7674 supposed you satisfied that Colonel Campbell was the giver, I saw
7675 it only as paternal kindness, and thought it the most natural thing
7676 in the world.  But when you mentioned Mrs. Dixon, I felt how much more
7677 probable that it should be the tribute of warm female friendship.
7678 And now I can see it in no other light than as an offering of love."
7679 
7680 There was no occasion to press the matter farther.  The conviction
7681 seemed real; he looked as if he felt it.  She said no more,
7682 other subjects took their turn; and the rest of the dinner passed away;
7683 the dessert succeeded, the children came in, and were talked
7684 to and admired amid the usual rate of conversation; a few clever
7685 things said, a few downright silly, but by much the larger proportion
7686 neither the one nor the other--nothing worse than everyday remarks,
7687 dull repetitions, old news, and heavy jokes.
7688 
7689 The ladies had not been long in the drawing-room, before the other ladies,
7690 in their different divisions, arrived.  Emma watched the entree of her
7691 own particular little friend; and if she could not exult in her dignity
7692 and grace, she could not only love the blooming sweetness and the
7693 artless manner, but could most heartily rejoice in that light, cheerful,
7694 unsentimental disposition which allowed her so many alleviations
7695 of pleasure, in the midst of the pangs of disappointed affection.
7696 There she sat--and who would have guessed how many tears she had
7697 been lately shedding?  To be in company, nicely dressed herself
7698 and seeing others nicely dressed, to sit and smile and look pretty,
7699 and say nothing, was enough for the happiness of the present hour.
7700 Jane Fairfax did look and move superior; but Emma suspected she
7701 might have been glad to change feelings with Harriet, very glad
7702 to have purchased the mortification of having loved--yes, of having
7703 loved even Mr. Elton in vain--by the surrender of all the dangerous
7704 pleasure of knowing herself beloved by the husband of her friend.
7705 
7706 In so large a party it was not necessary that Emma should approach her.
7707 She did not wish to speak of the pianoforte, she felt too much
7708 in the secret herself, to think the appearance of curiosity
7709 or interest fair, and therefore purposely kept at a distance;
7710 but by the others, the subject was almost immediately introduced,
7711 and she saw the blush of consciousness with which congratulations
7712 were received, the blush of guilt which accompanied the name of "my
7713 excellent friend Colonel Campbell."
7714 
7715 Mrs. Weston, kind-hearted and musical, was particularly interested
7716 by the circumstance, and Emma could not help being amused at her
7717 perseverance in dwelling on the subject; and having so much to ask
7718 and to say as to tone, touch, and pedal, totally unsuspicious
7719 of that wish of saying as little about it as possible, which she
7720 plainly read in the fair heroine's countenance.
7721 
7722 They were soon joined by some of the gentlemen; and the very first of the
7723 early was Frank Churchill.  In he walked, the first and the handsomest;
7724 and after paying his compliments en passant to Miss Bates and
7725 her niece, made his way directly to the opposite side of the circle,
7726 where sat Miss Woodhouse; and till he could find a seat by her,
7727 would not sit at all.  Emma divined what every body present must
7728 be thinking.  She was his object, and every body must perceive it.
7729 She introduced him to her friend, Miss Smith, and, at convenient
7730 moments afterwards, heard what each thought of the other.  "He had
7731 never seen so lovely a face, and was delighted with her naivete."
7732 And she, "Only to be sure it was paying him too great a compliment,
7733 but she did think there were some looks a little like Mr. Elton."
7734 Emma restrained her indignation, and only turned from her in silence.
7735 
7736 Smiles of intelligence passed between her and the gentleman on first
7737 glancing towards Miss Fairfax; but it was most prudent to avoid speech.
7738 He told her that he had been impatient to leave the dining-room--
7739 hated sitting long--was always the first to move when he could--
7740 that his father, Mr. Knightley, Mr. Cox, and Mr. Cole, were left
7741 very busy over parish business--that as long as he had staid,
7742 however, it had been pleasant enough, as he had found them in general
7743 a set of gentlemanlike, sensible men; and spoke so handsomely of
7744 Highbury altogether--thought it so abundant in agreeable families--
7745 that Emma began to feel she had been used to despise the place
7746 rather too much.  She questioned him as to the society in Yorkshire--
7747 the extent of the neighbourhood about Enscombe, and the sort;
7748 and could make out from his answers that, as far as Enscombe
7749 was concerned, there was very little going on, that their visitings
7750 were among a range of great families, none very near; and that even
7751 when days were fixed, and invitations accepted, it was an even
7752 chance that Mrs. Churchill were not in health and spirits for going;
7753 that they made a point of visiting no fresh person; and that,
7754 though he had his separate engagements, it was not without difficulty,
7755 without considerable address _at_ _times_, that he could get away,
7756 or introduce an acquaintance for a night.
7757 
7758 She saw that Enscombe could not satisfy, and that Highbury,
7759 taken at its best, might reasonably please a young man who had more
7760 retirement at home than he liked.  His importance at Enscombe was
7761 very evident.  He did not boast, but it naturally betrayed itself,
7762 that he had persuaded his aunt where his uncle could do nothing,
7763 and on her laughing and noticing it, he owned that he believed (excepting
7764 one or two points) he could _with_ _time_ persuade her to any thing.
7765 One of those points on which his influence failed, he then mentioned.
7766 He had wanted very much to go abroad--had been very eager indeed
7767 to be allowed to travel--but she would not hear of it.  This had
7768 happened the year before.  _Now_, he said, he was beginning to have
7769 no longer the same wish.
7770 
7771 The unpersuadable point, which he did not mention, Emma guessed
7772 to be good behaviour to his father.
7773 
7774 "I have made a most wretched discovery," said he, after a short pause.--
7775 "I have been here a week to-morrow--half my time.  I never knew
7776 days fly so fast.  A week to-morrow!--And I have hardly begun to
7777 enjoy myself.  But just got acquainted with Mrs. Weston, and others!--
7778 I hate the recollection."
7779 
7780 "Perhaps you may now begin to regret that you spent one whole day,
7781 out of so few, in having your hair cut."
7782 
7783 "No," said he, smiling, "that is no subject of regret at all.
7784 I have no pleasure in seeing my friends, unless I can believe myself
7785 fit to be seen."
7786 
7787 The rest of the gentlemen being now in the room, Emma found herself
7788 obliged to turn from him for a few minutes, and listen to Mr. Cole.
7789 When Mr. Cole had moved away, and her attention could be restored
7790 as before, she saw Frank Churchill looking intently across the room
7791 at Miss Fairfax, who was sitting exactly opposite.
7792 
7793 "What is the matter?" said she.
7794 
7795 He started.  "Thank you for rousing me," he replied.  "I believe
7796 I have been very rude; but really Miss Fairfax has done her hair
7797 in so odd a way--so very odd a way--that I cannot keep my eyes
7798 from her.  I never saw any thing so outree!--Those curls!--This must
7799 be a fancy of her own.  I see nobody else looking like her!--
7800 I must go and ask her whether it is an Irish fashion.  Shall I?--
7801 Yes, I will--I declare I will--and you shall see how she takes it;--
7802 whether she colours."
7803 
7804 He was gone immediately; and Emma soon saw him standing before Miss
7805 Fairfax, and talking to her; but as to its effect on the young lady,
7806 as he had improvidently placed himself exactly between them, exactly
7807 in front of Miss Fairfax, she could absolutely distinguish nothing.
7808 
7809 Before he could return to his chair, it was taken by Mrs. Weston.
7810 
7811 "This is the luxury of a large party," said she:--"one can get
7812 near every body, and say every thing.  My dear Emma, I am longing
7813 to talk to you.  I have been making discoveries and forming plans,
7814 just like yourself, and I must tell them while the idea is fresh.
7815 Do you know how Miss Bates and her niece came here?"
7816 
7817 "How?--They were invited, were not they?"
7818 
7819 "Oh! yes--but how they were conveyed hither?--the manner of their coming?"
7820 
7821 "They walked, I conclude.  How else could they come?"
7822 
7823 "Very true.--Well, a little while ago it occurred to me how very sad
7824 it would be to have Jane Fairfax walking home again, late at night,
7825 and cold as the nights are now.  And as I looked at her, though I
7826 never saw her appear to more advantage, it struck me that she
7827 was heated, and would therefore be particularly liable to take cold.
7828 Poor girl!  I could not bear the idea of it; so, as soon as Mr. Weston
7829 came into the room, and I could get at him, I spoke to him about
7830 the carriage.  You may guess how readily he came into my wishes;
7831 and having his approbation, I made my way directly to Miss Bates,
7832 to assure her that the carriage would be at her service before it took
7833 us home; for I thought it would be making her comfortable at once.
7834 Good soul! she was as grateful as possible, you may be sure.
7835 `Nobody was ever so fortunate as herself!'--but with many,
7836 many thanks--`there was no occasion to trouble us, for Mr. Knightley's
7837 carriage had brought, and was to take them home again.'  I was
7838 quite surprized;--very glad, I am sure; but really quite surprized.
7839 Such a very kind attention--and so thoughtful an attention!--
7840 the sort of thing that so few men would think of.  And, in short,
7841 from knowing his usual ways, I am very much inclined to think
7842 that it was for their accommodation the carriage was used at all.
7843 I do suspect he would not have had a pair of horses for himself,
7844 and that it was only as an excuse for assisting them."
7845 
7846 "Very likely," said Emma--"nothing more likely.  I know no man
7847 more likely than Mr. Knightley to do the sort of thing--to do any
7848 thing really good-natured, useful, considerate, or benevolent.
7849 He is not a gallant man, but he is a very humane one; and this,
7850 considering Jane Fairfax's ill-health, would appear a case
7851 of humanity to him;--and for an act of unostentatious kindness,
7852 there is nobody whom I would fix on more than on Mr. Knightley.
7853 I know he had horses to-day--for we arrived together; and I laughed at
7854 him about it, but he said not a word that could betray."
7855 
7856 "Well," said Mrs. Weston, smiling, "you give him credit for
7857 more simple, disinterested benevolence in this instance than I do;
7858 for while Miss Bates was speaking, a suspicion darted into my head,
7859 and I have never been able to get it out again.  The more I think
7860 of it, the more probable it appears.  In short, I have made a match
7861 between Mr. Knightley and Jane Fairfax.  See the consequence
7862 of keeping you company!--What do you say to it?"
7863 
7864 "Mr. Knightley and Jane Fairfax!" exclaimed Emma.  "Dear Mrs. Weston,
7865 how could you think of such a thing?--Mr. Knightley!--Mr. Knightley
7866 must not marry!--You would not have little Henry cut out from Donwell?--
7867 Oh! no, no, Henry must have Donwell.  I cannot at all consent to
7868 Mr. Knightley's marrying; and I am sure it is not at all likely.
7869 I am amazed that you should think of such a thing."
7870 
7871 "My dear Emma, I have told you what led me to think of it.
7872 I do not want the match--I do not want to injure dear little Henry--
7873 but the idea has been given me by circumstances; and if Mr. Knightley
7874 really wished to marry, you would not have him refrain on Henry's
7875 account, a boy of six years old, who knows nothing of the matter?"
7876 
7877 "Yes, I would.  I could not bear to have Henry supplanted.--
7878 Mr. Knightley marry!--No, I have never had such an idea, and I
7879 cannot adopt it now.  And Jane Fairfax, too, of all women!"
7880 
7881 "Nay, she has always been a first favourite with him, as you
7882 very well know."
7883 
7884 "But the imprudence of such a match!"
7885 
7886 "I am not speaking of its prudence; merely its probability."
7887 
7888 "I see no probability in it, unless you have any better foundation
7889 than what you mention.  His good-nature, his humanity, as I tell you,
7890 would be quite enough to account for the horses.  He has a great
7891 regard for the Bateses, you know, independent of Jane Fairfax--
7892 and is always glad to shew them attention.  My dear Mrs. Weston,
7893 do not take to match-making.  You do it very ill.  Jane Fairfax mistress
7894 of the Abbey!--Oh! no, no;--every feeling revolts.  For his own sake,
7895 I would not have him do so mad a thing."
7896 
7897 "Imprudent, if you please--but not mad.  Excepting inequality of fortune,
7898 and perhaps a little disparity of age, I can see nothing unsuitable."
7899 
7900 "But Mr. Knightley does not want to marry.  I am sure he has not the
7901 least idea of it.  Do not put it into his head.  Why should he marry?--
7902 He is as happy as possible by himself; with his farm, and his sheep,
7903 and his library, and all the parish to manage; and he is extremely
7904 fond of his brother's children.  He has no occasion to marry,
7905 either to fill up his time or his heart."
7906 
7907 "My dear Emma, as long as he thinks so, it is so; but if he really
7908 loves Jane Fairfax--"
7909 
7910 "Nonsense!  He does not care about Jane Fairfax.  In the way
7911 of love, I am sure he does not.  He would do any good to her,
7912 or her family; but--"
7913 
7914 "Well," said Mrs. Weston, laughing, "perhaps the greatest good he
7915 could do them, would be to give Jane such a respectable home."
7916 
7917 "If it would be good to her, I am sure it would be evil to himself;
7918 a very shameful and degrading connexion.  How would he bear to have
7919 Miss Bates belonging to him?--To have her haunting the Abbey,
7920 and thanking him all day long for his great kindness in marrying Jane?--
7921 `So very kind and obliging!--But he always had been such a very
7922 kind neighbour!'  And then fly off, through half a sentence,
7923 to her mother's old petticoat.  `Not that it was such a very old
7924 petticoat either--for still it would last a great while--and, indeed,
7925 she must thankfully say that their petticoats were all very strong.'"
7926 
7927 "For shame, Emma!  Do not mimic her.  You divert me against
7928 my conscience.  And, upon my word, I do not think Mr. Knightley would
7929 be much disturbed by Miss Bates.  Little things do not irritate him.
7930 She might talk on; and if he wanted to say any thing himself, he would
7931 only talk louder, and drown her voice.  But the question is not,
7932 whether it would be a bad connexion for him, but whether he wishes it;
7933 and I think he does.  I have heard him speak, and so must you,
7934 so very highly of Jane Fairfax!  The interest he takes in her--
7935 his anxiety about her health--his concern that she should have no
7936 happier prospect!  I have heard him express himself so warmly on
7937 those points!--Such an admirer of her performance on the pianoforte,
7938 and of her voice!  I have heard him say that he could listen to her
7939 for ever.  Oh! and I had almost forgotten one idea that occurred
7940 to me--this pianoforte that has been sent here by somebody--
7941 though we have all been so well satisfied to consider it a present
7942 from the Campbells, may it not be from Mr. Knightley?  I cannot
7943 help suspecting him.  I think he is just the person to do it,
7944 even without being in love."
7945 
7946 "Then it can be no argument to prove that he is in love.
7947 But I do not think it is at all a likely thing for him to do.
7948 Mr. Knightley does nothing mysteriously."
7949 
7950 "I have heard him lamenting her having no instrument repeatedly;
7951 oftener than I should suppose such a circumstance would, in the common
7952 course of things, occur to him."
7953 
7954 "Very well; and if he had intended to give her one, he would have
7955 told her so."
7956 
7957 "There might be scruples of delicacy, my dear Emma.  I have a very
7958 strong notion that it comes from him.  I am sure he was particularly
7959 silent when Mrs. Cole told us of it at dinner."
7960 
7961 "You take up an idea, Mrs. Weston, and run away with it; as you have
7962 many a time reproached me with doing.  I see no sign of attachment--
7963 I believe nothing of the pianoforte--and proof only shall convince
7964 me that Mr. Knightley has any thought of marrying Jane Fairfax."
7965 
7966 They combated the point some time longer in the same way; Emma rather
7967 gaining ground over the mind of her friend; for Mrs. Weston was
7968 the most used of the two to yield; till a little bustle in the room
7969 shewed them that tea was over, and the instrument in preparation;--
7970 and at the same moment Mr. Cole approaching to entreat Miss Woodhouse
7971 would do them the honour of trying it.  Frank Churchill, of whom,
7972 in the eagerness of her conversation with Mrs. Weston, she had been
7973 seeing nothing, except that he had found a seat by Miss Fairfax,
7974 followed Mr. Cole, to add his very pressing entreaties; and as,
7975 in every respect, it suited Emma best to lead, she gave a very
7976 proper compliance.
7977 
7978 She knew the limitations of her own powers too well to attempt
7979 more than she could perform with credit; she wanted neither taste
7980 nor spirit in the little things which are generally acceptable,
7981 and could accompany her own voice well.  One accompaniment to her song
7982 took her agreeably by surprize--a second, slightly but correctly
7983 taken by Frank Churchill.  Her pardon was duly begged at the close
7984 of the song, and every thing usual followed.  He was accused
7985 of having a delightful voice, and a perfect knowledge of music;
7986 which was properly denied; and that he knew nothing of the matter,
7987 and had no voice at all, roundly asserted.  They sang together
7988 once more; and Emma would then resign her place to Miss Fairfax,
7989 whose performance, both vocal and instrumental, she never could
7990 attempt to conceal from herself, was infinitely superior to her own.
7991 
7992 With mixed feelings, she seated herself at a little distance from the
7993 numbers round the instrument, to listen.  Frank Churchill sang again.
7994 They had sung together once or twice, it appeared, at Weymouth.
7995 But the sight of Mr. Knightley among the most attentive, soon drew
7996 away half Emma's mind; and she fell into a train of thinking
7997 on the subject of Mrs. Weston's suspicions, to which the sweet
7998 sounds of the united voices gave only momentary interruptions.
7999 Her objections to Mr. Knightley's marrying did not in the least subside.
8000 She could see nothing but evil in it.  It would be a great
8001 disappointment to Mr. John Knightley; consequently to Isabella.
8002 A real injury to the children--a most mortifying change,
8003 and material loss to them all;--a very great deduction from her
8004 father's daily comfort--and, as to herself, she could not at all
8005 endure the idea of Jane Fairfax at Donwell Abbey.  A Mrs. Knightley
8006 for them all to give way to!--No--Mr. Knightley must never marry.
8007 Little Henry must remain the heir of Donwell.
8008 
8009 Presently Mr. Knightley looked back, and came and sat down by her.
8010 They talked at first only of the performance.  His admiration
8011 was certainly very warm; yet she thought, but for Mrs. Weston,
8012 it would not have struck her.  As a sort of touchstone, however,
8013 she began to speak of his kindness in conveying the aunt and niece;
8014 and though his answer was in the spirit of cutting the matter short,
8015 she believed it to indicate only his disinclination to dwell on any
8016 kindness of his own.
8017 
8018 "I often feel concern," said she, "that I dare not make our carriage
8019 more useful on such occasions.  It is not that I am without the wish;
8020 but you know how impossible my father would deem it that James
8021 should put-to for such a purpose."
8022 
8023 "Quite out of the question, quite out of the question," he replied;--
8024 "but you must often wish it, I am sure."  And he smiled with such
8025 seeming pleasure at the conviction, that she must proceed another step.
8026 
8027 "This present from the Campbells," said she--"this pianoforte
8028 is very kindly given."
8029 
8030 "Yes," he replied, and without the smallest apparent embarrassment.--
8031 "But they would have done better had they given her notice of it.
8032 Surprizes are foolish things.  The pleasure is not enhanced, and the
8033 inconvenience is often considerable.  I should have expected better
8034 judgment in Colonel Campbell."
8035 
8036 From that moment, Emma could have taken her oath that Mr. Knightley
8037 had had no concern in giving the instrument.  But whether he
8038 were entirely free from peculiar attachment--whether there
8039 were no actual preference--remained a little longer doubtful.
8040 Towards the end of Jane's second song, her voice grew thick.
8041 
8042 "That will do," said he, when it was finished, thinking aloud--
8043 "you have sung quite enough for one evening--now be quiet."
8044 
8045 Another song, however, was soon begged for.  "One more;--they would
8046 not fatigue Miss Fairfax on any account, and would only ask for
8047 one more."  And Frank Churchill was heard to say, "I think you could
8048 manage this without effort; the first part is so very trifling.
8049 The strength of the song falls on the second."
8050 
8051 Mr. Knightley grew angry.
8052 
8053 "That fellow," said he, indignantly, "thinks of nothing but shewing
8054 off his own voice.  This must not be."  And touching Miss Bates,
8055 who at that moment passed near--"Miss Bates, are you mad, to let
8056 your niece sing herself hoarse in this manner?  Go, and interfere.
8057 They have no mercy on her."
8058 
8059 Miss Bates, in her real anxiety for Jane, could hardly stay even
8060 to be grateful, before she stept forward and put an end to all
8061 farther singing.  Here ceased the concert part of the evening,
8062 for Miss Woodhouse and Miss Fairfax were the only young lady performers;
8063 but soon (within five minutes) the proposal of dancing--
8064 originating nobody exactly knew where--was so effectually promoted
8065 by Mr. and Mrs. Cole, that every thing was rapidly clearing away,
8066 to give proper space.  Mrs. Weston, capital in her country-dances,
8067 was seated, and beginning an irresistible waltz; and Frank Churchill,
8068 coming up with most becoming gallantry to Emma, had secured her hand,
8069 and led her up to the top.
8070 
8071 While waiting till the other young people could pair themselves off,
8072 Emma found time, in spite of the compliments she was receiving on her
8073 voice and her taste, to look about, and see what became of Mr. Knightley.
8074 This would be a trial.  He was no dancer in general.  If he were to be
8075 very alert in engaging Jane Fairfax now, it might augur something.
8076 There was no immediate appearance.  No; he was talking to Mrs. Cole--
8077 he was looking on unconcerned; Jane was asked by somebody else,
8078 and he was still talking to Mrs. Cole.
8079 
8080 Emma had no longer an alarm for Henry; his interest was yet safe;
8081 and she led off the dance with genuine spirit and enjoyment.
8082 Not more than five couple could be mustered; but the rarity and the
8083 suddenness of it made it very delightful, and she found herself well
8084 matched in a partner.  They were a couple worth looking at.
8085 
8086 Two dances, unfortunately, were all that could be allowed.
8087 It was growing late, and Miss Bates became anxious to get home,
8088 on her mother's account.  After some attempts, therefore, to be
8089 permitted to begin again, they were obliged to thank Mrs. Weston,
8090 look sorrowful, and have done.
8091 
8092 "Perhaps it is as well," said Frank Churchill, as he attended Emma
8093 to her carriage.  "I must have asked Miss Fairfax, and her languid
8094 dancing would not have agreed with me, after your's."
8095 
8096 
8097 
8098 CHAPTER IX
8099 
8100 
8101 Emma did not repent her condescension in going to the Coles.
8102 The visit afforded her many pleasant recollections the next day;
8103 and all that she might be supposed to have lost on the side
8104 of dignified seclusion, must be amply repaid in the splendour
8105 of popularity.  She must have delighted the Coles--worthy people,
8106 who deserved to be made happy!--And left a name behind her that would
8107 not soon die away.
8108 
8109 Perfect happiness, even in memory, is not common; and there were
8110 two points on which she was not quite easy.  She doubted whether
8111 she had not transgressed the duty of woman by woman, in betraying
8112 her suspicions of Jane Fairfax's feelings to Frank Churchill.
8113 It was hardly right; but it had been so strong an idea, that it
8114 would escape her, and his submission to all that she told,
8115 was a compliment to her penetration, which made it difficult
8116 for her to be quite certain that she ought to have held her tongue.
8117 
8118 The other circumstance of regret related also to Jane Fairfax;
8119 and there she had no doubt.  She did unfeignedly and unequivocally
8120 regret the inferiority of her own playing and singing.  She did
8121 most heartily grieve over the idleness of her childhood--and sat
8122 down and practised vigorously an hour and a half.
8123 
8124 She was then interrupted by Harriet's coming in; and if Harriet's
8125 praise could have satisfied her, she might soon have been comforted.
8126 
8127 "Oh! if I could but play as well as you and Miss Fairfax!"
8128 
8129 "Don't class us together, Harriet.  My playing is no more like
8130 her's, than a lamp is like sunshine."
8131 
8132 "Oh! dear--I think you play the best of the two.  I think you play
8133 quite as well as she does.  I am sure I had much rather hear you.
8134 Every body last night said how well you played."
8135 
8136 "Those who knew any thing about it, must have felt the difference.
8137 The truth is, Harriet, that my playing is just good enough to be praised,
8138 but Jane Fairfax's is much beyond it."
8139 
8140 "Well, I always shall think that you play quite as well as she does,
8141 or that if there is any difference nobody would ever find it out.
8142 Mr. Cole said how much taste you had; and Mr. Frank Churchill talked
8143 a great deal about your taste, and that he valued taste much more
8144 than execution."
8145 
8146 "Ah! but Jane Fairfax has them both, Harriet."
8147 
8148 "Are you sure?  I saw she had execution, but I did not know she had
8149 any taste.  Nobody talked about it.  And I hate Italian singing.--
8150 There is no understanding a word of it.  Besides, if she does play
8151 so very well, you know, it is no more than she is obliged to do,
8152 because she will have to teach.  The Coxes were wondering last night
8153 whether she would get into any great family.  How did you think the
8154 Coxes looked?"
8155 
8156 "Just as they always do--very vulgar."
8157 
8158 "They told me something," said Harriet rather hesitatingly;"
8159 but it is nothing of any consequence."
8160 
8161 Emma was obliged to ask what they had told her, though fearful
8162 of its producing Mr. Elton.
8163 
8164 "They told me--that Mr. Martin dined with them last Saturday."
8165 
8166 "Oh!"
8167 
8168 "He came to their father upon some business, and he asked him
8169 to stay to dinner."
8170 
8171 "Oh!"
8172 
8173 "They talked a great deal about him, especially Anne Cox.
8174 I do not know what she meant, but she asked me if I thought I
8175 should go and stay there again next summer."
8176 
8177 "She meant to be impertinently curious, just as such an Anne Cox
8178 should be."
8179 
8180 "She said he was very agreeable the day he dined there.  He sat
8181 by her at dinner.  Miss Nash thinks either of the Coxes would
8182 be very glad to marry him."
8183 
8184 "Very likely.--I think they are, without exception, the most vulgar
8185 girls in Highbury."
8186 
8187 Harriet had business at Ford's.--Emma thought it most prudent to go
8188 with her.  Another accidental meeting with the Martins was possible,
8189 and in her present state, would be dangerous.
8190 
8191 Harriet, tempted by every thing and swayed by half a word, was always
8192 very long at a purchase; and while she was still hanging over muslins
8193 and changing her mind, Emma went to the door for amusement.--Much could
8194 not be hoped from the traffic of even the busiest part of Highbury;--
8195 Mr. Perry walking hastily by, Mr. William Cox letting himself in at
8196 the office-door, Mr. Cole's carriage-horses returning from exercise,
8197 or a stray letter-boy on an obstinate mule, were the liveliest
8198 objects she could presume to expect; and when her eyes fell only on
8199 the butcher with his tray, a tidy old woman travelling homewards from
8200 shop with her full basket, two curs quarrelling over a dirty bone,
8201 and a string of dawdling children round the baker's little bow-window
8202 eyeing the gingerbread, she knew she had no reason to complain,
8203 and was amused enough; quite enough still to stand at the door.
8204 A mind lively and at ease, can do with seeing nothing, and can see
8205 nothing that does not answer.
8206 
8207 She looked down the Randalls road.  The scene enlarged;
8208 two persons appeared; Mrs. Weston and her son-in-law; they were
8209 walking into Highbury;--to Hartfield of course.  They were stopping,
8210 however, in the first place at Mrs. Bates's; whose house was
8211 a little nearer Randalls than Ford's; and had all but knocked,
8212 when Emma caught their eye.--Immediately they crossed the road
8213 and came forward to her; and the agreeableness of yesterday's
8214 engagement seemed to give fresh pleasure to the present meeting.
8215 Mrs. Weston informed her that she was going to call on the Bateses,
8216 in order to hear the new instrument.
8217 
8218 "For my companion tells me," said she, "that I absolutely promised
8219 Miss Bates last night, that I would come this morning.  I was
8220 not aware of it myself.  I did not know that I had fixed a day,
8221 but as he says I did, I am going now."
8222 
8223 "And while Mrs. Weston pays her visit, I may be allowed, I hope,"
8224 said Frank Churchill, "to join your party and wait for her at Hartfield--
8225 if you are going home."
8226 
8227 Mrs. Weston was disappointed.
8228 
8229 "I thought you meant to go with me.  They would be very much pleased."
8230 
8231 "Me!  I should be quite in the way.  But, perhaps--I may be equally
8232 in the way here.  Miss Woodhouse looks as if she did not want me.
8233 My aunt always sends me off when she is shopping.  She says I fidget
8234 her to death; and Miss Woodhouse looks as if she could almost say
8235 the same.  What am I to do?"
8236 
8237 "I am here on no business of my own," said Emma; "I am only waiting
8238 for my friend.  She will probably have soon done, and then we
8239 shall go home.  But you had better go with Mrs. Weston and hear
8240 the instrument."
8241 
8242 "Well--if you advise it.--But (with a smile) if Colonel Campbell
8243 should have employed a careless friend, and if it should prove
8244 to have an indifferent tone--what shall I say?  I shall be no
8245 support to Mrs. Weston.  She might do very well by herself.
8246 A disagreeable truth would be palatable through her lips, but I
8247 am the wretchedest being in the world at a civil falsehood."
8248 
8249 "I do not believe any such thing," replied Emma.--"I am persuaded
8250 that you can be as insincere as your neighbours, when it is necessary;
8251 but there is no reason to suppose the instrument is indifferent.
8252 Quite otherwise indeed, if I understood Miss Fairfax's opinion
8253 last night."
8254 
8255 "Do come with me," said Mrs. Weston, "if it be not very disagreeable
8256 to you.  It need not detain us long.  We will go to Hartfield afterwards.
8257 We will follow them to Hartfield.  I really wish you to call with me.
8258 It will be felt so great an attention! and I always thought you
8259 meant it."
8260 
8261 He could say no more; and with the hope of Hartfield to reward him,
8262 returned with Mrs. Weston to Mrs. Bates's door.  Emma watched them in,
8263 and then joined Harriet at the interesting counter,--trying, with all
8264 the force of her own mind, to convince her that if she wanted plain
8265 muslin it was of no use to look at figured; and that a blue ribbon,
8266 be it ever so beautiful, would still never match her yellow pattern.
8267 At last it was all settled, even to the destination of the parcel.
8268 
8269 "Should I send it to Mrs. Goddard's, ma'am?" asked Mrs. Ford.--
8270 "Yes--no--yes, to Mrs. Goddard's. Only my pattern gown is
8271 at Hartfield.  No, you shall send it to Hartfield, if you please.
8272 But then, Mrs. Goddard will want to see it.--And I could take the
8273 pattern gown home any day.  But I shall want the ribbon directly--
8274 so it had better go to Hartfield--at least the ribbon.  You could
8275 make it into two parcels, Mrs. Ford, could not you?"
8276 
8277 "It is not worth while, Harriet, to give Mrs. Ford the trouble
8278 of two parcels."
8279 
8280 "No more it is."
8281 
8282 "No trouble in the world, ma'am," said the obliging Mrs. Ford.
8283 
8284 "Oh! but indeed I would much rather have it only in one.
8285 Then, if you please, you shall send it all to Mrs. Goddard's--
8286 I do not know--No, I think, Miss Woodhouse, I may just as well
8287 have it sent to Hartfield, and take it home with me at night.
8288 What do you advise?"
8289 
8290 "That you do not give another half-second to the subject.
8291 To Hartfield, if you please, Mrs. Ford."
8292 
8293 "Aye, that will be much best," said Harriet, quite satisfied,
8294 "I should not at all like to have it sent to Mrs. Goddard's."
8295 
8296 Voices approached the shop--or rather one voice and two ladies:
8297 Mrs. Weston and Miss Bates met them at the door.
8298 
8299 "My dear Miss Woodhouse," said the latter, "I am just run across to
8300 entreat the favour of you to come and sit down with us a little while,
8301 and give us your opinion of our new instrument; you and Miss Smith.
8302 How do you do, Miss Smith?--Very well I thank you.--And I begged
8303 Mrs. Weston to come with me, that I might be sure of succeeding."
8304 
8305 "I hope Mrs. Bates and Miss Fairfax are--"
8306 
8307 "Very well, I am much obliged to you.  My mother is delightfully well;
8308 and Jane caught no cold last night.  How is Mr. Woodhouse?--I am so glad
8309 to hear such a good account.  Mrs. Weston told me you were here.--
8310 Oh! then, said I, I must run across, I am sure Miss Woodhouse will
8311 allow me just to run across and entreat her to come in; my mother
8312 will be so very happy to see her--and now we are such a nice party,
8313 she cannot refuse.--`Aye, pray do,' said Mr. Frank Churchill,
8314 `Miss Woodhouse's opinion of the instrument will be worth having.'--
8315 But, said I, I shall be more sure of succeeding if one of you will go
8316 with me.--`Oh,' said he, `wait half a minute, till I have finished
8317 my job;'--For, would you believe it, Miss Woodhouse, there he is,
8318 in the most obliging manner in the world, fastening in the rivet of my
8319 mother's spectacles.--The rivet came out, you know, this morning.--
8320 So very obliging!--For my mother had no use of her spectacles--
8321 could not put them on.  And, by the bye, every body ought to have
8322 two pair of spectacles; they should indeed.  Jane said so.
8323 I meant to take them over to John Saunders the first thing I did,
8324 but something or other hindered me all the morning; first one thing,
8325 then another, there is no saying what, you know.  At one time Patty came
8326 to say she thought the kitchen chimney wanted sweeping.  Oh, said I,
8327 Patty do not come with your bad news to me.  Here is the rivet
8328 of your mistress's spectacles out.  Then the baked apples came home,
8329 Mrs. Wallis sent them by her boy; they are extremely civil and
8330 obliging to us, the Wallises, always--I have heard some people
8331 say that Mrs. Wallis can be uncivil and give a very rude answer,
8332 but we have never known any thing but the greatest attention
8333 from them.  And it cannot be for the value of our custom now,
8334 for what is our consumption of bread, you know?  Only three of us.--
8335 besides dear Jane at present--and she really eats nothing--makes such
8336 a shocking breakfast, you would be quite frightened if you saw it.
8337 I dare not let my mother know how little she eats--so I say one
8338 thing and then I say another, and it passes off.  But about the
8339 middle of the day she gets hungry, and there is nothing she likes
8340 so well as these baked apples, and they are extremely wholesome,
8341 for I took the opportunity the other day of asking Mr. Perry;
8342 I happened to meet him in the street.  Not that I had any doubt before--
8343 I have so often heard Mr. Woodhouse recommend a baked apple.
8344 I believe it is the only way that Mr. Woodhouse thinks the
8345 fruit thoroughly wholesome.  We have apple-dumplings, however,
8346 very often.  Patty makes an excellent apple-dumpling. Well,
8347 Mrs. Weston, you have prevailed, I hope, and these ladies will
8348 oblige us."
8349 
8350 Emma would be "very happy to wait on Mrs. Bates, &c.," and they
8351 did at last move out of the shop, with no farther delay from Miss
8352 Bates than,
8353 
8354 "How do you do, Mrs. Ford?  I beg your pardon.  I did not see
8355 you before.  I hear you have a charming collection of new ribbons
8356 from town.  Jane came back delighted yesterday.  Thank ye,
8357 the gloves do very well--only a little too large about the wrist;
8358 but Jane is taking them in."
8359 
8360 "What was I talking of?" said she, beginning again when they were
8361 all in the street.
8362 
8363 Emma wondered on what, of all the medley, she would fix.
8364 
8365 "I declare I cannot recollect what I was talking of.--Oh! my
8366 mother's spectacles.  So very obliging of Mr. Frank Churchill!
8367 `Oh!' said he, `I do think I can fasten the rivet; I like a job
8368 of this kind excessively.'--Which you know shewed him to be so
8369 very. . . . Indeed I must say that, much as I had heard of him
8370 before and much as I had expected, he very far exceeds any
8371 thing. . . . I do congratulate you, Mrs. Weston, most warmly.
8372 He seems every thing the fondest parent could. . . . `Oh!' said he,
8373 `I can fasten the rivet.  I like a job of that sort excessively.'
8374 I never shall forget his manner.  And when I brought out the baked
8375 apples from the closet, and hoped our friends would be so very
8376 obliging as to take some, `Oh!' said he directly, `there is nothing
8377 in the way of fruit half so good, and these are the finest-looking
8378 home-baked apples I ever saw in my life.'  That, you know, was so
8379 very. . . . And I am sure, by his manner, it was no compliment.
8380 Indeed they are very delightful apples, and Mrs. Wallis does them
8381 full justice--only we do not have them baked more than twice,
8382 and Mr. Woodhouse made us promise to have them done three times--
8383 but Miss Woodhouse will be so good as not to mention it.  The apples
8384 themselves are the very finest sort for baking, beyond a doubt;
8385 all from Donwell--some of Mr. Knightley's most liberal supply.
8386 He sends us a sack every year; and certainly there never was such
8387 a keeping apple anywhere as one of his trees--I believe there
8388 is two of them.  My mother says the orchard was always famous
8389 in her younger days.  But I was really quite shocked the other day--
8390 for Mr. Knightley called one morning, and Jane was eating these apples,
8391 and we talked about them and said how much she enjoyed them,
8392 and he asked whether we were not got to the end of our stock.
8393 `I am sure you must be,' said he, `and I will send you
8394 another supply; for I have a great many more than I can ever use.
8395 William Larkins let me keep a larger quantity than usual this year.
8396 I will send you some more, before they get good for nothing.'
8397 So I begged he would not--for really as to ours being gone, I could
8398 not absolutely say that we had a great many left--it was but half
8399 a dozen indeed; but they should be all kept for Jane; and I could
8400 not at all bear that he should be sending us more, so liberal as he
8401 had been already; and Jane said the same.  And when he was gone,
8402 she almost quarrelled with me--No, I should not say quarrelled,
8403 for we never had a quarrel in our lives; but she was quite distressed
8404 that I had owned the apples were so nearly gone; she wished I had
8405 made him believe we had a great many left.  Oh, said I, my dear,
8406 I did say as much as I could.  However, the very same evening
8407 William Larkins came over with a large basket of apples, the same
8408 sort of apples, a bushel at least, and I was very much obliged,
8409 and went down and spoke to William Larkins and said every thing,
8410 as you may suppose.  William Larkins is such an old acquaintance!
8411 I am always glad to see him.  But, however, I found afterwards
8412 from Patty, that William said it was all the apples of _that_ sort
8413 his master had; he had brought them all--and now his master had not
8414 one left to bake or boil.  William did not seem to mind it himself,
8415 he was so pleased to think his master had sold so many; for William,
8416 you know, thinks more of his master's profit than any thing;
8417 but Mrs. Hodges, he said, was quite displeased at their being
8418 all sent away.  She could not bear that her master should not be
8419 able to have another apple-tart this spring.  He told Patty this,
8420 but bid her not mind it, and be sure not to say any thing to us
8421 about it, for Mrs. Hodges _would_ be cross sometimes, and as long as
8422 so many sacks were sold, it did not signify who ate the remainder.
8423 And so Patty told me, and I was excessively shocked indeed!
8424 I would not have Mr. Knightley know any thing about it for
8425 the world!  He would be so very. . . . I wanted to keep it from
8426 Jane's knowledge; but, unluckily, I had mentioned it before I was
8427 aware."
8428 
8429 Miss Bates had just done as Patty opened the door; and her visitors
8430 walked upstairs without having any regular narration to attend to,
8431 pursued only by the sounds of her desultory good-will.
8432 
8433 "Pray take care, Mrs. Weston, there is a step at the turning.
8434 Pray take care, Miss Woodhouse, ours is rather a dark staircase--
8435 rather darker and narrower than one could wish.  Miss Smith,
8436 pray take care.  Miss Woodhouse, I am quite concerned, I am sure you
8437 hit your foot.  Miss Smith, the step at the turning."
8438 
8439 
8440 
8441 CHAPTER X
8442 
8443 
8444 The appearance of the little sitting-room as they entered,
8445 was tranquillity itself; Mrs. Bates, deprived of her usual employment,
8446 slumbering on one side of the fire, Frank Churchill, at a table
8447 near her, most deedily occupied about her spectacles, and Jane Fairfax,
8448 standing with her back to them, intent on her pianoforte.
8449 
8450 Busy as he was, however, the young man was yet able to shew a most
8451 happy countenance on seeing Emma again.
8452 
8453 "This is a pleasure," said he, in rather a low voice, "coming at
8454 least ten minutes earlier than I had calculated.  You find me
8455 trying to be useful; tell me if you think I shall succeed."
8456 
8457 "What!" said Mrs. Weston, "have not you finished it yet? you would
8458 not earn a very good livelihood as a working silversmith at this rate."
8459 
8460 "I have not been working uninterruptedly," he replied, "I have been
8461 assisting Miss Fairfax in trying to make her instrument stand steadily,
8462 it was not quite firm; an unevenness in the floor, I believe.
8463 You see we have been wedging one leg with paper.  This was very kind
8464 of you to be persuaded to come.  I was almost afraid you would be
8465 hurrying home."
8466 
8467 He contrived that she should be seated by him; and was sufficiently
8468 employed in looking out the best baked apple for her, and trying
8469 to make her help or advise him in his work, till Jane Fairfax was
8470 quite ready to sit down to the pianoforte again.  That she was not
8471 immediately ready, Emma did suspect to arise from the state of her nerves;
8472 she had not yet possessed the instrument long enough to touch it
8473 without emotion; she must reason herself into the power of performance;
8474 and Emma could not but pity such feelings, whatever their origin,
8475 and could not but resolve never to expose them to her neighbour again.
8476 
8477 At last Jane began, and though the first bars were feebly given,
8478 the powers of the instrument were gradually done full justice to.
8479 Mrs. Weston had been delighted before, and was delighted again;
8480 Emma joined her in all her praise; and the pianoforte, with every
8481 proper discrimination, was pronounced to be altogether of the
8482 highest promise.
8483 
8484 "Whoever Colonel Campbell might employ," said Frank Churchill,
8485 with a smile at Emma, "the person has not chosen ill.  I heard a good
8486 deal of Colonel Campbell's taste at Weymouth; and the softness of the
8487 upper notes I am sure is exactly what he and _all_ _that_ _party_ would
8488 particularly prize.  I dare say, Miss Fairfax, that he either gave
8489 his friend very minute directions, or wrote to Broadwood himself.
8490 Do not you think so?"
8491 
8492 Jane did not look round.  She was not obliged to hear.  Mrs. Weston
8493 had been speaking to her at the same moment.
8494 
8495 "It is not fair," said Emma, in a whisper; "mine was a random guess.
8496 Do not distress her."
8497 
8498 He shook his head with a smile, and looked as if he had very little
8499 doubt and very little mercy.  Soon afterwards he began again,
8500 
8501 "How much your friends in Ireland must be enjoying your pleasure
8502 on this occasion, Miss Fairfax.  I dare say they often think of you,
8503 and wonder which will be the day, the precise day of the instrument's
8504 coming to hand.  Do you imagine Colonel Campbell knows the business
8505 to be going forward just at this time?--Do you imagine it to be
8506 the consequence of an immediate commission from him, or that he may
8507 have sent only a general direction, an order indefinite as to time,
8508 to depend upon contingencies and conveniences?"
8509 
8510 He paused.  She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering,
8511 
8512 "Till I have a letter from Colonel Campbell," said she, in a voice
8513 of forced calmness, "I can imagine nothing with any confidence.
8514 It must be all conjecture."
8515
