8516 "Conjecture--aye, sometimes one conjectures right, and sometimes
8517 one conjectures wrong.  I wish I could conjecture how soon I shall
8518 make this rivet quite firm.  What nonsense one talks, Miss Woodhouse,
8519 when hard at work, if one talks at all;--your real workmen,
8520 I suppose, hold their tongues; but we gentlemen labourers if we get
8521 hold of a word--Miss Fairfax said something about conjecturing.
8522 There, it is done.  I have the pleasure, madam, (to Mrs. Bates,)
8523 of restoring your spectacles, healed for the present."
8524 
8525 He was very warmly thanked both by mother and daughter; to escape
8526 a little from the latter, he went to the pianoforte, and begged
8527 Miss Fairfax, who was still sitting at it, to play something more.
8528 
8529 "If you are very kind," said he, "it will be one of the waltzes
8530 we danced last night;--let me live them over again.  You did not
8531 enjoy them as I did; you appeared tired the whole time.  I believe
8532 you were glad we danced no longer; but I would have given worlds--
8533 all the worlds one ever has to give--for another half-hour."
8534 
8535 She played.
8536 
8537 "What felicity it is to hear a tune again which _has_ made one happy!--
8538 If I mistake not that was danced at Weymouth."
8539 
8540 She looked up at him for a moment, coloured deeply, and played
8541 something else.  He took some music from a chair near the pianoforte,
8542 and turning to Emma, said,
8543 
8544 "Here is something quite new to me.  Do you know it?--Cramer.--
8545 And here are a new set of Irish melodies.  That, from such a quarter,
8546 one might expect.  This was all sent with the instrument.  Very thoughtful
8547 of Colonel Campbell, was not it?--He knew Miss Fairfax could have
8548 no music here.  I honour that part of the attention particularly;
8549 it shews it to have been so thoroughly from the heart.  Nothing hastily
8550 done; nothing incomplete.  True affection only could have prompted it."
8551 
8552 Emma wished he would be less pointed, yet could not help being amused;
8553 and when on glancing her eye towards Jane Fairfax she caught
8554 the remains of a smile, when she saw that with all the deep blush
8555 of consciousness, there had been a smile of secret delight,
8556 she had less scruple in the amusement, and much less compunction
8557 with respect to her.--This amiable, upright, perfect Jane Fairfax
8558 was apparently cherishing very reprehensible feelings.
8559 
8560 He brought all the music to her, and they looked it over together.--
8561 Emma took the opportunity of whispering,
8562 
8563 "You speak too plain.  She must understand you."
8564 
8565 "I hope she does.  I would have her understand me.  I am not
8566 in the least ashamed of my meaning."
8567 
8568 "But really, I am half ashamed, and wish I had never taken up
8569 the idea."
8570 
8571 "I am very glad you did, and that you communicated it to me.
8572 I have now a key to all her odd looks and ways.  Leave shame to her.
8573 If she does wrong, she ought to feel it."
8574 
8575 "She is not entirely without it, I think."
8576 
8577 "I do not see much sign of it.  She is playing _Robin_ _Adair_
8578 at this moment--_his_ favourite."
8579 
8580 Shortly afterwards Miss Bates, passing near the window,
8581 descried Mr. Knightley on horse-back not far off.
8582 
8583 "Mr. Knightley I declare!--I must speak to him if possible,
8584 just to thank him.  I will not open the window here; it would give
8585 you all cold; but I can go into my mother's room you know.  I dare
8586 say he will come in when he knows who is here.  Quite delightful
8587 to have you all meet so!--Our little room so honoured!"
8588 
8589 She was in the adjoining chamber while she still spoke, and opening
8590 the casement there, immediately called Mr. Knightley's attention,
8591 and every syllable of their conversation was as distinctly heard
8592 by the others, as if it had passed within the same apartment.
8593 
8594 "How d' ye do?--how d'ye do?--Very well, I thank you.  So obliged
8595 to you for the carriage last night.  We were just in time;
8596 my mother just ready for us.  Pray come in; do come in.  You will
8597 find some friends here."
8598 
8599 So began Miss Bates; and Mr. Knightley seemed determined to be heard
8600 in his turn, for most resolutely and commandingly did he say,
8601 
8602 "How is your niece, Miss Bates?--I want to inquire after you all,
8603 but particularly your niece.  How is Miss Fairfax?--I hope she
8604 caught no cold last night.  How is she to-day? Tell me how Miss
8605 Fairfax is."
8606 
8607 And Miss Bates was obliged to give a direct answer before he
8608 would hear her in any thing else.  The listeners were amused;
8609 and Mrs. Weston gave Emma a look of particular meaning.  But Emma
8610 still shook her head in steady scepticism.
8611 
8612 "So obliged to you!--so very much obliged to you for the carriage,"
8613 resumed Miss Bates.
8614 
8615 He cut her short with,
8616 
8617 "I am going to Kingston.  Can I do any thing for you?"
8618 
8619 "Oh! dear, Kingston--are you?--Mrs. Cole was saying the other day
8620 she wanted something from Kingston."
8621 
8622 "Mrs. Cole has servants to send.  Can I do any thing for _you_?"
8623 
8624 "No, I thank you.  But do come in.  Who do you think is here?--
8625 Miss Woodhouse and Miss Smith; so kind as to call to hear the
8626 new pianoforte.  Do put up your horse at the Crown, and come in."
8627 
8628 "Well," said he, in a deliberating manner, "for five minutes, perhaps."
8629 
8630 "And here is Mrs. Weston and Mr. Frank Churchill too!--Quite delightful;
8631 so many friends!"
8632 
8633 "No, not now, I thank you.  I could not stay two minutes.
8634 I must get on to Kingston as fast as I can."
8635 
8636 "Oh! do come in.  They will be so very happy to see you."
8637 
8638 "No, no; your room is full enough.  I will call another day,
8639 and hear the pianoforte."
8640 
8641 "Well, I am so sorry!--Oh!  Mr. Knightley, what a delightful party
8642 last night; how extremely pleasant.--Did you ever see such dancing?--
8643 Was not it delightful?--Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill;
8644 I never saw any thing equal to it."
8645 
8646 "Oh! very delightful indeed; I can say nothing less, for I suppose
8647 Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill are hearing every thing
8648 that passes.  And (raising his voice still more) I do not see why Miss
8649 Fairfax should not be mentioned too.  I think Miss Fairfax dances
8650 very well; and Mrs. Weston is the very best country-dance player,
8651 without exception, in England.  Now, if your friends have any gratitude,
8652 they will say something pretty loud about you and me in return;
8653 but I cannot stay to hear it."
8654 
8655 "Oh!  Mr. Knightley, one moment more; something of consequence--
8656 so shocked!--Jane and I are both so shocked about the apples!"
8657 
8658 "What is the matter now?"
8659 
8660 "To think of your sending us all your store apples.  You said you had
8661 a great many, and now you have not one left.  We really are so shocked!
8662 Mrs. Hodges may well be angry.  William Larkins mentioned it here.
8663 You should not have done it, indeed you should not.  Ah! he is off.
8664 He never can bear to be thanked.  But I thought he would have staid now,
8665 and it would have been a pity not to have mentioned. . . . Well,
8666 (returning to the room,) I have not been able to succeed.
8667 Mr. Knightley cannot stop.  He is going to Kingston.  He asked me
8668 if he could do any thing. . . ."
8669 
8670 "Yes," said Jane, "we heard his kind offers, we heard every thing."
8671 
8672 "Oh! yes, my dear, I dare say you might, because you know, the door
8673 was open, and the window was open, and Mr. Knightley spoke loud.
8674 You must have heard every thing to be sure.  `Can I do any thing
8675 for you at Kingston?' said he; so I just mentioned. . . . Oh!
8676 Miss Woodhouse, must you be going?--You seem but just come--so very
8677 obliging of you."
8678 
8679 Emma found it really time to be at home; the visit had already
8680 lasted long; and on examining watches, so much of the morning was
8681 perceived to be gone, that Mrs. Weston and her companion taking
8682 leave also, could allow themselves only to walk with the two young
8683 ladies to Hartfield gates, before they set off for Randalls.
8684 
8685 
8686 
8687 CHAPTER XI
8688 
8689 
8690 It may be possible to do without dancing entirely.  Instances have
8691 been known of young people passing many, many months successively,
8692 without being at any ball of any description, and no material injury
8693 accrue either to body or mind;--but when a beginning is made--
8694 when the felicities of rapid motion have once been, though slightly,
8695 felt--it must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more.
8696 
8697 Frank Churchill had danced once at Highbury, and longed to dance again;
8698 and the last half-hour of an evening which Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded
8699 to spend with his daughter at Randalls, was passed by the two young
8700 people in schemes on the subject.  Frank's was the first idea;
8701 and his the greatest zeal in pursuing it; for the lady was the best
8702 judge of the difficulties, and the most solicitous for accommodation
8703 and appearance.  But still she had inclination enough for shewing
8704 people again how delightfully Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss
8705 Woodhouse danced--for doing that in which she need not blush to compare
8706 herself with Jane Fairfax--and even for simple dancing itself,
8707 without any of the wicked aids of vanity--to assist him first
8708 in pacing out the room they were in to see what it could be made
8709 to hold--and then in taking the dimensions of the other parlour,
8710 in the hope of discovering, in spite of all that Mr. Weston could
8711 say of their exactly equal size, that it was a little the largest.
8712 
8713 His first proposition and request, that the dance begun at Mr. Cole's
8714 should be finished there--that the same party should be collected,
8715 and the same musician engaged, met with the readiest acquiescence.
8716 Mr. Weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment,
8717 and Mrs. Weston most willingly undertook to play as long as they
8718 could wish to dance; and the interesting employment had followed,
8719 of reckoning up exactly who there would be, and portioning out the
8720 indispensable division of space to every couple.
8721 
8722 "You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two
8723 Miss Coxes five," had been repeated many times over.  "And there
8724 will be the two Gilberts, young Cox, my father, and myself,
8725 besides Mr. Knightley.  Yes, that will be quite enough for pleasure.
8726 You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss
8727 Coxes five; and for five couple there will be plenty of room."
8728 
8729 But soon it came to be on one side,
8730 
8731 "But will there be good room for five couple?--I really do not think
8732 there will."
8733 
8734 On another,
8735 
8736 "And after all, five couple are not enough to make it worth
8737 while to stand up.  Five couple are nothing, when one thinks
8738 seriously about it.  It will not do to _invite_ five couple.
8739 It can be allowable only as the thought of the moment."
8740 
8741 Somebody said that _Miss_ Gilbert was expected at her brother's,
8742 and must be invited with the rest.  Somebody else believed
8743 _Mrs_. Gilbert would have danced the other evening, if she had
8744 been asked.  A word was put in for a second young Cox; and at last,
8745 Mr. Weston naming one family of cousins who must be included,
8746 and another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out,
8747 it became a certainty that the five couple would be at least ten,
8748 and a very interesting speculation in what possible manner they
8749 could be disposed of.
8750 
8751 The doors of the two rooms were just opposite each other.
8752 "Might not they use both rooms, and dance across the passage?"
8753 It seemed the best scheme; and yet it was not so good but that
8754 many of them wanted a better.  Emma said it would be awkward;
8755 Mrs. Weston was in distress about the supper; and Mr. Woodhouse
8756 opposed it earnestly, on the score of health.  It made him so
8757 very unhappy, indeed, that it could not be persevered in.
8758 
8759 "Oh! no," said he; "it would be the extreme of imprudence.
8760 I could not bear it for Emma!--Emma is not strong.  She would
8761 catch a dreadful cold.  So would poor little Harriet.
8762 So you would all.  Mrs. Weston, you would be quite laid up;
8763 do not let them talk of such a wild thing.  Pray do not let them
8764 talk of it.  That young man (speaking lower) is very thoughtless.
8765 Do not tell his father, but that young man is not quite the thing.
8766 He has been opening the doors very often this evening, and keeping
8767 them open very inconsiderately.  He does not think of the draught.
8768 I do not mean to set you against him, but indeed he is not quite
8769 the thing!"
8770 
8771 Mrs. Weston was sorry for such a charge.  She knew the importance
8772 of it, and said every thing in her power to do it away.  Every door
8773 was now closed, the passage plan given up, and the first scheme
8774 of dancing only in the room they were in resorted to again;
8775 and with such good-will on Frank Churchill's part, that the space
8776 which a quarter of an hour before had been deemed barely sufficient
8777 for five couple, was now endeavoured to be made out quite enough
8778 for ten.
8779 
8780 "We were too magnificent," said he.  "We allowed unnecessary room.
8781 Ten couple may stand here very well."
8782 
8783 Emma demurred.  "It would be a crowd--a sad crowd; and what could
8784 be worse than dancing without space to turn in?"
8785 
8786 "Very true," he gravely replied; "it was very bad."  But still he
8787 went on measuring, and still he ended with,
8788 
8789 "I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple."
8790 
8791 "No, no," said she, "you are quite unreasonable.  It would be dreadful
8792 to be standing so close!  Nothing can be farther from pleasure
8793 than to be dancing in a crowd--and a crowd in a little room!"
8794 
8795 "There is no denying it," he replied.  "I agree with you exactly.
8796 A crowd in a little room--Miss Woodhouse, you have the art of giving
8797 pictures in a few words.  Exquisite, quite exquisite!--Still, however,
8798 having proceeded so far, one is unwilling to give the matter up.
8799 It would be a disappointment to my father--and altogether--I do
8800 not know that--I am rather of opinion that ten couple might stand
8801 here very well."
8802 
8803 Emma perceived that the nature of his gallantry was a little
8804 self-willed, and that he would rather oppose than lose the pleasure
8805 of dancing with her; but she took the compliment, and forgave
8806 the rest.  Had she intended ever to _marry_ him, it might have been
8807 worth while to pause and consider, and try to understand the value
8808 of his preference, and the character of his temper; but for
8809 all the purposes of their acquaintance, he was quite amiable enough.
8810 
8811 Before the middle of the next day, he was at Hartfield; and he entered
8812 the room with such an agreeable smile as certified the continuance
8813 of the scheme.  It soon appeared that he came to announce an improvement.
8814 
8815 "Well, Miss Woodhouse," he almost immediately began, "your inclination
8816 for dancing has not been quite frightened away, I hope, by the
8817 terrors of my father's little rooms.  I bring a new proposal
8818 on the subject:--a thought of my father's, which waits only your
8819 approbation to be acted upon.  May I hope for the honour of your
8820 hand for the two first dances of this little projected ball,
8821 to be given, not at Randalls, but at the Crown Inn?"
8822 
8823 "The Crown!"
8824 
8825 "Yes; if you and Mr. Woodhouse see no objection, and I trust you cannot,
8826 my father hopes his friends will be so kind as to visit him there.
8827 Better accommodations, he can promise them, and not a less grateful
8828 welcome than at Randalls.  It is his own idea.  Mrs. Weston sees
8829 no objection to it, provided you are satisfied.  This is what we
8830 all feel.  Oh! you were perfectly right!  Ten couple, in either of
8831 the Randalls rooms, would have been insufferable!--Dreadful!--I felt
8832 how right you were the whole time, but was too anxious for securing
8833 _any_ _thing_ to like to yield.  Is not it a good exchange?--You consent--
8834 I hope you consent?"
8835 
8836 "It appears to me a plan that nobody can object to, if Mr. and
8837 Mrs. Weston do not.  I think it admirable; and, as far as I can
8838 answer for myself, shall be most happy--It seems the only improvement
8839 that could be.  Papa, do you not think it an excellent improvement?"
8840 
8841 She was obliged to repeat and explain it, before it was fully
8842 comprehended; and then, being quite new, farther representations
8843 were necessary to make it acceptable.
8844 
8845 "No; he thought it very far from an improvement--a very bad plan--
8846 much worse than the other.  A room at an inn was always damp
8847 and dangerous; never properly aired, or fit to be inhabited.
8848 If they must dance, they had better dance at Randalls.  He had never
8849 been in the room at the Crown in his life--did not know the people
8850 who kept it by sight.--Oh! no--a very bad plan.  They would catch
8851 worse colds at the Crown than anywhere."
8852 
8853 "I was going to observe, sir," said Frank Churchill,
8854 "that one of the great recommendations of this change would
8855 be the very little danger of any body's catching cold--
8856 so much less danger at the Crown than at Randalls!  Mr. Perry
8857 might have reason to regret the alteration, but nobody else could."
8858 
8859 "Sir," said Mr. Woodhouse, rather warmly, "you are very much
8860 mistaken if you suppose Mr. Perry to be that sort of character.
8861 Mr. Perry is extremely concerned when any of us are ill.  But I
8862 do not understand how the room at the Crown can be safer for you
8863 than your father's house."
8864 
8865 "From the very circumstance of its being larger, sir.  We shall have
8866 no occasion to open the windows at all--not once the whole evening;
8867 and it is that dreadful habit of opening the windows, letting in cold
8868 air upon heated bodies, which (as you well know, sir) does the mischief."
8869 
8870 "Open the windows!--but surely, Mr. Churchill, nobody would think
8871 of opening the windows at Randalls.  Nobody could be so imprudent!
8872 I never heard of such a thing.  Dancing with open windows!--I am sure,
8873 neither your father nor Mrs. Weston (poor Miss Taylor that was)
8874 would suffer it."
8875 
8876 "Ah! sir--but a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind
8877 a window-curtain, and throw up a sash, without its being suspected.
8878 I have often known it done myself."
8879 
8880 "Have you indeed, sir?--Bless me!  I never could have supposed it.
8881 But I live out of the world, and am often astonished at what I hear.
8882 However, this does make a difference; and, perhaps, when we come
8883 to talk it over--but these sort of things require a good deal
8884 of consideration.  One cannot resolve upon them in a hurry.
8885 If Mr. and Mrs. Weston will be so obliging as to call here one morning,
8886 we may talk it over, and see what can be done."
8887 
8888 "But, unfortunately, sir, my time is so limited--"
8889 
8890 "Oh!" interrupted Emma, "there will be plenty of time for talking
8891 every thing over.  There is no hurry at all.  If it can be contrived
8892 to be at the Crown, papa, it will be very convenient for the horses.
8893 They will be so near their own stable."
8894 
8895 "So they will, my dear.  That is a great thing.  Not that James
8896 ever complains; but it is right to spare our horses when we can.
8897 If I could be sure of the rooms being thoroughly aired--but is
8898 Mrs. Stokes to be trusted?  I doubt it.  I do not know her,
8899 even by sight."
8900 
8901 "I can answer for every thing of that nature, sir, because it will
8902 be under Mrs. Weston's care.  Mrs. Weston undertakes to direct
8903 the whole."
8904 
8905 "There, papa!--Now you must be satisfied--Our own dear Mrs. Weston,
8906 who is carefulness itself.  Do not you remember what Mr. Perry said,
8907 so many years ago, when I had the measles?  `If _Miss_ _Taylor_ undertakes
8908 to wrap Miss Emma up, you need not have any fears, sir.'  How often
8909 have I heard you speak of it as such a compliment to her!"
8910 
8911 "Aye, very true.  Mr. Perry did say so.  I shall never forget it.
8912 Poor little Emma!  You were very bad with the measles; that is,
8913 you would have been very bad, but for Perry's great attention.
8914 He came four times a day for a week.  He said, from the first,
8915 it was a very good sort--which was our great comfort; but the measles
8916 are a dreadful complaint.  I hope whenever poor Isabella's little ones
8917 have the measles, she will send for Perry."
8918 
8919 "My father and Mrs. Weston are at the Crown at this moment,"
8920 said Frank Churchill, "examining the capabilities of the house.
8921 I left them there and came on to Hartfield, impatient for your opinion,
8922 and hoping you might be persuaded to join them and give your advice
8923 on the spot.  I was desired to say so from both.  It would be the
8924 greatest pleasure to them, if you could allow me to attend you there.
8925 They can do nothing satisfactorily without you."
8926 
8927 Emma was most happy to be called to such a council; and her father,
8928 engaging to think it all over while she was gone, the two young
8929 people set off together without delay for the Crown.  There were
8930 Mr. and Mrs. Weston; delighted to see her and receive her approbation,
8931 very busy and very happy in their different way; she, in some
8932 little distress; and he, finding every thing perfect.
8933 
8934 "Emma," said she, "this paper is worse than I expected.
8935 Look! in places you see it is dreadfully dirty; and the wainscot
8936 is more yellow and forlorn than any thing I could have imagined."
8937 
8938 "My dear, you are too particular," said her husband.  "What does
8939 all that signify?  You will see nothing of it by candlelight.
8940 It will be as clean as Randalls by candlelight.  We never see any
8941 thing of it on our club-nights."
8942 
8943 The ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant, "Men never
8944 know when things are dirty or not;" and the gentlemen perhaps
8945 thought each to himself, "Women will have their little nonsenses
8946 and needless cares."
8947 
8948 One perplexity, however, arose, which the gentlemen did not disdain.
8949 It regarded a supper-room.  At the time of the ballroom's being built,
8950 suppers had not been in question; and a small card-room adjoining,
8951 was the only addition.  What was to be done?  This card-room would
8952 be wanted as a card-room now; or, if cards were conveniently voted
8953 unnecessary by their four selves, still was it not too small for
8954 any comfortable supper?  Another room of much better size might be
8955 secured for the purpose; but it was at the other end of the house,
8956 and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at it.
8957 This made a difficulty.  Mrs. Weston was afraid of draughts
8958 for the young people in that passage; and neither Emma nor the
8959 gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded
8960 at supper.
8961 
8962 Mrs. Weston proposed having no regular supper; merely sandwiches,
8963 &c., set out in the little room; but that was scouted as a
8964 wretched suggestion.  A private dance, without sitting down to supper,
8965 was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of men and women;
8966 and Mrs. Weston must not speak of it again.  She then took another
8967 line of expediency, and looking into the doubtful room, observed,
8968 
8969 "I do not think it _is_ so very small.  We shall not be many,
8970 you know."
8971 
8972 And Mr. Weston at the same time, walking briskly with long steps
8973 through the passage, was calling out,
8974 
8975 "You talk a great deal of the length of this passage, my dear.
8976 It is a mere nothing after all; and not the least draught from
8977 the stairs."
8978 
8979 "I wish," said Mrs. Weston, "one could know which arrangement our
8980 guests in general would like best.  To do what would be most generally
8981 pleasing must be our object--if one could but tell what that would be."
8982 
8983 "Yes, very true," cried Frank, "very true.  You want your neighbours'
8984 opinions.  I do not wonder at you.  If one could ascertain what the
8985 chief of them--the Coles, for instance.  They are not far off.
8986 Shall I call upon them?  Or Miss Bates?  She is still nearer.--
8987 And I do not know whether Miss Bates is not as likely to understand
8988 the inclinations of the rest of the people as any body.  I think
8989 we do want a larger council.  Suppose I go and invite Miss Bates
8990 to join us?"
8991 
8992 "Well--if you please," said Mrs. Weston rather hesitating, "if you
8993 think she will be of any use."
8994 
8995 "You will get nothing to the purpose from Miss Bates," said Emma.
8996 "She will be all delight and gratitude, but she will tell you nothing.
8997 She will not even listen to your questions.  I see no advantage in
8998 consulting Miss Bates."
8999 
9000 "But she is so amusing, so extremely amusing!  I am very fond
9001 of hearing Miss Bates talk.  And I need not bring the whole family,
9002 you know."
9003 
9004 Here Mr. Weston joined them, and on hearing what was proposed,
9005 gave it his decided approbation.
9006 
9007 "Aye, do, Frank.--Go and fetch Miss Bates, and let us end the matter
9008 at once.  She will enjoy the scheme, I am sure; and I do not know
9009 a properer person for shewing us how to do away difficulties.
9010 Fetch Miss Bates.  We are growing a little too nice.  She is
9011 a standing lesson of how to be happy.  But fetch them both.
9012 Invite them both."
9013 
9014 "Both sir!  Can the old lady?" . . .
9015 
9016 "The old lady!  No, the young lady, to be sure.  I shall think you
9017 a great blockhead, Frank, if you bring the aunt without the niece."
9018 
9019 "Oh!  I beg your pardon, sir.  I did not immediately recollect.
9020 Undoubtedly if you wish it, I will endeavour to persuade them both."
9021 And away he ran.
9022 
9023 Long before he reappeared, attending the short, neat, brisk-moving aunt,
9024 and her elegant niece,--Mrs. Weston, like a sweet-tempered
9025 woman and a good wife, had examined the passage again,
9026 and found the evils of it much less than she had supposed before--
9027 indeed very trifling; and here ended the difficulties of decision.
9028 All the rest, in speculation at least, was perfectly smooth.
9029 All the minor arrangements of table and chair, lights and music,
9030 tea and supper, made themselves; or were left as mere trifles
9031 to be settled at any time between Mrs. Weston and Mrs. Stokes.--
9032 Every body invited, was certainly to come; Frank had already written
9033 to Enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond his fortnight,
9034 which could not possibly be refused.  And a delightful dance it was
9035 to be.
9036 
9037 Most cordially, when Miss Bates arrived, did she agree that it must.
9038 As a counsellor she was not wanted; but as an approver, (a much
9039 safer character,) she was truly welcome.  Her approbation, at once
9040 general and minute, warm and incessant, could not but please;
9041 and for another half-hour they were all walking to and fro,
9042 between the different rooms, some suggesting, some attending,
9043 and all in happy enjoyment of the future.  The party did not break
9044 up without Emma's being positively secured for the two first dances
9045 by the hero of the evening, nor without her overhearing Mr. Weston
9046 whisper to his wife, "He has asked her, my dear.  That's right.
9047 I knew he would!"
9048 
9049 
9050 
9051 CHAPTER XII
9052 
9053 
9054 One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball
9055 completely satisfactory to Emma--its being fixed for a day within
9056 the granted term of Frank Churchill's stay in Surry; for, in spite
9057 of Mr. Weston's confidence, she could not think it so very impossible
9058 that the Churchills might not allow their nephew to remain
9059 a day beyond his fortnight.  But this was not judged feasible.
9060 The preparations must take their time, nothing could be properly
9061 ready till the third week were entered on, and for a few days they
9062 must be planning, proceeding and hoping in uncertainty--at the risk--
9063 in her opinion, the great risk, of its being all in vain.
9064 
9065 Enscombe however was gracious, gracious in fact, if not in word.
9066 His wish of staying longer evidently did not please; but it was
9067 not opposed.  All was safe and prosperous; and as the removal of one
9068 solicitude generally makes way for another, Emma, being now certain
9069 of her ball, began to adopt as the next vexation Mr. Knightley's
9070 provoking indifference about it.  Either because he did not
9071 dance himself, or because the plan had been formed without his
9072 being consulted, he seemed resolved that it should not interest him,
9073 determined against its exciting any present curiosity, or affording
9074 him any future amusement.  To her voluntary communications Emma
9075 could get no more approving reply, than,
9076 
9077 "Very well.  If the Westons think it worth while to be at all this
9078 trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment, I have nothing
9079 to say against it, but that they shall not chuse pleasures for me.--
9080 Oh! yes, I must be there; I could not refuse; and I will keep
9081 as much awake as I can; but I would rather be at home, looking over
9082 William Larkins's week's account; much rather, I confess.--
9083 Pleasure in seeing dancing!--not I, indeed--I never look at it--
9084 I do not know who does.--Fine dancing, I believe, like virtue,
9085 must be its own reward.  Those who are standing by are usually
9086 thinking of something very different."
9087 
9088 This Emma felt was aimed at her; and it made her quite angry.
9089 It was not in compliment to Jane Fairfax however that he was
9090 so indifferent, or so indignant; he was not guided by _her_ feelings
9091 in reprobating the ball, for _she_ enjoyed the thought of it
9092 to an extraordinary degree.  It made her animated--open hearted--
9093 she voluntarily said;--
9094 
9095 "Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, I hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball.
9096 What a disappointment it would be!  I do look forward to it, I own,
9097 with _very_ great pleasure."
9098 
9099 It was not to oblige Jane Fairfax therefore that he would have
9100 preferred the society of William Larkins.  No!--she was more and more
9101 convinced that Mrs. Weston was quite mistaken in that surmise.
9102 There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment
9103 on his side--but no love.
9104 
9105 Alas! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with Mr. Knightley.
9106 Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the
9107 over-throw of every thing.  A letter arrived from Mr. Churchill
9108 to urge his nephew's instant return.  Mrs. Churchill was unwell--
9109 far too unwell to do without him; she had been in a very suffering
9110 state (so said her husband) when writing to her nephew two days before,
9111 though from her usual unwillingness to give pain, and constant
9112 habit of never thinking of herself, she had not mentioned it;
9113 but now she was too ill to trifle, and must entreat him to set off
9114 for Enscombe without delay.
9115 
9116 The substance of this letter was forwarded to Emma, in a note
9117 from Mrs. Weston, instantly.  As to his going, it was inevitable.
9118 He must be gone within a few hours, though without feeling any real
9119 alarm for his aunt, to lessen his repugnance.  He knew her illnesses;
9120 they never occurred but for her own convenience.
9121 
9122 Mrs. Weston added, "that he could only allow himself time to
9123 hurry to Highbury, after breakfast, and take leave of the few
9124 friends there whom he could suppose to feel any interest in him;
9125 and that he might be expected at Hartfield very soon."
9126 
9127 This wretched note was the finale of Emma's breakfast.  When once
9128 it had been read, there was no doing any thing, but lament
9129 and exclaim.  The loss of the ball--the loss of the young man--
9130 and all that the young man might be feeling!--It was too wretched!--
9131 Such a delightful evening as it would have been!--Every body so happy!
9132 and she and her partner the happiest!--"I said it would be so,"
9133 was the only consolation.
9134 
9135 Her father's feelings were quite distinct.  He thought principally
9136 of Mrs. Churchill's illness, and wanted to know how she was treated;
9137 and as for the ball, it was shocking to have dear Emma disappointed;
9138 but they would all be safer at home.
9139 
9140 Emma was ready for her visitor some time before he appeared;
9141 but if this reflected at all upon his impatience, his sorrowful
9142 look and total want of spirits when he did come might redeem him.
9143 He felt the going away almost too much to speak of it.  His dejection
9144 was most evident.  He sat really lost in thought for the first
9145 few minutes; and when rousing himself, it was only to say,
9146 
9147 "Of all horrid things, leave-taking is the worst."
9148 
9149 "But you will come again," said Emma.  "This will not be your only
9150 visit to Randalls."
9151 
9152 "Ah!--(shaking his head)--the uncertainty of when I may be able
9153 to return!--I shall try for it with a zeal!--It will be the object
9154 of all my thoughts and cares!--and if my uncle and aunt go to town
9155 this spring--but I am afraid--they did not stir last spring--
9156 I am afraid it is a custom gone for ever."
9157 
9158 "Our poor ball must be quite given up."
9159 
9160 "Ah! that ball!--why did we wait for any thing?--why not seize the
9161 pleasure at once?--How often is happiness destroyed by preparation,
9162 foolish preparation!--You told us it would be so.--Oh!  Miss Woodhouse,
9163 why are you always so right?"
9164 
9165 "Indeed, I am very sorry to be right in this instance.  I would
9166 much rather have been merry than wise."
9167 
9168 "If I can come again, we are still to have our ball.  My father
9169 depends on it.  Do not forget your engagement."
9170 
9171 Emma looked graciously.
9172 
9173 "Such a fortnight as it has been!" he continued; "every day more
9174 precious and more delightful than the day before!--every day making
9175 me less fit to bear any other place.  Happy those, who can remain
9176 at Highbury!"
9177 
9178 "As you do us such ample justice now," said Emma, laughing, "I will
9179 venture to ask, whether you did not come a little doubtfully at first?
9180 Do not we rather surpass your expectations?  I am sure we do.
9181 I am sure you did not much expect to like us.  You would not have been
9182 so long in coming, if you had had a pleasant idea of Highbury."
9183 
9184 He laughed rather consciously; and though denying the sentiment,
9185 Emma was convinced that it had been so.
9186 
9187 "And you must be off this very morning?"
9188 
9189 "Yes; my father is to join me here:  we shall walk back together,
9190 and I must be off immediately.  I am almost afraid that every moment
9191 will bring him."
9192 
9193 "Not five minutes to spare even for your friends Miss Fairfax and
9194 Miss Bates?  How unlucky!  Miss Bates's powerful, argumentative mind
9195 might have strengthened yours."
9196 
9197 "Yes--I _have_ called there; passing the door, I thought it better.
9198 It was a right thing to do.  I went in for three minutes, and was
9199 detained by Miss Bates's being absent.  She was out; and I felt it
9200 impossible not to wait till she came in.  She is a woman that one may,
9201 that one _must_ laugh at; but that one would not wish to slight.
9202 It was better to pay my visit, then"--
9203 
9204 He hesitated, got up, walked to a window.
9205 
9206 "In short," said he, "perhaps, Miss Woodhouse--I think you can
9207 hardly be quite without suspicion"--
9208 
9209 He looked at her, as if wanting to read her thoughts.  She hardly
9210 knew what to say.  It seemed like the forerunner of something
9211 absolutely serious, which she did not wish.  Forcing herself
9212 to speak, therefore, in the hope of putting it by, she calmly said,
9213 
9214 "You are quite in the right; it was most natural to pay your visit, then"--
9215 
9216 He was silent.  She believed he was looking at her; probably reflecting
9217 on what she had said, and trying to understand the manner.
9218 She heard him sigh.  It was natural for him to feel that he had
9219 _cause_ to sigh.  He could not believe her to be encouraging him.
9220 A few awkward moments passed, and he sat down again; and in a more
9221 determined manner said,
9222 
9223 "It was something to feel that all the rest of my time might be
9224 given to Hartfield.  My regard for Hartfield is most warm"--
9225 
9226 He stopt again, rose again, and seemed quite embarrassed.--
9227 He was more in love with her than Emma had supposed; and who can say
9228 how it might have ended, if his father had not made his appearance?
9229 Mr. Woodhouse soon followed; and the necessity of exertion made
9230 him composed.
9231 
9232 A very few minutes more, however, completed the present trial.
9233 Mr. Weston, always alert when business was to be done, and as
9234 incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable,
9235 as of foreseeing any that was doubtful, said, "It was time to go;"
9236 and the young man, though he might and did sigh, could not but agree,
9237 to take leave.
9238 
9239 "I shall hear about you all," said he; "that is my chief consolation.
9240 I shall hear of every thing that is going on among you.  I have
9241 engaged Mrs. Weston to correspond with me.  She has been so kind as
9242 to promise it.  Oh! the blessing of a female correspondent, when one
9243 is really interested in the absent!--she will tell me every thing.
9244 In her letters I shall be at dear Highbury again."
9245 
9246 A very friendly shake of the hand, a very earnest "Good-bye,"
9247 closed the speech, and the door had soon shut out Frank Churchill.
9248 Short had been the notice--short their meeting; he was gone; and Emma
9249 felt so sorry to part, and foresaw so great a loss to their little
9250 society from his absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry,
9251 and feeling it too much.
9252 
9253 It was a sad change.  They had been meeting almost every day
9254 since his arrival.  Certainly his being at Randalls had given
9255 great spirit to the last two weeks--indescribable spirit; the idea,
9256 the expectation of seeing him which every morning had brought,
9257 the assurance of his attentions, his liveliness, his manners!
9258 It had been a very happy fortnight, and forlorn must be the sinking
9259 from it into the common course of Hartfield days.  To complete every
9260 other recommendation, he had _almost_ told her that he loved her.
9261 What strength, or what constancy of affection he might be subject to,
9262 was another point; but at present she could not doubt his having
9263 a decidedly warm admiration, a conscious preference of herself;
9264 and this persuasion, joined to all the rest, made her think that
9265 she _must_ be a little in love with him, in spite of every previous
9266 determination against it.
9267 
9268 "I certainly must," said she.  "This sensation of listlessness,
9269 weariness, stupidity, this disinclination to sit down and employ myself,
9270 this feeling of every thing's being dull and insipid about the house!--
9271 I must be in love; I should be the oddest creature in the world if I
9272 were not--for a few weeks at least.  Well! evil to some is always
9273 good to others.  I shall have many fellow-mourners for the ball,
9274 if not for Frank Churchill; but Mr. Knightley will be happy.
9275 He may spend the evening with his dear William Larkins now if he likes."
9276 
9277 Mr. Knightley, however, shewed no triumphant happiness.  He could
9278 not say that he was sorry on his own account; his very cheerful look
9279 would have contradicted him if he had; but he said, and very steadily,
9280 that he was sorry for the disappointment of the others, and with
9281 considerable kindness added,
9282 
9283 "You, Emma, who have so few opportunities of dancing, you are really
9284 out of luck; you are very much out of luck!"
9285 
9286 It was some days before she saw Jane Fairfax, to judge of her
9287 honest regret in this woeful change; but when they did meet,
9288 her composure was odious.  She had been particularly unwell, however,
9289 suffering from headache to a degree, which made her aunt declare,
9290 that had the ball taken place, she did not think Jane could have
9291 attended it; and it was charity to impute some of her unbecoming
9292 indifference to the languor of ill-health.
9293 
9294 
9295 
9296 CHAPTER XIII
9297 
9298 
9299 Emma continued to entertain no doubt of her being in love.  Her ideas
9300 only varied as to the how much.  At first, she thought it was a good deal;
9301 and afterwards, but little.  She had great pleasure in hearing Frank
9302 Churchill talked of; and, for his sake, greater pleasure than ever
9303 in seeing Mr. and Mrs. Weston; she was very often thinking of him,
9304 and quite impatient for a letter, that she might know how he was,
9305 how were his spirits, how was his aunt, and what was the chance
9306 of his coming to Randalls again this spring.  But, on the other hand,
9307 she could not admit herself to be unhappy, nor, after the
9308 first morning, to be less disposed for employment than usual;
9309 she was still busy and cheerful; and, pleasing as he was, she could
9310 yet imagine him to have faults; and farther, though thinking of him
9311 so much, and, as she sat drawing or working, forming a thousand
9312 amusing schemes for the progress and close of their attachment,
9313 fancying interesting dialogues, and inventing elegant letters;
9314 the conclusion of every imaginary declaration on his side was that she
9315 _refused_ _him_.  Their affection was always to subside into friendship.
9316 Every thing tender and charming was to mark their parting;
9317 but still they were to part.  When she became sensible of this,
9318 it struck her that she could not be very much in love; for in spite
9319 of her previous and fixed determination never to quit her father,
9320 never to marry, a strong attachment certainly must produce more
9321 of a struggle than she could foresee in her own feelings.
9322 
9323 "I do not find myself making any use of the word _sacrifice_," said she.--
9324 "In not one of all my clever replies, my delicate negatives,
9325 is there any allusion to making a sacrifice.  I do suspect that he
9326 is not really necessary to my happiness.  So much the better.
9327 I certainly will not persuade myself to feel more than I do.  I am
9328 quite enough in love.  I should be sorry to be more."
9329 
9330 Upon the whole, she was equally contented with her view of his feelings.
9331 
9332 "_He_ is undoubtedly very much in love--every thing denotes it--very much
9333 in love indeed!--and when he comes again, if his affection continue,
9334 I must be on my guard not to encourage it.--It would be most
9335 inexcusable to do otherwise, as my own mind is quite made up.
9336 Not that I imagine he can think I have been encouraging him hitherto.
9337 No, if he had believed me at all to share his feelings, he would
9338 not have been so wretched.  Could he have thought himself encouraged,
9339 his looks and language at parting would have been different.--
9340 Still, however, I must be on my guard.  This is in the supposition
9341 of his attachment continuing what it now is; but I do not know that I
9342 expect it will; I do not look upon him to be quite the sort of man--
9343 I do not altogether build upon his steadiness or constancy.--
9344 His feelings are warm, but I can imagine them rather changeable.--
9345 Every consideration of the subject, in short, makes me thankful
9346 that my happiness is not more deeply involved.--I shall do very well
9347 again after a little while--and then, it will be a good thing over;
9348 for they say every body is in love once in their lives, and I shall
9349 have been let off easily."
9350 
9351 When his letter to Mrs. Weston arrived, Emma had the perusal of it;
9352 and she read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made
9353 her at first shake her head over her own sensations, and think she
9354 had undervalued their strength.  It was a long, well-written letter,
9355 giving the particulars of his journey and of his feelings,
9356 expressing all the affection, gratitude, and respect which was
9357 natural and honourable, and describing every thing exterior and local
9358 that could be supposed attractive, with spirit and precision.
9359 No suspicious flourishes now of apology or concern; it was the
9360 language of real feeling towards Mrs. Weston; and the transition
9361 from Highbury to Enscombe, the contrast between the places in some
9362 of the first blessings of social life was just enough touched on
9363 to shew how keenly it was felt, and how much more might have been
9364 said but for the restraints of propriety.--The charm of her own
9365 name was not wanting.  _Miss_ _Woodhouse_ appeared more than once,
9366 and never without a something of pleasing connexion, either a
9367 compliment to her taste, or a remembrance of what she had said;
9368 and in the very last time of its meeting her eye, unadorned as it
9369 was by any such broad wreath of gallantry, she yet could discern
9370 the effect of her influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment
9371 perhaps of all conveyed.  Compressed into the very lowest vacant
9372 corner were these words--"I had not a spare moment on Tuesday,
9373 as you know, for Miss Woodhouse's beautiful little friend.  Pray make
9374 my excuses and adieus to her."  This, Emma could not doubt, was all
9375 for herself.  Harriet was remembered only from being _her_ friend.
9376 His information and prospects as to Enscombe were neither worse nor
9377 better than had been anticipated; Mrs. Churchill was recovering,
9378 and he dared not yet, even in his own imagination, fix a time for
9379 coming to Randalls again.
9380 
9381 Gratifying, however, and stimulative as was the letter in the
9382 material part, its sentiments, she yet found, when it was folded up
9383 and returned to Mrs. Weston, that it had not added any lasting warmth,
9384 that she could still do without the writer, and that he must learn
9385 to do without her.  Her intentions were unchanged.  Her resolution
9386 of refusal only grew more interesting by the addition of a scheme for
9387 his subsequent consolation and happiness.  His recollection of Harriet,
9388 and the words which clothed it, the "beautiful little friend,"
9389 suggested to her the idea of Harriet's succeeding her in his affections.
9390 Was it impossible?--No.--Harriet undoubtedly was greatly his
9391 inferior in understanding; but he had been very much struck with
9392 the loveliness of her face and the warm simplicity of her manner;
9393 and all the probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in
9394 her favour.--For Harriet, it would be advantageous and delightful indeed.
9395 
9396 "I must not dwell upon it," said she.--"I must not think of it.
9397 I know the danger of indulging such speculations.  But stranger
9398 things have happened; and when we cease to care for each other
9399 as we do now, it will be the means of confirming us in that sort
9400 of true disinterested friendship which I can already look forward
9401 to with pleasure."
9402 
9403 It was well to have a comfort in store on Harriet's behalf,
9404 though it might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom; for evil
9405 in that quarter was at hand.  As Frank Churchill's arrival had
9406 succeeded Mr. Elton's engagement in the conversation of Highbury,
9407 as the latest interest had entirely borne down the first, so now
9408 upon Frank Churchill's disappearance, Mr. Elton's concerns were
9409 assuming the most irresistible form.--His wedding-day was named.
9410 He would soon be among them again; Mr. Elton and his bride.
9411 There was hardly time to talk over the first letter from Enscombe
9412 before "Mr. Elton and his bride" was in every body's mouth,
9413 and Frank Churchill was forgotten.  Emma grew sick at the sound.
9414 She had had three weeks of happy exemption from Mr. Elton;
9415 and Harriet's mind, she had been willing to hope, had been lately
9416 gaining strength.  With Mr. Weston's ball in view at least,
9417 there had been a great deal of insensibility to other things;
9418 but it was now too evident that she had not attained such a state
9419 of composure as could stand against the actual approach--new carriage,
9420 bell-ringing, and all.
9421 
9422 Poor Harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the
9423 reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that Emma
9424 could give.  Emma felt that she could not do too much for her,
9425 that Harriet had a right to all her ingenuity and all her patience;
9426 but it was heavy work to be for ever convincing without producing
9427 any effect, for ever agreed to, without being able to make their opinions
9428 the same.  Harriet listened submissively, and said "it was very true--
9429 it was just as Miss Woodhouse described--it was not worth while to
9430 think about them--and she would not think about them any longer"
9431 but no change of subject could avail, and the next half-hour
9432 saw her as anxious and restless about the Eltons as before.
9433 At last Emma attacked her on another ground.
9434 
9435 "Your allowing yourself to be so occupied and so unhappy about
9436 Mr. Elton's marrying, Harriet, is the strongest reproach you can
9437 make _me_.  You could not give me a greater reproof for the mistake I
9438 fell into.  It was all my doing, I know.  I have not forgotten it,
9439 I assure you.--Deceived myself, I did very miserably deceive you--
9440 and it will be a painful reflection to me for ever.  Do not imagine
9441 me in danger of forgetting it."
9442 
9443 Harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words
9444 of eager exclamation.  Emma continued,
9445 
9446 "I have not said, exert yourself Harriet for my sake; think less,
9447 talk less of Mr. Elton for my sake; because for your own sake rather,
9448 I would wish it to be done, for the sake of what is more important
9449 than my comfort, a habit of self-command in you, a consideration
9450 of what is your duty, an attention to propriety, an endeavour
9451 to avoid the suspicions of others, to save your health and credit,
9452 and restore your tranquillity.  These are the motives which I
9453 have been pressing on you.  They are very important--and sorry
9454 I am that you cannot feel them sufficiently to act upon them.
9455 My being saved from pain is a very secondary consideration.  I want
9456 you to save yourself from greater pain.  Perhaps I may sometimes
9457 have felt that Harriet would not forget what was due--or rather
9458 what would be kind by me."
9459 
9460 This appeal to her affections did more than all the rest.
9461 The idea of wanting gratitude and consideration for Miss Woodhouse,
9462 whom she really loved extremely, made her wretched for a while,
9463 and when the violence of grief was comforted away, still remained
9464 powerful enough to prompt to what was right and support her in it
9465 very tolerably.
9466 
9467 "You, who have been the best friend I ever had in my life--
9468 Want gratitude to you!--Nobody is equal to you!--I care for nobody
9469 as I do for you!--Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, how ungrateful I have been!"
9470 
9471 Such expressions, assisted as they were by every thing that look
9472 and manner could do, made Emma feel that she had never loved Harriet
9473 so well, nor valued her affection so highly before.
9474 
9475 "There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart," said she
9476 afterwards to herself.  "There is nothing to be compared to it.
9477 Warmth and tenderness of heart, with an affectionate, open manner,
9478 will beat all the clearness of head in the world, for attraction,
9479 I am sure it will.  It is tenderness of heart which makes my dear
9480 father so generally beloved--which gives Isabella all her popularity.--
9481 I have it not--but I know how to prize and respect it.--Harriet is
9482 my superior in all the charm and all the felicity it gives.
9483 Dear Harriet!--I would not change you for the clearest-headed,
9484 longest-sighted, best-judging female breathing.  Oh! the coldness
9485 of a Jane Fairfax!--Harriet is worth a hundred such--And for a wife--
9486 a sensible man's wife--it is invaluable.  I mention no names;
9487 but happy the man who changes Emma for Harriet!"
9488 
9489 
9490 
9491 CHAPTER XIV
9492 
9493 
9494 Mrs. Elton was first seen at church:  but though devotion might
9495 be interrupted, curiosity could not be satisfied by a bride in a pew,
9496 and it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid,
9497 to settle whether she were very pretty indeed, or only rather pretty,
9498 or not pretty at all.
9499 
9500 Emma had feelings, less of curiosity than of pride or propriety,
9501 to make her resolve on not being the last to pay her respects;
9502 and she made a point of Harriet's going with her, that the worst of
9503 the business might be gone through as soon as possible.
9504 
9505 She could not enter the house again, could not be in the same room
9506 to which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago,
9507 to lace up her boot, without _recollecting_.  A thousand vexatious
9508 thoughts would recur.  Compliments, charades, and horrible blunders;
9509 and it was not to be supposed that poor Harriet should not be
9510 recollecting too; but she behaved very well, and was only rather
9511 pale and silent.  The visit was of course short; and there was so
9512 much embarrassment and occupation of mind to shorten it, that Emma
9513 would not allow herself entirely to form an opinion of the lady,
9514 and on no account to give one, beyond the nothing-meaning terms
9515 of being "elegantly dressed, and very pleasing."
9516 
9517 She did not really like her.  She would not be in a hurry to find fault,
9518 but she suspected that there was no elegance;--ease, but not elegance.--
9519 She was almost sure that for a young woman, a stranger, a bride,
9520 there was too much ease.  Her person was rather good; her face
9521 not unpretty; but neither feature, nor air, nor voice, nor manner,
9522 were elegant.  Emma thought at least it would turn out so.
9523 
9524 As for Mr. Elton, his manners did not appear--but no, she would
9525 not permit a hasty or a witty word from herself about his manners.
9526 It was an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits,
9527 and a man had need be all grace to acquit himself well through it.
9528 The woman was better off; she might have the assistance of fine clothes,
9529 and the privilege of bashfulness, but the man had only his own
9530 good sense to depend on; and when she considered how peculiarly
9531 unlucky poor Mr. Elton was in being in the same room at once with
9532 the woman he had just married, the woman he had wanted to marry,
9533 and the woman whom he had been expected to marry, she must allow him
9534 to have the right to look as little wise, and to be as much affectedly,
9535 and as little really easy as could be.
9536 
9537 "Well, Miss Woodhouse," said Harriet, when they had quitted
9538 the house, and after waiting in vain for her friend to begin;
9539 "Well, Miss Woodhouse, (with a gentle sigh,) what do you think of her?--
9540 Is not she very charming?"
9541 
9542 There was a little hesitation in Emma's answer.
9543 
9544 "Oh! yes--very--a very pleasing young woman."
9545 
9546 "I think her beautiful, quite beautiful."
9547 
9548 "Very nicely dressed, indeed; a remarkably elegant gown."
9549 
9550 "I am not at all surprized that he should have fallen in love."
9551 
9552 "Oh! no--there is nothing to surprize one at all.--A pretty fortune;
9553 and she came in his way."
9554 
9555 "I dare say," returned Harriet, sighing again, "I dare say she
9556 was very much attached to him."
9557 
9558 "Perhaps she might; but it is not every man's fate to marry the
9559 woman who loves him best.  Miss Hawkins perhaps wanted a home,
9560 and thought this the best offer she was likely to have."
9561 
9562 "Yes," said Harriet earnestly, "and well she might, nobody could ever
9563 have a better.  Well, I wish them happy with all my heart.  And now,
9564 Miss Woodhouse, I do not think I shall mind seeing them again.
9565 He is just as superior as ever;--but being married, you know,
9566 it is quite a different thing.  No, indeed, Miss Woodhouse, you need
9567 not be afraid; I can sit and admire him now without any great misery.
9568 To know that he has not thrown himself away, is such a comfort!--
9569 She does seem a charming young woman, just what he deserves.
9570 Happy creature!  He called her `Augusta.'  How delightful!"
9571 
9572 When the visit was returned, Emma made up her mind.  She could then
9573 see more and judge better.  From Harriet's happening not to be
9574 at Hartfield, and her father's being present to engage Mr. Elton,
9575 she had a quarter of an hour of the lady's conversation to herself,
9576 and could composedly attend to her; and the quarter of an hour quite
9577 convinced her that Mrs. Elton was a vain woman, extremely well
9578 satisfied with herself, and thinking much of her own importance;
9579 that she meant to shine and be very superior, but with manners which
9580 had been formed in a bad school, pert and familiar; that all her
9581 notions were drawn from one set of people, and one style of living;
9582 that if not foolish she was ignorant, and that her society would
9583 certainly do Mr. Elton no good.
9584 
9585 Harriet would have been a better match.  If not wise or refined herself,
9586 she would have connected him with those who were; but Miss Hawkins,
9587 it might be fairly supposed from her easy conceit, had been the best
9588 of her own set.  The rich brother-in-law near Bristol was the pride
9589 of the alliance, and his place and his carriages were the pride
9590 of him.
9591 
9592 The very first subject after being seated was Maple Grove, "My brother
9593 Mr. Suckling's seat;"--a comparison of Hartfield to Maple Grove.
9594 The grounds of Hartfield were small, but neat and pretty; and the
9595 house was modern and well-built. Mrs. Elton seemed most favourably
9596 impressed by the size of the room, the entrance, and all that she
9597 could see or imagine.  "Very like Maple Grove indeed!--She was quite
9598 struck by the likeness!--That room was the very shape and size
9599 of the morning-room at Maple Grove; her sister's favourite room."--
9600 Mr. Elton was appealed to.--"Was not it astonishingly like?--
9601 She could really almost fancy herself at Maple Grove."
9602 
9603 "And the staircase--You know, as I came in, I observed how very like
9604 the staircase was; placed exactly in the same part of the house.
9605 I really could not help exclaiming!  I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,
9606 it is very delightful to me, to be reminded of a place I am so
9607 extremely partial to as Maple Grove.  I have spent so many happy
9608 months there! (with a little sigh of sentiment). A charming place,
9609 undoubtedly.  Every body who sees it is struck by its beauty;
9610 but to me, it has been quite a home.  Whenever you are transplanted,
9611 like me, Miss Woodhouse, you will understand how very delightful it
9612 is to meet with any thing at all like what one has left behind.
9613 I always say this is quite one of the evils of matrimony."
9614 
9615 Emma made as slight a reply as she could; but it was fully sufficient
9616 for Mrs. Elton, who only wanted to be talking herself.
9617 
9618 "So extremely like Maple Grove!  And it is not merely the house--
9619 the grounds, I assure you, as far as I could observe, are strikingly
9620 like.  The laurels at Maple Grove are in the same profusion as here,
9621 and stand very much in the same way--just across the lawn;
9622 and I had a glimpse of a fine large tree, with a bench round it,
9623 which put me so exactly in mind!  My brother and sister will be
9624 enchanted with this place.  People who have extensive grounds
9625 themselves are always pleased with any thing in the same style."
9626 
9627 Emma doubted the truth of this sentiment.  She had a great idea
9628 that people who had extensive grounds themselves cared very little
9629 for the extensive grounds of any body else; but it was not worth
9630 while to attack an error so double-dyed, and therefore only said
9631 in reply,
9632 
9633 "When you have seen more of this country, I am afraid you will think
9634 you have overrated Hartfield.  Surry is full of beauties."
9635 
9636 "Oh! yes, I am quite aware of that.  It is the garden of England,
9637 you know.  Surry is the garden of England."
9638 
9639 "Yes; but we must not rest our claims on that distinction.
9640 Many counties, I believe, are called the garden of England,
9641 as well as Surry."
9642 
9643 "No, I fancy not," replied Mrs. Elton, with a most satisfied smile."
9644 I never heard any county but Surry called so."
9645 
9646 Emma was silenced.
9647 
9648 "My brother and sister have promised us a visit in the spring,
9649 or summer at farthest," continued Mrs. Elton; "and that will be
9650 our time for exploring.  While they are with us, we shall explore
9651 a great deal, I dare say.  They will have their barouche-landau,
9652 of course, which holds four perfectly; and therefore, without saying
9653 any thing of _our_ carriage, we should be able to explore the different
9654 beauties extremely well.  They would hardly come in their chaise,
9655 I think, at that season of the year.  Indeed, when the time draws on,
9656 I shall decidedly recommend their bringing the barouche-landau;
9657 it will be so very much preferable.  When people come into a beautiful
9658 country of this sort, you know, Miss Woodhouse, one naturally wishes
9659 them to see as much as possible; and Mr. Suckling is extremely fond
9660 of exploring.  We explored to King's-Weston twice last summer,
9661 in that way, most delightfully, just after their first having the
9662 barouche-landau.  You have many parties of that kind here, I suppose,
9663 Miss Woodhouse, every summer?"
9664 
9665 "No; not immediately here.  We are rather out of distance of the very
9666 striking beauties which attract the sort of parties you speak of;
9667 and we are a very quiet set of people, I believe; more disposed
9668 to stay at home than engage in schemes of pleasure."
9669 
9670 "Ah! there is nothing like staying at home for real comfort.
9671 Nobody can be more devoted to home than I am.  I was quite
9672 a proverb for it at Maple Grove.  Many a time has Selina said,
9673 when she has been going to Bristol, `I really cannot get this girl
9674 to move from the house.  I absolutely must go in by myself, though I
9675 hate being stuck up in the barouche-landau without a companion;
9676 but Augusta, I believe, with her own good-will, would never stir
9677 beyond the park paling.'  Many a time has she said so; and yet I
9678 am no advocate for entire seclusion.  I think, on the contrary,
9679 when people shut themselves up entirely from society, it is a very
9680 bad thing; and that it is much more advisable to mix in the world in
9681 a proper degree, without living in it either too much or too little.
9682 I perfectly understand your situation, however, Miss Woodhouse--
9683 (looking towards Mr. Woodhouse), Your father's state of health must
9684 be a great drawback.  Why does not he try Bath?--Indeed he should.
9685 Let me recommend Bath to you.  I assure you I have no doubt of its doing
9686 Mr. Woodhouse good."
9687 
9688 "My father tried it more than once, formerly; but without receiving
9689 any benefit; and Mr. Perry, whose name, I dare say, is not unknown
9690 to you, does not conceive it would be at all more likely to be
9691 useful now."
9692 
9693 "Ah! that's a great pity; for I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,
9694 where the waters do agree, it is quite wonderful the relief
9695 they give.  In my Bath life, I have seen such instances of it!
9696 And it is so cheerful a place, that it could not fail of being of
9697 use to Mr. Woodhouse's spirits, which, I understand, are sometimes
9698 much depressed.  And as to its recommendations to _you_, I fancy I
9699 need not take much pains to dwell on them.  The advantages of Bath
9700 to the young are pretty generally understood.  It would be a charming
9701 introduction for you, who have lived so secluded a life; and I could
9702 immediately secure you some of the best society in the place.
9703 A line from me would bring you a little host of acquaintance; and my
9704 particular friend, Mrs. Partridge, the lady I have always resided
9705 with when in Bath, would be most happy to shew you any attentions,
9706 and would be the very person for you to go into public with."
9707 
9708 It was as much as Emma could bear, without being impolite.
9709 The idea of her being indebted to Mrs. Elton for what was called
9710 an _introduction_--of her going into public under the auspices
9711 of a friend of Mrs. Elton's--probably some vulgar, dashing widow,
9712 who, with the help of a boarder, just made a shift to live!--
9713 The dignity of Miss Woodhouse, of Hartfield, was sunk indeed!
9714 
9715 She restrained herself, however, from any of the reproofs she could
9716 have given, and only thanked Mrs. Elton coolly; "but their going
9717 to Bath was quite out of the question; and she was not perfectly
9718 convinced that the place might suit her better than her father."
9719 And then, to prevent farther outrage and indignation, changed the
9720 subject directly.
9721 
9722 "I do not ask whether you are musical, Mrs. Elton.  Upon these occasions,
9723 a lady's character generally precedes her; and Highbury has long
9724 known that you are a superior performer."
9725 
9726 "Oh! no, indeed; I must protest against any such idea.
9727 A superior performer!--very far from it, I assure you.
9728 Consider from how partial a quarter your information came.
9729 I am doatingly fond of music--passionately fond;--and my friends
9730 say I am not entirely devoid of taste; but as to any thing else,
9731 upon my honour my performance is _mediocre_ to the last degree.
9732 You, Miss Woodhouse, I well know, play delightfully.  I assure you
9733 it has been the greatest satisfaction, comfort, and delight to me,
9734 to hear what a musical society I am got into.  I absolutely cannot
9735 do without music.  It is a necessary of life to me; and having always
9736 been used to a very musical society, both at Maple Grove and in Bath,
9737 it would have been a most serious sacrifice.  I honestly said as much
9738 to Mr. E. when he was speaking of my future home, and expressing
9739 his fears lest the retirement of it should be disagreeable;
9740 and the inferiority of the house too--knowing what I had been
9741 accustomed to--of course he was not wholly without apprehension.
9742 When he was speaking of it in that way, I honestly said that _the_
9743 _world_ I could give up--parties, balls, plays--for I had no fear
9744 of retirement.  Blessed with so many resources within myself,
9745 the world was not necessary to _me_.  I could do very well without it.
9746 To those who had no resources it was a different thing; but my
9747 resources made me quite independent.  And as to smaller-sized rooms
9748 than I had been used to, I really could not give it a thought.
9749 I hoped I was perfectly equal to any sacrifice of that description.
9750 Certainly I had been accustomed to every luxury at Maple Grove; but I
9751 did assure him that two carriages were not necessary to my happiness,
9752 nor were spacious apartments.  `But,' said I, `to be quite honest,
9753 I do not think I can live without something of a musical society.
9754 I condition for nothing else; but without music, life would be a blank
9755 to me.'"
9756 
9757 "We cannot suppose," said Emma, smiling, "that Mr. Elton would hesitate
9758 to assure you of there being a _very_ musical society in Highbury;
9759 and I hope you will not find he has outstepped the truth more than
9760 may be pardoned, in consideration of the motive."
9761 
9762 "No, indeed, I have no doubts at all on that head.  I am delighted
9763 to find myself in such a circle.  I hope we shall have many sweet
9764 little concerts together.  I think, Miss Woodhouse, you and I
9765 must establish a musical club, and have regular weekly meetings
9766 at your house, or ours.  Will not it be a good plan?  If _we_
9767 exert ourselves, I think we shall not be long in want of allies.
9768 Something of that nature would be particularly desirable for _me_,
9769 as an inducement to keep me in practice; for married women, you know--
9770 there is a sad story against them, in general.  They are but too apt
9771 to give up music."
9772 
9773 "But you, who are so extremely fond of it--there can
9774 be no danger, surely?"
9775 
9776 "I should hope not; but really when I look around among my acquaintance,
9777 I tremble.  Selina has entirely given up music--never touches
9778 the instrument--though she played sweetly.  And the same may be said
9779 of Mrs. Jeffereys--Clara Partridge, that was--and of the two Milmans,
9780 now Mrs. Bird and Mrs. James Cooper; and of more than I can enumerate.
9781 Upon my word it is enough to put one in a fright.  I used to be
9782 quite angry with Selina; but really I begin now to comprehend
9783 that a married woman has many things to call her attention.
9784 I believe I was half an hour this morning shut up with my housekeeper."
9785 
9786 "But every thing of that kind," said Emma, "will soon
9787 be in so regular a train--"
9788 
9789 "Well," said Mrs. Elton, laughing, "we shall see."
9790 
9791 Emma, finding her so determined upon neglecting her music,
9792 had nothing more to say; and, after a moment's pause, Mrs. Elton
9793 chose another subject.
9794 
9795 "We have been calling at Randalls," said she, "and found them
9796 both at home; and very pleasant people they seem to be.
9797 I like them extremely.  Mr. Weston seems an excellent creature--
9798 quite a first-rate favourite with me already, I assure you.
9799 And _she_ appears so truly good--there is something so motherly
9800 and kind-hearted about her, that it wins upon one directly.
9801 She was your governess, I think?"
9802 
9803 Emma was almost too much astonished to answer; but Mrs. Elton
9804 hardly waited for the affirmative before she went on.
9805 
9806 "Having understood as much, I was rather astonished to find her
9807 so very lady-like!  But she is really quite the gentlewoman."
9808 
9809 "Mrs. Weston's manners," said Emma, "were always particularly good.
9810 Their propriety, simplicity, and elegance, would make them the safest
9811 model for any young woman."
9812 
9813 "And who do you think came in while we were there?"
9814 
9815 Emma was quite at a loss.  The tone implied some old acquaintance--
9816 and how could she possibly guess?
9817 
9818 "Knightley!" continued Mrs. Elton; "Knightley himself!--Was not
9819 it lucky?--for, not being within when he called the other day,
9820 I had never seen him before; and of course, as so particular a
9821 friend of Mr. E.'s, I had a great curiosity.  `My friend Knightley'
9822 had been so often mentioned, that I was really impatient to see him;
9823 and I must do my caro sposo the justice to say that he need not
9824 be ashamed of his friend.  Knightley is quite the gentleman.
9825 I like him very much.  Decidedly, I think, a very gentleman-like man."
9826 
9827 Happily, it was now time to be gone.  They were off; and Emma
9828 could breathe.
9829 
9830 "Insufferable woman!" was her immediate exclamation.  "Worse than I
9831 had supposed.  Absolutely insufferable!  Knightley!--I could not
9832 have believed it.  Knightley!--never seen him in her life before,
9833 and call him Knightley!--and discover that he is a gentleman!
9834 A little upstart, vulgar being, with her Mr. E., and her _caro_ _sposo_,
9835 and her resources, and all her airs of pert pretension and
9836 underbred finery.  Actually to discover that Mr. Knightley is
9837 a gentleman!  I doubt whether he will return the compliment,
9838 and discover her to be a lady.  I could not have believed it!
9839 And to propose that she and I should unite to form a musical club!
9840 One would fancy we were bosom friends!  And Mrs. Weston!--
9841 Astonished that the person who had brought me up should be
9842 a gentlewoman!  Worse and worse.  I never met with her equal.
9843 Much beyond my hopes.  Harriet is disgraced by any comparison.
9844 Oh! what would Frank Churchill say to her, if he were here?
9845 How angry and how diverted he would be!  Ah! there I am--
9846 thinking of him directly.  Always the first person to be thought of!
9847 How I catch myself out!  Frank Churchill comes as regularly into
9848 my mind!"--
9849 
9850 All this ran so glibly through her thoughts, that by the time
9851 her father had arranged himself, after the bustle of the Eltons'
9852 departure, and was ready to speak, she was very tolerably capable
9853 of attending.
9854 
9855 "Well, my dear," he deliberately began, "considering we never saw
9856 her before, she seems a very pretty sort of young lady; and I dare say
9857 she was very much pleased with you.  She speaks a little too quick.
9858 A little quickness of voice there is which rather hurts the ear.
9859 But I believe I am nice; I do not like strange voices; and nobody speaks
9860 like you and poor Miss Taylor.  However, she seems a very obliging,
9861 pretty-behaved young lady, and no doubt will make him a very good wife.
9862 Though I think he had better not have married.  I made the best
9863 excuses I could for not having been able to wait on him and Mrs. Elton
9864 on this happy occasion; I said that I hoped I _should_ in the course
9865 of the summer.  But I ought to have gone before.  Not to wait upon
9866 a bride is very remiss.  Ah! it shews what a sad invalid I am!
9867 But I do not like the corner into Vicarage Lane."
9868 
9869 "I dare say your apologies were accepted, sir.  Mr. Elton knows you."
9870 
9871 "Yes:  but a young lady--a bride--I ought to have paid my respects
9872 to her if possible.  It was being very deficient."
9873 
9874 "But, my dear papa, you are no friend to matrimony; and therefore
9875 why should you be so anxious to pay your respects to a _bride_?
9876 It ought to be no recommendation to _you_.  It is encouraging people
9877 to marry if you make so much of them."
9878 
9879 "No, my dear, I never encouraged any body to marry, but I would
9880 always wish to pay every proper attention to a lady--and a bride,
9881 especially, is never to be neglected.  More is avowedly due to _her_.
9882 A bride, you know, my dear, is always the first in company,
9883 let the others be who they may."
9884 
9885 "Well, papa, if this is not encouragement to marry, I do not know
9886 what is.  And I should never have expected you to be lending your
9887 sanction to such vanity-baits for poor young ladies."
9888 
9889 "My dear, you do not understand me.  This is a
9890 matter of mere common politeness and good-breeding,
9891 and has nothing to do with any encouragement to people to marry."
9892 
9893 Emma had done.  Her father was growing nervous, and could not
9894 understand _her_.  Her mind returned to Mrs. Elton's offences,
9895 and long, very long, did they occupy her.
9896 
9897 
9898 
9899 CHAPTER XV
9900 
9901 
9902 Emma was not required, by any subsequent discovery, to retract her ill
9903 opinion of Mrs. Elton.  Her observation had been pretty correct.
9904 Such as Mrs. Elton appeared to her on this second interview,
9905 such she appeared whenever they met again,--self-important, presuming,
9906 familiar, ignorant, and ill-bred. She had a little beauty and a
9907 little accomplishment, but so little judgment that she thought herself
9908 coming with superior knowledge of the world, to enliven and improve
9909 a country neighbourhood; and conceived Miss Hawkins to have held
9910 such a place in society as Mrs. Elton's consequence only could surpass.
9911 
9912 There was no reason to suppose Mr. Elton thought at all differently
9913 from his wife.  He seemed not merely happy with her, but proud.
9914 He had the air of congratulating himself on having brought such
9915 a woman to Highbury, as not even Miss Woodhouse could equal;
9916 and the greater part of her new acquaintance, disposed to commend,
9917 or not in the habit of judging, following the lead of Miss Bates's
9918 good-will, or taking it for granted that the bride must be as clever
9919 and as agreeable as she professed herself, were very well satisfied;
9920 so that Mrs. Elton's praise passed from one mouth to another as it
9921 ought to do, unimpeded by Miss Woodhouse, who readily continued her
9922 first contribution and talked with a good grace of her being "very
9923 pleasant and very elegantly dressed."
9924 
9925 In one respect Mrs. Elton grew even worse than she had appeared
9926 at first.  Her feelings altered towards Emma.--Offended, probably,
9927 by the little encouragement which her proposals of intimacy met with,
9928 she drew back in her turn and gradually became much more cold
9929 and distant; and though the effect was agreeable, the ill-will
9930 which produced it was necessarily increasing Emma's dislike.
9931 Her manners, too--and Mr. Elton's, were unpleasant towards Harriet.
9932 They were sneering and negligent.  Emma hoped it must rapidly work
9933 Harriet's cure; but the sensations which could prompt such behaviour
9934 sunk them both very much.--It was not to be doubted that poor
9935 Harriet's attachment had been an offering to conjugal unreserve,
9936 and her own share in the story, under a colouring the least favourable
9937 to her and the most soothing to him, had in all likelihood been
9938 given also.  She was, of course, the object of their joint dislike.--
9939 When they had nothing else to say, it must be always easy to begin
9940 abusing Miss Woodhouse; and the enmity which they dared not shew
9941 in open disrespect to her, found a broader vent in contemptuous
9942 treatment of Harriet.
9943 
9944 Mrs. Elton took a great fancy to Jane Fairfax; and from the first.
9945 Not merely when a state of warfare with one young lady might be
9946 supposed to recommend the other, but from the very first; and she
9947 was not satisfied with expressing a natural and reasonable admiration--
9948 but without solicitation, or plea, or privilege, she must be wanting
9949 to assist and befriend her.--Before Emma had forfeited her confidence,
9950 and about the third time of their meeting, she heard all Mrs. Elton's
9951 knight-errantry on the subject.--
9952 
9953 "Jane Fairfax is absolutely charming, Miss Woodhouse.--I quite
