9954 rave about Jane Fairfax.--A sweet, interesting creature.  So mild
9955 and ladylike--and with such talents!--I assure you I think she
9956 has very extraordinary talents.  I do not scruple to say that she
9957 plays extremely well.  I know enough of music to speak decidedly
9958 on that point.  Oh! she is absolutely charming!  You will laugh at
9959 my warmth--but, upon my word, I talk of nothing but Jane Fairfax.--
9960 And her situation is so calculated to affect one!--Miss Woodhouse,
9961 we must exert ourselves and endeavour to do something for her.
9962 We must bring her forward.  Such talent as hers must not be suffered
9963 to remain unknown.--I dare say you have heard those charming lines of
9964 the poet,
9965 
9966         `Full many a flower is born to blush unseen,
9967           `And waste its fragrance on the desert air.'
9968 
9969 We must not allow them to be verified in sweet Jane Fairfax."
9970 
9971 "I cannot think there is any danger of it," was Emma's calm answer--
9972 "and when you are better acquainted with Miss Fairfax's situation
9973 and understand what her home has been, with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell,
9974 I have no idea that you will suppose her talents can be unknown."
9975 
9976 "Oh! but dear Miss Woodhouse, she is now in such retirement,
9977 such obscurity, so thrown away.--Whatever advantages she may have
9978 enjoyed with the Campbells are so palpably at an end!  And I think
9979 she feels it.  I am sure she does.  She is very timid and silent.
9980 One can see that she feels the want of encouragement.  I like her
9981 the better for it.  I must confess it is a recommendation to me.
9982 I am a great advocate for timidity--and I am sure one does
9983 not often meet with it.--But in those who are at all inferior,
9984 it is extremely prepossessing.  Oh!  I assure you, Jane Fairfax
9985 is a very delightful character, and interests me more than I
9986 can express."
9987 
9988 "You appear to feel a great deal--but I am not aware how you or any
9989 of Miss Fairfax's acquaintance here, any of those who have known
9990 her longer than yourself, can shew her any other attention than"--
9991 
9992 "My dear Miss Woodhouse, a vast deal may be done by those who dare
9993 to act.  You and I need not be afraid.  If _we_ set the example,
9994 many will follow it as far as they can; though all have not
9995 our situations.  _We_ have carriages to fetch and convey her home,
9996 and _we_ live in a style which could not make the addition of
9997 Jane Fairfax, at any time, the least inconvenient.--I should be
9998 extremely displeased if Wright were to send us up such a dinner,
9999 as could make me regret having asked _more_ than Jane Fairfax
10000 to partake of it.  I have no idea of that sort of thing.  It is
10001 not likely that I _should_, considering what I have been used to.
10002 My greatest danger, perhaps, in housekeeping, may be quite the
10003 other way, in doing too much, and being too careless of expense.
10004 Maple Grove will probably be my model more than it ought to be--
10005 for we do not at all affect to equal my brother, Mr. Suckling,
10006 in income.--However, my resolution is taken as to noticing Jane Fairfax.--
10007 I shall certainly have her very often at my house, shall introduce
10008 her wherever I can, shall have musical parties to draw out her talents,
10009 and shall be constantly on the watch for an eligible situation.
10010 My acquaintance is so very extensive, that I have little doubt
10011 of hearing of something to suit her shortly.--I shall introduce her,
10012 of course, very particularly to my brother and sister when they come
10013 to us.  I am sure they will like her extremely; and when she gets
10014 a little acquainted with them, her fears will completely wear off,
10015 for there really is nothing in the manners of either but what is
10016 highly conciliating.--I shall have her very often indeed while they
10017 are with me, and I dare say we shall sometimes find a seat for her in
10018 the barouche-landau in some of our exploring parties."
10019 
10020 "Poor Jane Fairfax!"--thought Emma.--"You have not deserved this.
10021 You may have done wrong with regard to Mr. Dixon, but this is a
10022 punishment beyond what you can have merited!--The kindness and protection
10023 of Mrs. Elton!--`Jane Fairfax and Jane Fairfax.'  Heavens!  Let me
10024 not suppose that she dares go about, Emma Woodhouse-ing me!--
10025 But upon my honour, there seems no limits to the licentiousness
10026 of that woman's tongue!"
10027 
10028 Emma had not to listen to such paradings again--to any so exclusively
10029 addressed to herself--so disgustingly decorated with a "dear Miss
10030 Woodhouse."  The change on Mrs. Elton's side soon afterwards appeared,
10031 and she was left in peace--neither forced to be the very particular
10032 friend of Mrs. Elton, nor, under Mrs. Elton's guidance, the very
10033 active patroness of Jane Fairfax, and only sharing with others in a
10034 general way, in knowing what was felt, what was meditated, what was done.
10035 
10036 She looked on with some amusement.--Miss Bates's gratitude for
10037 Mrs. Elton's attentions to Jane was in the first style of guileless
10038 simplicity and warmth.  She was quite one of her worthies--
10039 the most amiable, affable, delightful woman--just as accomplished
10040 and condescending as Mrs. Elton meant to be considered.
10041 Emma's only surprize was that Jane Fairfax should accept
10042 those attentions and tolerate Mrs. Elton as she seemed to do.
10043 She heard of her walking with the Eltons, sitting with the Eltons,
10044 spending a day with the Eltons!  This was astonishing!--She could not
10045 have believed it possible that the taste or the pride of Miss Fairfax
10046 could endure such society and friendship as the Vicarage had to offer.
10047 
10048 "She is a riddle, quite a riddle!" said she.--"To chuse to remain
10049 here month after month, under privations of every sort!  And now
10050 to chuse the mortification of Mrs. Elton's notice and the penury
10051 of her conversation, rather than return to the superior companions
10052 who have always loved her with such real, generous affection."
10053 
10054 Jane had come to Highbury professedly for three months; the Campbells
10055 were gone to Ireland for three months; but now the Campbells
10056 had promised their daughter to stay at least till Midsummer,
10057 and fresh invitations had arrived for her to join them there.
10058 According to Miss Bates--it all came from her--Mrs. Dixon had
10059 written most pressingly.  Would Jane but go, means were to be found,
10060 servants sent, friends contrived--no travelling difficulty allowed
10061 to exist; but still she had declined it!
10062 
10063 "She must have some motive, more powerful than appears, for refusing
10064 this invitation," was Emma's conclusion.  "She must be under some
10065 sort of penance, inflicted either by the Campbells or herself.
10066 There is great fear, great caution, great resolution somewhere.--
10067 She is _not_ to be with the _Dixons_.  The decree is issued by somebody.
10068 But why must she consent to be with the Eltons?--Here is quite a
10069 separate puzzle."
10070 
10071 Upon her speaking her wonder aloud on that part of the subject,
10072 before the few who knew her opinion of Mrs. Elton, Mrs. Weston
10073 ventured this apology for Jane.
10074 
10075 "We cannot suppose that she has any great enjoyment at the Vicarage,
10076 my dear Emma--but it is better than being always at home.
10077 Her aunt is a good creature, but, as a constant companion,
10078 must be very tiresome.  We must consider what Miss Fairfax quits,
10079 before we condemn her taste for what she goes to."
10080 
10081 "You are right, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley warmly, "Miss Fairfax
10082 is as capable as any of us of forming a just opinion of Mrs. Elton.
10083 Could she have chosen with whom to associate, she would not have
10084 chosen her.  But (with a reproachful smile at Emma) she receives
10085 attentions from Mrs. Elton, which nobody else pays her."
10086 
10087 Emma felt that Mrs. Weston was giving her a momentary glance;
10088 and she was herself struck by his warmth.  With a faint blush,
10089 she presently replied,
10090 
10091 "Such attentions as Mrs. Elton's, I should have imagined,
10092 would rather disgust than gratify Miss Fairfax.  Mrs. Elton's
10093 invitations I should have imagined any thing but inviting."
10094 
10095 "I should not wonder," said Mrs. Weston, "if Miss Fairfax were to have
10096 been drawn on beyond her own inclination, by her aunt's eagerness
10097 in accepting Mrs. Elton's civilities for her.  Poor Miss Bates may
10098 very likely have committed her niece and hurried her into a greater
10099 appearance of intimacy than her own good sense would have dictated,
10100 in spite of the very natural wish of a little change."
10101 
10102 Both felt rather anxious to hear him speak again; and after a few
10103 minutes silence, he said,
10104 
10105 "Another thing must be taken into consideration too--Mrs. Elton
10106 does not talk _to_ Miss Fairfax as she speaks _of_ her.  We all know
10107 the difference between the pronouns he or she and thou, the plainest
10108 spoken amongst us; we all feel the influence of a something beyond
10109 common civility in our personal intercourse with each other--
10110 a something more early implanted.  We cannot give any body the
10111 disagreeable hints that we may have been very full of the hour before.
10112 We feel things differently.  And besides the operation of this,
10113 as a general principle, you may be sure that Miss Fairfax awes
10114 Mrs. Elton by her superiority both of mind and manner; and that,
10115 face to face, Mrs. Elton treats her with all the respect which she
10116 has a claim to.  Such a woman as Jane Fairfax probably never fell
10117 in Mrs. Elton's way before--and no degree of vanity can prevent
10118 her acknowledging her own comparative littleness in action, if not
10119 in consciousness."
10120 
10121 "I know how highly you think of Jane Fairfax," said Emma.
10122 Little Henry was in her thoughts, and a mixture of alarm and delicacy
10123 made her irresolute what else to say.
10124 
10125 "Yes," he replied, "any body may know how highly I think of her."
10126 
10127 "And yet," said Emma, beginning hastily and with an arch look,
10128 but soon stopping--it was better, however, to know the worst at once--
10129 she hurried on--"And yet, perhaps, you may hardly be aware yourself
10130 how highly it is.  The extent of your admiration may take you by
10131 surprize some day or other."
10132 
10133 Mr. Knightley was hard at work upon the lower buttons of his thick
10134 leather gaiters, and either the exertion of getting them together,
10135 or some other cause, brought the colour into his face, as he answered,
10136 
10137 "Oh! are you there?--But you are miserably behindhand.  Mr. Cole
10138 gave me a hint of it six weeks ago."
10139 
10140 He stopped.--Emma felt her foot pressed by Mrs. Weston, and did
10141 not herself know what to think.  In a moment he went on--
10142 
10143 "That will never be, however, I can assure you.  Miss Fairfax,
10144 I dare say, would not have me if I were to ask her--and I am very
10145 sure I shall never ask her."
10146 
10147 Emma returned her friend's pressure with interest; and was pleased
10148 enough to exclaim,
10149 
10150 "You are not vain, Mr. Knightley.  I will say that for you."
10151 
10152 He seemed hardly to hear her; he was thoughtful--and in a manner
10153 which shewed him not pleased, soon afterwards said,
10154 
10155 "So you have been settling that I should marry Jane Fairfax?"
10156 
10157 "No indeed I have not.  You have scolded me too much for match-making,
10158 for me to presume to take such a liberty with you.  What I said
10159 just now, meant nothing.  One says those sort of things, of course,
10160 without any idea of a serious meaning.  Oh! no, upon my word I have not
10161 the smallest wish for your marrying Jane Fairfax or Jane any body.
10162 You would not come in and sit with us in this comfortable way,
10163 if you were married."
10164 
10165 Mr. Knightley was thoughtful again.  The result of his reverie was,
10166 "No, Emma, I do not think the extent of my admiration for her will
10167 ever take me by surprize.--I never had a thought of her in that way,
10168 I assure you."  And soon afterwards, "Jane Fairfax is a very charming
10169 young woman--but not even Jane Fairfax is perfect.  She has a fault.
10170 She has not the open temper which a man would wish for in a wife."
10171 
10172 Emma could not but rejoice to hear that she had a fault.
10173 "Well," said she, "and you soon silenced Mr. Cole, I suppose?"
10174 
10175 "Yes, very soon.  He gave me a quiet hint; I told him he was mistaken;
10176 he asked my pardon and said no more.  Cole does not want to be wiser
10177 or wittier than his neighbours."
10178 
10179 "In that respect how unlike dear Mrs. Elton, who wants to be wiser
10180 and wittier than all the world!  I wonder how she speaks of the Coles--
10181 what she calls them!  How can she find any appellation for them,
10182 deep enough in familiar vulgarity?  She calls you, Knightley--what can
10183 she do for Mr. Cole?  And so I am not to be surprized that Jane
10184 Fairfax accepts her civilities and consents to be with her.
10185 Mrs. Weston, your argument weighs most with me.  I can much more
10186 readily enter into the temptation of getting away from Miss Bates,
10187 than I can believe in the triumph of Miss Fairfax's mind over
10188 Mrs. Elton.  I have no faith in Mrs. Elton's acknowledging herself
10189 the inferior in thought, word, or deed; or in her being under any
10190 restraint beyond her own scanty rule of good-breeding. I cannot
10191 imagine that she will not be continually insulting her visitor
10192 with praise, encouragement, and offers of service; that she will not be
10193 continually detailing her magnificent intentions, from the procuring
10194 her a permanent situation to the including her in those delightful
10195 exploring parties which are to take place in the barouche-landau."
10196 
10197 "Jane Fairfax has feeling," said Mr. Knightley--"I do not
10198 accuse her of want of feeling.  Her sensibilities, I suspect,
10199 are strong--and her temper excellent in its power of forbearance,
10200 patience, self-controul; but it wants openness.  She is reserved,
10201 more reserved, I think, than she used to be--And I love an
10202 open temper.  No--till Cole alluded to my supposed attachment,
10203 it had never entered my head.  I saw Jane Fairfax and conversed with
10204 her, with admiration and pleasure always--but with no thought beyond."
10205 
10206 "Well, Mrs. Weston," said Emma triumphantly when he left them,
10207 "what do you say now to Mr. Knightley's marrying Jane Fairfax?"
10208 
10209 "Why, really, dear Emma, I say that he is so very much occupied
10210 by the idea of _not_ being in love with her, that I should not wonder
10211 if it were to end in his being so at last.  Do not beat me."
10212 
10213 
10214 
10215 CHAPTER XVI
10216 
10217 
10218 Every body in and about Highbury who had ever visited Mr. Elton,
10219 was disposed to pay him attention on his marriage.  Dinner-parties and
10220 evening-parties were made for him and his lady; and invitations
10221 flowed in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending
10222 they were never to have a disengaged day.
10223 
10224 "I see how it is," said she.  "I see what a life I am to lead
10225 among you.  Upon my word we shall be absolutely dissipated.
10226 We really seem quite the fashion.  If this is living in the country,
10227 it is nothing very formidable.  From Monday next to Saturday,
10228 I assure you we have not a disengaged day!--A woman with fewer
10229 resources than I have, need not have been at a loss."
10230 
10231 No invitation came amiss to her.  Her Bath habits made evening-parties
10232 perfectly natural to her, and Maple Grove had given her a taste
10233 for dinners.  She was a little shocked at the want of two
10234 drawing rooms, at the poor attempt at rout-cakes, and there being
10235 no ice in the Highbury card-parties. Mrs. Bates, Mrs. Perry,
10236 Mrs. Goddard and others, were a good deal behind-hand in knowledge
10237 of the world, but she would soon shew them how every thing ought
10238 to be arranged.  In the course of the spring she must return their
10239 civilities by one very superior party--in which her card-tables
10240 should be set out with their separate candles and unbroken packs
10241 in the true style--and more waiters engaged for the evening
10242 than their own establishment could furnish, to carry round
10243 the refreshments at exactly the proper hour, and in the proper order.
10244 
10245 Emma, in the meanwhile, could not be satisfied without a dinner
10246 at Hartfield for the Eltons.  They must not do less than others,
10247 or she should be exposed to odious suspicions, and imagined capable
10248 of pitiful resentment.  A dinner there must be.  After Emma had
10249 talked about it for ten minutes, Mr. Woodhouse felt no unwillingness,
10250 and only made the usual stipulation of not sitting at the bottom
10251 of the table himself, with the usual regular difficulty of deciding
10252 who should do it for him.
10253 
10254 The persons to be invited, required little thought.  Besides the Eltons,
10255 it must be the Westons and Mr. Knightley; so far it was all of course--
10256 and it was hardly less inevitable that poor little Harriet must
10257 be asked to make the eighth:--but this invitation was not given
10258 with equal satisfaction, and on many accounts Emma was particularly
10259 pleased by Harriet's begging to be allowed to decline it.
10260 "She would rather not be in his company more than she could help.
10261 She was not yet quite able to see him and his charming happy
10262 wife together, without feeling uncomfortable.  If Miss Woodhouse
10263 would not be displeased, she would rather stay at home."
10264 It was precisely what Emma would have wished, had she deemed it
10265 possible enough for wishing.  She was delighted with the fortitude
10266 of her little friend--for fortitude she knew it was in her to give
10267 up being in company and stay at home; and she could now invite the
10268 very person whom she really wanted to make the eighth, Jane Fairfax.--
10269 Since her last conversation with Mrs. Weston and Mr. Knightley,
10270 she was more conscience-stricken about Jane Fairfax than she had
10271 often been.--Mr. Knightley's words dwelt with her.  He had said
10272 that Jane Fairfax received attentions from Mrs. Elton which nobody
10273 else paid her.
10274 
10275 "This is very true," said she, "at least as far as relates to me,
10276 which was all that was meant--and it is very shameful.--Of the same age--
10277 and always knowing her--I ought to have been more her friend.--
10278 She will never like me now.  I have neglected her too long.  But I
10279 will shew her greater attention than I have done."
10280 
10281 Every invitation was successful.  They were all disengaged and all happy.--
10282 The preparatory interest of this dinner, however, was not yet over.
10283 A circumstance rather unlucky occurred.  The two eldest little
10284 Knightleys were engaged to pay their grandpapa and aunt a visit of
10285 some weeks in the spring, and their papa now proposed bringing them,
10286 and staying one whole day at Hartfield--which one day would be
10287 the very day of this party.--His professional engagements did
10288 not allow of his being put off, but both father and daughter were
10289 disturbed by its happening so.  Mr. Woodhouse considered eight
10290 persons at dinner together as the utmost that his nerves could bear--
10291 and here would be a ninth--and Emma apprehended that it would
10292 be a ninth very much out of humour at not being able to come even
10293 to Hartfield for forty-eight hours without falling in with a dinner-party.
10294 
10295 She comforted her father better than she could comfort herself,
10296 by representing that though he certainly would make them nine,
10297 yet he always said so little, that the increase of noise would be
10298 very immaterial.  She thought it in reality a sad exchange for herself,
10299 to have him with his grave looks and reluctant conversation opposed
10300 to her instead of his brother.
10301 
10302 The event was more favourable to Mr. Woodhouse than to Emma.
10303 John Knightley came; but Mr. Weston was unexpectedly summoned to town
10304 and must be absent on the very day.  He might be able to join them
10305 in the evening, but certainly not to dinner.  Mr. Woodhouse was quite
10306 at ease; and the seeing him so, with the arrival of the little boys
10307 and the philosophic composure of her brother on hearing his fate,
10308 removed the chief of even Emma's vexation.
10309 
10310 The day came, the party were punctually assembled, and Mr. John Knightley
10311 seemed early to devote himself to the business of being agreeable.
10312 Instead of drawing his brother off to a window while they waited
10313 for dinner, he was talking to Miss Fairfax.  Mrs. Elton, as elegant
10314 as lace and pearls could make her, he looked at in silence--
10315 wanting only to observe enough for Isabella's information--but Miss
10316 Fairfax was an old acquaintance and a quiet girl, and he could
10317 talk to her.  He had met her before breakfast as he was returning
10318 from a walk with his little boys, when it had been just beginning
10319 to rain.  It was natural to have some civil hopes on the subject,
10320 and he said,
10321 
10322 "I hope you did not venture far, Miss Fairfax, this morning, or I
10323 am sure you must have been wet.--We scarcely got home in time.
10324 I hope you turned directly."
10325 
10326 "I went only to the post-office," said she, "and reached home
10327 before the rain was much.  It is my daily errand.  I always fetch
10328 the letters when I am here.  It saves trouble, and is a something
10329 to get me out.  A walk before breakfast does me good."
10330 
10331 "Not a walk in the rain, I should imagine."
10332 
10333 "No, but it did not absolutely rain when I set out."
10334 
10335 Mr. John Knightley smiled, and replied,
10336 
10337 "That is to say, you chose to have your walk, for you were not six
10338 yards from your own door when I had the pleasure of meeting you;
10339 and Henry and John had seen more drops than they could count long before.
10340 The post-office has a great charm at one period of our lives.
10341 When you have lived to my age, you will begin to think letters are
10342 never worth going through the rain for."
10343 
10344 There was a little blush, and then this answer,
10345 
10346 "I must not hope to be ever situated as you are, in the midst of
10347 every dearest connexion, and therefore I cannot expect that simply
10348 growing older should make me indifferent about letters."
10349 
10350 "Indifferent!  Oh! no--I never conceived you could become indifferent.
10351 Letters are no matter of indifference; they are generally a very
10352 positive curse."
10353 
10354 "You are speaking of letters of business; mine are letters
10355 of friendship."
10356 
10357 "I have often thought them the worst of the two," replied he coolly.
10358 "Business, you know, may bring money, but friendship hardly
10359 ever does."
10360 
10361 "Ah! you are not serious now.  I know Mr. John Knightley too well--
10362 I am very sure he understands the value of friendship as well as
10363 any body.  I can easily believe that letters are very little to you,
10364 much less than to me, but it is not your being ten years older than
10365 myself which makes the difference, it is not age, but situation.
10366 You have every body dearest to you always at hand, I, probably,
10367 never shall again; and therefore till I have outlived all my affections,
10368 a post-office, I think, must always have power to draw me out,
10369 in worse weather than to-day."
10370 
10371 "When I talked of your being altered by time, by the progress of years,"
10372 said John Knightley, "I meant to imply the change of situation
10373 which time usually brings.  I consider one as including the other.
10374 Time will generally lessen the interest of every attachment not within
10375 the daily circle--but that is not the change I had in view for you.
10376 As an old friend, you will allow me to hope, Miss Fairfax, that ten
10377 years hence you may have as many concentrated objects as I have."
10378 
10379 It was kindly said, and very far from giving offence.  A pleasant
10380 "thank you" seemed meant to laugh it off, but a blush, a quivering lip,
10381 a tear in the eye, shewed that it was felt beyond a laugh.
10382 Her attention was now claimed by Mr. Woodhouse, who being,
10383 according to his custom on such occasions, making the circle of
10384 his guests, and paying his particular compliments to the ladies,
10385 was ending with her--and with all his mildest urbanity, said,
10386 
10387 "I am very sorry to hear, Miss Fairfax, of your being out this
10388 morning in the rain.  Young ladies should take care of themselves.--
10389 Young ladies are delicate plants.  They should take care of their
10390 health and their complexion.  My dear, did you change your stockings?"
10391 
10392 "Yes, sir, I did indeed; and I am very much obliged by your kind
10393 solicitude about me."
10394 
10395 "My dear Miss Fairfax, young ladies are very sure to be cared for.--
10396 I hope your good grand-mama and aunt are well.  They are some
10397 of my very old friends.  I wish my health allowed me to be a
10398 better neighbour.  You do us a great deal of honour to-day, I am sure.
10399 My daughter and I are both highly sensible of your goodness,
10400 and have the greatest satisfaction in seeing you at Hartfield."
10401 
10402 The kind-hearted, polite old man might then sit down and feel
10403 that he had done his duty, and made every fair lady welcome and easy.
10404 
10405 By this time, the walk in the rain had reached Mrs. Elton,
10406 and her remonstrances now opened upon Jane.
10407 
10408 "My dear Jane, what is this I hear?--Going to the post-office
10409 in the rain!--This must not be, I assure you.--You sad girl,
10410 how could you do such a thing?--It is a sign I was not there
10411 to take care of you."
10412 
10413 Jane very patiently assured her that she had not caught any cold.
10414 
10415 "Oh! do not tell _me_.  You really are a very sad girl, and do not
10416 know how to take care of yourself.--To the post-office indeed!
10417 Mrs. Weston, did you ever hear the like?  You and I must positively
10418 exert our authority."
10419 
10420 "My advice," said Mrs. Weston kindly and persuasively, "I certainly
10421 do feel tempted to give.  Miss Fairfax, you must not run such risks.--
10422 Liable as you have been to severe colds, indeed you ought
10423 to be particularly careful, especially at this time of year.
10424 The spring I always think requires more than common care.
10425 Better wait an hour or two, or even half a day for your letters,
10426 than run the risk of bringing on your cough again.  Now do not you
10427 feel that you had?  Yes, I am sure you are much too reasonable.
10428 You look as if you would not do such a thing again."
10429 
10430 "Oh! she _shall_ _not_ do such a thing again," eagerly rejoined
10431 Mrs. Elton.  "We will not allow her to do such a thing again:"--
10432 and nodding significantly--"there must be some arrangement made,
10433 there must indeed.  I shall speak to Mr. E. The man who fetches
10434 our letters every morning (one of our men, I forget his name)
10435 shall inquire for yours too and bring them to you.  That will obviate
10436 all difficulties you know; and from _us_ I really think, my dear Jane,
10437 you can have no scruple to accept such an accommodation."
10438 
10439 "You are extremely kind," said Jane; "but I cannot give up my
10440 early walk.  I am advised to be out of doors as much as I can,
10441 I must walk somewhere, and the post-office is an object; and upon
10442 my word, I have scarcely ever had a bad morning before."
10443 
10444 "My dear Jane, say no more about it.  The thing is determined,
10445 that is (laughing affectedly) as far as I can presume to determine
10446 any thing without the concurrence of my lord and master.  You know,
10447 Mrs. Weston, you and I must be cautious how we express ourselves.
10448 But I do flatter myself, my dear Jane, that my influence is not entirely
10449 worn out.  If I meet with no insuperable difficulties therefore,
10450 consider that point as settled."
10451 
10452 "Excuse me," said Jane earnestly, "I cannot by any means consent
10453 to such an arrangement, so needlessly troublesome to your servant.
10454 If the errand were not a pleasure to me, it could be done, as it
10455 always is when I am not here, by my grandmama's."
10456 
10457 "Oh! my dear; but so much as Patty has to do!--And it is a kindness
10458 to employ our men."
10459 
10460 Jane looked as if she did not mean to be conquered; but instead
10461 of answering, she began speaking again to Mr. John Knightley.
10462 
10463 "The post-office is a wonderful establishment!" said she.--
10464 "The regularity and despatch of it!  If one thinks of all that it
10465 has to do, and all that it does so well, it is really astonishing!"
10466 
10467 "It is certainly very well regulated."
10468 
10469 "So seldom that any negligence or blunder appears!  So seldom
10470 that a letter, among the thousands that are constantly passing
10471 about the kingdom, is even carried wrong--and not one in a million,
10472 I suppose, actually lost!  And when one considers the variety
10473 of hands, and of bad hands too, that are to be deciphered,
10474 it increases the wonder."
10475 
10476 "The clerks grow expert from habit.--They must begin with some
10477 quickness of sight and hand, and exercise improves them.  If you
10478 want any farther explanation," continued he, smiling, "they are
10479 paid for it.  That is the key to a great deal of capacity.
10480 The public pays and must be served well."
10481 
10482 The varieties of handwriting were farther talked of, and the usual
10483 observations made.
10484 
10485 "I have heard it asserted," said John Knightley, "that the same
10486 sort of handwriting often prevails in a family; and where the
10487 same master teaches, it is natural enough.  But for that reason,
10488 I should imagine the likeness must be chiefly confined to the females,
10489 for boys have very little teaching after an early age, and scramble
10490 into any hand they can get.  Isabella and Emma, I think, do write
10491 very much alike.  I have not always known their writing apart."
10492 
10493 "Yes," said his brother hesitatingly, "there is a likeness.
10494 I know what you mean--but Emma's hand is the strongest."
10495 
10496 "Isabella and Emma both write beautifully," said Mr. Woodhouse;
10497 "and always did.  And so does poor Mrs. Weston"--with half a sigh
10498 and half a smile at her.
10499 
10500 "I never saw any gentleman's handwriting"--Emma began, looking also
10501 at Mrs. Weston; but stopped, on perceiving that Mrs. Weston was
10502 attending to some one else--and the pause gave her time to reflect,
10503 "Now, how am I going to introduce him?--Am I unequal to speaking
10504 his name at once before all these people?  Is it necessary
10505 for me to use any roundabout phrase?--Your Yorkshire friend--
10506 your correspondent in Yorkshire;--that would be the way, I suppose,
10507 if I were very bad.--No, I can pronounce his name without the
10508 smallest distress.  I certainly get better and better.--Now for it."
10509 
10510 Mrs. Weston was disengaged and Emma began again--"Mr. Frank Churchill
10511 writes one of the best gentleman's hands I ever saw."
10512 
10513 "I do not admire it," said Mr. Knightley.  "It is too small--
10514 wants strength.  It is like a woman's writing."
10515 
10516 This was not submitted to by either lady.  They vindicated him
10517 against the base aspersion.  "No, it by no means wanted strength--
10518 it was not a large hand, but very clear and certainly strong.
10519 Had not Mrs. Weston any letter about her to produce?"  No, she had
10520 heard from him very lately, but having answered the letter, had put
10521 it away.
10522 
10523 "If we were in the other room," said Emma, "if I had my writing-desk,
10524 I am sure I could produce a specimen.  I have a note of his.--
10525 Do not you remember, Mrs. Weston, employing him to write for you
10526 one day?"
10527 
10528 "He chose to say he was employed"--
10529 
10530 "Well, well, I have that note; and can shew it after dinner
10531 to convince Mr. Knightley."
10532 
10533 "Oh! when a gallant young man, like Mr. Frank Churchill,"
10534 said Mr. Knightley dryly, "writes to a fair lady like Miss Woodhouse,
10535 he will, of course, put forth his best."
10536 
10537 Dinner was on table.--Mrs. Elton, before she could be spoken to,
10538 was ready; and before Mr. Woodhouse had reached her with his request
10539 to be allowed to hand her into the dining-parlour, was saying--
10540 
10541 "Must I go first?  I really am ashamed of always leading the way."
10542 
10543 Jane's solicitude about fetching her own letters had not escaped Emma.
10544 She had heard and seen it all; and felt some curiosity to know
10545 whether the wet walk of this morning had produced any.  She suspected
10546 that it _had_; that it would not have been so resolutely encountered
10547 but in full expectation of hearing from some one very dear,
10548 and that it had not been in vain.  She thought there was an air
10549 of greater happiness than usual--a glow both of complexion and spirits.
10550 
10551 She could have made an inquiry or two, as to the expedition
10552 and the expense of the Irish mails;--it was at her tongue's end--
10553 but she abstained.  She was quite determined not to utter a word
10554 that should hurt Jane Fairfax's feelings; and they followed
10555 the other ladies out of the room, arm in arm, with an appearance
10556 of good-will highly becoming to the beauty and grace of each.
10557 
10558 
10559 
10560 CHAPTER XVII
10561 
10562 
10563 When the ladies returned to the drawing-room after dinner, Emma found
10564 it hardly possible to prevent their making two distinct parties;--
10565 with so much perseverance in judging and behaving ill did Mrs. Elton
10566 engross Jane Fairfax and slight herself.  She and Mrs. Weston were
10567 obliged to be almost always either talking together or silent together.
10568 Mrs. Elton left them no choice.  If Jane repressed her for a
10569 little time, she soon began again; and though much that passed
10570 between them was in a half-whisper, especially on Mrs. Elton's side,
10571 there was no avoiding a knowledge of their principal subjects:
10572 The post-office--catching cold--fetching letters--and friendship,
10573 were long under discussion; and to them succeeded one, which must
10574 be at least equally unpleasant to Jane--inquiries whether she had
10575 yet heard of any situation likely to suit her, and professions of
10576 Mrs. Elton's meditated activity.
10577 
10578 "Here is April come!" said she, "I get quite anxious about you.
10579 June will soon be here."
10580 
10581 "But I have never fixed on June or any other month--merely looked
10582 forward to the summer in general."
10583 
10584 "But have you really heard of nothing?"
10585 
10586 "I have not even made any inquiry; I do not wish to make any yet."
10587 
10588 "Oh! my dear, we cannot begin too early; you are not aware
10589 of the difficulty of procuring exactly the desirable thing."
10590 
10591 "I not aware!" said Jane, shaking her head; "dear Mrs. Elton,
10592 who can have thought of it as I have done?"
10593 
10594 "But you have not seen so much of the world as I have.  You do not
10595 know how many candidates there always are for the _first_ situations.
10596 I saw a vast deal of that in the neighbourhood round Maple Grove.
10597 A cousin of Mr. Suckling, Mrs. Bragge, had such an infinity
10598 of applications; every body was anxious to be in her family,
10599 for she moves in the first circle.  Wax-candles in the schoolroom!
10600 You may imagine how desirable!  Of all houses in the kingdom
10601 Mrs. Bragge's is the one I would most wish to see you in."
10602 
10603 "Colonel and Mrs. Campbell are to be in town again by midsummer,"
10604 said Jane.  "I must spend some time with them; I am sure they will
10605 want it;--afterwards I may probably be glad to dispose of myself.
10606 But I would not wish you to take the trouble of making any inquiries
10607 at present."
10608 
10609 "Trouble! aye, I know your scruples.  You are afraid of giving
10610 me trouble; but I assure you, my dear Jane, the Campbells can
10611 hardly be more interested about you than I am.  I shall write
10612 to Mrs. Partridge in a day or two, and shall give her a strict
10613 charge to be on the look-out for any thing eligible."
10614 
10615 "Thank you, but I would rather you did not mention the subject
10616 to her; till the time draws nearer, I do not wish to be giving
10617 any body trouble."
10618 
10619 "But, my dear child, the time is drawing near; here is April,
10620 and June, or say even July, is very near, with such business
10621 to accomplish before us.  Your inexperience really amuses me!
10622 A situation such as you deserve, and your friends would require for you,
10623 is no everyday occurrence, is not obtained at a moment's notice;
10624 indeed, indeed, we must begin inquiring directly."
10625 
10626 "Excuse me, ma'am, but this is by no means my intention; I make no
10627 inquiry myself, and should be sorry to have any made by my friends.
10628 When I am quite determined as to the time, I am not at all afraid
10629 of being long unemployed.  There are places in town, offices,
10630 where inquiry would soon produce something--Offices for the sale--
10631 not quite of human flesh--but of human intellect."
10632 
10633 "Oh! my dear, human flesh!  You quite shock me; if you mean a fling
10634 at the slave-trade, I assure you Mr. Suckling was always rather
10635 a friend to the abolition."
10636 
10637 "I did not mean, I was not thinking of the slave-trade," replied Jane;
10638 "governess-trade, I assure you, was all that I had in view;
10639 widely different certainly as to the guilt of those who carry it on;
10640 but as to the greater misery of the victims, I do not know where
10641 it lies.  But I only mean to say that there are advertising offices,
10642 and that by applying to them I should have no doubt of very soon
10643 meeting with something that would do."
10644 
10645 "Something that would do!" repeated Mrs. Elton.  "Aye, _that_ may
10646 suit your humble ideas of yourself;--I know what a modest creature
10647 you are; but it will not satisfy your friends to have you taking up
10648 with any thing that may offer, any inferior, commonplace situation,
10649 in a family not moving in a certain circle, or able to command
10650 the elegancies of life."
10651 
10652 "You are very obliging; but as to all that, I am very indifferent;
10653 it would be no object to me to be with the rich; my mortifications,
10654 I think, would only be the greater; I should suffer more from comparison.
10655 A gentleman's family is all that I should condition for."
10656 
10657 "I know you, I know you; you would take up with any thing; but I
10658 shall be a little more nice, and I am sure the good Campbells will
10659 be quite on my side; with your superior talents, you have a right
10660 to move in the first circle.  Your musical knowledge alone would
10661 entitle you to name your own terms, have as many rooms as you like,
10662 and mix in the family as much as you chose;--that is--I do not know--
10663 if you knew the harp, you might do all that, I am very sure;
10664 but you sing as well as play;--yes, I really believe you might,
10665 even without the harp, stipulate for what you chose;--and you must
10666 and shall be delightfully, honourably and comfortably settled before
10667 the Campbells or I have any rest."
10668 
10669 "You may well class the delight, the honour, and the comfort
10670 of such a situation together," said Jane, "they are pretty sure
10671 to be equal; however, I am very serious in not wishing any thing
10672 to be attempted at present for me.  I am exceedingly obliged to you,
10673 Mrs. Elton, I am obliged to any body who feels for me, but I am
10674 quite serious in wishing nothing to be done till the summer.
10675 For two or three months longer I shall remain where I am, and as
10676 I am."
10677 
10678 "And I am quite serious too, I assure you," replied Mrs. Elton gaily,
10679 "in resolving to be always on the watch, and employing my friends
10680 to watch also, that nothing really unexceptionable may pass us."
10681 
10682 In this style she ran on; never thoroughly stopped by any thing
10683 till Mr. Woodhouse came into the room; her vanity had then a change
10684 of object, and Emma heard her saying in the same half-whisper to Jane,
10685 
10686 "Here comes this dear old beau of mine, I protest!--Only think of his
10687 gallantry in coming away before the other men!--what a dear creature
10688 he is;--I assure you I like him excessively.  I admire all that quaint,
10689 old-fashioned politeness; it is much more to my taste than modern ease;
10690 modern ease often disgusts me.  But this good old Mr. Woodhouse,
10691 I wish you had heard his gallant speeches to me at dinner.  Oh!  I assure
10692 you I began to think my caro sposo would be absolutely jealous.
10693 I fancy I am rather a favourite; he took notice of my gown.
10694 How do you like it?--Selina's choice--handsome, I think, but I
10695 do not know whether it is not over-trimmed; I have the greatest
10696 dislike to the idea of being over-trimmed--quite a horror of finery.
10697 I must put on a few ornaments now, because it is expected of me.
10698 A bride, you know, must appear like a bride, but my natural taste
10699 is all for simplicity; a simple style of dress is so infinitely
10700 preferable to finery.  But I am quite in the minority, I believe;
10701 few people seem to value simplicity of dress,--show and finery
10702 are every thing.  I have some notion of putting such a trimming
10703 as this to my white and silver poplin.  Do you think it will
10704 look well?"
10705 
10706 The whole party were but just reassembled in the drawing-room
10707 when Mr. Weston made his appearance among them.  He had returned
10708 to a late dinner, and walked to Hartfield as soon as it was over.
10709 He had been too much expected by the best judges, for surprize--
10710 but there was great joy.  Mr. Woodhouse was almost as glad to see
10711 him now, as he would have been sorry to see him before.  John Knightley
10712 only was in mute astonishment.--That a man who might have spent
10713 his evening quietly at home after a day of business in London,
10714 should set off again, and walk half a mile to another man's house,
10715 for the sake of being in mixed company till bed-time, of finishing
10716 his day in the efforts of civility and the noise of numbers,
10717 was a circumstance to strike him deeply.  A man who had been in motion
10718 since eight o'clock in the morning, and might now have been still,
10719 who had been long talking, and might have been silent, who had been
10720 in more than one crowd, and might have been alone!--Such a man,
10721 to quit the tranquillity and independence of his own fireside,
10722 and on the evening of a cold sleety April day rush out again into
10723 the world!--Could he by a touch of his finger have instantly taken
10724 back his wife, there would have been a motive; but his coming would
10725 probably prolong rather than break up the party.  John Knightley
10726 looked at him with amazement, then shrugged his shoulders, and said,
10727 "I could not have believed it even of _him_."
10728 
10729 Mr. Weston meanwhile, perfectly unsuspicious of the indignation
10730 he was exciting, happy and cheerful as usual, and with all
10731 the right of being principal talker, which a day spent anywhere
10732 from home confers, was making himself agreeable among the rest;
10733 and having satisfied the inquiries of his wife as to his dinner,
10734 convincing her that none of all her careful directions to the servants
10735 had been forgotten, and spread abroad what public news he had heard,
10736 was proceeding to a family communication, which, though principally
10737 addressed to Mrs. Weston, he had not the smallest doubt of being
10738 highly interesting to every body in the room.  He gave her a letter,
10739 it was from Frank, and to herself; he had met with it in his way,
10740 and had taken the liberty of opening it.
10741 
10742 "Read it, read it," said he, "it will give you pleasure;
10743 only a few lines--will not take you long; read it to Emma."
10744 
10745 The two ladies looked over it together; and he sat smiling
10746 and talking to them the whole time, in a voice a little subdued,
10747 but very audible to every body.
10748 
10749 "Well, he is coming, you see; good news, I think.  Well, what do
10750 you say to it?--I always told you he would be here again soon,
10751 did not I?--Anne, my dear, did not I always tell you so, and you would
10752 not believe me?--In town next week, you see--at the latest, I dare say;
10753 for _she_ is as impatient as the black gentleman when any thing is
10754 to be done; most likely they will be there to-morrow or Saturday.
10755 As to her illness, all nothing of course.  But it is an excellent
10756 thing to have Frank among us again, so near as town.  They will stay
10757 a good while when they do come, and he will be half his time with us.
10758 This is precisely what I wanted.  Well, pretty good news, is not it?
10759 Have you finished it?  Has Emma read it all?  Put it up, put it up;
10760 we will have a good talk about it some other time, but it will not
10761 do now.  I shall only just mention the circumstance to the others in a
10762 common way."
10763 
10764 Mrs. Weston was most comfortably pleased on the occasion.
10765 Her looks and words had nothing to restrain them.  She was happy,
10766 she knew she was happy, and knew she ought to be happy.
10767 Her congratulations were warm and open; but Emma could not speak
10768 so fluently.  _She_ was a little occupied in weighing her own feelings,
10769 and trying to understand the degree of her agitation, which she
10770 rather thought was considerable.
10771 
10772 Mr. Weston, however, too eager to be very observant, too communicative
10773 to want others to talk, was very well satisfied with what she did say,
10774 and soon moved away to make the rest of his friends happy by a partial
10775 communication of what the whole room must have overheard already.
10776 
10777 It was well that he took every body's joy for granted, or he
10778 might not have thought either Mr. Woodhouse or Mr. Knightley
10779 particularly delighted.  They were the first entitled,
10780 after Mrs. Weston and Emma, to be made happy;--from them he would
10781 have proceeded to Miss Fairfax, but she was so deep in conversation
10782 with John Knightley, that it would have been too positive
10783 an interruption; and finding himself close to Mrs. Elton, and
10784 her attention disengaged, he necessarily began on the subject with her.
10785 
10786 
10787 
10788 CHAPTER XVIII
10789 
10790 
10791 "I hope I shall soon have the pleasure of introducing my son to you,"
10792 said Mr. Weston.
10793 
10794 Mrs. Elton, very willing to suppose a particular compliment intended
10795 her by such a hope, smiled most graciously.
10796 
10797 "You have heard of a certain Frank Churchill, I presume," he continued--
10798 "and know him to be my son, though he does not bear my name."
10799 
10800 "Oh! yes, and I shall be very happy in his acquaintance.
10801 I am sure Mr. Elton will lose no time in calling on him; and we
10802 shall both have great pleasure in seeing him at the Vicarage."
10803 
10804 "You are very obliging.--Frank will be extremely happy, I am sure.--
10805 He is to be in town next week, if not sooner.  We have notice of it
10806 in a letter to-day. I met the letters in my way this morning,
10807 and seeing my son's hand, presumed to open it--though it was not directed
10808 to me--it was to Mrs. Weston.  She is his principal correspondent,
10809 I assure you.  I hardly ever get a letter."
10810 
10811 "And so you absolutely opened what was directed to her!  Oh!  Mr. Weston--
10812 (laughing affectedly) I must protest against that.--A most dangerous
10813 precedent indeed!--I beg you will not let your neighbours follow
10814 your example.--Upon my word, if this is what I am to expect,
10815 we married women must begin to exert ourselves!--Oh!  Mr. Weston,
10816 I could not have believed it of you!"
10817 
10818 "Aye, we men are sad fellows.  You must take care of yourself,
10819 Mrs. Elton.--This letter tells us--it is a short letter--written in
10820 a hurry, merely to give us notice--it tells us that they are all
10821 coming up to town directly, on Mrs. Churchill's account--she has
10822 not been well the whole winter, and thinks Enscombe too cold for her--
10823 so they are all to move southward without loss of time."
10824 
10825 "Indeed!--from Yorkshire, I think.  Enscombe is in Yorkshire?"
10826 
10827 "Yes, they are about one hundred and ninety miles from London.
10828 a considerable journey."
10829 
10830 "Yes, upon my word, very considerable.  Sixty-five miles farther
10831 than from Maple Grove to London.  But what is distance, Mr. Weston,
10832 to people of large fortune?--You would be amazed to hear how my brother,
10833 Mr. Suckling, sometimes flies about.  You will hardly believe me--
10834 but twice in one week he and Mr. Bragge went to London and back again
10835 with four horses."
10836 
10837 "The evil of the distance from Enscombe," said Mr. Weston, "is, that
10838 Mrs. Churchill, _as_ _we_ _understand_, has not been able to leave the
10839 sofa for a week together.  In Frank's last letter she complained,
10840 he said, of being too weak to get into her conservatory without having
10841 both his arm and his uncle's! This, you know, speaks a great degree
10842 of weakness--but now she is so impatient to be in town, that she
10843 means to sleep only two nights on the road.--So Frank writes word.
10844 Certainly, delicate ladies have very extraordinary constitutions,
10845 Mrs. Elton.  You must grant me that."
10846 
10847 "No, indeed, I shall grant you nothing.  I Always take the part
10848 of my own sex.  I do indeed.  I give you notice--You will find me
10849 a formidable antagonist on that point.  I always stand up for women--
10850 and I assure you, if you knew how Selina feels with respect
10851 to sleeping at an inn, you would not wonder at Mrs. Churchill's
10852 making incredible exertions to avoid it.  Selina says it is quite
10853 horror to her--and I believe I have caught a little of her nicety.
10854 She always travels with her own sheets; an excellent precaution.
10855 Does Mrs. Churchill do the same?"
10856 
10857 "Depend upon it, Mrs. Churchill does every thing that any other
10858 fine lady ever did.  Mrs. Churchill will not be second to any lady
10859 in the land for"--
10860 
10861 Mrs. Elton eagerly interposed with,
10862 
10863 "Oh!  Mr. Weston, do not mistake me.  Selina is no fine lady,
10864 I assure you.  Do not run away with such an idea."
10865 
10866 "Is not she?  Then she is no rule for Mrs. Churchill, who is
10867 as thorough a fine lady as any body ever beheld."
10868 
10869 Mrs. Elton began to think she had been wrong in disclaiming so warmly.
10870 It was by no means her object to have it believed that her sister
10871 was _not_ a fine lady; perhaps there was want of spirit in the pretence
10872 of it;--and she was considering in what way she had best retract,
10873 when Mr. Weston went on.
10874 
10875 "Mrs. Churchill is not much in my good graces, as you may suspect--
10876 but this is quite between ourselves.  She is very fond of Frank,
10877 and therefore I would not speak ill of her.  Besides, she is out of
10878 health now; but _that_ indeed, by her own account, she has always been.
10879 I would not say so to every body, Mrs. Elton, but I have not much
10880 faith in Mrs. Churchill's illness."
10881 
10882 "If she is really ill, why not go to Bath, Mr. Weston?--To Bath,
10883 or to Clifton?"  "She has taken it into her head that Enscombe is too
10884 cold for her.  The fact is, I suppose, that she is tired of Enscombe.
10885 She has now been a longer time stationary there, than she ever
10886 was before, and she begins to want change.  It is a retired place.
10887 A fine place, but very retired."
10888 
10889 "Aye--like Maple Grove, I dare say.  Nothing can stand more retired from
10890 the road than Maple Grove.  Such an immense plantation all round it!
10891 You seem shut out from every thing--in the most complete retirement.--
10892 And Mrs. Churchill probably has not health or spirits like Selina
10893 to enjoy that sort of seclusion.  Or, perhaps she may not have
10894 resources enough in herself to be qualified for a country life.
10895 I always say a woman cannot have too many resources--and I feel
10896 very thankful that I have so many myself as to be quite independent
10897 of society."
10898 
10899 "Frank was here in February for a fortnight."
10900 
10901 "So I remember to have heard.  He will find an _addition_ to the
10902 society of Highbury when he comes again; that is, if I may presume
10903 to call myself an addition.  But perhaps he may never have heard
10904 of there being such a creature in the world."
10905 
10906 This was too loud a call for a compliment to be passed by,
10907 and Mr. Weston, with a very good grace, immediately exclaimed,
10908 
10909 "My dear madam!  Nobody but yourself could imagine such a
10910 thing possible.  Not heard of you!--I believe Mrs. Weston's
10911 letters lately have been full of very little else than Mrs. Elton."
10912 
10913 He had done his duty and could return to his son.
10914 
10915 "When Frank left us," continued he, "it was quite uncertain when we
10916 might see him again, which makes this day's news doubly welcome.
10917 It has been completely unexpected.  That is, _I_ always had a strong
10918 persuasion he would be here again soon, I was sure something
10919 favourable would turn up--but nobody believed me.  He and Mrs. Weston
10920 were both dreadfully desponding.  `How could he contrive to come?
10921 And how could it be supposed that his uncle and aunt would spare
10922 him again?' and so forth--I always felt that something would happen
10923 in our favour; and so it has, you see.  I have observed, Mrs. Elton,
10924 in the course of my life, that if things are going untowardly one month,
10925 they are sure to mend the next."
10926 
10927 "Very true, Mr. Weston, perfectly true.  It is just what I used
10928 to say to a certain gentleman in company in the days of courtship,
10929 when, because things did not go quite right, did not proceed with all
10930 the rapidity which suited his feelings, he was apt to be in despair,
10931 and exclaim that he was sure at this rate it would be _May_ before
10932 Hymen's saffron robe would be put on for us.  Oh! the pains I have
10933 been at to dispel those gloomy ideas and give him cheerfuller views!
10934 The carriage--we had disappointments about the carriage;--one morning,
10935 I remember, he came to me quite in despair."
10936 
10937 She was stopped by a slight fit of coughing, and Mr. Weston instantly
10938 seized the opportunity of going on.
10939 
10940 "You were mentioning May.  May is the very month which Mrs. Churchill
10941 is ordered, or has ordered herself, to spend in some warmer place
10942 than Enscombe--in short, to spend in London; so that we have the
10943 agreeable prospect of frequent visits from Frank the whole spring--
10944 precisely the season of the year which one should have chosen
10945 for it:  days almost at the longest; weather genial and pleasant,
10946 always inviting one out, and never too hot for exercise.  When he
10947 was here before, we made the best of it; but there was a good deal
10948 of wet, damp, cheerless weather; there always is in February, you know,
10949 and we could not do half that we intended.  Now will be the time.
10950 This will be complete enjoyment; and I do not know, Mrs. Elton,
10951 whether the uncertainty of our meetings, the sort of constant
10952 expectation there will be of his coming in to-day or to-morrow,
10953 and at any hour, may not be more friendly to happiness than having
10954 him actually in the house.  I think it is so.  I think it is the
10955 state of mind which gives most spirit and delight.  I hope you
10956 will be pleased with my son; but you must not expect a prodigy.
10957 He is generally thought a fine young man, but do not expect a prodigy.
10958 Mrs. Weston's partiality for him is very great, and, as you may suppose,
10959 most gratifying to me.  She thinks nobody equal to him."
10960 
10961 "And I assure you, Mr. Weston, I have very little doubt that my
10962 opinion will be decidedly in his favour.  I have heard so much
10963 in praise of Mr. Frank Churchill.--At the same time it is fair
10964 to observe, that I am one of those who always judge for themselves,
10965 and are by no means implicitly guided by others.  I give you notice
10966 that as I find your son, so I shall judge of him.--I am no flatterer."
10967 
10968 Mr. Weston was musing.
10969 
10970 "I hope," said he presently, "I have not been severe upon poor
10971 Mrs. Churchill.  If she is ill I should be sorry to do her injustice;
10972 but there are some traits in her character which make it difficult
10973 for me to speak of her with the forbearance I could wish.
10974 You cannot be ignorant, Mrs. Elton, of my connexion with the family,
10975 nor of the treatment I have met with; and, between ourselves,
10976 the whole blame of it is to be laid to her.  She was the instigator.
10977 Frank's mother would never have been slighted as she was but for her.
10978 Mr. Churchill has pride; but his pride is nothing to his wife's:
10979 his is a quiet, indolent, gentlemanlike sort of pride that would
10980 harm nobody, and only make himself a little helpless and tiresome;
10981 but her pride is arrogance and insolence!  And what inclines one less
10982 to bear, she has no fair pretence of family or blood.  She was nobody
10983 when he married her, barely the daughter of a gentleman; but ever
10984 since her being turned into a Churchill she has out-Churchill'd them
10985 all in high and mighty claims:  but in herself, I assure you, she is
10986 an upstart."
10987 
10988 "Only think! well, that must be infinitely provoking!  I have quite
10989 a horror of upstarts.  Maple Grove has given me a thorough disgust
10990 to people of that sort; for there is a family in that neighbourhood
10991 who are such an annoyance to my brother and sister from the airs
10992 they give themselves!  Your description of Mrs. Churchill made me
10993 think of them directly.  People of the name of Tupman, very lately
10994 settled there, and encumbered with many low connexions, but giving
10995 themselves immense airs, and expecting to be on a footing with the old
10996 established families.  A year and a half is the very utmost that they can
10997 have lived at West Hall; and how they got their fortune nobody knows.
10998 They came from Birmingham, which is not a place to promise much,
10999 you know, Mr. Weston.  One has not great hopes from Birmingham.
11000 I always say there is something direful in the sound:  but nothing
11001 more is positively known of the Tupmans, though a good many things
11002 I assure you are suspected; and yet by their manners they evidently
11003 think themselves equal even to my brother, Mr. Suckling, who happens
11004 to be one of their nearest neighbours.  It is infinitely too bad.
11005 Mr. Suckling, who has been eleven years a resident at Maple Grove,
11006 and whose father had it before him--I believe, at least--I am
11007 almost sure that old Mr. Suckling had completed the purchase before
11008 his death."
11009 
11010 They were interrupted.  Tea was carrying round, and Mr. Weston,
11011 having said all that he wanted, soon took the opportunity of
11012 walking away.
11013 
11014 After tea, Mr. and Mrs. Weston, and Mr. Elton sat down with Mr. Woodhouse
11015 to cards.  The remaining five were left to their own powers,
11016 and Emma doubted their getting on very well; for Mr. Knightley seemed
11017 little disposed for conversation; Mrs. Elton was wanting notice,
11018 which nobody had inclination to pay, and she was herself
11019 in a worry of spirits which would have made her prefer being silent.
11020 
11021 Mr. John Knightley proved more talkative than his brother.
11022 He was to leave them early the next day; and he soon began with--
11023 
11024 "Well, Emma, I do not believe I have any thing more to say about
11025 the boys; but you have your sister's letter, and every thing is
11026 down at full length there we may be sure.  My charge would be much
11027 more concise than her's, and probably not much in the same spirit;
11028 all that I have to recommend being comprised in, do not spoil them,
11029 and do not physic them."
11030 
11031 "I rather hope to satisfy you both," said Emma, "for I shall do all
11032 in my power to make them happy, which will be enough for Isabella;
11033 and happiness must preclude false indulgence and physic."
11034 
11035 "And if you find them troublesome, you must send them home again."
11036 
11037 "That is very likely.  You think so, do not you?"
11038 
11039 "I hope I am aware that they may be too noisy for your father--
11040 or even may be some encumbrance to you, if your visiting engagements
11041 continue to increase as much as they have done lately."
11042 
11043 "Increase!"
11044 
11045 "Certainly; you must be sensible that the last half-year has made
11046 a great difference in your way of life."
11047 
11048 "Difference!  No indeed I am not."
11049 
11050 "There can be no doubt of your being much more engaged with company
11051 than you used to be.  Witness this very time.  Here am I come
11052 down for only one day, and you are engaged with a dinner-party!--
11053 When did it happen before, or any thing like it?  Your neighbourhood
11054 is increasing, and you mix more with it.  A little while ago,
11055 every letter to Isabella brought an account of fresh gaieties;
11056 dinners at Mr. Cole's, or balls at the Crown.  The difference
11057 which Randalls, Randalls alone makes in your goings-on, is very great."
11058 
11059 "Yes," said his brother quickly, "it is Randalls that does it all."
11060 
11061 "Very well--and as Randalls, I suppose, is not likely to have less
11062 influence than heretofore, it strikes me as a possible thing, Emma,
11063 that Henry and John may be sometimes in the way.  And if they are,
11064 I only beg you to send them home."
11065 
11066 "No," cried Mr. Knightley, "that need not be the consequence.
11067 Let them be sent to Donwell.  I shall certainly be at leisure."
11068 
11069 "Upon my word," exclaimed Emma, "you amuse me!  I should like to know
11070 how many of all my numerous engagements take place without your being
11071 of the party; and why I am to be supposed in danger of wanting leisure
11072 to attend to the little boys.  These amazing engagements of mine--
11073 what have they been?  Dining once with the Coles--and having a ball
11074 talked of, which never took place.  I can understand you--(nodding at
11075 Mr. John Knightley)--your good fortune in meeting with so many of
11076 your friends at once here, delights you too much to pass unnoticed.
11077 But you, (turning to Mr. Knightley,) who know how very, very seldom
11078 I am ever two hours from Hartfield, why you should foresee such a
11079 series of dissipation for me, I cannot imagine.  And as to my dear
11080 little boys, I must say, that if Aunt Emma has not time for them,
11081 I do not think they would fare much better with Uncle Knightley,
11082 who is absent from home about five hours where she is absent one--
11083 and who, when he is at home, is either reading to himself or settling
11084 his accounts."
11085 
11086 Mr. Knightley seemed to be trying not to smile; and succeeded
11087 without difficulty, upon Mrs. Elton's beginning to talk to him.
11088 
11089 
11090 
11091 
11092 VOLUME III
11093 
11094 
11095 
11096 CHAPTER I
11097 
11098 
11099 A very little quiet reflection was enough to satisfy Emma as to the
11100 nature of her agitation on hearing this news of Frank Churchill.
11101 She was soon convinced that it was not for herself she was feeling at
11102 all apprehensive or embarrassed; it was for him.  Her own attachment
11103 had really subsided into a mere nothing; it was not worth thinking of;--
11104 but if he, who had undoubtedly been always so much the most in love
11105 of the two, were to be returning with the same warmth of sentiment
11106 which he had taken away, it would be very distressing.  If a separation
11107 of two months should not have cooled him, there were dangers and evils
11108 before her:--caution for him and for herself would be necessary.
11109 She did not mean to have her own affections entangled again,
11110 and it would be incumbent on her to avoid any encouragement of his.
11111 
11112 She wished she might be able to keep him from an absolute declaration.
11113 That would be so very painful a conclusion of their present acquaintance!
11114 and yet, she could not help rather anticipating something decisive.
11115 She felt as if the spring would not pass without bringing a crisis,
11116 an event, a something to alter her present composed and tranquil state.
11117 
11118 It was not very long, though rather longer than Mr. Weston had foreseen,
11119 before she had the power of forming some opinion of Frank Churchill's
11120 feelings.  The Enscombe family were not in town quite so soon as had
11121 been imagined, but he was at Highbury very soon afterwards.  He rode
11122 down for a couple of hours; he could not yet do more; but as he came
11123 from Randalls immediately to Hartfield, she could then exercise all
11124 her quick observation, and speedily determine how he was influenced,
11125 and how she must act.  They met with the utmost friendliness.
11126 There could be no doubt of his great pleasure in seeing her.
11127 But she had an almost instant doubt of his caring for her as he
11128 had done, of his feeling the same tenderness in the same degree.
11129 She watched him well.  It was a clear thing he was less in love than he
11130 had been.  Absence, with the conviction probably of her indifference,
11131 had produced this very natural and very desirable effect.
11132 
11133 He was in high spirits; as ready to talk and laugh as ever, and seemed
11134 delighted to speak of his former visit, and recur to old stories:
11135 and he was not without agitation.  It was not in his calmness that
11136 she read his comparative difference.  He was not calm; his spirits
11137 were evidently fluttered; there was restlessness about him.
11138 Lively as he was, it seemed a liveliness that did not satisfy himself;
11139 but what decided her belief on the subject, was his staying only a
11140 quarter of an hour, and hurrying away to make other calls in Highbury.
11141 "He had seen a group of old acquaintance in the street as he passed--
11142 he had not stopped, he would not stop for more than a word--but he
11143 had the vanity to think they would be disappointed if he did not call,
11144 and much as he wished to stay longer at Hartfield, he must hurry off."
11145 She had no doubt as to his being less in love--but neither his
11146 agitated spirits, nor his hurrying away, seemed like a perfect cure;
11147 and she was rather inclined to think it implied a dread of her
11148 returning power, and a discreet resolution of not trusting himself
11149 with her long.
11150 
11151 This was the only visit from Frank Churchill in the course of ten days.
11152 He was often hoping, intending to come--but was always prevented.
11153 His aunt could not bear to have him leave her.  Such was his own account
11154 at Randall's. If he were quite sincere, if he really tried to come,
11155 it was to be inferred that Mrs. Churchill's removal to London had
11156 been of no service to the wilful or nervous part of her disorder.
11157 That she was really ill was very certain; he had declared himself
11158 convinced of it, at Randalls.  Though much might be fancy, he could
11159 not doubt, when he looked back, that she was in a weaker state
11160 of health than she had been half a year ago.  He did not believe it
11161 to proceed from any thing that care and medicine might not remove,
11162 or at least that she might not have many years of existence before her;
11163 but he could not be prevailed on, by all his father's doubts, to say
11164 that her complaints were merely imaginary, or that she was as strong
11165 as ever.
11166 
11167 It soon appeared that London was not the place for her.  She could
11168 not endure its noise.  Her nerves were under continual irritation
11169 and suffering; and by the ten days' end, her nephew's letter to
11170 Randalls communicated a change of plan.  They were going to remove
11171 immediately to Richmond.  Mrs. Churchill had been recommended
11172 to the medical skill of an eminent person there, and had otherwise
11173 a fancy for the place.  A ready-furnished house in a favourite
11174 spot was engaged, and much benefit expected from the change.
11175 
11176 Emma heard that Frank wrote in the highest spirits of this arrangement,
11177 and seemed most fully to appreciate the blessing of having two
11178 months before him of such near neighbourhood to many dear friends--
11179 for the house was taken for May and June.  She was told that now
11180 he wrote with the greatest confidence of being often with them,
11181 almost as often as he could even wish.
11182 
11183 Emma saw how Mr. Weston understood these joyous prospects.  He was
11184 considering her as the source of all the happiness they offered.
11185 She hoped it was not so.  Two months must bring it to the proof.
11186 
11187 Mr. Weston's own happiness was indisputable.  He was quite delighted.
11188 It was the very circumstance he could have wished for.  Now, it would
11189 be really having Frank in their neighbourhood.  What were nine miles
11190 to a young man?--An hour's ride.  He would be always coming over.
11191 The difference in that respect of Richmond and London was enough
11192 to make the whole difference of seeing him always and seeing
11193 him never.  Sixteen miles--nay, eighteen--it must be full eighteen
11194 to Manchester-street--was a serious obstacle.  Were he ever able
11195 to get away, the day would be spent in coming and returning.
11196 There was no comfort in having him in London; he might as well be
11197 at Enscombe; but Richmond was the very distance for easy intercourse.
11198 Better than nearer!
11199 
11200 One good thing was immediately brought to a certainty by this removal,--
11201 the ball at the Crown.  It had not been forgotten before, but it had
11202 been soon acknowledged vain to attempt to fix a day.  Now, however,
11203 it was absolutely to be; every preparation was resumed, and very soon
11204 after the Churchills had removed to Richmond, a few lines from Frank,
11205 to say that his aunt felt already much better for the change,
11206 and that he had no doubt of being able to join them for twenty-four
11207 hours at any given time, induced them to name as early a day as possible.
11208 
11209 Mr. Weston's ball was to be a real thing.  A very few to-morrows
11210 stood between the young people of Highbury and happiness.
11211 
11212 Mr. Woodhouse was resigned.  The time of year lightened the evil
11213 to him.  May was better for every thing than February.  Mrs. Bates
11214 was engaged to spend the evening at Hartfield, James had due notice,
11215 and he sanguinely hoped that neither dear little Henry nor dear
11216 little John would have any thing the matter with them, while dear
11217 Emma were gone.
11218 
11219 
11220 
11221 CHAPTER II
11222 
11223 
11224 No misfortune occurred, again to prevent the ball.  The day approached,
11225 the day arrived; and after a morning of some anxious watching,
11226 Frank Churchill, in all the certainty of his own self, reached Randalls
11227 before dinner, and every thing was safe.
11228 
11229 No second meeting had there yet been between him and Emma.
11230 The room at the Crown was to witness it;--but it would be better
11231 than a common meeting in a crowd.  Mr. Weston had been so very
11232 earnest in his entreaties for her arriving there as soon as possible
11233 after themselves, for the purpose of taking her opinion as to the
11234 propriety and comfort of the rooms before any other persons came,
11235 that she could not refuse him, and must therefore spend some quiet
11236 interval in the young man's company.  She was to convey Harriet,
11237 and they drove to the Crown in good time, the Randalls party just
11238 sufficiently before them.
11239 
11240 Frank Churchill seemed to have been on the watch; and though
11241 he did not say much, his eyes declared that he meant to have
11242 a delightful evening.  They all walked about together, to see
11243 that every thing was as it should be; and within a few minutes
11244 were joined by the contents of another carriage, which Emma
11245 could not hear the sound of at first, without great surprize.
11246 "So unreasonably early!" she was going to exclaim; but she presently
11247 found that it was a family of old friends, who were coming, like herself,
11248 by particular desire, to help Mr. Weston's judgment; and they were
11249 so very closely followed by another carriage of cousins, who had been
11250 entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness,
11251 on the same errand, that it seemed as if half the company might
11252 soon be collected together for the purpose of preparatory inspection.
11253 
11254 Emma perceived that her taste was not the only taste on which
11255 Mr. Weston depended, and felt, that to be the favourite and
11256 intimate of a man who had so many intimates and confidantes,
11257 was not the very first distinction in the scale of vanity.
11258 She liked his open manners, but a little less of open-heartedness
11259 would have made him a higher character.--General benevolence,
11260 but not general friendship, made a man what he ought to be.--
11261 She could fancy such a man.  The whole party walked about,
11262 and looked, and praised again; and then, having nothing else to do,
11263 formed a sort of half-circle round the fire, to observe in their
11264 various modes, till other subjects were started, that, though _May_,
11265 a fire in the evening was still very pleasant.
11266 
11267 Emma found that it was not Mr. Weston's fault that the number
11268 of privy councillors was not yet larger.  They had stopped
11269 at Mrs. Bates's door to offer the use of their carriage,
11270 but the aunt and niece were to be brought by the Eltons.
11271 
11272 Frank was standing by her, but not steadily; there was a restlessness,
11273 which shewed a mind not at ease.  He was looking about, he was going
11274 to the door, he was watching for the sound of other carriages,--
11275 impatient to begin, or afraid of being always near her.
11276 
11277 Mrs. Elton was spoken of.  "I think she must be here soon," said he.
11278 "I have a great curiosity to see Mrs. Elton, I have heard so much
11279 of her.  It cannot be long, I think, before she comes."
11280 
11281 A carriage was heard.  He was on the move immediately;
11282 but coming back, said,
11283 
11284 "I am forgetting that I am not acquainted with her.  I have never seen
11285 either Mr. or Mrs. Elton.  I have no business to put myself forward."
11286 
11287 Mr. and Mrs. Elton appeared; and all the smiles and the proprieties passed.
11288 
11289 "But Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax!" said Mr. Weston, looking about.
11290 "We thought you were to bring them."
11291 
11292 The mistake had been slight.  The carriage was sent for them now.
11293 Emma longed to know what Frank's first opinion of Mrs. Elton
11294 might be; how he was affected by the studied elegance of her dress,
11295 and her smiles of graciousness.  He was immediately qualifying
11296 himself to form an opinion, by giving her very proper attention,
11297 after the introduction had passed.
11298 
11299 In a few minutes the carriage returned.--Somebody talked of rain.--
11300 "I will see that there are umbrellas, sir," said Frank to his father:
11301 "Miss Bates must not be forgotten:"  and away he went.  Mr. Weston
11302 was following; but Mrs. Elton detained him, to gratify him by her
11303 opinion of his son; and so briskly did she begin, that the young
11304 man himself, though by no means moving slowly, could hardly be out
11305 of hearing.
11306 
11307 "A very fine young man indeed, Mr. Weston.  You know I candidly told
11308 you I should form my own opinion; and I am happy to say that I am
11309 extremely pleased with him.--You may believe me.  I never compliment.
11310 I think him a very handsome young man, and his manners are precisely
11311 what I like and approve--so truly the gentleman, without the least
11312 conceit or puppyism.  You must know I have a vast dislike to puppies--
11313 quite a horror of them.  They were never tolerated at Maple Grove.
11314 Neither Mr. Suckling nor me had ever any patience with them; and we
11315 used sometimes to say very cutting things!  Selina, who is mild almost
11316 to a fault, bore with them much better."
11317 
11318 While she talked of his son, Mr. Weston's attention was chained;
11319 but when she got to Maple Grove, he could recollect that there were
11320 ladies just arriving to be attended to, and with happy smiles must
11321 hurry away.
11322 
11323 Mrs. Elton turned to Mrs. Weston.  "I have no doubt of its being
11324 our carriage with Miss Bates and Jane.  Our coachman and horses are
11325 so extremely expeditious!--I believe we drive faster than any body.--
11326 What a pleasure it is to send one's carriage for a friend!--
11327 I understand you were so kind as to offer, but another time it
11328 will be quite unnecessary.  You may be very sure I shall always
11329 take care of _them_."
11330 
11331 Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax, escorted by the two gentlemen,
11332 walked into the room; and Mrs. Elton seemed to think it as much
11333 her duty as Mrs. Weston's to receive them.  Her gestures and
11334 movements might be understood by any one who looked on like Emma;
11335 but her words, every body's words, were soon lost under the
11336 incessant flow of Miss Bates, who came in talking, and had not
11337 finished her speech under many minutes after her being admitted
11338 into the circle at the fire.  As the door opened she was heard,
11339 
11340 "So very obliging of you!--No rain at all.  Nothing to signify.
11341 I do not care for myself.  Quite thick shoes.  And Jane declares--
11342 Well!--(as soon as she was within the door) Well!  This is brilliant
