11343 indeed!--This is admirable!--Excellently contrived, upon my word.
11344 Nothing wanting.  Could not have imagined it.--So well lighted up!--
11345 Jane, Jane, look!--did you ever see any thing?  Oh!  Mr. Weston,
11346 you must really have had Aladdin's lamp.  Good Mrs. Stokes
11347 would not know her own room again.  I saw her as I came in;
11348 she was standing in the entrance.  `Oh!  Mrs. Stokes,' said I--
11349 but I had not time for more."  She was now met by Mrs. Weston.--
11350 "Very well, I thank you, ma'am. I hope you are quite well.
11351 Very happy to hear it.  So afraid you might have a headache!--
11352 seeing you pass by so often, and knowing how much trouble you must have.
11353 Delighted to hear it indeed.  Ah! dear Mrs. Elton, so obliged
11354 to you for the carriage!--excellent time.  Jane and I quite ready.
11355 Did not keep the horses a moment.  Most comfortable carriage.--
11356 Oh! and I am sure our thanks are due to you, Mrs. Weston, on that score.
11357 Mrs. Elton had most kindly sent Jane a note, or we should have been.--
11358 But two such offers in one day!--Never were such neighbours.
11359 I said to my mother, `Upon my word, ma'am--.'  Thank you, my mother
11360 is remarkably well.  Gone to Mr. Woodhouse's. I made her take
11361 her shawl--for the evenings are not warm--her large new shawl--
11362 Mrs. Dixon's wedding-present.--So kind of her to think of my mother!
11363 Bought at Weymouth, you know--Mr. Dixon's choice.  There were
11364 three others, Jane says, which they hesitated about some time.
11365 Colonel Campbell rather preferred an olive.  My dear Jane,
11366 are you sure you did not wet your feet?--It was but a drop or two,
11367 but I am so afraid:--but Mr. Frank Churchill was so extremely--
11368 and there was a mat to step upon--I shall never forget his
11369 extreme politeness.--Oh!  Mr. Frank Churchill, I must tell you
11370 my mother's spectacles have never been in fault since; the rivet
11371 never came out again.  My mother often talks of your good-nature.
11372 Does not she, Jane?--Do not we often talk of Mr. Frank Churchill?--
11373 Ah! here's Miss Woodhouse.--Dear Miss Woodhouse, how do you do?--
11374 Very well I thank you, quite well.  This is meeting quite in fairy-land!--
11375 Such a transformation!--Must not compliment, I know (eyeing Emma
11376 most complacently)--that would be rude--but upon my word, Miss Woodhouse,
11377 you do look--how do you like Jane's hair?--You are a judge.--
11378 She did it all herself.  Quite wonderful how she does her hair!--
11379 No hairdresser from London I think could.--Ah! Dr. Hughes I declare--
11380 and Mrs. Hughes.  Must go and speak to Dr. and Mrs. Hughes for
11381 a moment.--How do you do?  How do you do?--Very well, I thank you.
11382 This is delightful, is not it?--Where's dear Mr. Richard?--
11383 Oh! there he is.  Don't disturb him.  Much better employed talking
11384 to the young ladies.  How do you do, Mr. Richard?--I saw you the
11385 other day as you rode through the town--Mrs. Otway, I protest!--
11386 and good Mr. Otway, and Miss Otway and Miss Caroline.--Such a host
11387 of friends!--and Mr. George and Mr. Arthur!--How do you do?  How do
11388 you all do?--Quite well, I am much obliged to you.  Never better.--
11389 Don't I hear another carriage?--Who can this be?--very likely the
11390 worthy Coles.--Upon my word, this is charming to be standing about
11391 among such friends!  And such a noble fire!--I am quite roasted.
11392 No coffee, I thank you, for me--never take coffee.--A little tea
11393 if you please, sir, by and bye,--no hurry--Oh! here it comes.
11394 Every thing so good!"
11395 
11396 Frank Churchill returned to his station by Emma; and as soon as Miss
11397 Bates was quiet, she found herself necessarily overhearing the
11398 discourse of Mrs. Elton and Miss Fairfax, who were standing a little
11399 way behind her.--He was thoughtful.  Whether he were overhearing too,
11400 she could not determine.  After a good many compliments to Jane
11401 on her dress and look, compliments very quietly and properly taken,
11402 Mrs. Elton was evidently wanting to be complimented herself--
11403 and it was, "How do you like my gown?--How do you like my trimming?--
11404 How has Wright done my hair?"--with many other relative questions,
11405 all answered with patient politeness.  Mrs. Elton then said,
11406 "Nobody can think less of dress in general than I do--but upon such
11407 an occasion as this, when every body's eyes are so much upon me,
11408 and in compliment to the Westons--who I have no doubt are giving
11409 this ball chiefly to do me honour--I would not wish to be inferior
11410 to others.  And I see very few pearls in the room except mine.--
11411 So Frank Churchill is a capital dancer, I understand.--We shall see
11412 if our styles suit.--A fine young man certainly is Frank Churchill.
11413 I like him very well."
11414 
11415 At this moment Frank began talking so vigorously, that Emma could
11416 not but imagine he had overheard his own praises, and did not want
11417 to hear more;--and the voices of the ladies were drowned for a while,
11418 till another suspension brought Mrs. Elton's tones again distinctly
11419 forward.--Mr. Elton had just joined them, and his wife was exclaiming,
11420 
11421 "Oh! you have found us out at last, have you, in our seclusion?--
11422 I was this moment telling Jane, I thought you would begin to be
11423 impatient for tidings of us."
11424 
11425 "Jane!"--repeated Frank Churchill, with a look of surprize and displeasure.--
11426 "That is easy--but Miss Fairfax does not disapprove it, I suppose."
11427 
11428 "How do you like Mrs. Elton?" said Emma in a whisper.
11429 
11430 "Not at all."
11431 
11432 "You are ungrateful."
11433 
11434 "Ungrateful!--What do you mean?"  Then changing from a frown to
11435 a smile--"No, do not tell me--I do not want to know what you mean.--
11436 Where is my father?--When are we to begin dancing?"
11437 
11438 Emma could hardly understand him; he seemed in an odd humour.
11439 He walked off to find his father, but was quickly back again with both
11440 Mr. and Mrs. Weston.  He had met with them in a little perplexity,
11441 which must be laid before Emma.  It had just occurred to Mrs. Weston
11442 that Mrs. Elton must be asked to begin the ball; that she would
11443 expect it; which interfered with all their wishes of giving Emma
11444 that distinction.--Emma heard the sad truth with fortitude.
11445 
11446 "And what are we to do for a proper partner for her?" said Mr. Weston.
11447 "She will think Frank ought to ask her."
11448 
11449 Frank turned instantly to Emma, to claim her former promise;
11450 and boasted himself an engaged man, which his father looked his most
11451 perfect approbation of--and it then appeared that Mrs. Weston was
11452 wanting _him_ to dance with Mrs. Elton himself, and that their business
11453 was to help to persuade him into it, which was done pretty soon.--
11454 Mr. Weston and Mrs. Elton led the way, Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss
11455 Woodhouse followed.  Emma must submit to stand second to Mrs. Elton,
11456 though she had always considered the ball as peculiarly for her.
11457 It was almost enough to make her think of marrying.  Mrs. Elton had
11458 undoubtedly the advantage, at this time, in vanity completely gratified;
11459 for though she had intended to begin with Frank Churchill, she could
11460 not lose by the change.  Mr. Weston might be his son's superior.--
11461 In spite of this little rub, however, Emma was smiling with enjoyment,
11462 delighted to see the respectable length of the set as it was forming,
11463 and to feel that she had so many hours of unusual festivity before her.--
11464 She was more disturbed by Mr. Knightley's not dancing than by any
11465 thing else.--There he was, among the standers-by, where he ought not
11466 to be; he ought to be dancing,--not classing himself with the husbands,
11467 and fathers, and whist-players, who were pretending to feel an interest
11468 in the dance till their rubbers were made up,--so young as he looked!--
11469 He could not have appeared to greater advantage perhaps anywhere,
11470 than where he had placed himself.  His tall, firm, upright figure,
11471 among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of the elderly men,
11472 was such as Emma felt must draw every body's eyes; and, excepting her
11473 own partner, there was not one among the whole row of young men
11474 who could be compared with him.--He moved a few steps nearer,
11475 and those few steps were enough to prove in how gentlemanlike
11476 a manner, with what natural grace, he must have danced, would he
11477 but take the trouble.--Whenever she caught his eye, she forced him
11478 to smile; but in general he was looking grave.  She wished he could
11479 love a ballroom better, and could like Frank Churchill better.--
11480 He seemed often observing her.  She must not flatter herself that he
11481 thought of her dancing, but if he were criticising her behaviour,
11482 she did not feel afraid.  There was nothing like flirtation between
11483 her and her partner.  They seemed more like cheerful, easy friends,
11484 than lovers.  That Frank Churchill thought less of her than he had done,
11485 was indubitable.
11486 
11487 The ball proceeded pleasantly.  The anxious cares, the incessant
11488 attentions of Mrs. Weston, were not thrown away.  Every body
11489 seemed happy; and the praise of being a delightful ball,
11490 which is seldom bestowed till after a ball has ceased to be,
11491 was repeatedly given in the very beginning of the existence of this.
11492 Of very important, very recordable events, it was not more productive
11493 than such meetings usually are.  There was one, however, which Emma
11494 thought something of.--The two last dances before supper were begun,
11495 and Harriet had no partner;--the only young lady sitting down;--
11496 and so equal had been hitherto the number of dancers, that how there
11497 could be any one disengaged was the wonder!--But Emma's wonder
11498 lessened soon afterwards, on seeing Mr. Elton sauntering about.
11499 He would not ask Harriet to dance if it were possible to be avoided:
11500 she was sure he would not--and she was expecting him every moment to
11501 escape into the card-room.
11502 
11503 Escape, however, was not his plan.  He came to the part of the room
11504 where the sitters-by were collected, spoke to some, and walked about
11505 in front of them, as if to shew his liberty, and his resolution
11506 of maintaining it.  He did not omit being sometimes directly
11507 before Miss Smith, or speaking to those who were close to her.--
11508 Emma saw it.  She was not yet dancing; she was working her way
11509 up from the bottom, and had therefore leisure to look around,
11510 and by only turning her head a little she saw it all.  When she was
11511 half-way up the set, the whole group were exactly behind her, and she
11512 would no longer allow her eyes to watch; but Mr. Elton was so near,
11513 that she heard every syllable of a dialogue which just then took
11514 place between him and Mrs. Weston; and she perceived that his wife,
11515 who was standing immediately above her, was not only listening also,
11516 but even encouraging him by significant glances.--The kind-hearted,
11517 gentle Mrs. Weston had left her seat to join him and say, "Do not
11518 you dance, Mr. Elton?" to which his prompt reply was, "Most readily,
11519 Mrs. Weston, if you will dance with me."
11520 
11521 "Me!--oh! no--I would get you a better partner than myself.
11522 I am no dancer."
11523 
11524 "If Mrs. Gilbert wishes to dance," said he, "I shall have great pleasure,
11525 I am sure--for, though beginning to feel myself rather an old married man,
11526 and that my dancing days are over, it would give me very great
11527 pleasure at any time to stand up with an old friend like Mrs. Gilbert."
11528 
11529 "Mrs. Gilbert does not mean to dance, but there is a young lady
11530 disengaged whom I should be very glad to see dancing--Miss Smith."
11531 "Miss Smith!--oh!--I had not observed.--You are extremely obliging--
11532 and if I were not an old married man.--But my dancing days are over,
11533 Mrs. Weston.  You will excuse me.  Any thing else I should be most happy
11534 to do, at your command--but my dancing days are over."
11535 
11536 Mrs. Weston said no more; and Emma could imagine with what
11537 surprize and mortification she must be returning to her seat.
11538 This was Mr. Elton! the amiable, obliging, gentle Mr. Elton.--
11539 She looked round for a moment; he had joined Mr. Knightley at a
11540 little distance, and was arranging himself for settled conversation,
11541 while smiles of high glee passed between him and his wife.
11542 
11543 She would not look again.  Her heart was in a glow, and she feared
11544 her face might be as hot.
11545 
11546 In another moment a happier sight caught her;--Mr. Knightley
11547 leading Harriet to the set!--Never had she been more surprized,
11548 seldom more delighted, than at that instant.  She was all pleasure
11549 and gratitude, both for Harriet and herself, and longed to be
11550 thanking him; and though too distant for speech, her countenance
11551 said much, as soon as she could catch his eye again.
11552 
11553 His dancing proved to be just what she had believed it,
11554 extremely good; and Harriet would have seemed almost too lucky,
11555 if it had not been for the cruel state of things before, and for
11556 the very complete enjoyment and very high sense of the distinction
11557 which her happy features announced.  It was not thrown away on her,
11558 she bounded higher than ever, flew farther down the middle,
11559 and was in a continual course of smiles.
11560 
11561 Mr. Elton had retreated into the card-room, looking (Emma trusted)
11562 very foolish.  She did not think he was quite so hardened as his wife,
11563 though growing very like her;--_she_ spoke some of her feelings,
11564 by observing audibly to her partner,
11565 
11566 "Knightley has taken pity on poor little Miss Smith!--Very goodnatured,
11567 I declare."
11568 
11569 Supper was announced.  The move began; and Miss Bates might be
11570 heard from that moment, without interruption, till her being
11571 seated at table and taking up her spoon.
11572 
11573 "Jane, Jane, my dear Jane, where are you?--Here is your tippet.
11574 Mrs. Weston begs you to put on your tippet.  She says she is afraid
11575 there will be draughts in the passage, though every thing has
11576 been done--One door nailed up--Quantities of matting--My dear Jane,
11577 indeed you must.  Mr. Churchill, oh! you are too obliging!
11578 How well you put it on!--so gratified!  Excellent dancing indeed!--
11579 Yes, my dear, I ran home, as I said I should, to help grandmama
11580 to bed, and got back again, and nobody missed me.--I set off without
11581 saying a word, just as I told you.  Grandmama was quite well,
11582 had a charming evening with Mr. Woodhouse, a vast deal of chat,
11583 and backgammon.--Tea was made downstairs, biscuits and baked apples
11584 and wine before she came away:  amazing luck in some of her throws:
11585 and she inquired a great deal about you, how you were amused,
11586 and who were your partners.  `Oh!' said I, `I shall not forestall Jane;
11587 I left her dancing with Mr. George Otway; she will love to tell you
11588 all about it herself to-morrow: her first partner was Mr. Elton,
11589 I do not know who will ask her next, perhaps Mr. William Cox.'
11590 My dear sir, you are too obliging.--Is there nobody you would
11591 not rather?--I am not helpless.  Sir, you are most kind.  Upon my word,
11592 Jane on one arm, and me on the other!--Stop, stop, let us stand
11593 a little back, Mrs. Elton is going; dear Mrs. Elton, how elegant
11594 she looks!--Beautiful lace!--Now we all follow in her train.
11595 Quite the queen of the evening!--Well, here we are at the passage.
11596 Two steps, Jane, take care of the two steps.  Oh! no, there is
11597 but one.  Well, I was persuaded there were two.  How very odd!
11598 I was convinced there were two, and there is but one.  I never saw any
11599 thing equal to the comfort and style--Candles everywhere.--I was telling
11600 you of your grandmama, Jane,--There was a little disappointment.--
11601 The baked apples and biscuits, excellent in their way, you know;
11602 but there was a delicate fricassee of sweetbread and some asparagus
11603 brought in at first, and good Mr. Woodhouse, not thinking the
11604 asparagus quite boiled enough, sent it all out again.  Now there
11605 is nothing grandmama loves better than sweetbread and asparagus--
11606 so she was rather disappointed, but we agreed we would not speak of it
11607 to any body, for fear of its getting round to dear Miss Woodhouse,
11608 who would be so very much concerned!--Well, this is brilliant!
11609 I am all amazement! could not have supposed any thing!--Such
11610 elegance and profusion!--I have seen nothing like it since--
11611 Well, where shall we sit? where shall we sit?  Anywhere, so that
11612 Jane is not in a draught.  Where _I_ sit is of no consequence.
11613 Oh! do you recommend this side?--Well, I am sure, Mr. Churchill--
11614 only it seems too good--but just as you please.  What you direct
11615 in this house cannot be wrong.  Dear Jane, how shall we ever
11616 recollect half the dishes for grandmama?  Soup too!  Bless me!
11617 I should not be helped so soon, but it smells most excellent, and I
11618 cannot help beginning."
11619 
11620 Emma had no opportunity of speaking to Mr. Knightley till
11621 after supper; but, when they were all in the ballroom again,
11622 her eyes invited him irresistibly to come to her and be thanked.
11623 He was warm in his reprobation of Mr. Elton's conduct; it had been
11624 unpardonable rudeness; and Mrs. Elton's looks also received the due
11625 share of censure.
11626 
11627 "They aimed at wounding more than Harriet," said he.  "Emma, why
11628 is it that they are your enemies?"
11629 
11630 He looked with smiling penetration; and, on receiving
11631 no answer, added, "_She_ ought not to be angry with you, I suspect,
11632 whatever he may be.--To that surmise, you say nothing, of course;
11633 but confess, Emma, that you did want him to marry Harriet."
11634 
11635 "I did," replied Emma, "and they cannot forgive me."
11636 
11637 He shook his head; but there was a smile of indulgence with it,
11638 and he only said,
11639 
11640 "I shall not scold you.  I leave you to your own reflections."
11641 
11642 "Can you trust me with such flatterers?--Does my vain spirit ever
11643 tell me I am wrong?"
11644 
11645 "Not your vain spirit, but your serious spirit.--If one leads
11646 you wrong, I am sure the other tells you of it."
11647 
11648 "I do own myself to have been completely mistaken in Mr. Elton.
11649 There is a littleness about him which you discovered, and which I
11650 did not:  and I was fully convinced of his being in love with Harriet.
11651 It was through a series of strange blunders!"
11652 
11653 "And, in return for your acknowledging so much, I will do you the justice
11654 to say, that you would have chosen for him better than he has chosen for
11655 himself.--Harriet Smith has some first-rate qualities, which Mrs. Elton
11656 is totally without.  An unpretending, single-minded, artless girl--
11657 infinitely to be preferred by any man of sense and taste to such
11658 a woman as Mrs. Elton.  I found Harriet more conversable than I expected."
11659 
11660 Emma was extremely gratified.--They were interrupted by the bustle
11661 of Mr. Weston calling on every body to begin dancing again.
11662 
11663 "Come Miss Woodhouse, Miss Otway, Miss Fairfax, what are you all doing?--
11664 Come Emma, set your companions the example.  Every body is lazy!
11665 Every body is asleep!"
11666 
11667 "I am ready," said Emma, "whenever I am wanted."
11668 
11669 "Whom are you going to dance with?" asked Mr. Knightley.
11670 
11671 She hesitated a moment, and then replied, "With you, if you will
11672 ask me."
11673 
11674 "Will you?" said he, offering his hand.
11675 
11676 "Indeed I will.  You have shewn that you can dance, and you know we
11677 are not really so much brother and sister as to make it at all improper."
11678 
11679 "Brother and sister! no, indeed."
11680 
11681 
11682 
11683 CHAPTER III
11684 
11685 
11686 This little explanation with Mr. Knightley gave Emma considerable
11687 pleasure.  It was one of the agreeable recollections of the ball,
11688 which she walked about the lawn the next morning to enjoy.--She was
11689 extremely glad that they had come to so good an understanding respecting
11690 the Eltons, and that their opinions of both husband and wife were so
11691 much alike; and his praise of Harriet, his concession in her favour,
11692 was peculiarly gratifying.  The impertinence of the Eltons, which for
11693 a few minutes had threatened to ruin the rest of her evening, had been
11694 the occasion of some of its highest satisfactions; and she looked
11695 forward to another happy result--the cure of Harriet's infatuation.--
11696 From Harriet's manner of speaking of the circumstance before they
11697 quitted the ballroom, she had strong hopes.  It seemed as if her eyes
11698 were suddenly opened, and she were enabled to see that Mr. Elton
11699 was not the superior creature she had believed him.  The fever
11700 was over, and Emma could harbour little fear of the pulse being
11701 quickened again by injurious courtesy.  She depended on the evil
11702 feelings of the Eltons for supplying all the discipline of pointed
11703 neglect that could be farther requisite.--Harriet rational,
11704 Frank Churchill not too much in love, and Mr. Knightley not
11705 wanting to quarrel with her, how very happy a summer must be before her!
11706 
11707 She was not to see Frank Churchill this morning.  He had told
11708 her that he could not allow himself the pleasure of stopping
11709 at Hartfield, as he was to be at home by the middle of the day.
11710 She did not regret it.
11711 
11712 Having arranged all these matters, looked them through, and put them all
11713 to rights, she was just turning to the house with spirits freshened up
11714 for the demands of the two little boys, as well as of their grandpapa,
11715 when the great iron sweep-gate opened, and two persons entered
11716 whom she had never less expected to see together--Frank Churchill,
11717 with Harriet leaning on his arm--actually Harriet!--A moment
11718 sufficed to convince her that something extraordinary had happened.
11719 Harriet looked white and frightened, and he was trying to cheer her.--
11720 The iron gates and the front-door were not twenty yards asunder;--
11721 they were all three soon in the hall, and Harriet immediately sinking
11722 into a chair fainted away.
11723 
11724 A young lady who faints, must be recovered; questions must be answered,
11725 and surprizes be explained.  Such events are very interesting,
11726 but the suspense of them cannot last long.  A few minutes made Emma
11727 acquainted with the whole.
11728 
11729 Miss Smith, and Miss Bickerton, another parlour boarder at
11730 Mrs. Goddard's, who had been also at the ball, had walked out together,
11731 and taken a road, the Richmond road, which, though apparently public
11732 enough for safety, had led them into alarm.--About half a mile
11733 beyond Highbury, making a sudden turn, and deeply shaded by elms
11734 on each side, it became for a considerable stretch very retired;
11735 and when the young ladies had advanced some way into it,
11736 they had suddenly perceived at a small distance before them,
11737 on a broader patch of greensward by the side, a party of gipsies.
11738 A child on the watch, came towards them to beg; and Miss Bickerton,
11739 excessively frightened, gave a great scream, and calling on Harriet
11740 to follow her, ran up a steep bank, cleared a slight hedge at the top,
11741 and made the best of her way by a short cut back to Highbury.
11742 But poor Harriet could not follow.  She had suffered very much
11743 from cramp after dancing, and her first attempt to mount the bank
11744 brought on such a return of it as made her absolutely powerless--
11745 and in this state, and exceedingly terrified, she had been obliged
11746 to remain.
11747 
11748 How the trampers might have behaved, had the young ladies been
11749 more courageous, must be doubtful; but such an invitation for attack
11750 could not be resisted; and Harriet was soon assailed by half a
11751 dozen children, headed by a stout woman and a great boy, all clamorous,
11752 and impertinent in look, though not absolutely in word.--More and
11753 more frightened, she immediately promised them money, and taking out
11754 her purse, gave them a shilling, and begged them not to want more,
11755 or to use her ill.--She was then able to walk, though but slowly,
11756 and was moving away--but her terror and her purse were too tempting,
11757 and she was followed, or rather surrounded, by the whole gang,
11758 demanding more.
11759 
11760 In this state Frank Churchill had found her, she trembling
11761 and conditioning, they loud and insolent.  By a most fortunate
11762 chance his leaving Highbury had been delayed so as to bring him
11763 to her assistance at this critical moment.  The pleasantness
11764 of the morning had induced him to walk forward, and leave his
11765 horses to meet him by another road, a mile or two beyond Highbury--
11766 and happening to have borrowed a pair of scissors the night before
11767 of Miss Bates, and to have forgotten to restore them, he had
11768 been obliged to stop at her door, and go in for a few minutes:
11769 he was therefore later than he had intended; and being on foot,
11770 was unseen by the whole party till almost close to them.
11771 The terror which the woman and boy had been creating in Harriet
11772 was then their own portion.  He had left them completely frightened;
11773 and Harriet eagerly clinging to him, and hardly able to speak,
11774 had just strength enough to reach Hartfield, before her spirits
11775 were quite overcome.  It was his idea to bring her to Hartfield:
11776 he had thought of no other place.
11777 
11778 This was the amount of the whole story,--of his communication and
11779 of Harriet's as soon as she had recovered her senses and speech.--
11780 He dared not stay longer than to see her well; these several delays
11781 left him not another minute to lose; and Emma engaging to give
11782 assurance of her safety to Mrs. Goddard, and notice of there
11783 being such a set of people in the neighbourhood to Mr. Knightley,
11784 he set off, with all the grateful blessings that she could utter
11785 for her friend and herself.
11786 
11787 Such an adventure as this,--a fine young man and a lovely young
11788 woman thrown together in such a way, could hardly fail of suggesting
11789 certain ideas to the coldest heart and the steadiest brain.
11790 So Emma thought, at least.  Could a linguist, could a grammarian,
11791 could even a mathematician have seen what she did, have witnessed their
11792 appearance together, and heard their history of it, without feeling
11793 that circumstances had been at work to make them peculiarly interesting
11794 to each other?--How much more must an imaginist, like herself,
11795 be on fire with speculation and foresight!--especially with such
11796 a groundwork of anticipation as her mind had already made.
11797 
11798 It was a very extraordinary thing!  Nothing of the sort had ever
11799 occurred before to any young ladies in the place, within her memory;
11800 no rencontre, no alarm of the kind;--and now it had happened
11801 to the very person, and at the very hour, when the other very
11802 person was chancing to pass by to rescue her!--It certainly
11803 was very extraordinary!--And knowing, as she did, the favourable
11804 state of mind of each at this period, it struck her the more.
11805 He was wishing to get the better of his attachment to herself,
11806 she just recovering from her mania for Mr. Elton.  It seemed as if
11807 every thing united to promise the most interesting consequences.
11808 It was not possible that the occurrence should not be strongly
11809 recommending each to the other.
11810 
11811 In the few minutes' conversation which she had yet had with him,
11812 while Harriet had been partially insensible, he had spoken of her terror,
11813 her naivete, her fervour as she seized and clung to his arm, with a
11814 sensibility amused and delighted; and just at last, after Harriet's
11815 own account had been given, he had expressed his indignation
11816 at the abominable folly of Miss Bickerton in the warmest terms.
11817 Every thing was to take its natural course, however, neither impelled
11818 nor assisted.  She would not stir a step, nor drop a hint.
11819 No, she had had enough of interference.  There could be no harm
11820 in a scheme, a mere passive scheme.  It was no more than a wish.
11821 Beyond it she would on no account proceed.
11822 
11823 Emma's first resolution was to keep her father from the knowledge
11824 of what had passed,--aware of the anxiety and alarm it would occasion:
11825 but she soon felt that concealment must be impossible.  Within half
11826 an hour it was known all over Highbury.  It was the very event
11827 to engage those who talk most, the young and the low; and all
11828 the youth and servants in the place were soon in the happiness of
11829 frightful news.  The last night's ball seemed lost in the gipsies.
11830 Poor Mr. Woodhouse trembled as he sat, and, as Emma had foreseen,
11831 would scarcely be satisfied without their promising never to go
11832 beyond the shrubbery again.  It was some comfort to him that many
11833 inquiries after himself and Miss Woodhouse (for his neighbours
11834 knew that he loved to be inquired after), as well as Miss Smith,
11835 were coming in during the rest of the day; and he had the pleasure
11836 of returning for answer, that they were all very indifferent--
11837 which, though not exactly true, for she was perfectly well,
11838 and Harriet not much otherwise, Emma would not interfere with.
11839 She had an unhappy state of health in general for the child of such
11840 a man, for she hardly knew what indisposition was; and if he did not
11841 invent illnesses for her, she could make no figure in a message.
11842 
11843 The gipsies did not wait for the operations of justice; they took
11844 themselves off in a hurry.  The young ladies of Highbury might have
11845 walked again in safety before their panic began, and the whole
11846 history dwindled soon into a matter of little importance but to Emma
11847 and her nephews:--in her imagination it maintained its ground,
11848 and Henry and John were still asking every day for the story of
11849 Harriet and the gipsies, and still tenaciously setting her right
11850 if she varied in the slightest particular from the original recital.
11851 
11852 
11853 
11854 CHAPTER IV
11855 
11856 
11857 A very few days had passed after this adventure, when Harriet came
11858 one morning to Emma with a small parcel in her hand, and after
11859 sitting down and hesitating, thus began:
11860 
11861 "Miss Woodhouse--if you are at leisure--I have something that I
11862 should like to tell you--a sort of confession to make--and then,
11863 you know, it will be over."
11864 
11865 Emma was a good deal surprized; but begged her to speak.
11866 There was a seriousness in Harriet's manner which prepared her,
11867 quite as much as her words, for something more than ordinary.
11868 
11869 "It is my duty, and I am sure it is my wish," she continued,
11870 "to have no reserves with you on this subject.  As I am happily
11871 quite an altered creature in _one_ _respect_, it is very fit that you
11872 should have the satisfaction of knowing it.  I do not want to say
11873 more than is necessary--I am too much ashamed of having given way
11874 as I have done, and I dare say you understand me."
11875 
11876 "Yes," said Emma, "I hope I do."
11877 
11878 "How I could so long a time be fancying myself! . . ."
11879 cried Harriet, warmly.  "It seems like madness!  I can see nothing
11880 at all extraordinary in him now.--I do not care whether I meet
11881 him or not--except that of the two I had rather not see him--
11882 and indeed I would go any distance round to avoid him--but I do
11883 not envy his wife in the least; I neither admire her nor envy her,
11884 as I have done:  she is very charming, I dare say, and all that,
11885 but I think her very ill-tempered and disagreeable--I shall never forget
11886 her look the other night!--However, I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,
11887 I wish her no evil.--No, let them be ever so happy together,
11888 it will not give me another moment's pang:  and to convince you
11889 that I have been speaking truth, I am now going to destroy--what I
11890 ought to have destroyed long ago--what I ought never to have kept--
11891 I know that very well (blushing as she spoke).--However, now I
11892 will destroy it all--and it is my particular wish to do it
11893 in your presence, that you may see how rational I am grown.
11894 Cannot you guess what this parcel holds?" said she, with a conscious look.
11895 
11896 "Not the least in the world.--Did he ever give you any thing?"
11897 
11898 "No--I cannot call them gifts; but they are things that I have
11899 valued very much."
11900 
11901 She held the parcel towards her, and Emma read the words _Most_
11902 _precious_ _treasures_ on the top.  Her curiosity was greatly excited.
11903 Harriet unfolded the parcel, and she looked on with impatience.
11904 Within abundance of silver paper was a pretty little Tunbridge-ware box,
11905 which Harriet opened:  it was well lined with the softest cotton;
11906 but, excepting the cotton, Emma saw only a small piece of court-plaister.
11907 
11908 "Now," said Harriet, "you _must_ recollect."
11909 
11910 "No, indeed I do not."
11911 
11912 "Dear me!  I should not have thought it possible you could forget
11913 what passed in this very room about court-plaister, one of the very
11914 last times we ever met in it!--It was but a very few days before I
11915 had my sore throat--just before Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley came--
11916 I think the very evening.--Do not you remember his cutting his finger
11917 with your new penknife, and your recommending court-plaister?--
11918 But, as you had none about you, and knew I had, you desired
11919 me to supply him; and so I took mine out and cut him a piece;
11920 but it was a great deal too large, and he cut it smaller, and kept
11921 playing some time with what was left, before he gave it back to me.
11922 And so then, in my nonsense, I could not help making a treasure of it--
11923 so I put it by never to be used, and looked at it now and then
11924 as a great treat."
11925 
11926 "My dearest Harriet!" cried Emma, putting her hand before her face,
11927 and jumping up, "you make me more ashamed of myself than I can bear.
11928 Remember it?  Aye, I remember it all now; all, except your saving
11929 this relic--I knew nothing of that till this moment--but the cutting
11930 the finger, and my recommending court-plaister, and saying I had none
11931 about me!--Oh! my sins, my sins!--And I had plenty all the while in
11932 my pocket!--One of my senseless tricks!--I deserve to be under a
11933 continual blush all the rest of my life.--Well--(sitting down again)--
11934 go on--what else?"
11935 
11936 "And had you really some at hand yourself?  I am sure I never
11937 suspected it, you did it so naturally."
11938 
11939 "And so you actually put this piece of court-plaister by for his sake!"
11940 said Emma, recovering from her state of shame and feeling divided
11941 between wonder and amusement.  And secretly she added to herself,
11942 "Lord bless me! when should I ever have thought of putting by in cotton
11943 a piece of court-plaister that Frank Churchill had been pulling about!
11944 I never was equal to this."
11945 
11946 "Here," resumed Harriet, turning to her box again, "here is
11947 something still more valuable, I mean that _has_ _been_ more valuable,
11948 because this is what did really once belong to him, which the
11949 court-plaister never did."
11950 
11951 Emma was quite eager to see this superior treasure.  It was the end
11952 of an old pencil,--the part without any lead.
11953 
11954 "This was really his," said Harriet.--"Do not you remember
11955 one morning?--no, I dare say you do not.  But one morning--I forget
11956 exactly the day--but perhaps it was the Tuesday or Wednesday before
11957 _that_ _evening_, he wanted to make a memorandum in his pocket-book;
11958 it was about spruce-beer. Mr. Knightley had been telling him
11959 something about brewing spruce-beer, and he wanted to put it down;
11960 but when he took out his pencil, there was so little lead that he
11961 soon cut it all away, and it would not do, so you lent him another,
11962 and this was left upon the table as good for nothing.  But I kept
11963 my eye on it; and, as soon as I dared, caught it up, and never
11964 parted with it again from that moment."
11965 
11966 "I do remember it," cried Emma; "I perfectly remember it.--
11967 Talking about spruce-beer.--Oh! yes--Mr. Knightley and I both saying we
11968 liked it, and Mr. Elton's seeming resolved to learn to like it too.
11969 I perfectly remember it.--Stop; Mr. Knightley was standing just here,
11970 was not he?  I have an idea he was standing just here."
11971 
11972 "Ah!  I do not know.  I cannot recollect.--It is very odd,
11973 but I cannot recollect.--Mr. Elton was sitting here, I remember,
11974 much about where I am now."--
11975 
11976 "Well, go on."
11977 
11978 "Oh! that's all.  I have nothing more to shew you, or to say--
11979 except that I am now going to throw them both behind the fire,
11980 and I wish you to see me do it."
11981 
11982 "My poor dear Harriet! and have you actually found happiness
11983 in treasuring up these things?"
11984 
11985 "Yes, simpleton as I was!--but I am quite ashamed of it now, and wish
11986 I could forget as easily as I can burn them.  It was very wrong
11987 of me, you know, to keep any remembrances, after he was married.
11988 I knew it was--but had not resolution enough to part with them."
11989 
11990 "But, Harriet, is it necessary to burn the court-plaister?--I have
11991 not a word to say for the bit of old pencil, but the court-plaister
11992 might be useful."
11993 
11994 "I shall be happier to burn it," replied Harriet.  "It has
11995 a disagreeable look to me.  I must get rid of every thing.--
11996 There it goes, and there is an end, thank Heaven! of Mr. Elton."
11997 
11998 "And when," thought Emma, "will there be a beginning of Mr. Churchill?"
11999 
12000 She had soon afterwards reason to believe that the beginning was
12001 already made, and could not but hope that the gipsy, though she had
12002 _told_ no fortune, might be proved to have made Harriet's.--About a
12003 fortnight after the alarm, they came to a sufficient explanation,
12004 and quite undesignedly.  Emma was not thinking of it at the moment,
12005 which made the information she received more valuable.
12006 She merely said, in the course of some trivial chat, "Well, Harriet,
12007 whenever you marry I would advise you to do so and so"--and thought
12008 no more of it, till after a minute's silence she heard Harriet
12009 say in a very serious tone, "I shall never marry."
12010 
12011 Emma then looked up, and immediately saw how it was; and after a
12012 moment's debate, as to whether it should pass unnoticed or not, replied,
12013 
12014 "Never marry!--This is a new resolution."
12015 
12016 "It is one that I shall never change, however."
12017 
12018 After another short hesitation, "I hope it does not proceed from--
12019 I hope it is not in compliment to Mr. Elton?"
12020 
12021 "Mr. Elton indeed!" cried Harriet indignantly.--"Oh! no"--and Emma
12022 could just catch the words, "so superior to Mr. Elton!"
12023 
12024 She then took a longer time for consideration.  Should she proceed
12025 no farther?--should she let it pass, and seem to suspect nothing?--
12026 Perhaps Harriet might think her cold or angry if she did;
12027 or perhaps if she were totally silent, it might only drive
12028 Harriet into asking her to hear too much; and against any thing
12029 like such an unreserve as had been, such an open and frequent
12030 discussion of hopes and chances, she was perfectly resolved.--
12031 She believed it would be wiser for her to say and know at once,
12032 all that she meant to say and know.  Plain dealing was always best.
12033 She had previously determined how far she would proceed,
12034 on any application of the sort; and it would be safer for both,
12035 to have the judicious law of her own brain laid down with speed.--
12036 She was decided, and thus spoke--
12037 
12038 "Harriet, I will not affect to be in doubt of your meaning.
12039 Your resolution, or rather your expectation of never marrying,
12040 results from an idea that the person whom you might prefer,
12041 would be too greatly your superior in situation to think of you.
12042 Is not it so?"
12043 
12044 "Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, believe me I have not the presumption to suppose--
12045 Indeed I am not so mad.--But it is a pleasure to me to admire him
12046 at a distance--and to think of his infinite superiority to all
12047 the rest of the world, with the gratitude, wonder, and veneration,
12048 which are so proper, in me especially."
12049 
12050 "I am not at all surprized at you, Harriet.  The service he rendered
12051 you was enough to warm your heart."
12052 
12053 "Service! oh! it was such an inexpressible obligation!--
12054 The very recollection of it, and all that I felt at the time--
12055 when I saw him coming--his noble look--and my wretchedness before.
12056 Such a change!  In one moment such a change!  From perfect misery
12057 to perfect happiness!"
12058 
12059 "It is very natural.  It is natural, and it is honourable.--
12060 Yes, honourable, I think, to chuse so well and so gratefully.--
12061 But that it will be a fortunate preference is more that I can promise.
12062 I do not advise you to give way to it, Harriet.  I do not by any
12063 means engage for its being returned.  Consider what you are about.
12064 Perhaps it will be wisest in you to check your feelings while you can:
12065 at any rate do not let them carry you far, unless you are persuaded
12066 of his liking you.  Be observant of him.  Let his behaviour be the
12067 guide of your sensations.  I give you this caution now, because I
12068 shall never speak to you again on the subject.  I am determined
12069 against all interference.  Henceforward I know nothing of the matter.
12070 Let no name ever pass our lips.  We were very wrong before;
12071 we will be cautious now.--He is your superior, no doubt, and there
12072 do seem objections and obstacles of a very serious nature;
12073 but yet, Harriet, more wonderful things have taken place, there have
12074 been matches of greater disparity.  But take care of yourself.
12075 I would not have you too sanguine; though, however it may end,
12076 be assured your raising your thoughts to _him_, is a mark of good taste
12077 which I shall always know how to value."
12078 
12079 Harriet kissed her hand in silent and submissive gratitude.
12080 Emma was very decided in thinking such an attachment no bad thing
12081 for her friend.  Its tendency would be to raise and refine her mind--
12082 and it must be saving her from the danger of degradation.
12083 
12084 
12085 
12086 CHAPTER V
12087 
12088 
12089 In this state of schemes, and hopes, and connivance, June opened
12090 upon Hartfield.  To Highbury in general it brought no material change.
12091 The Eltons were still talking of a visit from the Sucklings,
12092 and of the use to be made of their barouche-landau; and Jane Fairfax
12093 was still at her grandmother's; and as the return of the Campbells
12094 from Ireland was again delayed, and August, instead of Midsummer,
12095 fixed for it, she was likely to remain there full two months longer,
12096 provided at least she were able to defeat Mrs. Elton's activity
12097 in her service, and save herself from being hurried into a delightful
12098 situation against her will.
12099 
12100 Mr. Knightley, who, for some reason best known to himself, had certainly
12101 taken an early dislike to Frank Churchill, was only growing to dislike
12102 him more.  He began to suspect him of some double dealing in his
12103 pursuit of Emma.  That Emma was his object appeared indisputable.
12104 Every thing declared it; his own attentions, his father's hints,
12105 his mother-in-law's guarded silence; it was all in unison;
12106 words, conduct, discretion, and indiscretion, told the same story.
12107 But while so many were devoting him to Emma, and Emma herself making him
12108 over to Harriet, Mr. Knightley began to suspect him of some inclination
12109 to trifle with Jane Fairfax.  He could not understand it; but there
12110 were symptoms of intelligence between them--he thought so at least--
12111 symptoms of admiration on his side, which, having once observed,
12112 he could not persuade himself to think entirely void of meaning,
12113 however he might wish to escape any of Emma's errors of imagination.
12114 _She_ was not present when the suspicion first arose.  He was dining
12115 with the Randalls family, and Jane, at the Eltons'; and he had
12116 seen a look, more than a single look, at Miss Fairfax, which,
12117 from the admirer of Miss Woodhouse, seemed somewhat out of place.
12118 When he was again in their company, he could not help remembering
12119 what he had seen; nor could he avoid observations which, unless it
12120 were like Cowper and his fire at twilight,
12121 
12122 "Myself creating what I saw,"
12123 
12124 brought him yet stronger suspicion of there being a something
12125 of private liking, of private understanding even, between Frank
12126 Churchill and Jane.
12127 
12128 He had walked up one day after dinner, as he very often did,
12129 to spend his evening at Hartfield.  Emma and Harriet were going
12130 to walk; he joined them; and, on returning, they fell in with a
12131 larger party, who, like themselves, judged it wisest to take their
12132 exercise early, as the weather threatened rain; Mr. and Mrs. Weston
12133 and their son, Miss Bates and her niece, who had accidentally met.
12134 They all united; and, on reaching Hartfield gates, Emma, who knew it
12135 was exactly the sort of visiting that would be welcome to her father,
12136 pressed them all to go in and drink tea with him.  The Randalls
12137 party agreed to it immediately; and after a pretty long speech
12138 from Miss Bates, which few persons listened to, she also found it
12139 possible to accept dear Miss Woodhouse's most obliging invitation.
12140 
12141 As they were turning into the grounds, Mr. Perry passed by on horseback.
12142 The gentlemen spoke of his horse.
12143 
12144 "By the bye," said Frank Churchill to Mrs. Weston presently,
12145 "what became of Mr. Perry's plan of setting up his carriage?"
12146 
12147 Mrs. Weston looked surprized, and said, "I did not know that he
12148 ever had any such plan."
12149 
12150 "Nay, I had it from you.  You wrote me word of it three months ago."
12151 
12152 "Me! impossible!"
12153 
12154 "Indeed you did.  I remember it perfectly.  You mentioned it as
12155 what was certainly to be very soon.  Mrs. Perry had told somebody,
12156 and was extremely happy about it.  It was owing to _her_ persuasion,
12157 as she thought his being out in bad weather did him a great deal
12158 of harm.  You must remember it now?"
12159 
12160 "Upon my word I never heard of it till this moment."
12161 
12162 "Never! really, never!--Bless me! how could it be?--Then I must
12163 have dreamt it--but I was completely persuaded--Miss Smith,
12164 you walk as if you were tired.  You will not be sorry to find
12165 yourself at home."
12166 
12167 "What is this?--What is this?" cried Mr. Weston, "about Perry
12168 and a carriage?  Is Perry going to set up his carriage, Frank?
12169 I am glad he can afford it.  You had it from himself, had you?"
12170 
12171 "No, sir," replied his son, laughing, "I seem to have had it
12172 from nobody.--Very odd!--I really was persuaded of Mrs. Weston's
12173 having mentioned it in one of her letters to Enscombe, many weeks ago,
12174 with all these particulars--but as she declares she never heard
12175 a syllable of it before, of course it must have been a dream.  I am
12176 a great dreamer.  I dream of every body at Highbury when I am away--
12177 and when I have gone through my particular friends, then I begin
12178 dreaming of Mr. and Mrs. Perry."
12179 
12180 "It is odd though," observed his father, "that you should have had such
12181 a regular connected dream about people whom it was not very likely you
12182 should be thinking of at Enscombe.  Perry's setting up his carriage!
12183 and his wife's persuading him to it, out of care for his health--
12184 just what will happen, I have no doubt, some time or other;
12185 only a little premature.  What an air of probability sometimes
12186 runs through a dream!  And at others, what a heap of absurdities
12187 it is!  Well, Frank, your dream certainly shews that Highbury is in
12188 your thoughts when you are absent.  Emma, you are a great dreamer,
12189 I think?"
12190 
12191 Emma was out of hearing.  She had hurried on before her guests
12192 to prepare her father for their appearance, and was beyond the reach
12193 of Mr. Weston's hint.
12194 
12195 "Why, to own the truth," cried Miss Bates, who had been trying in vain
12196 to be heard the last two minutes, "if I must speak on this subject,
12197 there is no denying that Mr. Frank Churchill might have--I do not
12198 mean to say that he did not dream it--I am sure I have sometimes
12199 the oddest dreams in the world--but if I am questioned about it,
12200 I must acknowledge that there was such an idea last spring;
12201 for Mrs. Perry herself mentioned it to my mother, and the Coles
12202 knew of it as well as ourselves--but it was quite a secret,
12203 known to nobody else, and only thought of about three days.
12204 Mrs. Perry was very anxious that he should have a carriage, and came
12205 to my mother in great spirits one morning because she thought she
12206 had prevailed.  Jane, don't you remember grandmama's telling us
12207 of it when we got home?  I forget where we had been walking to--
12208 very likely to Randalls; yes, I think it was to Randalls.
12209 Mrs. Perry was always particularly fond of my mother--indeed I do
12210 not know who is not--and she had mentioned it to her in confidence;
12211 she had no objection to her telling us, of course, but it was not
12212 to go beyond:  and, from that day to this, I never mentioned it
12213 to a soul that I know of.  At the same time, I will not positively
12214 answer for my having never dropt a hint, because I know I do
12215 sometimes pop out a thing before I am aware.  I am a talker,
12216 you know; I am rather a talker; and now and then I have let a thing
12217 escape me which I should not.  I am not like Jane; I wish I were.
12218 I will answer for it _she_ never betrayed the least thing in the world.
12219 Where is she?--Oh! just behind.  Perfectly remember Mrs. Perry's coming.--
12220 Extraordinary dream, indeed!"
12221 
12222 They were entering the hall.  Mr. Knightley's eyes had preceded
12223 Miss Bates's in a glance at Jane.  From Frank Churchill's face,
12224 where he thought he saw confusion suppressed or laughed away,
12225 he had involuntarily turned to hers; but she was indeed behind,
12226 and too busy with her shawl.  Mr. Weston had walked in.  The two
12227 other gentlemen waited at the door to let her pass.  Mr. Knightley
12228 suspected in Frank Churchill the determination of catching her eye--
12229 he seemed watching her intently--in vain, however, if it were so--
12230 Jane passed between them into the hall, and looked at neither.
12231 
12232 There was no time for farther remark or explanation.  The dream must
12233 be borne with, and Mr. Knightley must take his seat with the rest round
12234 the large modern circular table which Emma had introduced at Hartfield,
12235 and which none but Emma could have had power to place there and
12236 persuade her father to use, instead of the small-sized Pembroke,
12237 on which two of his daily meals had, for forty years been crowded.
12238 Tea passed pleasantly, and nobody seemed in a hurry to move.
12239 
12240 "Miss Woodhouse," said Frank Churchill, after examining a table
12241 behind him, which he could reach as he sat, "have your nephews taken
12242 away their alphabets--their box of letters?  It used to stand here.
12243 Where is it?  This is a sort of dull-looking evening, that ought
12244 to be treated rather as winter than summer.  We had great amusement
12245 with those letters one morning.  I want to puzzle you again."
12246 
12247 Emma was pleased with the thought; and producing the box, the table
12248 was quickly scattered over with alphabets, which no one seemed so much
12249 disposed to employ as their two selves.  They were rapidly forming
12250 words for each other, or for any body else who would be puzzled.
12251 The quietness of the game made it particularly eligible for
12252 Mr. Woodhouse, who had often been distressed by the more animated sort,
12253 which Mr. Weston had occasionally introduced, and who now sat happily
12254 occupied in lamenting, with tender melancholy, over the departure
12255 of the "poor little boys," or in fondly pointing out, as he took
12256 up any stray letter near him, how beautifully Emma had written it.
12257 
12258 Frank Churchill placed a word before Miss Fairfax.  She gave
12259 a slight glance round the table, and applied herself to it.
12260 Frank was next to Emma, Jane opposite to them--and Mr. Knightley
12261 so placed as to see them all; and it was his object to see as much
12262 as he could, with as little apparent observation.  The word
12263 was discovered, and with a faint smile pushed away.  If meant
12264 to be immediately mixed with the others, and buried from sight,
12265 she should have looked on the table instead of looking just across,
12266 for it was not mixed; and Harriet, eager after every fresh word,
12267 and finding out none, directly took it up, and fell to work.
12268 She was sitting by Mr. Knightley, and turned to him for help.
12269 The word was _blunder_; and as Harriet exultingly proclaimed it,
12270 there was a blush on Jane's cheek which gave it a meaning not
12271 otherwise ostensible.  Mr. Knightley connected it with the dream;
12272 but how it could all be, was beyond his comprehension.
12273 How the delicacy, the discretion of his favourite could have been
12274 so lain asleep!  He feared there must be some decided involvement.
12275 Disingenuousness and double dealing seemed to meet him at every turn.
12276 These letters were but the vehicle for gallantry and trick.
12277 It was a child's play, chosen to conceal a deeper game on Frank
12278 Churchill's part.
12279 
12280 With great indignation did he continue to observe him; with great
12281 alarm and distrust, to observe also his two blinded companions.
12282 He saw a short word prepared for Emma, and given to her with a look
12283 sly and demure.  He saw that Emma had soon made it out, and found
12284 it highly entertaining, though it was something which she judged it
12285 proper to appear to censure; for she said, "Nonsense! for shame!"
12286 He heard Frank Churchill next say, with a glance towards Jane,
12287 "I will give it to her--shall I?"--and as clearly heard Emma
12288 opposing it with eager laughing warmth.  "No, no, you must not;
12289 you shall not, indeed."
12290 
12291 It was done however.  This gallant young man, who seemed to love
12292 without feeling, and to recommend himself without complaisance,
12293 directly handed over the word to Miss Fairfax, and with a particular
12294 degree of sedate civility entreated her to study it.  Mr. Knightley's
12295 excessive curiosity to know what this word might be, made him seize
12296 every possible moment for darting his eye towards it, and it was
12297 not long before he saw it to be _Dixon_.  Jane Fairfax's perception
12298 seemed to accompany his; her comprehension was certainly more equal
12299 to the covert meaning, the superior intelligence, of those five letters
12300 so arranged.  She was evidently displeased; looked up, and seeing
12301 herself watched, blushed more deeply than he had ever perceived her,
12302 and saying only, "I did not know that proper names were allowed,"
12303 pushed away the letters with even an angry spirit, and looked
12304 resolved to be engaged by no other word that could be offered.
12305 Her face was averted from those who had made the attack, and turned
12306 towards her aunt.
12307 
12308 "Aye, very true, my dear," cried the latter, though Jane had not
12309 spoken a word--"I was just going to say the same thing.  It is time
12310 for us to be going indeed.  The evening is closing in, and grandmama
12311 will be looking for us.  My dear sir, you are too obliging.
12312 We really must wish you good night."
12313 
12314 Jane's alertness in moving, proved her as ready as her aunt
12315 had preconceived.  She was immediately up, and wanting to quit
12316 the table; but so many were also moving, that she could not get away;
12317 and Mr. Knightley thought he saw another collection of letters anxiously
12318 pushed towards her, and resolutely swept away by her unexamined.
12319 She was afterwards looking for her shawl--Frank Churchill was
12320 looking also--it was growing dusk, and the room was in confusion;
12321 and how they parted, Mr. Knightley could not tell.
12322 
12323 He remained at Hartfield after all the rest, his thoughts full
12324 of what he had seen; so full, that when the candles came to assist
12325 his observations, he must--yes, he certainly must, as a friend--
12326 an anxious friend--give Emma some hint, ask her some question.
12327 He could not see her in a situation of such danger, without trying to
12328 preserve her.  It was his duty.
12329 
12330 "Pray, Emma," said he, "may I ask in what lay the great amusement,
12331 the poignant sting of the last word given to you and Miss Fairfax?
12332 I saw the word, and am curious to know how it could be so very
12333 entertaining to the one, and so very distressing to the other."
12334 
12335 Emma was extremely confused.  She could not endure to give him the
12336 true explanation; for though her suspicions were by no means removed,
12337 she was really ashamed of having ever imparted them.
12338 
12339 "Oh!" she cried in evident embarrassment, "it all meant nothing;
12340 a mere joke among ourselves."
12341 
12342 "The joke," he replied gravely, "seemed confined to you
12343 and Mr. Churchill."
12344 
12345 He had hoped she would speak again, but she did not.  She would
12346 rather busy herself about any thing than speak.  He sat a little
12347 while in doubt.  A variety of evils crossed his mind.  Interference--
12348 fruitless interference.  Emma's confusion, and the acknowledged intimacy,
12349 seemed to declare her affection engaged.  Yet he would speak.
12350 He owed it to her, to risk any thing that might be involved in
12351 an unwelcome interference, rather than her welfare; to encounter
12352 any thing, rather than the remembrance of neglect in such a cause.
12353 
12354 "My dear Emma," said he at last, with earnest kindness, "do you
12355 think you perfectly understand the degree of acquaintance between
12356 the gentleman and lady we have been speaking of?"
12357 
12358 "Between Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax?  Oh! yes, perfectly.--
12359 Why do you make a doubt of it?"
12360 
12361 "Have you never at any time had reason to think that he admired her,
12362 or that she admired him?"
12363 
12364 "Never, never!" she cried with a most open eagerness--"Never, for
12365 the twentieth part of a moment, did such an idea occur to me.
12366 And how could it possibly come into your head?"
12367 
12368 "I have lately imagined that I saw symptoms of attachment between them--
12369 certain expressive looks, which I did not believe meant to be public."
12370 
12371 "Oh! you amuse me excessively.  I am delighted to find that you
12372 can vouchsafe to let your imagination wander--but it will not do--
12373 very sorry to check you in your first essay--but indeed it will
12374 not do.  There is no admiration between them, I do assure you;
12375 and the appearances which have caught you, have arisen from some
12376 peculiar circumstances--feelings rather of a totally different nature--
12377 it is impossible exactly to explain:--there is a good deal of
12378 nonsense in it--but the part which is capable of being communicated,
12379 which is sense, is, that they are as far from any attachment or
12380 admiration for one another, as any two beings in the world can be.
12381 That is, I _presume_ it to be so on her side, and I can _answer_ for its
12382 being so on his.  I will answer for the gentleman's indifference."
12383 
12384 She spoke with a confidence which staggered, with a satisfaction
12385 which silenced, Mr. Knightley.  She was in gay spirits, and would
12386 have prolonged the conversation, wanting to hear the particulars
12387 of his suspicions, every look described, and all the wheres and hows
12388 of a circumstance which highly entertained her:  but his gaiety did
12389 not meet hers.  He found he could not be useful, and his feelings
12390 were too much irritated for talking.  That he might not be irritated
12391 into an absolute fever, by the fire which Mr. Woodhouse's tender
12392 habits required almost every evening throughout the year, he soon
12393 afterwards took a hasty leave, and walked home to the coolness
12394 and solitude of Donwell Abbey.
12395 
12396 
12397 
12398 CHAPTER VI
12399 
12400 
12401 After being long fed with hopes of a speedy visit from Mr. and
12402 Mrs. Suckling, the Highbury world were obliged to endure the mortification
12403 of hearing that they could not possibly come till the autumn.
12404 No such importation of novelties could enrich their intellectual stores
12405 at present.  In the daily interchange of news, they must be again
12406 restricted to the other topics with which for a while the Sucklings'
12407 coming had been united, such as the last accounts of Mrs. Churchill,
12408 whose health seemed every day to supply a different report,
12409 and the situation of Mrs. Weston, whose happiness it was to be hoped
12410 might eventually be as much increased by the arrival of a child,
12411 as that of all her neighbours was by the approach of it.
12412 
12413 Mrs. Elton was very much disappointed.  It was the delay of a great
12414 deal of pleasure and parade.  Her introductions and recommendations
12415 must all wait, and every projected party be still only talked of.
12416 So she thought at first;--but a little consideration convinced
12417 her that every thing need not be put off.  Why should not they
12418 explore to Box Hill though the Sucklings did not come?  They could
12419 go there again with them in the autumn.  It was settled that they
12420 should go to Box Hill.  That there was to be such a party had been
12421 long generally known:  it had even given the idea of another.
12422 Emma had never been to Box Hill; she wished to see what every body
12423 found so well worth seeing, and she and Mr. Weston had agreed
12424 to chuse some fine morning and drive thither.  Two or three more
12425 of the chosen only were to be admitted to join them, and it was to
12426 be done in a quiet, unpretending, elegant way, infinitely superior
12427 to the bustle and preparation, the regular eating and drinking,
12428 and picnic parade of the Eltons and the Sucklings.
12429 
12430 This was so very well understood between them, that Emma could
12431 not but feel some surprise, and a little displeasure, on hearing
12432 from Mr. Weston that he had been proposing to Mrs. Elton, as her
12433 brother and sister had failed her, that the two parties should unite,
12434 and go together; and that as Mrs. Elton had very readily acceded
12435 to it, so it was to be, if she had no objection.  Now, as her
12436 objection was nothing but her very great dislike of Mrs. Elton,
12437 of which Mr. Weston must already be perfectly aware, it was not worth
12438 bringing forward again:--it could not be done without a reproof
12439 to him, which would be giving pain to his wife; and she found
12440 herself therefore obliged to consent to an arrangement which she
12441 would have done a great deal to avoid; an arrangement which would
12442 probably expose her even to the degradation of being said to be of
12443 Mrs. Elton's party!  Every feeling was offended; and the forbearance
12444 of her outward submission left a heavy arrear due of secret severity
12445 in her reflections on the unmanageable goodwill of Mr. Weston's temper.
12446 
12447 "I am glad you approve of what I have done," said he very comfortably.
12448 "But I thought you would.  Such schemes as these are nothing
12449 without numbers.  One cannot have too large a party.  A large party
12450 secures its own amusement.  And she is a good-natured woman after all.
12451 One could not leave her out."
12452 
12453 Emma denied none of it aloud, and agreed to none of it in private.
12454 
12455 It was now the middle of June, and the weather fine; and Mrs. Elton
12456 was growing impatient to name the day, and settle with Mr. Weston
12457 as to pigeon-pies and cold lamb, when a lame carriage-horse threw
12458 every thing into sad uncertainty.  It might be weeks, it might be
12459 only a few days, before the horse were useable; but no preparations
12460 could be ventured on, and it was all melancholy stagnation.
12461 Mrs. Elton's resources were inadequate to such an attack.
12462 
12463 "Is not this most vexations, Knightley?" she cried.--"And such weather
12464 for exploring!--These delays and disappointments are quite odious.
12465 What are we to do?--The year will wear away at this rate,
12466 and nothing done.  Before this time last year I assure you we had
12467 had a delightful exploring party from Maple Grove to Kings Weston."
12468 
12469 "You had better explore to Donwell," replied Mr. Knightley.
12470 "That may be done without horses.  Come, and eat my strawberries.
12471 They are ripening fast."
12472 
12473 If Mr. Knightley did not begin seriously, he was obliged to proceed so,
12474 for his proposal was caught at with delight; and the "Oh!  I should
12475 like it of all things," was not plainer in words than manner.
12476 Donwell was famous for its strawberry-beds, which seemed a plea for
12477 the invitation:  but no plea was necessary; cabbage-beds would have
12478 been enough to tempt the lady, who only wanted to be going somewhere.
12479 She promised him again and again to come--much oftener than
12480 he doubted--and was extremely gratified by such a proof of intimacy,
12481 such a distinguishing compliment as she chose to consider it.
12482 
12483 "You may depend upon me," said she.  "I certainly will come.
12484 Name your day, and I will come.  You will allow me to bring
12485 Jane Fairfax?"
12486 
12487 "I cannot name a day," said he, "till I have spoken to some others
12488 whom I would wish to meet you."
12489 
12490 "Oh! leave all that to me.  Only give me a carte-blanche.--I am
12491 Lady Patroness, you know.  It is my party.  I will bring friends
12492 with me."
12493 
12494 "I hope you will bring Elton," said he:  "but I will not trouble
12495 you to give any other invitations."
12496 
12497 "Oh! now you are looking very sly.  But consider--you need not be afraid
12498 of delegating power to _me_.  I am no young lady on her preferment.
12499 Married women, you know, may be safely authorised.  It is my party.
12500 Leave it all to me.  I will invite your guests."
12501 
12502 "No,"--he calmly replied,--"there is but one married woman in the world
12503 whom I can ever allow to invite what guests she pleases to Donwell,
12504 and that one is--"
12505 
12506 "--Mrs. Weston, I suppose," interrupted Mrs. Elton, rather mortified.
12507 
12508 "No--Mrs. Knightley;--and till she is in being, I will manage
12509 such matters myself."
12510 
12511 "Ah! you are an odd creature!" she cried, satisfied to have no
12512 one preferred to herself.--"You are a humourist, and may say what
12513 you like.  Quite a humourist.  Well, I shall bring Jane with me--
12514 Jane and her aunt.--The rest I leave to you.  I have no objections
12515 at all to meeting the Hartfield family.  Don't scruple.  I know
12516 you are attached to them."
12517 
12518 "You certainly will meet them if I can prevail; and I shall call
12519 on Miss Bates in my way home."
12520 
12521 "That's quite unnecessary; I see Jane every day:--but as you like.
12522 It is to be a morning scheme, you know, Knightley; quite a simple thing.
12523 I shall wear a large bonnet, and bring one of my little baskets
12524 hanging on my arm.  Here,--probably this basket with pink ribbon.
12525 Nothing can be more simple, you see.  And Jane will have such another.
12526 There is to be no form or parade--a sort of gipsy party.  We are
12527 to walk about your gardens, and gather the strawberries ourselves,
12528 and sit under trees;--and whatever else you may like to provide,
12529 it is to be all out of doors--a table spread in the shade, you know.
12530 Every thing as natural and simple as possible.  Is not that your idea?"
12531 
12532 "Not quite.  My idea of the simple and the natural will be to have
12533 the table spread in the dining-room. The nature and the simplicity
12534 of gentlemen and ladies, with their servants and furniture, I think
12535 is best observed by meals within doors.  When you are tired of eating
12536 strawberries in the garden, there shall be cold meat in the house."
12537 
12538 "Well--as you please; only don't have a great set out.  And, by the bye,
12539 can I or my housekeeper be of any use to you with our opinion?--
12540 Pray be sincere, Knightley.  If you wish me to talk to Mrs. Hodges,
12541 or to inspect anything--"
12542 
12543 "I have not the least wish for it, I thank you."
12544 
12545 "Well--but if any difficulties should arise, my housekeeper
12546 is extremely clever."
12547 
12548 "I will answer for it, that mine thinks herself full as clever,
12549 and would spurn any body's assistance."
12550 
12551 "I wish we had a donkey.  The thing would be for us all to come
12552 on donkeys, Jane, Miss Bates, and me--and my caro sposo walking by.
12553 I really must talk to him about purchasing a donkey.  In a country
12554 life I conceive it to be a sort of necessary; for, let a woman have
12555 ever so many resources, it is not possible for her to be always shut
12556 up at home;--and very long walks, you know--in summer there is dust,
12557 and in winter there is dirt."
12558 
12559 "You will not find either, between Donwell and Highbury.
12560 Donwell Lane is never dusty, and now it is perfectly dry.  Come on
12561 a donkey, however, if you prefer it.  You can borrow Mrs. Cole's.
12562 I would wish every thing to be as much to your taste as possible."
12563 
12564 "That I am sure you would.  Indeed I do you justice, my good friend.
12565 Under that peculiar sort of dry, blunt manner, I know you have the
12566 warmest heart.  As I tell Mr. E., you are a thorough humourist.--
12567 Yes, believe me, Knightley, I am fully sensible of your attention
12568 to me in the whole of this scheme.  You have hit upon the very thing
12569 to please me."
12570 
12571 Mr. Knightley had another reason for avoiding a table in the shade.
12572 He wished to persuade Mr. Woodhouse, as well as Emma, to join the party;
12573 and he knew that to have any of them sitting down out of doors
12574 to eat would inevitably make him ill.  Mr. Woodhouse must not,
12575 under the specious pretence of a morning drive, and an hour or two
12576 spent at Donwell, be tempted away to his misery.
12577 
12578 He was invited on good faith.  No lurking horrors were to upbraid
12579 him for his easy credulity.  He did consent.  He had not been
12580 at Donwell for two years.  "Some very fine morning, he, and Emma,
12581 and Harriet, could go very well; and he could sit still with
12582 Mrs. Weston, while the dear girls walked about the gardens.
12583 He did not suppose they could be damp now, in the middle of
12584 the day.  He should like to see the old house again exceedingly,
12585 and should be very happy to meet Mr. and Mrs. Elton, and any other
12586 of his neighbours.--He could not see any objection at all to his,
12587 and Emma's, and Harriet's going there some very fine morning.
12588 He thought it very well done of Mr. Knightley to invite them--
12589 very kind and sensible--much cleverer than dining out.--He was not
12590 fond of dining out."
12591 
12592 Mr. Knightley was fortunate in every body's most ready concurrence.
12593 The invitation was everywhere so well received, that it seemed as if,
12594 like Mrs. Elton, they were all taking the scheme as a particular
12595 compliment to themselves.--Emma and Harriet professed very high
12596 expectations of pleasure from it; and Mr. Weston, unasked,
12597 promised to get Frank over to join them, if possible; a proof
12598 of approbation and gratitude which could have been dispensed with.--
12599 Mr. Knightley was then obliged to say that he should be glad
12600 to see him; and Mr. Weston engaged to lose no time in writing,
12601 and spare no arguments to induce him to come.
12602 
12603 In the meanwhile the lame horse recovered so fast, that the party
12604 to Box Hill was again under happy consideration; and at last Donwell
12605 was settled for one day, and Box Hill for the next,--the weather
12606 appearing exactly right.
12607 
12608 Under a bright mid-day sun, at almost Midsummer, Mr. Woodhouse
12609 was safely conveyed in his carriage, with one window down,
12610 to partake of this al-fresco party; and in one of the most
12611 comfortable rooms in the Abbey, especially prepared for him by a
12612 fire all the morning, he was happily placed, quite at his ease,
12613 ready to talk with pleasure of what had been achieved, and advise
12614 every body to come and sit down, and not to heat themselves.--
12615 Mrs. Weston, who seemed to have walked there on purpose to be tired,
12616 and sit all the time with him, remained, when all the others
12617 were invited or persuaded out, his patient listener and sympathiser.
12618 
12619 It was so long since Emma had been at the Abbey, that as soon as she
12620 was satisfied of her father's comfort, she was glad to leave him,
12621 and look around her; eager to refresh and correct her memory with
12622 more particular observation, more exact understanding of a house
12623 and grounds which must ever be so interesting to her and all her family.
12624 
12625 She felt all the honest pride and complacency which her alliance
12626 with the present and future proprietor could fairly warrant,
12627 as she viewed the respectable size and style of the building,
12628 its suitable, becoming, characteristic situation, low and sheltered--
12629 its ample gardens stretching down to meadows washed by a stream,
12630 of which the Abbey, with all the old neglect of prospect,
12631 had scarcely a sight--and its abundance of timber in rows and avenues,
12632 which neither fashion nor extravagance had rooted up.--The house
12633 was larger than Hartfield, and totally unlike it, covering a good
12634 deal of ground, rambling and irregular, with many comfortable,
12635 and one or two handsome rooms.--It was just what it ought to be,
12636 and it looked what it was--and Emma felt an increasing respect
12637 for it, as the residence of a family of such true gentility,
12638 untainted in blood and understanding.--Some faults of temper John
12639 Knightley had; but Isabella had connected herself unexceptionably.
12640 She had given them neither men, nor names, nor places, that could
12641 raise a blush.  These were pleasant feelings, and she walked about
12642 and indulged them till it was necessary to do as the others did,
12643 and collect round the strawberry-beds.--The whole party were assembled,
12644 excepting Frank Churchill, who was expected every moment from Richmond;
12645 and Mrs. Elton, in all her apparatus of happiness, her large bonnet
12646 and her basket, was very ready to lead the way in gathering,
12647 accepting, or talking--strawberries, and only strawberries,
12648 could now be thought or spoken of.--"The best fruit in England--
12649 every body's favourite--always wholesome.--These the finest beds
12650 and finest sorts.--Delightful to gather for one's self--the only way
12651 of really enjoying them.--Morning decidedly the best time--never tired--
12652 every sort good--hautboy infinitely superior--no comparison--
12653 the others hardly eatable--hautboys very scarce--Chili preferred--
12654 white wood finest flavour of all--price of strawberries in London--
12655 abundance about Bristol--Maple Grove--cultivation--beds when to
12656 be renewed--gardeners thinking exactly different--no general rule--
12657 gardeners never to be put out of their way--delicious fruit--
12658 only too rich to be eaten much of--inferior to cherries--
12659 currants more refreshing--only objection to gathering strawberries
12660 the stooping--glaring sun--tired to death--could bear it no longer--
12661 must go and sit in the shade."
12662 
12663 Such, for half an hour, was the conversation--interrupted only
12664 once by Mrs. Weston, who came out, in her solicitude after her
12665 son-in-law, to inquire if he were come--and she was a little uneasy.--
12666 She had some fears of his horse.
12667 
12668 Seats tolerably in the shade were found; and now Emma was obliged
12669 to overhear what Mrs. Elton and Jane Fairfax were talking of.--
12670 A situation, a most desirable situation, was in question.  Mrs. Elton
12671 had received notice of it that morning, and was in raptures.
12672 It was not with Mrs. Suckling, it was not with Mrs. Bragge,
12673 but in felicity and splendour it fell short only of them:  it was
12674 with a cousin of Mrs. Bragge, an acquaintance of Mrs. Suckling,
12675 a lady known at Maple Grove.  Delightful, charming, superior,
12676 first circles, spheres, lines, ranks, every thing--and Mrs. Elton
12677 was wild to have the offer closed with immediately.--On her side,
12678 all was warmth, energy, and triumph--and she positively refused
12679 to take her friend's negative, though Miss Fairfax continued
12680 to assure her that she would not at present engage in any thing,
12681 repeating the same motives which she had been heard to urge before.--
12682 Still Mrs. Elton insisted on being authorised to write an acquiescence
12683 by the morrow's post.--How Jane could bear it at all, was astonishing
12684 to Emma.--She did look vexed, she did speak pointedly--and at last,
12685 with a decision of action unusual to her, proposed a removal.--
12686 "Should not they walk?  Would not Mr. Knightley shew them the gardens--
12687 all the gardens?--She wished to see the whole extent."--The pertinacity
