12688 of her friend seemed more than she could bear.
12689 
12690 It was hot; and after walking some time over the gardens in a scattered,
12691 dispersed way, scarcely any three together, they insensibly
12692 followed one another to the delicious shade of a broad short
12693 avenue of limes, which stretching beyond the garden at an equal
12694 distance from the river, seemed the finish of the pleasure grounds.--
12695 It led to nothing; nothing but a view at the end over a low stone
12696 wall with high pillars, which seemed intended, in their erection,
12697 to give the appearance of an approach to the house, which never had
12698 been there.  Disputable, however, as might be the taste of such
12699 a termination, it was in itself a charming walk, and the view
12700 which closed it extremely pretty.--The considerable slope, at nearly
12701 the foot of which the Abbey stood, gradually acquired a steeper
12702 form beyond its grounds; and at half a mile distant was a bank
12703 of considerable abruptness and grandeur, well clothed with wood;--
12704 and at the bottom of this bank, favourably placed and sheltered,
12705 rose the Abbey Mill Farm, with meadows in front, and the river
12706 making a close and handsome curve around it.
12707 
12708 It was a sweet view--sweet to the eye and the mind.  English verdure,
12709 English culture, English comfort, seen under a sun bright,
12710 without being oppressive.
12711 
12712 In this walk Emma and Mr. Weston found all the others assembled;
12713 and towards this view she immediately perceived Mr. Knightley
12714 and Harriet distinct from the rest, quietly leading the way.
12715 Mr. Knightley and Harriet!--It was an odd tete-a-tete; but she was
12716 glad to see it.--There had been a time when he would have scorned
12717 her as a companion, and turned from her with little ceremony.
12718 Now they seemed in pleasant conversation.  There had been a time
12719 also when Emma would have been sorry to see Harriet in a spot
12720 so favourable for the Abbey Mill Farm; but now she feared it not.
12721 It might be safely viewed with all its appendages of prosperity
12722 and beauty, its rich pastures, spreading flocks, orchard in blossom,
12723 and light column of smoke ascending.--She joined them at the wall,
12724 and found them more engaged in talking than in looking around.
12725 He was giving Harriet information as to modes of agriculture, etc.
12726 and Emma received a smile which seemed to say, "These are my
12727 own concerns.  I have a right to talk on such subjects, without being
12728 suspected of introducing Robert Martin."--She did not suspect him.
12729 It was too old a story.--Robert Martin had probably ceased to think
12730 of Harriet.--They took a few turns together along the walk.--The shade
12731 was most refreshing, and Emma found it the pleasantest part of
12732 the day.
12733 
12734 The next remove was to the house; they must all go in and eat;--
12735 and they were all seated and busy, and still Frank Churchill did
12736 not come.  Mrs. Weston looked, and looked in vain.  His father would
12737 not own himself uneasy, and laughed at her fears; but she could
12738 not be cured of wishing that he would part with his black mare.
12739 He had expressed himself as to coming, with more than common certainty.
12740 "His aunt was so much better, that he had not a doubt of getting
12741 over to them."--Mrs. Churchill's state, however, as many were ready
12742 to remind her, was liable to such sudden variation as might disappoint
12743 her nephew in the most reasonable dependence--and Mrs. Weston
12744 was at last persuaded to believe, or to say, that it must be
12745 by some attack of Mrs. Churchill that he was prevented coming.--
12746 Emma looked at Harriet while the point was under consideration;
12747 she behaved very well, and betrayed no emotion.
12748 
12749 The cold repast was over, and the party were to go out once more
12750 to see what had not yet been seen, the old Abbey fish-ponds;
12751 perhaps get as far as the clover, which was to be begun cutting
12752 on the morrow, or, at any rate, have the pleasure of being hot,
12753 and growing cool again.--Mr. Woodhouse, who had already taken
12754 his little round in the highest part of the gardens, where no
12755 damps from the river were imagined even by him, stirred no more;
12756 and his daughter resolved to remain with him, that Mrs. Weston
12757 might be persuaded away by her husband to the exercise and variety
12758 which her spirits seemed to need.
12759 
12760 Mr. Knightley had done all in his power for Mr. Woodhouse's
12761 entertainment.  Books of engravings, drawers of medals, cameos,
12762 corals, shells, and every other family collection within his cabinets,
12763 had been prepared for his old friend, to while away the morning;
12764 and the kindness had perfectly answered.  Mr. Woodhouse had been
12765 exceedingly well amused.  Mrs. Weston had been shewing them all to him,
12766 and now he would shew them all to Emma;--fortunate in having no other
12767 resemblance to a child, than in a total want of taste for what he saw,
12768 for he was slow, constant, and methodical.--Before this second looking
12769 over was begun, however, Emma walked into the hall for the sake
12770 of a few moments' free observation of the entrance and ground-plot
12771 of the house--and was hardly there, when Jane Fairfax appeared,
12772 coming quickly in from the garden, and with a look of escape.--
12773 Little expecting to meet Miss Woodhouse so soon, there was a start
12774 at first; but Miss Woodhouse was the very person she was in quest of.
12775 
12776 "Will you be so kind," said she, "when I am missed, as to say
12777 that I am gone home?--I am going this moment.--My aunt is not aware
12778 how late it is, nor how long we have been absent--but I am sure we
12779 shall be wanted, and I am determined to go directly.--I have said
12780 nothing about it to any body.  It would only be giving trouble
12781 and distress.  Some are gone to the ponds, and some to the lime walk.
12782 Till they all come in I shall not be missed; and when they do,
12783 will you have the goodness to say that I am gone?"
12784 
12785 "Certainly, if you wish it;--but you are not going to walk
12786 to Highbury alone?"
12787 
12788 "Yes--what should hurt me?--I walk fast.  I shall be at home
12789 in twenty minutes."
12790 
12791 "But it is too far, indeed it is, to be walking quite alone.
12792 Let my father's servant go with you.--Let me order the carriage.
12793 It can be round in five minutes."
12794 
12795 "Thank you, thank you--but on no account.--I would rather walk.--
12796 And for _me_ to be afraid of walking alone!--I, who may so soon have
12797 to guard others!"
12798 
12799 She spoke with great agitation; and Emma very feelingly replied,
12800 "That can be no reason for your being exposed to danger now.
12801 I must order the carriage.  The heat even would be danger.--You are
12802 fatigued already."
12803 
12804 "I am,"--she answered--"I am fatigued; but it is not the sort
12805 of fatigue--quick walking will refresh me.--Miss Woodhouse, we all
12806 know at times what it is to be wearied in spirits.  Mine, I confess,
12807 are exhausted.  The greatest kindness you can shew me, will be to let
12808 me have my own way, and only say that I am gone when it is necessary."
12809 
12810 Emma had not another word to oppose.  She saw it all; and entering
12811 into her feelings, promoted her quitting the house immediately,
12812 and watched her safely off with the zeal of a friend.  Her parting
12813 look was grateful--and her parting words, "Oh!  Miss Woodhouse,
12814 the comfort of being sometimes alone!"--seemed to burst from
12815 an overcharged heart, and to describe somewhat of the continual
12816 endurance to be practised by her, even towards some of those who
12817 loved her best.
12818 
12819 "Such a home, indeed! such an aunt!" said Emma, as she turned back
12820 into the hall again.  "I do pity you.  And the more sensibility
12821 you betray of their just horrors, the more I shall like you."
12822 
12823 Jane had not been gone a quarter of an hour, and they had only
12824 accomplished some views of St. Mark's Place, Venice, when Frank
12825 Churchill entered the room.  Emma had not been thinking of him,
12826 she had forgotten to think of him--but she was very glad to see him.
12827 Mrs. Weston would be at ease.  The black mare was blameless;
12828 _they_ were right who had named Mrs. Churchill as the cause.
12829 He had been detained by a temporary increase of illness in her;
12830 a nervous seizure, which had lasted some hours--and he had quite given
12831 up every thought of coming, till very late;--and had he known how hot
12832 a ride he should have, and how late, with all his hurry, he must be,
12833 he believed he should not have come at all.  The heat was excessive;
12834 he had never suffered any thing like it--almost wished he had staid
12835 at home--nothing killed him like heat--he could bear any degree of cold,
12836 etc., but heat was intolerable--and he sat down, at the greatest
12837 possible distance from the slight remains of Mr. Woodhouse's fire,
12838 looking very deplorable.
12839 
12840 "You will soon be cooler, if you sit still," said Emma.
12841 
12842 "As soon as I am cooler I shall go back again.  I could very
12843 ill be spared--but such a point had been made of my coming!
12844 You will all be going soon I suppose; the whole party breaking up.
12845 I met _one_ as I came--Madness in such weather!--absolute madness!"
12846 
12847 Emma listened, and looked, and soon perceived that Frank Churchill's
12848 state might be best defined by the expressive phrase of being
12849 out of humour.  Some people were always cross when they were hot.
12850 Such might be his constitution; and as she knew that eating
12851 and drinking were often the cure of such incidental complaints,
12852 she recommended his taking some refreshment; he would find abundance
12853 of every thing in the dining-room--and she humanely pointed out
12854 the door.
12855 
12856 "No--he should not eat.  He was not hungry; it would only make
12857 him hotter."  In two minutes, however, he relented in his own favour;
12858 and muttering something about spruce-beer, walked off.  Emma returned
12859 all her attention to her father, saying in secret--
12860 
12861 "I am glad I have done being in love with him.  I should not like a
12862 man who is so soon discomposed by a hot morning.  Harriet's sweet
12863 easy temper will not mind it."
12864 
12865 He was gone long enough to have had a very comfortable meal, and came
12866 back all the better--grown quite cool--and, with good manners,
12867 like himself--able to draw a chair close to them, take an interest
12868 in their employment; and regret, in a reasonable way, that he
12869 should be so late.  He was not in his best spirits, but seemed
12870 trying to improve them; and, at last, made himself talk nonsense
12871 very agreeably.  They were looking over views in Swisserland.
12872 
12873 "As soon as my aunt gets well, I shall go abroad," said he.
12874 "I shall never be easy till I have seen some of these places.
12875 You will have my sketches, some time or other, to look at--or my tour
12876 to read--or my poem.  I shall do something to expose myself."
12877 
12878 "That may be--but not by sketches in Swisserland.  You will
12879 never go to Swisserland.  Your uncle and aunt will never allow
12880 you to leave England."
12881 
12882 "They may be induced to go too.  A warm climate may be prescribed
12883 for her.  I have more than half an expectation of our all going abroad.
12884 I assure you I have.  I feel a strong persuasion, this morning,
12885 that I shall soon be abroad.  I ought to travel.  I am tired
12886 of doing nothing.  I want a change.  I am serious, Miss Woodhouse,
12887 whatever your penetrating eyes may fancy--I am sick of England--
12888 and would leave it to-morrow, if I could."
12889 
12890 "You are sick of prosperity and indulgence.  Cannot you invent
12891 a few hardships for yourself, and be contented to stay?"
12892 
12893 "_I_ sick of prosperity and indulgence!  You are quite mistaken.
12894 I do not look upon myself as either prosperous or indulged.  I am
12895 thwarted in every thing material.  I do not consider myself at all
12896 a fortunate person."
12897 
12898 "You are not quite so miserable, though, as when you first came.
12899 Go and eat and drink a little more, and you will do very well.
12900 Another slice of cold meat, another draught of Madeira and water,
12901 will make you nearly on a par with the rest of us."
12902 
12903 "No--I shall not stir.  I shall sit by you.  You are my best cure."
12904 
12905 "We are going to Box Hill to-morrow;--you will join us.
12906 It is not Swisserland, but it will be something for a young
12907 man so much in want of a change.  You will stay, and go with us?"
12908 
12909 "No, certainly not; I shall go home in the cool of the evening."
12910 
12911 "But you may come again in the cool of to-morrow morning."
12912 
12913 "No--It will not be worth while.  If I come, I shall be cross."
12914 
12915 "Then pray stay at Richmond."
12916 
12917 "But if I do, I shall be crosser still.  I can never bear to think
12918 of you all there without me."
12919 
12920 "These are difficulties which you must settle for yourself.
12921 Chuse your own degree of crossness.  I shall press you no more."
12922 
12923 The rest of the party were now returning, and all were soon collected.
12924 With some there was great joy at the sight of Frank Churchill;
12925 others took it very composedly; but there was a very general distress
12926 and disturbance on Miss Fairfax's disappearance being explained.
12927 That it was time for every body to go, concluded the subject; and with
12928 a short final arrangement for the next day's scheme, they parted.
12929 Frank Churchill's little inclination to exclude himself increased
12930 so much, that his last words to Emma were,
12931 
12932 "Well;--if _you_ wish me to stay and join the party, I will."
12933 
12934 She smiled her acceptance; and nothing less than a summons from
12935 Richmond was to take him back before the following evening.
12936 
12937 
12938 
12939 CHAPTER VII
12940 
12941 
12942 They had a very fine day for Box Hill; and all the other outward
12943 circumstances of arrangement, accommodation, and punctuality,
12944 were in favour of a pleasant party.  Mr. Weston directed the whole,
12945 officiating safely between Hartfield and the Vicarage, and every
12946 body was in good time.  Emma and Harriet went together; Miss Bates
12947 and her niece, with the Eltons; the gentlemen on horseback.
12948 Mrs. Weston remained with Mr. Woodhouse.  Nothing was wanting
12949 but to be happy when they got there.  Seven miles were travelled
12950 in expectation of enjoyment, and every body had a burst of admiration
12951 on first arriving; but in the general amount of the day there
12952 was deficiency.  There was a languor, a want of spirits, a want of union,
12953 which could not be got over.  They separated too much into parties.
12954 The Eltons walked together; Mr. Knightley took charge of Miss
12955 Bates and Jane; and Emma and Harriet belonged to Frank Churchill.
12956 And Mr. Weston tried, in vain, to make them harmonise better.  It seemed
12957 at first an accidental division, but it never materially varied.
12958 Mr. and Mrs. Elton, indeed, shewed no unwillingness to mix,
12959 and be as agreeable as they could; but during the two whole hours
12960 that were spent on the hill, there seemed a principle of separation,
12961 between the other parties, too strong for any fine prospects, or any
12962 cold collation, or any cheerful Mr. Weston, to remove.
12963 
12964 At first it was downright dulness to Emma.  She had never seen Frank
12965 Churchill so silent and stupid.  He said nothing worth hearing--
12966 looked without seeing--admired without intelligence--listened without
12967 knowing what she said.  While he was so dull, it was no wonder that
12968 Harriet should be dull likewise; and they were both insufferable.
12969 
12970 When they all sat down it was better; to her taste a great deal better,
12971 for Frank Churchill grew talkative and gay, making her his first object.
12972 Every distinguishing attention that could be paid, was paid to her.
12973 To amuse her, and be agreeable in her eyes, seemed all that he
12974 cared for--and Emma, glad to be enlivened, not sorry to be flattered,
12975 was gay and easy too, and gave him all the friendly encouragement,
12976 the admission to be gallant, which she had ever given in the first
12977 and most animating period of their acquaintance; but which now,
12978 in her own estimation, meant nothing, though in the judgment of most
12979 people looking on it must have had such an appearance as no English
12980 word but flirtation could very well describe.  "Mr. Frank Churchill
12981 and Miss Woodhouse flirted together excessively."  They were laying
12982 themselves open to that very phrase--and to having it sent off
12983 in a letter to Maple Grove by one lady, to Ireland by another.
12984 Not that Emma was gay and thoughtless from any real felicity;
12985 it was rather because she felt less happy than she had expected.
12986 She laughed because she was disappointed; and though she liked him
12987 for his attentions, and thought them all, whether in friendship,
12988 admiration, or playfulness, extremely judicious, they were not winning
12989 back her heart.  She still intended him for her friend.
12990 
12991 "How much I am obliged to you," said he, "for telling me to come to-day!--
12992 If it had not been for you, I should certainly have lost all the
12993 happiness of this party.  I had quite determined to go away again."
12994 
12995 "Yes, you were very cross; and I do not know what about,
12996 except that you were too late for the best strawberries.
12997 I was a kinder friend than you deserved.  But you were humble.
12998 You begged hard to be commanded to come."
12999 
13000 "Don't say I was cross.  I was fatigued.  The heat overcame me."
13001 
13002 "It is hotter to-day."
13003 
13004 "Not to my feelings.  I am perfectly comfortable to-day."
13005 
13006 "You are comfortable because you are under command."
13007 
13008 "Your command?--Yes."
13009 
13010 "Perhaps I intended you to say so, but I meant self-command. You had,
13011 somehow or other, broken bounds yesterday, and run away from your
13012 own management; but to-day you are got back again--and as I cannot
13013 be always with you, it is best to believe your temper under your
13014 own command rather than mine."
13015 
13016 "It comes to the same thing.  I can have no self-command without
13017 a motive.  You order me, whether you speak or not.  And you can
13018 be always with me.  You are always with me."
13019 
13020 "Dating from three o'clock yesterday.  My perpetual influence
13021 could not begin earlier, or you would not have been so much
13022 out of humour before."
13023 
13024 "Three o'clock yesterday!  That is your date.  I thought I had seen
13025 you first in February."
13026 
13027 "Your gallantry is really unanswerable.  But (lowering her voice)--
13028 nobody speaks except ourselves, and it is rather too much to be
13029 talking nonsense for the entertainment of seven silent people."
13030 
13031 "I say nothing of which I am ashamed," replied he, with lively impudence.
13032 "I saw you first in February.  Let every body on the Hill hear me if
13033 they can.  Let my accents swell to Mickleham on one side, and Dorking
13034 on the other.  I saw you first in February."  And then whispering--
13035 "Our companions are excessively stupid.  What shall we do to rouse them?
13036 Any nonsense will serve.  They _shall_ talk.  Ladies and gentlemen,
13037 I am ordered by Miss Woodhouse (who, wherever she is, presides)
13038 to say, that she desires to know what you are all thinking of?"
13039 
13040 Some laughed, and answered good-humouredly. Miss Bates said a great deal;
13041 Mrs. Elton swelled at the idea of Miss Woodhouse's presiding;
13042 Mr. Knightley's answer was the most distinct.
13043 
13044 "Is Miss Woodhouse sure that she would like to hear what we are
13045 all thinking of?"
13046 
13047 "Oh! no, no"--cried Emma, laughing as carelessly as she could--
13048 "Upon no account in the world.  It is the very last thing I
13049 would stand the brunt of just now.  Let me hear any thing rather
13050 than what you are all thinking of.  I will not say quite all.
13051 There are one or two, perhaps, (glancing at Mr. Weston and Harriet,)
13052 whose thoughts I might not be afraid of knowing."
13053 
13054 "It is a sort of thing," cried Mrs. Elton emphatically,
13055 "which _I_ should not have thought myself privileged to
13056 inquire into.  Though, perhaps, as the _Chaperon_ of the party--
13057 _I_ never was in any circle--exploring parties--young ladies--married women--"
13058 
13059 Her mutterings were chiefly to her husband; and he murmured,
13060 in reply,
13061 
13062 "Very true, my love, very true.  Exactly so, indeed--quite unheard of--
13063 but some ladies say any thing.  Better pass it off as a joke.
13064 Every body knows what is due to _you_."
13065 
13066 "It will not do," whispered Frank to Emma; "they are most
13067 of them affronted.  I will attack them with more address.
13068 Ladies and gentlemen--I am ordered by Miss Woodhouse to say, that she
13069 waives her right of knowing exactly what you may all be thinking of,
13070 and only requires something very entertaining from each of you,
13071 in a general way.  Here are seven of you, besides myself, (who, she
13072 is pleased to say, am very entertaining already,) and she only
13073 demands from each of you either one thing very clever, be it prose
13074 or verse, original or repeated--or two things moderately clever--
13075 or three things very dull indeed, and she engages to laugh heartily
13076 at them all."
13077 
13078 "Oh! very well," exclaimed Miss Bates, "then I need not be uneasy.
13079 `Three things very dull indeed.'  That will just do for me, you know.
13080 I shall be sure to say three dull things as soon as ever I open
13081 my mouth, shan't I? (looking round with the most good-humoured
13082 dependence on every body's assent)--Do not you all think I shall?"
13083 
13084 Emma could not resist.
13085 
13086 "Ah! ma'am, but there may be a difficulty.  Pardon me--but you
13087 will be limited as to number--only three at once."
13088 
13089 Miss Bates, deceived by the mock ceremony of her manner, did not
13090 immediately catch her meaning; but, when it burst on her, it could
13091 not anger, though a slight blush shewed that it could pain her.
13092 
13093 "Ah!--well--to be sure.  Yes, I see what she means, (turning to
13094 Mr. Knightley,) and I will try to hold my tongue.  I must make
13095 myself very disagreeable, or she would not have said such a thing
13096 to an old friend."
13097 
13098 "I like your plan," cried Mr. Weston.  "Agreed, agreed.  I will do
13099 my best.  I am making a conundrum.  How will a conundrum reckon?"
13100 
13101 "Low, I am afraid, sir, very low," answered his son;--"but we shall
13102 be indulgent--especially to any one who leads the way."
13103 
13104 "No, no," said Emma, "it will not reckon low.  A conundrum of
13105 Mr. Weston's shall clear him and his next neighbour.  Come, sir,
13106 pray let me hear it."
13107 
13108 "I doubt its being very clever myself," said Mr. Weston.
13109 "It is too much a matter of fact, but here it is.--What two letters
13110 of the alphabet are there, that express perfection?"
13111 
13112 "What two letters!--express perfection!  I am sure I do not know."
13113 
13114 "Ah! you will never guess.  You, (to Emma), I am certain, will
13115 never guess.--I will tell you.--M. and A.--Em-ma.--Do you understand?"
13116 
13117 Understanding and gratification came together.  It might be a very
13118 indifferent piece of wit, but Emma found a great deal to laugh
13119 at and enjoy in it--and so did Frank and Harriet.--It did not seem
13120 to touch the rest of the party equally; some looked very stupid
13121 about it, and Mr. Knightley gravely said,
13122 
13123 "This explains the sort of clever thing that is wanted, and Mr. Weston
13124 has done very well for himself; but he must have knocked up every
13125 body else.  _Perfection_ should not have come quite so soon."
13126 
13127 "Oh! for myself, I protest I must be excused," said Mrs. Elton;
13128 "_I_ really cannot attempt--I am not at all fond of the sort of thing.
13129 I had an acrostic once sent to me upon my own name, which I was not
13130 at all pleased with.  I knew who it came from.  An abominable puppy!--
13131 You know who I mean (nodding to her husband). These kind of things
13132 are very well at Christmas, when one is sitting round the fire;
13133 but quite out of place, in my opinion, when one is exploring
13134 about the country in summer.  Miss Woodhouse must excuse me.
13135 I am not one of those who have witty things at every body's service.
13136 I do not pretend to be a wit.  I have a great deal of vivacity
13137 in my own way, but I really must be allowed to judge when to speak
13138 and when to hold my tongue.  Pass us, if you please, Mr. Churchill.
13139 Pass Mr. E., Knightley, Jane, and myself.  We have nothing clever to say--
13140 not one of us.
13141 
13142 "Yes, yes, pray pass _me_," added her husband, with a sort of
13143 sneering consciousness; "_I_ have nothing to say that can entertain
13144 Miss Woodhouse, or any other young lady.  An old married man--
13145 quite good for nothing.  Shall we walk, Augusta?"
13146 
13147 "With all my heart.  I am really tired of exploring so long
13148 on one spot.  Come, Jane, take my other arm."
13149 
13150 Jane declined it, however, and the husband and wife walked off.
13151 "Happy couple!" said Frank Churchill, as soon as they were out
13152 of hearing:--"How well they suit one another!--Very lucky--marrying as
13153 they did, upon an acquaintance formed only in a public place!--They only
13154 knew each other, I think, a few weeks in Bath!  Peculiarly lucky!--
13155 for as to any real knowledge of a person's disposition that Bath,
13156 or any public place, can give--it is all nothing; there can be
13157 no knowledge.  It is only by seeing women in their own homes,
13158 among their own set, just as they always are, that you can form
13159 any just judgment.  Short of that, it is all guess and luck--
13160 and will generally be ill-luck. How many a man has committed himself
13161 on a short acquaintance, and rued it all the rest of his life!"
13162 
13163 Miss Fairfax, who had seldom spoken before, except among her
13164 own confederates, spoke now.
13165 
13166 "Such things do occur, undoubtedly."--She was stopped by a cough.
13167 Frank Churchill turned towards her to listen.
13168 
13169 "You were speaking," said he, gravely.  She recovered her voice.
13170 
13171 "I was only going to observe, that though such unfortunate circumstances
13172 do sometimes occur both to men and women, I cannot imagine them
13173 to be very frequent.  A hasty and imprudent attachment may arise--
13174 but there is generally time to recover from it afterwards.  I would
13175 be understood to mean, that it can be only weak, irresolute characters,
13176 (whose happiness must be always at the mercy of chance,)
13177 who will suffer an unfortunate acquaintance to be an inconvenience,
13178 an oppression for ever."
13179 
13180 He made no answer; merely looked, and bowed in submission; and soon
13181 afterwards said, in a lively tone,
13182 
13183 "Well, I have so little confidence in my own judgment, that whenever
13184 I marry, I hope some body will chuse my wife for me.  Will you?
13185 (turning to Emma.) Will you chuse a wife for me?--I am sure I
13186 should like any body fixed on by you.  You provide for the family,
13187 you know, (with a smile at his father). Find some body for me.
13188 I am in no hurry.  Adopt her, educate her."
13189 
13190 "And make her like myself."
13191 
13192 "By all means, if you can."
13193 
13194 "Very well.  I undertake the commission.  You shall have a charming wife."
13195 
13196 "She must be very lively, and have hazle eyes.  I care for nothing else.
13197 I shall go abroad for a couple of years--and when I return,
13198 I shall come to you for my wife.  Remember."
13199 
13200 Emma was in no danger of forgetting.  It was a commission to touch every
13201 favourite feeling.  Would not Harriet be the very creature described?
13202 Hazle eyes excepted, two years more might make her all that he wished.
13203 He might even have Harriet in his thoughts at the moment;
13204 who could say?  Referring the education to her seemed to imply it.
13205 
13206 "Now, ma'am," said Jane to her aunt, "shall we join Mrs. Elton?"
13207 
13208 "If you please, my dear.  With all my heart.  I am quite ready.
13209 I was ready to have gone with her, but this will do just as well.
13210 We shall soon overtake her.  There she is--no, that's somebody else.
13211 That's one of the ladies in the Irish car party, not at all like her.--
13212 Well, I declare--"
13213 
13214 They walked off, followed in half a minute by Mr. Knightley.
13215 Mr. Weston, his son, Emma, and Harriet, only remained; and the young
13216 man's spirits now rose to a pitch almost unpleasant.  Even Emma grew
13217 tired at last of flattery and merriment, and wished herself rather
13218 walking quietly about with any of the others, or sitting almost alone,
13219 and quite unattended to, in tranquil observation of the beautiful
13220 views beneath her.  The appearance of the servants looking out
13221 for them to give notice of the carriages was a joyful sight;
13222 and even the bustle of collecting and preparing to depart,
13223 and the solicitude of Mrs. Elton to have _her_ carriage first,
13224 were gladly endured, in the prospect of the quiet drive home which was
13225 to close the very questionable enjoyments of this day of pleasure.
13226 Such another scheme, composed of so many ill-assorted people,
13227 she hoped never to be betrayed into again.
13228 
13229 While waiting for the carriage, she found Mr. Knightley by her side.
13230 He looked around, as if to see that no one were near, and then said,
13231 
13232 "Emma, I must once more speak to you as I have been used to do:
13233 a privilege rather endured than allowed, perhaps, but I must still
13234 use it.  I cannot see you acting wrong, without a remonstrance.
13235 How could you be so unfeeling to Miss Bates?  How could you be so
13236 insolent in your wit to a woman of her character, age, and situation?--
13237 Emma, I had not thought it possible."
13238 
13239 Emma recollected, blushed, was sorry, but tried to laugh it off.
13240 
13241 "Nay, how could I help saying what I did?--Nobody could have helped it.
13242 It was not so very bad.  I dare say she did not understand me."
13243 
13244 "I assure you she did.  She felt your full meaning.  She has talked
13245 of it since.  I wish you could have heard how she talked of it--
13246 with what candour and generosity.  I wish you could have heard her
13247 honouring your forbearance, in being able to pay her such attentions,
13248 as she was for ever receiving from yourself and your father,
13249 when her society must be so irksome."
13250 
13251 "Oh!" cried Emma, "I know there is not a better creature in the world:
13252 but you must allow, that what is good and what is ridiculous are
13253 most unfortunately blended in her."
13254 
13255 "They are blended," said he, "I acknowledge; and, were she prosperous,
13256 I could allow much for the occasional prevalence of the ridiculous
13257 over the good.  Were she a woman of fortune, I would leave every
13258 harmless absurdity to take its chance, I would not quarrel with you
13259 for any liberties of manner.  Were she your equal in situation--
13260 but, Emma, consider how far this is from being the case.  She is poor;
13261 she has sunk from the comforts she was born to; and, if she live
13262 to old age, must probably sink more.  Her situation should secure
13263 your compassion.  It was badly done, indeed!  You, whom she had known
13264 from an infant, whom she had seen grow up from a period when her
13265 notice was an honour, to have you now, in thoughtless spirits,
13266 and the pride of the moment, laugh at her, humble her--and before
13267 her niece, too--and before others, many of whom (certainly _some_,)
13268 would be entirely guided by _your_ treatment of her.--This is not
13269 pleasant to you, Emma--and it is very far from pleasant to me;
13270 but I must, I will,--I will tell you truths while I can;
13271 satisfied with proving myself your friend by very faithful counsel,
13272 and trusting that you will some time or other do me greater justice
13273 than you can do now."
13274 
13275 While they talked, they were advancing towards the carriage;
13276 it was ready; and, before she could speak again, he had handed her in.
13277 He had misinterpreted the feelings which had kept her face averted,
13278 and her tongue motionless.  They were combined only of anger
13279 against herself, mortification, and deep concern.  She had not
13280 been able to speak; and, on entering the carriage, sunk back
13281 for a moment overcome--then reproaching herself for having taken
13282 no leave, making no acknowledgment, parting in apparent sullenness,
13283 she looked out with voice and hand eager to shew a difference;
13284 but it was just too late.  He had turned away, and the horses were
13285 in motion.  She continued to look back, but in vain; and soon,
13286 with what appeared unusual speed, they were half way down the hill,
13287 and every thing left far behind.  She was vexed beyond what could
13288 have been expressed--almost beyond what she could conceal.
13289 Never had she felt so agitated, mortified, grieved, at any circumstance
13290 in her life.  She was most forcibly struck.  The truth of this
13291 representation there was no denying.  She felt it at her heart.
13292 How could she have been so brutal, so cruel to Miss Bates!  How could
13293 she have exposed herself to such ill opinion in any one she valued!
13294 And how suffer him to leave her without saying one word of gratitude,
13295 of concurrence, of common kindness!
13296 
13297 Time did not compose her.  As she reflected more, she seemed
13298 but to feel it more.  She never had been so depressed.  Happily it
13299 was not necessary to speak.  There was only Harriet, who seemed not
13300 in spirits herself, fagged, and very willing to be silent; and Emma
13301 felt the tears running down her cheeks almost all the way home,
13302 without being at any trouble to check them, extraordinary as they were.
13303 
13304 
13305 
13306 CHAPTER VIII
13307 
13308 
13309 The wretchedness of a scheme to Box Hill was in Emma's thoughts all
13310 the evening.  How it might be considered by the rest of the party,
13311 she could not tell.  They, in their different homes, and their different
13312 ways, might be looking back on it with pleasure; but in her view it
13313 was a morning more completely misspent, more totally bare of rational
13314 satisfaction at the time, and more to be abhorred in recollection,
13315 than any she had ever passed.  A whole evening of back-gammon with
13316 her father, was felicity to it.  _There_, indeed, lay real pleasure,
13317 for there she was giving up the sweetest hours of the twenty-four
13318 to his comfort; and feeling that, unmerited as might be the degree
13319 of his fond affection and confiding esteem, she could not, in her
13320 general conduct, be open to any severe reproach.  As a daughter,
13321 she hoped she was not without a heart.  She hoped no one could
13322 have said to her, "How could you be so unfeeling to your father?--
13323 I must, I will tell you truths while I can."  Miss Bates should
13324 never again--no, never!  If attention, in future, could do away
13325 the past, she might hope to be forgiven.  She had been often remiss,
13326 her conscience told her so; remiss, perhaps, more in thought
13327 than fact; scornful, ungracious.  But it should be so no more.
13328 In the warmth of true contrition, she would call upon her the
13329 very next morning, and it should be the beginning, on her side,
13330 of a regular, equal, kindly intercourse.
13331 
13332 She was just as determined when the morrow came, and went early,
13333 that nothing might prevent her.  It was not unlikely, she thought,
13334 that she might see Mr. Knightley in her way; or, perhaps, he might
13335 come in while she were paying her visit.  She had no objection.
13336 She would not be ashamed of the appearance of the penitence, so justly
13337 and truly hers.  Her eyes were towards Donwell as she walked, but she
13338 saw him not.
13339 
13340 "The ladies were all at home."  She had never rejoiced at the sound
13341 before, nor ever before entered the passage, nor walked up the stairs,
13342 with any wish of giving pleasure, but in conferring obligation,
13343 or of deriving it, except in subsequent ridicule.
13344 
13345 There was a bustle on her approach; a good deal of moving and talking.
13346 She heard Miss Bates's voice, something was to be done in a hurry;
13347 the maid looked frightened and awkward; hoped she would be pleased
13348 to wait a moment, and then ushered her in too soon.  The aunt and
13349 niece seemed both escaping into the adjoining room.  Jane she had
13350 a distinct glimpse of, looking extremely ill; and, before the door
13351 had shut them out, she heard Miss Bates saying, "Well, my dear,
13352 I shall _say_ you are laid down upon the bed, and I am sure you are
13353 ill enough."
13354 
13355 Poor old Mrs. Bates, civil and humble as usual, looked as if she
13356 did not quite understand what was going on.
13357 
13358 "I am afraid Jane is not very well," said she, "but I do not know;
13359 they _tell_ me she is well.  I dare say my daughter will be here presently,
13360 Miss Woodhouse.  I hope you find a chair.  I wish Hetty had not gone.
13361 I am very little able--Have you a chair, ma'am? Do you sit where
13362 you like?  I am sure she will be here presently."
13363 
13364 Emma seriously hoped she would.  She had a moment's fear of Miss
13365 Bates keeping away from her.  But Miss Bates soon came--"Very happy
13366 and obliged"--but Emma's conscience told her that there was not the
13367 same cheerful volubility as before--less ease of look and manner.
13368 A very friendly inquiry after Miss Fairfax, she hoped, might lead
13369 the way to a return of old feelings.  The touch seemed immediate.
13370 
13371 "Ah!  Miss Woodhouse, how kind you are!--I suppose you have heard--
13372 and are come to give us joy.  This does not seem much like joy,
13373 indeed, in me--(twinkling away a tear or two)--but it will be
13374 very trying for us to part with her, after having had her so long,
13375 and she has a dreadful headache just now, writing all the morning:--
13376 such long letters, you know, to be written to Colonel Campbell,
13377 and Mrs. Dixon.  `My dear,' said I, `you will blind yourself'--
13378 for tears were in her eyes perpetually.  One cannot wonder,
13379 one cannot wonder.  It is a great change; and though she is
13380 amazingly fortunate--such a situation, I suppose, as no young woman
13381 before ever met with on first going out--do not think us ungrateful,
13382 Miss Woodhouse, for such surprising good fortune--(again dispersing
13383 her tears)--but, poor dear soul! if you were to see what a headache
13384 she has.  When one is in great pain, you know one cannot feel
13385 any blessing quite as it may deserve.  She is as low as possible.
13386 To look at her, nobody would think how delighted and happy she
13387 is to have secured such a situation.  You will excuse her not
13388 coming to you--she is not able--she is gone into her own room--
13389 I want her to lie down upon the bed.  `My dear,' said I, `I shall
13390 say you are laid down upon the bed:'  but, however, she is not;
13391 she is walking about the room.  But, now that she has written
13392 her letters, she says she shall soon be well.  She will be extremely
13393 sorry to miss seeing you, Miss Woodhouse, but your kindness will
13394 excuse her.  You were kept waiting at the door--I was quite ashamed--
13395 but somehow there was a little bustle--for it so happened that we
13396 had not heard the knock, and till you were on the stairs, we did
13397 not know any body was coming.  `It is only Mrs. Cole,' said I,
13398 `depend upon it.  Nobody else would come so early.'  `Well,' said she,
13399 `it must be borne some time or other, and it may as well be now.'
13400 But then Patty came in, and said it was you.  `Oh!' said I,
13401 `it is Miss Woodhouse:  I am sure you will like to see her.'--
13402 `I can see nobody,' said she; and up she got, and would go away;
13403 and that was what made us keep you waiting--and extremely sorry
13404 and ashamed we were.  `If you must go, my dear,' said I, `you must,
13405 and I will say you are laid down upon the bed.'"
13406 
13407 Emma was most sincerely interested.  Her heart had been long growing
13408 kinder towards Jane; and this picture of her present sufferings acted
13409 as a cure of every former ungenerous suspicion, and left her nothing
13410 but pity; and the remembrance of the less just and less gentle
13411 sensations of the past, obliged her to admit that Jane might very
13412 naturally resolve on seeing Mrs. Cole or any other steady friend,
13413 when she might not bear to see herself.  She spoke as she felt,
13414 with earnest regret and solicitude--sincerely wishing that the
13415 circumstances which she collected from Miss Bates to be now actually
13416 determined on, might be as much for Miss Fairfax's advantage
13417 and comfort as possible.  "It must be a severe trial to them all.
13418 She had understood it was to be delayed till Colonel Campbell's return."
13419 
13420 "So very kind!" replied Miss Bates.  "But you are always kind."
13421 
13422 There was no bearing such an "always;" and to break through her
13423 dreadful gratitude, Emma made the direct inquiry of--
13424 
13425 "Where--may I ask?--is Miss Fairfax going?"
13426 
13427 "To a Mrs. Smallridge--charming woman--most superior--to have
13428 the charge of her three little girls--delightful children.
13429 Impossible that any situation could be more replete with comfort;
13430 if we except, perhaps, Mrs. Suckling's own family, and Mrs. Bragge's;
13431 but Mrs. Smallridge is intimate with both, and in the very
13432 same neighbourhood:--lives only four miles from Maple Grove.
13433 Jane will be only four miles from Maple Grove."
13434 
13435 "Mrs. Elton, I suppose, has been the person to whom Miss Fairfax owes--"
13436 
13437 "Yes, our good Mrs. Elton.  The most indefatigable, true friend.
13438 She would not take a denial.  She would not let Jane say, `No;' for
13439 when Jane first heard of it, (it was the day before yesterday,
13440 the very morning we were at Donwell,) when Jane first heard of it,
13441 she was quite decided against accepting the offer, and for the
13442 reasons you mention; exactly as you say, she had made up her mind
13443 to close with nothing till Colonel Campbell's return, and nothing
13444 should induce her to enter into any engagement at present--and so she
13445 told Mrs. Elton over and over again--and I am sure I had no more
13446 idea that she would change her mind!--but that good Mrs. Elton,
13447 whose judgment never fails her, saw farther than I did.  It is not
13448 every body that would have stood out in such a kind way as she did,
13449 and refuse to take Jane's answer; but she positively declared she
13450 would _not_ write any such denial yesterday, as Jane wished her;
13451 she would wait--and, sure enough, yesterday evening it was all
13452 settled that Jane should go.  Quite a surprize to me!  I had not
13453 the least idea!--Jane took Mrs. Elton aside, and told her at once,
13454 that upon thinking over the advantages of Mrs. Smallridge's situation,
13455 she had come to the resolution of accepting it.--I did not know a word
13456 of it till it was all settled."
13457 
13458 "You spent the evening with Mrs. Elton?"
13459 
13460 "Yes, all of us; Mrs. Elton would have us come.  It was settled so,
13461 upon the hill, while we were walking about with Mr. Knightley.
13462 `You _must_ _all_ spend your evening with us,' said she--`I positively must
13463 have you _all_ come.'"
13464 
13465 "Mr. Knightley was there too, was he?"
13466 
13467 "No, not Mr. Knightley; he declined it from the first; and though I
13468 thought he would come, because Mrs. Elton declared she would not let
13469 him off, he did not;--but my mother, and Jane, and I, were all there,
13470 and a very agreeable evening we had.  Such kind friends, you know,
13471 Miss Woodhouse, one must always find agreeable, though every body
13472 seemed rather fagged after the morning's party.  Even pleasure,
13473 you know, is fatiguing--and I cannot say that any of them seemed
13474 very much to have enjoyed it.  However, _I_ shall always think it
13475 a very pleasant party, and feel extremely obliged to the kind friends
13476 who included me in it."
13477 
13478 "Miss Fairfax, I suppose, though you were not aware of it, had been
13479 making up her mind the whole day?"
13480 
13481 "I dare say she had."
13482 
13483 "Whenever the time may come, it must be unwelcome to her and all
13484 her friends--but I hope her engagement will have every alleviation
13485 that is possible--I mean, as to the character and manners of the family."
13486 
13487 "Thank you, dear Miss Woodhouse.  Yes, indeed, there is every thing
13488 in the world that can make her happy in it.  Except the Sucklings
13489 and Bragges, there is not such another nursery establishment,
13490 so liberal and elegant, in all Mrs. Elton's acquaintance.
13491 Mrs. Smallridge, a most delightful woman!--A style of living almost
13492 equal to Maple Grove--and as to the children, except the little
13493 Sucklings and little Bragges, there are not such elegant sweet
13494 children anywhere.  Jane will be treated with such regard and kindness!--
13495 It will be nothing but pleasure, a life of pleasure.--And her salary!--
13496 I really cannot venture to name her salary to you, Miss Woodhouse.
13497 Even you, used as you are to great sums, would hardly believe that
13498 so much could be given to a young person like Jane."
13499 
13500 "Ah! madam," cried Emma, "if other children are at all like what I
13501 remember to have been myself, I should think five times the amount
13502 of what I have ever yet heard named as a salary on such occasions,
13503 dearly earned."
13504 
13505 "You are so noble in your ideas!"
13506 
13507 "And when is Miss Fairfax to leave you?"
13508 
13509 "Very soon, very soon, indeed; that's the worst of it.
13510 Within a fortnight.  Mrs. Smallridge is in a great hurry.  My poor
13511 mother does not know how to bear it.  So then, I try to put it out of
13512 her thoughts, and say, Come ma'am, do not let us think about it any more."
13513 
13514 "Her friends must all be sorry to lose her; and will not Colonel
13515 and Mrs. Campbell be sorry to find that she has engaged herself
13516 before their return?"
13517 
13518 "Yes; Jane says she is sure they will; but yet, this is such
13519 a situation as she cannot feel herself justified in declining.
13520 I was so astonished when she first told me what she had been saying
13521 to Mrs. Elton, and when Mrs. Elton at the same moment came congratulating
13522 me upon it!  It was before tea--stay--no, it could not be before tea,
13523 because we were just going to cards--and yet it was before tea,
13524 because I remember thinking--Oh! no, now I recollect, now I have it;
13525 something happened before tea, but not that.  Mr. Elton was called
13526 out of the room before tea, old John Abdy's son wanted to speak
13527 with him.  Poor old John, I have a great regard for him; he was clerk
13528 to my poor father twenty-seven years; and now, poor old man, he is
13529 bed-ridden, and very poorly with the rheumatic gout in his joints--
13530 I must go and see him to-day; and so will Jane, I am sure, if she
13531 gets out at all.  And poor John's son came to talk to Mr. Elton
13532 about relief from the parish; he is very well to do himself,
13533 you know, being head man at the Crown, ostler, and every thing
13534 of that sort, but still he cannot keep his father without some help;
13535 and so, when Mr. Elton came back, he told us what John ostler
13536 had been telling him, and then it came out about the chaise having
13537 been sent to Randalls to take Mr. Frank Churchill to Richmond.
13538 That was what happened before tea.  It was after tea that Jane spoke
13539 to Mrs. Elton."
13540 
13541 Miss Bates would hardly give Emma time to say how perfectly
13542 new this circumstance was to her; but as without supposing it
13543 possible that she could be ignorant of any of the particulars
13544 of Mr. Frank Churchill's going, she proceeded to give them all,
13545 it was of no consequence.
13546 
13547 What Mr. Elton had learned from the ostler on the subject, being the
13548 accumulation of the ostler's own knowledge, and the knowledge
13549 of the servants at Randalls, was, that a messenger had come over
13550 from Richmond soon after the return of the party from Box Hill--
13551 which messenger, however, had been no more than was expected;
13552 and that Mr. Churchill had sent his nephew a few lines, containing,
13553 upon the whole, a tolerable account of Mrs. Churchill, and only
13554 wishing him not to delay coming back beyond the next morning early;
13555 but that Mr. Frank Churchill having resolved to go home directly,
13556 without waiting at all, and his horse seeming to have got a cold,
13557 Tom had been sent off immediately for the Crown chaise, and the
13558 ostler had stood out and seen it pass by, the boy going a good pace,
13559 and driving very steady.
13560 
13561 There was nothing in all this either to astonish or interest,
13562 and it caught Emma's attention only as it united with the subject
13563 which already engaged her mind.  The contrast between Mrs. Churchill's
13564 importance in the world, and Jane Fairfax's, struck her; one was
13565 every thing, the other nothing--and she sat musing on the difference
13566 of woman's destiny, and quite unconscious on what her eyes were fixed,
13567 till roused by Miss Bates's saying,
13568 
13569 "Aye, I see what you are thinking of, the pianoforte.  What is to become
13570 of that?--Very true.  Poor dear Jane was talking of it just now.--
13571 `You must go,' said she.  `You and I must part.  You will have no
13572 business here.--Let it stay, however,' said she; `give it houseroom
13573 till Colonel Campbell comes back.  I shall talk about it to him;
13574 he will settle for me; he will help me out of all my difficulties.'--
13575 And to this day, I do believe, she knows not whether it was his
13576 present or his daughter's."
13577 
13578 Now Emma was obliged to think of the pianoforte; and the remembrance
13579 of all her former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing,
13580 that she soon allowed herself to believe her visit had been
13581 long enough; and, with a repetition of every thing that she could
13582 venture to say of the good wishes which she really felt, took leave.
13583 
13584 
13585 
13586 CHAPTER IX
13587 
13588 
13589 Emma's pensive meditations, as she walked home, were not interrupted;
13590 but on entering the parlour, she found those who must rouse her.
13591 Mr. Knightley and Harriet had arrived during her absence, and were
13592 sitting with her father.--Mr. Knightley immediately got up, and in a
13593 manner decidedly graver than usual, said,
13594 
13595 "I would not go away without seeing you, but I have no time to spare,
13596 and therefore must now be gone directly.  I am going to London,
13597 to spend a few days with John and Isabella.  Have you any thing to
13598 send or say, besides the `love,' which nobody carries?"
13599 
13600 "Nothing at all.  But is not this a sudden scheme?"
13601 
13602 "Yes--rather--I have been thinking of it some little time."
13603 
13604 Emma was sure he had not forgiven her; he looked unlike himself.
13605 Time, however, she thought, would tell him that they ought to be
13606 friends again.  While he stood, as if meaning to go, but not going--
13607 her father began his inquiries.
13608 
13609 "Well, my dear, and did you get there safely?--And how did you
13610 find my worthy old friend and her daughter?--I dare say they must
13611 have been very much obliged to you for coming.  Dear Emma has been
13612 to call on Mrs. and Miss Bates, Mr. Knightley, as I told you before.
13613 She is always so attentive to them!"
13614 
13615 Emma's colour was heightened by this unjust praise; and with a smile,
13616 and shake of the head, which spoke much, she looked at Mr. Knightley.--
13617 It seemed as if there were an instantaneous impression in her favour,
13618 as if his eyes received the truth from her's, and all that had
13619 passed of good in her feelings were at once caught and honoured.--
13620 He looked at her with a glow of regard.  She was warmly gratified--
13621 and in another moment still more so, by a little movement of
13622 more than common friendliness on his part.--He took her hand;--
13623 whether she had not herself made the first motion, she could not say--
13624 she might, perhaps, have rather offered it--but he took her hand,
13625 pressed it, and certainly was on the point of carrying it to his lips--
13626 when, from some fancy or other, he suddenly let it go.--Why he should feel
13627 such a scruple, why he should change his mind when it was all but done,
13628 she could not perceive.--He would have judged better, she thought,
13629 if he had not stopped.--The intention, however, was indubitable;
13630 and whether it was that his manners had in general so little gallantry,
13631 or however else it happened, but she thought nothing became him more.--
13632 It was with him, of so simple, yet so dignified a nature.--
13633 She could not but recall the attempt with great satisfaction.
13634 It spoke such perfect amity.--He left them immediately afterwards--
13635 gone in a moment.  He always moved with the alertness of a mind which
13636 could neither be undecided nor dilatory, but now he seemed more sudden
13637 than usual in his disappearance.
13638 
13639 Emma could not regret her having gone to Miss Bates, but she wished
13640 she had left her ten minutes earlier;--it would have been a great
13641 pleasure to talk over Jane Fairfax's situation with Mr. Knightley.--
13642 Neither would she regret that he should be going to Brunswick Square,
13643 for she knew how much his visit would be enjoyed--but it might have
13644 happened at a better time--and to have had longer notice of it,
13645 would have been pleasanter.--They parted thorough friends, however;
13646 she could not be deceived as to the meaning of his countenance,
13647 and his unfinished gallantry;--it was all done to assure her that she
13648 had fully recovered his good opinion.--He had been sitting with them
13649 half an hour, she found.  It was a pity that she had not come
13650 back earlier!
13651 
13652 In the hope of diverting her father's thoughts from the disagreeableness
13653 of Mr. Knightley's going to London; and going so suddenly;
13654 and going on horseback, which she knew would be all very bad;
13655 Emma communicated her news of Jane Fairfax, and her dependence
13656 on the effect was justified; it supplied a very useful check,--
13657 interested, without disturbing him.  He had long made up his mind to Jane
13658 Fairfax's going out as governess, and could talk of it cheerfully,
13659 but Mr. Knightley's going to London had been an unexpected blow.
13660 
13661 "I am very glad, indeed, my dear, to hear she is to be so
13662 comfortably settled.  Mrs. Elton is very good-natured and agreeable,
13663 and I dare say her acquaintance are just what they ought
13664 to be.  I hope it is a dry situation, and that her health
13665 will be taken good care of.  It ought to be a first object,
13666 as I am sure poor Miss Taylor's always was with me.  You know,
13667 my dear, she is going to be to this new lady what Miss Taylor
13668 was to us.  And I hope she will be better off in one respect,
13669 and not be induced to go away after it has been her home so long."
13670 
13671 The following day brought news from Richmond to throw every
13672 thing else into the background.  An express arrived at Randalls
13673 to announce the death of Mrs. Churchill!  Though her nephew
13674 had had no particular reason to hasten back on her account,
13675 she had not lived above six-and-thirty hours after his return.
13676 A sudden seizure of a different nature from any thing foreboded
13677 by her general state, had carried her off after a short struggle.
13678 The great Mrs. Churchill was no more.
13679 
13680 It was felt as such things must be felt.  Every body had a
13681 degree of gravity and sorrow; tenderness towards the departed,
13682 solicitude for the surviving friends; and, in a reasonable time,
13683 curiosity to know where she would be buried.  Goldsmith tells us,
13684 that when lovely woman stoops to folly, she has nothing to do
13685 but to die; and when she stoops to be disagreeable, it is equally
13686 to be recommended as a clearer of ill-fame. Mrs. Churchill,
13687 after being disliked at least twenty-five years, was now spoken of
13688 with compassionate allowances.  In one point she was fully justified.
13689 She had never been admitted before to be seriously ill.  The event
13690 acquitted her of all the fancifulness, and all the selfishness
13691 of imaginary complaints.
13692 
13693 "Poor Mrs. Churchill! no doubt she had been suffering a great deal:
13694 more than any body had ever supposed--and continual pain would try
13695 the temper.  It was a sad event--a great shock--with all her faults,
13696 what would Mr. Churchill do without her?  Mr. Churchill's loss
13697 would be dreadful indeed.  Mr. Churchill would never get over it."--
13698 Even Mr. Weston shook his head, and looked solemn, and said,
13699 "Ah! poor woman, who would have thought it!" and resolved, that his
13700 mourning should be as handsome as possible; and his wife sat sighing
13701 and moralising over her broad hems with a commiseration and good sense,
13702 true and steady.  How it would affect Frank was among the earliest
13703 thoughts of both.  It was also a very early speculation with Emma.
13704 The character of Mrs. Churchill, the grief of her husband--her mind
13705 glanced over them both with awe and compassion--and then rested
13706 with lightened feelings on how Frank might be affected by the event,
13707 how benefited, how freed.  She saw in a moment all the possible good.
13708 Now, an attachment to Harriet Smith would have nothing to encounter.
13709 Mr. Churchill, independent of his wife, was feared by nobody;
13710 an easy, guidable man, to be persuaded into any thing by his nephew.
13711 All that remained to be wished was, that the nephew should form
13712 the attachment, as, with all her goodwill in the cause, Emma could feel
13713 no certainty of its being already formed.
13714 
13715 Harriet behaved extremely well on the occasion, with great self-command.
13716 What ever she might feel of brighter hope, she betrayed nothing.  Emma was
13717 gratified, to observe such a proof in her of strengthened character,
13718 and refrained from any allusion that might endanger its maintenance.
13719 They spoke, therefore, of Mrs. Churchill's death with mutual forbearance.
13720 
13721 Short letters from Frank were received at Randalls, communicating
13722 all that was immediately important of their state and plans.
13723 Mr. Churchill was better than could be expected; and their
13724 first removal, on the departure of the funeral for Yorkshire,
13725 was to be to the house of a very old friend in Windsor, to whom
13726 Mr. Churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years.
13727 At present, there was nothing to be done for Harriet; good wishes
13728 for the future were all that could yet be possible on Emma's side.
13729 
13730 It was a more pressing concern to shew attention to Jane Fairfax,
13731 whose prospects were closing, while Harriet's opened, and whose
13732 engagements now allowed of no delay in any one at Highbury, who wished
13733 to shew her kindness--and with Emma it was grown into a first wish.
13734 She had scarcely a stronger regret than for her past coldness;
13735 and the person, whom she had been so many months neglecting, was now
13736 the very one on whom she would have lavished every distinction of
13737 regard or sympathy.  She wanted to be of use to her; wanted to shew
13738 a value for her society, and testify respect and consideration.
13739 She resolved to prevail on her to spend a day at Hartfield.
13740 A note was written to urge it.  The invitation was refused, and by
13741 a verbal message.  "Miss Fairfax was not well enough to write;"
13742 and when Mr. Perry called at Hartfield, the same morning,
13743 it appeared that she was so much indisposed as to have been visited,
13744 though against her own consent, by himself, and that she was suffering
13745 under severe headaches, and a nervous fever to a degree, which made
13746 him doubt the possibility of her going to Mrs. Smallridge's at the
13747 time proposed.  Her health seemed for the moment completely deranged--
13748 appetite quite gone--and though there were no absolutely
13749 alarming symptoms, nothing touching the pulmonary complaint,
13750 which was the standing apprehension of the family, Mr. Perry was
13751 uneasy about her.  He thought she had undertaken more than she
13752 was equal to, and that she felt it so herself, though she would
13753 not own it.  Her spirits seemed overcome.  Her present home,
13754 he could not but observe, was unfavourable to a nervous disorder:--
13755 confined always to one room;--he could have wished it otherwise--
13756 and her good aunt, though his very old friend, he must acknowledge
13757 to be not the best companion for an invalid of that description.
13758 Her care and attention could not be questioned; they were, in fact,
13759 only too great.  He very much feared that Miss Fairfax derived more
13760 evil than good from them.  Emma listened with the warmest concern;
13761 grieved for her more and more, and looked around eager to discover
13762 some way of being useful.  To take her--be it only an hour
13763 or two--from her aunt, to give her change of air and scene,
13764 and quiet rational conversation, even for an hour or two,
13765 might do her good; and the following morning she wrote again to say,
13766 in the most feeling language she could command, that she would
13767 call for her in the carriage at any hour that Jane would name--
13768 mentioning that she had Mr. Perry's decided opinion, in favour
13769 of such exercise for his patient.  The answer was only in this
13770 short note:
13771 
13772 "Miss Fairfax's compliments and thanks, but is quite unequal
13773 to any exercise."
13774 
13775 Emma felt that her own note had deserved something better; but it
13776 was impossible to quarrel with words, whose tremulous inequality
13777 shewed indisposition so plainly, and she thought only of how she
13778 might best counteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted.
13779 In spite of the answer, therefore, she ordered the carriage, and drove
13780 to Mrs. Bates's, in the hope that Jane would be induced to join her--
13781 but it would not do;--Miss Bates came to the carriage door, all gratitude,
13782 and agreeing with her most earnestly in thinking an airing might be of
13783 the greatest service--and every thing that message could do was tried--
13784 but all in vain.  Miss Bates was obliged to return without success;
13785 Jane was quite unpersuadable; the mere proposal of going out
13786 seemed to make her worse.--Emma wished she could have seen her,
13787 and tried her own powers; but, almost before she could hint the wish,
13788 Miss Bates made it appear that she had promised her niece on
13789 no account to let Miss Woodhouse in.  "Indeed, the truth was,
13790 that poor dear Jane could not bear to see any body--any body at all--
13791 Mrs. Elton, indeed, could not be denied--and Mrs. Cole had made
13792 such a point--and Mrs. Perry had said so much--but, except them,
13793 Jane would really see nobody."
13794 
13795 Emma did not want to be classed with the Mrs. Eltons, the Mrs. Perrys,
13796 and the Mrs. Coles, who would force themselves anywhere;
13797 neither could she feel any right of preference herself--
13798 she submitted, therefore, and only questioned Miss Bates farther
13799 as to her niece's appetite and diet, which she longed to be able
13800 to assist.  On that subject poor Miss Bates was very unhappy,
13801 and very communicative; Jane would hardly eat any thing:--
13802 Mr. Perry recommended nourishing food; but every thing they could
13803 command (and never had any body such good neighbours) was distasteful.
13804 
13805 Emma, on reaching home, called the housekeeper directly, to an
13806 examination of her stores; and some arrowroot of very superior quality
13807 was speedily despatched to Miss Bates with a most friendly note.
13808 In half an hour the arrowroot was returned, with a thousand thanks
13809 from Miss Bates, but "dear Jane would not be satisfied without its
13810 being sent back; it was a thing she could not take--and, moreover,
13811 she insisted on her saying, that she was not at all in want of any thing."
13812 
13813 When Emma afterwards heard that Jane Fairfax had been seen wandering
13814 about the meadows, at some distance from Highbury, on the afternoon
13815 of the very day on which she had, under the plea of being unequal
13816 to any exercise, so peremptorily refused to go out with her in
13817 the carriage, she could have no doubt--putting every thing together--
13818 that Jane was resolved to receive no kindness from _her_.  She was sorry,
13819 very sorry.  Her heart was grieved for a state which seemed
13820 but the more pitiable from this sort of irritation of spirits,
13821 inconsistency of action, and inequality of powers; and it mortified
13822 her that she was given so little credit for proper feeling, or esteemed
13823 so little worthy as a friend:  but she had the consolation of knowing
13824 that her intentions were good, and of being able to say to herself,
13825 that could Mr. Knightley have been privy to all her attempts
13826 of assisting Jane Fairfax, could he even have seen into her heart,
13827 he would not, on this occasion, have found any thing to reprove.
13828 
13829 
13830 
13831 CHAPTER X
13832 
13833 
13834 One morning, about ten days after Mrs. Churchill's decease,
13835 Emma was called downstairs to Mr. Weston, who "could not stay
13836 five minutes, and wanted particularly to speak with her."--
13837 He met her at the parlour-door, and hardly asking her how she did,
13838 in the natural key of his voice, sunk it immediately, to say,
13839 unheard by her father,
13840 
13841 "Can you come to Randalls at any time this morning?--Do, if it
13842 be possible.  Mrs. Weston wants to see you.  She must see you."
13843 
13844 "Is she unwell?"
13845 
13846 "No, no, not at all--only a little agitated.  She would have
13847 ordered the carriage, and come to you, but she must see you _alone_,
13848 and that you know--(nodding towards her father)--Humph!--Can you come?"
13849 
13850 "Certainly.  This moment, if you please.  It is impossible to
13851 refuse what you ask in such a way.  But what can be the matter?--
13852 Is she really not ill?"
13853 
13854 "Depend upon me--but ask no more questions.  You will know it
13855 all in time.  The most unaccountable business!  But hush, hush!"
13856 
13857 To guess what all this meant, was impossible even for Emma.
13858 Something really important seemed announced by his looks;
13859 but, as her friend was well, she endeavoured not to be uneasy,
13860 and settling it with her father, that she would take her walk now,
13861 she and Mr. Weston were soon out of the house together and on
13862 their way at a quick pace for Randalls.
13863 
13864 "Now,"--said Emma, when they were fairly beyond the sweep gates,--
13865 "now Mr. Weston, do let me know what has happened."
13866 
13867 "No, no,"--he gravely replied.--"Don't ask me.  I promised my wife
13868 to leave it all to her.  She will break it to you better than I can.
13869 Do not be impatient, Emma; it will all come out too soon."
13870 
13871 "Break it to me," cried Emma, standing still with terror.--
13872 "Good God!--Mr. Weston, tell me at once.--Something has happened
13873 in Brunswick Square.  I know it has.  Tell me, I charge you tell
13874 me this moment what it is."
13875 
13876 "No, indeed you are mistaken."--
13877 
13878 "Mr. Weston do not trifle with me.--Consider how many of my dearest
13879 friends are now in Brunswick Square.  Which of them is it?--
13880 I charge you by all that is sacred, not to attempt concealment."
13881 
13882 "Upon my word, Emma."--
13883 
13884 "Your word!--why not your honour!--why not say upon your honour,
13885 that it has nothing to do with any of them?  Good Heavens!--What can
13886 be to be _broke_ to me, that does not relate to one of that family?"
13887 
13888 "Upon my honour," said he very seriously, "it does not.  It is not
13889 in the smallest degree connected with any human being of the name
13890 of Knightley."
13891 
13892 Emma's courage returned, and she walked on.
13893 
13894 "I was wrong," he continued, "in talking of its being _broke_ to you.
13895 I should not have used the expression.  In fact, it does not concern you--
13896 it concerns only myself,--that is, we hope.--Humph!--In short,
13897 my dear Emma, there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it.
13898 I don't say that it is not a disagreeable business--but things might
13899 be much worse.--If we walk fast, we shall soon be at Randalls."
13900 
13901 Emma found that she must wait; and now it required little effort.
13902 She asked no more questions therefore, merely employed her own fancy,
13903 and that soon pointed out to her the probability of its being some
13904 money concern--something just come to light, of a disagreeable
13905 nature in the circumstances of the family,--something which the late
13906 event at Richmond had brought forward.  Her fancy was very active.
13907 Half a dozen natural children, perhaps--and poor Frank cut off!--
13908 This, though very undesirable, would be no matter of agony to her.
13909 It inspired little more than an animating curiosity.
13910 
13911 "Who is that gentleman on horseback?" said she, as they proceeded--
13912 speaking more to assist Mr. Weston in keeping his secret, than with
13913 any other view.
13914 
13915 "I do not know.--One of the Otways.--Not Frank;--it is not Frank,
13916 I assure you.  You will not see him.  He is half way to Windsor
13917 by this time."
13918 
13919 "Has your son been with you, then?"
13920 
13921 "Oh! yes--did not you know?--Well, well, never mind."
13922 
13923 For a moment he was silent; and then added, in a tone much more
13924 guarded and demure,
13925 
13926 "Yes, Frank came over this morning, just to ask us how we did."
13927 
13928 They hurried on, and were speedily at Randalls.--"Well, my dear,"
13929 said he, as they entered the room--"I have brought her, and now
13930 I hope you will soon be better.  I shall leave you together.
13931 There is no use in delay.  I shall not be far off, if you want me."--
13932 And Emma distinctly heard him add, in a lower tone, before he
13933 quitted the room,--"I have been as good as my word.  She has not the
13934 least idea."
13935 
13936 Mrs. Weston was looking so ill, and had an air of so much perturbation,
13937 that Emma's uneasiness increased; and the moment they were alone,
13938 she eagerly said,
13939 
13940 "What is it my dear friend?  Something of a very unpleasant nature,
13941 I find, has occurred;--do let me know directly what it is.
13942 I have been walking all this way in complete suspense.  We both
13943 abhor suspense.  Do not let mine continue longer.  It will do you
13944 good to speak of your distress, whatever it may be."
13945 
13946 "Have you indeed no idea?" said Mrs. Weston in a trembling voice.
13947 "Cannot you, my dear Emma--cannot you form a guess as to what you
13948 are to hear?"
13949 
13950 "So far as that it relates to Mr. Frank Churchill, I do guess."
13951 
13952 "You are right.  It does relate to him, and I will tell you directly;"
13953 (resuming her work, and seeming resolved against looking up.)
13954 "He has been here this very morning, on a most extraordinary errand.
13955 It is impossible to express our surprize.  He came to speak to his
13956 father on a subject,--to announce an attachment--"
13957 
13958 She stopped to breathe.  Emma thought first of herself, and then
13959 of Harriet.
13960 
13961 "More than an attachment, indeed," resumed Mrs. Weston; "an engagement--
13962 a positive engagement.--What will you say, Emma--what will any
13963 body say, when it is known that Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax
13964 are engaged;--nay, that they have been long engaged!"
13965 
13966 Emma even jumped with surprize;--and, horror-struck, exclaimed,
13967 
13968 "Jane Fairfax!--Good God!  You are not serious?  You do not mean it?"
13969 
13970 "You may well be amazed," returned Mrs. Weston, still averting her eyes,
13971 and talking on with eagerness, that Emma might have time to recover--
13972 "You may well be amazed.  But it is even so.  There has been a solemn
13973 engagement between them ever since October--formed at Weymouth,
13974 and kept a secret from every body.  Not a creature knowing it
13975 but themselves--neither the Campbells, nor her family, nor his.--
13976 It is so wonderful, that though perfectly convinced of the fact,
13977 it is yet almost incredible to myself.  I can hardly believe it.--
13978 I thought I knew him."
13979 
13980 Emma scarcely heard what was said.--Her mind was divided between
13981 two ideas--her own former conversations with him about Miss Fairfax;
13982 and poor Harriet;--and for some time she could only exclaim,
13983 and require confirmation, repeated confirmation.
13984 
13985 "Well," said she at last, trying to recover herself; "this is a
13986 circumstance which I must think of at least half a day, before I
13987 can at all comprehend it.  What!--engaged to her all the winter--
13988 before either of them came to Highbury?"
13989 
13990 "Engaged since October,--secretly engaged.--It has hurt me,
13991 Emma, very much.  It has hurt his father equally.  _Some_ _part_
13992 of his conduct we cannot excuse."
13993 
13994 Emma pondered a moment, and then replied, "I will not pretend
13995 _not_ to understand you; and to give you all the relief in my power,
13996 be assured that no such effect has followed his attentions to me,
13997 as you are apprehensive of."
13998 
13999 Mrs. Weston looked up, afraid to believe; but Emma's countenance
14000 was as steady as her words.
14001 
14002 "That you may have less difficulty in believing this boast, of my
14003 present perfect indifference," she continued, "I will farther tell you,
14004 that there was a period in the early part of our acquaintance,
14005 when I did like him, when I was very much disposed to be
14006 attached to him--nay, was attached--and how it came to cease,
14007 is perhaps the wonder.  Fortunately, however, it did cease.
14008 I have really for some time past, for at least these three months,
14009 cared nothing about him.  You may believe me, Mrs. Weston.
14010 This is the simple truth."
14011 
14012 Mrs. Weston kissed her with tears of joy; and when she could
14013 find utterance, assured her, that this protestation had done
14014 her more good than any thing else in the world could do.
14015 
14016 "Mr. Weston will be almost as much relieved as myself," said she.
14017 "On this point we have been wretched.  It was our darling wish that you
14018 might be attached to each other--and we were persuaded that it was so.--
14019 Imagine what we have been feeling on your account."
14020 
14021 "I have escaped; and that I should escape, may be a matter of
14022 grateful wonder to you and myself.  But this does not acquit _him_,
14023 Mrs. Weston; and I must say, that I think him greatly to blame.
14024 What right had he to come among us with affection and faith engaged,
14025 and with manners so _very_ disengaged?  What right had he to endeavour
14026 to please, as he certainly did--to distinguish any one young woman with
14027 persevering attention, as he certainly did--while he really belonged
14028 to another?--How could he tell what mischief he might be doing?--
14029 How could he tell that he might not be making me in love with him?--
14030 very wrong, very wrong indeed."
14031 
14032 "From something that he said, my dear Emma, I rather imagine--"
14033 
14034 "And how could _she_ bear such behaviour!  Composure with a witness!
14035 to look on, while repeated attentions were offering to another woman,
14036 before her face, and not resent it.--That is a degree of placidity,
14037 which I can neither comprehend nor respect."
14038 
14039 "There were misunderstandings between them, Emma; he said
14040 so expressly.  He had not time to enter into much explanation.
14041 He was here only a quarter of an hour, and in a state of agitation
14042 which did not allow the full use even of the time he could stay--
14043 but that there had been misunderstandings he decidedly said.
14044 The present crisis, indeed, seemed to be brought on by them;
14045 and those misunderstandings might very possibly arise from the
14046 impropriety of his conduct."
14047 
14048 "Impropriety!  Oh!  Mrs. Weston--it is too calm a censure.
14049 Much, much beyond impropriety!--It has sunk him, I cannot say how
14050 it has sunk him in my opinion.  So unlike what a man should be!--
14051 None of that upright integrity, that strict adherence to truth
14052 and principle, that disdain of trick and littleness, which a man
14053 should display in every transaction of his life."
14054 
14055 "Nay, dear Emma, now I must take his part; for though he has been
14056 wrong in this instance, I have known him long enough to answer
14057 for his having many, very many, good qualities; and--"
14058 
14059 "Good God!" cried Emma, not attending to her.--"Mrs. Smallridge, too!
14060 Jane actually on the point of going as governess!  What could he
14061 mean by such horrible indelicacy?  To suffer her to engage herself--
14062 to suffer her even to think of such a measure!"
14063 
14064 "He knew nothing about it, Emma.  On this article I can fully
14065 acquit him.  It was a private resolution of hers, not communicated
14066 to him--or at least not communicated in a way to carry conviction.--
14067 Till yesterday, I know he said he was in the dark as to her plans.
14068 They burst on him, I do not know how, but by some letter or message--
14069 and it was the discovery of what she was doing, of this very project
