14070 of hers, which determined him to come forward at once, own it
14071 all to his uncle, throw himself on his kindness, and, in short,
14072 put an end to the miserable state of concealment that had been
14073 carrying on so long."
14074 
14075 Emma began to listen better.
14076 
14077 "I am to hear from him soon," continued Mrs. Weston.  "He told me
14078 at parting, that he should soon write; and he spoke in a manner which
14079 seemed to promise me many particulars that could not be given now.
14080 Let us wait, therefore, for this letter.  It may bring many extenuations.
14081 It may make many things intelligible and excusable which now are
14082 not to be understood.  Don't let us be severe, don't let us be in
14083 a hurry to condemn him.  Let us have patience.  I must love him;
14084 and now that I am satisfied on one point, the one material point,
14085 I am sincerely anxious for its all turning out well, and ready
14086 to hope that it may.  They must both have suffered a great deal
14087 under such a system of secresy and concealment."
14088 
14089 "_His_ sufferings," replied Emma dryly, "do not appear to have done
14090 him much harm.  Well, and how did Mr. Churchill take it?"
14091 
14092 "Most favourably for his nephew--gave his consent with scarcely
14093 a difficulty.  Conceive what the events of a week have done
14094 in that family!  While poor Mrs. Churchill lived, I suppose there
14095 could not have been a hope, a chance, a possibility;--but scarcely
14096 are her remains at rest in the family vault, than her husband is
14097 persuaded to act exactly opposite to what she would have required.
14098 What a blessing it is, when undue influence does not survive the grave!--
14099 He gave his consent with very little persuasion."
14100 
14101 "Ah!" thought Emma, "he would have done as much for Harriet."
14102 
14103 "This was settled last night, and Frank was off with the light
14104 this morning.  He stopped at Highbury, at the Bates's, I fancy,
14105 some time--and then came on hither; but was in such a hurry to get
14106 back to his uncle, to whom he is just now more necessary than ever,
14107 that, as I tell you, he could stay with us but a quarter of an hour.--
14108 He was very much agitated--very much, indeed--to a degree that made
14109 him appear quite a different creature from any thing I had ever seen
14110 him before.--In addition to all the rest, there had been the shock of
14111 finding her so very unwell, which he had had no previous suspicion of--
14112 and there was every appearance of his having been feeling a great deal."
14113 
14114 "And do you really believe the affair to have been carrying on
14115 with such perfect secresy?--The Campbells, the Dixons, did none
14116 of them know of the engagement?"
14117 
14118 Emma could not speak the name of Dixon without a little blush.
14119 
14120 "None; not one.  He positively said that it had been known to no
14121 being in the world but their two selves."
14122 
14123 "Well," said Emma, "I suppose we shall gradually grow reconciled
14124 to the idea, and I wish them very happy.  But I shall always
14125 think it a very abominable sort of proceeding.  What has it been
14126 but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,--espionage, and treachery?--
14127 To come among us with professions of openness and simplicity;
14128 and such a league in secret to judge us all!--Here have we been,
14129 the whole winter and spring, completely duped, fancying ourselves
14130 all on an equal footing of truth and honour, with two people in the
14131 midst of us who may have been carrying round, comparing and sitting
14132 in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both
14133 to hear.--They must take the consequence, if they have heard each
14134 other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable!"
14135 
14136 "I am quite easy on that head," replied Mrs. Weston.  "I am
14137 very sure that I never said any thing of either to the other,
14138 which both might not have heard."
14139 
14140 "You are in luck.--Your only blunder was confined to my ear,
14141 when you imagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady."
14142 
14143 "True.  But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss
14144 Fairfax, I never could, under any blunder, have spoken ill of her;
14145 and as to speaking ill of him, there I must have been safe."
14146 
14147 At this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the window,
14148 evidently on the watch.  His wife gave him a look which invited
14149 him in; and, while he was coming round, added, "Now, dearest Emma,
14150 let me intreat you to say and look every thing that may set his
14151 heart at ease, and incline him to be satisfied with the match.
14152 Let us make the best of it--and, indeed, almost every thing may
14153 be fairly said in her favour.  It is not a connexion to gratify;
14154 but if Mr. Churchill does not feel that, why should we? and it
14155 may be a very fortunate circumstance for him, for Frank, I mean,
14156 that he should have attached himself to a girl of such steadiness
14157 of character and good judgment as I have always given her credit for--
14158 and still am disposed to give her credit for, in spite of this
14159 one great deviation from the strict rule of right.  And how much
14160 may be said in her situation for even that error!"
14161 
14162 "Much, indeed!" cried Emma feelingly.  "If a woman can ever
14163 be excused for thinking only of herself, it is in a situation
14164 like Jane Fairfax's.--Of such, one may almost say, that `the
14165 world is not their's, nor the world's law.'"
14166 
14167 She met Mr. Weston on his entrance, with a smiling countenance,
14168 exclaiming,
14169 
14170 "A very pretty trick you have been playing me, upon my word!
14171 This was a device, I suppose, to sport with my curiosity,
14172 and exercise my talent of guessing.  But you really frightened me.
14173 I thought you had lost half your property, at least.  And here,
14174 instead of its being a matter of condolence, it turns out to be one
14175 of congratulation.--I congratulate you, Mr. Weston, with all my heart,
14176 on the prospect of having one of the most lovely and accomplished
14177 young women in England for your daughter."
14178 
14179 A glance or two between him and his wife, convinced him that all was
14180 as right as this speech proclaimed; and its happy effect on his spirits
14181 was immediate.  His air and voice recovered their usual briskness:
14182 he shook her heartily and gratefully by the hand, and entered
14183 on the subject in a manner to prove, that he now only wanted
14184 time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing.
14185 His companions suggested only what could palliate imprudence,
14186 or smooth objections; and by the time they had talked it all
14187 over together, and he had talked it all over again with Emma,
14188 in their walk back to Hartfield, he was become perfectly reconciled,
14189 and not far from thinking it the very best thing that Frank could
14190 possibly have done.
14191 
14192 
14193 
14194 CHAPTER XI
14195 
14196 
14197 "Harriet, poor Harriet!"--Those were the words; in them lay the
14198 tormenting ideas which Emma could not get rid of, and which constituted
14199 the real misery of the business to her.  Frank Churchill had behaved
14200 very ill by herself--very ill in many ways,--but it was not so much
14201 _his_ behaviour as her _own_, which made her so angry with him.
14202 It was the scrape which he had drawn her into on Harriet's account,
14203 that gave the deepest hue to his offence.--Poor Harriet! to be a second
14204 time the dupe of her misconceptions and flattery.  Mr. Knightley
14205 had spoken prophetically, when he once said, "Emma, you have been
14206 no friend to Harriet Smith."--She was afraid she had done her nothing
14207 but disservice.--It was true that she had not to charge herself,
14208 in this instance as in the former, with being the sole and original
14209 author of the mischief; with having suggested such feelings as might
14210 otherwise never have entered Harriet's imagination; for Harriet
14211 had acknowledged her admiration and preference of Frank Churchill
14212 before she had ever given her a hint on the subject; but she felt
14213 completely guilty of having encouraged what she might have repressed.
14214 She might have prevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments.
14215 Her influence would have been enough.  And now she was very conscious
14216 that she ought to have prevented them.--She felt that she had been
14217 risking her friend's happiness on most insufficient grounds.
14218 Common sense would have directed her to tell Harriet, that she
14219 must not allow herself to think of him, and that there were five
14220 hundred chances to one against his ever caring for her.--"But, with
14221 common sense," she added, "I am afraid I have had little to do."
14222 
14223 She was extremely angry with herself.  If she could not have been
14224 angry with Frank Churchill too, it would have been dreadful.--
14225 As for Jane Fairfax, she might at least relieve her feelings
14226 from any present solicitude on her account.  Harriet would
14227 be anxiety enough; she need no longer be unhappy about Jane,
14228 whose troubles and whose ill-health having, of course, the same origin,
14229 must be equally under cure.--Her days of insignificance and evil
14230 were over.--She would soon be well, and happy, and prosperous.--
14231 Emma could now imagine why her own attentions had been slighted.
14232 This discovery laid many smaller matters open.  No doubt it had been
14233 from jealousy.--In Jane's eyes she had been a rival; and well might
14234 any thing she could offer of assistance or regard be repulsed.
14235 An airing in the Hartfield carriage would have been the rack,
14236 and arrowroot from the Hartfield storeroom must have been poison.
14237 She understood it all; and as far as her mind could disengage itself
14238 from the injustice and selfishness of angry feelings, she acknowledged
14239 that Jane Fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond
14240 her desert.  But poor Harriet was such an engrossing charge!
14241 There was little sympathy to be spared for any body else.
14242 Emma was sadly fearful that this second disappointment would be
14243 more severe than the first.  Considering the very superior claims
14244 of the object, it ought; and judging by its apparently stronger effect
14245 on Harriet's mind, producing reserve and self-command, it would.--
14246 She must communicate the painful truth, however, and as soon
14247 as possible.  An injunction of secresy had been among Mr. Weston's
14248 parting words.  "For the present, the whole affair was to be
14249 completely a secret.  Mr. Churchill had made a point of it,
14250 as a token of respect to the wife he had so very recently lost;
14251 and every body admitted it to be no more than due decorum."--
14252 Emma had promised; but still Harriet must be excepted.  It was her
14253 superior duty.
14254 
14255 In spite of her vexation, she could not help feeling it almost ridiculous,
14256 that she should have the very same distressing and delicate office to
14257 perform by Harriet, which Mrs. Weston had just gone through by herself.
14258 The intelligence, which had been so anxiously announced to her,
14259 she was now to be anxiously announcing to another.  Her heart beat
14260 quick on hearing Harriet's footstep and voice; so, she supposed,
14261 had poor Mrs. Weston felt when _she_ was approaching Randalls.
14262 Could the event of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!--
14263 But of that, unfortunately, there could be no chance.
14264 
14265 "Well, Miss Woodhouse!" cried Harriet, coming eagerly into the room--
14266 "is not this the oddest news that ever was?"
14267 
14268 "What news do you mean?" replied Emma, unable to guess, by look
14269 or voice, whether Harriet could indeed have received any hint.
14270 
14271 "About Jane Fairfax.  Did you ever hear any thing so strange?
14272 Oh!--you need not be afraid of owning it to me, for Mr. Weston has
14273 told me himself.  I met him just now.  He told me it was to be
14274 a great secret; and, therefore, I should not think of mentioning
14275 it to any body but you, but he said you knew it."
14276 
14277 "What did Mr. Weston tell you?"--said Emma, still perplexed.
14278 
14279 "Oh! he told me all about it; that Jane Fairfax and Mr. Frank
14280 Churchill are to be married, and that they have been privately
14281 engaged to one another this long while.  How very odd!"
14282 
14283 It was, indeed, so odd; Harriet's behaviour was so extremely odd,
14284 that Emma did not know how to understand it.  Her character appeared
14285 absolutely changed.  She seemed to propose shewing no agitation,
14286 or disappointment, or peculiar concern in the discovery.  Emma looked
14287 at her, quite unable to speak.
14288 
14289 "Had you any idea," cried Harriet, "of his being in love
14290 with her?--You, perhaps, might.--You (blushing as she spoke)
14291 who can see into every body's heart; but nobody else--"
14292 
14293 "Upon my word," said Emma, "I begin to doubt my having any such talent.
14294 Can you seriously ask me, Harriet, whether I imagined him attached
14295 to another woman at the very time that I was--tacitly, if not openly--
14296 encouraging you to give way to your own feelings?--I never had
14297 the slightest suspicion, till within the last hour, of Mr. Frank
14298 Churchill's having the least regard for Jane Fairfax.  You may be
14299 very sure that if I had, I should have cautioned you accordingly."
14300 
14301 "Me!" cried Harriet, colouring, and astonished.  "Why should you
14302 caution me?--You do not think I care about Mr. Frank Churchill."
14303 
14304 "I am delighted to hear you speak so stoutly on the subject,"
14305 replied Emma, smiling; "but you do not mean to deny that there
14306 was a time--and not very distant either--when you gave me reason
14307 to understand that you did care about him?"
14308 
14309 "Him!--never, never.  Dear Miss Woodhouse, how could you so mistake me?"
14310 turning away distressed.
14311 
14312 "Harriet!" cried Emma, after a moment's pause--"What do you mean?--
14313 Good Heaven! what do you mean?--Mistake you!--Am I to suppose then?--"
14314 
14315 She could not speak another word.--Her voice was lost; and she
14316 sat down, waiting in great terror till Harriet should answer.
14317 
14318 Harriet, who was standing at some distance, and with face turned
14319 from her, did not immediately say any thing; and when she did speak,
14320 it was in a voice nearly as agitated as Emma's.
14321 
14322 "I should not have thought it possible," she began, "that you
14323 could have misunderstood me!  I know we agreed never to name him--
14324 but considering how infinitely superior he is to every body else,
14325 I should not have thought it possible that I could be supposed
14326 to mean any other person.  Mr. Frank Churchill, indeed!  I do not
14327 know who would ever look at him in the company of the other.
14328 I hope I have a better taste than to think of Mr. Frank Churchill,
14329 who is like nobody by his side.  And that you should have been
14330 so mistaken, is amazing!--I am sure, but for believing that you
14331 entirely approved and meant to encourage me in my attachment,
14332 I should have considered it at first too great a presumption almost,
14333 to dare to think of him.  At first, if you had not told me
14334 that more wonderful things had happened; that there had been
14335 matches of greater disparity (those were your very words);--
14336 I should not have dared to give way to--I should not have thought
14337 it possible--But if _you_, who had been always acquainted with him--"
14338 
14339 "Harriet!" cried Emma, collecting herself resolutely--"Let us
14340 understand each other now, without the possibility of farther mistake.
14341 Are you speaking of--Mr. Knightley?"
14342 
14343 "To be sure I am.  I never could have an idea of any body else--
14344 and so I thought you knew.  When we talked about him, it was as clear
14345 as possible."
14346 
14347 "Not quite," returned Emma, with forced calmness, "for all that
14348 you then said, appeared to me to relate to a different person.
14349 I could almost assert that you had _named_ Mr. Frank Churchill.
14350 I am sure the service Mr. Frank Churchill had rendered you,
14351 in protecting you from the gipsies, was spoken of."
14352 
14353 "Oh!  Miss Woodhouse, how you do forget!"
14354 
14355 "My dear Harriet, I perfectly remember the substance of what I
14356 said on the occasion.  I told you that I did not wonder at
14357 your attachment; that considering the service he had rendered you,
14358 it was extremely natural:--and you agreed to it, expressing yourself
14359 very warmly as to your sense of that service, and mentioning
14360 even what your sensations had been in seeing him come forward
14361 to your rescue.--The impression of it is strong on my memory."
14362 
14363 "Oh, dear," cried Harriet, "now I recollect what you mean; but I
14364 was thinking of something very different at the time.  It was not
14365 the gipsies--it was not Mr. Frank Churchill that I meant.  No! (with
14366 some elevation) I was thinking of a much more precious circumstance--
14367 of Mr. Knightley's coming and asking me to dance, when Mr. Elton
14368 would not stand up with me; and when there was no other partner in
14369 the room.  That was the kind action; that was the noble benevolence
14370 and generosity; that was the service which made me begin to feel
14371 how superior he was to every other being upon earth."
14372 
14373 "Good God!" cried Emma, "this has been a most unfortunate--
14374 most deplorable mistake!--What is to be done?"
14375 
14376 "You would not have encouraged me, then, if you had understood me?
14377 At least, however, I cannot be worse off than I should have been,
14378 if the other had been the person; and now--it _is_ possible--"
14379 
14380 She paused a few moments.  Emma could not speak.
14381 
14382 "I do not wonder, Miss Woodhouse," she resumed, "that you should feel
14383 a great difference between the two, as to me or as to any body.
14384 You must think one five hundred million times more above me than
14385 the other.  But I hope, Miss Woodhouse, that supposing--that if--
14386 strange as it may appear--.  But you know they were your own words,
14387 that _more_ wonderful things had happened, matches of _greater_ disparity
14388 had taken place than between Mr. Frank Churchill and me; and, therefore,
14389 it seems as if such a thing even as this, may have occurred before--
14390 and if I should be so fortunate, beyond expression, as to--
14391 if Mr. Knightley should really--if _he_ does not mind the disparity,
14392 I hope, dear Miss Woodhouse, you will not set yourself against it,
14393 and try to put difficulties in the way.  But you are too good for that,
14394 I am sure."
14395 
14396 Harriet was standing at one of the windows.  Emma turned round
14397 to look at her in consternation, and hastily said,
14398 
14399 "Have you any idea of Mr. Knightley's returning your affection?"
14400 
14401 "Yes," replied Harriet modestly, but not fearfully--"I must say
14402 that I have."
14403 
14404 Emma's eyes were instantly withdrawn; and she sat silently meditating,
14405 in a fixed attitude, for a few minutes.  A few minutes were sufficient
14406 for making her acquainted with her own heart.  A mind like hers,
14407 once opening to suspicion, made rapid progress.  She touched--
14408 she admitted--she acknowledged the whole truth.  Why was it
14409 so much worse that Harriet should be in love with Mr. Knightley,
14410 than with Frank Churchill?  Why was the evil so dreadfully increased
14411 by Harriet's having some hope of a return?  It darted through her,
14412 with the speed of an arrow, that Mr. Knightley must marry no one
14413 but herself!
14414 
14415 Her own conduct, as well as her own heart, was before her in the
14416 same few minutes.  She saw it all with a clearness which had
14417 never blessed her before.  How improperly had she been acting
14418 by Harriet!  How inconsiderate, how indelicate, how irrational,
14419 how unfeeling had been her conduct!  What blindness, what madness,
14420 had led her on!  It struck her with dreadful force, and she
14421 was ready to give it every bad name in the world.  Some portion
14422 of respect for herself, however, in spite of all these demerits--
14423 some concern for her own appearance, and a strong sense of justice
14424 by Harriet--(there would be no need of _compassion_ to the girl
14425 who believed herself loved by Mr. Knightley--but justice required
14426 that she should not be made unhappy by any coldness now,)
14427 gave Emma the resolution to sit and endure farther with calmness,
14428 with even apparent kindness.--For her own advantage indeed, it was fit
14429 that the utmost extent of Harriet's hopes should be enquired into;
14430 and Harriet had done nothing to forfeit the regard and interest
14431 which had been so voluntarily formed and maintained--or to deserve
14432 to be slighted by the person, whose counsels had never led her right.--
14433 Rousing from reflection, therefore, and subduing her emotion,
14434 she turned to Harriet again, and, in a more inviting accent, renewed
14435 the conversation; for as to the subject which had first introduced it,
14436 the wonderful story of Jane Fairfax, that was quite sunk and lost.--
14437 Neither of them thought but of Mr. Knightley and themselves.
14438 
14439 Harriet, who had been standing in no unhappy reverie, was yet very glad
14440 to be called from it, by the now encouraging manner of such a judge,
14441 and such a friend as Miss Woodhouse, and only wanted invitation,
14442 to give the history of her hopes with great, though trembling
14443 delight.--Emma's tremblings as she asked, and as she listened,
14444 were better concealed than Harriet's, but they were not less.
14445 Her voice was not unsteady; but her mind was in all the perturbation
14446 that such a development of self, such a burst of threatening evil,
14447 such a confusion of sudden and perplexing emotions, must create.--
14448 She listened with much inward suffering, but with great outward
14449 patience, to Harriet's detail.--Methodical, or well arranged,
14450 or very well delivered, it could not be expected to be;
14451 but it contained, when separated from all the feebleness and
14452 tautology of the narration, a substance to sink her spirit--
14453 especially with the corroborating circumstances, which her own memory
14454 brought in favour of Mr. Knightley's most improved opinion of Harriet.
14455 
14456 Harriet had been conscious of a difference in his behaviour ever since
14457 those two decisive dances.--Emma knew that he had, on that occasion,
14458 found her much superior to his expectation.  From that evening,
14459 or at least from the time of Miss Woodhouse's encouraging her
14460 to think of him, Harriet had begun to be sensible of his talking
14461 to her much more than he had been used to do, and of his having
14462 indeed quite a different manner towards her; a manner of kindness
14463 and sweetness!--Latterly she had been more and more aware of it.
14464 When they had been all walking together, he had so often come and walked
14465 by her, and talked so very delightfully!--He seemed to want to be
14466 acquainted with her.  Emma knew it to have been very much the case.
14467 She had often observed the change, to almost the same extent.--
14468 Harriet repeated expressions of approbation and praise from him--
14469 and Emma felt them to be in the closest agreement with what she had
14470 known of his opinion of Harriet.  He praised her for being without
14471 art or affectation, for having simple, honest, generous, feelings.--
14472 She knew that he saw such recommendations in Harriet; he had dwelt
14473 on them to her more than once.--Much that lived in Harriet's memory,
14474 many little particulars of the notice she had received from him, a look,
14475 a speech, a removal from one chair to another, a compliment implied,
14476 a preference inferred, had been unnoticed, because unsuspected,
14477 by Emma.  Circumstances that might swell to half an hour's relation,
14478 and contained multiplied proofs to her who had seen them, had passed
14479 undiscerned by her who now heard them; but the two latest occurrences
14480 to be mentioned, the two of strongest promise to Harriet, were not
14481 without some degree of witness from Emma herself.--The first,
14482 was his walking with her apart from the others, in the lime-walk
14483 at Donwell, where they had been walking some time before Emma came,
14484 and he had taken pains (as she was convinced) to draw her from
14485 the rest to himself--and at first, he had talked to her in a more
14486 particular way than he had ever done before, in a very particular
14487 way indeed!--(Harriet could not recall it without a blush.) He seemed
14488 to be almost asking her, whether her affections were engaged.--
14489 But as soon as she (Miss Woodhouse) appeared likely to join them,
14490 he changed the subject, and began talking about farming:--
14491 The second, was his having sat talking with her nearly half an hour
14492 before Emma came back from her visit, the very last morning of his
14493 being at Hartfield--though, when he first came in, he had said
14494 that he could not stay five minutes--and his having told her,
14495 during their conversation, that though he must go to London,
14496 it was very much against his inclination that he left home at all,
14497 which was much more (as Emma felt) than he had acknowledged to _her_.
14498 The superior degree of confidence towards Harriet, which this one
14499 article marked, gave her severe pain.
14500 
14501 On the subject of the first of the two circumstances, she did,
14502 after a little reflection, venture the following question.
14503 "Might he not?--Is not it possible, that when enquiring, as you thought,
14504 into the state of your affections, he might be alluding to Mr. Martin--
14505 he might have Mr. Martin's interest in view?  But Harriet rejected
14506 the suspicion with spirit.
14507 
14508 "Mr. Martin!  No indeed!--There was not a hint of Mr. Martin.
14509 I hope I know better now, than to care for Mr. Martin, or to be
14510 suspected of it."
14511 
14512 When Harriet had closed her evidence, she appealed to her dear
14513 Miss Woodhouse, to say whether she had not good ground for hope.
14514 
14515 "I never should have presumed to think of it at first," said she,
14516 "but for you.  You told me to observe him carefully, and let
14517 his behaviour be the rule of mine--and so I have.  But now I seem
14518 to feel that I may deserve him; and that if he does chuse me,
14519 it will not be any thing so very wonderful."
14520 
14521 The bitter feelings occasioned by this speech, the many bitter
14522 feelings, made the utmost exertion necessary on Emma's side,
14523 to enable her to say on reply,
14524 
14525 "Harriet, I will only venture to declare, that Mr. Knightley is
14526 the last man in the world, who would intentionally give any woman
14527 the idea of his feeling for her more than he really does."
14528 
14529 Harriet seemed ready to worship her friend for a sentence so satisfactory;
14530 and Emma was only saved from raptures and fondness, which at
14531 that moment would have been dreadful penance, by the sound of her
14532 father's footsteps.  He was coming through the hall.  Harriet was
14533 too much agitated to encounter him.  "She could not compose herself--
14534 Mr. Woodhouse would be alarmed--she had better go;"--with most ready
14535 encouragement from her friend, therefore, she passed off through
14536 another door--and the moment she was gone, this was the spontaneous
14537 burst of Emma's feelings:  "Oh God! that I had never seen her!"
14538 
14539 The rest of the day, the following night, were hardly enough
14540 for her thoughts.--She was bewildered amidst the confusion
14541 of all that had rushed on her within the last few hours.
14542 Every moment had brought a fresh surprize; and every surprize
14543 must be matter of humiliation to her.--How to understand it all!
14544 How to understand the deceptions she had been thus practising
14545 on herself, and living under!--The blunders, the blindness of her
14546 own head and heart!--she sat still, she walked about, she tried her
14547 own room, she tried the shrubbery--in every place, every posture,
14548 she perceived that she had acted most weakly; that she had been imposed
14549 on by others in a most mortifying degree; that she had been imposing
14550 on herself in a degree yet more mortifying; that she was wretched,
14551 and should probably find this day but the beginning of wretchedness.
14552 
14553 To understand, thoroughly understand her own heart, was the
14554 first endeavour.  To that point went every leisure moment which her
14555 father's claims on her allowed, and every moment of involuntary
14556 absence of mind.
14557 
14558 How long had Mr. Knightley been so dear to her, as every feeling
14559 declared him now to be?  When had his influence, such influence begun?--
14560 When had he succeeded to that place in her affection, which Frank
14561 Churchill had once, for a short period, occupied?--She looked back;
14562 she compared the two--compared them, as they had always stood in
14563 her estimation, from the time of the latter's becoming known to her--
14564 and as they must at any time have been compared by her, had it--
14565 oh! had it, by any blessed felicity, occurred to her, to institute
14566 the comparison.--She saw that there never had been a time when she
14567 did not consider Mr. Knightley as infinitely the superior, or when
14568 his regard for her had not been infinitely the most dear.  She saw,
14569 that in persuading herself, in fancying, in acting to the contrary,
14570 she had been entirely under a delusion, totally ignorant of her
14571 own heart--and, in short, that she had never really cared for Frank
14572 Churchill at all!
14573 
14574 This was the conclusion of the first series of reflection.
14575 This was the knowledge of herself, on the first question of inquiry,
14576 which she reached; and without being long in reaching it.--
14577 She was most sorrowfully indignant; ashamed of every sensation
14578 but the one revealed to her--her affection for Mr. Knightley.--
14579 Every other part of her mind was disgusting.
14580 
14581 With insufferable vanity had she believed herself in the secret of every
14582 body's feelings; with unpardonable arrogance proposed to arrange every
14583 body's destiny.  She was proved to have been universally mistaken;
14584 and she had not quite done nothing--for she had done mischief.
14585 She had brought evil on Harriet, on herself, and she too much feared,
14586 on Mr. Knightley.--Were this most unequal of all connexions to
14587 take place, on her must rest all the reproach of having given it
14588 a beginning; for his attachment, she must believe to be produced only
14589 by a consciousness of Harriet's;--and even were this not the case,
14590 he would never have known Harriet at all but for her folly.
14591 
14592 Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!--It was a union to distance every
14593 wonder of the kind.--The attachment of Frank Churchill and Jane
14594 Fairfax became commonplace, threadbare, stale in the comparison,
14595 exciting no surprize, presenting no disparity, affording nothing
14596 to be said or thought.--Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!--Such an
14597 elevation on her side!  Such a debasement on his!  It was horrible
14598 to Emma to think how it must sink him in the general opinion,
14599 to foresee the smiles, the sneers, the merriment it would prompt at
14600 his expense; the mortification and disdain of his brother, the thousand
14601 inconveniences to himself.--Could it be?--No; it was impossible.
14602 And yet it was far, very far, from impossible.--Was it a new
14603 circumstance for a man of first-rate abilities to be captivated by
14604 very inferior powers?  Was it new for one, perhaps too busy to seek,
14605 to be the prize of a girl who would seek him?--Was it new for any
14606 thing in this world to be unequal, inconsistent, incongruous--or for
14607 chance and circumstance (as second causes) to direct the human fate?
14608 
14609 Oh! had she never brought Harriet forward!  Had she left her where
14610 she ought, and where he had told her she ought!--Had she not,
14611 with a folly which no tongue could express, prevented her marrying
14612 the unexceptionable young man who would have made her happy
14613 and respectable in the line of life to which she ought to belong--
14614 all would have been safe; none of this dreadful sequel would have been.
14615 
14616 How Harriet could ever have had the presumption to raise
14617 her thoughts to Mr. Knightley!--How she could dare to fancy
14618 herself the chosen of such a man till actually assured of it!--
14619 But Harriet was less humble, had fewer scruples than formerly.--
14620 Her inferiority, whether of mind or situation, seemed little felt.--
14621 She had seemed more sensible of Mr. Elton's being to stoop
14622 in marrying her, than she now seemed of Mr. Knightley's.--
14623 Alas! was not that her own doing too?  Who had been at pains to give
14624 Harriet notions of self-consequence but herself?--Who but herself
14625 had taught her, that she was to elevate herself if possible,
14626 and that her claims were great to a high worldly establishment?--
14627 If Harriet, from being humble, were grown vain, it was her doing too.
14628 
14629 
14630 
14631 CHAPTER XII
14632 
14633 
14634 Till now that she was threatened with its loss, Emma had never known
14635 how much of her happiness depended on being _first_ with Mr. Knightley,
14636 first in interest and affection.--Satisfied that it was so,
14637 and feeling it her due, she had enjoyed it without reflection;
14638 and only in the dread of being supplanted, found how inexpressibly
14639 important it had been.--Long, very long, she felt she had been first;
14640 for, having no female connexions of his own, there had been
14641 only Isabella whose claims could be compared with hers, and she
14642 had always known exactly how far he loved and esteemed Isabella.
14643 She had herself been first with him for many years past.
14644 She had not deserved it; she had often been negligent or perverse,
14645 slighting his advice, or even wilfully opposing him, insensible of
14646 half his merits, and quarrelling with him because he would not
14647 acknowledge her false and insolent estimate of her own--but still,
14648 from family attachment and habit, and thorough excellence of mind,
14649 he had loved her, and watched over her from a girl, with an endeavour
14650 to improve her, and an anxiety for her doing right, which no
14651 other creature had at all shared.  In spite of all her faults,
14652 she knew she was dear to him; might she not say, very dear?--
14653 When the suggestions of hope, however, which must follow here,
14654 presented themselves, she could not presume to indulge them.
14655 Harriet Smith might think herself not unworthy of being peculiarly,
14656 exclusively, passionately loved by Mr. Knightley.  _She_ could not.
14657 She could not flatter herself with any idea of blindness in his attachment
14658 to _her_.  She had received a very recent proof of its impartiality.--
14659 How shocked had he been by her behaviour to Miss Bates!  How directly,
14660 how strongly had he expressed himself to her on the subject!--Not too
14661 strongly for the offence--but far, far too strongly to issue from
14662 any feeling softer than upright justice and clear-sighted goodwill.--
14663 She had no hope, nothing to deserve the name of hope, that he could
14664 have that sort of affection for herself which was now in question;
14665 but there was a hope (at times a slight one, at times much stronger,)
14666 that Harriet might have deceived herself, and be overrating his
14667 regard for _her_.--Wish it she must, for his sake--be the consequence
14668 nothing to herself, but his remaining single all his life.
14669 Could she be secure of that, indeed, of his never marrying at all,
14670 she believed she should be perfectly satisfied.--Let him but continue
14671 the same Mr. Knightley to her and her father, the same Mr. Knightley
14672 to all the world; let Donwell and Hartfield lose none of their
14673 precious intercourse of friendship and confidence, and her peace
14674 would be fully secured.--Marriage, in fact, would not do for her.
14675 It would be incompatible with what she owed to her father, and with
14676 what she felt for him.  Nothing should separate her from her father.
14677 She would not marry, even if she were asked by Mr. Knightley.
14678 
14679 It must be her ardent wish that Harriet might be disappointed;
14680 and she hoped, that when able to see them together again, she might at
14681 least be able to ascertain what the chances for it were.--She should
14682 see them henceforward with the closest observance; and wretchedly
14683 as she had hitherto misunderstood even those she was watching,
14684 she did not know how to admit that she could be blinded here.--
14685 He was expected back every day.  The power of observation would be
14686 soon given--frightfully soon it appeared when her thoughts were in
14687 one course.  In the meanwhile, she resolved against seeing Harriet.--
14688 It would do neither of them good, it would do the subject no good,
14689 to be talking of it farther.--She was resolved not to be convinced,
14690 as long as she could doubt, and yet had no authority for opposing
14691 Harriet's confidence.  To talk would be only to irritate.--She wrote
14692 to her, therefore, kindly, but decisively, to beg that she would not,
14693 at present, come to Hartfield; acknowledging it to be her conviction,
14694 that all farther confidential discussion of _one_ topic had better
14695 be avoided; and hoping, that if a few days were allowed to pass before
14696 they met again, except in the company of others--she objected only
14697 to a tete-a-tete--they might be able to act as if they had forgotten
14698 the conversation of yesterday.--Harriet submitted, and approved,
14699 and was grateful.
14700 
14701 This point was just arranged, when a visitor arrived to tear Emma's
14702 thoughts a little from the one subject which had engrossed them,
14703 sleeping or waking, the last twenty-four hours--Mrs. Weston, who had
14704 been calling on her daughter-in-law elect, and took Hartfield in her
14705 way home, almost as much in duty to Emma as in pleasure to herself,
14706 to relate all the particulars of so interesting an interview.
14707 
14708 Mr. Weston had accompanied her to Mrs. Bates's, and gone through his
14709 share of this essential attention most handsomely; but she having
14710 then induced Miss Fairfax to join her in an airing, was now returned
14711 with much more to say, and much more to say with satisfaction,
14712 than a quarter of an hour spent in Mrs. Bates's parlour, with all
14713 the encumbrance of awkward feelings, could have afforded.
14714 
14715 A little curiosity Emma had; and she made the most of it while
14716 her friend related.  Mrs. Weston had set off to pay the visit
14717 in a good deal of agitation herself; and in the first place had
14718 wished not to go at all at present, to be allowed merely to write
14719 to Miss Fairfax instead, and to defer this ceremonious call till
14720 a little time had passed, and Mr. Churchill could be reconciled
14721 to the engagement's becoming known; as, considering every thing,
14722 she thought such a visit could not be paid without leading to reports:--
14723 but Mr. Weston had thought differently; he was extremely anxious
14724 to shew his approbation to Miss Fairfax and her family, and did not
14725 conceive that any suspicion could be excited by it; or if it were,
14726 that it would be of any consequence; for "such things," he observed,
14727 "always got about."  Emma smiled, and felt that Mr. Weston had
14728 very good reason for saying so.  They had gone, in short--and very
14729 great had been the evident distress and confusion of the lady.
14730 She had hardly been able to speak a word, and every look and action
14731 had shewn how deeply she was suffering from consciousness.  The quiet,
14732 heart-felt satisfaction of the old lady, and the rapturous delight
14733 of her daughter--who proved even too joyous to talk as usual,
14734 had been a gratifying, yet almost an affecting, scene.  They were
14735 both so truly respectable in their happiness, so disinterested
14736 in every sensation; thought so much of Jane; so much of every body,
14737 and so little of themselves, that every kindly feeling was at work
14738 for them.  Miss Fairfax's recent illness had offered a fair plea
14739 for Mrs. Weston to invite her to an airing; she had drawn back and
14740 declined at first, but, on being pressed had yielded; and, in the
14741 course of their drive, Mrs. Weston had, by gentle encouragement,
14742 overcome so much of her embarrassment, as to bring her to converse
14743 on the important subject.  Apologies for her seemingly ungracious
14744 silence in their first reception, and the warmest expressions of the
14745 gratitude she was always feeling towards herself and Mr. Weston,
14746 must necessarily open the cause; but when these effusions were put by,
14747 they had talked a good deal of the present and of the future state
14748 of the engagement.  Mrs. Weston was convinced that such conversation
14749 must be the greatest relief to her companion, pent up within her own
14750 mind as every thing had so long been, and was very much pleased
14751 with all that she had said on the subject.
14752 
14753 "On the misery of what she had suffered, during the concealment
14754 of so many months," continued Mrs. Weston, "she was energetic.
14755 This was one of her expressions.  `I will not say, that since I
14756 entered into the engagement I have not had some happy moments; but I
14757 can say, that I have never known the blessing of one tranquil hour:'--
14758 and the quivering lip, Emma, which uttered it, was an attestation
14759 that I felt at my heart."
14760 
14761 "Poor girl!" said Emma.  "She thinks herself wrong, then, for having
14762 consented to a private engagement?"
14763 
14764 "Wrong!  No one, I believe, can blame her more than she is disposed
14765 to blame herself.  `The consequence,' said she, `has been a state
14766 of perpetual suffering to me; and so it ought.  But after all the
14767 punishment that misconduct can bring, it is still not less misconduct.
14768 Pain is no expiation.  I never can be blameless.  I have been acting
14769 contrary to all my sense of right; and the fortunate turn that every
14770 thing has taken, and the kindness I am now receiving, is what my
14771 conscience tells me ought not to be.'  `Do not imagine, madam,'
14772 she continued, `that I was taught wrong.  Do not let any reflection
14773 fall on the principles or the care of the friends who brought
14774 me up.  The error has been all my own; and I do assure you that,
14775 with all the excuse that present circumstances may appear to give,
14776 I shall yet dread making the story known to Colonel Campbell.'"
14777 
14778 "Poor girl!" said Emma again.  "She loves him then excessively,
14779 I suppose.  It must have been from attachment only, that she could
14780 be led to form the engagement.  Her affection must have overpowered
14781 her judgment."
14782 
14783 "Yes, I have no doubt of her being extremely attached to him."
14784 
14785 "I am afraid," returned Emma, sighing, "that I must often have
14786 contributed to make her unhappy."
14787 
14788 "On your side, my love, it was very innocently done.  But she
14789 probably had something of that in her thoughts, when alluding
14790 to the misunderstandings which he had given us hints of before.
14791 One natural consequence of the evil she had involved herself in,"
14792 she said, "was that of making her _unreasonable_.  The consciousness
14793 of having done amiss, had exposed her to a thousand inquietudes,
14794 and made her captious and irritable to a degree that must have been--
14795 that had been--hard for him to bear.  `I did not make the allowances,'
14796 said she, `which I ought to have done, for his temper and spirits--
14797 his delightful spirits, and that gaiety, that playfulness
14798 of disposition, which, under any other circumstances, would, I am sure,
14799 have been as constantly bewitching to me, as they were at first.'
14800 She then began to speak of you, and of the great kindness you
14801 had shewn her during her illness; and with a blush which shewed me
14802 how it was all connected, desired me, whenever I had an opportunity,
14803 to thank you--I could not thank you too much--for every wish and
14804 every endeavour to do her good.  She was sensible that you had never
14805 received any proper acknowledgment from herself."
14806 
14807 "If I did not know her to be happy now," said Emma, seriously,
14808 "which, in spite of every little drawback from her scrupulous
14809 conscience, she must be, I could not bear these thanks;--for, oh!
14810 Mrs. Weston, if there were an account drawn up of the evil
14811 and the good I have done Miss Fairfax!--Well (checking herself,
14812 and trying to be more lively), this is all to be forgotten.
14813 You are very kind to bring me these interesting particulars.
14814 They shew her to the greatest advantage.  I am sure she is very good--
14815 I hope she will be very happy.  It is fit that the fortune
14816 should be on his side, for I think the merit will be all on hers."
14817 
14818 Such a conclusion could not pass unanswered by Mrs. Weston.
14819 She thought well of Frank in almost every respect; and, what was more,
14820 she loved him very much, and her defence was, therefore, earnest.
14821 She talked with a great deal of reason, and at least equal affection--
14822 but she had too much to urge for Emma's attention; it was soon gone
14823 to Brunswick Square or to Donwell; she forgot to attempt to listen;
14824 and when Mrs. Weston ended with, "We have not yet had the letter
14825 we are so anxious for, you know, but I hope it will soon come,"
14826 she was obliged to pause before she answered, and at last obliged
14827 to answer at random, before she could at all recollect what letter it
14828 was which they were so anxious for.
14829 
14830 "Are you well, my Emma?" was Mrs. Weston's parting question.
14831 
14832 "Oh! perfectly.  I am always well, you know.  Be sure to give me
14833 intelligence of the letter as soon as possible."
14834 
14835 Mrs. Weston's communications furnished Emma with more food for
14836 unpleasant reflection, by increasing her esteem and compassion,
14837 and her sense of past injustice towards Miss Fairfax.  She bitterly
14838 regretted not having sought a closer acquaintance with her, and blushed
14839 for the envious feelings which had certainly been, in some measure,
14840 the cause.  Had she followed Mr. Knightley's known wishes, in paying
14841 that attention to Miss Fairfax, which was every way her due; had she
14842 tried to know her better; had she done her part towards intimacy;
14843 had she endeavoured to find a friend there instead of in Harriet Smith;
14844 she must, in all probability, have been spared from every pain
14845 which pressed on her now.--Birth, abilities, and education,
14846 had been equally marking one as an associate for her, to be received
14847 with gratitude; and the other--what was she?--Supposing even that
14848 they had never become intimate friends; that she had never been
14849 admitted into Miss Fairfax's confidence on this important matter--
14850 which was most probable--still, in knowing her as she ought,
14851 and as she might, she must have been preserved from the abominable
14852 suspicions of an improper attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she had
14853 not only so foolishly fashioned and harboured herself, but had so
14854 unpardonably imparted; an idea which she greatly feared had been made
14855 a subject of material distress to the delicacy of Jane's feelings,
14856 by the levity or carelessness of Frank Churchill's.  Of all the sources
14857 of evil surrounding the former, since her coming to Highbury,
14858 she was persuaded that she must herself have been the worst.
14859 She must have been a perpetual enemy.  They never could have been
14860 all three together, without her having stabbed Jane Fairfax's peace
14861 in a thousand instances; and on Box Hill, perhaps, it had been
14862 the agony of a mind that would bear no more.
14863 
14864 The evening of this day was very long, and melancholy, at Hartfield.
14865 The weather added what it could of gloom.  A cold stormy rain set in,
14866 and nothing of July appeared but in the trees and shrubs, which the
14867 wind was despoiling, and the length of the day, which only made
14868 such cruel sights the longer visible.
14869 
14870 The weather affected Mr. Woodhouse, and he could only be kept tolerably
14871 comfortable by almost ceaseless attention on his daughter's side,
14872 and by exertions which had never cost her half so much before.
14873 It reminded her of their first forlorn tete-a-tete, on the evening
14874 of Mrs. Weston's wedding-day; but Mr. Knightley had walked
14875 in then, soon after tea, and dissipated every melancholy fancy.
14876 Alas! such delightful proofs of Hartfield's attraction, as those
14877 sort of visits conveyed, might shortly be over.  The picture which
14878 she had then drawn of the privations of the approaching winter,
14879 had proved erroneous; no friends had deserted them, no pleasures
14880 had been lost.--But her present forebodings she feared would
14881 experience no similar contradiction.  The prospect before her now,
14882 was threatening to a degree that could not be entirely dispelled--
14883 that might not be even partially brightened.  If all took place
14884 that might take place among the circle of her friends, Hartfield must
14885 be comparatively deserted; and she left to cheer her father with the
14886 spirits only of ruined happiness.
14887 
14888 The child to be born at Randalls must be a tie there even dearer
14889 than herself; and Mrs. Weston's heart and time would be occupied
14890 by it.  They should lose her; and, probably, in great measure,
14891 her husband also.--Frank Churchill would return among them no more;
14892 and Miss Fairfax, it was reasonable to suppose, would soon cease
14893 to belong to Highbury.  They would be married, and settled either
14894 at or near Enscombe.  All that were good would be withdrawn; and if
14895 to these losses, the loss of Donwell were to be added, what would
14896 remain of cheerful or of rational society within their reach?
14897 Mr. Knightley to be no longer coming there for his evening comfort!--
14898 No longer walking in at all hours, as if ever willing to change
14899 his own home for their's!--How was it to be endured?  And if he were
14900 to be lost to them for Harriet's sake; if he were to be thought
14901 of hereafter, as finding in Harriet's society all that he wanted;
14902 if Harriet were to be the chosen, the first, the dearest, the friend,
14903 the wife to whom he looked for all the best blessings of existence;
14904 what could be increasing Emma's wretchedness but the reflection never far
14905 distant from her mind, that it had been all her own work?
14906 
14907 When it came to such a pitch as this, she was not able to refrain
14908 from a start, or a heavy sigh, or even from walking about the room
14909 for a few seconds--and the only source whence any thing like consolation
14910 or composure could be drawn, was in the resolution of her own
14911 better conduct, and the hope that, however inferior in spirit and
14912 gaiety might be the following and every future winter of her life
14913 to the past, it would yet find her more rational, more acquainted
14914 with herself, and leave her less to regret when it were gone.
14915 
14916 
14917 
14918 CHAPTER XIII
14919 
14920 
14921 The weather continued much the same all the following morning;
14922 and the same loneliness, and the same melancholy, seemed to
14923 reign at Hartfield--but in the afternoon it cleared; the wind
14924 changed into a softer quarter; the clouds were carried off;
14925 the sun appeared; it was summer again.  With all the eagerness
14926 which such a transition gives, Emma resolved to be out of doors
14927 as soon as possible.  Never had the exquisite sight, smell,
14928 sensation of nature, tranquil, warm, and brilliant after a storm,
14929 been more attractive to her.  She longed for the serenity they might
14930 gradually introduce; and on Mr. Perry's coming in soon after dinner,
14931 with a disengaged hour to give her father, she lost no time ill
14932 hurrying into the shrubbery.--There, with spirits freshened,
14933 and thoughts a little relieved, she had taken a few turns, when she
14934 saw Mr. Knightley passing through the garden door, and coming
14935 towards her.--It was the first intimation of his being returned
14936 from London.  She had been thinking of him the moment before,
14937 as unquestionably sixteen miles distant.--There was time only for
14938 the quickest arrangement of mind.  She must be collected and calm.
14939 In half a minute they were together.  The "How d'ye do's" were quiet
14940 and constrained on each side.  She asked after their mutual friends;
14941 they were all well.--When had he left them?--Only that morning.
14942 He must have had a wet ride.--Yes.--He meant to walk with her,
14943 she found.  "He had just looked into the dining-room, and as he
14944 was not wanted there, preferred being out of doors."--She thought
14945 he neither looked nor spoke cheerfully; and the first possible
14946 cause for it, suggested by her fears, was, that he had perhaps been
14947 communicating his plans to his brother, and was pained by the manner
14948 in which they had been received.
14949 
14950 They walked together.  He was silent.  She thought he was often
14951 looking at her, and trying for a fuller view of her face than it
14952 suited her to give.  And this belief produced another dread.
14953 Perhaps he wanted to speak to her, of his attachment to Harriet;
14954 he might be watching for encouragement to begin.--She did not,
14955 could not, feel equal to lead the way to any such subject.
14956 He must do it all himself.  Yet she could not bear this silence.
14957 With him it was most unnatural.  She considered--resolved--and, trying
14958 to smile, began--
14959 
14960 "You have some news to hear, now you are come back, that will rather
14961 surprize you."
14962 
14963 "Have I?" said he quietly, and looking at her; "of what nature?"
14964 
14965 "Oh! the best nature in the world--a wedding."
14966 
14967 After waiting a moment, as if to be sure she intended to say no more,
14968 he replied,
14969 
14970 "If you mean Miss Fairfax and Frank Churchill, I have heard
14971 that already."
14972 
14973 "How is it possible?" cried Emma, turning her glowing cheeks
14974 towards him; for, while she spoke, it occurred to her that he
14975 might have called at Mrs. Goddard's in his way.
14976 
14977 "I had a few lines on parish business from Mr. Weston this morning,
14978 and at the end of them he gave me a brief account of what had happened."
14979 
14980 Emma was quite relieved, and could presently say, with a little
14981 more composure,
14982 
14983 "_You_ probably have been less surprized than any of us, for you have
14984 had your suspicions.--I have not forgotten that you once tried to give
14985 me a caution.--I wish I had attended to it--but--(with a sinking
14986 voice and a heavy sigh) I seem to have been doomed to blindness."
14987 
14988 For a moment or two nothing was said, and she was unsuspicious
14989 of having excited any particular interest, till she found her arm
14990 drawn within his, and pressed against his heart, and heard him
14991 thus saying, in a tone of great sensibility, speaking low,
14992 
14993 "Time, my dearest Emma, time will heal the wound.--Your own
14994 excellent sense--your exertions for your father's sake--I know
14995 you will not allow yourself--."  Her arm was pressed again,
14996 as he added, in a more broken and subdued accent, "The feelings
14997 of the warmest friendship--Indignation--Abominable scoundrel!"--
14998 And in a louder, steadier tone, he concluded with, "He will soon
14999 be gone.  They will soon be in Yorkshire.  I am sorry for _her_.
15000 She deserves a better fate."
15001 
15002 Emma understood him; and as soon as she could recover from the
15003 flutter of pleasure, excited by such tender consideration, replied,
15004 
15005 "You are very kind--but you are mistaken--and I must set you right.--
15006 I am not in want of that sort of compassion.  My blindness to what
15007 was going on, led me to act by them in a way that I must always
15008 be ashamed of, and I was very foolishly tempted to say and do many
15009 things which may well lay me open to unpleasant conjectures, but I
15010 have no other reason to regret that I was not in the secret earlier."
15011 
15012 "Emma!" cried he, looking eagerly at her, "are you, indeed?"--
15013 but checking himself--"No, no, I understand you--forgive me--I am
15014 pleased that you can say even so much.--He is no object of regret,
15015 indeed! and it will not be very long, I hope, before that becomes
15016 the acknowledgment of more than your reason.--Fortunate that your
15017 affections were not farther entangled!--I could never, I confess,
15018 from your manners, assure myself as to the degree of what you felt--
15019 I could only be certain that there was a preference--and a preference
15020 which I never believed him to deserve.--He is a disgrace to the name
15021 of man.--And is he to be rewarded with that sweet young woman?--
15022 Jane, Jane, you will be a miserable creature."
15023 
15024 "Mr. Knightley," said Emma, trying to be lively, but really confused--
15025 "I am in a very extraordinary situation.  I cannot let you continue in
15026 your error; and yet, perhaps, since my manners gave such an impression,
15027 I have as much reason to be ashamed of confessing that I never have
15028 been at all attached to the person we are speaking of, as it might
15029 be natural for a woman to feel in confessing exactly the reverse.--
15030 But I never have."
15031 
15032 He listened in perfect silence.  She wished him to speak, but he
15033 would not.  She supposed she must say more before she were entitled
15034 to his clemency; but it was a hard case to be obliged still to lower
15035 herself in his opinion.  She went on, however.
15036 
15037 "I have very little to say for my own conduct.--I was tempted
15038 by his attentions, and allowed myself to appear pleased.--
15039 An old story, probably--a common case--and no more than has happened
15040 to hundreds of my sex before; and yet it may not be the more excusable
15041 in one who sets up as I do for Understanding.  Many circumstances
15042 assisted the temptation.  He was the son of Mr. Weston--he was
15043 continually here--I always found him very pleasant--and, in short,
15044 for (with a sigh) let me swell out the causes ever so ingeniously,
15045 they all centre in this at last--my vanity was flattered, and I
15046 allowed his attentions.  Latterly, however--for some time, indeed--
15047 I have had no idea of their meaning any thing.--I thought them
15048 a habit, a trick, nothing that called for seriousness on my side.
15049 He has imposed on me, but he has not injured me.  I have never been
15050 attached to him.  And now I can tolerably comprehend his behaviour.
15051 He never wished to attach me.  It was merely a blind to conceal
15052 his real situation with another.--It was his object to blind
15053 all about him; and no one, I am sure, could be more effectually
15054 blinded than myself--except that I was _not_ blinded--that it was my
15055 good fortune--that, in short, I was somehow or other safe from him."
15056 
15057 She had hoped for an answer here--for a few words to say that her
15058 conduct was at least intelligible; but he was silent; and, as far
15059 as she could judge, deep in thought.  At last, and tolerably
15060 in his usual tone, he said,
15061 
15062 "I have never had a high opinion of Frank Churchill.--I can suppose,
15063 however, that I may have underrated him.  My acquaintance with
15064 him has been but trifling.--And even if I have not underrated
15065 him hitherto, he may yet turn out well.--With such a woman he has
15066 a chance.--I have no motive for wishing him ill--and for her sake,
15067 whose happiness will be involved in his good character and conduct,
15068 I shall certainly wish him well."
15069 
15070 "I have no doubt of their being happy together," said Emma;
15071 "I believe them to be very mutually and very sincerely attached."
15072 
15073 "He is a most fortunate man!" returned Mr. Knightley, with energy.
15074 "So early in life--at three-and-twenty--a period when, if a man
15075 chuses a wife, he generally chuses ill.  At three-and-twenty
15076 to have drawn such a prize!  What years of felicity that man,
15077 in all human calculation, has before him!--Assured of the love of
15078 such a woman--the disinterested love, for Jane Fairfax's character
15079 vouches for her disinterestedness; every thing in his favour,--
15080 equality of situation--I mean, as far as regards society, and all the
15081 habits and manners that are important; equality in every point but one--
15082 and that one, since the purity of her heart is not to be doubted,
15083 such as must increase his felicity, for it will be his to bestow the
15084 only advantages she wants.--A man would always wish to give a woman
15085 a better home than the one he takes her from; and he who can do it,
15086 where there is no doubt of _her_ regard, must, I think, be the happiest
15087 of mortals.--Frank Churchill is, indeed, the favourite of fortune.
15088 Every thing turns out for his good.--He meets with a young woman
15089 at a watering-place, gains her affection, cannot even weary her
15090 by negligent treatment--and had he and all his family sought round
15091 the world for a perfect wife for him, they could not have found
15092 her superior.--His aunt is in the way.--His aunt dies.--He has
15093 only to speak.--His friends are eager to promote his happiness.--
15094 He had used every body ill--and they are all delighted to forgive him.--
15095 He is a fortunate man indeed!"
15096 
15097 "You speak as if you envied him."
15098 
15099 "And I do envy him, Emma.  In one respect he is the object of my envy."
15100 
15101 Emma could say no more.  They seemed to be within half a sentence
15102 of Harriet, and her immediate feeling was to avert the subject,
15103 if possible.  She made her plan; she would speak of something
15104 totally different--the children in Brunswick Square; and she
15105 only waited for breath to begin, when Mr. Knightley startled her,
15106 by saying,
15107 
15108 "You will not ask me what is the point of envy.--You are determined,
15109 I see, to have no curiosity.--You are wise--but _I_ cannot be wise.
15110 Emma, I must tell you what you will not ask, though I may wish it
15111 unsaid the next moment."
15112 
15113 "Oh! then, don't speak it, don't speak it," she eagerly cried.
15114 "Take a little time, consider, do not commit yourself."
15115 
15116 "Thank you," said he, in an accent of deep mortification, and not
15117 another syllable followed.
15118 
15119 Emma could not bear to give him pain.  He was wishing to confide in her--
15120 perhaps to consult her;--cost her what it would, she would listen.
15121 She might assist his resolution, or reconcile him to it;
15122 she might give just praise to Harriet, or, by representing to him
15123 his own independence, relieve him from that state of indecision,
15124 which must be more intolerable than any alternative to such a mind
15125 as his.--They had reached the house.
15126 
15127 "You are going in, I suppose?" said he.
15128 
15129 "No,"--replied Emma--quite confirmed by the depressed manner
15130 in which he still spoke--"I should like to take another turn.
15131 Mr. Perry is not gone."  And, after proceeding a few steps, she added--
15132 "I stopped you ungraciously, just now, Mr. Knightley, and, I am afraid,
15133 gave you pain.--But if you have any wish to speak openly to me
15134 as a friend, or to ask my opinion of any thing that you may have
15135 in contemplation--as a friend, indeed, you may command me.--I will
15136 hear whatever you like.  I will tell you exactly what I think."
15137 
15138 "As a friend!"--repeated Mr. Knightley.--"Emma, that I fear is
15139 a word--No, I have no wish--Stay, yes, why should I hesitate?--
15140 I have gone too far already for concealment.--Emma, I accept your offer--
15141 Extraordinary as it may seem, I accept it, and refer myself to you
15142 as a friend.--Tell me, then, have I no chance of ever succeeding?"
15143 
15144 He stopped in his earnestness to look the question, and the expression
15145 of his eyes overpowered her.
15146 
15147 "My dearest Emma," said he, "for dearest you will always be,
15148 whatever the event of this hour's conversation, my dearest,
15149 most beloved Emma--tell me at once.  Say `No,' if it is to be said."--
15150 She could really say nothing.--"You are silent," he cried,
15151 with great animation; "absolutely silent! at present I ask no more."
15152 
15153 Emma was almost ready to sink under the agitation of this moment.
15154 The dread of being awakened from the happiest dream, was perhaps
15155 the most prominent feeling.
15156 
15157 "I cannot make speeches, Emma:"  he soon resumed; and in a tone
15158 of such sincere, decided, intelligible tenderness as was
15159 tolerably convincing.--"If I loved you less, I might be able
15160 to talk about it more.  But you know what I am.--You hear nothing
15161 but truth from me.--I have blamed you, and lectured you, and you
15162 have borne it as no other woman in England would have borne it.--
15163 Bear with the truths I would tell you now, dearest Emma, as well as
15164 you have borne with them.  The manner, perhaps, may have as little
15165 to recommend them.  God knows, I have been a very indifferent lover.--
15166 But you understand me.--Yes, you see, you understand my feelings--
15167 and will return them if you can.  At present, I ask only to hear,
15168 once to hear your voice."
15169 
15170 While he spoke, Emma's mind was most busy, and, with all the wonderful
15171 velocity of thought, had been able--and yet without losing a word--
15172 to catch and comprehend the exact truth of the whole; to see that
15173 Harriet's hopes had been entirely groundless, a mistake, a delusion,
15174 as complete a delusion as any of her own--that Harriet was nothing;
15175 that she was every thing herself; that what she had been saying
15176 relative to Harriet had been all taken as the language of her
15177 own feelings; and that her agitation, her doubts, her reluctance,
15178 her discouragement, had been all received as discouragement
15179 from herself.--And not only was there time for these convictions,
15180 with all their glow of attendant happiness; there was time also to
15181 rejoice that Harriet's secret had not escaped her, and to resolve
15182 that it need not, and should not.--It was all the service she could
15183 now render her poor friend; for as to any of that heroism of sentiment
15184 which might have prompted her to entreat him to transfer his affection
15185 from herself to Harriet, as infinitely the most worthy of the two--
15186 or even the more simple sublimity of resolving to refuse him
15187 at once and for ever, without vouchsafing any motive, because he
15188 could not marry them both, Emma had it not.  She felt for Harriet,
15189 with pain and with contrition; but no flight of generosity run mad,
15190 opposing all that could be probable or reasonable, entered her brain.
15191 She had led her friend astray, and it would be a reproach to
15192 her for ever; but her judgment was as strong as her feelings,
15193 and as strong as it had ever been before, in reprobating any such
15194 alliance for him, as most unequal and degrading.  Her way was clear,
15195 though not quite smooth.--She spoke then, on being so entreated.--
15196 What did she say?--Just what she ought, of course.  A lady always does.--
15197 She said enough to shew there need not be despair--and to invite him
15198 to say more himself.  He _had_ despaired at one period; he had received
15199 such an injunction to caution and silence, as for the time crushed
15200 every hope;--she had begun by refusing to hear him.--The change had
15201 perhaps been somewhat sudden;--her proposal of taking another turn,
15202 her renewing the conversation which she had just put an end to,
15203 might be a little extraordinary!--She felt its inconsistency;
15204 but Mr. Knightley was so obliging as to put up with it, and seek no
15205 farther explanation.
15206 
15207 Seldom, very seldom, does complete truth belong to any human disclosure;
15208 seldom can it happen that something is not a little disguised,
15209 or a little mistaken; but where, as in this case, though the conduct
15210 is mistaken, the feelings are not, it may not be very material.--
15211 Mr. Knightley could not impute to Emma a more relenting heart than
15212 she possessed, or a heart more disposed to accept of his.
15213 
15214 He had, in fact, been wholly unsuspicious of his own influence.
15215 He had followed her into the shrubbery with no idea of trying it.
15216 He had come, in his anxiety to see how she bore Frank Churchill's
15217 engagement, with no selfish view, no view at all, but of endeavouring,
15218 if she allowed him an opening, to soothe or to counsel her.--The rest
15219 had been the work of the moment, the immediate effect of what he heard,
15220 on his feelings.  The delightful assurance of her total indifference
15221 towards Frank Churchill, of her having a heart completely disengaged
15222 from him, had given birth to the hope, that, in time, he might gain
15223 her affection himself;--but it had been no present hope--he had only,
15224 in the momentary conquest of eagerness over judgment, aspired to be
15225 told that she did not forbid his attempt to attach her.--The superior
15226 hopes which gradually opened were so much the more enchanting.--
15227 The affection, which he had been asking to be allowed to create,
15228 if he could, was already his!--Within half an hour, he had passed
15229 from a thoroughly distressed state of mind, to something so like
15230 perfect happiness, that it could bear no other name.
15231 
15232 _Her_ change was equal.--This one half-hour had given to each the
15233 same precious certainty of being beloved, had cleared from each
15234 the same degree of ignorance, jealousy, or distrust.--On his side,
15235 there had been a long-standing jealousy, old as the arrival,
15236 or even the expectation, of Frank Churchill.--He had been in love
15237 with Emma, and jealous of Frank Churchill, from about the same period,
15238 one sentiment having probably enlightened him as to the other.
15239 It was his jealousy of Frank Churchill that had taken him from
15240 the country.--The Box Hill party had decided him on going away.
15241 He would save himself from witnessing again such permitted,
15242 encouraged attentions.--He had gone to learn to be indifferent.--
15243 But he had gone to a wrong place.  There was too much domestic
15244 happiness in his brother's house; woman wore too amiable a form in it;
15245 Isabella was too much like Emma--differing only in those striking
15246 inferiorities, which always brought the other in brilliancy before him,
15247 for much to have been done, even had his time been longer.--He had
15248 stayed on, however, vigorously, day after day--till this very morning's
15249 post had conveyed the history of Jane Fairfax.--Then, with the
15250 gladness which must be felt, nay, which he did not scruple to feel,
15251 having never believed Frank Churchill to be at all deserving Emma,
15252 was there so much fond solicitude, so much keen anxiety for her,
15253 that he could stay no longer.  He had ridden home through the rain;
15254 and had walked up directly after dinner, to see how this sweetest
15255 and best of all creatures, faultless in spite of all her faults,
15256 bore the discovery.
15257 
15258 He had found her agitated and low.--Frank Churchill was a villain.--
15259 He heard her declare that she had never loved him.  Frank Churchill's
15260 character was not desperate.--She was his own Emma, by hand and word,
15261 when they returned into the house; and if he could have thought
15262 of Frank Churchill then, he might have deemed him a very good sort
15263 of fellow.
15264 
15265 
15266 
15267 CHAPTER XIV
15268 
15269 
15270 What totally different feelings did Emma take back into the house
15271 from what she had brought out!--she had then been only daring to hope
15272 for a little respite of suffering;--she was now in an exquisite
15273 flutter of happiness, and such happiness moreover as she believed
15274 must still be greater when the flutter should have passed away.
15275 
15276 They sat down to tea--the same party round the same table--
15277 how often it had been collected!--and how often had her eyes fallen
15278 on the same shrubs in the lawn, and observed the same beautiful
15279 effect of the western sun!--But never in such a state of spirits,
15280 never in any thing like it; and it was with difficulty that she could
15281 summon enough of her usual self to be the attentive lady of the house,
15282 or even the attentive daughter.
15283 
15284 Poor Mr. Woodhouse little suspected what was plotting against him
15285 in the breast of that man whom he was so cordially welcoming, and so
15286 anxiously hoping might not have taken cold from his ride.--Could he
15287 have seen the heart, he would have cared very little for the lungs;
15288 but without the most distant imagination of the impending evil,
15289 without the slightest perception of any thing extraordinary in
15290 the looks or ways of either, he repeated to them very comfortably
15291 all the articles of news he had received from Mr. Perry, and talked
15292 on with much self-contentment, totally unsuspicious of what they
15293 could have told him in return.
15294 
15295 As long as Mr. Knightley remained with them, Emma's fever continued;
15296 but when he was gone, she began to be a little tranquillised
15297 and subdued--and in the course of the sleepless night, which was
15298 the tax for such an evening, she found one or two such very serious
15299 points to consider, as made her feel, that even her happiness
15300 must have some alloy.  Her father--and Harriet.  She could not be
15301 alone without feeling the full weight of their separate claims;
15302 and how to guard the comfort of both to the utmost, was the question.
15303 With respect to her father, it was a question soon answered.
15304 She hardly knew yet what Mr. Knightley would ask; but a very short
15305 parley with her own heart produced the most solemn resolution
15306 of never quitting her father.--She even wept over the idea of it,
15307 as a sin of thought.  While he lived, it must be only an engagement;
15308 but she flattered herself, that if divested of the danger of
15309 drawing her away, it might become an increase of comfort to him.--
15310 How to do her best by Harriet, was of more difficult decision;--
15311 how to spare her from any unnecessary pain; how to make
15312 her any possible atonement; how to appear least her enemy?--
15313 On these subjects, her perplexity and distress were very great--
15314 and her mind had to pass again and again through every bitter
15315 reproach and sorrowful regret that had ever surrounded it.--
15316 She could only resolve at last, that she would still avoid a
15317 meeting with her, and communicate all that need be told by letter;
15318 that it would be inexpressibly desirable to have her removed just
15319 now for a time from Highbury, and--indulging in one scheme more--
15320 nearly resolve, that it might be practicable to get an invitation
15321 for her to Brunswick Square.--Isabella had been pleased with Harriet;
15322 and a few weeks spent in London must give her some amusement.--
15323 She did not think it in Harriet's nature to escape being benefited
15324 by novelty and variety, by the streets, the shops, and the children.--
15325 At any rate, it would be a proof of attention and kindness in herself,
15326 from whom every thing was due; a separation for the present; an averting
15327 of the evil day, when they must all be together again.
15328 
15329 She rose early, and wrote her letter to Harriet; an employment
15330 which left her so very serious, so nearly sad, that Mr. Knightley,
15331 in walking up to Hartfield to breakfast, did not arrive at all too soon;
15332 and half an hour stolen afterwards to go over the same ground again
15333 with him, literally and figuratively, was quite necessary to reinstate
15334 her in a proper share of the happiness of the evening before.
15335 
15336 He had not left her long, by no means long enough for her to have
15337 the slightest inclination for thinking of any body else, when a letter
15338 was brought her from Randalls--a very thick letter;--she guessed
15339 what it must contain, and deprecated the necessity of reading it.--
15340 She was now in perfect charity with Frank Churchill; she wanted
15341 no explanations, she wanted only to have her thoughts to herself--
15342 and as for understanding any thing he wrote, she was sure she was
15343 incapable of it.--It must be waded through, however.  She opened
15344 the packet; it was too surely so;--a note from Mrs. Weston to herself,
15345 ushered in the letter from Frank to Mrs. Weston.
15346 
15347 "I have the greatest pleasure, my dear Emma, in forwarding
15348 to you the enclosed.  I know what thorough justice you will
15349 do it, and have scarcely a doubt of its happy effect.--I think
15350 we shall never materially disagree about the writer again;
15351 but I will not delay you by a long preface.--We are quite well.--
15352 This letter has been the cure of all the little nervousness I have
15353 been feeling lately.--I did not quite like your looks on Tuesday,
15354 but it was an ungenial morning; and though you will never own being
15355 affected by weather, I think every body feels a north-east wind.--
15356 I felt for your dear father very much in the storm of Tuesday
15357 afternoon and yesterday morning, but had the comfort of hearing
15358 last night, by Mr. Perry, that it had not made him ill.
15359                               "Yours ever,
15360                                                        "A. W."
15361 
15362                        [To Mrs. Weston.]
15363                                                        WINDSOR-JULY.
15364 MY DEAR MADAM,
15365
