15366 "If I made myself intelligible yesterday, this letter will be expected;
15367 but expected or not, I know it will be read with candour and indulgence.--
15368 You are all goodness, and I believe there will be need of even
15369 all your goodness to allow for some parts of my past conduct.--
15370 But I have been forgiven by one who had still more to resent.
15371 My courage rises while I write.  It is very difficult for the
15372 prosperous to be humble.  I have already met with such success
15373 in two applications for pardon, that I may be in danger of thinking
15374 myself too sure of yours, and of those among your friends who have
15375 had any ground of offence.--You must all endeavour to comprehend
15376 the exact nature of my situation when I first arrived at Randalls;
15377 you must consider me as having a secret which was to be kept
15378 at all hazards.  This was the fact.  My right to place myself
15379 in a situation requiring such concealment, is another question.
15380 I shall not discuss it here.  For my temptation to _think_ it a right,
15381 I refer every caviller to a brick house, sashed windows below,
15382 and casements above, in Highbury.  I dared not address her openly;
15383 my difficulties in the then state of Enscombe must be too well
15384 known to require definition; and I was fortunate enough to prevail,
15385 before we parted at Weymouth, and to induce the most upright female
15386 mind in the creation to stoop in charity to a secret engagement.--
15387 Had she refused, I should have gone mad.--But you will be ready to say,
15388 what was your hope in doing this?--What did you look forward to?--
15389 To any thing, every thing--to time, chance, circumstance, slow effects,
15390 sudden bursts, perseverance and weariness, health and sickness.
15391 Every possibility of good was before me, and the first of blessings
15392 secured, in obtaining her promises of faith and correspondence.
15393 If you need farther explanation, I have the honour, my dear madam,
15394 of being your husband's son, and the advantage of inheriting
15395 a disposition to hope for good, which no inheritance of houses
15396 or lands can ever equal the value of.--See me, then, under these
15397 circumstances, arriving on my first visit to Randalls;--and here I
15398 am conscious of wrong, for that visit might have been sooner paid.
15399 You will look back and see that I did not come till Miss Fairfax
15400 was in Highbury; and as _you_ were the person slighted, you will
15401 forgive me instantly; but I must work on my father's compassion,
15402 by reminding him, that so long as I absented myself from his house,
15403 so long I lost the blessing of knowing you.  My behaviour,
15404 during the very happy fortnight which I spent with you, did not,
15405 I hope, lay me open to reprehension, excepting on one point.
15406 And now I come to the principal, the only important part of my
15407 conduct while belonging to you, which excites my own anxiety,
15408 or requires very solicitous explanation.  With the greatest respect,
15409 and the warmest friendship, do I mention Miss Woodhouse; my father
15410 perhaps will think I ought to add, with the deepest humiliation.--
15411 A few words which dropped from him yesterday spoke his opinion,
15412 and some censure I acknowledge myself liable to.--My behaviour
15413 to Miss Woodhouse indicated, I believe, more than it ought.--
15414 In order to assist a concealment so essential to me, I was led
15415 on to make more than an allowable use of the sort of intimacy
15416 into which we were immediately thrown.--I cannot deny that Miss
15417 Woodhouse was my ostensible object--but I am sure you will believe
15418 the declaration, that had I not been convinced of her indifference,
15419 I would not have been induced by any selfish views to go on.--
15420 Amiable and delightful as Miss Woodhouse is, she never gave me
15421 the idea of a young woman likely to be attached; and that she was
15422 perfectly free from any tendency to being attached to me, was as much
15423 my conviction as my wish.--She received my attentions with an easy,
15424 friendly, goodhumoured playfulness, which exactly suited me.
15425 We seemed to understand each other.  From our relative situation,
15426 those attentions were her due, and were felt to be so.--Whether Miss
15427 Woodhouse began really to understand me before the expiration of
15428 that fortnight, I cannot say;--when I called to take leave of her,
15429 I remember that I was within a moment of confessing the truth,
15430 and I then fancied she was not without suspicion; but I have no
15431 doubt of her having since detected me, at least in some degree.--
15432 She may not have surmised the whole, but her quickness must
15433 have penetrated a part.  I cannot doubt it.  You will find,
15434 whenever the subject becomes freed from its present restraints,
15435 that it did not take her wholly by surprize.  She frequently gave
15436 me hints of it.  I remember her telling me at the ball, that I
15437 owed Mrs. Elton gratitude for her attentions to Miss Fairfax.--
15438 I hope this history of my conduct towards her will be admitted
15439 by you and my father as great extenuation of what you saw amiss.
15440 While you considered me as having sinned against Emma Woodhouse,
15441 I could deserve nothing from either.  Acquit me here, and procure
15442 for me, when it is allowable, the acquittal and good wishes of that
15443 said Emma Woodhouse, whom I regard with so much brotherly affection,
15444 as to long to have her as deeply and as happily in love as myself.--
15445 Whatever strange things I said or did during that fortnight, you have
15446 now a key to.  My heart was in Highbury, and my business was to get
15447 my body thither as often as might be, and with the least suspicion.
15448 If you remember any queernesses, set them all to the right account.--
15449 Of the pianoforte so much talked of, I feel it only necessary to say,
15450 that its being ordered was absolutely unknown to Miss F--, who would
15451 never have allowed me to send it, had any choice been given her.--
15452 The delicacy of her mind throughout the whole engagement,
15453 my dear madam, is much beyond my power of doing justice to.
15454 You will soon, I earnestly hope, know her thoroughly yourself.--
15455 No description can describe her.  She must tell you herself what she is--
15456 yet not by word, for never was there a human creature who would
15457 so designedly suppress her own merit.--Since I began this letter,
15458 which will be longer than I foresaw, I have heard from her.--
15459 She gives a good account of her own health; but as she never complains,
15460 I dare not depend.  I want to have your opinion of her looks.
15461 I know you will soon call on her; she is living in dread of the visit.
15462 Perhaps it is paid already.  Let me hear from you without delay;
15463 I am impatient for a thousand particulars.  Remember how few
15464 minutes I was at Randalls, and in how bewildered, how mad a state:
15465 and I am not much better yet; still insane either from happiness
15466 or misery.  When I think of the kindness and favour I have met with,
15467 of her excellence and patience, and my uncle's generosity, I am mad
15468 with joy:  but when I recollect all the uneasiness I occasioned her,
15469 and how little I deserve to be forgiven, I am mad with anger.
15470 If I could but see her again!--But I must not propose it yet.
15471 My uncle has been too good for me to encroach.--I must still add
15472 to this long letter.  You have not heard all that you ought to hear.
15473 I could not give any connected detail yesterday; but the suddenness,
15474 and, in one light, the unseasonableness with which the affair burst out,
15475 needs explanation; for though the event of the 26th ult., as you
15476 will conclude, immediately opened to me the happiest prospects,
15477 I should not have presumed on such early measures, but from the
15478 very particular circumstances, which left me not an hour to lose.
15479 I should myself have shrunk from any thing so hasty, and she would have
15480 felt every scruple of mine with multiplied strength and refinement.--
15481 But I had no choice.  The hasty engagement she had entered into with
15482 that woman--Here, my dear madam, I was obliged to leave off abruptly,
15483 to recollect and compose myself.--I have been walking over the country,
15484 and am now, I hope, rational enough to make the rest of my letter
15485 what it ought to be.--It is, in fact, a most mortifying retrospect
15486 for me.  I behaved shamefully.  And here I can admit, that my manners
15487 to Miss W., in being unpleasant to Miss F., were highly blameable.
15488 _She_ disapproved them, which ought to have been enough.--My plea of
15489 concealing the truth she did not think sufficient.--She was displeased;
15490 I thought unreasonably so:  I thought her, on a thousand occasions,
15491 unnecessarily scrupulous and cautious:  I thought her even cold.
15492 But she was always right.  If I had followed her judgment, and subdued
15493 my spirits to the level of what she deemed proper, I should have
15494 escaped the greatest unhappiness I have ever known.--We quarrelled.--
15495 Do you remember the morning spent at Donwell?--_There_ every little
15496 dissatisfaction that had occurred before came to a crisis.  I was late;
15497 I met her walking home by herself, and wanted to walk with her,
15498 but she would not suffer it.  She absolutely refused to allow me,
15499 which I then thought most unreasonable.  Now, however, I see nothing
15500 in it but a very natural and consistent degree of discretion.
15501 While I, to blind the world to our engagement, was behaving one
15502 hour with objectionable particularity to another woman, was she
15503 to be consenting the next to a proposal which might have made
15504 every previous caution useless?--Had we been met walking together
15505 between Donwell and Highbury, the truth must have been suspected.--
15506 I was mad enough, however, to resent.--I doubted her affection.
15507 I doubted it more the next day on Box Hill; when, provoked by
15508 such conduct on my side, such shameful, insolent neglect of her,
15509 and such apparent devotion to Miss W., as it would have been
15510 impossible for any woman of sense to endure, she spoke her
15511 resentment in a form of words perfectly intelligible to me.--
15512 In short, my dear madam, it was a quarrel blameless on her side,
15513 abominable on mine; and I returned the same evening to Richmond,
15514 though I might have staid with you till the next morning,
15515 merely because I would be as angry with her as possible.  Even then,
15516 I was not such a fool as not to mean to be reconciled in time;
15517 but I was the injured person, injured by her coldness, and I went
15518 away determined that she should make the first advances.--I shall
15519 always congratulate myself that you were not of the Box Hill party.
15520 Had you witnessed my behaviour there, I can hardly suppose you would
15521 ever have thought well of me again.  Its effect upon her appears
15522 in the immediate resolution it produced:  as soon as she found I
15523 was really gone from Randalls, she closed with the offer of that
15524 officious Mrs. Elton; the whole system of whose treatment of her,
15525 by the bye, has ever filled me with indignation and hatred.
15526 I must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has been
15527 so richly extended towards myself; but, otherwise, I should loudly
15528 protest against the share of it which that woman has known.--
15529 `Jane,' indeed!--You will observe that I have not yet indulged myself
15530 in calling her by that name, even to you.  Think, then, what I must
15531 have endured in hearing it bandied between the Eltons with all
15532 the vulgarity of needless repetition, and all the insolence of
15533 imaginary superiority.  Have patience with me, I shall soon have done.--
15534 She closed with this offer, resolving to break with me entirely,
15535 and wrote the next day to tell me that we never were to meet again.--
15536 _She_ _felt_ _the_ _engagement_ _to_ _be_ _a_ _source_ _of_ _repentance_ _and_ _misery_
15537 _to_ _each_:  _she_ _dissolved_ _it_.--This letter reached me on the very
15538 morning of my poor aunt's death.  I answered it within an hour;
15539 but from the confusion of my mind, and the multiplicity of business
15540 falling on me at once, my answer, instead of being sent with all
15541 the many other letters of that day, was locked up in my writing-desk;
15542 and I, trusting that I had written enough, though but a few lines,
15543 to satisfy her, remained without any uneasiness.--I was rather
15544 disappointed that I did not hear from her again speedily;
15545 but I made excuses for her, and was too busy, and--may I add?--
15546 too cheerful in my views to be captious.--We removed to Windsor;
15547 and two days afterwards I received a parcel from her, my own letters
15548 all returned!--and a few lines at the same time by the post,
15549 stating her extreme surprize at not having had the smallest reply
15550 to her last; and adding, that as silence on such a point could
15551 not be misconstrued, and as it must be equally desirable to both
15552 to have every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible,
15553 she now sent me, by a safe conveyance, all my letters, and requested,
15554 that if I could not directly command hers, so as to send them
15555 to Highbury within a week, I would forward them after that period
15556 to her at--:  in short, the full direction to Mr. Smallridge's,
15557 near Bristol, stared me in the face.  I knew the name, the place,
15558 I knew all about it, and instantly saw what she had been doing.
15559 It was perfectly accordant with that resolution of character
15560 which I knew her to possess; and the secrecy she had maintained,
15561 as to any such design in her former letter, was equally descriptive
15562 of its anxious delicacy.  For the world would not she have seemed
15563 to threaten me.--Imagine the shock; imagine how, till I had actually
15564 detected my own blunder, I raved at the blunders of the post.--
15565 What was to be done?--One thing only.--I must speak to my uncle.
15566 Without his sanction I could not hope to be listened to again.--
15567 I spoke; circumstances were in my favour; the late event had softened
15568 away his pride, and he was, earlier than I could have anticipated,
15569 wholly reconciled and complying; and could say at last, poor man!
15570 with a deep sigh, that he wished I might find as much happiness
15571 in the marriage state as he had done.--I felt that it would be
15572 of a different sort.--Are you disposed to pity me for what I must
15573 have suffered in opening the cause to him, for my suspense while
15574 all was at stake?--No; do not pity me till I reached Highbury,
15575 and saw how ill I had made her.  Do not pity me till I saw her wan,
15576 sick looks.--I reached Highbury at the time of day when, from my
15577 knowledge of their late breakfast hour, I was certain of a good chance
15578 of finding her alone.--I was not disappointed; and at last I was
15579 not disappointed either in the object of my journey.  A great deal
15580 of very reasonable, very just displeasure I had to persuade away.
15581 But it is done; we are reconciled, dearer, much dearer, than ever,
15582 and no moment's uneasiness can ever occur between us again.  Now, my
15583 dear madam, I will release you; but I could not conclude before.
15584 A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness you have
15585 ever shewn me, and ten thousand for the attentions your heart
15586 will dictate towards her.--If you think me in a way to be happier
15587 than I deserve, I am quite of your opinion.--Miss W. calls me
15588 the child of good fortune.  I hope she is right.--In one respect,
15589 my good fortune is undoubted, that of being able to subscribe
15590 myself,
15591                     Your obliged and affectionate Son,
15592                                           F. C. WESTON CHURCHILL.
15593 
15594 
15595 
15596 CHAPTER XV
15597 
15598 
15599 This letter must make its way to Emma's feelings.  She was obliged,
15600 in spite of her previous determination to the contrary, to do
15601 it all the justice that Mrs. Weston foretold.  As soon as she
15602 came to her own name, it was irresistible; every line relating
15603 to herself was interesting, and almost every line agreeable;
15604 and when this charm ceased, the subject could still maintain itself,
15605 by the natural return of her former regard for the writer, and the
15606 very strong attraction which any picture of love must have for her at
15607 that moment.  She never stopt till she had gone through the whole;
15608 and though it was impossible not to feel that he had been wrong,
15609 yet he had been less wrong than she had supposed--and he had suffered,
15610 and was very sorry--and he was so grateful to Mrs. Weston,
15611 and so much in love with Miss Fairfax, and she was so happy herself,
15612 that there was no being severe; and could he have entered the room,
15613 she must have shaken hands with him as heartily as ever.
15614 
15615 She thought so well of the letter, that when Mr. Knightley came again,
15616 she desired him to read it.  She was sure of Mrs. Weston's wishing
15617 it to be communicated; especially to one, who, like Mr. Knightley,
15618 had seen so much to blame in his conduct.
15619 
15620 "I shall be very glad to look it over," said he; "but it seems long.
15621 I will take it home with me at night."
15622 
15623 But that would not do.  Mr. Weston was to call in the evening,
15624 and she must return it by him.
15625 
15626 "I would rather be talking to you," he replied; "but as it seems
15627 a matter of justice, it shall be done."
15628 
15629 He began--stopping, however, almost directly to say, "Had I been offered
15630 the sight of one of this gentleman's letters to his mother-in-law a few
15631 months ago, Emma, it would not have been taken with such indifference."
15632 
15633 He proceeded a little farther, reading to himself; and then,
15634 with a smile, observed, "Humph! a fine complimentary opening:
15635 But it is his way.  One man's style must not be the rule of another's.
15636 We will not be severe."
15637 
15638 "It will be natural for me," he added shortly afterwards, "to speak my
15639 opinion aloud as I read.  By doing it, I shall feel that I am near you.
15640 It will not be so great a loss of time:  but if you dislike it--"
15641 
15642 "Not at all.  I should wish it."
15643 
15644 Mr. Knightley returned to his reading with greater alacrity.
15645 
15646 "He trifles here," said he, "as to the temptation.  He knows
15647 he is wrong, and has nothing rational to urge.--Bad.--He ought
15648 not to have formed the engagement.--`His father's disposition:'--
15649 he is unjust, however, to his father.  Mr. Weston's sanguine
15650 temper was a blessing on all his upright and honourable exertions;
15651 but Mr. Weston earned every present comfort before he endeavoured
15652 to gain it.--Very true; he did not come till Miss Fairfax was here."
15653 
15654 "And I have not forgotten," said Emma, "how sure you were that he
15655 might have come sooner if he would.  You pass it over very handsomely--
15656 but you were perfectly right."
15657 
15658 "I was not quite impartial in my judgment, Emma:--but yet, I think--
15659 had _you_ not been in the case--I should still have distrusted him."
15660 
15661 When he came to Miss Woodhouse, he was obliged to read the whole
15662 of it aloud--all that related to her, with a smile; a look;
15663 a shake of the head; a word or two of assent, or disapprobation;
15664 or merely of love, as the subject required; concluding, however,
15665 seriously, and, after steady reflection, thus--
15666 
15667 "Very bad--though it might have been worse.--Playing a most
15668 dangerous game.  Too much indebted to the event for his acquittal.--
15669 No judge of his own manners by you.--Always deceived in fact by his
15670 own wishes, and regardless of little besides his own convenience.--
15671 Fancying you to have fathomed his secret.  Natural enough!--
15672 his own mind full of intrigue, that he should suspect it
15673 in others.--Mystery; Finesse--how they pervert the understanding!
15674 My Emma, does not every thing serve to prove more and more the
15675 beauty of truth and sincerity in all our dealings with each other?"
15676 
15677 Emma agreed to it, and with a blush of sensibility on Harriet's account,
15678 which she could not give any sincere explanation of.
15679 
15680 "You had better go on," said she.
15681 
15682 He did so, but very soon stopt again to say, "the pianoforte!
15683 Ah!  That was the act of a very, very young man, one too young
15684 to consider whether the inconvenience of it might not very much
15685 exceed the pleasure.  A boyish scheme, indeed!--I cannot
15686 comprehend a man's wishing to give a woman any proof of affection
15687 which he knows she would rather dispense with; and he did
15688 know that she would have prevented the instrument's coming if she could."
15689 
15690 After this, he made some progress without any pause.
15691 Frank Churchill's confession of having behaved shamefully
15692 was the first thing to call for more than a word in passing.
15693 
15694 "I perfectly agree with you, sir,"--was then his remark.
15695 "You did behave very shamefully.  You never wrote a truer line."
15696 And having gone through what immediately followed of the basis
15697 of their disagreement, and his persisting to act in direct
15698 opposition to Jane Fairfax's sense of right, he made a fuller pause
15699 to say, "This is very bad.--He had induced her to place herself,
15700 for his sake, in a situation of extreme difficulty and uneasiness,
15701 and it should have been his first object to prevent her from
15702 suffering unnecessarily.--She must have had much more to contend with,
15703 in carrying on the correspondence, than he could.  He should have
15704 respected even unreasonable scruples, had there been such; but hers
15705 were all reasonable.  We must look to her one fault, and remember
15706 that she had done a wrong thing in consenting to the engagement,
15707 to bear that she should have been in such a state of punishment."
15708 
15709 Emma knew that he was now getting to the Box Hill party,
15710 and grew uncomfortable.  Her own behaviour had been so very improper!
15711 She was deeply ashamed, and a little afraid of his next look.
15712 It was all read, however, steadily, attentively, and without
15713 the smallest remark; and, excepting one momentary glance at her,
15714 instantly withdrawn, in the fear of giving pain--no remembrance
15715 of Box Hill seemed to exist.
15716 
15717 "There is no saying much for the delicacy of our good friends,
15718 the Eltons," was his next observation.--"His feelings are natural.--
15719 What! actually resolve to break with him entirely!--She felt
15720 the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery to each--
15721 she dissolved it.--What a view this gives of her sense of
15722 his behaviour!--Well, he must be a most extraordinary--"
15723 
15724 "Nay, nay, read on.--You will find how very much he suffers."
15725 
15726 "I hope he does," replied Mr. Knightley coolly, and resuming the letter.
15727 "`Smallridge!'--What does this mean?  What is all this?"
15728 
15729 "She had engaged to go as governess to Mrs. Smallridge's children--
15730 a dear friend of Mrs. Elton's--a neighbour of Maple Grove; and,
15731 by the bye, I wonder how Mrs. Elton bears the disappointment?"
15732 
15733 "Say nothing, my dear Emma, while you oblige me to read--not even
15734 of Mrs. Elton.  Only one page more.  I shall soon have done.
15735 What a letter the man writes!"
15736 
15737 "I wish you would read it with a kinder spirit towards him."
15738 
15739 "Well, there _is_ feeling here.--He does seem to have suffered in finding
15740 her ill.--Certainly, I can have no doubt of his being fond of her.
15741 `Dearer, much dearer than ever.'  I hope he may long continue to feel
15742 all the value of such a reconciliation.--He is a very liberal thanker,
15743 with his thousands and tens of thousands.--`Happier than I deserve.'
15744 Come, he knows himself there.  `Miss Woodhouse calls me the child
15745 of good fortune.'--Those were Miss Woodhouse's words, were they?--
15746 And a fine ending--and there is the letter.  The child of good fortune!
15747 That was your name for him, was it?"
15748 
15749 "You do not appear so well satisfied with his letter as I am;
15750 but still you must, at least I hope you must, think the better
15751 of him for it.  I hope it does him some service with you."
15752 
15753 "Yes, certainly it does.  He has had great faults, faults of
15754 inconsideration and thoughtlessness; and I am very much of his
15755 opinion in thinking him likely to be happier than he deserves:
15756 but still as he is, beyond a doubt, really attached to Miss Fairfax,
15757 and will soon, it may be hoped, have the advantage of being constantly
15758 with her, I am very ready to believe his character will improve,
15759 and acquire from hers the steadiness and delicacy of principle
15760 that it wants.  And now, let me talk to you of something else.
15761 I have another person's interest at present so much at heart,
15762 that I cannot think any longer about Frank Churchill.  Ever since I
15763 left you this morning, Emma, my mind has been hard at work on
15764 one subject."
15765 
15766 The subject followed; it was in plain, unaffected, gentlemanlike English,
15767 such as Mr. Knightley used even to the woman he was in love with,
15768 how to be able to ask her to marry him, without attacking the
15769 happiness of her father.  Emma's answer was ready at the first word.
15770 "While her dear father lived, any change of condition must be impossible
15771 for her.  She could never quit him."  Part only of this answer,
15772 however, was admitted.  The impossibility of her quitting her father,
15773 Mr. Knightley felt as strongly as herself; but the inadmissibility
15774 of any other change, he could not agree to.  He had been thinking
15775 it over most deeply, most intently; he had at first hoped to induce
15776 Mr. Woodhouse to remove with her to Donwell; he had wanted to believe
15777 it feasible, but his knowledge of Mr. Woodhouse would not suffer
15778 him to deceive himself long; and now he confessed his persuasion,
15779 that such a transplantation would be a risk of her father's comfort,
15780 perhaps even of his life, which must not be hazarded.  Mr. Woodhouse
15781 taken from Hartfield!--No, he felt that it ought not to be attempted.
15782 But the plan which had arisen on the sacrifice of this, he trusted
15783 his dearest Emma would not find in any respect objectionable;
15784 it was, that he should be received at Hartfield; that so long as
15785 her father's happiness in other words his life--required Hartfield
15786 to continue her home, it should be his likewise.
15787 
15788 Of their all removing to Donwell, Emma had already had her own
15789 passing thoughts.  Like him, she had tried the scheme and rejected it;
15790 but such an alternative as this had not occurred to her.
15791 She was sensible of all the affection it evinced.  She felt that,
15792 in quitting Donwell, he must be sacrificing a great deal of independence
15793 of hours and habits; that in living constantly with her father,
15794 and in no house of his own, there would be much, very much,
15795 to be borne with.  She promised to think of it, and advised him
15796 to think of it more; but he was fully convinced, that no reflection
15797 could alter his wishes or his opinion on the subject.  He had
15798 given it, he could assure her, very long and calm consideration;
15799 he had been walking away from William Larkins the whole morning,
15800 to have his thoughts to himself.
15801 
15802 "Ah! there is one difficulty unprovided for," cried Emma.  "I am
15803 sure William Larkins will not like it.  You must get his consent
15804 before you ask mine."
15805 
15806 She promised, however, to think of it; and pretty nearly promised, moreover,
15807 to think of it, with the intention of finding it a very good scheme.
15808 
15809 It is remarkable, that Emma, in the many, very many, points of view
15810 in which she was now beginning to consider Donwell Abbey, was never
15811 struck with any sense of injury to her nephew Henry, whose rights
15812 as heir-expectant had formerly been so tenaciously regarded.
15813 Think she must of the possible difference to the poor little boy;
15814 and yet she only gave herself a saucy conscious smile about it,
15815 and found amusement in detecting the real cause of that violent
15816 dislike of Mr. Knightley's marrying Jane Fairfax, or any body else,
15817 which at the time she had wholly imputed to the amiable solicitude of
15818 the sister and the aunt.
15819 
15820 This proposal of his, this plan of marrying and continuing at Hartfield--
15821 the more she contemplated it, the more pleasing it became.
15822 His evils seemed to lessen, her own advantages to increase,
15823 their mutual good to outweigh every drawback.  Such a companion
15824 for herself in the periods of anxiety and cheerlessness before her!--
15825 Such a partner in all those duties and cares to which time must be
15826 giving increase of melancholy!
15827 
15828 She would have been too happy but for poor Harriet; but every
15829 blessing of her own seemed to involve and advance the sufferings
15830 of her friend, who must now be even excluded from Hartfield.
15831 The delightful family party which Emma was securing for herself,
15832 poor Harriet must, in mere charitable caution, be kept at a
15833 distance from.  She would be a loser in every way.  Emma could not
15834 deplore her future absence as any deduction from her own enjoyment.
15835 In such a party, Harriet would be rather a dead weight than otherwise;
15836 but for the poor girl herself, it seemed a peculiarly cruel necessity
15837 that was to be placing her in such a state of unmerited punishment.
15838 
15839 In time, of course, Mr. Knightley would be forgotten, that is,
15840 supplanted; but this could not be expected to happen very early.
15841 Mr. Knightley himself would be doing nothing to assist the cure;--
15842 not like Mr. Elton.  Mr. Knightley, always so kind, so feeling,
15843 so truly considerate for every body, would never deserve to be
15844 less worshipped than now; and it really was too much to hope even
15845 of Harriet, that she could be in love with more than _three_ men
15846 in one year.
15847 
15848 
15849 
15850 CHAPTER XVI
15851 
15852 
15853 It was a very great relief to Emma to find Harriet as desirous
15854 as herself to avoid a meeting.  Their intercourse was painful
15855 enough by letter.  How much worse, had they been obliged to meet!
15856 
15857 Harriet expressed herself very much as might be supposed,
15858 without reproaches, or apparent sense of ill-usage; and yet Emma fancied
15859 there was a something of resentment, a something bordering on it in
15860 her style, which increased the desirableness of their being separate.--
15861 It might be only her own consciousness; but it seemed as if an
15862 angel only could have been quite without resentment under such a stroke.
15863 
15864 She had no difficulty in procuring Isabella's invitation;
15865 and she was fortunate in having a sufficient reason for asking it,
15866 without resorting to invention.--There was a tooth amiss.
15867 Harriet really wished, and had wished some time, to consult a dentist.
15868 Mrs. John Knightley was delighted to be of use; any thing of ill
15869 health was a recommendation to her--and though not so fond of a
15870 dentist as of a Mr. Wingfield, she was quite eager to have Harriet
15871 under her care.--When it was thus settled on her sister's side,
15872 Emma proposed it to her friend, and found her very persuadable.--
15873 Harriet was to go; she was invited for at least a fortnight; she was
15874 to be conveyed in Mr. Woodhouse's carriage.--It was all arranged,
15875 it was all completed, and Harriet was safe in Brunswick Square.
15876 
15877 Now Emma could, indeed, enjoy Mr. Knightley's visits; now she
15878 could talk, and she could listen with true happiness, unchecked by
15879 that sense of injustice, of guilt, of something most painful,
15880 which had haunted her when remembering how disappointed a heart was
15881 near her, how much might at that moment, and at a little distance,
15882 be enduring by the feelings which she had led astray herself.
15883 
15884 The difference of Harriet at Mrs. Goddard's, or in London, made perhaps
15885 an unreasonable difference in Emma's sensations; but she could not
15886 think of her in London without objects of curiosity and employment,
15887 which must be averting the past, and carrying her out of herself.
15888 
15889 She would not allow any other anxiety to succeed directly to the place
15890 in her mind which Harriet had occupied.  There was a communication
15891 before her, one which _she_ only could be competent to make--
15892 the confession of her engagement to her father; but she would
15893 have nothing to do with it at present.--She had resolved to defer
15894 the disclosure till Mrs. Weston were safe and well.  No additional
15895 agitation should be thrown at this period among those she loved--
15896 and the evil should not act on herself by anticipation before the
15897 appointed time.--A fortnight, at least, of leisure and peace of mind,
15898 to crown every warmer, but more agitating, delight, should be hers.
15899 
15900 She soon resolved, equally as a duty and a pleasure, to employ half
15901 an hour of this holiday of spirits in calling on Miss Fairfax.--
15902 She ought to go--and she was longing to see her; the resemblance of
15903 their present situations increasing every other motive of goodwill.
15904 It would be a _secret_ satisfaction; but the consciousness of a
15905 similarity of prospect would certainly add to the interest with
15906 which she should attend to any thing Jane might communicate.
15907 
15908 She went--she had driven once unsuccessfully to the door, but had
15909 not been into the house since the morning after Box Hill, when poor
15910 Jane had been in such distress as had filled her with compassion,
15911 though all the worst of her sufferings had been unsuspected.--
15912 The fear of being still unwelcome, determined her, though assured
15913 of their being at home, to wait in the passage, and send up her name.--
15914 She heard Patty announcing it; but no such bustle succeeded as poor
15915 Miss Bates had before made so happily intelligible.--No; she heard
15916 nothing but the instant reply of, "Beg her to walk up;"--and a moment
15917 afterwards she was met on the stairs by Jane herself, coming eagerly
15918 forward, as if no other reception of her were felt sufficient.--
15919 Emma had never seen her look so well, so lovely, so engaging.
15920 There was consciousness, animation, and warmth; there was every
15921 thing which her countenance or manner could ever have wanted.--
15922 She came forward with an offered hand; and said, in a low, but very
15923 feeling tone,
15924 
15925 "This is most kind, indeed!--Miss Woodhouse, it is impossible
15926 for me to express--I hope you will believe--Excuse me for being
15927 so entirely without words."
15928 
15929 Emma was gratified, and would soon have shewn no want of words,
15930 if the sound of Mrs. Elton's voice from the sitting-room had not
15931 checked her, and made it expedient to compress all her friendly
15932 and all her congratulatory sensations into a very, very earnest
15933 shake of the hand.
15934 
15935 Mrs. Bates and Mrs. Elton were together.  Miss Bates was out,
15936 which accounted for the previous tranquillity.  Emma could have
15937 wished Mrs. Elton elsewhere; but she was in a humour to have patience
15938 with every body; and as Mrs. Elton met her with unusual graciousness,
15939 she hoped the rencontre would do them no harm.
15940 
15941 She soon believed herself to penetrate Mrs. Elton's thoughts,
15942 and understand why she was, like herself, in happy spirits;
15943 it was being in Miss Fairfax's confidence, and fancying herself
15944 acquainted with what was still a secret to other people.
15945 Emma saw symptoms of it immediately in the expression of her face;
15946 and while paying her own compliments to Mrs. Bates, and appearing
15947 to attend to the good old lady's replies, she saw her with a sort
15948 of anxious parade of mystery fold up a letter which she had apparently
15949 been reading aloud to Miss Fairfax, and return it into the purple
15950 and gold reticule by her side, saying, with significant nods,
15951 
15952 "We can finish this some other time, you know.  You and I shall
15953 not want opportunities.  And, in fact, you have heard all the
15954 essential already.  I only wanted to prove to you that Mrs. S. admits
15955 our apology, and is not offended.  You see how delightfully
15956 she writes.  Oh! she is a sweet creature!  You would have doated
15957 on her, had you gone.--But not a word more.  Let us be discreet--
15958 quite on our good behaviour.--Hush!--You remember those lines--
15959 I forget the poem at this moment:
15960 
15961         "For when a lady's in the case,
15962         "You know all other things give place."
15963 
15964 Now I say, my dear, in _our_ case, for _lady_, read----mum! a word
15965 to the wise.--I am in a fine flow of spirits, an't I?  But I want
15966 to set your heart at ease as to Mrs. S.--_My_ representation, you see,
15967 has quite appeased her."
15968 
15969 And again, on Emma's merely turning her head to look
15970 at Mrs. Bates's knitting, she added, in a half whisper,
15971 
15972 "I mentioned no _names_, you will observe.--Oh! no; cautious as
15973 a minister of state.  I managed it extremely well."
15974 
15975 Emma could not doubt.  It was a palpable display, repeated on every
15976 possible occasion.  When they had all talked a little while in harmony
15977 of the weather and Mrs. Weston, she found herself abruptly addressed with,
15978 
15979 "Do not you think, Miss Woodhouse, our saucy little friend here is
15980 charmingly recovered?--Do not you think her cure does Perry the
15981 highest credit?--(here was a side-glance of great meaning at Jane.)
15982 Upon my word, Perry has restored her in a wonderful short time!--
15983 Oh! if you had seen her, as I did, when she was at the worst!"--
15984 And when Mrs. Bates was saying something to Emma, whispered farther,
15985 "We do not say a word of any _assistance_ that Perry might have;
15986 not a word of a certain young physician from Windsor.--Oh! no;
15987 Perry shall have all the credit."
15988 
15989 "I have scarce had the pleasure of seeing you, Miss Woodhouse,"
15990 she shortly afterwards began, "since the party to Box Hill.
15991 Very pleasant party.  But yet I think there was something wanting.
15992 Things did not seem--that is, there seemed a little cloud upon
15993 the spirits of some.--So it appeared to me at least, but I might
15994 be mistaken.  However, I think it answered so far as to tempt one
15995 to go again.  What say you both to our collecting the same party,
15996 and exploring to Box Hill again, while the fine weather lasts?--
15997 It must be the same party, you know, quite the same party,
15998 not _one_ exception."
15999 
16000 Soon after this Miss Bates came in, and Emma could not help being diverted
16001 by the perplexity of her first answer to herself, resulting, she supposed,
16002 from doubt of what might be said, and impatience to say every thing.
16003 
16004 "Thank you, dear Miss Woodhouse, you are all kindness.--It is impossible
16005 to say--Yes, indeed, I quite understand--dearest Jane's prospects--
16006 that is, I do not mean.--But she is charmingly recovered.--
16007 How is Mr. Woodhouse?--I am so glad.--Quite out of my power.--
16008 Such a happy little circle as you find us here.--Yes, indeed.--
16009 Charming young man!--that is--so very friendly; I mean good Mr. Perry!--
16010 such attention to Jane!"--And from her great, her more than commonly
16011 thankful delight towards Mrs. Elton for being there, Emma guessed
16012 that there had been a little show of resentment towards Jane,
16013 from the vicarage quarter, which was now graciously overcome.--
16014 After a few whispers, indeed, which placed it beyond a guess,
16015 Mrs. Elton, speaking louder, said,
16016 
16017 "Yes, here I am, my good friend; and here I have been so long,
16018 that anywhere else I should think it necessary to apologise;
16019 but, the truth is, that I am waiting for my lord and master.
16020 He promised to join me here, and pay his respects to you."
16021 
16022 "What! are we to have the pleasure of a call from Mr. Elton?--
16023 That will be a favour indeed! for I know gentlemen do not like
16024 morning visits, and Mr. Elton's time is so engaged."
16025 
16026 "Upon my word it is, Miss Bates.--He really is engaged from morning
16027 to night.--There is no end of people's coming to him, on some pretence
16028 or other.--The magistrates, and overseers, and churchwardens,
16029 are always wanting his opinion.  They seem not able to do any thing
16030 without him.--`Upon my word, Mr. E.,' I often say, `rather you than I.--
16031 I do not know what would become of my crayons and my instrument,
16032 if I had half so many applicants.'--Bad enough as it is, for I
16033 absolutely neglect them both to an unpardonable degree.--I believe
16034 I have not played a bar this fortnight.--However, he is coming,
16035 I assure you:  yes, indeed, on purpose to wait on you all."  And putting
16036 up her hand to screen her words from Emma--"A congratulatory visit,
16037 you know.--Oh! yes, quite indispensable."
16038 
16039 Miss Bates looked about her, so happily!--
16040 
16041 "He promised to come to me as soon as he could disengage himself
16042 from Knightley; but he and Knightley are shut up together
16043 in deep consultation.--Mr. E. is Knightley's right hand."
16044 
16045 Emma would not have smiled for the world, and only said, "Is Mr. Elton
16046 gone on foot to Donwell?--He will have a hot walk."
16047 
16048 "Oh! no, it is a meeting at the Crown, a regular meeting.
16049 Weston and Cole will be there too; but one is apt to speak only
16050 of those who lead.--I fancy Mr. E. and Knightley have every thing
16051 their own way."
16052 
16053 "Have not you mistaken the day?" said Emma.  "I am almost certain
16054 that the meeting at the Crown is not till to-morrow.--Mr. Knightley
16055 was at Hartfield yesterday, and spoke of it as for Saturday."
16056 
16057 "Oh! no, the meeting is certainly to-day," was the abrupt answer,
16058 which denoted the impossibility of any blunder on Mrs. Elton's side.--
16059 "I do believe," she continued, "this is the most troublesome parish
16060 that ever was.  We never heard of such things at Maple Grove."
16061 
16062 "Your parish there was small," said Jane.
16063 
16064 "Upon my word, my dear, I do not know, for I never heard the subject
16065 talked of."
16066 
16067 "But it is proved by the smallness of the school, which I have heard
16068 you speak of, as under the patronage of your sister and Mrs. Bragge;
16069 the only school, and not more than five-and-twenty children."
16070 
16071 "Ah! you clever creature, that's very true.  What a thinking brain
16072 you have!  I say, Jane, what a perfect character you and I should make,
16073 if we could be shaken together.  My liveliness and your solidity
16074 would produce perfection.--Not that I presume to insinuate, however,
16075 that _some_ people may not think _you_ perfection already.--But hush!--
16076 not a word, if you please."
16077 
16078 It seemed an unnecessary caution; Jane was wanting to give her words,
16079 not to Mrs. Elton, but to Miss Woodhouse, as the latter plainly saw.
16080 The wish of distinguishing her, as far as civility permitted,
16081 was very evident, though it could not often proceed beyond a look.
16082 
16083 Mr. Elton made his appearance.  His lady greeted him with some
16084 of her sparkling vivacity.
16085 
16086 "Very pretty, sir, upon my word; to send me on here, to be an
16087 encumbrance to my friends, so long before you vouchsafe to come!--
16088 But you knew what a dutiful creature you had to deal with.
16089 You knew I should not stir till my lord and master appeared.--
16090 Here have I been sitting this hour, giving these young ladies
16091 a sample of true conjugal obedience--for who can say, you know,
16092 how soon it may be wanted?"
16093 
16094 Mr. Elton was so hot and tired, that all this wit seemed thrown away.
16095 His civilities to the other ladies must be paid; but his subsequent
16096 object was to lament over himself for the heat he was suffering,
16097 and the walk he had had for nothing.
16098 
16099 "When I got to Donwell," said he, "Knightley could not be found.
16100 Very odd! very unaccountable! after the note I sent him this morning,
16101 and the message he returned, that he should certainly be at home
16102 till one."
16103 
16104 "Donwell!" cried his wife.--"My dear Mr. E., you have not been
16105 to Donwell!--You mean the Crown; you come from the meeting at the Crown."
16106 
16107 "No, no, that's to-morrow; and I particularly wanted to see Knightley
16108 to-day on that very account.--Such a dreadful broiling morning!--
16109 I went over the fields too--(speaking in a tone of great ill-usage,)
16110 which made it so much the worse.  And then not to find him at home!
16111 I assure you I am not at all pleased.  And no apology left, no message
16112 for me.  The housekeeper declared she knew nothing of my being expected.--
16113 Very extraordinary!--And nobody knew at all which way he was gone.
16114 Perhaps to Hartfield, perhaps to the Abbey Mill, perhaps into his woods.--
16115 Miss Woodhouse, this is not like our friend Knightley!--Can you
16116 explain it?"
16117 
16118 Emma amused herself by protesting that it was very extraordinary,
16119 indeed, and that she had not a syllable to say for him.
16120 
16121 "I cannot imagine," said Mrs. Elton, (feeling the indignity as a wife
16122 ought to do,) "I cannot imagine how he could do such a thing by you,
16123 of all people in the world!  The very last person whom one should expect
16124 to be forgotten!--My dear Mr. E., he must have left a message for you,
16125 I am sure he must.--Not even Knightley could be so very eccentric;--
16126 and his servants forgot it.  Depend upon it, that was the case:
16127 and very likely to happen with the Donwell servants, who are all,
16128 I have often observed, extremely awkward and remiss.--I am sure I
16129 would not have such a creature as his Harry stand at our sideboard
16130 for any consideration.  And as for Mrs. Hodges, Wright holds
16131 her very cheap indeed.--She promised Wright a receipt, and never
16132 sent it."
16133 
16134 "I met William Larkins," continued Mr. Elton, "as I got near
16135 the house, and he told me I should not find his master at home,
16136 but I did not believe him.--William seemed rather out of humour.
16137 He did not know what was come to his master lately, he said, but he
16138 could hardly ever get the speech of him.  I have nothing to do with
16139 William's wants, but it really is of very great importance that _I_
16140 should see Knightley to-day; and it becomes a matter, therefore,
16141 of very serious inconvenience that I should have had this hot walk
16142 to no purpose."
16143 
16144 Emma felt that she could not do better than go home directly.
16145 In all probability she was at this very time waited for there;
16146 and Mr. Knightley might be preserved from sinking deeper in aggression
16147 towards Mr. Elton, if not towards William Larkins.
16148 
16149 She was pleased, on taking leave, to find Miss Fairfax determined
16150 to attend her out of the room, to go with her even downstairs;
16151 it gave her an opportunity which she immediately made use of,
16152 to say,
16153 
16154 "It is as well, perhaps, that I have not had the possibility.
16155 Had you not been surrounded by other friends, I might have been
16156 tempted to introduce a subject, to ask questions, to speak more
16157 openly than might have been strictly correct.--I feel that I should
16158 certainly have been impertinent."
16159 
16160 "Oh!" cried Jane, with a blush and an hesitation which Emma thought
16161 infinitely more becoming to her than all the elegance of all her
16162 usual composure--"there would have been no danger.  The danger
16163 would have been of my wearying you.  You could not have gratified
16164 me more than by expressing an interest--.  Indeed, Miss Woodhouse,
16165 (speaking more collectedly,) with the consciousness which I
16166 have of misconduct, very great misconduct, it is particularly
16167 consoling to me to know that those of my friends, whose good
16168 opinion is most worth preserving, are not disgusted to such a
16169 degree as to--I have not time for half that I could wish to say.
16170 I long to make apologies, excuses, to urge something for myself.
16171 I feel it so very due.  But, unfortunately--in short, if your
16172 compassion does not stand my friend--"
16173 
16174 "Oh! you are too scrupulous, indeed you are," cried Emma warmly,
16175 and taking her hand.  "You owe me no apologies; and every body to
16176 whom you might be supposed to owe them, is so perfectly satisfied,
16177 so delighted even--"
16178 
16179 "You are very kind, but I know what my manners were to you.--
16180 So cold and artificial!--I had always a part to act.--It was a life
16181 of deceit!--I know that I must have disgusted you."
16182 
16183 "Pray say no more.  I feel that all the apologies should be on my side.
16184 Let us forgive each other at once.  We must do whatever is to be
16185 done quickest, and I think our feelings will lose no time there.
16186 I hope you have pleasant accounts from Windsor?"
16187 
16188 "Very."
16189 
16190 "And the next news, I suppose, will be, that we are to lose you--
16191 just as I begin to know you."
16192 
16193 "Oh! as to all that, of course nothing can be thought of yet.
16194 I am here till claimed by Colonel and Mrs. Campbell."
16195 
16196 "Nothing can be actually settled yet, perhaps," replied Emma,
16197 smiling--"but, excuse me, it must be thought of."
16198 
16199 The smile was returned as Jane answered,
16200 
16201 "You are very right; it has been thought of.  And I will own
16202 to you, (I am sure it will be safe), that so far as our living
16203 with Mr. Churchill at Enscombe, it is settled.  There must be
16204 three months, at least, of deep mourning; but when they are over,
16205 I imagine there will be nothing more to wait for."
16206 
16207 "Thank you, thank you.--This is just what I wanted to be assured of.--
16208 Oh! if you knew how much I love every thing that is decided and open!--
16209 Good-bye, good-bye."
16210 
16211 
16212 
16213 CHAPTER XVII
16214 
16215 
16216 Mrs. Weston's friends were all made happy by her safety;
16217 and if the satisfaction of her well-doing could be increased
16218 to Emma, it was by knowing her to be the mother of a little girl.
16219 She had been decided in wishing for a Miss Weston.  She would
16220 not acknowledge that it was with any view of making a match
16221 for her, hereafter, with either of Isabella's sons; but she was
16222 convinced that a daughter would suit both father and mother best.
16223 It would be a great comfort to Mr. Weston, as he grew older--
16224 and even Mr. Weston might be growing older ten years hence--to have
16225 his fireside enlivened by the sports and the nonsense, the freaks
16226 and the fancies of a child never banished from home; and Mrs. Weston--
16227 no one could doubt that a daughter would be most to her; and it
16228 would be quite a pity that any one who so well knew how to teach,
16229 should not have their powers in exercise again.
16230 
16231 "She has had the advantage, you know, of practising on me,"
16232 she continued--"like La Baronne d'Almane on La Comtesse d'Ostalis,
16233 in Madame de Genlis' Adelaide and Theodore, and we shall now see
16234 her own little Adelaide educated on a more perfect plan."
16235 
16236 "That is," replied Mr. Knightley, "she will indulge her even more
16237 than she did you, and believe that she does not indulge her at all.
16238 It will be the only difference."
16239 
16240 "Poor child!" cried Emma; "at that rate, what will become of her?"
16241 
16242 "Nothing very bad.--The fate of thousands.  She will be disagreeable
16243 in infancy, and correct herself as she grows older.  I am losing
16244 all my bitterness against spoilt children, my dearest Emma.
16245 I, who am owing all my happiness to _you_, would not it be horrible
16246 ingratitude in me to be severe on them?"
16247 
16248 Emma laughed, and replied:  "But I had the assistance of all
16249 your endeavours to counteract the indulgence of other people.
16250 I doubt whether my own sense would have corrected me without it."
16251 
16252 "Do you?--I have no doubt.  Nature gave you understanding:--
16253 Miss Taylor gave you principles.  You must have done well.
16254 My interference was quite as likely to do harm as good.  It was
16255 very natural for you to say, what right has he to lecture me?--
16256 and I am afraid very natural for you to feel that it was done
16257 in a disagreeable manner.  I do not believe I did you any good.
16258 The good was all to myself, by making you an object of the tenderest
16259 affection to me.  I could not think about you so much without doating
16260 on you, faults and all; and by dint of fancying so many errors,
16261 have been in love with you ever since you were thirteen at least."
16262 
16263 "I am sure you were of use to me," cried Emma.  "I was very often
16264 influenced rightly by you--oftener than I would own at the time.
16265 I am very sure you did me good.  And if poor little Anna Weston is
16266 to be spoiled, it will be the greatest humanity in you to do as much
16267 for her as you have done for me, except falling in love with her
16268 when she is thirteen."
16269 
16270 "How often, when you were a girl, have you said to me, with one
16271 of your saucy looks--`Mr. Knightley, I am going to do so-and-so;
16272 papa says I may, or I have Miss Taylor's leave'--something which,
16273 you knew, I did not approve.  In such cases my interference was giving
16274 you two bad feelings instead of one."
16275 
16276 "What an amiable creature I was!--No wonder you should hold
16277 my speeches in such affectionate remembrance."
16278 
16279 "`Mr. Knightley.'--You always called me, `Mr. Knightley;' and,
16280 from habit, it has not so very formal a sound.--And yet it is formal.
16281 I want you to call me something else, but I do not know what."
16282 
16283 "I remember once calling you `George,' in one of my amiable fits,
16284 about ten years ago.  I did it because I thought it would offend you;
16285 but, as you made no objection, I never did it again."
16286 
16287 "And cannot you call me `George' now?"
16288 
16289 "Impossible!--I never can call you any thing but `Mr. Knightley.'
16290 I will not promise even to equal the elegant terseness of Mrs. Elton,
16291 by calling you Mr. K.--But I will promise," she added presently,
16292 laughing and blushing--"I will promise to call you once by your
16293 Christian name.  I do not say when, but perhaps you may guess
16294 where;--in the building in which N. takes M. for better, for worse."
16295 
16296 Emma grieved that she could not be more openly just to one
16297 important service which his better sense would have rendered her,
16298 to the advice which would have saved her from the worst of all
16299 her womanly follies--her wilful intimacy with Harriet Smith;
16300 but it was too tender a subject.--She could not enter on it.--
16301 Harriet was very seldom mentioned between them.  This, on his side,
16302 might merely proceed from her not being thought of; but Emma
16303 was rather inclined to attribute it to delicacy, and a suspicion,
16304 from some appearances, that their friendship were declining.
16305 She was aware herself, that, parting under any other circumstances,
16306 they certainly should have corresponded more, and that her
16307 intelligence would not have rested, as it now almost wholly did,
16308 on Isabella's letters.  He might observe that it was so.  The pain
16309 of being obliged to practise concealment towards him, was very little
16310 inferior to the pain of having made Harriet unhappy.
16311 
16312 Isabella sent quite as good an account of her visitor as could
16313 be expected; on her first arrival she had thought her out of spirits,
16314 which appeared perfectly natural, as there was a dentist to
16315 be consulted; but, since that business had been over, she did not
16316 appear to find Harriet different from what she had known her before.--
16317 Isabella, to be sure, was no very quick observer; yet if Harriet
16318 had not been equal to playing with the children, it would not have
16319 escaped her.  Emma's comforts and hopes were most agreeably carried on,
16320 by Harriet's being to stay longer; her fortnight was likely to be
16321 a month at least.  Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley were to come down
16322 in August, and she was invited to remain till they could bring her back.
16323 
16324 "John does not even mention your friend," said Mr. Knightley.
16325 "Here is his answer, if you like to see it."
16326 
16327 It was the answer to the communication of his intended marriage.
16328 Emma accepted it with a very eager hand, with an impatience all alive
16329 to know what he would say about it, and not at all checked by hearing
16330 that her friend was unmentioned.
16331 
16332 "John enters like a brother into my happiness," continued Mr. Knightley,
16333 "but he is no complimenter; and though I well know him to have,
16334 likewise, a most brotherly affection for you, he is so far from
16335 making flourishes, that any other young woman might think him rather
16336 cool in her praise.  But I am not afraid of your seeing what he writes."
16337 
16338 "He writes like a sensible man," replied Emma, when she had read
16339 the letter.  "I honour his sincerity.  It is very plain that he
16340 considers the good fortune of the engagement as all on my side,
16341 but that he is not without hope of my growing, in time, as worthy
16342 of your affection, as you think me already.  Had he said any thing
16343 to bear a different construction, I should not have believed him."
16344 
16345 "My Emma, he means no such thing.  He only means--"
16346 
16347 "He and I should differ very little in our estimation of the two,"
16348 interrupted she, with a sort of serious smile--"much less, perhaps,
16349 than he is aware of, if we could enter without ceremony or reserve
16350 on the subject."
16351 
16352 "Emma, my dear Emma--"
16353 
16354 "Oh!" she cried with more thorough gaiety, "if you fancy your
16355 brother does not do me justice, only wait till my dear father is in
16356 the secret, and hear his opinion.  Depend upon it, he will be much
16357 farther from doing _you_ justice.  He will think all the happiness,
16358 all the advantage, on your side of the question; all the merit
16359 on mine.  I wish I may not sink into `poor Emma' with him at once.--
16360 His tender compassion towards oppressed worth can go no farther."
16361 
16362 "Ah!" he cried, "I wish your father might be half as easily convinced
16363 as John will be, of our having every right that equal worth can give,
16364 to be happy together.  I am amused by one part of John's letter--
16365 did you notice it?--where he says, that my information did not take
16366 him wholly by surprize, that he was rather in expectation of hearing
16367 something of the kind."
16368 
16369 "If I understand your brother, he only means so far as your having
16370 some thoughts of marrying.  He had no idea of me.  He seems perfectly
16371 unprepared for that."
16372 
16373 "Yes, yes--but I am amused that he should have seen so far into
16374 my feelings.  What has he been judging by?--I am not conscious
16375 of any difference in my spirits or conversation that could prepare
16376 him at this time for my marrying any more than at another.--
16377 But it was so, I suppose.  I dare say there was a difference when I
16378 was staying with them the other day.  I believe I did not play
16379 with the children quite so much as usual.  I remember one evening
16380 the poor boys saying, `Uncle seems always tired now.'"
16381 
16382 The time was coming when the news must spread farther, and other persons'
16383 reception of it tried.  As soon as Mrs. Weston was sufficiently
16384 recovered to admit Mr. Woodhouse's visits, Emma having it in view
16385 that her gentle reasonings should be employed in the cause,
16386 resolved first to announce it at home, and then at Randalls.--
16387 But how to break it to her father at last!--She had bound herself
16388 to do it, in such an hour of Mr. Knightley's absence, or when it
16389 came to the point her heart would have failed her, and she must
16390 have put it off; but Mr. Knightley was to come at such a time,
16391 and follow up the beginning she was to make.--She was forced
16392 to speak, and to speak cheerfully too.  She must not make it a more
16393 decided subject of misery to him, by a melancholy tone herself.
16394 She must not appear to think it a misfortune.--With all the spirits
16395 she could command, she prepared him first for something strange,
16396 and then, in a few words, said, that if his consent and approbation
16397 could be obtained--which, she trusted, would be attended with
16398 no difficulty, since it was a plan to promote the happiness of all--
16399 she and Mr. Knightley meant to marry; by which means Hartfield
16400 would receive the constant addition of that person's company
16401 whom she knew he loved, next to his daughters and Mrs. Weston,
16402 best in the world.
16403 
16404 Poor man!--it was at first a considerable shock to him, and he tried
16405 earnestly to dissuade her from it.  She was reminded, more than once,
16406 of having always said she would never marry, and assured that it
16407 would be a great deal better for her to remain single; and told of
16408 poor Isabella, and poor Miss Taylor.--But it would not do.  Emma hung
16409 about him affectionately, and smiled, and said it must be so; and that
16410 he must not class her with Isabella and Mrs. Weston, whose marriages
16411 taking them from Hartfield, had, indeed, made a melancholy change:
16412 but she was not going from Hartfield; she should be always there;
16413 she was introducing no change in their numbers or their comforts but
16414 for the better; and she was very sure that he would be a great deal
16415 the happier for having Mr. Knightley always at hand, when he were once
16416 got used to the idea.--Did he not love Mr. Knightley very much?--
16417 He would not deny that he did, she was sure.--Whom did he ever want
16418 to consult on business but Mr. Knightley?--Who was so useful to him,
16419 who so ready to write his letters, who so glad to assist him?--
16420 Who so cheerful, so attentive, so attached to him?--Would not he
16421 like to have him always on the spot?--Yes.  That was all very true.
16422 Mr. Knightley could not be there too often; he should be glad to see
16423 him every day;--but they did see him every day as it was.--Why could
16424 not they go on as they had done?
16425 
16426 Mr. Woodhouse could not be soon reconciled; but the worst was overcome,
16427 the idea was given; time and continual repetition must do the rest.--
16428 To Emma's entreaties and assurances succeeded Mr. Knightley's,
16429 whose fond praise of her gave the subject even a kind of welcome;
16430 and he was soon used to be talked to by each, on every fair occasion.--
16431 They had all the assistance which Isabella could give, by letters
16432 of the strongest approbation; and Mrs. Weston was ready,
16433 on the first meeting, to consider the subject in the most
16434 serviceable light--first, as a settled, and, secondly, as a good one--
16435 well aware of the nearly equal importance of the two recommendations
16436 to Mr. Woodhouse's mind.--It was agreed upon, as what was to be;
16437 and every body by whom he was used to be guided assuring him that
16438 it would be for his happiness; and having some feelings himself
16439 which almost admitted it, he began to think that some time or other--
16440 in another year or two, perhaps--it might not be so very bad
16441 if the marriage did take place.
16442 
16443 Mrs. Weston was acting no part, feigning no feelings in all that she
16444 said to him in favour of the event.--She had been extremely surprized,
16445 never more so, than when Emma first opened the affair to her;
16446 but she saw in it only increase of happiness to all, and had
16447 no scruple in urging him to the utmost.--She had such a regard
16448 for Mr. Knightley, as to think he deserved even her dearest Emma;
16449 and it was in every respect so proper, suitable, and unexceptionable
16450 a connexion, and in one respect, one point of the highest importance,
16451 so peculiarly eligible, so singularly fortunate, that now it seemed
16452 as if Emma could not safely have attached herself to any other creature,
16453 and that she had herself been the stupidest of beings in not having
16454 thought of it, and wished it long ago.--How very few of those men
16455 in a rank of life to address Emma would have renounced their own
16456 home for Hartfield!  And who but Mr. Knightley could know and bear
16457 with Mr. Woodhouse, so as to make such an arrangement desirable!--
16458 The difficulty of disposing of poor Mr. Woodhouse had been always
16459 felt in her husband's plans and her own, for a marriage between Frank
16460 and Emma.  How to settle the claims of Enscombe and Hartfield had
16461 been a continual impediment--less acknowledged by Mr. Weston than
16462 by herself--but even he had never been able to finish the subject
16463 better than by saying--"Those matters will take care of themselves;
16464 the young people will find a way."  But here there was nothing to be
16465 shifted off in a wild speculation on the future.  It was all right,
16466 all open, all equal.  No sacrifice on any side worth the name.
16467 It was a union of the highest promise of felicity in itself,
16468 and without one real, rational difficulty to oppose or delay it.
16469 
16470 Mrs. Weston, with her baby on her knee, indulging in such reflections
16471 as these, was one of the happiest women in the world.  If any thing
16472 could increase her delight, it was perceiving that the baby would
16473 soon have outgrown its first set of caps.
16474 
16475 The news was universally a surprize wherever it spread;
16476 and Mr. Weston had his five minutes share of it; but five minutes
16477 were enough to familiarise the idea to his quickness of mind.--
16478 He saw the advantages of the match, and rejoiced in them with all
16479 the constancy of his wife; but the wonder of it was very soon nothing;
16480 and by the end of an hour he was not far from believing that he
16481 had always foreseen it.
16482 
16483 "It is to be a secret, I conclude," said he.  "These matters are
16484 always a secret, till it is found out that every body knows them.
16485 Only let me be told when I may speak out.--I wonder whether Jane has
16486 any suspicion."
16487 
16488 He went to Highbury the next morning, and satisfied himself on
16489 that point.  He told her the news.  Was not she like a daughter,
16490 his eldest daughter?--he must tell her; and Miss Bates being present,
16491 it passed, of course, to Mrs. Cole, Mrs. Perry, and Mrs. Elton,
16492 immediately afterwards.  It was no more than the principals were
16493 prepared for; they had calculated from the time of its being known
16494 at Randalls, how soon it would be over Highbury; and were thinking
16495 of themselves, as the evening wonder in many a family circle,
16496 with great sagacity.
16497 
16498 In general, it was a very well approved match.  Some might think him,
16499 and others might think her, the most in luck.  One set might
16500 recommend their all removing to Donwell, and leaving Hartfield
16501 for the John Knightleys; and another might predict disagreements
16502 among their servants; but yet, upon the whole, there was no serious
16503 objection raised, except in one habitation, the Vicarage.--There,
16504 the surprize was not softened by any satisfaction.  Mr. Elton
16505 cared little about it, compared with his wife; he only hoped "the
16506 young lady's pride would now be contented;" and supposed "she had
16507 always meant to catch Knightley if she could;" and, on the point
16508 of living at Hartfield, could daringly exclaim, "Rather he than I!"--
16509 But Mrs. Elton was very much discomposed indeed.--"Poor Knightley!
16510 poor fellow!--sad business for him.--She was extremely concerned;
16511 for, though very eccentric, he had a thousand good qualities.--
16512 How could he be so taken in?--Did not think him at all in love--
16513 not in the least.--Poor Knightley!--There would be an end of all
16514 pleasant intercourse with him.--How happy he had been to come and dine
16515 with them whenever they asked him!  But that would be all over now.--
16516 Poor fellow!--No more exploring parties to Donwell made for _her_.
16517 Oh! no; there would be a Mrs. Knightley to throw cold water on
16518 every thing.--Extremely disagreeable!  But she was not at all sorry
16519 that she had abused the housekeeper the other day.--Shocking plan,
16520 living together.  It would never do.  She knew a family near Maple
16521 Grove who had tried it, and been obliged to separate before the end
16522 of the first quarter.
16523 
16524 
16525 
16526 CHAPTER XVIII
16527 
16528 
16529 Time passed on.  A few more to-morrows, and the party from London
16530 would be arriving.  It was an alarming change; and Emma was thinking
16531 of it one morning, as what must bring a great deal to agitate and
16532 grieve her, when Mr. Knightley came in, and distressing thoughts
16533 were put by.  After the first chat of pleasure he was silent;
16534 and then, in a graver tone, began with,
16535 
16536 "I have something to tell you, Emma; some news."
16537 
16538 "Good or bad?" said she, quickly, looking up in his face.
16539 
16540 "I do not know which it ought to be called."
16541 
16542 "Oh! good I am sure.--I see it in your countenance.  You are trying
16543 not to smile."
16544 
16545 "I am afraid," said he, composing his features, "I am very much afraid,
16546 my dear Emma, that you will not smile when you hear it."
16547 
16548 "Indeed! but why so?--I can hardly imagine that any thing which
16549 pleases or amuses you, should not please and amuse me too."
16550 
16551 "There is one subject," he replied, "I hope but one, on which
16552 we do not think alike."  He paused a moment, again smiling,
16553 with his eyes fixed on her face.  "Does nothing occur to you?--
16554 Do not you recollect?--Harriet Smith."
16555 
16556 Her cheeks flushed at the name, and she felt afraid of something,
16557 though she knew not what.
16558 
16559 "Have you heard from her yourself this morning?" cried he.
16560 "You have, I believe, and know the whole."
16561 
16562 "No, I have not; I know nothing; pray tell me."
16563 
16564 "You are prepared for the worst, I see--and very bad it is.
16565 Harriet Smith marries Robert Martin."
16566 
16567 Emma gave a start, which did not seem like being prepared--
16568 and her eyes, in eager gaze, said, "No, this is impossible!"
16569 but her lips were closed.
16570 
16571 "It is so, indeed," continued Mr. Knightley; "I have it from Robert
16572 Martin himself.  He left me not half an hour ago."
16573 
16574 She was still looking at him with the most speaking amazement.
16575 
16576 "You like it, my Emma, as little as I feared.--I wish our opinions were
16577 the same.  But in time they will.  Time, you may be sure, will make
16578 one or the other of us think differently; and, in the meanwhile,
16579 we need not talk much on the subject."
16580 
16581 "You mistake me, you quite mistake me," she replied, exerting herself.
16582 "It is not that such a circumstance would now make me unhappy,
16583 but I cannot believe it.  It seems an impossibility!--You cannot mean
16584 to say, that Harriet Smith has accepted Robert Martin.  You cannot
16585 mean that he has even proposed to her again--yet.  You only mean,
16586 that he intends it."
16587 
16588 "I mean that he has done it," answered Mr. Knightley, with smiling
16589 but determined decision, "and been accepted."
16590 
16591 "Good God!" she cried.--"Well!"--Then having recourse to her workbasket,
16592 in excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the
16593 exquisite feelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she
16594 must be expressing, she added, "Well, now tell me every thing;
16595 make this intelligible to me.  How, where, when?--Let me know it all.
16596 I never was more surprized--but it does not make me unhappy,
16597 I assure you.--How--how has it been possible?"
16598 
16599 "It is a very simple story.  He went to town on business three days ago,
16600 and I got him to take charge of some papers which I was wanting
16601 to send to John.--He delivered these papers to John, at his chambers,
16602 and was asked by him to join their party the same evening to Astley's.
16603 They were going to take the two eldest boys to Astley's. The party
16604 was to be our brother and sister, Henry, John--and Miss Smith.
16605 My friend Robert could not resist.  They called for him in their way;
16606 were all extremely amused; and my brother asked him to dine with
16607 them the next day--which he did--and in the course of that visit
16608 (as I understand) he found an opportunity of speaking to Harriet;
16609 and certainly did not speak in vain.--She made him, by her acceptance,
16610 as happy even as he is deserving.  He came down by yesterday's coach,
16611 and was with me this morning immediately after breakfast, to report
16612 his proceedings, first on my affairs, and then on his own.
16613 This is all that I can relate of the how, where, and when.
16614 Your friend Harriet will make a much longer history when you see her.--
16615 She will give you all the minute particulars, which only woman's
16616 language can make interesting.--In our communications we deal only
16617 in the great.--However, I must say, that Robert Martin's heart seemed
16618 for _him_, and to _me_, very overflowing; and that he did mention,
16619 without its being much to the purpose, that on quitting their
16620 box at Astley's, my brother took charge of Mrs. John Knightley
16621 and little John, and he followed with Miss Smith and Henry;
16622 and that at one time they were in such a crowd, as to make Miss Smith
16623 rather uneasy."
16624 
16625 He stopped.--Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply.  To speak,
16626 she was sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree
16627 of happiness.  She must wait a moment, or he would think her mad.
16628 Her silence disturbed him; and after observing her a little while,
16629 he added,
16630 
16631 "Emma, my love, you said that this circumstance would not now make
16632 you unhappy; but I am afraid it gives you more pain than you expected.
16633 His situation is an evil--but you must consider it as what satisfies
16634 your friend; and I will answer for your thinking better and better
16635 of him as you know him more.  His good sense and good principles would
16636 delight you.--As far as the man is concerned, you could not wish your
16637 friend in better hands.  His rank in society I would alter if I could,
16638 which is saying a great deal I assure you, Emma.--You laugh at me
16639 about William Larkins; but I could quite as ill spare Robert Martin."
16640 
16641 He wanted her to look up and smile; and having now brought herself
16642 not to smile too broadly--she did--cheerfully answering,
16643 
16644 "You need not be at any pains to reconcile me to the match.  I think
16645 Harriet is doing extremely well.  _Her_ connexions may be worse than _his_.
16646 In respectability of character, there can be no doubt that they are.
16647 I have been silent from surprize merely, excessive surprize.
16648 You cannot imagine how suddenly it has come on me! how peculiarly
16649 unprepared I was!--for I had reason to believe her very lately more
16650 determined against him, much more, than she was before."
16651 
16652 "You ought to know your friend best," replied Mr. Knightley;
16653 "but I should say she was a good-tempered, soft-hearted girl,
16654 not likely to be very, very determined against any young man who told
16655 her he loved her."
16656 
16657 Emma could not help laughing as she answered, "Upon my word,
16658 I believe you know her quite as well as I do.--But, Mr. Knightley,
16659 are you perfectly sure that she has absolutely and downright
16660 _accepted_ him.  I could suppose she might in time--but can she already?--
16661 Did not you misunderstand him?--You were both talking of other things;
16662 of business, shows of cattle, or new drills--and might not you,
16663 in the confusion of so many subjects, mistake him?--It was not
16664 Harriet's hand that he was certain of--it was the dimensions of some
16665 famous ox."
16666 
16667 The contrast between the countenance and air of Mr. Knightley and
16668 Robert Martin was, at this moment, so strong to Emma's feelings,
16669 and so strong was the recollection of all that had so recently
16670 passed on Harriet's side, so fresh the sound of those words,
16671 spoken with such emphasis, "No, I hope I know better than to think
16672 of Robert Martin," that she was really expecting the intelligence
16673 to prove, in some measure, premature.  It could not be otherwise.
16674 
16675 "Do you dare say this?" cried Mr. Knightley.  "Do you dare to suppose
16676 me so great a blockhead, as not to know what a man is talking of?--
16677 What do you deserve?"
16678 
16679 "Oh!  I always deserve the best treatment, because I never put
16680 up with any other; and, therefore, you must give me a plain,
16681 direct answer.  Are you quite sure that you understand the terms
16682 on which Mr. Martin and Harriet now are?"
16683 
16684 "I am quite sure," he replied, speaking very distinctly, "that he
16685 told me she had accepted him; and that there was no obscurity,
16686 nothing doubtful, in the words he used; and I think I can give you
16687 a proof that it must be so.  He asked my opinion as to what he
16688 was now to do.  He knew of no one but Mrs. Goddard to whom he
16689 could apply for information of her relations or friends.  Could I
16690 mention any thing more fit to be done, than to go to Mrs. Goddard?
16691 I assured him that I could not.  Then, he said, he would endeavour
16692 to see her in the course of this day."
16693 
16694 "I am perfectly satisfied," replied Emma, with the brightest smiles,
16695 "and most sincerely wish them happy."
16696
