16697 "You are materially changed since we talked on this subject before."
16698 
16699 "I hope so--for at that time I was a fool."
16700 
16701 "And I am changed also; for I am now very willing to grant you all
16702 Harriet's good qualities.  I have taken some pains for your sake,
16703 and for Robert Martin's sake, (whom I have always had reason to believe
16704 as much in love with her as ever,) to get acquainted with her.
16705 I have often talked to her a good deal.  You must have seen that
16706 I did.  Sometimes, indeed, I have thought you were half suspecting me
16707 of pleading poor Martin's cause, which was never the case; but, from all
16708 my observations, I am convinced of her being an artless, amiable girl,
16709 with very good notions, very seriously good principles, and placing
16710 her happiness in the affections and utility of domestic life.--
16711 Much of this, I have no doubt, she may thank you for."
16712 
16713 "Me!" cried Emma, shaking her head.--"Ah! poor Harriet!"
16714 
16715 She checked herself, however, and submitted quietly to a little
16716 more praise than she deserved.
16717 
16718 Their conversation was soon afterwards closed by the entrance of
16719 her father.  She was not sorry.  She wanted to be alone.  Her mind
16720 was in a state of flutter and wonder, which made it impossible for her
16721 to be collected.  She was in dancing, singing, exclaiming spirits;
16722 and till she had moved about, and talked to herself, and laughed
16723 and reflected, she could be fit for nothing rational.
16724 
16725 Her father's business was to announce James's being gone out to put
16726 the horses to, preparatory to their now daily drive to Randalls;
16727 and she had, therefore, an immediate excuse for disappearing.
16728 
16729 The joy, the gratitude, the exquisite delight of her sensations
16730 may be imagined.  The sole grievance and alloy thus removed in the
16731 prospect of Harriet's welfare, she was really in danger of becoming
16732 too happy for security.--What had she to wish for?  Nothing, but to
16733 grow more worthy of him, whose intentions and judgment had been
16734 ever so superior to her own.  Nothing, but that the lessons
16735 of her past folly might teach her humility and circumspection in future.
16736 
16737 Serious she was, very serious in her thankfulness, and in her resolutions;
16738 and yet there was no preventing a laugh, sometimes in the very midst
16739 of them.  She must laugh at such a close!  Such an end of the doleful
16740 disappointment of five weeks back!  Such a heart--such a Harriet!
16741 
16742 Now there would be pleasure in her returning--Every thing would
16743 be a pleasure.  It would be a great pleasure to know Robert Martin.
16744 
16745 High in the rank of her most serious and heartfelt felicities,
16746 was the reflection that all necessity of concealment from
16747 Mr. Knightley would soon be over.  The disguise, equivocation,
16748 mystery, so hateful to her to practise, might soon be over.
16749 She could now look forward to giving him that full and perfect
16750 confidence which her disposition was most ready to welcome as a duty.
16751 
16752 In the gayest and happiest spirits she set forward with her father;
16753 not always listening, but always agreeing to what he said;
16754 and, whether in speech or silence, conniving at the comfortable
16755 persuasion of his being obliged to go to Randalls every day,
16756 or poor Mrs. Weston would be disappointed.
16757 
16758 They arrived.--Mrs. Weston was alone in the drawing-room:--
16759 but hardly had they been told of the baby, and Mr. Woodhouse
16760 received the thanks for coming, which he asked for, when a glimpse
16761 was caught through the blind, of two figures passing near the window.
16762 
16763 "It is Frank and Miss Fairfax," said Mrs. Weston.  "I was just
16764 going to tell you of our agreeable surprize in seeing him arrive
16765 this morning.  He stays till to-morrow, and Miss Fairfax has been
16766 persuaded to spend the day with us.--They are coming in, I hope."
16767 
16768 In half a minute they were in the room.  Emma was extremely glad
16769 to see him--but there was a degree of confusion--a number of
16770 embarrassing recollections on each side.  They met readily and smiling,
16771 but with a consciousness which at first allowed little to be said;
16772 and having all sat down again, there was for some time such a blank
16773 in the circle, that Emma began to doubt whether the wish now indulged,
16774 which she had long felt, of seeing Frank Churchill once more,
16775 and of seeing him with Jane, would yield its proportion of pleasure.
16776 When Mr. Weston joined the party, however, and when the baby
16777 was fetched, there was no longer a want of subject or animation--
16778 or of courage and opportunity for Frank Churchill to draw near her
16779 and say,
16780 
16781 "I have to thank you, Miss Woodhouse, for a very kind forgiving
16782 message in one of Mrs. Weston's letters.  I hope time has not made
16783 you less willing to pardon.  I hope you do not retract what you
16784 then said."
16785 
16786 "No, indeed," cried Emma, most happy to begin, "not in the least.
16787 I am particularly glad to see and shake hands with you--and to give
16788 you joy in person."
16789 
16790 He thanked her with all his heart, and continued some time to speak
16791 with serious feeling of his gratitude and happiness.
16792 
16793 "Is not she looking well?" said he, turning his eyes towards Jane.
16794 "Better than she ever used to do?--You see how my father and
16795 Mrs. Weston doat upon her."
16796 
16797 But his spirits were soon rising again, and with laughing eyes,
16798 after mentioning the expected return of the Campbells, he named
16799 the name of Dixon.--Emma blushed, and forbade its being pronounced
16800 in her hearing.
16801 
16802 "I can never think of it," she cried, "without extreme shame."
16803 
16804 "The shame," he answered, "is all mine, or ought to be.  But is it
16805 possible that you had no suspicion?--I mean of late.  Early, I know,
16806 you had none."
16807 
16808 "I never had the smallest, I assure you."
16809 
16810 "That appears quite wonderful.  I was once very near--and I wish I had--
16811 it would have been better.  But though I was always doing wrong things,
16812 they were very bad wrong things, and such as did me no service.--
16813 It would have been a much better transgression had I broken the bond
16814 of secrecy and told you every thing."
16815 
16816 "It is not now worth a regret," said Emma.
16817 
16818 "I have some hope," resumed he, "of my uncle's being persuaded
16819 to pay a visit at Randalls; he wants to be introduced to her.
16820 When the Campbells are returned, we shall meet them in London,
16821 and continue there, I trust, till we may carry her northward.--But now,
16822 I am at such a distance from her--is not it hard, Miss Woodhouse?--
16823 Till this morning, we have not once met since the day of reconciliation.
16824 Do not you pity me?"
16825 
16826 Emma spoke her pity so very kindly, that with a sudden accession
16827 of gay thought, he cried,
16828 
16829 "Ah! by the bye," then sinking his voice, and looking demure for
16830 the moment--"I hope Mr. Knightley is well?"  He paused.--She coloured
16831 and laughed.--"I know you saw my letter, and think you may remember
16832 my wish in your favour.  Let me return your congratulations.--
16833 I assure you that I have heard the news with the warmest interest
16834 and satisfaction.--He is a man whom I cannot presume to praise."
16835 
16836 Emma was delighted, and only wanted him to go on in the same style;
16837 but his mind was the next moment in his own concerns and with his
16838 own Jane, and his next words were,
16839 
16840 "Did you ever see such a skin?--such smoothness! such delicacy!--
16841 and yet without being actually fair.--One cannot call her fair.
16842 It is a most uncommon complexion, with her dark eye-lashes and hair--
16843 a most distinguishing complexion!  So peculiarly the lady in it.--
16844 Just colour enough for beauty."
16845 
16846 "I have always admired her complexion," replied Emma, archly; "but do not
16847 I remember the time when you found fault with her for being so pale?--
16848 When we first began to talk of her.--Have you quite forgotten?"
16849 
16850 "Oh! no--what an impudent dog I was!--How could I dare--"
16851 
16852 But he laughed so heartily at the recollection, that Emma could
16853 not help saying,
16854 
16855 "I do suspect that in the midst of your perplexities at that time,
16856 you had very great amusement in tricking us all.--I am sure you had.--
16857 I am sure it was a consolation to you."
16858 
16859 "Oh! no, no, no--how can you suspect me of such a thing?
16860 I was the most miserable wretch!"
16861 
16862 "Not quite so miserable as to be insensible to mirth.  I am sure it
16863 was a source of high entertainment to you, to feel that you were taking
16864 us all in.--Perhaps I am the readier to suspect, because, to tell
16865 you the truth, I think it might have been some amusement to myself
16866 in the same situation.  I think there is a little likeness between us."
16867 
16868 He bowed.
16869 
16870 "If not in our dispositions," she presently added, with a look of
16871 true sensibility, "there is a likeness in our destiny; the destiny
16872 which bids fair to connect us with two characters so much superior
16873 to our own."
16874 
16875 "True, true," he answered, warmly.  "No, not true on your side.  You can
16876 have no superior, but most true on mine.--She is a complete angel.
16877 Look at her.  Is not she an angel in every gesture?  Observe the turn
16878 of her throat.  Observe her eyes, as she is looking up at my father.--
16879 You will be glad to hear (inclining his head, and whispering seriously)
16880 that my uncle means to give her all my aunt's jewels.  They are to be
16881 new set.  I am resolved to have some in an ornament for the head.
16882 Will not it be beautiful in her dark hair?"
16883 
16884 "Very beautiful, indeed," replied Emma; and she spoke so kindly,
16885 that he gratefully burst out,
16886 
16887 "How delighted I am to see you again! and to see you in such
16888 excellent looks!--I would not have missed this meeting for the world.
16889 I should certainly have called at Hartfield, had you failed to come."
16890 
16891 The others had been talking of the child, Mrs. Weston giving an
16892 account of a little alarm she had been under, the evening before,
16893 from the infant's appearing not quite well.  She believed she had
16894 been foolish, but it had alarmed her, and she had been within half
16895 a minute of sending for Mr. Perry.  Perhaps she ought to be ashamed,
16896 but Mr. Weston had been almost as uneasy as herself.--In ten minutes,
16897 however, the child had been perfectly well again.  This was
16898 her history; and particularly interesting it was to Mr. Woodhouse,
16899 who commended her very much for thinking of sending for Perry,
16900 and only regretted that she had not done it.  "She should always send
16901 for Perry, if the child appeared in the slightest degree disordered,
16902 were it only for a moment.  She could not be too soon alarmed,
16903 nor send for Perry too often.  It was a pity, perhaps, that he
16904 had not come last night; for, though the child seemed well now,
16905 very well considering, it would probably have been better if Perry
16906 had seen it."
16907 
16908 Frank Churchill caught the name.
16909 
16910 "Perry!" said he to Emma, and trying, as he spoke, to catch Miss
16911 Fairfax's eye.  "My friend Mr. Perry!  What are they saying
16912 about Mr. Perry?--Has he been here this morning?--And how does
16913 he travel now?--Has he set up his carriage?"
16914 
16915 Emma soon recollected, and understood him; and while she joined
16916 in the laugh, it was evident from Jane's countenance that she
16917 too was really hearing him, though trying to seem deaf.
16918 
16919 "Such an extraordinary dream of mine!" he cried.  "I can never think
16920 of it without laughing.--She hears us, she hears us, Miss Woodhouse.
16921 I see it in her cheek, her smile, her vain attempt to frown.
16922 Look at her.  Do not you see that, at this instant, the very passage
16923 of her own letter, which sent me the report, is passing under her eye--
16924 that the whole blunder is spread before her--that she can attend to
16925 nothing else, though pretending to listen to the others?"
16926 
16927 Jane was forced to smile completely, for a moment; and the smile
16928 partly remained as she turned towards him, and said in a conscious,
16929 low, yet steady voice,
16930 
16931 "How you can bear such recollections, is astonishing to me!--
16932 They _will_ sometimes obtrude--but how you can court them!"
16933 
16934 He had a great deal to say in return, and very entertainingly;
16935 but Emma's feelings were chiefly with Jane, in the argument; and on
16936 leaving Randalls, and falling naturally into a comparison of the two men,
16937 she felt, that pleased as she had been to see Frank Churchill,
16938 and really regarding him as she did with friendship, she had never
16939 been more sensible of Mr. Knightley's high superiority of character.
16940 The happiness of this most happy day, received its completion, in the
16941 animated contemplation of his worth which this comparison produced.
16942 
16943 
16944 
16945 CHAPTER XIX
16946 
16947 
16948 If Emma had still, at intervals, an anxious feeling for Harriet,
16949 a momentary doubt of its being possible for her to be really cured
16950 of her attachment to Mr. Knightley, and really able to accept
16951 another man from unbiased inclination, it was not long that she
16952 had to suffer from the recurrence of any such uncertainty.
16953 A very few days brought the party from London, and she had no
16954 sooner an opportunity of being one hour alone with Harriet,
16955 than she became perfectly satisfied--unaccountable as it was!--
16956 that Robert Martin had thoroughly supplanted Mr. Knightley,
16957 and was now forming all her views of happiness.
16958 
16959 Harriet was a little distressed--did look a little foolish at first:
16960 but having once owned that she had been presumptuous and silly,
16961 and self-deceived, before, her pain and confusion seemed to die
16962 away with the words, and leave her without a care for the past,
16963 and with the fullest exultation in the present and future; for, as to
16964 her friend's approbation, Emma had instantly removed every fear of
16965 that nature, by meeting her with the most unqualified congratulations.--
16966 Harriet was most happy to give every particular of the evening at
16967 Astley's, and the dinner the next day; she could dwell on it all
16968 with the utmost delight.  But what did such particulars explain?--
16969 The fact was, as Emma could now acknowledge, that Harriet had
16970 always liked Robert Martin; and that his continuing to love her had
16971 been irresistible.--Beyond this, it must ever be unintelligible
16972 to Emma.
16973 
16974 The event, however, was most joyful; and every day was giving her
16975 fresh reason for thinking so.--Harriet's parentage became known.
16976 She proved to be the daughter of a tradesman, rich enough to afford
16977 her the comfortable maintenance which had ever been hers, and decent
16978 enough to have always wished for concealment.--Such was the blood
16979 of gentility which Emma had formerly been so ready to vouch for!--
16980 It was likely to be as untainted, perhaps, as the blood of many
16981 a gentleman:  but what a connexion had she been preparing for
16982 Mr. Knightley--or for the Churchills--or even for Mr. Elton!--
16983 The stain of illegitimacy, unbleached by nobility or wealth,
16984 would have been a stain indeed.
16985 
16986 No objection was raised on the father's side; the young man was
16987 treated liberally; it was all as it should be:  and as Emma became
16988 acquainted with Robert Martin, who was now introduced at Hartfield,
16989 she fully acknowledged in him all the appearance of sense and worth
16990 which could bid fairest for her little friend.  She had no doubt
16991 of Harriet's happiness with any good-tempered man; but with him,
16992 and in the home he offered, there would be the hope of more,
16993 of security, stability, and improvement.  She would be placed in the
16994 midst of those who loved her, and who had better sense than herself;
16995 retired enough for safety, and occupied enough for cheerfulness.
16996 She would be never led into temptation, nor left for it to find her out.
16997 She would be respectable and happy; and Emma admitted her to be
16998 the luckiest creature in the world, to have created so steady and
16999 persevering an affection in such a man;--or, if not quite the luckiest,
17000 to yield only to herself.
17001 
17002 Harriet, necessarily drawn away by her engagements with the Martins,
17003 was less and less at Hartfield; which was not to be regretted.--
17004 The intimacy between her and Emma must sink; their friendship must
17005 change into a calmer sort of goodwill; and, fortunately, what ought
17006 to be, and must be, seemed already beginning, and in the most gradual,
17007 natural manner.
17008 
17009 Before the end of September, Emma attended Harriet to church, and saw
17010 her hand bestowed on Robert Martin with so complete a satisfaction,
17011 as no remembrances, even connected with Mr. Elton as he stood
17012 before them, could impair.--Perhaps, indeed, at that time she
17013 scarcely saw Mr. Elton, but as the clergyman whose blessing at the
17014 altar might next fall on herself.--Robert Martin and Harriet Smith,
17015 the latest couple engaged of the three, were the first to be married.
17016 
17017 Jane Fairfax had already quitted Highbury, and was restored to the
17018 comforts of her beloved home with the Campbells.--The Mr. Churchills
17019 were also in town; and they were only waiting for November.
17020 
17021 The intermediate month was the one fixed on, as far as they dared,
17022 by Emma and Mr. Knightley.--They had determined that their marriage
17023 ought to be concluded while John and Isabella were still at Hartfield,
17024 to allow them the fortnight's absence in a tour to the seaside,
17025 which was the plan.--John and Isabella, and every other friend,
17026 were agreed in approving it.  But Mr. Woodhouse--how was Mr. Woodhouse
17027 to be induced to consent?--he, who had never yet alluded to their
17028 marriage but as a distant event.
17029 
17030 When first sounded on the subject, he was so miserable, that they
17031 were almost hopeless.--A second allusion, indeed, gave less pain.--
17032 He began to think it was to be, and that he could not prevent it--
17033 a very promising step of the mind on its way to resignation.
17034 Still, however, he was not happy.  Nay, he appeared so much otherwise,
17035 that his daughter's courage failed.  She could not bear to see
17036 him suffering, to know him fancying himself neglected; and though
17037 her understanding almost acquiesced in the assurance of both the
17038 Mr. Knightleys, that when once the event were over, his distress
17039 would be soon over too, she hesitated--she could not proceed.
17040 
17041 In this state of suspense they were befriended, not by any sudden
17042 illumination of Mr. Woodhouse's mind, or any wonderful change of his
17043 nervous system, but by the operation of the same system in another way.--
17044 Mrs. Weston's poultry-house was robbed one night of all her turkeys--
17045 evidently by the ingenuity of man.  Other poultry-yards in the
17046 neighbourhood also suffered.--Pilfering was _housebreaking_ to
17047 Mr. Woodhouse's fears.--He was very uneasy; and but for the sense
17048 of his son-in-law's protection, would have been under wretched alarm
17049 every night of his life.  The strength, resolution, and presence
17050 of mind of the Mr. Knightleys, commanded his fullest dependence.
17051 While either of them protected him and his, Hartfield was safe.--
17052 But Mr. John Knightley must be in London again by the end of the
17053 first week in November.
17054 
17055 The result of this distress was, that, with a much more voluntary,
17056 cheerful consent than his daughter had ever presumed to hope for at
17057 the moment, she was able to fix her wedding-day--and Mr. Elton was
17058 called on, within a month from the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Robert
17059 Martin, to join the hands of Mr. Knightley and Miss Woodhouse.
17060 
17061 The wedding was very much like other weddings, where the parties
17062 have no taste for finery or parade; and Mrs. Elton, from the
17063 particulars detailed by her husband, thought it all extremely shabby,
17064 and very inferior to her own.--"Very little white satin, very few
17065 lace veils; a most pitiful business!--Selina would stare when she
17066 heard of it."--But, in spite of these deficiencies, the wishes,
17067 the hopes, the confidence, the predictions of the small band
17068 of true friends who witnessed the ceremony, were fully answered
17069 in the perfect happiness of the union.
17070 
17071 
17072 FINIS
